description: LANDOVER, Md., April 1  With barrages of long shots and short cliches, two teams of wheezing, rubberlegged legislators from New York and Maryland met on a basketball court at the Capital Centre outside Washington today to decide what had been billed as the Battle for Legislative Supremacy.

title: Evacuation: Youngsters and the Pregnant Go First
description: The selection of pregnant women and young children as the first to be evacuated from the area of the crippled nuclear reactor in Pennsylvania was based on the fact that the developing embryo, the fetus and growing children are most vulnerble to the hazards of radiation.

title: Omega 7 Uses Bombs for a Cause
description: WEEHAWKEN, N.J.  Omega 7 is nothing but a name, said Eulalio Jos Negrin. He spoke at an office filled with rubble. There were twisted metal folding chairs, immigration forms for Cuban refugees and calling cards identifying him as the head of the New Jersey Cuban Program, established here a few months ago.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, April 1 (AP)  Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party will win Britain's May 3 national election with 100seat majority, according to a publicopinion poll the results of which were made public here today.

title: Dawson Award to Mirabella
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 1  Paul Mirabella, the Yankee pitcher who is on the verge of winning a major league job, won the James Dawson Award today as the outstanding Yankee rookie in saying training. The award is named for the late New York Times sportswriter.

title: Capitals Top Islanders, 64
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 1  The Capitals, a club that will have to watch the Stanley Cup playoffs from the arena seats, dealt the New York Islanders a 64 defeat tonight to the delight of the Washington fans in the crowd of 9.838.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: It has been pointed out, on occasion, that you never can tell what on earth interests readers of this column and to what degree. With tongue in cheek, we stated recently that we had a file of letters marked Unanswered and Unanswerable. We quoted one of those letters, not fictional, in which someone asked if we could explain why peanut butter cookies were creased with a fork before baking.

title: New Jazz: Abrams Gives 2 Concerts
description: THE concerts by Muhal Richard Abrams on Friday and Saturday nights, part of the New Jazz series at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Estelle R. Newman Theater, stepped delicately along that fine line that separates experimental jazz from supposedly classical avantgarde music.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BRISTOL, Term., April 1 (UPI) Dale Earnhardt, a rookie, took the lead from Darrell Waltrip 13 miles from the finish today and went on to capture the Southeastern 500. It was Earnhardt's first NASCAR Grand National victory. He also earned the biggest paycheck of his career, $19,800.

title: Flying Paster Triumphs
description: ARCADIA, Calif., April 1 (AP) Flying Paster stamped himself as the West's best bet for the Triple Crown horse races when he captured the $192,400 Santa Anita Derby today.

title: Egypt Dismisses Punitive Measures Taken Against It at Baghdad Parley
description: CAIRO, April 1  The Egyptian Government today dismissed as null and void the political and economic measures that were enacted against it yesterday at the meeting of Arab ministers in Baghdad, Iraq.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Bernard Guilbert Guerney, Owner Of Bookstore and a Translator
description: Bernard Guilbert Guerney, a translator of Russian authors and the editor of many anthologies, died Friday in State College, Pa., where he had lived since moving from New York City a year ago.

title: Kennedy Seeks International Indochina Conference
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy called yesterday for an international conference on Indochina to arrange a ceasefire in Cambodia and to deal with the plight of Indochinese refugees.

title: 21 Held in Thefts of Greek Icons
description: ATHENS, April 2 (Reuters)  The Athens police are holding a West German archeologist and 20 Greeks for questioning about a ring dealing in stolen icons and other antiquities and the murder of a gang member. A police spokesman said that Stefan Gericke of Munich was detained last week in connection with the theft of a 450yearold icon from a church on Ios.

title: Music: Modern Chamber
description: THE program of mostly American vocal chamber music that Edith Gordon Ainsberg and members of the Bronx Arts Ensemble put together at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night was an appealing mixture of contemporary styles. Beginning with Kurt Weill's Frauentanz (Op. 10), it went on to unequivocally American composers: Allan Blank, John Freeman, William Mayer, Samuel Barber and Lester Trimble. It was particularly interesting to have a chance to revisit Mr. Trimble's Four Fragments From The Canterbury Tales, a much praised work from a generation ago that rarely turns up nowadays.

title: Harrisburg Is Disrupted By Employees Absence
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 2  A combination of voluntary evacuations and absenteeism from work caused unexpected disruptions here today. Civil Defense officials said that as many as half the 200.000 people for whom they would be responsible in an evacuation of the state capital may have already left.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  A Federal grand jury here yesterday accused 10 large cigarette wholesalers  nine from New Jersey and one from New York  of fixing prices during the last decade.

title: BUBBLE NEARLY GONE
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., April 2  Federal nuclear safety officials said today that the hazards connected with cooling the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear reactor were abating but that radiation levels in its containment vessel were

title: Election Agency Endorses Conduct Of Carter's 76 Primary Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  The Federal Election Commission, in an audit released today, gave its stamp of approval to the conduct of Jimmy Carter's 1976 primary election campaign committee but did not address a number of controversial aspects of that campaign's financing.

title: Iran Reports CeaseFire With Turkoman Rebels After 8 Days of Fighting
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 2  The provisional Government announced a ceasefire agreement today between Turkomans and Government forces. Yesterday, Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan threatened to use the army against the tribesmen unless the fighting stopped.

title: Leak Found March 26 In Jersey Nuclear Plant
description: TRENTON, April 2  An official of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company said today that a leak was discovered in the cooling system at the company's Oyster Creek nuclear power plant on March 26, but that it was nothing to be concerned about.

title: Rangers Rebound, Defeat Kings by 54
description: Phil Esposito's fist in the air told all last night. The Ranger center had just put his own rebound into the Los Angeles Kings net for the fifth New York goal in a 54 victory over the Los Angeles Kings. Until that moment in the third period, the Rangers looked as if they were going to be overtaken one more time.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT PERIL ABATES, BUT LEVEL OF RADIATION INSIDE IS WORRYING SAFETY OFFICIALS
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  The Federal Government took steps today to see that the potentially serious nuclear accident that has threatened a large area of central Pennsylvania for the last five days did not occur at any of the eight other plants that operate reactors made by the', same company.

title: Bettors Throng the 10 OTB Shops Open During Strike
description: Bettors stood shouldertoshoulder in the 10 offices of the Offtrack Betting Corporation that were open around New York City yesterday as supervisory personnel manned the windows during the seventh day of a strike by clerks.

title: U.S. Criticizes the Arabs Threat to Boycott Egypt
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 The United States said today that the decision by Saudi Arabia and 18 other Arab states to impose an economic boycott against Egypt and to withdraw ,their ambassadors was negative and unhelpful?,

title: Battle Shaping on Job Curbs for ExFederal Employees
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  A Congressional subcommittee started wrestling today with the rules that will govern the behavior of bureaucrats once they leave Government service.

title: Viola: Donald McInnes
description: BY training and temperament, viola players tend to be modest, cooperative people who do not entertain unrealistic hopes of fame and glory. Although the time has long since passed when violists were generally drawn from the ranks of failed violinists, audiences still hear the viola, when they hear it at all, as the useful but unexciting character actor of the orchestra or string quartet. And, composers have traditionally not been much kinder, especially considering that some have been proficient violists. The viola recital, therefore, is not an everyday phenomenon, even in a time when the instrument has bred a number of authentic virtuosos.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY. APRIL 2, 1979

title: Screen: Discussing Liberation:Dialogue on Liberation
description: JUST four weeks less than eight years after the event, D.A. Pennebaker's "Town Bloody Hall," his cinma vrit recording of an all-star "Dialogue on Women's Liberation," at Town Hall on April 30,1971, opens today at the Whitney Museum of American Art. No one who participated in the event, or who is a close friend of someone who participated in it, or who just likes a bang-up show of ideas that often get muddled with personalities, will want to miss this movie. Or put it this way: When was the last time you saw Norman Mailer in the ring with his gloves on?Mr. Mailer, the moderator, meets and takes on with good humor the panel members (Germaine Greer, Diana Trilling, Jacqueline Ceballos and Jill Johnston) and members of the audience, some prominent in their fields, such as Elizabeth Hardwicke, Susan Sontag and Betty Friedan (all of whom keep their heads), and others who don't keep their heads and look extremely foolish.Much of what is said at the symposium, one of a series of events produced for the Theater of Ideas, is still relevant, which also says something about the march of women's liberation (it's slow) and a lot of it is just fooling around, as when Jill Johnston starts fooling around on stage with a couple of her admirers.As a movie, "Town Bloody Hall" reflects some of the chaos the discussion keeps threatening to fall into, but Mr. Pennebaker, one of our best documentary film makers, and Chris Negedus, his associate and the editor of the film, succeed in capturing a great deal of the live presence of the occasion. Undoubtedly, though, the way one responds to the film depends on the way one responds to the people in it. It helps if they're pals.

title: Ben Holt Dead in Paris; Long in Public Relations
description: PARIS, April 2  Ben Holt, a publicrelations man here for many years and a prominent member of the American community, died today in Nice of injuries suffered in a road accident a week ago. He was 60 years old.

title: Adding New Safety Gear Would Bring Shutdowns
description: Many parts of the country face the possibility of acute electricity shortages next summer and sharp increases in electric bills if nuclear plants are forced to close as a result of adverse public reaction to the accident at Pennsylvania's Three Mile Island nuclear facility.

title: Cost of Airborne Mobile Missile May Be Prohibitive
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  A secret Pentagon study has concluded that a proposal for deploying a new, mobile intercontinental missile aboard a fleet of launcher aircraft could cost more than $40 billion, a finding that defense officials said today was bound to complicate efforts by the Carter Administration to agree on a plan for reducing the vulnerability of the American strategic arsenal.

title: Do Nothing for New York ...
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Not too long ago American Airlines announced that it was moving its corporate headquarters from New York City to the DallasFort Worth International Airport. New Yorkers reacted as if the airline were trying to spirit away the Statue of Liberty.

title: Paris Bourse Strikers Return
description: PARIS, April 2  The Paris stock exchange, known as the Bourse, resumed operations today after more than a month of inactivity due to a strike of personnel.

title: Steel Capacity Use At Record 94.7%
description: The steel industry surpassed its previous record operating level in the week ended last Saturday, figures released by the American Iron and Steel Institute showed yesterday. Capacity utilization reached a new high of 94.7 percent, compared with the previous high of 94.6 percent, attained in the second week in March.

title: Tanzanians Bomb City in Uganda And Renew Shelling of the Capital
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 2 (AP)  Tanzania's Air Force struck at Uganda's second largest city today, and its forces on the ground renewed shelling of the Ugandan capital after apparently pushing back Libyan defenders.

title: Layoffs Starting As Truck Lines Halt Operations
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  Reports from around the country today indicated that there was broad compliance with the lockout called yesterday by trucking industry leaders in response to a selective strike by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Vienna Cardinal Said to Predict Visit by the Pope for September
description: TURIN, Italy, April 2 (AP)  Pope John Paul II plans to visit Austria in September, the Roman Catholic newspaper La Gazzetta del Popolo reports.

title: Computer Will Teach Language Courses
description: IN a development that could radically change the way foreign languages are taught, a computer that speaks two or more languages will begin teaching its first course next September at Stanford University.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The National Basketball Association said yesterday that the site for the 1980 AllStar game had been switched from Boston Garden to the Capital Centre in Landover, Md.

title: Patriots Let Fairbanks Co to Colorado
description: BOSTON, April 2 (AP)  The New England Patriots announced today that Chuck Fairbanks, whb tried to quit as coach before the National Football League playoffs to return to college coaching, was free to take the job at the University of Colorado. The Patriots said they had not yet hired another coach.

title: Beattie Is Sent to Columbus
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 2  On the bulletin board in the Yankee clubhouse is a list of players who want rooms at the Sheraton Heights Hotel in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., when the team arrives home tomorrow night. One name is Beattie.

title: Recital: Evelyn Lear
description: IN recent years, Evelyn Lear's New York recital programs have ranged far from the beaten path to take in the likes of Ludwig Spohr, Stephen Sondheim and Jerome Kern. Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, howevr, Miss Lear offered  thoroughly traditional program of songs in German, French, Russian, English and Spanish by such familiar composers as Schumann, Faur and Tchaikovsky.

title: Benjamin Bauer, Leader in Audio
description: Benjamin B. Bauer, former vice president and general manager of the CBS Technology Center in Stamford, Conn., and inventor of the diiectional microphone now used almost universally in broadcasting and publicaddress sytems, died of a heart attack at the Stamford Hospital on Saturday. He was 65 years old.

title: Israel Is Able to Watch Begin's Arrival on TV
description: TEL AVIV, April 2 Prime Minister Menachem Begin's arrival in Cairo today was telecast live in Israel.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN the prologue of Peter Straub's fourth novel, Ghost Story, a feverish young man named Don Wanderley is driving south to Panama City, Fla., with a mysterious 10yearold girl he has kidnapped and seems to want to kill. The girl gives her name as Angie Maule or Angie Mitchell, tells her abductor I am you when he asks her to explain herself, and seems blithely unconcerned by the apparent threat to her life. Mystery.

title: How Economists Put Model Together
description: Economists like to joke about outsiders who ask to see their model as if they expected a Rube Goldberg contraption.

title: West Germans Try 11 Teirorists
description: FRANKFURT, April 2 (Reuters) Eleven young people who took over a news agency office to get publicity for two jailed urban guerrillas went on trial today charged with supporting a terrorist organization. The prosecution said that when they burst into the Frankfurt office of the West German news agency Nov. they were masked and armed with sticks and demanded the transmission of statement on the conditions of the prisoners.

title: Tiny Brooklyn Road Job Grows Into a Westway
description: What city and state officials had thought would be a relatively minor repair of less than a mile of the BrooklynQueens Expressway has turned into a major confrontation with community groups in Carroll Gardens and Cobble Hill who want that stretch of the expressway completely relocated.

title: PLAN DUE THIS WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  President Carter plans to propose a complex twopart tax on domestic oil and to begin immediately allowing the price of oil produced in the United States to rise, Administration officials said today.

title: Brezhnev Illness Defers Giscard's Trip a Month
description: MOSCOW, April 2  The Soviet Government announced today that a visit by President Valery. Giscard d'Estaing of France, postponed last week because Leonid I. Brezhnev had influenza, will take place April 2628.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Legal subcommittee on outer space 10:30A.M.

title: 100 Vietnamese Refugees Drown
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 2 (Reuters)  More than 100 Vietnamese refugees drowned off the country's east coast Saturday when their boat capsized while being towed to sea, the United Nations refugee agency said today.

title: Trudeau Gives Voters His Views of Unity and Treason
description: OTTAWA, April 2  In an improvised radio studio in a downtown Toronto hotel last Thursday, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau hunched over a microphone and startled listeners with talk of treason.

title: Taxes
description: THE Internal Revenue Service has decided make it tougher on people who request extensions of time for filing their income tax returns. In a ruling issued yesterday, the I.R.S. makes clear that the simple act of filing the extension Form 4868 provides no immunity against being fined if a taxpayer neglects to make a goodfaith estimate of the tax due. If the person estimates his tax as zero despite ample evidence of taxable income and tax ability, he has filed an invalid Form 4868, according to the I.R.S.

title: Airlines Extend Fare Debate
description: GENEVA, April 2  Most of the world's international airlines are debating at a conference here the exceptions to a general fare increase of 7 percent that they see as needed to meet the rising cost of fuel, aviation sources said today.

title: Brooklyn Man Found Shot
description: A 23yearold Brooklyn man, wounded in the groin in what appeared to be drugrelated shooting, was listed in stable condition yesterday at Harlem Hospital, a hospital spokesman said. The Transit Police said the man, Steven Spano of 293 Dahlgreen Place, was found Sunday evening on the stairway of the IND station at 125th Street and Eighth Avenue. They said a smallcaliber revolver and a package of heroin were found near Mr. Spano.

title: Market Place
description: LAST Friday, in the wake of the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island near Harrisburg, Pa., the prices of leading coal shares shot up 10 to 15 percent. There was no selectivity, it seemed; as long as a company mined coal, the shares advanced.

title: Kennedy Calls for Study Of Nuclear Power Roles
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy called yesterday for a review of nuclear power's role in reducing United States dependence on oil imports from the Middle East and urged a fresh examination of the nuclear weapons risks'4arising out of the wide international use of atomic energy. He also urged tightened procedures for licensing nuclear power plants.

title: Bridge:
description: When the last board arrives in an important match, experts tend to slow down. This is not merely an attempt to counter fatigue and an impatient, inclination to end the proceedings and compare scores: In a close match a player may feel a need to review mentally the previous results to judge whether he needs to swing.

title: Tugboat Strike Snarls Ships and Garbage Removal
description: The strike of tugboat, barge and tanker crewmen slowed the movement of shipping in the Port of New York yesterday and forced the city to move tons of garbage by truck rather than by barge.

title: In Plant Vicinity, Suspicion and Doubt
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 2 Families are divided here. So are options. So are opinions.

title: Deaths
description: FISHMANWilliam Lee. Passed away March 31. 1979. President of Sundance Computer Systems, Inc. He will be missed by his many friends.

title: Highlights of $12.6 Billion New York State Budget
description: ALBANY, April 2  Following are the highlights of the $12.6 billion budget for New York State's 197980 fiscal year that was debated by the Legislature today:

title: Ashland Changing Emphasis
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 2  Ashland Oil Inc., one of the mavericks of the oil industry, has been bucking the current trend toward growth through acquisition by selling off large parts of its business and using the proceeds to buy up equally large blocks of its own stock.

title: Delay Refused For Liquor Pact
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI)  A Federal judge today turned down a request by a group of whisky distillers for a court order to prevent Robert S. Strauss, the President's special trade representative, from signing an international agreement covering their industry.

title: Cousins, Former Admiral, Gets Tenneco Assignment in Europe
description: Ralph Cousins, a retired admiral who was commander in chief of the United States Atlantic Fleet, got his fifth assignment yesterday since becoming a corporate manager four years ago.

title: More Amateurs Are Deciding Astronomy Is Good for the Sou
description: TWO weeks ago, on the first evening of spring, hundreds of New Yorkers patiently lined up on the grounds of the Hayden Planetarium for a glimpse of Jupiter and Saturn through one of the telescopes set up by the Amateur Astronomers Association.

title: Illinois Governor Orders Study of Seven Reactors
description: CHICAGO, April 2  Gov. James R. Thompson ordered the Illinois Commission on Atomic Energy today to conduct a technical review of the state's seven nuclear power reactors.

title: Ernest Zobian, ExAide Of Drug Company, Dies
description: Ernest P. Zobian, a retired vice president of the WarnerLambert Company, died Sunday at his home in Bay Head, N.J. He was 72 years old.

description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (515) 7470500, SUFFOLK CO.
