title: Opera: The Met Brings Back Parsifal
description: THERE are those who would say that the trouble with Parsitar is that it never makes up its mind whether it is musical theater or a religious play. There are others, of course, who would deny there is any trouble with the work at all, and would say that its fluctuations of style and intent are precisely what make it the most ineffably satisfying of all the Wagner dramas. The Metropolitan Opera last night brought back its nineyearold production, most recently seen in the house five seasons ago, and once more the old polarities of opinion are likely to be voiced. No fewer than 16 singers in the cast were taking their roles for the first time with this company, and the conductor, James Levine, also was being initiated.

title: Roger Vaughan Pugh, 74, Dead; Was an Official of Lazard Frres
description: Roger Vaughan Pugh, retired vice president of Lazard Frres & Company, died Sunday at his home in Rye, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Marilyn W. Black thinks she's fighting a losing battle but she's still fighting  against the influence of television on her pupils, mostly. Mrs. Black, who is to be officially named Teacher of the Year by President Carter tomorrow, says that she just can't turn on the set in prime time without seeing people jumping into bed and being violent, and her students are forever telling her: 'Well, soandso said it on TV last night, why can't I say it here.  Mrs. Black, who has two daughters, is steadfast: So far I have stood firm. I tell them we just don't accept it in our classroom. I hope to make it stick. She teaches at the Ray School in Hanover, N.H.

title: Letters
description: Arctic Mirages

title: Issue and Debate
description: In a season beset by declining attendance and television ratings, the National Basketball Association has pressed the panic button and now is trying to figure out why. It has hired a highpriced promotion agency to give the league a better image. Meanwhile, round the league, general managers, coaches and players are pointing to almost everything, ranging from the fall of the Knicks to the absence of the 3point field goal, as responsible for the declines.

title: Girl, 2, Woman, 73, Hurt in Fire
description: A 2yearold girl and a 73yearold woman were severely burned yesteiday in a suspicious fire in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. Fire officials said two firemen rescued the child, Tinisha Jones, and Marjorie Robinson from their burning apartment at 611 Central Avenueshortly after 3:30 P.M. The child suffered burns over all of her body and was listed in critical condition at Wyckoff Heights Hospital. The woman was also in critical condition at that hospital.

title: Nuclear Bid Is Doubted
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  The nuclear accident at Three Mile Island has effectively eliminated any new initiative on nuclear power from President Carter's forthcoming policy statement on energy, Administration officials said today.

title: British Fashion Moves to Center Stage
description: LONDON, April 2  The fashion houses here are making a mighty effort to regain the position in the world markets that they had achieved in the 1960's. That's when London's mods and rockers, with their wide ties and miniskirts, set the tone for the fashion aspect of the youth revolution.

title: State Senate RollCall On Abortion Financing
description: ALBANY, April 2  The following is the rollcall vote by which the State Senate tonight adopted an amendment to cut off Medicaid money for abortions except in cases where the mother's life or physical health was in danger or where she was a victim of rape or incest.

title: Mets Win While Awaiting Final Cuts
description: DUNEDIN, Fla., April 2  The New York Mets overpowered the Toronto Blue Jays, 114, today with a rare burst of home runs. But nobody was celebrating yet because three more players must be dropped from the team tomorrow before the Mets close spring training and fly north to open the season.

title: The Circus Lady Who Hangs by Her Hair
description: When Marguerite Michele pays a visit to the hairdresser, her dark, hiplength tresses tend to draw compliments.

title: Chemical Is Being Sent To Combat Radiation
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)  One million doses of a chemical designed to reduce the effects of radiation on the human thyroid gland are being sent to the area of the nuclear accident in Pennsylvania, a White House official said today.

title: Films of 14 Famous Plays Acquired by WORTV
description: Fourteen films of wellknown plays that were made a halfdozen years ago for showing in theaters will be coming to WORTV, Channel 9, among other stations, next fall.

title: Prediction: Martin to Red Sox
description: Just as April demands that the baseball season open, the baseball season demands predictions. But with the Yankees, it is not enough to predict that they will win the World Series again. With the Yankees, it is necessary to predict what disputes will develop. One is inevitable  that George Steinbrenner, who is betrothed to Billy Martin as the Yankee man ager in 1980, will break the engagement. And as a result of that dispute, the prediction is that Billy Martin will be managing the Boston Red Sox by midseason. With their question

title: Record Set For Index On Building
description: The value of new construction con- tracts rose 46 percent to $14.2 billion in February, pushing the Dodge index to a record 231, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday. The index is seasonally adjusted with 1972 representing 100.

title: 20 Killed in Thai Train Crash
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 2 (Reuters)At least 20 people were killed and dozens injured today when a train and an oil truck collided in central Thailand, the police said.

title: Dr. Mary I. Crawford, Former Vice President Of Nursing at Hospital
description: Dr. Mary I. Crawford, former vice president of nursing of the Presbyterian Hospital in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan, died of cancer at that hospital Sunday. She was 57 years old and lived in HastingsonHudson, N.Y.

title: New Way Asked To Choose Panel For Sheriff Jury
description: Lawrence H. Cooke, Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals of New York, said last night that he would soon take definitive steps to democratize the sheriff's jury, which consists of some of the most distinguished and influential members of Manhattan's financial and commercial community.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THRESHOLD In his New York debut tonight at 8 at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association, near Lexington Avenue, the English cellist Robert Cohen is the latest performer to be presented by Young Concert Artists. The series has been commended for aiding rising young musicians of international train ing and background, after competitive auditioning for sponsorship. The 18yearold cellist has played at various British festivals, on Dutch television and last year at the American Festival in Tanglewood. At the Y tonight he will perform Beethoven, Chopin, Franck and Shostakovich.

title: Dollar Up Sharply In Tokyo
description: TOKYO, April 2The United States dollar rose sharply against the yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today despite intervention by the Bank of Japan. The American currency closed at 211.10 yen, its highest level in nine and a half months.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Emmett Kelly Is Buried in Indiana Near His Mother and His Sister
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., April 2 (AP) Emmett Kelly, the forlorn clown who spent his circus life sweeping away the spotlight, was buried today in a simple grave between his mother and sister.

title: Cement Ship Sinks in Caribbean; Seven. Crewmen Feared Drowned
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., April 2 (AP)  A Venezuelan ship that carried a cargo of cement sank about 200 miles north of Curagao in rough weather, the Coast Guard said today.

title: The Show Went On Without a Hitch
Stage: Phoenix Offers Big and Little
description: BIG and Little is a work of curious and troubling splinters. They are uncertainly organized, and some are fashioned with such hermetic privacy of vision that they seem inert. But out of them Botho Strauss, a young German playwright, has created a central figure whose humanity is both elusive and unforgettable.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: TORONTO, April 2  Kenneth Thomson, the Toronto newspaper pubflsher, has fired the latest shot in the bidding war for control of the Hudson's Bay Company, the big Canadian department store chain.

title: Topics Literary Licenses
description: Intelligence

title: Petition Filed to Stay Execution Of Condemned Killer in Alabama
description: MOBILE, Ala., April 2 (AP)  The mother of John Louis Evans 3d, the 29.1 yearold condemned killer who is scheduled to be electrocuted Friday, today petitioned a Federal court to block the execution of her son despite his pleas that the death sentence be carried out.

title: Carey Expected to Name Scoppetta To Post on Waterfront Commission.
description: Nicholas Scoppetta is expected to be named to the Waterfront Commission of New York. Harbor, according to sources in city government. He was Deputy Mayor for Criminal Justice and Commissioner of Investigation in the administration of former Mayor Abraham D. Beame.

title: Air in Tristate Region Still Free of Radiation, Continuing Tests Find
description: Yesterday's rain gave officials a chance to collect rainwater samples for additional radiation checks to back up the air samples. Mr. Giardina said it would be a day or two before the tests of the rainwater samples could be completed, but he said he expected them to show no excess radiation.

title: Jazz Rock: Smith and Pointer
description: CARNEGIE HALL was not designed for amplified music, and groups that play there with electric guitars and keyboards and loud drummers do so at their peril. But one has heard electric bands achieve accentabl a sound balances there from time to time, so the aural muck one had to wade through to listen to Lonnie Liston Smith and Noel Pointer on Sunday night was unforgivable. Nobody the reviewer talked to could remember hearing worse sound in the hall.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, April 2,1979

title: Uncertainty On Reactors Lingers As Crisis Eases
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 2 With the crisis at the Three Mile Island nuclear electric plant apparently safely past today, disturbing uncertainties remained about both this reactor and others similar design.

title: Missouri Blaze Kills 25 at Home For Retirees and Mental Patients
description: FARMINGTON, Mo., April 2 (AP) Twentyfive persons died in a boarding house fire today, many of them trapped by flaming debris after the roof collapsed.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Miss Lieberman: Prize to Shout About
description: The telegram arrived last Tuesday, but Nancy Lieberman was in no rush to open it. It came just two days after she had led Old Dominion to the women's national collegiate basketball championship and, really, there had already been so many telegrams.

title: Magic Chef Acquires Norge for 13 Million
description: Magic Chef Inc. announced the consummation of the acquisition of the Norge Company, a manufacturer of home laundry products and commercial laundry and dry cleaning equipment, for more than $13 million in cash and notes.

title: Marcos Schedules Election in Area Where Moslem Rebels Wage War
description: MANILA, April 2  President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today that regional elections would be held May 7 in the southern Philippines, where Moslem insurgents have battled Government forces in a long separatist war that has claimed some 60,000 lives.

title: French Chiefs See Ford on Plant Bid
description: PARIS, April 2  Henry Ford 2d was the luncheon guest today of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing after having conferred in the morning with Prime Minister Raymond Barre. a sign that hopes were still high here that the Ford Motor Company might install its projected new European automobile plant in France rather than elsewhere on the Continent.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A frontal band with showers and thundershowers is apparent from the New England through the Ohio Valley to the Texas Gulf Coast. Low and middle level clouds stretch from the lake region through the upper Mississippi Valley to the Northern Plains States. Low and middle level clouds cover the West.

title: Army Test Will Enlist Men in Ready Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)  The Army announced today that it was testing the direct enlistment of young men for combat assignments in the Ready Reserve manpower pool, which it said was seriously under strength.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Nuclear Event
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., April 2  The Federal and state authorities have used a wide array of sophisticated monitoring devices to check the amount of radiation escaping from the damaged nuclear generating plant here.

title: Mr. Carter on the Family Record
description: When the Justice Department appointed a special counsel two weeks ago to manage the investigation of the Carter family's peanut business, we called on the President to keep his postWatergate compact with the nation by telling what he knew of the situation. We said he could presumably assure the public that he and his campaign were in no way involved in the bookkeeping legerdemain that has aroused the curiosity of Federal investigators.

title: Opponents of Amtrak Cutbacks Open Attack on Eve of Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  Organized opponents of the Carter Administration's plans to cut back Amtrak service charged today that the proposals were misleading and seemed capable of raising future operating costs rather than lowering them.

title: TV: Clones Dominate
description: THE question of the divided self, of twinning and doubling as a metaphor for moral ambiguity and alienation, has long been a preoccupation in the high culture of the West. As T.S. Eliot says, quoting Baudelaire's Les Fleurs du Mal, in the last line of the first section of The Waste Land:

title: A Fair Shake for Savers
description: If you deposit $100 at the corner savings bank, the interest is 5 percent a year. If you bring in $10,000 and leave it for six months, you get about 9 percent. But if you have $100,000 and buy a certificate of deposit from a bank, the rate could exceed 10 percent.

title: About East Meadow
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., April 2  It may not be as dramatic or carcinogenit as a nuclear radiation leak, but a steady, underground gasolinetank leak from the local Exxon station drove 25 families into a claustrophobic motel exile that has already lasted nine weeks.

title: Dominican Republic Lacks Gas
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 2 (UPI)  Vehicular traffic was almost at a standstill yesterday because of widespread gasoline shortages. Buses and taxis immediately raised fares.

title: Assembly's RollCall on Abortion
description: ALBANY, April 2 The following is the rollcall vote by which the State Assembly tonight defeated an amendment to cut off Medicaid money for abortions except in cases where the mother's life or physical health was in danger or where she was a victim of rape or incest:

title: G.I.'s Drown in Tank in Germany
description: BREMERHAVEN, West Germany, April 2 (Reuters)  Two American soldiers were drowned today when their tank plunged into the harbor, the police said. The 50ton tank broke through a ramp as it was being unloaded from a ship, they said.

title: Jobs in New York City Rise Sharply
description: The number of jobs in New York City increased sharply in the first two months of this year over the corresponding period last year, according to Federal and state data issued yesterday. The figures showed payroll employment up by 55,600 jobs in January and by 55,000 in February from the totals for the same months in 1978.

title: Accord Reached On Houdaille
description: Houdaille Industries and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company announced that definitive loan and other agreements had been entered into with institutions and other investors for 100 percent of the financing, amounting to about $355 million, necessary to consummate the acquisition of Houdaille by an investor group organized by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts.

title: EARNINGS Chessie Profit Up In Quarter
description: The Chessie System reported yesterday a profit of $8.3 million, or 42 cents share, for the first quarter of this year, in contrast to a $67 million loss in the similar period a year ago. It cited an upsurge in revenues derived from transporting coal and iron ore in its 13state operating area.

title: Science Library
description: The eminent paleontologist Stephen Jay Gould conceded in a scholarly article that his passion for dinosaurs dated from childhood, when his father took him to the Walt Disney movie Fantasia. One episode of the cartoon classic depicts the evolution of dinosaurs, as set to the music of Stravinsky's ballet Sacre de Printemns.

title: Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center. Tchalkovsky's Eugen Onegine 8.

title: U.S. Embassy in Beirut Attacked
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 2  Three men fired two rocketpropelled grenades at the United States Embassy today in what some analysts said could be the beginning of Palestinian guerrilla retaliation for American sponsorship of the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty.

title: Effect of CableTV Ruling
description: THE Supreme Court's ruling yesterday striking down federally mandated publicaccess channels for cable television severely diminishes the Federal Communications Commission's jurisdiction over the growing cable industry. It also deals a blow to publicinterest and freespeech organizations, which had pressed for rules at the F.C.C. that would open channels on cable systems for free publiexpression channels that would serve in effect as a video soapbox.

title: Knicks' Webster Has Surgery
description: Marvin Webster, the 7footIinch center whose persistent knee problems hampered his first year with the Knicks, underwent minor surgery yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Corporate Earnings Are Reported for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) Ind cates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Large publishing houses, suddenly inspiring a gleam in the eye of mergerminded companies, have used a variety of methods to discourage unwanted suitors.

title: Life Plans Television Campaign
description: CHARLES A. WHITTINGHAM will be the first magazine publisher of Time Inc. in the long, proud history of that company to appear in a television commercial promoting subscriptions. His performance makes Adolph Menjou look like a peon.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Atomic Facility Bonds Show Increased Yields
description: The breakdown of the nuclear power plant at Three Mile. Island in Pennsylvania raised yields yesterday on bonds sold to finance atomic generating facilities, and it seemed certain to raise borrowing costs on nuclearrelated securities about to come to market.

title: Australians May Float U.S. Paper
description: The thriving commercial paper market in the United States is expected to be officially opened to foreign banks for the first time next week.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: HARRIMAN, N.Y. PUBLIC confidence in American higher education has been eroded in recent years. Consensus on what constitutes legitimate higher education has been reduced, and expectations of it  and claims for it  have not been fulfilled. Neither financial resources nor enrollments will grow appreciably, and, in tact, will probably decline .... Failure to address the problems forthrightly and imaginatively will have serious negative effects on the integrity of universities and colleges.

title: Leo Fennelly Dies at 81; Assistant U.S. Attorney
description: Leo G. Fennelly, a former special assistant United States Attorney, died of a heart attack Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: Big Hair Dryers Tied to Asbestos, Senate Unit Told
description: Some floormodel hair dryers, the hooded devices that are a fixture in virtually every beauty parlor in the country, may pose the same risk of asbestos pollution previously linked to handheld models, a Senate subcommittee was told yesterday in Washington.

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS F.C.C.'S REGULATIONS ON CABLE TV ACCESS
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  The Supreme Court today struck down Federal regulations requiring operators of major cable television systems to allow community, educational and local government groups access, either free or at lowcost, to at least four of their channels.

title: TV: CBS Reports Pits Handicapped vs. Costs
description: OPPOSING the handicapped may seem about as morally and politically feasible in this country as a rousing condemnation of mom and apple pie. But, across the nation, increasingly militant handicapped groups are running into stronger public resistance, while there takes place, as Marlene Sanders explains, a collision between cost and conscience at a time when there are many competing claims for our tax dollars.

title: Koch Balks at Glum Setting For City's Financial Picture
description: Mayor Koch dismissed it as morgue. Deputy Mayor Philip L. Toia swore it looked like a funeral parlor. Other City Hall staff members detected a Moorish influence and saw the arched ceilings, the Oriental carpets hung on the wall and the banked house plants on pedestals as a more proper setting for giving a key to the city to Sinbad the Sailor than for reports on deficits and revenues.

title: Zamir Chorale Sings to Israel
description: THE Zamir Chorale presented its annual concert in honor of Israel's Independence Day on Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall. The program, consisting mainly of short, tuneful selections on Israeli and religious themes, was less enterprising than some the group has given in the past. But the music was eminently pleasant, and it seemed to be what the large, attentive audience had come to hear.

title: Sheine B. Krinsky Is the Bride Of Rabbi Joseph B. Friedman
description: Sheine B. Krinsky, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Yehuda Krinsky, was married last night to Rabbi Joseph B. Friedman, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Jacob Friedman. Both families live in Brooklyn. Rabbi Zalman S. Dworkin, dean of the Lubavitch Rabbinic Board, officiated at the Lubavitch World Center in Brooklyn. Seven rabbis, including the fathers of the couple. assisted.

title: PhoneIn Setup for Jurors Is Started in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 2  A juror phonein system, intended to spare prospective jurors an often useless daylong wait to be impaneled, was inaugurated today in Westchester County after apparent success in Dutchess, Orange, Putnam and Rockland Counties.

title: Passman Tells of Nixon View
description: MONROE, La., April 2 (AP)  Former United States Representative Otto E. Passman said today that former President Richard M. Nixon congratulated him on his acquittal yesterday in the Korean ricebuying scandal. I'm going to visit him in California in a few weeks and he's coming to Monroe later, Mr. Passman told a news conference.

title: NUCLEAR REACTORS UNDER CLOSE STUDY
description: Nuclear reactors are built in several shapes and sizes, and the worrisome one that the Babcock & Wilcox Company supplied for the Three Mile Island plant one of the more common types, known as a pressurizedwater reactor.

title: Hustling Obscenity
description: Larry Flynt's latest clash with the law, culminating in his obscenity conviction by an Atlanta jury, advanced neither the cause of free expression nor that censorship.

title: Flying Paster Emerging As New Factor in Derby
description: ARCADIA, Calif., April 2In Barn of the. Santa Anita stables early this morning, the prospect of taking Flying Paster to Louisville and beating Spectacular Bid in the Kentucky Derby had the horse's trainer as fired up as the sun that was burning through the gray haze of the San Gabriel Mountains.

title: MatsushitaChinese Deal
description: TOKYO, April 2 (AP)  The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company announced today that China had ordered 200,000 of its blackandwhite television sets. Matsushita said the Chinese had requested shipment of more than 30,000 10inchscreen TV sets a month for six months beginning in June.

title: Utility to Curb Building To Pay Reactor Repairs
description: PARSIPPANY, N.J., April 2 (UPI)The General Public Utilities Corporation said today that it was stopping all but the most critical construction of new facilities, raising the possibility of a halt in building a second nuclear reactor at Forked River, N.J.

title: Gov. Brown, Embarrassed, Ends New Hampshire Stay
description: CONCORD, N.H., April 2  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California dipped his toe into the political waters here for the first time tonight, only to withdraw it in chagrined embarrassment a few minutes after his arrival.

title: Around the Nation
description: COVINGTON, Ky., April 2 (AP) Nearly two years after a fire that killed 165 persons at the Beverly Hills Supper Club, the first of several trials of nearly $3 billion in claims got under way today in Federal Court here.

title: World News Briefs
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 2  Prime Minister P. W. Botha of South Africa met with political leaders from SouthWest Africa today and asked them to decide within a week whether to accept compromise proposals for a United Nationssupervised ceasefire in the territory.

title: THORNBURGH WEIGHS RISKS OF RADIATION
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 2  Dick Thornburgh, Governor of Pennsylvania for less than three months, is struggling with the anomalous problems posed by the most serious and frightening accident ever in a commercial nuclear reactor.

title: 28 Strikers Arrested Lying Down Before School Buses
description: Twentyeight striking bus drivers and matrons were arrested yesterday as they lay down in front of garages in Queens and Staten Island. They were attempting to block the Board of Education from using nonunion drivers to transport handicapped children to school. All 28 were charged with disorderly conduct.

title: Parliament in Italy Is Disbanded
description: ROME, April 2  President Sandro Pertini disbanded Parliament today, making early elections necessary.

title: Begin Lands in Egypt and Receives A Polite but Restrained Welcome
description: CAIRO, April 2  Menachem Begin, the first Israeli Prime Minister to visit Cairo, arrived today to a polite but subdued reception.

title: .... But the City's in Trouble
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn.  I have just returned from one of my occasional visits to New York City and I am disturbed.

title: Teachers and Students Return After Baton Rouge School Strike
description: BATON ROUGE, La., April 2 (AP)The parish's 115 public schools returned to pretty much normal operations today as students returned to classes after a twoweek teacher strike.

title: Taiwan Still in Federation, British Court Decides
description: LONDON, April 2 (AP)  The expulsion of Taiwan from the International Amateur Athletics Federation last October in deference to China was ruled invalid by a High Court judge here today.

title: ALBANY DEADLOCKED ON ABORTION FUNDS
description: ALBANY, Tuesday, April 3  Passage of the state's $12.6 billion budget was blocked last night when the State Senate voted to eliminate Medicaid money to finance abortions for poor women and the Asssembly refused to do so.

title: Nuclear Issues Lead Stock Drop
description: The stock market moved broadly lower yesterday as investors sought to gauge what longterm impact the nuclear accident at the Three Mile Island power plant in Middletown, Pa., would have upon the nation's energy policies.

title: U.S. to Provide $1.9 Million For Times Sq. Renovation
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  New York City's efforts to redevelop the Times Square area got a major stimulus today with the announcement that the Federal Government would put up $1.9 million to help create a complex of new theaters, restaurants and other entertainment facilities on 42d Street west of Ninth Avenue.

title: A Key Report in Scandal Is Upheld in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 2  A South African Government inquiry gave the first official confirmation today that the scandalridden Information Ministry attempted to gain control of The Washington Star as part of its worldwide effort to defend the country's racial policies.

title: Carroll Rosenbloom, 72, Drowns In Miami;Owner of N.F.L. Rams
description: Carroll Rosenbloom, the 72yearold owner of the Los Angeles Rams football team, drowned yesterday while swimming in the surf off Golden Beach, Fla., according to the police. Mr. Rosenbloom had rented a home while vacationing at the resort, near Miami, where he had owned a house for many years.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  The Supreme Court ruled today that evidence obtained by a Federal agency in violation of the agency's own rules can be introduced at a criminal defendant's trial.

title: U.S. to Mourn Victims of Nazis
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)  President Carter today proclaimed April 28 and 29, the 34th anniversary of the liberation of the Nazi death camp at Dachau, as days of remembrance of victims of the Holocaust.

title: Hollywood, Hoopla Over, Now the Wait for Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES, April 2  Nearly $3 million has been spent in pursuit of the 1978 Academy Awards, and now it is all over except the applause. The ballots had to be in the hands of the accounting firm of Price, Waterhouse by 5 P.M. yesterday; the results will be announced next Monday night.

title: Hot Sun, Cool Reception Leave Begin Undaunted
description: CAIRO, April 2  Crowds did not show up or they were kept away by tight Egyptian security. The highest Government officials were not on hand to receive him throughout most of the day, and a merciless sun rumpled his gray suit, white shirt and tie.

title: Chemical Stench in New Orleans
description: BELLE CHASSE, La., April 2 (AP)A small tank of mercaptan, the chemical used to put the odor into natural gas, overflowed late yesterday and sent a nauseating stench wafting over the New Orleans area.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: No Title -- Article 1
description: Deaths

title: Dance: June Finch's Items, 2 Others
description: JUNE FINCH is a former member of the Viola Farber Dance Company and of the teaching staff at the Merce Cunningham Studio. Now a respected teacher and choreographer in her own right, Miss Finch presented an evening of three dances at the Cunningham Studio on Sunday. The pedigree was obvious. This was a program of fluid and elegant dance, performed by an equally elegant company of eight men and women.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Working quickly to rebuild its depleted cash balances and avoid default in paying the Federal Government's bills, the Treasury early last evening announced a crowded schedule of financings to raise $26.7 billion over the next week. Three issues will be sold today.

title: U.S. Debt Ceiling Raised; Threats of Default Ended
description: WASHINGTON, April 2The House of Representatives today approved an increase in the national debt's ceiling to $830 billion from $798 billion, ending a threat that the nation would default on its bills for the first time in history.

title: Britain Tightens Security at Houses of Parliament
description: LONDON, April 2  The British Government announced a tightening of security precautions today at the Houses of Parliament as a result of the murder of a prominent Conservative in the area Friday.

title: Lufthansa Ordering 25 A310 Airbuses
description: BONN, April 2  Lufthansa German Airlines announced today that it was ordering 25 European A310 Airbuses and taking options on 25 more in what a spokesman for the manufacturer, Airbus Industrie, called the largest sale of aircraft ever by a European company.

title: News Summary
description: Hazards of cooling a nuclear reactor in the crippled plant in Middletown, Pa., were abating, according to Federal safety officials. But they said that radiation levels in the containment vessel were very high, causing continuing concern for public health. Civil Defense units and other agencies remained on alert, and pregnant women and preschool children were still under warning to stay away from the immediate area. President Carter's chief representative at the plant said the size of the gas bubble trapped in the reactor core had all but disappeared and that uranium oxide in the core was being adequately cooled. [Page A1, Co1.6.]

title: Uganda's New U.N. Mission Is a Monument to Idi Amin
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 2 The sleek 15story building near the United Nations was intended by President Idi Amin to be Uganda's showcase in the United States, a headquarters for his delegation to the United Nations that would enhance its prestige before the world community.

title: Western Loans To Pretoria
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 2 (UPI)  A report commissioned by the United Nations showed today that banks in five Western countries had lent South Africa nearly $5.5 billion since 1972, a figure that Nigeria called welldocumented evidence of Western support for Pretoria's apartheid regime.

title: Budget Battle Opens In House Committee
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  The opening salvo in the battle of the 1980 budget, a struggle of major consequence both within and between the Republican and Democratic Parties, was fired rather quietly this morning on Capitol Hill.

title: House Panel Kills Move to Send Observers to Rhodesian Election
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  The House of Representatives Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa today killed a resolution decisively approved by the Senate last week that would have sent a team of private citizens to observe the elections scheduled in Rhodesia later this month.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Step Forward in a New Seder
description: Wherefore was this seder different from all other seders?

title: Mildred G. Feldman Wed To Dr. Samuel Frankel
description: Mildred Goldstein Feldman of Short Hills, N.J., widow of Dr. Noah Feldman, was married yesterday evening to Dr. Samuel, Frankel, a widower of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Alexander M, Shapiro perfotmed the ceremony in the chapel of Temple Oheb Shalom in South Orange, N.J.

title: CantonHong Kong Rail Service
description: HONG KONG, April 2 (Reuters)  Direct expresstrain service between China and Hong Kong, suspended for 30 years, is to resume Wednesday, the New China News Agency said today. The airconditioned train will take about two hours.

title: Ethel Harper, Actress Was Aunt Jemima In Ads for Pancakes
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 2 (AP)$ Ethel Ernestine Harper, known to millions of Americans as Aunt Jemima, died of a heart attack Saturday evening while driving her automobile. She was 75 years old.

title: Placebos Work, but Survey Shows Widespread Misuse
description: ANEW survey among young physicians and nurses at three hospitals in New Mexico has disclosed that most of them are ignorant of the proven power of the placebo  the proverbial sugar pill that is perhaps the most timehonored treatment in the history of medicineand tend to use it for the wrong reasons.

title: Why Evacuation Was Not Ruled Out
description: WHILE the possibility of major release of radiation from the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania seems greatly reduced, the consequences of such a release would be so grave that officials there were still unwilling to rule out an evacuation.

title: The Pentagon Tax Drains New York. Cut It.
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  The New York taxpayer is assured at regular intervals by his Senators and Representatives of their abiding and vigilant pursuit of Federal programs that add to the wealth and resources of the community.

title: CARTER MAPS POLICY TO PROTECT PRIVACY
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  President Carter asked Congress today for legislation to protect Americans from threats to privacy in the computer age.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: A twopart tax on domestic oil and gradual price increases on oil produced in the United States will be endorsed by President Carter as the centerpieces of the Administration's complex new energy program, officials said. The measures are expected to produce $3 billion to $5 billion annually in Federal revenues by 1981 and to result in higher prices for domestic oil products in addition to any increases imposed by oilexporting countries. The White House is expected to announce the new program within the next few days. [Page A1]

title: Ruling Restricts Loan Offices
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  A Federal district judge has ruled that national banks cannot operate loan production offices in states that bar or severely restrict branch banking.

title: Slow Job Growth for 1980's Seen In New York Econometric Study
description: Employment in New York City and its suburbs will grow at only half the annual rate of the rest of the country in the coming decade, but personal income will climb faster than the national rate, according to the first comprehensive econometric model constructed for the metropolitan area.

title: Revue: The City Suite Sings of Life
description: THE pains and joys of adolescence and the subsequent adjustment to adult life are themes that have been chewed over so frequently that it is surprising that there can still be some juice in them. But the juices are still there in the eyes and minds of each new generation confronting them, so it is not surprising that Keith Levenson, a 19yearold composer and lyricist, has found them worth working over once again.

title: Richard Ettinghausen, Teacher, A Leading Islamic Art Authority
description: Richard Ettinghausen, consultative chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's department of Islamic art and Hagop Kevorkian Professor of Islamic Art at the New York University Institute of Fine Arts since 1969, died yesterday in Princeton (N.J.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Cuomo Is Offering Legal Services to People Fighting Bureaucracy
description: ALBANY, April 2  Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, whose proposed ombudsman's office was scuttled by the Legislature, said today that he would go to court himself, free of charge in some cases, to represent needy people fighting government bureaucracy.

title: Senate Vote Means End Of Renegotiation Board
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)  The Senate dealt a final, killing blow today to the Renegotiation Board, an agency designed to curtail excessive profits for contactors handling Government projects.

title: Trading Delay In Commodities
description: Trading at four member exchanges at the Commodities Exchange Center in the World Trade Center was halted for about two hours yesterday due to a computer malfunction caused by a power failure.

title: New Chrysler Repair Plan Challenges Ford and G.M.
description: DETROIT, April 2 (UPI)  The Chrysler Corporation, firing the latest salvo in an emerging warranty war involving the Big Three auto makers, said today that it was offering a new optional fiveyear or 50,000mile service contract on new cars and trucks.

title: IN THE NATION Democrats in Trouble
description: BOISE, Idaho  All through the Mountain States, the signs of trouble for the Democrats in 1980 are clearly visible:

title: Rebellion by Bayern Players Causes Commotion in West German Soccer
description: MUNICH, West Germany  An airportlounge putsch in which the players on West Germany's soccer equivalent of the New York Yankees rebelled against the club president and rejected his appointment of a new coach has shaken the sport here. The details might terrify George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner.

title: Q & A
description: Q. What exactly is recombinant DNA?

title: Bengal Tiger Dies in Capital Zoo
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)  Mohini Rewa, the first white tiger to be exhibited in a zoo outside of India, died of old age today at the National Zoo. The 20yearold Bengal tiger was officially received Dec. 5,1960, at the White House.

title: Court Frees $20 Million Aid For Private Schools in State
description: The United States Supreme Court refused yesterday to continue a lowercourt order that has prevented New York State from reimbursing parochial schools for complying with statemandated tests and recordkeeping tasks. Within hours of the High Court's action, the State Comptroller announces that Checks amounting to $20 million would be mailed out, starting tomorrow, to nearly 2,000 nonpublic schools.

title: Issues in Walkout by Teamsters
description: Parties: About 1,700 American trucking companies are covered by the national Master Freight Agreement. The industry is represented in the negotiations by Trucking Management Inc.

title: Pakistani Leader Is Reportedly Undecided on Bhutto
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 2  A final decision on the fate of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto is expected in a few days, and there were indications tonight that President Mohammed Zia ulHag is undecided whether to commute the death sentence imposed on the 51yearold Pakistani leader who has been convicted of ordering the assassination of a political opponent in 1979.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Regulator to Reject Savings Bank Purchases of Home Loan Units
description: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has declared that he no longer will consider applications for acquisitions of federally chartered savings and loan associations by mutual savings banks, unless unusual situations arise.

title: 7 College Teams Remain Undefeated in Lacrosse
description: Only seven of the nation's top 30 lacrosse teams remained undefeated at the close of the third full week of the season.

title: The City
description: A $10,000 increase was announced yesterday in the reward offered in connection with last Saturday's burglary in Greenwich Village at one of the world's largest makers of religious symbolic jewelry.

title: Rock: An Elvis Costello Marathon
description: ELVIS COSTELLO's marathon of New York performances last weekend might have been newsy enough, even without the controversy over his recently quoted, apparently racist remarks about Ray Charles and James Brown. With them, the weekend took on an added edge, and made a lot of people think hard about just, what Elvis Costello has to offer.

title: Ballet: Heinz Poll Directs Ohioans
description: THE Ohio Ballet from Akron, founded and directed by Heinz Poll, turns out to be the best news in dance this season. In its second program, Sunday, as part of a brief engagement at Brooklyn College's Whitman Hall, the young company came across as amazingly polished.

title: Science Watch
description: The first largescale American trial of a vaccine for a sexually transmitted disease is expected to begin next month, according to a report in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Music: Claire Polin  and Blumenfeld
description: ACONCERT of new music took place Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Although no particular group appeared to be in charge of the proceedings and the varied program represented no one special style, two composers did dominate the evening, Claire Polin and Harold Blumenfeld, both of whom contributed two works each.

title: Notes on the Bronx Zoo
description: The Bronx Zoo opens its season tomorrow with new exhibits in some of the cages but with most of the menagerie still on display. Luis Tiant and Tommy John have been added to the cast, Sparky Lyle and Billy Martin have departed, but the likes of Reggie Jackson, Thurman Munson, Mickey Rivers, Catfish Hunter and George Steinbrenner are back at the old stand. Especially George Steinbrenner. They populate the Bronx Zoo at East 161st Street and River Avenue, officially known as Yankee Stadium. There is another, quieter

title: Unions for Public Workers Continue to Grow in South
description: ATLANTA, April 3  Officials of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees are to march through the streets of Memphis tomorrow in ceremonies marking the 11th anniversary of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who died supporting a strike by that city's union garbage workers.

title: Islanders Victors by 32 on Acrobatic Shot
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 3  There was morethanusual satisfaction in the New York Islanders 32 victory over the Atlanta Flames tonight in Nassau Coliseum.

title: No Escape, It Seems
description: HERSHEY, Pa.  I have a sense of vu about what is happening southwest of me at Three Mile Island. When I was very young and lived 2,200 miles away in southern Utah, something similar happened.

title: Hispanic Leaders Promote Zoot Suit
description: A group of Hispanic people linked to the theater and to community and cultural organizations, led by Miriam Colon, the actress and director of the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, has accelerated efforts to mobilize a new kind of audience  rather than the traditional Broadway audience to attend Zoot Suit. The play by the California writer Luis Valdez is it the Winter Garden.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Victor Posuer, the financier, disclosed yesterday that the NVF Company, the flagship of his business empire, owned 11.7 percent of the APL Corporation's outstanding Common shares.

title: Jane Byrne, With Machine Help, Sweeps Mayoral Vote in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, April 3  With the formal blessing but sometimes reluctant help of the Democratic machine she humiliated In the February primary, Jane M. Byrne was swept into office today as Mayor of Chicago. She defeated her nearest challenger by a ratio of more than 5 to 1.

title: Private Lives
description: THEY will find him under the coffee table, supine on the rug. His right arm is folded over his eyes. His right wrist is gripped by his left hand. He looks as if he is praying with his elbows. Not so. There is, instead, a vision he wishes to occlude. The vision is of a mouth. The mouth is the size of a swamp. The world is disappearing into the swampmouth. The swampmouth is eating the world.

title: About Real Estate Tarrytown Builder Makes Corporate Center Headway
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.  Beep Beep, driven by Joel Halpern of Bronxville, N.Y. roared out of the dark haze draped across the choppy Atlantic Ocean today and crossed the finish line 17 minutes ahead of the rest of the open boat fleet.

title: For Britain's Voters, the Clearest Choice Since 1945
description: LONDON, April 3  A month from today, the British people vote in a general election that may prove the most signifiant since the sweeping Labor Party victory at the end of World War II.

title: Radiation Overdose: All in a Day's Work
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 3  Last Wednesday afternoon Edward Houser dressed more carefully than usual for work.

title: Pope Condemns a Book; First Such Act Since 67
description: ROME, April 3 (Reuters)  Pope John Paul II publicly condemned a book today, the first such action since the Roman Catholic Church stopped banning books in 1967.

title: Deaths
description: BAUERBenjamin. We are saddened by the loss of our friend and former colleague. ThomsonCSF Laboratories Renville H. McMann, President

title: G.O.P. Candidates Looking to Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, March 3  Lodge, Alcorn, Bush  some of the Grand Old Party names from Connecticut's past are coming back into Republican prominence these days for the state's first fullfledged Presidential primary election, still 11 months away.

title: U.S. Inquiry on Rights Opens With a Promise Of an InDepth Effort
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)  A panel of Congressmen began a public inquiry today into alleged violations of human rights in the United States with pledge to examine every charge honestly and openly.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: CALIFORNIA SEEKING COASTAL LAW SHIFTS
description: LOS ANGELES, April 3  California's pioneering venture in rigorous controls on coastal development is encountering heavy weather.

title: Advertising
description: FOR the people who stuck with N. W. Ayer during the dark days of the 1960's, the agency's current acclaim and fame are a just and fitting reward for loyalty.

title: EARNINGS
description: MetroGoldwynMayer Inc., which now derives the major part of its earnings from hotel and casino operations, reported yesterday an 8 percent gain in net income in its second fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28 to a record $10.4 million, or 34 cents a share, on a, 20.1 percent rise in revenues to $111.3 million.

title: Republican Wins Special Election For Rep. Ryan's Seat in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 Overcoming a huge disadvantage in voter registration, William Royer, a Republican, won a seat today In the United States House of Representatives that had been held through four elections by a Democrat. He defeated Joe Holsinger, who was weakened by intraparty squabbling among Democrats.

title: Stage: Of TV Survivors, Clinics and Drug Addicts
description: THERE are nine months to go in 1979, but in Leave It to Beaver Is Dead, which opened last night as a workshop production at the Public Theater, the playwrightdirector Des McAnuff it already tolling a dirge for the 70's. Can nostalgia for the 80's be far away? The characters in Mr. McAnuff's new play are survivors of television young people who grew up with sitcoms ,ind think of life as a game show.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: SOME inventions in food that are absolutely delectable seem to have come from a bizarre and adventurous brain. An ingredient may seem odd, perhaps daring. There is a Swedish recipe for roast lamb with coffee (including the cream) and a Southern creation known as red eye gravy, a sauce made by adding hot coffee to the skillet in which a slice of country ham cooked. Eggs or fish au beurre noir,which is to say with a burnt butter sauce, hardly sems a traditional blend of foods. Asafetida, the resinous substanc that is foulsmelling to some nostrils, has an honorable place (used in small quantities) in Indian kitchens, particularly those that deal in vegetarian cooking. which is to say with a burnt butter sauce, hardly sems a traditional blend of foods. Asafetida, the resinous substanc that is foulsmelling to some nostrils, has an honorable place (used in small quantities) in Indian kitchens, particularly those that deal in vegetarian cooking.

title: BEGIN, ENDING VISIT, SAYS EGYPT BORDER WILL OPEN MAY 27
description: CAIRO, April 3  Prime Minister Menachem Begin ended a twoday visit here today with the announcement that the opening of the EgyptianIsraeli frontier would be accelerated by seven months.

title: Saudis Lift Prices On Quality Oil
description: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, which has so far bucked the trend in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to tack large surcharges onto the price of oil, has increased the quality differential on some of its oil, industry sources said yesterday. But they emphasized that the price rise was not a surcharge.

title: U.S. Transit Agency Cuts Plan to Aid Handicapped
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  After months of heated debate about the facilities that local transit authorities must provide for handicapped and elderly people, Transportation Secretary Brock Adams ruled today that the authorities must offer easy access only to key subway and commuter train stations.

title: Legislature's Vote on Pay Raises
description: ALBANY, April 3  The following is the vote by which the State Legislature approved pay increases tonight for legislators, judges and top members of the executive branch:

title: Mets Bow in Finale; Riles Is Dropped
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3The New York Mets ended spring training today with a 6.2 loss to the Pittsburgh Pirates, an exhibition record of 10 victories and 13 defeats and five rookies, an unusually high number, on the 25man team heading north.

title: Steak  With a Little Gospel on the Side
description: SANGER, TEX. Serious eaters in New York City report that there are still one or two wellregarded bistros that omit prices from the velourbacked menus they reserve for escorted women diners. Well, Dr. Ron Thomas, who owns and operates the Fatted Calf steakhouse here, will have none of that male chauvinist foolishness. His menus are covered with grease stains instead of velour, and they bear no prices at all.

title: Around the Nation
description: MIAMI, April 3 (AP)  Five persons were missing in the Atlantic Ocean today after one boat burned at sea and another was swamped when it apparently ran into a submerged object, the Coast Guard reported. Five persons were rescued.

title: Going out Guide
description: REFLECTIONS Beverly Sills will discuss her forthcoming career as director of the New York City Opera at today's twohour breakfast session of the New York Forum, starting at 9:30 A.M. on the mezzanine of Marymount College, 221 East 71st Street. Admission to the coffeeandcake sessions, which include a period of questions and answers, is $10.

title: 11097 Victory for Denver
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J. April 3  The Denver Nuggets tnoved within one victory (or one loss by the San Diego Clippers) of a playoff berth in the National Basketball Association by rolling to a 11097 victory over the New Jersey Nets tonight.

title: Emigration of Soviet Jews in March Sets Record
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  More Jews were permitted to emigrate from the Soviet Union in March than in any previous month.

title: Israeli Diplomats Told To Pay Parking Fines
description: TEL AVIV, April 3  Israeli diplomats who break New York City's traffic laws will be required to pay fines out of their own pockets instead of being allowed to invoke diplomatic immunity, Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan told Parliament in Jerusalem today.

title: Dennis Arlan, Known For Children's Operas
description: Dennis Arlan, a composer best known for his children's operas, died of cancer Sunday at the SloanKettering Memorial Hospital. He was 33 years old.

title: Blessings of Food and Family:  A Passover Memoir
description: O F all the Jewish holidays in the year, none meant more to me as a child than Passover, for it was in every way a joyous and lyrical celebration, bringing with it two brandnew party dresses and wonderfully rich and fragrant foods that I had not tasted for a year.

title: Ouster of Energy Officials Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  The Union of Concerned Scientists called today for the resignation of Joseph M. Hendrie, chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, accusing him of being not fit to be the nation's chief nuclear regulator.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 4, 1979

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Treasury, quickly utilizing its new borrowing power, sold three issues of bills yesterday to raise $16 billion in shortterm funds. The average rate on threemonth bills, 9.593 percent, was the highest for these Government securities since the record of 9.908 percent was set in August 1974.

title: Peking Decides to Let 50 Soviet Amity Pact Expire in April of 80
description: HONG KONG, April 3  China announced today that it had decided not to extend its 1950 friendship treaty with the Soviet Union when it expires next year.

title: ExChampions Differ On Boxing Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, April 3Like their distinct boxing styles, the former champions who testified today at a Congressional hearing presented divergent viewpoints on the merits of proposed legislation to regulate the sport.

title: Soviet Cyclist Dies
description: MOSCOW, April 3 (UPI)  Gennadi Komnatov, a member of the Soviet cycling team that won a gold medal in the 100kilometer race at the 1972 Olympics, was killed in an automobile crash last Sunday, the newspaper Sovetsky Sport reported today. He was 29 years old.

title: Wine Talk
description: ONE of the problems with most wine books is that they deal mostly with wine. Not that wine isn't fascinating, but it's not nearly so interesting as the people who make it and the places it is made.

title: Technology
description: THE race to develop faster, more complex integrated circuits can often lead to dramatic changes in the fortunes of the companies that build the equipment that produces those circuits. Today the challenge  and hence the opportunity to snare new business  lies in keeping pace with an everchanging, moredemanding technology.

title: Gault Promoted To Jobs Director By Mayor Koch
description: Succeeds Brezenoff in Post  Pressley Appointed

title: Yanks to Honor 10 War Heroes
description: Ten former servicemen whose heroism at Lanzerath, Belgium, 35 years ago bought time for the American Army just before the Battle of the Bulge will be honored by the Yankees tomorrow when the team opens the baseball season against the Milwaukee Brewers at Yankee Stadium.

title: Playfulness Displayed By Pianist
description: TWO contrasting Beethoven sonatas made up the first half of Gary Kirkpatrick's piano recital in Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, an early one in C (Op. 2, No. 3) and the famous Appassionata in F minor (Op. 57).

title: Carter Oil Speech On TV Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)President Carter scheduled a nationally broadcast address for Thursday night to announce plans to ease controls on crude oil prices and possibly to appoint a commission to investigate the Three Mile Island nuclear plant accident.

title: Citicorp Notes Rise
description: Citicorp reported that the average rate on its threemonth notes, which the bankholding company has been selling weekly since last September, rose yesterday to 10.116 percent from 9.984 percent on March 27. Citicorp received $803.5 million of orders for the $100 million issue at rates ranging from 9.90 percent to 10.124 percent, and it accepted 91.5 percent of the issue at the higher rate.

title: L.I.R.R. Seeking Advice From Its Severest Critics
description: The Long Island Rail Road yesterday began a program of inviting commuters to give advice on how the line could be improved, and among those who took up the offer were:

title: Bridge:
description: During the last 90 years the opening one notrump bid and its consequences have been subject to more refinement than almost any other area of bidding. Ely Culbertson's idea was to give the bid narrow requirements and then never use it, because he did not have any sensible structure of responses.

title: Laboratory Is Making Computer Simulation Of Nuclear Accident
description: The Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island has been assigned the task of constructing a computer model of the nuclear powerplant accident in Middletown, Pa., so that the extent of damage,to the fuel elements in the core can be estimated.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Adams Express Company and its noncontrolled affiliate, the Petroleum and Resources Corporation, have both elected Karl G. Wassmann 3d as treasurer, succeeding Robert J.M. Wilson, who continues as president.

title: Dividends
description: Pe Stk. of pay.

title: 5 Are Arrested After Besieging Of Bus in Strike
description: Five persons were arrested yesterday after more than 200 striking schoolbus drivers, defying police escorts, besieged a bus as it. left a Brooklyn garage to pick up handicapped children.

title: From Croissants to Matzoh
description: PARIS Bread has always been uppermost in importance to the French, so it is no surprise to find a whole museum devoted to it in CharentonlePont, small suburb of Paris. The museum, single room above a working granary, mill and experimental bakery, houses an unusual historical collection of tools, documents, decorations and memorabilia pertaining to bread.

title: World News Briefs
description: Mailbag Blast Injures 10 At Frankfurt Airport

title: Elmhurst Flourishes as Melting Pot
description: Jun Soo, Tony Yoon and Seung Hwang, friends from Korea, were having fried chicken and CocaColas after school the other day at the Continental Donuts Shop in Elmhurst, Queens, when a woman from the Dominican Re public approached the Indonesian waitress.

title: Wide Gains Send Dow Up 13.08
description: Stock prices rebounded sharply yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average gained more than a dozen points. The bluechip Dow shared honors with glamour, oil, airline and gambling issues  and even segments of the recently battered nuclear group.

title: Max Conrad, Pioneer Pilot, at 76
description: WINONA, Minn., April 3 (AP)  Max Conrad, a pioneer aviator who was cited for logging more flight time than any other pilot, died in his sleep today at a friend's home in Summit, N.J., relatives said. He was 76 years old.

title: Opera: Parsifar Ends 5Year Absence at Met
description: THERE are those who would say that the trouble with  Parsifal is that it never makes up its mind whether it is musical theater or. a religious play. There are others, of course, who would deny there is any trouble with the work at all, and would say that its fluctuations of style and intent are precisely what make it the most ineffably satisfying of all the Wagner dramas. The Metropolitan Opera Monday night brought back its nineyearold production, most recently seen in the houte five seasons ago, and once more the old polarities of opinion are likely to be voiced. No fewer than 16 singers in the cast were taking their roles for the first time with this company, and the conductor, James Levine, also was being initiated.

title: Troops Take Over Gas Stations During Dominican Fuel Shortage
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 3 (AP)  Troops took over gas stations and the national refinery today as the Government, faced with a fuel shortage, sought to insure distribution of gasoline and prevent price speculation.

title: Ormandy to Retire
description: Eugene Ormandy will retire as music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra at the end of next season, when he will be 80 years old and will have held the post for 94 years. The orchestra; in announcing the conductor's decision yesterday, said he would become conductor laureate at the close of the 1979.80 season, and that Riccardo Muti, who has been principal guest conductor since 1975, was the prime candidate, though not the only one, to succeed Mr. Ormandy.

title: The Man Who Wants to Die
description: John Louis Evans 3d, who is scheduled to die Friday in Alabama's electric chair, seems determined to force the state to end his life. At his trial for murder, Evans freely admitted his crime and urged the jury to condemn him to die. He testified that he was beyond redemption and might kill again if released.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Air fare increases of 7 percent were agreed on by most of the world's major international carriers at a meeting of the International Air Transport Association in Geneva. The increases, subject to ,government approval in each country, are intended to offset the rising costs of aviation fuel. The higher fares were tentatively set for May 1 and would remain in force until next March 31. [Page A1.]

title: Political Chess a Draw at City Hall
description: Mayor Koch with Anatoly Karpov, Soviet grandmaster and world chess champion, at City Hall yesterday. The Mayor implored Bobby Fischer, who is from Brooklyn, end his sevenyear selfimposed exile and come back and defend us, implying a championship match be held in New York. Grandmaster that he is, Mr. Karpov nessed those issues and presented Mr. Koch with a computer chess game. International Chess Federation awarded world title, by default, to Mr. Karpov in 1975 when Mr. Fischer refused to meet his Soviet opponent.

title: Bosworth Shifts Burden of Price Proof to Companies
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  Sounding angry, chagrined and determined, Barry P. Bosworth, the chief pricewage monitor, said today that his agency would shift the burden of proof to companies believed to have violated the Administration's standards for voluntary price restraint.

title: U.S. Women Disappoint In British Lacrosse Tour
description: LONDON, April 3  Television cameras clicked off, a packed house stood and cheered, and champagne began to flow in the English locker room. The United States women's lacrosse team left the mudsoaked field at Hotspur Park outside London last Saturday after having lost the final match of disappointing threeweek tour of Britain.

title: Borg, Gerulaitis, McEnroe Gain in Rotterdam Tennis
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 3 (AP)  Bjorn Borg of Sweden and Vitas Gerulaitis and John McEnroe of the United States scored easy victories in the first round of a World Championship Tennis tournament today.

title: Nation Gets Ford Memoir
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford's, memoirs, to be published in June, have been obtained in typescript form by The Nation, which is running a summary and some excerpts in its April 7 issue. Harper & Row and The Reader's Digest, joint owners of the Ford book, are threatening legal action against the weekly opinion magazine, which will appear on newsstands today.

title: Heinz Car Wins Race to Coast
description: Unofficially, Dave Heinz and Dave Yarborough won the fifth Cannonball SeatoShiningSea Memorial Trophy Dash in 32 hours 51 minutes, which figures to an average speed of 86.7 miles an hour for the trip from a Darien, Conn., shopping plaza to an inn in Redondo Beach, Calif.

title: Careers
description: PROVIDING vocational guidance services has become a bigger and more complete activity on many college and university campuses in recent years. In fact, while teaching staffs may have been reduced in size on some campuses, the vocational staffs have been increasing in numbers and importance.

title: Appeals Court Backs Prison Guard Who Refused to Reply on K. K. K.
description: The New York Court of, Appeals ruled yesterday that prison authorities could not dismiss a guard who refused to say if he belonged to the Ku Klux Klan.

title: Europe Backs Trade Pact
description: LUXEMBOURG, April 3  The nine Common Market countries gave their qualified approval today to the agreement emerging from the Geneva trade liberalizing talks designed to prevent the world from slipping back into a new era of protectionism.

title: Corporate Earnings Are Reported for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Cairo Paper Is Said to Ask Eban To Do a Regular Political Column
description: TEL AVIV, April 3 (UPI)  The editor of the Cairo newspaper Al Ahram has invited former Israeli Foreign Minister Abba Eban to write a regular political column, the Israeli newspaper Maariv reported today.

title: The City
description: Two members of the City Council proposed yesterday that the name of Shea Stadium be changed to Jackie Robinson Memorial Stadium, in honor of the late Brooklyn Dodger Hall of Famer who was the first black player in the major leagues.

title: Belgian Premier Is Sworn In
description: BRUSSELS, April 3 (Reuters)Wilfried Martens, the Flemish Social Christian leader, was sworn in today by King Baudouin as Belgium's new Prime Minister, ending a void of almost six months in the country's politics. Paul Vanden

title: Dance: Joyce Trisler's Concerto and Fantasies
description: THE JOYCE TRISLER DANSCOMPANY celebrated its fifth anniversary last night with the opening of a new season that will run through Sunday at the Roundabout Theater, 333 West 23d Street.

title: Greek Resident Is Held in Brooklyn After Extradition on Drug Charges
description: A former New York City resident who Federal drug officials say is head of a ring responsible for having smuggled $100 million in drugs into the United States over the last decade was arraigned in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday on a fivecount indictment.

title: In Fashion, a Very British Fantasy
description: LONDON, April 3  The clothes here, like the presentations, have mood all their own, a little eccentric, perhaps, but friendly and gentle. Hard chic is not the prevailing style. Of course, there are the trendies, who believe in shoulder pads, narrow skirts and slits. But more often, fabric is shirred or draped in unusual ways. A lot of attention is given to finding new shapes for details such as yokes and pockets or the body of the garment itself. Some work, some don't, but there is always the feeling that imagination is in progress.

title: Talks on Mexico Gas Reopened
description: MEXICO CITY, April 3  After a 16month break, frequently marked by bitter exchanges, the United States and Mexico resumed official talks today on the sale of Mexican natural gas.

title: RADIOACTIVE PLANT FACES A SHUTDOWN AS LONG AS 4 YEARS
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., April 3  The Three Mile Island nuclear reactor continued to cool down today, but attention turned to the lingering effects of the lowlevel radiation that was still being released and to the possibility of a longterm shutdown of the contaminated plant.

title: A Health Writer's Favorite Recipes
description: Here are some Brody family favor. ices.

title: Swiss National Bank Loss
description: ZURICH, April 3 (Reuters)  The Swiss National Bank announced today that it posted a net loss last year for the first time since the 1930's. Its annual report showed a loss equivalent to $1.52 billion, in contrast to a $4.4 million profit in 1977. The bank attributed this to the rise of the Swiss franc from an average value of 2.25 to the United States dollar at the beginning of the year to 1.68 to the dollar at the end.

title: Puerto Rico Bond Sale Enlarged
description: The. $80 million in bonds scheduled for sale tomorrow by the Puerto Rico Building Authority was enlarged yesterday to $100 million and priced to yield as much as 7 oercent.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: SOME of the same people who have nothing but scorn for the dehydrated powder called instant coffee readily dine on reconstituted pasta. Yet the dried pasta that turns up In most kitchens is as far from the fresh variety as instant coffee is from the homebrewed. And the truth is that pasta Isn't all that much harder to make than coffee.

title: Honda May Build Cars In Britain
description: LONDON, April 3  British Leyland said today that it was discussing a link with the Honda Motor Company that could lead to production of Japanese cars at Levland's British plants.

title: Bhutto Hanged In Pakistan Jail For Murder Plot
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Wednesday, April 4 Zulfikar All Bhutto, the former Prime Minister of Pakistan, was hanged early today in the Rawalpindi District Jail, where he had been confined since his conviction last year on charges of conspiring to murder a political opponent in 1974.

title: Calmer Waters for Electric Boat
description: GROTON, Conn.  When the first Trident submarine, the U.S.S. Ohio, Is launched at the Electric Boat works here on Saturday it will mark a remarkable turnaround at the venerable shipyard.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN the second half of the 19th century, according to Patrick Bade, there was an extraordinary proliferation of femmes fatales in European art and literature. Wherever he went, the exhibition visitor of the 1890's found walls crowded with malefactors of the female sex.

title: TV: Deep Cold War Is Underwater
description: Afascinating glimpse of largely secret contest of wits and technology that is being waged between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies and the Soviet Union is provided by The Deep Cold War.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: ANYONE who has lived in New York more than 20 minutes without being invited to a cocktail party is just not going to make it in the Big Apple. It is easier to get invited to a cocktail party than it is to find out how to get to Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, especially if you ask a taxi driver.

title: Brooklyn Jewish Hospital Bid Fails
description: ALBANY, April 3  A lastminute effort by a bankruptcy judge to save Brooklyn Jewish Hospital apparently failed today when the Senate majority leader refused to meet with him to discuss a way to obtain $2.5 million in state funds for the financially troubled facility.

title: Collision in Mississippi River
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 3 (AP)  A Soviet cargo ship, a tug with two barges, an empty tanker and a Greek tanker collided today near the mouth of the Mississippi River, shutting down river traffic. the Coast Guard said. The two barges were loaded with a flammable liquid, and there was fear of pollution. No injuries were reported, and river traffic was resumed in an hour, the Coast Guard said.

title: Yankees Are Not Worried
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 3  Charley Lau, the Yankees new hitting coach, sat across the desk from Bob Lemon and studied the team's exhibition batting averages.

title: Holiday Recipes: Recollections From Childhood
description: Hot and cold beet borscht at Passover are traditionally made with russell, a fermentation of beets and beet juice that must be prepared six weeks in advance,. Prepared russell, as well as all other kosher for Passover ingredients in these recipes, can be purchased at Bistritzky's, a kosher grocery and food store, at 19 Essex Street and 17 Essex Street. The russell is $1.99 a gallon. In lieu of russell, prepare borscht with fresh or canned beets as described below, using lemon juice and sour salt (citric acid) for the winey effect.

title: Judge Moderates Prison Sentences Of 76 Hijackers
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn, who had sentenced four Croatian nationalists to up to life in prison for the 1976 hijacking of an American airliner, yesterday declared them eligible for parole after Dec. 31. A. New York City bomb squad officer was killed trying to dismantle a bomb left behind by the hijackers, who hoped to dramatize demands for Croatian independence from Yugoslavia.

title: 7 Simultaneous RaidsOn Betting OperationsReported by the Police
description: One of the largest sports betting operations ever discovered in the metropolitan area was raided last night by officers from three law enforcement agencies, the police said. In simultaneous raids on seven suspected wire rooms, they arrested 14 persons and confiscated $45,000 in cash, five handguns and 23 telephones.

title: Pay Increases Are Voted for Legislators and Judges
description: ALBANY, April 3 The New York State Legislature voted pay increases tonight for legislators, judges and top executive employees as it completed action on major remaining pieces of the state's 197980 budget.

title: Governor in an Uncomrnon Crisis
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 3Trained in engineering and law, Gov. Dick Thornburgh has spent most of his adult life dealing with cold, hard facts.

description: ON a subway platform the other morning, writes Louis Witkin, I saw this old gent flag down an attachcased young man hurrying through the crowd.

description: SHARES of General Public Utilities, the holding company whose subsidiary, the Metropolitan Edison Company, owns the disabled Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania, opened yesterday at 14 after a suspension in trading.

title: Spanning the Bridge Color Gap
description: It is a short step in New York from emergency esthetics. Alarm about whether the city's bridges were falling down has been replaced by concern about their color. Possible disaster has been averted by a $244million Federally assisted rehabilitation plan that will include the repaihting of 186 of the city's 1,336 publicly owned bridges. This effort at protective maintenance has triggered an esthetic debate equaled only by the controversy over the Empire State Building's living color.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Four Eyes on the Ball

title: Eban Reported Invited To Do Cairo Column
description: TEL AVIV, April 3 (UPI)  The editor of the Cairo newspaper Al Ahram has invited former Israeli Foreign Minister Abba Eban to write a regular political column, the Israeli newspaper Maariv reported today.

title: Japin to Let Refugees Settle
description: TOKYO, April 3 (UPI)  Japan will permit up to 500 Indochinese refugees to settle permanently, the Foreign Ministry announced today. The ministry said Japan would continue to ask Vietnam to take appropriate measures to stem the flow of displaced people from the country.

title: A Volume Bulging With Facts on Food
description: Add to the list of books spawned by the bestselling The Book of Lists new book, which lists two titles: The Food Lover's Book of ListsP or The List Lover's List of Foods.

title: Judge Finds Options Fraud
description: WASHINGTON; April 3 (AP)  Two companies and nine individual members of the Pacific Stock Exchange in San Francisco were suspended for 20 days by a Securities and Exchange Commission law judge today on charges of inflating the volume of sales of options in the Houston Oil and Minerals Corporation.

title: 110 Oklahoma U. Players Start Spring Football Drills
description: NORMAN, Okla., April 3 (AP)  The University of Oklahoma opened spring football drills today under weather conditions more suitable for winter.
