description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I enjoyed your article on greens [It's Time for the Eating of the Greens, March 14] and I feel that you may be interested in an old German sandwich called Spring Sandwich, or Frhlingsschnitte, with which I have delighted the natives for almost 40 years. The recipe is:

title: U.S. Will Not Move Now To End Truck Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall said today that the teamsters strike and lockout in the trucking industry had already started to pinch, but added that there was no immediate shortage of critical supplies and that no intervention by the Government was planned at this time.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. DieFledermaus, paraphrase, StraussGodowsky; Cantata, Jesu, Joy of Man's Desiring Bach.

title: Flavors of Easter: Sophisticated Sweets
description: Easter gardens of flowers, sugarfrosted confections, are blossoming forth all over town, with more abundance than usual. In addition to the more customary sources of holiday candies, a number of bakeries are making or decorating their own Easter chocolates, along with the egg, bunny and floraltrimmed cakes they generally prepare. Because of the holiday rush, it is best to place orders for any of these confections as soon as possible.

title: The Answer Isn't Homo Atomicus
description: One of the nuclear scientists merrily spinning the roulette wheel of man's future has reminded us that the human factor is ultimately just as important as all of the fascinating formulas and exciting new technology.

title: Rockets Score Here, 116115
description: Moses Malone, who has matured into the National Basketball Association's premier rebounder, came alive in the second halt last night, and led the Houston Rockets to a 116115 victory over the Knicks at Madison Square Garden.

title: Zulfikar Ali Bhutto: A Dominant Force in Pakistan for Two Decades
description: Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was a strong believer in fate, and for two decades his was intricately entwined with that of his oftenturbulent nation.

title: G.M. Previews FuelSaving Car
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., April 3  The General Motors Corporation introduced its new, fuelefficient, frontwheeldrive Chevrolet Citation here today in the first of a fourday series of previews. Introduction of the Citation, which replaces the Nova, will be followed by showings of a radically redesigned Oldsmobile Omega, Pontiac Phoenix and Buick Skylark.

title: Wisconsin Congressional Vote
description: OSHKOSH, Wis., Wednesday, April 4 Voters in the eastcentral Wisconsin congressional district here went to the polls today in a special election to fill the House vacancy caused by the death last December of William A. Steiger.

title: Film: Zeffirelli's 'The Champ':A Return Match
description: EVEN when it was first made in 1931, with Wallace Beery as the punch-drunk ex-prizefighter and Jackie Cooper as his plucky 7-year-old son, King Vidor's "The Champ" posed problems for the critics, if not for millions of moviegoers. Mordaunt Hall, The New York Times critic of that day, praised the performers while suggesting that the story was a tiny bit sentimental, maybe even simple-minded, for the sophisticated 30's. It might have served in the silent days, Mr. Hall said from the vantage point of the dawn of the talkies.Pretty much the same thing can be said about Franco Zeffirelli's multimillion-dollar updated remake, with Jon Voight as the boxer, Ricky Schroder as his little boy and Faye Dunaway as the former wife and mother who left her family years before to become rich, beautiful, intelligent and famous  the role played by Irene Rich in the original.However, there's not much use in bemoaning the movie's frontal assault on the emotions. Mr. Zeffirelli never aspired to subtlety. To criticize "The Champ" for a lack of sophistication is not to see the film itself. The most offputting thing about such canny, tear-stained movies as "The Champ" is not their navet but their unholy sophistication. These movies don't mean to deal with the world as it really is, but as it should be, a place where there's no pile-up of emotional garbage too big that it can't be washed clean by a good cry. My problem with "The Champ" is that I didn't cry. The garbage accumulated.Walter Newman's modernized screenplay, based on the original story by Frances Marion, is set in Miami, where the Champ and his son, T.J., eke out a cheerfully aimless living at the racetrack, exercising horses. It has been only seven or eight years since the Champ actually was the world's heavyweight champion, but his fall has been so rapid and complete that he apparently can't even get jobs selling sparkplugs on television. When Annie, now happily married to a remarkably understanding gerontologist (Arthur Hill), re-enters the Champ's life and asks for visitation rights, the Champ decides to go back into the ring, which is clearly the wrong thing for a fellow to do if he is an ex-fighter who has headaches.Mr. Voight looks very fit to be the boozing character he's supposed to be. Though it is convincing, his Lower East Side accent, which seems to have been borrowed from Rocky Graziano, has the effect of making his earlier liaison with Miss Dunaway seem highly improbable. Also improbable is the small boy, cleverly impersonated by Mr. Schroder, who has appeared in television commercials. The performance is surprising in the smoothness of its mechanics without being either comic or endearing, as was Tatum O'Neal in "Paper Moon."Miss Dunaway? Most of the time she looks like someone who was en route to Acapulco and was stranded in Newark. At one point, she emcees a fashion show for no good reason except to give her something to do with her fine stature and velvet voice. Late in the film, when she breaks the news of her momhood to the little boy, both he and we feel uncomfortable. The scene is  well  sexy."The Champ," which opens today at Loews Astor Plaza and other theaters, is Mr. Zeffirelli's first made-in-America film, though both his "Romeo and Juliet" and "Brother Son, Sister Moon" were in English. He doesn't play down to the material or understate it. Instead he exalts it. People don't cry in this film, they erupt. Mr. Zeffirelli orchestrates it as if it were "Tosca." The photography is fancily romantic and often sort of pink, like the flamingos at Hialeah, and the music (by Dave Grusin) is so lush it seems to use up all the oxygen. Like too much cologne, it makes breathing difficult."The Champ," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some vulgar language.

title: Chemicals in Fire Debris Peril Children
description: Bottles of toxic chemicals and poisonous pills strewn on the streets after fire damaged a Washington Heights laboratorysupply store fell into the hands of neighborhood children yesterday. City health officials asked parents to warn their children that the chemicals were extremely dangerous.

title: Best Buys
description: CONSUMERS can save considerable amounts of money by buying fresh fruits and vegetables in bulk. New Yorkers are fortunate to have the Hunts Point Terminal Market in the Bronx, where most of the city's greengrocers, restaurants and some supermarkets make their daily produce purchases. Each weekday some 7,500 tons of fruits and vegetables from around the world go through the market, where 50pound bags of onions or potatoes, crates of oranges and apples and bushels of beans are about the minimum sizes available.

title: Hoffa's Teamster Local Isn't Angry  Yet
description: DETROIT, April 3  For the men of James R. Hoffa's old local who are standing on the picket line here, the lockout is not welcome, but it's not the end of the world, either.

title: A Cheerful Begin, Back in Israel, Tells of Agreements With Sadat
description: JERUSALEM, April 3  Returning to Israel in an ebullient mood, Prime Minister Menachem Begin declared that his trip to Cairo had been a success and that he and President Anwar elSadat had reached very important agreements.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Studies on the Pill Downgrade Link To Heart Attacks
description: THREE new reports further complicate the question of how the use of oral contraceptives may affect a woman's risk of suffering a heart attack.

title: The Region
description: Milk Strikers Refuse Binding Arbitration

title: Officials Abroad Indicate Nuclear Plants Will Stay
description: LONDON, April 3  The nuclear accident in Pennsylvania has prompted expressions of concern around the world, but energy officials in the Soviet Union and elsewhere indicated today that, while precautions might be increased, nuclear power programs would go forward.

title: Issue and Debate City's RentStabilization Law Faces Crucial Test Today
description: Should rent increases in rentstabilized apartments be larger than they are, as owners say, or smaller, as tenants say?

title: U.S. Agencies Urge Rise In Rates for Small Savers
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  The agencies that regulate the nation's financial institutions today proposed a bonus savings account and a new fiveyear, floatingrate certificate. Both innovations are aimed at giving the small saver a better chance of sharing in the present high interest rates.

title: News Summary
description: Nuclear Plant

title: Business Records
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 3, 1979

title: Umpires to Picket at Reds Game
description: Between 15 and 20 major league umpires are expected to be on picket duty in Cincinnati when the 1979 baseball season opens today.

title: Queens Psychologist Arrested in His Home On DrugSale Charge
description: A prominent Queens psychologist, who once served as a consultant to both the New York State Supreme Court and the Great Neck, L.I., school system, was arrested at his Jamaica Estates apartment last night after he allegedly sold a $2,500 ounce of cocaine to an undercover narcotics agent.

title: New of the Theater
description: IRENE WORTH is a believer. They say that if you want a thing badly enough, you'll get it, she said, her rich, regal voice resounding over the phone. One of the many things she has wanted, she said, is to appear on stage in Samuel Beckett's Happy Days. She will get her chance,next month at the Public Theater. Opening night is May 15.

title: Disastrous Drought and Central Planning by the Vientiane Regime Have Produced Scarcity, Stagnant Lives and Economic Chaos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 31  Dedicated to the creation of a centrally planned Communist economy and plagued by a disastrous drought in 1977 followed by equally catastrophic flooding last year, Laos remains among the world's poorest countries.

title: Italian Reds, in Uneasy Truce, End Parley
description: ROME, April 3  The Italian Communist Party ended a national congress today with an uneasy compromise between a proSoviet wing that seemed to have made headway lately with the rank and file and a wellentrenched leadership group that is advocating a measure of autonomy from Moscow.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE dangers of a disaster at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant have apparently eased. Nevertheless, this most serious and dramatic accident of the atomic age threatens to have lasting effects on America's energy supplies and on the national economy.

title: A Bounty of Rice in Asth, Stubborn Poverty in Laos
description: MANILA, April 3  Dramatic increases in rice production, aided by five years of mostly favorable weather, have produced a rice glut in most of Asia, where many food experts in the early 1970's were forecasting chronic shortages.

title: Bid to Buy Hudson's Bay Fought
description: TORONTO, April 3  A 50,000-member organization representing smallbusiness men in Canada called on the Government today to begin a formal investigation of a $40.ashare offer for control of the Hudson's Bay Company department store chain.

title: Hearings on Two Nuclear Plants Proposed for Long Island Are Suspended Indefinitely
description: Hearings on the Long Island Lighting Company's request to build two nuclear generating plants in Jamesport, L.I., have been suspended indefinitely by the State Site Selection Board's chief examiner. An official of the Public Service Commission cited the nuclear accident near Middletown, Pa., as one of several masons for the decision.

title: Carter Reelection Unit Has Raised Enough to Obtain Matching Funds
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 President carter's reelection committee has already raised enough money to qualify for Federal matching grants for the 1980 primary campaign and hoes to finish its fundraising chores tbls year to leave 1980 free for undistracted politicking, Evan S. Dobelle chairman of the committee, said today.

title: Britain Will Repay Last of I.M.F. Loan
description: LONDON, April 3 (AP)  Britain's gold and foreigncurrency reserves have reached a record level, the Treasury said today, and the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Denis Healey, announced that Britain would, repay the last $1 billion of its loan from the International Monetary Fund.

title: Sports Today
description: New Jersey Gems vs. New York Stars, Women's Professional League, at Thomas Dunn Center, Elizabeth, N.J., 8 P.M. Nets vs. Spurs, at San Antonio. (Television Channel 9, 10 P.M., delayed broadcast.)

title: Spaniards Vote in Local Elections, With Left Favored in the Big Cities
description: MADRID, Wednesday, April 4  Socialists, Communists and regional parties were running strong in large cities early this morning as votecounting continued from yesterday's landmark municipal elections  the first free voting for city council members and mayors in 46 years.

title: Miss Lieberman Chosen For PanAm Games Team
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn, (AP)  Nancy Lieberman of Old Dominion University heads the women's basketball team, announced today at the University of Tennessee, for the PanAmerican Games.

title: Dutch Defensive Star Is Signed by Cosmos
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 3 The Cosmos announced the acquisition today of another talented European soccer player, Wilhelmus Rijsbergen, an outstanding defensive performer for the Dutch team in the World Cup tournaments of 1974 and 1978.

title: KLM Plans To Order 10 Airbuses
description: AMSTERDAM, April 3 (AP)  KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, the Dutch national airline, announced today that it would buy 10 A310 Airbus jetliners and take options on 10 others. The deal is valued at about $500 million.

title: Senate Panel Begins Effort to Revise Carter Budget
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  The Senate Budget Committee began its annual effort to rewrite the President's budget today and, although committed to a new speed record, promptly sank in a sea of talk.

title: Plane Fares Will Rise By 7% on Most Flights To and From the U.S.
description: GENEVA, April 3  Travelers on most major International airlines will have to pay 7 percent more on flights to and from the United States beginning May 1 under an agreement reached by the airlines today. The increase is subject to approval of the governments concerned.

title: U.S. May Use Modified U2 to Monitor Soviet Tests
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  The Carter Administration plans to try to compensate for the loss of two American electronic listening posts in northern Iran by using a modified version of the U2 spy plane to monitor missile tests in the Soviet Union, officials said today.

title: RADIATION MEDICINE WAS FLOWN TO AREA
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  It was late last Saturday night, and an Air Force C130 jet transport was revving its engines on the windswept runway at Scott Air Force Base in Bellville, Ill. Soon had loaded an unusual chemical cargo, concocted hastily at a nearby laboratory, and was airborne for Harrisburg. Pa.

title: C.I.A. IN CONTROVERSY OVER POLYGRAPH USE
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  A controversy has arisen within the Central Intelligence Agency over the use of polygraph tests to establish employee reliability since the Director of Central Intelligence, Adm. Stanfield Turner, waived standard procedures in two hiring cases, Carter Administration officials said today.

title: Breaking the Nuclear Fever
description: Scientists appear to have broken the fever at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant. The temperature of the damaged nuclear reactor continues to fall and a cold shutdown seems in sight. But already, a different kind of fever is evident. Some people worry that the plant may be so contaminated that it must be abandoned. Plenty of protest groups and politicians are ready to bury not just one plant but all nucleargenerated electricity.

title: Virginia Electric Bonds Sell Fast at 10.30% Yield
description: The Virginia Electric and Power Company sold $100 million in bonds yesterday in a financing that was regarded as the first major test in the credit markets of the impact of the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania last week.

title: Carey Signs Bill to Aid Convention Hall Plan
description: ALBANY, April 3  Governor Carey today signed a bill providing for state assistance for the construction of a $375 million Convention and Exhibition Center in New York City.

title: Issues in Walkout by Teamsters
description: Parties: About 1,100 American trucking companies are covered by the national Master Freight Agreement. The industry is represented in the negotiations by Trucking Management Inc.

title: Ormandy: Reliable, Faithful Virtuoso
description: EUGENE ORMANDY has been the last of the Americanbased conductors who haves dedi- cated their lives to a single or- chestra. In the old days there were mu- sicians like Frederick Stock in Chicago,

title: Chess
description: Boris Spassky, the former world champion, has been recognized as one of the most determined upholders of classical play, yet there are times when he permits himself to depart from the severity of the orthodox.

title: Notes on People
description: Most everyone thought it was all very British, down to yesterday's dreadful weather, which only Jean Marsh liked because it made her feel at home. No finer ambiance could there. have been for the rechristening of the Billy Rose Theater on West 41st Street, which from now on is the Trafalgar Theater, a name that its new owners hope will appeal to Americans who have fond thoughts of the London square or the 1805 battle it was named after.

title: Situation Comedy Still Most Popular TV Staple
description: In show business, comedy has always been king, but in television these days it is also the ace.

title: China Delays Signing Settlement Of Money Claim Made With U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  China has withheld its, final approval of an agreement made last month on American monetary claims against it, thus holding up other steps in normalizing relations with the United States.

title: For Iacocca, $1.5 Million In Bonus, $360,000 Salary
description: DETROIT, April 3  Lee A. Iacocca is being paid a $1.5 million cash bonus for joining the Chrysler Corporation, as well as a base pay of $30,000 a month for his services as president and chief operating officer, the company's proxy statement to shareholders disclosed today. He also received an option to purchase 400,000 shares of Chrysler common stock at $11.07 per share. The stock closed today at 10, up .

title: GORDON PARKS JR., FILM MAKER, DEAD
description: Gordon Parks Jr., a film maker who directed the controversial Super Fly, one of the most artistically and financially successful blackoriented films of the early 70's, died with three other men yesterday when their small private plane crashed on takeoff from Wilson Airport on the outskirts of Nairobi, Kenya.

title: When Nuclear Crisis Imitates a Film
description: LOS ANGELES, April 3  The boxoffice grosses of The China Syndrome last weekendthe third weekend of its national run  were more than $5 million. Instead of the anticipated third weekend drop, ticket sales per theater averaged $3,200, almost as high as the opening weekend's $3,400. The movie about a possible meltdown in a nuclear power plant  which the Harrisburg, Pa., accident has eerily and macabrely imitated  is the biggest nonholiday film in Columbia's history. Although it was successful at the box office from the start, it is obvious that the accident at Three Mile Island has stimulated extra interest in moviegoers.

title: Pact on Storing Nuclear Wastes Denied by Carey
description: ALBANY, April 3 Governor Carey denied today that any agreement had been struck between the state and the Federal Government on the storage of nuclear wastes at West Valley, N.Y., or on the eventual cleanup of the highly radioactive waste material there. His statement directly contradicted one made by his Energy Commissioner, James L. Larocca, two weeks ago.

title: WASHINGTON The Politics Of Fear
description: WASHINGTON  President Carter is now facing three fundamental issues that will test his fragile relations with Congress. These are the control of strategic military arms, the develop.. ment of a longrange energy policy and, as part of this, the production of atomic energy as a source of domestic industrial power.

title: Suit by Bustop Shelter Against Comptroller Thrown Out by Judge
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday threw out an $800 million damage suit that had been filed by Bustop Shelters Inc. against City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Recently in a restaurant in New Orleans, we dined on pompano en papillote. What is the precise meaning of that term?

title: House Unit Bars Wage Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) President Carter's plan for real wage insurance  a key part of his antiinflation fight  was dealt a severe blow today when the House Budget Committee voted to delete $2.5 billion earmarked for it from next year's budget.

title: Sidney Lovett, Yak ExChaplain
description: The Rev. Sidney Lovett, chaplain emeritus at Yale University, died yesterday at the YaleNew Haven Hospital following surgery. He was 89 years old, and lived in New Haven and Holderness, N.H.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Linkage Revisited
description: WASHINGTON  Asked his opinion of the diplomacy of Lloyd George in the years crowded with summit conferences that followed the First World War, Lord Grey of Fallodon said: Both too much limelight and too

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Mathieu. Expected To Head Korvettes

title: Swedes Shun Norse Adage, Ban Spanking
description: STOCKHOLM, March 28  Odin, the Norse god of war and wisdom, said it clearly enough in the Havamal, an ancient northcountry collection of Talmudicstyle admonition and Contucianstyle advice: He who goes without corporal punishment will go lawless and die without honor.

title: Magazines Battling For Checkout Racks
description: At Sloan's Supermarket on Avenue of the Americas near 13th Street, the line at the checkout lane was moving sluggishly. As the shoppers waited and chafed, they picked over a sizable library of periodicals in the rack at the checkout counter: TV Guide, Family Circle, Reader's Digest, Time, Good Housekeeping, Newsweek, Redbook, Soap Opera Digest, McCall's, People, Us, Life, Look, The National Star, The National Enquirer and even Playboy and Penthouse. Many of the shoppers tossed one or another of the offerings into their carts.

title: Personal Health
description: You will live long and enjoy life. IKNOW full well that this paper prophecy, which I found in a fortune cookie the other day, comes with no moneyback guarantee for a good or long life. But while many people are content to accept whatever fate life may have in store, in the 15 years I have been a medical and science writer, I have come to believe that I can and should adopt reasonable measures to help preserve my health and prolong my life.

title: Letter: On Hospital Costs
description: To the Editor: Why should hospitals be singled out for mandatory controls when Presi dent Carter rejects them for the rest of the economy? The reason, says the President, is that the law of supply and demand does not work in the medical market place. (Editorial March 13)

title: Wait Till Last Year
description: Unless rain produces some miraculous recoveries, there is apt to be an unusually large number of people whose grandmothers fall mortally Ill this afternoon. is the opening day of the 1979 baseball season at Yankee Stadium and a lot of people will be out to see if the day can possibly match last year's.

title: Electricity Is Restored, Ending Blackout in Boston's Back Bay
description: BOSTON, April 4 (AP)  Boston Edison crews restored power to a 12block area in the city's Back Bay section today, ending an intermittent, threeday blackout that left up to 30,000 residents without Dower.

title: Leasing Keeps Boating Afloat
description: LOS ANGELES, April  There are two days when a boat owner is said to be happiest: the day he buys and the day he sells.As boats become more expensive, maintenance costs rise, and slip and docking facilities become more limited, many of America's 53 million recreational boaters are trying to avoid the boat owner's rut.

title: 2 ExOfficm Convicted In Houston Slaying Case
description: HOUSTON, April 4 (AP)  Two former Houston policemen were convicted today of planting a gun on the body of a 17yearold Shreveport, La., youth and later lying to a grand jury investigating the fatal shooting of the teenager. A third officer was acuuitted.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: WE ought to come away from reading Jonathan Kwitny's latest book in, a state of shock and loathing. After all, Vicious Circles: The Mafia in the Marketplace presents a hellish view of American society.

title: Albany Leaders Unable to Settle Budget Impasse
description: ALBANY, April 4  Legislative leaders failed tonight to resolve the impasse that has left. New York State without budget foi four days as the Republicancontrolled State Senate met briefly and adjourned until tomorrow morning. The Assembly, which is controlled by the Democrats, followed suit a short time later.

title: EDGAR BUCHANAN, ACTOR, 76, IS DEAD
description: Edgar Buchanan, the actor, died yesterday at Eisenhower Medical Center in Palm Desert, Calif., two months after undergoing brain surgery. He was 76 years old.

title: Snow Greets Reorganized Mets
description: CHICAGO, April 4  The New York Mets, radically changed with 10 newcomers on their 25man club, worked out briefly in cold Wrigley Field today and braced to open the baseball season with one overriding goal: to escape a third straight year in last place.

title: Ban on Construction Divides Jersey Pine Barrens
description: CHATSWORTH, N.J.  This rustic village in the heart of New Jersey's million acres of pinelands is suddenly divided, like most of the other settlements in the sandy pineclad Barrens, into three camps  for, against and don't know.

title: CORRECTION
description: in an article in The Living Section yesterday about Easter confections, the address for Just Desserts was incorrect. The shop is at 443 East 75th Strat.

title: Backgammon:
description: The fourth Big Apple Backgammon Champion. ship, sponsored by the Metropolitan Backgammon Association, was held in New York last week. Dr. Robert Hill defeated Lou Tyrell to take first place in the championship division; Mike Valentine and Julian Zissman were semifinalists. Alphonse Mekalainas won the consolation; Ray Sawchak beat Andy Treskin for the intermediate.

title: S.E.C. Drops Annuity Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  The Securities and Exchange Commission decided today to withdraw a proposal that would have required insurance companies to register certain annuity contracts that the agency contends are securities.

title: OneYear Treasury Bills Greeted by Lower Rates
description: The Treasury, continuing to catch up on borrowing postponed by the debate over raising the temporary debt ceiling, sold $3.34 billion of oneyear bills yesterday at an average discount rate of 9.23 percent, the lowest rate for such securities since last October.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, April 4 (Reuters)  The captain and crew of a ship that brought 2,318 Vietnamese refugees to the Philippines face up to 10 years in jail if convicted on charges of violating immigration laws, the Manila prosecutor's office said today.

title: Consumer Leaders Urge Beefless Wednesdays to Fight High Prices
description: Declaring that the price of supermarket beef had gone out of control, the leaders of consumeraffairs agencies in the metropolitan New York region called on buyers yesterday to start an immediate onedayaweek beef boycott.

title: Advertising
description: TELEVISION advertising, despite the feeling you might have gotten, does not automatically insure great gains in sales, as Robert Gutwillig, editor and president of the new Look maeazine. has discovered.

title: Penn State Is Placed On Year's Probation
description: While Old Dominion was still waiting to hear about its appeal, Penn State was placed on a oneyear, nopenalty probation by the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women yesterday for illegal recruiting in its women's basketball program.

title: S. African Runners Use Ploy
description: Five runners from South Africa, whose athletes are barred from competing in United States amateur competition, have entered the Boston Marathon by claiming they are American or Rhodesian.

title: A Thoroughly Modern Milieu: Simply Classic
description: AT first glance, you think you've seen it all before  bare white walls, classic cane and wood chairs, bleached floors, plump pillows, white plastic laminate table tops, subdued lighting. And indeed you might have. These furnishings are by now a familiar part of the contemporary design vocabulary.

title: Deaths
description: DRUSIN  David, Beloved husband of Gladys, loving father of Lewis and Ronald Drusin, and Diane Linshaw, dear brother of Leon, Arnold and Ralph Drusin and Sylvia Rogers, cherished grandfather of Charles and Andrew Linshaw. Services Friday 10AM at Garlick's 1091 Yonkers Ave, Yonkers NY. In lieu of flowers contribution to New York Hospital, 525 E 6851, NYC.

title: Red Sox Pitcher May Be Next Baseball Millionaire
description: BOSTON, April 4 (UPI)  Dennis Eckersley took a step toward becoming baseball's latest millionaire today by agreeing in principle to a fiveyear contract extension that his agent said would make him one of the top 10 salaried players in the game.

title: Design Notebook
description: NEW YORK is always being taken apart, as everybody knows. Sometimes it seems as if the house opposite has been pulled down in about as much time as it takes us to sneeze. Gone forever, except in the collections of the NewYork Historical Society, is the neat and ordered look that captivated the 19thcentury engraver.

title: Letters
description: Tables and Tools

title: ATOM MISHAP CALLED PRODUCT OF ERRORS, HUMAN AND MACHINE
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  Federal safety investigators said today that serious human, mechanical and design errors, including an operator's improper closing of two key valves, had contributed to the worst accident in the history of the nation's commercial use of nuclear power.

title: Deaths
description: KRAMER  Sam died March 29, 1979, in his 79th year. Beloved husband of Rhoda. Father of the late Renee. Gross. Loving grandfather & greetgrandfather. Private services were held.

title: 10 Years Given In Fraud Case
description: A 10year prison sentence was imposed yesterday on John DeLyra, a convicted swindler, who was described by the Government as the mastermind of a nationwide scheme that bilked victims of almost $1 million in advance fees for financial assistance that was never delivered.

title: A Marriage Carved In Design
description: ROMANCE was the last thing on Margee Gardner's mind as she trudged along West Houston Street carrying her broken Victorian mirror. Miss Gardner, an intenor designer who owns Nonpareil, an antiques store at 207 Sullivan Street, was on her way to the shop of Hector Olszewski, a wood carver who also restores antiques.

title: Shift Confirmed By Korvettes
description: A spokesman for the AgacheWillot Group, the French company that has acquired control of the Korvettes discountstore chain, confirmed yesterday that Alain Mathieu had been appointed chairman of Korvettes and that David Brous had resigned as president.

title: About New York
description: With time, the hooker had become grandmotherly gray and the junkie had become state director of something called substance abuse when they met on East 116th Street the other morning.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: LADY IN. THE DARK The dramatic lure of Strindberg's Miss Julie (1880) Seems undimmed by time. The Swedish playwright's study of a young aristocrat enslaved and doomed by passion. remains one of the world's bestknown short plays. A musical version by'Ned Rorem, with a libretto by Kenward Elmslie, was presented by the New York City Opera in 1965. Starting tonight, a streamlined Miss Julie is being given its first New York revival by the New York Lyric Opera Company.

title: Stage: Sada Thompson In The Matchmaker
description: IIARTFORD, April 4  Dolly Gallagher Levi is, as Horace Vandergelder describes her, a damned exasperating woman. An inveterate busybody and manager of o'her people's affairs, she storms through Thornton Wilder's The Matchmaker like Hurricane Dolly, leaving in her wake good will and a glow of optimism.

title: Three Rob Financial District Bank Of $335,600, a Record Cash Theft
description: Three men wearing ski masks robbed Bank of New York branch in the financial district of $335,600 early yesterday, just 10 minutes after a large cash shipment was delivered to the bank at 90 Washington Street by the Purolator Inc. armoredcar company.

title: Art: Chardin Exhibition at Grand Palms
description: TWO fine retrospectives dominate the Paris art season, both rewarded by critical acclaim and popular success: Rend Magritte, the Belgian surrealist, at the Centre Georges Pompidou until next.

title: U.S. Will Test SameDay Mail
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  The United States. Postal Service has approved on a trial basis a new sameday delivery service in Chicago, Columbus, Ohio, and Gulfport, Miss.

title: CHARLES M. SIEGFRIED
description: Charles M. Siegfried, a lawyer, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan at the age of 74. He was the senior member of the law firm of Siegfried & Siegfried in New York, which he established in 1945.

title: United Press International
description: TWOPOINT BASKET: Cavaliers Austin Carr putting layup through hoop during the first period of game at Indianapolis. Article and other N.B.A. stories, page D19.SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 4 (AP) San Antonio clinched a tie for the National Basketball Association's Central Division title tonight at the expense of the New Jersey Nets as George Gervin poured in 30 points to pace the Spurs to a 110103 victory.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: JERUSALEM, April 4  Something happened in Cairo, a member of the Knesset said. Begin is euphoric; and he is not just performing. The mood has changed. It is not a grudging peace any longer.

title: Andrew Young Has Hip Surgery
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 4 Andrew Young, the United States chief delegate here, underwent an hourlong operation today to drain an infected hip and is expected to be hospitalized for two to three weeks, a spokesman for the American delegation said tonight.

title: Sullivan Official Pleads Guilty
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., April 4 (AP) Sullivan County's former probation director pleaded guilty today to selling 10 pounds of marijuana for $3,800 in the county office building. Alan Greenfield. who was suspended from his $15,500ayear post when he was charged last October, could be sentenced to a maximum of seven years in prison, and fined $5.000. However, the judge indicated he might not send Mr. Greenfield to prison.

title: Stake for,Mitsubishi In Chrysler Australia
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, April 4 (Reuters)  The Mitsubishi Group of Japan will pay $27 million for a stake of a little more than onethird in the Chrysler Corporation's Australian operations, the American company said today.

title: Report Recommends Construction of 8 More Nuclear Plants in New York
description: The New York State Power Pool, made up of virtually all suppliers of electricity in the state, has said the state should build eight more nuclear power plants to meet future generating needs despite the incident at the Three Mile River plant near Middletown. Pa.

title: U.S. Reports Modest Revival for Marriage
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  Marriage staged a modest comeback and divorce rates continued to level off. After a small rise in fertility in 1977, women were back to not having babies in 1978. Infant mortality dropped some more.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of metals futures rebounded sharply yesterday on Government warnings that inflation would soon worsen, largely because of its plans to decontrol oil prices.

title: State Mutual Plans Stock Sale and Offer
description: State Mutual Investors said it planned to sell 2.8 million of its common shares to interests affiliated with Samuel Belzberg, a Vancouver, British Columbia, financier, for $14 million in cash and real estate.

title: 28 Food Establishments Are Cited for Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 28 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code. The department also named 13 restaurants that had corrected earlier violations and three that had rech. pened after correcting their earlier violations.

title: Now, Oil Decontrol
description: WASHINGTON  Once more, the sledgehammer of price is about to be used on the consumer as the solution to our energy problems. And once more the oit industry is playing out a charade with confused statistics, contrived shortages and promises of fantastic supply increases. Schlesinger has used the Iranian situation to justify his contention that we have a shortage.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allied Van Linea Inc., Chicago, announced that Jack E. Schang had resigned as president and chief operating officer, and that Donald J. Storseth, chairman, was assuming the operational responsibilities for the company while a replacement was selected.

title: Mariners 5, Angels 4
description: SEATTLE, April 4 (UPI)  Leon Roberts snapped a 33 tie with a tworun homer in the sixth inning tonight to give the Seattle Mariners a 54 victory over the California Angels in the American League opener.

title: Illegal Alien Is Seized On Green Card Sales Of $100,000 a Month
description: An illegal alien from Trinidad who the police said made more than $100,000 a month selling United States residency cards to other illegal aliens living in New York City was arrested yesterday in Brooklyn.

title: Bhutto: A Tragic Figure Overwhelmed by His Ambitions
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 At the pinnacle of his power, Zulfikar All Bhutto blended the style of shrewd politician, cunning ruler and theatrical showman. He dragged Pakistan from despair to a brief moment of confidence and hope, and yet Mr. Bhutto's soaring ambitions for himself and his country finally overwhelmed him.

title: Inmate Charged in Jail Fire
description: DAYTON, Ohio, April 4 (AP)  A 20yearold inmate, Roderick Trice, has been charged with aggravated arson in Monday's fire at the Dayton Safety Building. The police said that he had set fire to his padded cell with a book of matches. Twentyfive people are still hospitalized with injuries suffered in the blaze, offi cials said today.

title: March 2131 Auto Sales Down 1.2%
description: DETROIT, April 4  Sales of United Statesmade new cars in the final 10 days of March slipped 1.2 percent below the yearearlier level, the four major domestic automobile manufacturpra Said today.

title: Hongisto Fields Tough Questions By Albany Panel
description: ALBANY, April 4  The Senate Cornmittee on Crime and Corrections opened its hearings today on the nomination of Richard D. Hongisto, Governor Carey's choice for State Corrections Commissioner. Republicans asked hostile questions centering on the Commissioner's controversial past as sheriff of San Francisco.

title: Neighbor Held as Phone Tapper Wb6se Calls Costa Bank $8,000
description: The superintendent of a building on Manhattan's upper West Side was adcused yesterday of tapping into the telephonefline, of a nearby bank and running up a dill of more than $8,000 by allowing neighbors to make longdistance calls.

title: The Region
description: Guilty Pleas Made In Medicaid Case

title: U.S. Officials Outline Benefits in Trade Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  Administration officials, offering the first rough calculations of the benefits from a new tradeliberalization pact, told a Senate hearing that major new export opportunities would open up while job losses from higher imports would be minimal.

title: Yes, There Is an Oil Shortage
description: When the President steps before the cameras tonight to tell what serious steps he intends to take on energy, his biggest obstacle will be the question that lingers in many minds: Is there really an oil shortage? By word and deed, Americans continue to express their doubts. In a recent poll, only 20 percent believed there is a shortage. And, as if to show their contempt for Government exhortations fo conserve, motorists have gone on a driving jag.

title: House Panel Rejects a Carter Program for Aid to Cities
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  The House Budget Committee chopped a $1.5 billion chunk out of President Carter's 1980 spending program today, denying the White House virtually all the money it had requested for a program of urban development grants and loans.

title: Calendar of Events: Spring in the Air
description: Flower Show, Macy's Herald Square.

title: Plant Witch Hazel In the Early Spring
description: Witch hazel is more than a good foot rub for tired joggers feet. It's a way to extend the flowering season of your garden past the early frosts of fall you start by planting in spring. Plant Witch Hazel In the Early Spring

title: Dance: Irish Ballet Troupe Does Playboy of the Western World
description: THE Irish Ballet Company from Cork, founded in 1973 by the Irish choreographer, Joan Denise Moriarty, as an outgrowth of her attempts since 1947 to establish a national ballet troupe, made its American debut last night at the City Center 55th Street Theater. very appropriately !Or Its Irish image, it came with Miss Moriarty's dance version of a play that has been classic of her country's dramatic literature  John Millington Synge's The Playboy of the Western World and with music composed and played by a wonderful folk group, The Chieftains.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Fairy Tale for Violin and Piano in E minor, Medtner; Toy Symphony, Mozart (attrib. to Haydn.); Gigue, Damase; Pe Loc, Bartok.

title: carter Officials Assert Bill in House Violates Panama Canal Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  High Carter Administration officials said today that a bill approved by a House committee would violate both the letter and the spirit of the treaty under which the Panama Canal is to be turned over to Panamanian control by the year 2000. used discreet language before the House Foreign Affairs Committee in an obvious effort to avoid offense to Representative John M. Murphy, Democrat of Staten Island, author of the bill approved yesterday by the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, which he heads.

title: Deaths
description: SLUTSKIN  Barney On Apr. 4, 1919. beloved husband of Edith, loving father of Barry, Diane and Karen, adored grandfather of Adam, Lisa and Jeremy. Brother of Anna Rubin, Arthur and Sonny Gllck. Funeral today at 9:15, Gutterman's. Rockville Center, NY.

title: United Press International
description: BASEBALL SEASON BEGINS: Paul Pryor, one of only two major league umpires not on strike, at game in Cincinnati in which the Giants beat the Reds, 115. In the American League opener, Seattle beat California, 54. Page D17.

title: Man Denies Guilt in Fatal Fire
description: BOSTON, April 4 (UPI)  An unemployed dishwasher charged with setting fires at two of the city's largest hotels pleaded not guilty today to murder in the death of a woman guest. The dishwasher, Julio Valentin Rodrigues, was charged with seconddegree murder yesterday, hours after Patrica Mulcahey, 28 years old, of Boston, died at 4:35 A.M. at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital.

title: South and West Joining Forces in Hope of Outvoting the Northeast in Congress
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 30 After President Carter announced his standby gasoline rationing plan, the National. Econorriic Research Institute described it as not rationing at all, but an income transfer program which moves money from the $outh to the North.

title: Yeichi Nimura, Dancer, Choreographer, Teacher
description: Yeichi Nimura, darcer, choreographer, teacher and founder of New York's Ballet. Arts School, died Tuesday in New York. He was 82 vears old.

title: Rock.. British Police Trio
description: THE Police, who opened a twonight run at the Bottom Line on Tuesday, are the best British newwave rock band to play in this city in a long time; certainly within the last five days. This is a trio consisting of Stewart Copeland, drums (an American who organized the band); Andy Summers, guitar, and Sting, bass and lead vocals (Sting's original name was Gordon Sumners).

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M., (Television  Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio WINS, 2 P.M.)

title: The Bee Gees Will Star In a Special on NBCTV
description: The rock music group the Bee Gees will star in a 90minute television special on NBCTV next season. Although the British group has appeared on television shows before, this is the first time in the United States that the trio will have its own television special, NBC officials said.

title: Suit Spurring Mississippi Efforts To Teach Handicapped Children
description: MADISON COUNTY, Miss.  Eddie is a cheerful 12yearold, affectionate and quick to smile, who lives with his mother and seven of his nine brothers and sisters in a tinroof shack on the edge of a cotton field. lie spends his days in the dilapidated fourroom house, hearing and saying nothing because he is deaf and does not speak. He is also believed to be mentally retarded. Eddie has never been to school.

title: Right to Life Party's Gain
description: The New York State Conservative Party, created as a counter to the oncepredominant relative liberalism of the two major parties, now faces its most serious threat not from the left but from the right  the newly formed Right to Life Party.

title: Entertainment Events
description: FAITH HEALER, by Brian Friel, the Longacre Theater. 220 West 48th Street,6:30.

title: Slayer Again Asks Death
description: ATMORE, Ala., April 4  Calling his death the one constructive, positive act in a blasted life,' 29yearold John Louis Evans 3d. today again demanded execution and asked that his final moments in Alabama's bright yellow electric chair be videotaped to show what he termed the barbarity of the death penalty and to teach young offenders the final end to crime.

title: Police Helicopter Patrols To Fight Grave Vandals
description: As a result of recent widespread vandalism at three Jewish cemeteries in New York City, the Police Department announced yesterday that within the next few days it would start a night helicopter patrol aiming powerful lights on cemeteries, particularly on those with a history of troubles, and would also use undercover units.

title: Jersey's Essex County Is.Facing A Revamping of Its Government
description: NEWARK, April 4  In the first major revision of Essex County government in 181 years, the County Executive, Peter Shapiro, today formally adopted a new administrative code that will provide the framework for the operation of government for the 900,000 residents of New Jersey's largest political subdivision.

title: Flames Tie Rangers On Goal by Houston
description: With only a few games left to decide the finish of the National Hockey League's regular season, Madison Square Garden fans are getting nasty. While the Rangers and Atlanta Flames battled to a 33 tie last night, clusters of fans yelled obscenities at the referee, threw debris and toilet paper on the ice and generally disrupted the game.

title: Fleming Defeats Mottram, Gains in Rotterdam Tennis
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 4 (AP)  Peter Fleming of the United States advanced to the third round of a $175,000 World Championship Tennis tournament today, beating Buster Mottram of Britain. 6.3.64.

title: Schaefer Upheld In Schmidt Case
description: The F. & M. Schaefer Corporation said the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit had unanimously affirmed the issuance of a preliminary injunction that prevents C. Schmidt & Sons Inc. from purchasing notes that are convertible into Schaefer's stock. Both concerns are brewers.

title: At Disaster Center, Balloons and Boredom
description: HERSHEY, Pa., April 4  The smell hanging heavy in the air is chocolate, not fear. The adults who sought shelter here from the Three Mile Island nuclear plant aren't even certain they have been part of something awful and children only know a disaster when they've felt one.

title: Accident Cools Down Campaign In Austin on Atomic Plant Bonds
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 9  As news filtered in of the crisis at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant near Harrisburg, Pa., pronuclear spokesmen found it more difficult to reel off reasons why voters here should agree to remain part of the largest nuclear project planned for Texas.

title: Market Place
description: WRILE antiques, diamonds and even old comic books are selling at premium prices, one major investment resource remains that appears to be underpricedcommon stocks.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanee.

title: Mexican, Indonesian Oil Up
description: Mexico and Indonesia raised the prices of their crude oil exports yesterday by more than the 9 percent increase approved by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries last week.

title: TV: Duke,  A Series On Boxer
description: THE Duke, a limited run series about a prizefighter who becomes a private eye, starts with a twohour opener on NBCTV tonight at 9:30, and the viewer may well want to throw in the towel by the end of the first round. it is not so much that this is not serviceable timekiller for nonreaders; it is that it chokes on its own cliches. Robert Conrad is a likable performer and here is Duke Ramsey, a boxer who has just lost what proves to be his last fight, going down just as robbers are stealing the night's gate in the front of the house.

title: ESSAY
description: MONTREAL  On New Year's Eve of 1776, Gen. Benedict Arnold stormed the fortress of Quebec with a force of Americans to drive the British from Canada. He failed. In 1976, separatist Rend Levesque challenged Englishspeaking dominance of the largely Frenchspeaking province with his Quebecer Party. He succeeded.

title: Letters
description: Pitfalls of Bypassing Con Ed

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSLouise May. On April 3. 1979 of East Orange, N.J. Wife of the late Leo. Mother of Mrs. Augusta Groinek, Jay J., Joseph L., Paul J., William F. and the late George 1. Sister of Frederick Hipp and Mrs. Frieda Burnett. Also survived by six grandchildren and one great. grandchild. Funeral service at the Hopping Funeral Home, 145 East Mount Pleasant Avenue, Livingston, NJ on Friday at 11AM. Visit. Ing hours Thursday 24 and 7.9PM.

title: Hanoi Calls on China to Start Talks
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 4  Vietnam called on China today to begin negotiations in Hanoi next week on the restoration of normal relations. It did so without insisting on its earlier condition that all Chinese troops withdraw from Vietnamese territory.

title: Talking Business
description: With the advent of dtente six years ago, business leaders envisioned a boom in AmericanSoviet trade. But after an initial spurt, mainly in American grain exports, volume has in fact declined. Among other political considerations, actions of Congress in denying Moscow favorable tariff and credit treatment and in tying the relaxation of trade restrictions to the easing of Soviet emigration restrictions have barred trade expansion.

title: RUSSELL M. COOK
description: Russell M. Cook, a furnace company executive, died Monday in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. He was 74 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J.

title: 21 Series Picked for PBS
description: Publictelevision stations have made their first pick of the year of programs to be seen on PBS, and among the 21 series totaling 750 hours of viewing time are some older ones that will continue and some new ventures, including one that will teach you disco dancing.

title: Cauthen May Stay In Britain
description: LONDON, April 4  Steve Cauthen, who will make his riding debut in England Saturday at Salisbury, said today that he might finish out his career in Britain.

title: Music: Stahl Conducts
description: DAVID STAHL, a 29yearold conductor who began the study of his craft at Queens College and is now in his third year as an Exxon assistant conductor of the Cincinnati Symphony, was the podium guest of the National Orchestra Association for its concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night. For Mr. Stahl it was something of a homecoming, because he was connected with the association as a conducting student a few years ago. Although the chief purpose of the association is to provide orchestral experience for young instrumentalists, it has also contributed to the development of a number of conductors.

title: INVADERS IN UGANDA CLOSE IN ON CAPITAL
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 4  An invasion aimed at deposing President Idi Amin of Uganda appeared to move into a decisive phase today, with an assault upon his capital of Kampala.

title: Virginia U. Evicts Campus Paper for Defying Student Media Panel
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 4  The staff of The Cavalier Daily, the student newspaper at the University of Virginia, was evicted from its campus offices yesterday after its editors refused to recognize the authority of a studentrun Media Board.

title: GARDENING
description: AFLOWER that will grow just about anywhere does seem an impossible dream, yet one of nature's most beguiling plants  the columbine  comes very close to filling this role.

title: Companies Cope With Truck Halt
description: As the teamster strike and lockout ended their fourth day yesterday, many companies found that advance planning plus the large number of both union and nonunion drivers still on the roads enabled them to carry on at a nearnormal pace.

title: Truck Stoppage Spurring Layoffs By Auto Makers
description: DETROIT, April 4  Automobile industry layoffs attributed to the teamster strike and lockout rose to nearly 50,000 today when the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation shut down plants across the nation and laid off an additional 35,200 workers. By the end of the week, strikerelated unemployment in the industry was expected to exceed 100,000 workers.

title: 'Goodbye, Wall for Democracy'
description: Today marks the third anniversary of the mass demonstration in Peking's Tian An Men Square, which became a symbol of popular discontent with the Maoist regime. Deng Xiaoping, who now appears to be the most powerful figure in China, was blamed for that disturbance and purged. He was rehabilitated in 1977, and last fall, as Deputy  Prime Minister, he presided benevolently over a resurgence of wall posters that attacked his leftist opponents (identified with the disgraced Gang of Four) and called for greater political freedom.

title: Dr. John Krout, Scholar, Author And Columbia U. Vice President
description: Dr. John Allen Krout, vice president emeritus of Columbia University, died Tuesday at Tiffin (Ohio) Mercy Hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: JapanU.S. Energy Pact Set
description: TOKYO, April 4 (UPI)  Japan anc the United States will sign a $1 billior agreement to cooperate in developing new energy sources when Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira visits Washington next month, Government sources said today.

title: A JerusalemCairo Hot Line Has Been Set Up, Begin Informs Parliament
description: JERUSALEM, April 4  Prime Minister Menachem Begin told the Israeli Parliament that a hotline telephone link was opened today between Jerusalem and Cairo to permit instant communications with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt.

title: Carbon Monoxide Kills 2
description: Two people were found dead of carbonmonoxide poisoning in a car parked Tuesday in a Staten Island garage. The police said that one victim was Willy James, 37 years, of 93 Wayne Place. The body of the a second person, a woman, was not immediately identified. They were found in a garage at SO Fillmore Street, with the engine of the car in which they were sitting still running.

title: Bhutto: A Pakistani Force for 2 Decades
description: Photographs by Keystone, Associated Press, Pictorial Parade and Nancy Palmer/Frederic Obringer

title: Soviet Denounces China On Letting Treaty Lapse
description: MOSCOW, April 4 (AP)  The Soviet Union denounced as a hostile action today China's decision to terminate their 1950 friendship treaty.

title: GLENN L. PITZER
description: Glenn L. Pitzer, retired president of Union Carbide's former Plastic Products Division, died yesterday at Scottsdale Memorial Hospital in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 69 years old.

title: TV: Razzmatzz, With Upbeat Youths
description: RAZZMATAZZ is the kind of project that just can't help scoring brownie points for a broadcaster. In fact, that may be its only purpose.

title: Suspect in .22Caliber Killings Convicted and Sentenced in Ohio
description: MANSFIELD, Ohio, April 4 (AP) Thaddeus Lewingdon was convicted today of committing six murders that prosecutors said were part of a series of slayings in central Ohio last year known as the 22caliber killings.

title: Teamster Strike Seen Continuing
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  The lockout and strike in the nation's trucking industry, now in their fourth day, will probably continue at least into next week, according to a high Carter Administration official who is monitoring the situation closely.

title: Music: Artistry in a Religious Ritual
description: THE ceremonial dhikr performed by Sheikh Muzaffer and 30 HalvetiJerrahi dervishes from Istanbul at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Tuesday evening was not a concert, a dance recital, or a program of therapeutic exercise, although it was something like all of them. It was religious ritual, and one had to wonder about the propriety of reviewing it. But it was cosponsored by the Dia Art Foundation; which has often presented musical evenings that aim to trigger mystical or religious experiences, and one was able to choose whether to enjoy it as a more or less conventional concert spectacle or to participate.

title: U.S. Study of Sleep Drugs Finds Risks and Overuse
description: An expert panel of the National Academy of Sciences reported yesterday that the prescription sleeping pills most widely used in recent years are not as free of hazard as many physicians believe and that there is little evidence that sleeping pills in general are effective when used nightly over long periods.

title: Film: 13 Directors Make 'Germany in Autumn':After the Fall
description: "GERMANY in Autumn," which opens this evening at the Film Forum, is the collective work of 13 German directors and writers who attempt to assess the political state of that country in the autumn of 1977, when Hans-Martin Schleyer, the German industrialist was kidnapped and murdered by terrorists, followed almost immediately by the mysterious deaths in the maximum-security Stuttgart-Stammheim prison of three members of the notorious Baader-Meinhof gang. The state's assertion that the three were suicides was widely ridiculed.Like most joint film efforts of this sort, "Germany in Autumn," a two-hour documentary, is very uneven. It's sometimes startlingly beautiful, often obscure and confusing, sometimes funny and mostly disturbing, as it should be. The film's credits do not identify the authors of individual sequences, though the contribution of Rainer Werner Fassbinder is obvious (he stars in it), as is that of the novelist Heinrich Bll, who wrote a broadly satiric sketch about some television executives who finally decide not to televise Sophocles's "Antigone" because it's "too topical." Among the other contributors are Alexander Kluge and Volker Schlondorff.The film is framed by interments. It opens with the state funeral of Mr. Schleyer and closes with the funerals of the three terrorists, buried in a Stuttgart cemetery with the permission of that city's Mayor, whose father, General Field Marshal Rommel, was himself given an elaborate state funeral by the Nazis after they had forced him to commit suicide."Germany in Autumn" embraces such ironies, freely associating between segments of fact and fiction as it considers the legacy of the country's fascist past and the meaning of its democratic present. Illuminating even the most oblique episodes is a concern with the terrorism that has become the policy of dissent for the ultra-left-wing. Horst Mahler, a former lawyer for the radical opposition, now serving a 14-year prison term, speaks eloquently about the roots of postwar radicalism, though he now disavows terrorism that, he says, has become no different from the ills that prompted the left's original frustration and dissent.Very often the film is beyond the reach of someone not up on contemporary German affairs. It's a movie that needs even more program notes than the extensive ones already provided by the Film Forum. I'd like to have heard more than a snippet of a speech given to a convention of Social Democrats by Max Frisch, in which the Swiss playwright ("The Firebugs") urges Germans to provide the young with some goal other than "cheerful consumerism." A couple of fictional segments intended to satirize the fears and obsessions of the bourgeoisie are simply opaque.Far from opaque is Mr. Fassbinder's aggressively stylish segment, in which Mr. Fassbinders a romantic projection of himself, a radical young film director who finds Germany's middle-class complacency too painful to bear. He rails at his monumentally patient male lover, who supports the state position on terrorism, and bullies his mother until she finally admits (as if to shut him up) that life was in some ways better under a dictatorship. The fictional Rainer drinks like Edgar Allen Poe, takes drugs, cries and films himself in the middle of the night talking distractedly on the telephone, nude.The segment is the most interesting part of the film. It's typically, intentionally disorienting in the Fassbinder way, photographed and acted with such intense self-absorption that it has the effect of transforming narcissism into a higher form of political commitment."Germany in Autumn" will be shown at the Film Forum at 7:45 tonight through Sunday and repeated there next week at the same time Thursday through Sunday.

Now a coalition of abortion foes, led by Senator James Donovan from upstate New York, is employing an unusual tactic in an effort to add the state to the list. We deplore both the maneuver and the objective.

title: Music: Juilliard Quartet Plays Lerdahl
description: THERE seem to be three maim types of composers. One, probably the most common sort, is struck by a musical idea and then looks around for a form in which to cast it. Another, the rigorously intellectual type, works out a form and then tries to find material to fit into it. Yet another sort of composer, such as Mozart, apparently had music bestowed on him like a gift, already wrapped, with form and materials inseparably merged into the whole.

The organist and choirmaster of the United Methodist Church in Port Washington, L.I., played a relatively standard program, but he did so with an admirable mixture of good taste, imagination and excellent technical equipment.

title: Movie Spurs Real Death Scene

Witnesses said that William Dillon Gates, 32 years old, had pointed a 38caliber pistol at his head and pulled the trigger. He was killed instantly. Two other men had taken turns at the game with no bullet's being fired, the police said.

Their victory in the first free Municipal elections  since 1933 appeared to presage moves toward closer collaboration betwee.n the two parties and a sharpening of diVisions in the nation's politics.

Rather, it is said to result from recent settlements Of labor disputes that had affected production in a time of tightdemand.

title: Disks: Singing Along With the Guitar
description: SINGING to the accompaniment of a guitar (or its ancestors) is one of the older traditions in music. It has always existed in rural and urban folk culture, but it is a tradition that has been taken up by classical composers, particularly in our times. This recording is an example of how well the combination of voice and guitar has been used by a number of wellknown and notsowellknown writers in the last 40 years or so. There isn't a dud in the lot.

Add to this the mess and confusion generated by the filming of a major motion Picture.

title: BRZEZINSKI DEFENDS ARMS TREATY IMPACT
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser; said today that a new strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union would provide the needed strategic stability for progress in political relations between our two countries.

title: He Loved to Swim in the Surf
description: He had swum in that surf so often. For years Carroll Rosenbloom had owned an oceanfront home amid the palm trees of Golden Beach, Fla., where millionaires go to relax. When he took over the Los Angeles Rams in 1972 after trading the Baltimore Colts franchise, Carroll Rosenbloom sold his home in Golden Beach and purchased two homes in the Los Angeles area one in Bel Air with gardens and a tennis court, the other on the beach at Malibu where he could swim in the surf. And last week, while vacationing in Florida with his wife, Georgia, the 72yearold Rams owner decided to rent a home in Golden Beach for old time's sake. For him, the surf was like everything else in his life  a challenge to be conquered. Anybody can swim in a pool. But when he went swimming in the surf at Golden Beach last Monday afternoon, the surf won. Trapped by the undertow 75 yards from the beach, Carroll Rosenbloom drowned. Yesterday his body was cremated at a funeral in Hollywood, Fla.,'attended by family and close friends. Next Monday a public service will be held in Los AnReles.

title: Arts Academy Will Induct 14 New Members May 23
description: Barbara Tuchman, president of the American Academy and Institute of, Arts and Letters, said yesterday that 19 new members would be inducted May 23. They are Roy, Lichtenstein, Joan Mitchell and Larry Rivers, painters; John M. Johansen, architect; Tony Smith, sculptor; Joseph Brodsky, Robert Hayden, and John Hollander, poets; Rene Dubos, writer and bacteriologist; Susan Sontag, essayist and novelist; Irving Howe, literary critic and historian; and Henry Brant, Ulysses Kay, and Ned Rorem, composers.

title: Auction Fees Challenged
description: LONDON, April 14  Britain's art and antique dealers have combined to challenge the legality of the 10 percent buyers premiums that Sotheby's and Christie's, the two top auction houses here, have charged since 1975.

title: Tornado Damages Seven Homes

title: Music: Ozawa Leads the Bostonians
description: ARNOLD SCHOENBERG spent a decade on his Gurrelieder, which he finished in 1901 but did not score until 1911. It is a work known more, by reputation than through actual performance. On the face of things, the Gurrelieder should be as popular as Schoenberg's Verkliirte Nacht. It is composed in the lushest PostRomantic idiom, and is full of soaring melodies that often stem right from Wagner (the KlausNarr ana is prime Meistersinger'), and the entire world of the late 19th century is summarized in this huge score.

In a ceremony marking the north Atlantic Treaty Organization's 30th anniversary, Mr. Luns said the West was committed to a policy of dtente, but that dtente without maintaining a credible defense would be foolhardy.

description: WASHINGTON, April 5  For the Administration, the transformation could hardly have been more complete. From his unwavering support for continued oil price controls during the 1976 election campaign, President Carter has now staked out firm ground in the camp of the decontrol forces.

title: Advertising
description: THE marketers of Benedictine, French liqueur for more than 250 years, are turning their back on the older, affluent afterdinner cordial sippers in an attempt to win over the young, swinging, cocktaildrinking set. That's where the action is.

title: Music: Brendel Leads Philharmonic
description: IT was all Viennese classicism at the Philharmonic concert last night. Using a reduced orchestra for the entire program, Zubin Mehta conducted Schubert's Overture in C in the Italian Style and Third Symmphony, and a pair of Mozart piano concertos in E flat (K. 271) and C minor (K. 491). Alfred Brendel was the soloist.

title: Giants and Jets to Return To Monday Night on TV
description: The Jets and Giants have been restored to pro football's weekly showrase, Monday Night Football, which indicates that the National League believes both clubs will have attractive teams next season.

title: Auctions
description: THE recovery of the market in Impressionist and modem paintings, which began slowly 18 months ago, moved into high gear last Monday night at Sotheby Parke Bernet in London, with a recordbreaking auction of 80 paintings. The twopart sale, comprising 18 paintings from the collection of the Sydney R. Barlows of Beverly Hills, Calif., and 62 from other owners, rewrote the record for a painting sale with a total of $8.9 million, even though 22 of the paintings did not sell. The previous high, $7.9 million, was established at Christie's in London in 1971.

title: 87 on Airliner in Michigan Survive A Nose Dive Near Speed of Sound
description: ROMULUS, Mich., April 5 (AP)  A Trans World Airlines plane carrying 87 persons survived a harrowing barrel roll and may have exceeded the speed of sound in a nose dive before being brought under control by a freakish maneuver, Federal inspectors said today.

title: Bill Jorgensen to Become Action News CoAnchor
description: Bill Jorgensen, who quit as the anchorman of WNEWTV's 10 P.M. newscast a few weeks ago, has now been hired by WPIXTV as a coanchor with Pat Harper of that station's 10 P.M. Action News  a position in which he will be competing against his old. news program.

title: Topics Sic Transit
description: We shared the subway shuttle the other morning with a hollerer, one of those people with the lungs to make sure the world hears their grievances. She had on her mind and tongue the prevailing crookedness of politicians.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, April 5  The Christian Democratic Party, Italy's strongest political force, pledged today that it would not agree to form a government in alliance with the Communists after coming elections.

title: Bay State Women's Panel Disbanded
description: BOSTON, April 5  Massachusetts is currently without a Governor's Commission on the Status of Women, but it may soon have two such groups. one Of these will be appointed within several weeks by Gov. Edward J. King to replace the 40member commission he disbanded last week. Another will function as a commission in exile, to serve as a reminder, according to a former commission member, that gubernatorial executive orders may remove dissenters from an administration, but not necessarily silence them.

title: Theater: A Comedy By Frisch
description: QUESTIONS of identity, memory and chance have concerned and troubled Max Frisch in his novels as well as in his plays, most particularly in Biography: A Game, which was given its New York premiere last night at the Chelea Theater Center's Westside Theater.

title: In Tanzanian Capital, Little 1$ Heard of War With Uganda
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 5  As a Tanzanianbacked rebel force closed in on Kampala, the capital of Uganda, this ramshackle capital went about its business in its usual orderly, Quiet, matteroffact way.

title: Don't Throw Your Old Suits Away
description: In the press box somebody asked who had been the last man to pitch a nohitter on opening day. There had been only one, the guy was told, Bob Feller. Nobody knew for sure just when that had happened, but there would be time to look it up. It was still only the sixth inning. Well, someone else said, this will be the first by a lefthander. And the first perfect game ever on opening day.

title: Woodstock Turns Down Bid to Hold Rock Festival
description: WOODSTOCK, N.Y., April 5 (UPI) The Ulster County town of Woodstock has turned down a milliondollar offer to hold the 10th anniversary Woodstock Rock Festival.

title: Ford Motors Agrees to $500,000 For Survivors of 3 in Auto Crash
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)  The Ford Motor Company agreed today to pay $500,000 to the families of a budding rock star and two members of his band who were killed in a car crash nine years ago.

title: Alabamian Granted a Supreme Court Stay
description: ATMORE, Ala., April 5  Supreme Court Justice William H. Rehnquist granted a stay tonight in the execution of John Louis Evans 3d, a convicted Alabama murderer who has repeatedly demanded to die.

title: Calendar of Easter Music in Churches and Concert Halls
description: Following is a list of some of the special musical presentations and other events planned for the Easter season at churches and concert halls in the metropolitan area.

title: P.L.O. Official Is Admitted to U.S. For a ThreeWeek Speaking Tour
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has approved the admission to the United States of a prominent official of the Palestine Liberation Organization for a speaking tour.

title: CIA, AIDE DEPLORES DATARELEASE LAW
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)  The Deputy Director of Central Intelligence testified today that his agency was losing valuable information because its domestic and foreign sources feared that their identities would be exposed under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: Knicks End Season By Losing, 114107
description: The Knicks closed out their season of turmoil and disarray last night, losing to the Denver Nuggets, 114107, at Madison Square Garden. It was the eighth straight defeat for the Knicks, their longest losing streak since November 1964.

title: Pol Pot's Main Post Is Said to Fall
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 5  The Hanoi radio announced today that Cambodian forces of President Heng Samrin had overrun the headquarters of former Prime Minister Pol Pot and that Mr. Pol Pot had escaped to Thailand.

title: Resorts Optimistic On Casino Take
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 5 (AP) The Resorts International Hotel Casino could gross more than $130 million in its first year of operation, company officers said today.

title: Drug Ship Tracked by Satellite
description: VICTORIA, British Columbia, April 5 (Reuters)  A boat carrying 13.5 tons of marijuana from Colombia to Canada last year was tracked by satellite, a court here was told by an agent of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration. The agent, Ernest Staples, said yesterday that he helped install tracking devices on the boat in Mexico before it sailed to Colombia. The boat was seized in Vancouver on July 15 and five Canadians were charged with trying to import the drug.

title: Draths
description: SEIDMANIrving, devoted husband of Sylvia. Beloved father of Steven, amd Judith. Loving brother of Louts B., Joseph, and the late Jack. Service today, 2 P.M., The River. side. 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment following at the Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: Screen:Truffaut's Antoine Doinel Looks Back on a Life in Films:Prodigal Returns
description: FRANCOIS TRUFFAUT'S "Love on the Run," which opens today at the Coronet, is the fifth film and, Mr. Truffaut says, the last in his extraordinary Antoine Doinel series that began 20 years ago with "The 400 Blows." Mr. Truffaut said the same thing in 1971 when "Bed and Board," the fourth Doinel film, was released, but this time there's good reason to believe him. There's no place left to go for either Antoine, still played by Jean-Pierre Laud, or for Mr. Truffaut, who has here made a movie that spells a more absolute end than death for a favorite character. The film is also an examination of principles  a unique essay on the methods and purposes of romantic comedy.We've all seen actors over the years deal with age on the screen, some, with the aid of surgery, becoming miraculously more youthful looking while all around them disintegrated. Yet never before have we had the same director, the same actor and the same character evolve, more or less naturally, over such an extended period of time.After "The 400 Blows," which introduced Antoine as the 13-year-old juvenile delinquent, there were the "Colette" sequence from "Love at 20" (1963), in which Antoine courted the spirited Marie-France Pisier but won only the affection of her parents; "Stolen Kisses" (1969), in which Antoine, discharged without honor from the army, pursued the music student, Christine (Claude Jade); and "Bed and Board" (1971), in which the marriage of Antoine and Christine fell apart as the self-interested Antoine sought a literary career and extra-marital affairs."Love on the Run" picks up Antoine and Christine on the morning that their no-contest divorce becomes final. Neither Antoine nor Christine is especially upset by this development. Christine has learned to live without Antoine and Antoine is busily involved in a new affair with Sabine, a pretty, bright young woman played by Dorothee, a new actress who looks a lot like the younger Claude Jade and like Catherine Deneuve, who has also figured in Mr. Truffaut's career.That same evening Antoine runs into Colette, again played by Marie-France Pisier, who is now a lawyer and still a woman with a mind of her own, which is to say that she has Antoine's number. By one of those coincidences that tie such comedies together, Colette's lover, a librarian, turns out to be the brother of Antoine's Sabine, which leads to a certain amount of misunderstanding of no real importance.You should be told here, however, that there's very little in the way of conventional story to "Love on the Run," whose screenplay is jointly credited to Mr. Truffaut, Miss Pisier, Jean Aurel and Suzanne Schiffman.It is, instead, a series of sequences in which everyone takes stock  the now serenely self-aware Christine, the beautiful, sensitive, funny Colette, as well as the perplexed Antoine. They take stock in great swatches of flashbacks lifted from "The 400 Blows" (black-and-white), "Colette" (sepia), and "Stolen Kisses" and "Bed and Board" (both in color).This method is initially disturbing.
