If you know the films well as I do  it seems that Mr. Truffaut has ransacked his own archives in the manner of the television vultures who put together omnibus features with titles such as "The Hollywood Sirens" or "The Silver Age of the Golden Screen." The bits and pieces  like Antoine's interview with the psychiatrist from "400 Blows"  are too good to be used in this fashion. The new context doesn't do them justice. It also appears to be lazy movie making.Then, too, I wonder if people who do not know the earlier films will make any sense at all of "Love on the Run." It's rather like opening a new book and skipping immediately to the epilogue.But if you admire Mr. Truffaut. I urge you to stay with "Love on the Run," which is this brilliantly, comically authoritative French director's analysis of his own work. I don't think any other film maker of his stature has ever attempted such a thing, certainly not in public with a feature film.While Antoine, Christine and Colette relive their earlier entanglements, Mr. Truffaut makes it clear that his identification with Antoine/Laud has grown from one based on concern, fondness and superficial likenesses to one having to do with a philosophy of life and art. Antoine's stories  the ones he acts out in these films as well as the ones he wants to write as a novelist  are so totally concerned with the processes and emotions of falling in love that he's continually surprised when the affairs are suddenly over.Whether by design or accident, the Antoine films have always taken a dim view of those romantic comedies that insist that the stereotypical boy and girl, having met, lost each other and met again, will live happily ever after. In the past Mr. Truffaut has shied away from such unequivocal cheeriness.In "Love on the Run" he is expressing doubts. At one point the pragmatic Sabine says to Antoine with a good deal of patience, "Why impose despair on everyone else while you go around enjoying life?"Mr. Truffaut ends "Love on the Run" in the only optimistic way he will permit himself. When Sabine and Antoine decide to stay together, they acknowledge that the decision may be a mistake and that it may end badly, but they agree to pretend that it's forever. For Mr. Truffaut to pretend is a major commitment.I hope this analysis doesn't make "Love on the Run" seem tediously schematic. Once you get its rhythm it is great fun  full of the wit, the humanity and the kind of mysterious references that separate Truffaut comedies from those of all other directors. It also offers a ravishing performance by Marie-France Pisier and very charming ones by Claude Jade and Dorothee.Mr. Laud is something else. He's exactly right but it's impossible now to identify the actor apart from the role. Seeing him as an obsessively selfish, unfeeling adult is a disappointment. He isn't as interesting or appealing as he used to be. As do some childhood friends, Antoine Doinel has grown away from us."Love on the Run," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), includes some mildly erotic sexual sequences.

title: The Clandestine Service, Fondly
description: McLEAN, Va.  Toward the end of my 27 years with what used to be called the Clandestine Service of the Central Intelligence Agency, the Service was badly, and probably inevitably, wounded. At a time when this part of our defense Establishment is trying to make difficult adjustments, it seems that a mythology has grown up about the agency that makes it difficult for the American people  the sole owners and proprietors of the C.I.A.  to think clearly about it.

title: Art: A Pastoral Vision Of the Hudson Valley
description: THE Hudson Valley is not what it was when the school of landscape painting was named for it. But Its a noble spectacle nonetheless and they'll have to pave over the river and grind down the Palisades before it ceases to be so. Of the villages that lurk along the Westchester bank, there may be many older than Hastings, now celebrating its began painting full time, and became, at the age of 21, a member of the National Academy of Design.. Married three years later, Cropsey took the grand tour of Italy and England, returning in 1849 to settle in New York City. There he exhibited regujarly, and taught as well. He was soon prosperous enough to travel abroad again and eventually to build a substantial house in Warwick, N.Y. As a sideline, Cropsey reverted to architecture by designing the stairways, platforms and waiting rooms for the Sixth Avenue El. But by 1884, his fortunes were declining, perhaps because, as his obituary notes, Mr. Cropsey was an artist of the Old Hudson River school [which] has been largely superseded by the French Impressionist class of artists, who pay less attention to detailed drawing In any event, the estate was sold and Cropsey repaired with his family to Hastings

title: Bank Stockholders Told Of a Lance Case Inquiry
description: ATLANTA, April 5 (AP)  The National Bank of Georgia has reported to its stockholders that it is under investigation by a Federal grand jury, apparently in connection with the activities of its former president, Bert Lance.

title: Bridge:
description: The big event of the bridge year for players in Long Island begins today at the Hofstra University Physical Center in Hempstead and is expected to attract players from far afield. It is the Long Island Regional Championships, in which the following events are scheduled:

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: ART (GR 34014)

title: Mrs. Rankin, on 67, Leads Golf by Shot
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 6 'C;They're all intimidated by her, Carol Mann was saying of Nancy Lopez. They sit around the locker room asking each other How are we going to beat Lopez?

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: EGLEVSKT BALLET ON L.I.

title: A New Approach to Selling the Arms Pact
description: Saying that a new strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union is imminent, the Carter Administration has begun a campaign that is designed to win support for the accord without raising false hopes that it would halt the AmericanSoviet arms race.

title: New Bombing in Australian City; Police Are Unable to Find Motive
description: PERTH, Australia, April 5 (AP)  The second bomb in two days exploded in Perth today, causing no injuries, and the department store bombed yestrday was cleared because of a crank call.

title: Deaths
description: WOODCOCKGeorge Anthony Neville, 90,in Witllamstown,Mass.April 3rd. A Maryborough Queensland.Australia native. Graduate UNv.of Sidney. Retired Industrial chemist for Colonial Sugar Refineries and DoorOliver in Queensland, Cuba and Fill. Malor Machine Gun Corp British Army WWI, Battle the Somme and trained American troops for combat. Retired Sternford,Conn.where he was influential in establishment of Resources Unlimited. Author of A Book of Limericks. His wife,the former Janet Franklin of New York City,died 1967. Only survivors nieces and nephews In Australia and great neghews including Prof.Alexander Woodcock, Williams College, Williamstown, Mass. Memorial services Saturday, April 6, 12 noon St.John's Episcopal Church,W11liamstown. Interment Flushing Cemetery, New York. Donations in his memory may be made to the Activities Fund, Sweetbrook Nursing Home, Williamstown, Mass. through the Hopkins Funeral Home, 6070 Spring St., Williamstown. Mass. 01267

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Low and middle level cloudiness covers the Northeast while a frontal band stretches from the Middle Atlantic States across Florida into the Gulf of Mexico. Clouds extend from the lake region through the Northern Plains States to the northern Rockies. Low level cloudiness is apparent along the coastal regions of the Far West.

title: New Iranian Regime, Resuming Executions, Kills 3 ExPolicemen
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Friday, April 6 (AP)  Iran's revolutionary regime executed three members of Shah Mohammed.Riza Pahlevi's police force before dawn today, Teheran Radio reported. The executions ended a threeweek moratorium.

title: Koch Urges City Be Considered As a Site for Gambling Casinos
description: The Koch administration urged publicly yesterday that New York City be specified as a potential casinogambling site and warned privately that the Mayor would oppose a constitutional amendment authorizing the casinos unless the city was included.

title: Racing Accord Reached
description: A tentative agreement on a new contract was reached yesterday between the New York Racing Association and its picketing parimutuel clerks. The agreement could end the 50day work stoppage at Aqueduct in the next few days.

title: AMAX Stock Split Voted by Directors
description: AMAX Inc., a diversified natural resource company, has authorized a 3for2 stock split for distribution June 15. In addition, the board also voted to raise the quarterly dividend to 67% cents a share, payable June 1 on the presplit shares to holders of record May 10.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Detroit teamsters in The Times on Wednesday stated incorrectly that members of that union are not eligible for strike benfits in a lockout. They arc entitled to such benefits.

title: 3 Homers, Eckersley Win for Red Sox, 71
description: BOSTON, April 5 (AP)  Jim Rice smashed a threerun homer and Dwight Evans and Fred Lynn added home runs with the bases empty today, powering Boston to a 71 victory over the Cleveland Indians in the Red Sox opener at Fenwav Park.

title: Faculty Begins Contract Strike at Boston University
description: BOSTON, April 5  Union faculty members attempting to win their first contract at a major private educational institution went out on strike at Boston University today.

title: Labor's Signal To President
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  By land, sea and air, organized labor is sending a message to President Carter this week telling him what it thinks of his antiinflation wage standard.

title: Tiunscript of Carter's Talk On National Energy Policy
description: Following is a transcript of President Carter's address on energy policy last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: Parlors Struck, Bettors Turning to Nassau
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., April 5 When your main concern is the morning line, and your main obstacle is the picket line, there is a simple solution you cross the county line.

title: NuclearPower Expansion Due
description: PARIS, April 5  The French Government has approved a $1.4 billion program to spur new business investment. The measures, which Prime Minister Raymond Barre said today were intended to compensate for the negative effect on our economy of the recent oil price increases, were the first such reaction by a Western industrialized country to the oil cartel's latest round of oil price increases.

title: Senate, in a Surprise Move, Votes To Permit Prayer in Public Schools
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  The Senate voted 47 to 37 today to restore the right of voluntary prayer in the public schools.

title: Pakistani Police Arrest Hundreds After Violence at Rites for Bhutto
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, April 5 Moslem prayer services for Zulfikar All Bhutto, the widely admired former Prime Minister who was hanged yesterday, erupted today into violent political demonstrations marked by stone throwing, the use of tear gas, the burning of vehicles and hundreds of arrests in Pakistan's main cities.

title: IN THE NATION
description: SACRAMENTO  Fear is going to change the fabric of our political process, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. said in the wake of the nuclear accident the experts said could never happen. As events in California suggest, fear may change, perhaps destroy, the future of the nuclear power industry in America.

title: Islanders 3 in Third Defeat Flyers by 31
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 5  The New York Islanders and Philadelphia Flyers played a hockey gathe at playoff pitch tonight in the Spectrum and the Islanders came out on top by 31.

title: A Spanish Chapel Holds Medieval Dramas
description: Springtime Saturday afternoons at the Cloisters are even nicer now that Stephen de Pietri's Actors Guild has brought the spectacle of medieval drama to this madetoorder settins.

title: The New York Times/Micha BarAm
description: YAMIT, IsraeliOccupied Sinai, April 5  With an impressive display of political footwork and oratory, Prime Minister Menachem Begin turned a hostile, jeering crowd of Israeli settlers in Sinai into an applauding audience today.

title: Ross A. Von Wiegand, Developed Programs to Combat Alcoholism
description: Ross A. Von Wiegand, an authority on alcoholism and one of the founders of the Association of LaborManagement Administrators and Consultants on Alcoholism, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 71 years old and lived in New York City.

title: President Establishing Commission To Study Nuclear Reactor Mishap
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  President Carter ordered today that an independent Presidential commission be established to investigate the causes of the accident at the Three Mile Island reactor in Pennsylvania and to recommend safety improvements for all nuclear power plants in the United States.

title: Federal Ethics Held Within Bounds
description: The pleas of Federal officials who are worried about the tough new ethics law have finally begn heard on Capitol Hill. A House Judiciary subcommittee is considering amendments, sponsored by the Carter Administration, to clarify and cushion the effect of last yekr's statute on postGovernment employment. Theamendments are reasonable and we hope they are enacted. Together with detailed regulations issued by the Office of Government Ethics, they should produce a code that is both palatable and workable.

title: National Merger Bids Lose Round
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  Pan American World Airways and Texas International Airlines should be denied permission to merge with National Airlines because of the potential impact on competition in the airline industry, the chief hearing officer for the Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today.

title: Striking Tug Crewmen Tow Sludge From L.I; Jersey Problem Grows
description: A major health problem stemming from the fivedayold tugboat strike was resolved yesterday after a court order on Long Island, but a similar problem was developing in New Jersey.

title: Producer Prices Up 1% in Month; Rising Food Cost a Major Factor
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  Inflation continued at a rapid pace in March as producer prices at the wholesale level rose by 1 percent for the second straight month, the Government reported today. Producer prices are eventually reflected in the retail prices that consumers pay.

title: East Germans Race to Spend Their Foreign Money
description: EAST BERLIN, April 5  Hundreds of angry East Berliners lined up at stateoperated hardcurrency shops today after the East German Government announced restrictions on the free circulation and use of hard currencies from the West. The action is designed to combat widespread blackmarket activities.

title: Publishing: 800 Volumes That Contain a Library
description: ONE of the greatest and most important bibliographic resources of the Western world will soon be available in book form to libraries and individuals everywhere when the New York Public Library's ninemillion card catalogue is photographed and published in book form in 80014inch by 14inch volumes.

title: A StrategicArms Glossary
description: MIRV  A multiple independently targetable reentry vehicles. MIRV's are separate warheads  that is, nuclear bombs fitted to a single missile. The American Minuteman missile, for example, is fitted with three MIRV's and can be used to attack three targets in a single strike.

title: Drilling Prospects Mixed Under Carter's Oil Plan
description: HOUSTON, April 5 In the long run, President Carter's new energy plan would likely rejuvenate the lagging efforts to find new supplies of oil in the United States, industry spokesmen and analysts predicted today. But in the shorter term, they warned, the President's proposals would probably further inhibit petroleum exploration.

title: Drama: Judith Jamison in Stage Debut
description: Asking too Much? is theatrical venture on view April 22 at the Katie Murphy Amphitheater of the Fashion Institute of Technology. For those who may be lured by the presence of Judith Jamison in the cast, here making her acting debut, the answer to that question is yes. Ten minutes into this inept threehour musical, and it's obvious that it's all just public psychotherapy for a handful of dimwitted characters assembled by the show's writer and director, Ken Rubenstein.  Jaj, Bernie, Kristy and Cuba are nightclub performers who come together to rehearse an act created by Jaj's father, Cookie, who is in love with another cast member, a wouldbe Italian sex symbol named Favolosa. Considering the amount of rehearsing they all do, the show might never go on, but it's probably just as well, on the evidence of the bits that do manage to interrupt the endless talk.

title: Boeing Seen Rethinking the 767
description: SEATTLE, April 5  The Boeing Company is being forced to rethink the future of its intermediatesize 767 aircraft as a result of the sales success of the European A310 Airbus, according to industry sources.

title: 2 Million Drivers to Get No Fault Refunds
description: In the first major dividend of New York State's sixyearold nofault automobile insurance law, $20 million in credits and refunds will be issued to nearly two million motorists over the next six months, the State Insurance Department announced yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: One of television's historic moments wax the 1954 See It Now program on which Edward R. Murrow attacked Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. Today is the 25th anniversary of the Senator's ontheair reply, and although both principals are dead, they have surrogates to carry on their battles.

title: Australian Truck Drivers Strike
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 5 (Reuters)  Meat and vegetable supplies began running short today as 7,000 truck drivers, demanding cuts in road taxes, blocked main roads into Sydney. More vehicles joined the threedayold blockade of main highways around the city after the collapse of talks between drivers and state authorities.

title: Bank Robbers Car Is Found by Police
description: A stolen 1976 Chevrolet that was used by three holdup men who robbed a bank in lower Manhattan of. 6335,600 on Wednesday was recovered by the police.

title: Black Attorney Cites Hongisto as a Racist At Hearing in Albany
description: ALBANY, April 5  A black lawyer and former member of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors today characterized Richard D. Hongisto, Governor Carey's nominee for State Corrections Commissioner, as a racist.

title: Longshoremen in Baltimore Defy Judge's Order to Return to Work
description: BALTIMORE, April 5 (AP)  Longshoremen who walked off their jobs to protest alleged harassment by the police defied a Federal injunction and refused to report for work today at the city's two largest marine terminals, a terminal spokesman said.

title: German Book Events at N.Y.U.
description: Contemporary German literature is the subject of an exhibition, readings and discussions during German Book Week at New York University's Deutsches Haus, 42 Washington Mews, from today until Wednesday. The events, cosponsored by the Goethe Institute at N.Y.U. and the German Booksellers Association, are open to the public.

title: Market Place
description: NATIONAL AIRLINES, which had four suitors seeking corporate matrimony as recently as Wednesday, could yet remain single, and such a development would have important implications for speculators in National stock.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Preparatory committee for new international development strategy 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Lie by Port Authority P.B.A. Aide Ties Up Tunnel
description: Port Authority officials said yesterday that hundreds of New Yorkbound commuters had experienced long delays in the morning rush hour after deciding to drive through the Lincoln Tunnel to avoid what radio news reports warned was a trafficslowing job action by Port Authority policemen at the Holland Tunnel.

title: Frigidaire Tie Is Not Blocked
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  The Justice Department said today that it would not bring an antitrust suit to block the acquisition of the General Motors Corporation's Frigidaire division by White Consolidated Industries because no other company was interested in buvine Frigidaire.

title: Inez Robb, an ExColumnist, Dies; Was a World Waa II Correspondent
description: Inez Robb, a nationally syndicated columnist who started as a teenage reporter in Boise, Idaho, and became a war correspondent for The International Nevo Service, died Wednesday in Tuscon, Ariz. Mrs. Robb, who retired in 1969, had suffered from Parkinson's Disease. She was 78 years old.

title: Levich Is Out of Soviet Academy
description: MOSCOW, April 5  The Soviet Academy of Sciences was reported today to have automatically expelled Veniamin G. Levich an migr, because he had given up his citizenship as part of emigration.

title: Radio
description: 7.8 A.M., WNCN. Suite Masques et Bergamasques, excerpt, Faur; Air on the G String, Bach; Pavane de Spanje, Vois; First Concert in C minor, Rameau.

title: U.S. to Let Soviet Buy Computer
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)  The Carter Administration has quietly approved the sale of an American computer system to the Soviet Union, reversing a decision made by the President last July.

title: Groups Oppose Waiving Of Proposal for Subways
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  Groups representing the handicapped and the elderly attacked a proposal today that would allow cities to substitute van service for extensive refitting of tsubway stations to accommodate the disabled. The waiver of the proposed requirements was suggested on Tuesday by Brock Adams, the Secretary of Transportation.

title: Frugal Man's Cache Is a Font of Cash for All
description: CLEVELAND, April 5 (AP) One youngster found a $100 bill and bought a bicycle. Other children bought candy. Linda C. Dodge scooped up $1,000.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Aberdeen Manufacturing Corporation, a producer and distributor of window curtains, textiles and furnishings, has named Charles B. Reiter president of the textiles group.

title: New York Power Agency Drops NuclearEnergy Project Upstate
description: A proposed 1.2 millionkilowatt nuclear, power project, on which $147 million has already been spent for design and some equipment, was abandoned yesterday by the New York State Power Authority amid rising costs and controversy about nuclear energy.

title: Draths
description: MASLOWMac. Beloved husband of Ethel, father of Robert and Joel and grandfather of Laura and Dawn. Funeral services will be held at Jet. fer Funeral Homes, Hollis, L.I. 10AM on Friday.

title: Liechtenstein Acts On Fake Concerns
description: VADUZ, Liechtenstein, April (AP)  Liechtenstein proposed new laws today for stricter control of tens of thousands of socalled mailbox companies that have blemished the reputation of this small principality.

title: Europe in NonCrisis
description: LONDON  Three years ago, Western Europe emerged from its worst postwar recession, and now there are signs of a new relapse. Mainly the result of increased oil prices, inflation is rising, unemployment has not fallen, economic growth is slowing. But the downturn from 1973 to 1975 was not, in retrospect, a slump; nor is the economy likely to collapse in 1980. Instead of a 4 percent annual growth there will be only 2.5 to 3 percent.

title: N.&W., Southern Talk Merger
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway and the Southern Railway disclosed yesterday that they were discussing a merger, a move that would create the nation's third lamest railroad.

title: Pressure Grows in Bus Strike
description: When the city's School Chancellor, Frank J. Macchiarola, decided to remove jobsecurity provisions from new school bus transportation contracts last fall, in what he said was an effort to save money, he knew he was taking a calculated risk.

title: News Summary
description: savings from an arms accord were predicted by Defense Secretary Harold Brown, who said that a new strategic weapons limitation treaty with Moscow could save Washington as much as $30 billion on nuclear arms over the next 10 years. He also said that the pact would forestall a pointless arms race and would mean greater stability and predictability in the strategic challenges we face. [Page Al, Columns 12.]

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Interest rates continued to decline yesterday, extending a trend that has surprised and pleased bond traders and borrowers this spring.

title: Economic Scene
description: PRESIDENT CARTER'S plan to decontrol oil prices, announced last night, will almost certainly spread cheer on Wall Street by adding strength to the already recovering dollar.

title: Energy
description: President Carter said he would, gradually lift price controls domestic crude oil and would ask Congress for a tax on the resulting windfall profits. In a nationally televised address, the President presented his complex new plan to end the country's dependency on foreign oil. [Page AL] The President's proposal was initially interpreted as a complete turnabout of the strategy he used in campaign.. ing for office in 1476, when he voiced unwavering support for continued oil price controls. [03.]

title: Earlier Election Dates Scheduled in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 5  Officials of Rhodesia's transitional Government said today that elections for limited black rule would begin on April 17, three days earlier than originally scheduled, and would continue through April 21.

title: Wild Pitch in 9th Gives Padres 43 Triumph Over the Dodgers
description: LOS ANGELES, April 5  The sunshine boys returned to Southern California today, 193 days after Thurman Munson caught Ron Cey's foul pop at Dodger Stadium to end the World Series and the 1978 season.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW,AprIl 7 OCEANIC (Home). Left Nassau April 5; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Strong Demand for Beef Sends Cattle Futures Up
description: Cattle futures rose yesterday on continuing strong wholesale demand for beef. The gains in live cattle futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, amounting to 0.05 to 0.83 cent a pound, surprised some traders who expected prices to fall after Wednesday's session, when they gained as much as the Phcentapound daily trading limit, an analyst said.

title: Favretto Gets Antitrust Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  The Justice Department announced the promotion, effective today, of Richard J. Favretto to be a deputy assistant attorney general in the antitrust division.

title: Time to Trade Up in Soviet Trade
description: When the United States demanded four years ago, by law, that. the Soviet Union exchange refugees, mostly Jews, for trade benefits and credits, Moscow replied by reducing the number of exit permits by half. When Americans recently asked Deng Xiaoping whether would let people out of China to qualify for trade concessions, he is said to have replied, How about 20 million?

title: Draths
description: BERKTheodore D. The Directors and his many friends and associates at Lightolier, Inc. extend their deepest sympathy to the family of Ted Berk, Director, former VicePreS ident, leader, counselor, friend and associate for over SO years: He will be greatly missed.

title: Building Costs Rise by 12.3%
description: The cost of construction materials and labor in the United States increased by an average of 12.3 percent in the 12month period ended March 31, the Dodge Building Cost Services Department of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday. This compared with an 8.5 percent gain for the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: No Playoffs For Walton
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 5 (AP)  Bill Walton will not be placed on the active roster of the Portland Trail Blazers for the National Basketball Association playoffs, Coach Jack Ramsay said today.

title: Wife of Buyer for Lilco Fighting Nuclear Power
description: MINEOLA, L.i., April 5 A 35yearold mother of five children whose husband was recently appointed vice president of purchasing, including uranium, for the Long Island Lighting Company today publicly called for an end to nuclear power plants.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DETROIT, April 5 (AP)  The Ford Motor Company, following the lead earlier in the week of the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation, today raised the prices of its 1979 model cars an average of $153 a car, or 2.1 percent.

title: Television
description: 5:55(4) Inflation

title: For Children
description: ART MUSE, an art and musk creoram, for Noe 8 to 13 years old; African Lanouaoe of Ghana, (EWE). fcr the same ape rout). both on Saturday at 10 IS A.M., and at the same time, Stone Ribs, Moving Mountains & Other Folk Heroes, fcr children a to 12, at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street. Similar Programs on April 14 and 21. Free. Redletration:11731300, extensicn 576, between 3 to 5 P.M.

title: Koppell, Backed by Abrams, Opens Democratic Race for Top Bronx Post
description: The race for the Democratic nomination for the borough presidency of the Bronx, a battleground for regulars and insurgents as well as black and Hispanic political leaders, began yesterday.

title: Sales Rise Is Slower At Many Big Chains
description: Sales among many of the nation's largest retailers showed smaller yeartoyear gains in March than in previous months, indicating a slowing pace in consumer buying, according to reports yesterday from more than a dozen leading chains.

title: Umpires Picketing Games on 2 Coasts
description: Baseball's unsigned major league umpires moved their picketing to Yankee Stadium and Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles yesterday as their call for contract improvements continued to go unanswered.

title: Basic Rate Cut at Bank Of England
description: LONDON, April 5 (AP)  The Bank of England, citing recent upward pressure on the pound and a decline in shortterm interest rates, reduced its minimum lending rate today to 12 percent from 13 percent.

title: Upstate Survey Describes Perils At 215 Dumps
description: BUFFALO, April 5  A Federalstate task force report released here today pinpointed and described 215 wastedisposal sites in heavily industrialized Erie and Niagara Counties, including 36 of them known to contain large amounts of poisonous, carcinogenic or radioactive wastes.

title: Paraguayan Tied to Murders Is Ordered Deported
description: A former Paraguayan police official who has been accused by humanrights groups of political torturemurders in his country was ordered deported yesterday after he admitted overstaying a tourist visa and living illegally for nine months in Brooklyn.

title: The Pop Life
description: EVEN for rock fans who have accepted disco, the band called Chic remains something of a test case. A lot of disco is clearly complex or akin to trance music or related to more familiar forms of soul or salsa. But Chic  at least in its two hit singles  seems almost defiantly simpleminded, defined by a thudding disco beat, blatant hooks and chirpy female cooing of trivial doggerel.

title: And in Jersey They're Playing Football
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 5  It was opening day for the Giants football too, today, as players introduced themselves to coaches and coaches introduced themselves to players on the opening of a threeday minicamp at Giants Stadium.

title: WASHINGTON
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 5The Soviet Union, which been kept on the sidelines against its will for a long time, is now reentering the Middle East peace arrangements through the side door of the United Nations.

title: Key Congressmen Back Oil Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  President Carter's energy proposal received qualified but crucial support from influential Congressmen tonight, although several liberals were sharply critical.

title: Talmadge Case to Get Polygraphs
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  The chief witness against Senator Herman E. Talmadge failed a Governmentadministered polygraph test but passed two other examinations given by private polygraph examiners, sources close to the investigation said today.

title: Sports Today
description: New York Stars vs. Houston Angels, Women's ProfeSsional League, at Queens College's FitzGerald gym, Flushing, 8 P.M.

title: White House Solar Cost
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)  The solar waterheating system being built at the White House is more than $4,000 more expensive than the original $24,000 estimate and probably will not pay for itself with its $1,000 a year in projected initial energy savings, according to the President's cousin, Hugh Carter, who handles the payroll and expenses at the White House.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: JOHN WAIN  after 11 books of fiction, 5 of poetry, 5 of criticism, 1 biography and a memoir  is no longer the Angry Young Man he was in Britain in 1953. Nor, of course, should he be. Instead of mellowing, he has saddened. He now goes quietly about his business of building a book, with a board here and a brick there, mortar on the narrative, a nail in the wall from which the hide will hang. The result is something sturdy and functional; it keeps the rain out. And inside, people are making interesting mistakes with their lives.

title: The Tugmen's Passage
description: Senior tugboat captains, working only half the days in the year, can make as much as $70,000. Yet nobody who rides down the East River with one of them, piloting an 800foot tanker through Hell Gate, near the Mayor's house, and over the river's shallow, rocky bottom at Poor House Flats opposite 20th Street, would begrudge them their money. The tugrnan, on the bridge of the ship, gives his orders as confidently as if he owned the lordly real estate he has been passing (and as though another tug captain hadn't recently hit the Brooklyn Bridge with the mast of a tanker). Now they and other marine crewmen are on strike, seeking a 40 percent raise; the employers are offering 6 percent.

title: Stadium Opener Glitters Despite Dissenter
description: A 23yearold roofer from Kearny, N.J., took a large gamble yesterday in the Bronx. He showed up at Yankee Stadium for the 1979 baseball opener wearing a flaming red cap with Boston Red Sox across the front.

title: Ivy League Women Face Social Barriers
description: At some, the changeover took a couple of centuries in coming; at most, was unthinkable for generations. But at all eight Ivy League colleges, among the most prestigious  and maledominated  schools in the nation, coeducation in the last decade has become the norm.

title: ArchitectureHistory Prize
description: Sebastiano Serlio on Domestic Architecture, the first publication of the Architectural History Foundation, a new nonprofit publishing organization, will receive the Society of Architectural Historians Alice Davis Hitchcock Book Award today at the group's annual meeting in Savannah. Ga. The award, which is presented annually by the society to the most distinguished work of scholarship in architectural history to be published in North America, will be divided between Myra Nan Rosenfeld, a Montreal architectural historian who wrote the book's introductory essay, and the Architectural History Foundation for making possible publication of the work, which was issued Jointly by the foundation and the M.I.T. Press.

title: Drama: Friel's Faith Healer
description: BRIAN FRIEL'S new play uses a brokendown, itinerant Irish faith healer to construct a parable about the artist and his estranging art.'The Faith Healer,'They defied me to endow them with hopelessness, he says. But I couldn't even do that for them. And they knew I couldn't. A peculiar situation, wasn't it? No, not peculiar  eerie. Because occasionally, just occasionally, the miracle would happen. And then panicpanic panic!

title: Continental Adds Twist To Notes
description: Two large bank holding companies moved ahead yesterday to raise $200 million, or possibly more, by selling notes carrying rates that are to be linked to fluctuations in the rates for sixmonth Treasury bills.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Shipowners have been a harassed group since the recession of 197475., Their industry has yet to recover from the overbuilding of the early 1970's, and in recent years longshoremen's strikes, fuelprice increases and currency fluctuations have bedeviled them further.

title: Experts Plan to Pump Gases Back to Reactor Building
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., April 5  In the hope of significantly reducing the amount of radioactive gases being released from the damaged Three Mile Island nuclear power plant, engineers have fashioned a system to pump toxic gases that have accumulated in an outside storage tank back into the containment building of the reactor.

title: Koch Is Given Friendly Welcome In Visit to Van Cortlandt Sectioi
description: Mayor Koch received an unusually friendly welcome last night as he held another of his constituent hours in the Van Cortlandt section of the Bronx.

title: Sheila Janet Kann Wed To Dr. Michael S. Siegal
description: In Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., last evening, Sheila Janet Kann, daughter of Kurt Kann of New York, and Fran Farrell of San Francisco, became the bride of Dr. Michael Selig Siegal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul T. Siegal of Bayside, Queens. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Robert Forrest Walkoff, assisted by Cantor David Benedict.

title: McGraw Expansion
description: The McGrawdison Company announced plans to construct a $12 million addition to its present evaporative cooler manufacturing facility in Phoenix. The new plant will also provide the company's international metal products division plant with additional capacity.

title: Lending Up By Banks in New York
description: Demand for business loans continued strong in the week ended April 4 as the 10 major New York City banks increased their lending by $592 million to commercial and industrial enterprises, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: CHRYST LOUKAS
description: Chryst Loukas, educational director of the AngloAmericanHellenic Bureau of Education, which was founded at Columbia University after World War II, died Wednesday in Lafayette, Ind. He was 77 years old.

title: McEnroe, Gerulaitis Gain In Netherlands Tourney
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 5 (AP)  John McEnroe and Vitas Gerulaitis of the United States and Sweden's Bjorn Borg won secondround matches today in a World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: Misses Stove, Durr Gain In Japan Doubles Event
description: OSAKA, Japan, April 5 (AP)  Betty Stove of the Netherlands and Francoise Durr of France beat two Australians, Kerry Reid and Wendy Turnbull, 76, 63, today in the semifinals of a $150,000 women's doubles tennis tournament.

title: Met Hears New Voices In Opera Auditions
description: One singer is a Russian migr who works as a cleaning woman at McDonald's. Another has never been outside the state he was born in, and his only professional experience has been as chief soloist in a dinner club.

title: Screen:'Perfect Couple,' Altman's Musical:Raising Questions
description: THE most distressing thing about Robert Altman's latest films  whether they've been unwatchable, like the grim "Quintet," or just low-keyed and pleasantly insubstantial, like "A Wedding" and now "A Perfect Couple"  is the light they cast upon his previous triumphs. At least "Quintet" could be construed as a fluke: even if "3 Women" was nearly this pretentious, it was also  like "Images," Mr. Altman's only successful foray into anything murky  resplendently lovely. "Quintet," on the other hand, looked every bit as awful as it sounded.But both "A Wedding" and "A Perfect Couple" are watered-down reminders of the director's better work  so characteristic, and yet so dim. And they raise not only the question of what's gone wrong lately, but also that of how everything in "Nashville" went so right. If Mr. Altman keeps on operating at such a small fraction of his powers, his masterworks may begin to look more and more like happy accidents."A Perfect Couple," which opens today at the Beekman, Paramount, Gramercy and other theaters, started out as Mr. Altman's attempt  along with his co-screenwriter, the actor Allan Nicholls  to write a love story that would feature Paul Dooley and Marta Heflin, whose performances in "A Wedding" he had very much liked. (Mr. Dooley played Snooks, the bride's father; Miss Heflin had a smaller role as a nervous bridesmaid.) Then it turned out that Mr. Nicholls had a rock group, a bunch of actor-singers called "Keepin' 'Em Off the Streets," and quicker than you could say "Marriage of Convenience" the rock group had become integral to the plot. Miss Heflin had once been a member of a large communal rock group herself, so art imitated life as the screenwriters turned her into a singer who lived and worked with the band.The lovers are supposed to be opposites, so Mr. Dooley is cast as a member of a wealthy Greek family, living with a large troupe of relatives in a hilltop castle, somewhat gothic but equipped with an electric garage door opener. (Miss Heflin and the band have been given a loft in downtown Los Angeles to call home.) The lovers are supposed to be essentially similar, too, so each is shown to be tyrannized by a father figure  he by a Greek patriarch, she by the band's lead singer. Life is supposed to be tough but funny in these modern times, so they meet through a computer dating service alter sizing up one another via videocassette.So far, so-so. Mr. Altman renders the story gently, with his camera slowly panning toward things or slowly panning away, and with a number of familiar comic twists; the best scenes in "A Perfect Couple" recall even better scenes in other Altman movies. Mr. Dooley is most endearing, and so are the crazy relatives who have him hamstrung. Miss Heflin is less successful, partly because of a built-in problem with the script, which makes the businessman older and more aggressive, the singer very timid and shy. Shy she may be, but in that case what is she doing in a loft where no one has any privacy, everyone is inexhaustibly convivial, and the atmosphere is Flower Power with a vengeance? The glum, inexpressive Miss Heflin makes it very hard to believe that the heroine has anything to do with this band.Keepin' 'Em Off the Streets has an elaborate act, featuring members wandering around the stage when they aren't singing, a woman who sits rocking her baby as she listens to the music, and a dog who perches beside a fire hydrant prop. The singers include a number of people once connected with "Hair" plus Ted Neeley, who had the title role in "Jesus Christ Superstar," and they perform tuneful, very Californian songs with lyrics that are often furiously silly ("Pity the poor millionaire/Who's never sure if people care").Mr. Neeley, the lead singer, sounds enough like John Fogerty (late of Creedence Clearwater Revival) to make up for his irritating offstage manner, and the group harmonizes nicely; they're at least interesting enough to carry three or four lengthy musical numbers. The film includes 11. By the time it's over, the thing you may wish most fervently about Keepin' 'Em Off The Streets is that Mr. Altman hadn't decided to.When it isn't bending over backward to accommodate the songs, the film has some sweet, funny moments. There's a very amusing episode about Mr. Dooley's date with an oversexed veterinarian (Ann Ryerson), and a first-blush-of-love scene that includes Mr. Dooley, Miss Heflin, and the doctor who's sewing up the part of Mr. Dooley's head that Miss Heflin has just dented with a fireplace poker. Some of the incidental performances are very good, especially that of Belita Moreno, as Mr. Dooley's sickly sister (she also played the groom's twin in "A Wedding").There is also a running gag about another couple that flattens out long before it's over. And the ending hinges on a cheap, morbid trick, just as the end of "A Wedding" did. If Mr. Altman is going to rework pieces of his own work, there are better bits he could have borrowed."A Perfect Couple" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It includes one love scene, no violence, and a few mild mentions of homosexuality.

title: Carter Suffers Two ForeignAid Defeats in House
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  The Carter Administration sustained two defeats but won one important victory today as the House completed its second day of debate on a bill that would authorize $8.5 billion in foreign aid over the next two years.

title: Sadat Urges Palestinians to Shun Terrorism and Make Peace With Israel
description: CAIRO, April 5  President Anwar elSadat urged today that the Palestinian people disavow the terrorism, intimidation and threats of their leaders and join the talks he has arranged with Israel on home rule for Israelioccupied Palestinian areas.

title: Art People
description: STILL infiltrating downtown, the Whitney Museum has just clinched a deal with the city to take over the abandoned First Precinct police station, a neoRenaissance landmark on Old Slip in the South Street Seaport area.

title: Corporate Earnings Reported
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock Is listed as the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Teamster Talks Resume as Auto Industry Layoffs Continue to Climb
description: DETROIT, April 5  Negotiators for the trucking industry anil the International Brotherhood of Teamsters returned to the bargaining table in Washington today, but this did not stop the layoffs by industries hard hit by their inability to move goods from point to point.

title: Excerpts From Speech by Brown on a Strategic Arms Pact With Soviet Union
description: The debate over SALT. !rill's already begun and, in fact, has been under way for as long as or longer than the negotiations themselves. MoreoVer, the debate is a farreaching one and has, properly, addressed our broader strategic policy objectives and programs, as well as the provisions of the agreement itself.

title: About Real Estate
description: Few issues in mortgage banking are as controversial as socalled redlining, defined as geographic discrimination in mortgage lending.

title: A.C.L.U. Will Represent Editors In Dispute Over Article on Bomb
description: MADISON, Wis., April 5  The American Civil Liberties Union agreed today to represent the editor and the managing editor of The Progressive magazine in their appeal of a Federal district court's preliminary injunction prohibiting them from publishing an article on the hydrogen bomb.

title: Dow, Up 7.80 to 877.60, At Highest in Sfr Months
description: The stock market caught its second wind yesterday and roared ahead to its highest reading in nearly six months. Trading was active as oilandgas issues, selected glamour stocks and special situations led the way.

title: Nuns in Saris Help Poorest in Bronx
description: Two by two, wrapped in white saris, the women leave the threestory brick house in the South Bronx at 8:15 A.M. and filter into the neighborhood, reciting the rosary aloud as they go.

title: Around the Nation
description: Student Newspaper Allowed To Return After Agreement

title: Issues and Debate Linking U.S. Trade Relations With the Right to Emigrate
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  More than four years ago Congress passed a new trade act that included a provision designed to bar the Soviet Unipn from receiving normal trade privileges unless it gave assurances to the United States that Soviet Jews and others could emigrate freely.

title: CITY PLANNING SITES FOR SMALL INDUSTRY
description: Deputy Mayor Peter J. Solomon yesterday unveiled the city's latest economic development strategy, based on a plan to build vestpocket industrial parks in areas of abandoned housing.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Bolstered by expectations that President Carter would announce measures to reduce United States dependence on foreign oil, the dollar rose yesterday against every major currency except the British pound.

title: Guerrilla Hanged in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Friday, April 6 (AP)  Solomon Mahlangu, a young black nationalist, was hanged just after dawn today despite clemency appeals from President Carterand other foreign leaders.

title: Trumpets Proclaim Easter Music Season
description: Trumpets Proclaim Easter Music Season

title: Music: Schuller Leads 4 New Works
description: FOUR works new to New York were conducted by Gunther Schuller in a Composers Showcase concert at the Whitney Museum on Wednesday night. The event was presented in conjunction with the Fromm Music Foundation at Harvard. The works were Roger Hourland's Seven Pollock Paintings (1978), Jacob Druckman's 'Animus IV (1977), Ralph Shapey's PartitaFantasia for Cello and 16 Players (1967) and Gerald Levinson's Light dances/stones sing (1978). Paul Sperry, tenor, was soloist in Animus and Joel Krosnick was the cellist in the PartitaFantasia.

title: Brass Ensembles Send Notes on High
description: When Easter comes, the trumpets will sound in churches around town, and so will some French horns, trombones and at least one tuba. Timpani, too, though they are hard to haul up into church balconies.

title: A Lavish Blass Show At Embassy in Paris
description: PARIS, April 5  It wasn't the sort of Collection anyone could call understated. The curvy day clothes were wreathed in fur. The sumptuous evening styles were awash with poufs and plumes.

title: CARTER TO END PRICE CONTROL ON U.S. OIL AND URGE CONGRESS TO TAX ANY WINDFALL PROFITS
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  President. Carter told the nation tonight that he would gradually lift price controls on domestic crude oil, and ask Congress for a tax on any windfall profits that resulted for oil producers, as part of a complex and potentially controversial plan to end America's dependency on foreign oil.

title: Nigeria to Lift Oil Price 25%
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 5 (AP)  In statement that confirmed earlier reports that a crude oil price increase was coming, the chief economist for Nigeria's oil industry said that his country's increases of 23 to 25 percent were relatively restrained because the world market could bear price rises of up to 33 percent.

title: House Budget Panel Trims Plan For Deficit in 1980 to $25.2 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  The House Budget Committee approved today a Federal fiscal plan for 1980 economical enough to reduce President Carter's most recent estimate of the prospective deficit, $41 billion, to $25.2 billion.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, Apr il 3, 1979

title: AnheuserSesame Venture
description: AnheuserBusch Inc. announced yesterday that its family entertainment division, Busch Gardens, had entered into a joint venture with Children's Television Workshop, creator of the Sesame Street and Electric COMnanv television oroorams. to develon a series of educational play parks called Sesame Place. Constniction of prototype Sesame Place will begin in June on a 15acre site in lower Bucks County, Pa., about equidistant between Philadelphia and Trenton. The opening is planned for the spring of 1980.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The accident at the Three. Mile Island plant serves to remind me that, in addition to the scores of such plants throughout the world, there are even a larger number of atomicpowered submarines and other vessels in the seas. All are subject to the same kind of accident and, in time of even a limited war, to deliberate destruction and the spread of their contents throughout the. oceans and the atmosphere.

title: Trash Job Action Besets Yonkers
description: YONKERS, April 5 Nearly 1,000 tons of garbage lined this city's streets today as sanitation workers continued a work slowdown over deadlocked contract pegotiations.

title: Seeded Players Advance In Junior Invitation Tennis
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y. April 5 The topseeded players scored victories in the opening round of the 12th annual junior invitation tennis tournament here today.

title: A HydrogenGas Warning Given On Nuclear Plant on Long Island
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission issued a warning last March 5 that a possible generic problem with the accumulation of hydrogen gas existed in proposed nuclearpower generating plants for which 11 licenses were being sought.

title: Concert: Two Delights
description: MUSCIA AETERNA's second program, on Wednesday night, in its Alice Tully Hall series offered two works that were delights in themselves and two that gave delight through the beauty of their performances. Frederic Waldman, the orchestra's founder and conductor, opened the evening with Handel's Concerto Grosso in F (Op. 6, No. 9) and closed it with Haydn's Symphony No. 103 in E flat, bearing the nickname Drum Roll, and these were the pieces that gave pleasure primarily through their substance.

title: TV Weekend: An Embryo Transplant, Michelangelo's Pieta and Giselle
description: AN allnew Supertrain,  not offered for review, limps onto the NBC schedule tomorrow night at 10. And Franco Zeffirelli's Jesus of Nazareth, also on NBC, reaches its final installment Sunday at 8. Meanwhile, heralded with assorted puff features, television prepares for Monday's Academy Awards presentation  the event that provokes universal sneering and, inevitably, blockbuster ratings. It will be carried on ABC.

title: One Dies in Philippine Ship Fire
description: MANILA, April 5 (AP)  Fire swept an island steamer preparing to get under way today, and passengers leaped into Manila Bay. One person died and two were injured, officials said.

title: Broadway
description: THE KINGFISHER will go on tour; will Daisy Mayme, and Jack the Ripper is supposed to come to Broadway next season. For that matter, the hope that Daisy Mayme, which was first done in 1926, will come to Broadway, too. The Kingfisher will tour with Claudette Colbert, Rex Harrison and George Rose, who are in it now, while Daisy Mayme will star Jean Stapleton. Daisy Mayme is by George Kelly, who is best known for The Torchbearers and The Showoff, while Miss Stapleton is best known as Edith Bunker in television's All in the Family. It is not certain who will be in Jack the Ripper, although it is likely that Neva Small, who is in the musical now at Trinity Square in Providence, R.I., will stay with it when it reaches New York. The common denominator for all these shows Is Elliot Martin, the producer. Mr. Martin is very busy.

title: Events and Openings
description: LOVE ON THE RUN, a French film directed by Fran; cols Truffaut starring Jean Pierre Leaud, at the Coronet Theater.

title: EARNINGS Bowater Profits Up 15.3%
description: The Bowater Corporation Ltd., reported from London headquarters yesterday that its profits last year increased by 15.3 percent from 1977 despite a decline of 9.3 percent in sales.

title: Deaths
description: AMBROSEBarbara Melick. Widow of A. Rommel Ambrose of Irvington. Virginia. Died Wednesday, April 4, 1979. She is survived by son, Arthur Tennent Ambrose, Tat. ton, Pa. and two grandchildren. She was the mother of the late Geraldine Ambrose Williamson. She Is also survived by her brother W. Dixon Melick, Nazareth, Pa. and a soninlaw, Robert P. Williamson, Lynchburg, Va. Services will be held 11 AM Saturday, at Grace EpisCopal Church, Kilmarnock, Va. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer SoBARNERTDr. Alan H. The Department of Ophthalmology of the Mount Sinai Medical Center express great sorrow over the passing of our devoted colleague, Dr. Alan H. Barnert, who passed away on Wednesday while on vacation in Barbados. Dr. Barnert was a valued member of the department, an esteemed clinician, and a great teacher. In addition to his appointment to the staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital and Mount Sinai School of Medicine, Dr. Barnert was the chief of the Contact Lens. Clinic at Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital in New York, and worked with the low vision clinic at the Lighthouse. He was the author of many books and articles on the subject of low vision. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Libby and his children, David, WilBARNERTAlan H., M.D. The Associated Alumni of the Mount Sinai Hospital and School of Medicine is shocked at the untimely death of its distinguished colleague and past president of 1967, 1968, a devoted and active member of the Alumni since 1947. His outstanding qualities as a physician, his sweetness, humor and gentleness of character and exceptional devotion to his patients have earned him a lasting memory in the hearts of all who knew him. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his bereaved family.

title: Quietly, Goldsboro Hums With Life Again
description: GOLDSBORO, Pa., April 5  Hard as it was to tell, life started returning to normal today in the town closest to the Three Mile Island nuclear plant.

title: Two Dancers Celebrate The Art of Partnering
description: Nancy Colahan and William Soleau came to New York to perform. They were lucky. Talented enough to draw attention from their first performances with Joyce Trisler's Danscompany, the two young dancers have grown with a young dance troupe and, in turn, have provided Miss Trisler with the material for choreoeranhic experimentation. The technique is there, but both dancers also perform with a special sense of self, a serenity that draws the eye on a busy stage. And in the two years they have danced together, Miss Colahan and Mr. Soleau have become unusually sympathetic partners. This weekend they will perform with Danscompany at the Roundabout Theater, most noticeably in Miss Trisler's new Concerto in E. Inspired by Romeo and Juliet, the pas de deux not only tells the Shakespearean story in abstract, compressed form, but also celebrates the art of partnering.

title: Restaurants
description: CONSIDERING the widespread interest here in new and unusual foods, and the wealth of subtle, enticing and varied dishes one finds while traveling through Mexico, it is difficult to understand why no Mexican restaurateur is willing to present a fuller range of that savory cuisine in New York. Throughout Mexico one finds delicate and subtle specialties based on fish and shellfish, chicken and pork, a staggering variety of exquisite soups, superb egg dishes and irresistible chilispiked pickled vegetables that appear as relishes on many tables.

title: STATE BUDGET VOTED AS ALBANY APPROVES I AID FOR ABORTIONS
description: ALBANY, Friday, April 6  The New York State Senate approved the final piece of a $12.6 billion state budget early this morning, ending a bitter battle over whether Medicaid funds should be used to pay for abortions for poor women.

title: The Region
description: BELLEVILLE, N.J. (UPI)  The Wife of a member of the Kearny school board was arrested on homicide charges following the fatal shooting of an offduty North Arlington police officer.

title: Customs Agent Gets 4 Years
description: LOS ANGELES, April 5 (UPI)  A United States Customs inspector who admitted stealing $5 million in jewelry from packages in the last 20 years has been sentenced to four and a half years in prisonand fined $6,000. Judge Irvin Hill of Federal District Court imposed the sentence on Francisco Terrendanio, 55 years old, of Whittier, who pleaded guilty to three counts of mail theft.

title: Reopening a Steel Plant in Ohio: Reaction to the Federal Rejection
description: When the news reached Youngstown last week that the Commerce Department had turned down the application of the Ecumenical Coalition, of Mahoning Valley for $295 million to loan guarantees to support the reopening of a steel plant in Campbell, Ohio, Marsha Peskin, coordinator of the coalition, remarked, I think the reason they turned us down is that they just don't like new Ideas.

title: An Art Critic Rediscovers The Riches of the Cloisters
description: QLUTE a few of us could say of the Cloisters what the American aphorist Logan Pearsall Smith once said of a great cultural institution in London: How often my soul visits the National Gallery, and how rarely I go there myself! It's disgraceful. We all know that the Cloisters is one of the great resources of New York. It has moreover a fairytale side that is a continual astonishment to the foreign visitor. How is it possible, he asks himself, that this patently European hill village should overlook the Hudson River, and this monastery garden, with its herbs authenticated by Charlemagne, be almost within earshot of Harlem? Our foreign visitors never get over it, and neither should we.

title: A STUART PORTRAIT OF WASHINGTON SOLD
description: A pair of portraits of George and Martha Washington by Gilbert Stuart, probably the bestknown pictures eller painted in America, will be sold by the Boston Athenaeum for $5 million to the National Portrait Gallery in Washington. Although owned by the Athenaeum, a private library founded in Boston in 1806, the portraits have been on loan for more than 100 years to the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, where they have hung in the main rotunda.

title: Art: Jean Dubuffet At Pace Gallery
description: JEAN DUBUFFET, born in 1901 in Le Havre, is the most celebrated latestarter in the annals of modern French painting. It was not until 1942 that he set up as a fulltime artist and began to produce the work by which we know his name today. Since that time. however. he has amply compensated for his early hesitations. Few artists of recent decades have been as copious in production as he.

title: KM&G Appoints A New York Chief
description: KM&G International, which has a president and chief executive officer running each of its offices, has just filled that slot at Ketchum, MacLeod & Grove, New York, with Henry J. Wasiak, 35yearold senior vice president of DKG Advertising.

title: Business and the Law
description: FIRST, in medieval times, there were trials by ordeal. Plowshares were heated until they glowed and were placed along a Course. The accused walked blindfolded and barefooted through the course. If there was no injury, the accused was acquitted.

title: Mets and Hebner Start Fast in 106 Victory Over Cubs
description: CHICAGO, April 5  The reconstructed New York Mets swept into another phase of their new era today with 45mileanhour wind gusts, minor league umpires and a 13hit offense that overpowered the Chicago Cubs, 106.

title: The New York Times/Barton SlIverman
description: After his scintillating summer of 1978, what could Ron Guidry do for an encore? How about opening the season of 79 with a perfect game, or at least a nohitter?

title: At the Movies
description: THE aroma of garlic, paprika and other pungent condiments hung heavily in Milos Forman's 30thfloor apartment on Central Park South. It was, he said, between pulls on a bottle of PilsnerUrquell, an olfactory souvenir of a fullbodied fish soup he had made himself for his breakfast a few hours before.

title: Brown Says Atom Pact With Soviet Will Save Money and Aid Stability
description: Secretary of Defense Harold Brown said yesterday that a new SovietAmerican treaty limiting strategic arms could save the United States as much as $30 billion on nuclear weaponry over the next 10 years.

title: Draths
description: HAROUTUNIANDr. Lulu Markarid, on April 3. 1979 at Johns Hopkiss Hospital, Balt., Md., devoted daughter of the late Rev. Garabed and Mrs. Zekiye Haroutunian of Aleppo and Beirut andsister of the late Rev. Joseph Haroutunian of Chicago and of Berkey Haroutunian of NYC. Survived by nephews Joseph and Peter Haroutunian and nieces Sophie Kahn and Rosig and Marie Sanossian. Beloved friend of her patients, her colleagues and of Dr. Catherine A. Neill. Funeral will be private. Memorial services at the Johns Hopkins Hospital on Friday. April 20 at 11:00AM.

title: Libyan Troops Supporting Amin Said to Flee Kampala, Leaving It Defenseless
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 5  Libyan troops allied with President Idi Amin have fled from the Ugandan capital of Kampala over the last 24 hours, leaving the city defenseless before an invading force of Tanzanians and Ugandan rebels, Western diplomats here said today.

title: Trade Talks Suffer New Setback
description: GENEVA, April 6  The European Economic Community and developing countries have failed to resolve their differences over cheap imports. As a result, the package of tradeliberalizing measures that negotiators from 98 nations are to wrap up here next week and submit to individual governments and the executive commission of the European Common Market for approval has shrunk.

title: Jersey Checking Gas Pricing
description: TRENTON, April 6  Governor Byrne said the President's message contained very little good news for anyone and said he was particularly concerned by indications that the plan for an excess profits tax on the oil companies would run into heavy Congressional opposition.

title: Koch, in Upper Manhattan, Acclaims SelfHelp Projects
description: Mayor Koch barnstormed through Washington Heights and Inwood yesterday, visiting several neighborhood selfhelp projects that he said would save these middleclass neighborhoods and show the rest of the city how it's done.

title: Dr. Irving Graef, 77, an Internist And Expert on Diabetes Control
description: Dr. Irving Graef, an internationally known authority on the control of, diabetes, died Thursday of cancer at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES JOB PROGRAM CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  The Senate Budget Committee cut $2.2 billion today from President Carter's program to combat unemployment by creating public service jobs. It was the largest single reduction the group had vet achieved.

title: Letter: On Savings Account Interest
description: To the Editor: I am pleased that you have noted the inherent unfairness of current Federal regulations on savings accounts [editorial April 3]. The rate ceilings that prevent banks from paying small savers the same high rates available to those who can afford $10,000 money market certificates are openly discriminatory and very restrictive. Largely because of such regulations; the elderly and others of moderate means are unable to earn enough on their savings to offset the steady erosion by inflation.

title: Weissenberg Concentrates On Schumann
description: In concluding a series of three recitals at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Alexis Weissenberg turned his attendon to the works of Scnumann. pianist played the Scenes of Childhood, Fantasy and Symphonic Etudes. A prodigious technician, he was able to show off his virtuosity to best advantage in the last piece, and his performance of it was remarkable and quite astonishing.

title: UGANDAN REBELS SAY CAPITAL IS ENCIRCLED
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 6  The Uganda National Liberation Front said tonight that its forces had encircled the Ugandan capital and are making steady progress in the march to Kampala from various directions.

title: Energy Stocks List Gains
description: Shares of selected energy companies with production concentrated in North America moved ahead in the stock market yesterday in response to President Carter's program for decontrolling domestic crudeoil prices.

title: U.S. AID TO PAKISTAN CUT AFTER EVIDENCE OF ATOM ARMS PUN
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  Intelligence reports indicating that Pakistan is acquiring the ability to make nuclear weapons led the Carter Administration today to cut off economic and military assistance.

title: Precious Metals Theft
description: LONDON, April 6 (Reuters)  The police are seeking a truck driver who. disappeared with $700,000 worth of precious metals shipped by a Massachusetts company. Policemen said 22 sealed drums containing gold, silver and platinum shipped to England 15y the Eastern Smelting and Refining Corporation of Lynn, Mass., were missing.

title: LEO A. DECMAN
description: The Rev. Leo A. Decman, a member of the Roman Catholic Maryknoll order who served as a missionary in South Korea for 20 years, died Wednesday of a heart attack in Seoul. He was 53 years old.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: PITTSBURGH, April 6  The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, today followed the lead of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's secondlargest steelmaker, and increased prices of steel used in the construction industry by 3 and 3 percent.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Your March 28 news article on violations of the Rent Stabilization Law In New York City totally missed an important point.

title: Teachers Ordered Back to Work
description: HAZELWOOD, Mo., April 6 (AP)  A temporary restraining order was issued today ordering striking teachers here back to work and prohibiting their strike on the ground that it is illegal under Missouri law. The teachers walked off the job Monday overa salary dispute, forcing the closure of all 26 schools.

title: Old Asphalt Plant Off F.D.R. Drive to Become a Recreation Center
description: An abandoned municipal asphalt plant at 91st Street and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive will be turned into a gymnasium, theater, arts studio and center for studying solar and wind technology, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: Ciulei Transfers Don Juan To PreWorld War I Era
description: WASHINGTON  Moliere's Don Juan, written hastily in a couple of weeks to replace the. banned Tartuffe. shows the signs of its haste.

title: The New York Times/Neel Boenzi
description: GALEFORCE WINDS LASH CITY: Buffeted by high winds yesterday, a woman tried to hail a taxi at 51st Street and Broadway. After she struggled to reach a lamppost, a strong gust swept her glasses off and into a trash basket, but she clung tenaciously to the pole. Finally, with the wind billowing her coat, she found refuge as a cab stopped. Page 27.

title: Electronic Mail Bid Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  The Federal Communications Commission rejected today an application by the Postal Service to offer a highvolume computerized mail service to businesses.

title: LrgeVolume Business
description: There was this petite woman called Phyllis Prinz and an averagesize man named Robert Malkin. One day they discovered that they both loved the gigantic replicas used by display companies to show off their products. neyMed to get together and pool their talent and experience  Mrs. Prinz had been design director for Pace Editions; Mr. Malkin was a partner in a plastic and metal fabrication company.

title: Subway Union Raises a Threat Of a Slowdown
description: The head of the union representing New York City transit workers yesterday threatened a job slowdown unless subway and bus workers were given more protection against crime.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Vance and Soviet Envoy To Meet on Arms Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  The State Department announced tonight that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance would hold his longawaited meeting with the Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, tomorrow morning in an apparent effort to conclude the treaty to limit strategic arms.

title: Music by Woods, Kohn, Harris, Zahler and Miss Cory in Concert
description: Even within the rather grim context of the League of Composers/International Society for Contemporary Music concerts, Thursday evening's offering of five contemporary works at the Carnegie Recital Hall was an especially dispiriting affair. Not that any one of tne pieces was particularly bad. But none stood out above the others, as sometimes happens at these concerts. Instead, we had an unrelieved sequence of earnest, dutiful, sincere and irredeemably uninteresting pieces.

title: Aunt of ExPresident Ford Dies
description: OMAHA, April 6 (AP)  Savilla King Pettis, an aunt of former President Gerald R. Ford, died yesterday at a hospital here. She was 90 years old. Mrs. Pettis was the widow of Edward F. Pettis, an officer and director of J. L. Brandeis Stores and a longtime civic figure here. Survivors include two daughters, a son, 13 grandchildren and 29 greatgrandchildren.

title: Reactor's Operator Once More Faces Fight on Rates
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 6  A Techicolor rubber turkeY dangles from a knotted piece of twine in a door of the 19thfloor suite of Pennsylvania's consumer advocate. At its neck is a placard on which is scrawled: If Henry Ford had had to worry about the safety risks, we never would have had automobiles. Walter Creitz, pres., MetEd, 32979.

title: South African Leader Is Expelled From Party
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, April (Reuters)  Cornelius P. Mulder, once a leading candidate to be Prime Minister of South Africa, was expelled from the ruling National Party today because of his role in the scandal now shaking the Government.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/ UPIClouds representing an Intense storm extend from the eastern lake region to New England. There are clear skies over the South extending northward through most of Plains States. Clouds are evident across the Pacific Northwest. Snow cover Is seen over the Cascades and the intermountain region.

title: Consumer Debt Rose In February
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) Consumers stepped up their borrowing slightly in February, but the increase remained below the record pace of last year, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Hoveida Believed Doomed in Iran; 6 More Die in Renewed Executions
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Saturday, April 7 The trial of Amir Abbas Hoveida, who was the Shah's Prime Minister for 13 years, may resume today, and his execution is a virtual certainty, according to a senior aide of Prime Minister Mehdi BazarRan.

title: Services for Gordon Parks Jr.
description: Memorial services for Gordon Parks Jr. will be held tomorrow at 10 A.M. in the United Nations Chapel, at 94th Street and First Avenue. Mr. Parks, a film maker, was killed last Tuesday in the crash of private plane in Nairobi, Kenya. The pilot and two other men involved in the film project were also killed. A spokesman for Mr. Parks's father, Gordon Parks Sr., the photographer and film maker, said that his son's body had been cremated and that some of the ashes would be brought to New York. Ted Baehr, a friend of the younger Parks, will preside at the service.

title: Boston Attorney Agent for Bird
description: BOSTON, April 6 (AP)  Larry Bird, the Indiana State basketball star, has selected Bob Woolf, a Boston attorney, from among more than 90 applicants to repre, sent him in negotiations with the Boston Celtics.

title: Betteanne Mitchell Is Married
description: Betteanne Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mitchell of Worcester, Mass., was married last evening to Dr. Walter H. Kuhnen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter T. Kuhnen of Hasbrouck Heights, N.J. The Rev. Aldan J. Walsh. Vice Officiolias of the Tribunal of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Worcester, performed the ceremony at the Assumption College Chapel in Worcester. The bride teaches in Worcester. Her husband will begin his residency in July at the New Jersey College of Medicine in Ncwark

title: News Summary
description: All aid to Pakistan was cut off by the Carter Administration when it learned from intelligence reports that Pakistan was acquiring the ability to build nuclear weapons. An amendment to the 1976 Nuclear Proliferation Act prohibits economic and military assistance to any country that obtains equipment for nuclear enrichment without placing it under international safeguards. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Congress Chiefs See Hard Battle On OilTax Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  Several Congressional leaders predicted today that President Carter faced a tough, perhaps losing, battle to gain enactment of a tax on the windfall profits that oil companies are expected to reap as a result of the lifting of price controls on domestic oil.

title: Soviet Man Reported Sentenced To Death for Attacks on Women
description: MOSCOW, April 6 (AP) A 32yearold habitual offender has been sentenced to death in connection with a series of attacks against Moscow women, the newspaper Vechernyaya Moskva said today.

title: The Laws of Lemon Issued to Yankees
description: Earlier this week, Manager Bob Lemon issued his team rules for the season. The rules, although mostly routine, could be especially interesting as the season progresses because Steinbrenner made it plain this spring that the manager's rules were to be followed. Such Obedience, he said, is necessary for discipline.

title: Buses Stoned to Protest South African Hanging
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, April 6 (AP)  Students stoned buses today in a black township here to protest the hanging of a black nationalist guerrilla. There was also sharp criticism of the execution by foreign governments.

title: Sports Today
description: Long Beach (Calif.) procelebrity race. Highlights and periodic updates of the Long Beach Grand. Prix qualifying time trials, will also be shown. (Television Channel 2, 5 P.M.)

title: A Schlesinger Victory Seen in Energy Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  Late last year, when the turmoil in Teheran cut off the flow of Iranian oil, James R. Schlesinger, Secretary of Energy, saw in the chaos a chance to generate a new sense of urgency about America's energy problems.

title: Bell Denies Phone Deal With Iran Was Dropped
description: American Bell International Inc. said yesterday that a large telecommunications contract to expand the Iranian telephone system had not been canceled, as was reported in an article last month in The New York Times.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar finished the week on an upbeat swing in most major currency markets yesterday, hitting a fourmonth high against the West German mark and scoring modesogains against most other European currencies.

title: You Got No Bread With One Meatball
description: It's all the fault of those nosy bureaucrats and their meddlesome regulations. If it wasn't for them and the union bosses and environmental freaks and newsmedia manipulators who whoop it up for them, we'd have no problems: no unemployment, no inflation, no energy crisis, no welfare chiselers, no high taxes. If only they would let the American freeenterprise system alone to do its thing, all our national difficulties would fold their tents and silently steal away.

title: Erhardt Gets Patriots Post
description: FOXBORO, Mass., April 6 (UPI)  Ron Erhardt was named head coach of the New England Patriots today, replacing Chuck Fairbanks, who officially returned to college football Monday after a fourmonth dispute.

title: Dance: Joyce Trisler Company Offers By Dawn's Early Light
