description: Continuing its fifth anniversary season at the Roundabout Theater, the Joyce Trisler Danscompany offered the premiere of Miss Trisler's By Dawn's Early Light on Thursday evening. Set to songs by Stephen Foster, the work took its music very seriously.

title: Boeing Objects To Times's Article
description: The Boeing Company took strong exception to an article in The New York Times yesterday on the outlook for Boeing's new 767 aircraft. The article reported from Seattle the view of industry sources that Boeing was being forced to rethink the future of the 767 model in view of the sales success of the competing European A310 Airbus.

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 6, 1979

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, April 6  The start of a campaign for nationwide elections in Italy is beng disrupted by a wave of strikes.

title: 2d WNET Public Meeting On April 17 in Newark
description: The second of WNETTV's public board meetings is scheduled for April 17 in Newark.

title: Eleanore Eggleton Bride of Physician
description: Eleanore D. Eggleton of Bronxville, N.Y., widow of Charles V. Eggleton, was married at the West Center Congregational Church in Bronxville yesterday to Dr. Colgate Phillips, a widower, of Cleverdale, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Roy Buchell, senior minister of the church, performed the ceremony, was assisted by the Rev. LaMont Robinson of the Harrisena Community Church in Glens Falls, N.Y.

title: Ike Film to Be Telecast By ABC May 3, 4 and 6
description: Ike, a madefortelevision dramatization of the wartime experiences of Dwight D. Eisenhower, will be broadcast early next month on ABCTV.

title: Deaths
description: DOLANEugene P. On April 6, 1979, beloved husband of Lucile, devoted father of Ellen Miller and Dr. Rory Dolan, loving grandfather of Jennifer and Christina. Regional Eastern Sales Manager for Dayco Corp. Graduate of the University of Notre Dame. Friends may call at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street. Garden City, Saturday and Sunday 2.5 and 79 P.M. Funeral Mass on Monday 10:15 A.M. at Notre Dame Church, N.H.P. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Deaths
description: MURPHYThomas J. on April 6, 1979. Beloved brother of Mary T. John and the late Elizabeth Cahill. Uncle of Kevin Cahill. Reposing at the Jamie Funeral Home. 11126 Northern Blvd., Flushing. Mass of Christian Burial St. Michael's Church, Monday, 11 A.M. Interment Mt. St. Mary Cemetery.

title: Around the Nation
description: CINCINNATI, April 6 (AP) Two outofcourt settlements totaling nearly $6.7 million were announced. today in connection with the Beverly FrillsSupper Club fire in which 165 people died in 1977.

title: Components for APlant Are Sabotaged in France
description: LA SEYNESURMER, France, April (AP)  Saboteurs slipped into an industrial plant early today. and bombed nuclear equipment bound for Iraq and two other countries, Government officials said.

title: Milwaukee Brews a Challenger
description: For the Milv;aukee Brewers, the magic number is 161 any combination of Brewer victories or Yankee defeats adding up to 161 will assure the Brewers the American League Fast title. Which means it's a little early in the season to jump to any conclusions. But the Brewers, who finished only 6 games behind the Yankees last season, have lumped into serious consideration as a challenger. Even before their rude knockout of Ron Guidry during a 51 triumph over the Yankees in the season opener Thursday, the Brewers manager, Cieorge Bamberger, had been saying that his team was as good as the Yankees are. And their third baseman, Sal Bando, rates the Brewers as having better hitting and more depth than the Oakland A's, who won three consecutive World Series champlonships before Charles 0. Finley let them scatter in the wind.

title: Pennsylvania Governor Doubts Plant to Reopen
description: HARRISBURG, Pa. April 6 (UPI) Gov. Dick Thornburgh said tonight that he has deep and serious doubts about whether the Three Mile Island nuclear plant would be reopened and whether nuclear power should be expanded in Pennsylvania.

title: Nets Lose by 3 In Overtime
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 6 (UPI) Phil Ford and Otis Birdsong scored two baskets each in the final 2% minutes of overtime tonight to give the Kansas City Kings a 117114 victory over the New Jersey Nets.

title: Blair Completes Deal
description: Blair Broadcasting of California Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of John Blab. & Company, said it had completed the acquisition of the Central California Communications Corporation, licensee of California VHF television stations KSBWTV, which telecasts to the SalinasMonterey area, and KSBYTV, which serves the San Luis Obispo, Santa Maria and Santa Barbara area.

title: The City
description: New York City must provide a reasonable standard of police protection for subway passengers, Justice Arnold G. Freiman of State Supreme Court in (Manhattan ruled yesterday. He refused to dismiss a $6.5 million negligence suit brought by the wife of a Long Island man who was slain in a passageway last July 27.

title: Carey Signs Pay Rise for Legislators
description: ALBANY, April 6  Governor Carey tonight signed bills raising the pay of legislators and state officials and providing emergency aid to Brooklyn Jewish Hospital.

title: Milk Shows Slight Radiation
description: Very, very low levels of radioactive iodine have been found in samples of milk from Pennsylvania and New Jersey taken off the shelves of stores in New York City, a spokesman for the State Health Department said yesterday, emphasizing that this constituted no public health concern whatsoever.

title: Striking OTB Clerks Warned of Sanctions
description: Victor Gotbaum, president of District 37 of the municipal employees union, addressing a meeting of Offtrack Betting Corporation workers at district headquarters, 140 Park Place. Despite warnings by their lawyer and Mr. Gotbaum that they faced legal sanctions, the members of Local 2021 rejected a move to retreat from a $9anhour wage demand that has stalled contract negotiations. The more than 1,000 members at the meeting were apparently unaware that Justice Herbert Shapiro of State Supreme Court, citing the ban on strikes public employees, signed a tempopry injunction ordering them back to work.

title: William Neale Roach Dies at 66; Ran 4 Democratic Conventions
description: William Neale Roach, manager of four Democratic national conventions, from 1944 to 1956, died Wednesday at Suburban Hospital in Montgomery County, Maryland. He was 66 years old.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Friday. April 6, 1979.

title: Vienna Boys to Sing for Easter
description: VIENNA, April 7 (AP)  The Vienna Boys Choir, silenced last Christmas by enforcement of an old childlabor law, will be singing again this Easter thanks to legislation recently enacted by the Austrian Parliament.

title: Macy's Liquor. Shop Yields to Men's Wear
description: Macy's wine and liquor shop, once one of the most important retail stores in that trade and the holder of New York State retail license No. 1, closed its doors today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY,AgrIl 7 OCEANIC (Home). Lett Nassau AgrIl 5; duel) A.M. at W. 55th Street. ARRIVING TOMORROW, AprIl I QUEEN ELIZABETH 2 (Cunard). Lett Port Everglades Awl, 6; due A.M. et W. 55th Street. ROYAL VIKING (Revel Viking Line). Lett Port Everglades AgrIl 7; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Streeet.

title: Plane Passengers Prayed But Expected to Be Killed
description: DETROIT, April 6  The Federal Aviation Administrator call it a miracle, and the passengers on TWA flight 841 say, Amen!

title: Jobs Up in March, Jobless Rate Steady
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  Employment rose smartly again in March and the unemployment rate remained unchanged, indicating, as Senator William Proxmire said today, that the economy is still steaming ahead.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Several Congressional leaders said President Carter faces tough, perhaps losing, battle to enact a tax on windfall profits oil companies. Some other Congressmen disagreed. [Page 1.]

title: About New York
description: In the drab meandering of military people at Fort Wadsworth, no one bothers to salute, so it already seems a shame that the city will lose the installation under the Pentagon's latest economizing plans. Any place that relaxed is sorely needed by the city.

title: Pakistani Police Crack Down on Bhutto Mourners
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 5  The police cracked down roughly today on people protesting the hanging of former Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto, but angry crowds still managed to set fire to three Government buildings in Lahore and cause damage in cities, towns and villages throughout the country.

title: Helena Rubinstein Sold To a Japanese Concern
description: Helena Rubinstein Inc., one of the most famous nam's in cosmetics, is to be sold to a Japanese soap and chemical company, under an agreement announced yesterday by the ColgatePalmolive Company, the parent of Rubinstein.

title: In Key West, the Latest Invaders Have Set Off a Backlash
description: KEY WEST, Fla.  This place is really wild, the young man in blue jeans and a tank top undershirt was telling a newly arrived acquaintance one night recently on Duval Street, the main thoroughfare here. You can do anything and everything.

title: China Sets Vietnam Peace Talks
description: PEKING, April 6 (Reuters)  China said today it would start peace talks with Vietnam next week, provided that no further complication is created by the Vietnamese side.

title: French Auto Expansion Set
description: PARIS, April 6 (AP)  France's two largest auto makers, Renault and PeugeotCitroen, announced plans today to expand in the depressed steel regions of northeastern France in a move seen as an attempt to block possible construction of a plant by the Ford Motor Company.

title: Carter Package Hailed Abroad
description: PARIS, April 6  Leaders of Western Europe and Japan welcomed President Carter's new energy package today but made clear their view that the new measures were no more than they had a right to expect from a United States Government that preached energy conservation without practicing it.

title: The Region
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I.  Representative Thomas J. Downey turned over the leadership of the Long Island Coalition for Fair Broadcasting yesterday to a nonpolitician, saying the move was necessary to assure New York City television stations that its goals were not political.

title: Connecticut Costs Assessed
description: HARTFORD, April 6  Gov. Ella T. Grasso estimated that the impact of total decontrol on the state could be as much as $260 million a year.

title: Boat People Reach Philippines
description: MANILA, April 6 (Reuters)  A boat carrying 50 Vietnamese refugees has reached the island of Palawan despite Philippine naval blockade, official sources said today.

title: As Easter Approaches, a Harvest of Orchids
description: EAST PATCHOGUE, L.I.  It is spring and, while most Long Island farmers have not yet even begun to plant their crops, I. William Bianchi Inc. has begun its biggest harvest of the year.

title: 10Day Notice Ordered On Payments to Iran
description: An appeals court ruled yesterday that the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company must give two American telecommunications companies 10 days notice before honoring letters of credit to Iranian banks.

title: Palmer Pitches ThreeHitter as Orioles Turn Back White Sox, 53
description: BALTIMORE, Apri1.6 (AP)  Jim Palmer pitched a threehitter and Rich Dauer's tworun single keyed a threerun Baltimore rally in the. second inning as the Orioles defeated the Chicago White Sox, 53, in the baseball opener for both teams today.

title: Chapman, Orosco Star in Debuts
description: CHICAGO, April 6  When the deed was done and the Mets were kings for day, Joe Torre strode into the locker room at Wrigley Field Thursday and awarded copies of the lineup card to the two rookie prodigies who may help the Mets to forget.

title: Auto Insurance: Rises Speed Up
description: FOR some motorists, particularly those with teenage children of driving age, the cost of auto insurance can sometimes rival the cost of purchasing a car itself. It often seems that the only thing consumers can count on from their insurance brokers is the word that auto premiums are going up again.

title: But Analysts Doubt the Attacks by Cambodia Guerrillas Will Halt
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 6  A major Vietnamese offensive in western Cambodia has seriously disrupted the continued resistance to Vietnamese occupation by forces loyal to the regime of Pol Pot, the routed Prime Minister, Western analysts have concluded.

title: Susan Angela Manganaro Bride of Andrew Janszky
description: Susan Angela Manganaro and Andrew B. Janszky were married yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. The Rev. Paul E. Dinter performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Miss Julie by Ned Rorem Is Revived by Lyric Opera
description: One problem with American opera is that new works are judged hastily after one performance and rarely given other chances to prove themselves. Ned Rorem's Miss Julie suffered this fate after its premiere at the New York City Opera in 1965, and the opera instantly disappeared. Because Mr. Korem 1S a composer or quality, seems only fair to give Miss Julie second hearing after 19 years, and that is what the New York Lyric Opera Company is doing this weekend at New York University's University Theater on West Fourth Street.

title: EventsToday
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Wagner's Der Filegende Hoilex:oder. 2:30; Tchaikovsky's. Eugene Onegine B.

title: Lamhut Dancers' Mirage Blanc'
description: Phyllis Lamhut is probably the bestknown choreographer in the Alwin NikolaisMurray Louis lineage. Their influence is evident, but Miss Lamhut has developed her own voice in the 29 years she has been choreographing. That idiom shone through in two works Thursday, when the Phyllis Lamhut Dance Company performed at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: Lufthansa Theft Suspect Indicted for Earlier Robbery
description: Louis Werner, the Lufthansa employee already charged with setting up the $5.8 million robbery in the airline's cargo terminal last Dec. 11, was indicted yesterday for a theft in 1976 in which a shipment of $22,000 worth of foreign currency disappeared from Lufthansa's cargo building.

title: Notes on People
description: Out at Kennedy International Airport yesterday, two people waited for a plane to Liberia, and maybe they were Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California and the singer Linda Ronstadt. A certain degree of hesitancy is required, because no paid observer could get near enough to the two to confirm their identities.

title: 8 Reactors by Babcock &
description: WASINGTON, April 6  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission announced today that eight nuclear reactors made by the manufacturer of the severely crippled Three Mile Island power station in Pennsylvania would be permitted to continue generating electricity at full power.

title: Seminars Lure Eager Investors
description: LOS ANGELES Concern about the performance of traditional investments and the deteriorating value of the dollar appear to be the reason why increasing numbers of people are willing to pay stiff fees to attend investment seminars.

title: Opera: Workshop's La Finta Giardiruera
description: There are at least two ways in which La Finta Giardinlera, the opera that Mozart composed for Munich at age 18, might plausibly be approached. Depending upon how seriously one takes the libretto, it might be thought of as comicserious work in the tradition that was to reach its peak with Le Nozze di Figaro and Cosi fan tutte, or as seriouscomic effort on the road toward Don Giovanni. What seemed clear, however, after Thursday night's operaworkshop production at the Juilliard School was that it cannot profitably be treated as collegiate camp or Animal House burlesque.

title: Equipment Fails Twice; Reactor Work Goes On
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., April 6  Two equipment failures occurred today as technical experts worked to bring the damaged Three Mile Island nuclear reactor under full control, but Federal officials said that the consequences of the malfunctions were not serious.

title: Fed Warned on Subpoena of Data
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  A House subcommittee chairman said today that his panel would issue a sweeping subpoena for Federal Reserve documents after the agency refused to produce material requested by the subcommittee.

title: D. THEODORE BERK
description: D. Theodore Berk, senior member of the board of directors of Lightolier Inc., manufacturer of lighting fixtures, died Thursday on the way to his Manhattan, home following a vacation in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 74 years old.

title: For Creation of a Council of the Pacific
description: WASHINGTON  Ready or not, America faces a future increasingly linked to the nations of the Pacific. Unfortunately, that future may continue tobe beset with the frictions and hostilities that historically have contradicted the meaning of the word after which this planet's largest body of water is named.

title: Justice Dept. Backs Busing in Columbus and Dayton
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)  In major statement of principle in school desegregation cases, the Government today defended courtordered plans that require extensive busing of school children in Columbus and Dayton Ohio The victims of purposeful school discrimination are entitled to a remedy that eliminates all vestiges of prior discrimination, the Justice Department said in 72page brief filed with the Supreme Court. A systemwide remedy will accorriplish this end, the brief went on, arid school officials who believe a more limited decree will remedy the violations have the burden of proving that such a decree will effectively do so.

title: The State's New Budget
description: ALBANY, April 6  It was not quite so simple as win, lose and draw, but the new state budget proVided a victory for Governor Carey, gave something of a battering to the new Assembly Speaker, Stanley Fink, and accommodated the limited wishes Of the Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: RollCall Votes In State Senate
description: ALBANY, April 6  Following are the roll call votes by which the State Senate this week adopted the local assistance budget. The first column is its vote on the adoption of the budget this morning, with money for Medicaid abortions intact. The second is the vote earlier this week on an amendment to cut off Medicaid money for abortions except in cases in which the mother's life or physical health was in danger or where she was a victim of rape or incest:

title: Herman H. Maass Is Dead at 81; Headed Security National Bank
description: Herman Henry Maass, the retired chairman and chief executive officer of the nowdefunct Security National Bank, died Thursday at his home in Massapequa, L.I. He was 81 years old.

title: Chemetron, BASF Tie Challenged
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)  The Federal Trade Commission issued a complaint today challenging the acquisition of the Chemetron Corporati'n's pigment division by the BASF Wyandotte Corporation.

title: Chavez Fights To Bar Defeat
description: LOS ANGELES, April 6  Cesar Chavez, whose success in organizing a farm labor union was one of the great victones in the American labor movement, is discovering that there is a difference between leading a social cause and running a union.

title: AmerMex, After Villa
description: TUCSON, Ariz.  Columbus, New Mexico, three miles north of the Mexican border, recently celebrated  or rather commemorated  the 63rd'anniversary of Pancho Villa's predawn raid.

title: ConfUsion Abounds on 0il Tax
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  From the White House to Capitol Hill, confusion abounded today about the specifics of the new windfall profits tax on oil producers that President Carter wants to accompany the gradual decontrol of domestic crude oil prices.

title: Carter News Parley Tuesday
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)  President Carter will hold a news conference at 4 P.M. next Tuesday, Tody Powell, the White House press secretary, said today. It will be available for live television and radio broadcast.

title: Still Separate in North Carolina
description: The dispute between Washington and the University of North Carolina over desegregating the state's college system has dragged on far too long. It began in 1970 when the NAACP Legal Defense Fund filed suit to force several Southern states, including North Carolina, to integrate their colleges. A Federal court ordered them to end their dual systems of higher education or face the loss of Federal funds.

title: Coffee Prices Up, Traders End Talks
description: LONDON, April 6  The executive board of the International Coffee Organization ended a week's meeting here today without taking any action to stabilize world coffee prices because the problem bad solved itself, at least temporarily.

title: Plane's Dive Is Laid to Malfunctioning Wing Flap
description: The malfunction of a device similar to a flap on the forward edge of the right wing is considered the most likely explanation for the terrifying roll and dive of Trans World Airlines plane Wednesday evening.

title: Economic Adviser Backs Regulatory Reform Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)  President Carter's chief economic adviser told Congress today that the Administration's proposal to revise the operations of regulatory agencies would not deprive officials of their ability to exercise judgment on questions of health and safety.

title: Columbia's Engineering Faculty Agrees to Shelve Reactor Project
description: Columbia University's engineering faculty agreed yesterday to a request by the school's president not to activate a small nuclear reactor on the Morningside Heights campus.

title: Jobless Rate Up in New York and Lower in Jersey
description: The rate of unemployment in New York State and in New York City went up in March while the rate in New Jersey dropped, Herbert Bienstock, the regional Commissioner of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 6, 1979

title: PROFITS Dow Jones Net Up 15% to 10.7 Million
description: Dow Jones &; Co., the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, yesterday reported firstquarter net income of $10.7 million, equal to 69 cents a share, up 15 percent from $9.3 million, or 60 cents share, for the initial three months last year. Revenues climbed 24.6 percent to 599.2 million.

title: Yankees Limit Access Of Reporters to Clubhouse
description: The Yankees rescinded yesterday the unlimited access of reporters to the team clubhouse following games, two days after the players agreed to the nolimit rule for male and female reporters and a day after the Yankees opened their season and their clubhouse to all reporters.

title: Reo. Lona Suffers Heart Attack
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI)  Representative Gillis W. Long, 55yearold Democrat of Louisiana, suffered a heart attack yesterday and was admitted to Bethesda Naval Hospital, where he is reported resting comfortably, his office said today.

title: White House to Recruit Consumers To Watch Prices in Inflation Fight
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  The White House called today for a citizens campaign against inflation and said consumers would be recruited to monitor prices in an expansion of the Administration's effort to reduce inflationary pressures in the national economy.

title: Joe Ely, HonkyTonk Singer
description: Joe Ely is a distinctive and wholly believable honkytonk singer; he could probably build a long and successful career on beerhall ballads. But Mr. Ely, who was at the Other End Thursday night, has staked his claim to a wide range of vernacular music from the American South. He comes from Lubbock, in West Texas, a town that is perhaps best known as Buddy Holly's birthplace, so it is not surprising that he sings rockabilly very well indeed. West Texas is also a stronghold of western swing, that unlikely but delightful hybrid of country, jazz, blues and Cajun music. And Mr. Ely and his band swing some, too.

title: Murderer of a Writer Is Implicated in Cases Of Unsolved Slayings
description: Paul Bateson, the convicted killer of Addison Verrill, a New York writer, was sentenced yesterday to from 20 years to life, and the prosecutor in the case told the judge that Mr. Bateson had boasted to an acquaintance that Mr. Bateson had also killed other men.

title: Mortgage Rates at Peak
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  Mortgage rates on newly built, singlefamily homes averaged 10.32 percent in early March. the highest level on record.

title: Death
description: BARDITCHBerdaniin. The Hewlett East Rockaway Jewish Center re cords with sorrow the passing of th father of its esteemed member Helen Austin, and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family.

title: Impact of Decontrol Plan Is Chief Tristate Concern
description: ALBANY, April 6  President Carter's plan to lift price controls on domestic crude oil could result to a significant increase in New York State's energy costs, ranging from roughly $139 million to twice that amount for the rest of this year, New York State's Energy Commissioner. James L. Larocca. said today.

title: 150 Flee When a Fire Threatens To Explode Tank of Butane Gas
description: SULPHUR, La., April 6 (AP) A roaring fire that threatened to explode 30,000gallon tank of butane gas forced the evacuation of 150 people from a milewide area before it was snuffed out today, 11 hours after it started.

title: Flames Romp, 92, Close In on Rangers
description: ATLANTA, April 6  The Atlanta Flames, playing like a battalion of tanks against a rifle platoon, took the Rangers by storm tonight and trounced them by 92.

title: The Political Fallout in New York
description: The frightening accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania has had some political fallout in New York. It has already disrupted a promis ing plan for the nuclear waste storage site in West Valley, near Buffalo. Just two weeks ago Governor Carey's Energy Commissioner, James Larocca, said the state had struck a bargain with the Federal Government: New York would accept more nuclear waste in the short run and the Federal Government would clean it up in the long run.

title: Teamster Talks Collapse; Prolonged Strike Feared
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  Talks between negotiators for the teamsters union and the trucking industry collapsed again today, raising the possibility of prolonged and economically disruptive shutdown'of the nation's trucking industry.

title: Help for the Incompetent Students
description: The New York State Board of Regents has stuck by its decision to require all high school students to pass competency tests before graduation this year and to make the exams even tougher three years hence. Now attention needs to be focused on the seniors  7,800 in New York City alone  who have yet to pass and therefore face the prospect of not graduating.

title: Survival Is Key Concern of Paper in South Africa Scandal
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 5  When South Africa's most controversial newspaper changed buildings recently, the businessnews department posted a sign in the corridor identifying its new quarters. Department of Finance, declared the carefully handlettered sign. Underneath, in brackets, another hand had added: Sorry, but Senator Horwood is out.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BOSTON, April 6 (AP)  Dennis Eckersley, the top Boston Red Sox pitcher, officially joined baseball'smillionaire club today by signing a fiveyear contract extension for a reported $2.8 million starting in 1980.

title: COMMODMES Prices of Soybeans Surge On Brazil Crop Rumors
description: Soybean futures rose sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly on speculation that Brazil, the main competitor of the United States in world soybean markets. may he barvesting a smallerthanexpected.crop.

title: Blair Accepts Likely Departure
description: Back from the dead, Paul Blair said with a laugh when he learned he was in the Yankees openingday lineup. I'm back from the dead.

title: FULL REDUCTION BY 81 ASKED
description: ALBANY, April 6  The leaders of the New York State Assembly and. Senate agreed today to propose a reduction in the state's maximum incometax rate, just hours after the. Legislature finally ap.. proved the last part of the state's $12.6 billion budget.

title: TV: NBC Nightly News Seems to Be Losing Ground in the Ratings
description: After years of maintaining a flat, or unchanging, pattern, the audience ratings for the television networks evening newscasts have shifted during the last few weeks in a manner that hints of a possible impending crisis for the NBC Nightly News Long in second place, WIG always within striking distance of the lead held by the CBS Evening News with Walter Cronkite, the NBCTV newscast with John Chancellor and David Brinkley recently has declined about three share points below its usual audience level and is being challenged seriously, for the first time, by ABCTV's World News Tonight.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 24.

title: 3 Women Lead Golf By a Shot
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 6 There's nothing like a pot of gold to bring out the best in people, and the second round of the richest of all women's sports events proved to be no exception today.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WQXR. Symphony in C, Haydn; Le Temple de la Gloire, Suite, Rameau; Overture to Der Vierjaluige Posten, Schubert; Concerto Russe, Lebo; Malaga from Iberia, Albeniz; Prelude to Act III from Ivan The Terrible, RimskyKorsakov.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 21.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON PATENTS granted this week to Americans and foreigners reflect the worldwide research being conducted on nuclear energy. A control rod assembly invented for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation is intended for use in breeder reactors, which are still under development. A breeder reactor, besides generating nuclear energy, creates additional fuel by producing more fissionable material than it consumes.

title: Prague a Haven and a Trap For Expatriates of the Left
description: PRAGUE  The line at the Greek Consulate on Wenceslas Square was 20 deep half an hour before its opening at 10 A.M. There was a 67yearold partisan warrior from the Greek civil war of 1949, sons and daughters of other partisans and husbands and wives of still more.

title: Bridge:
description: The Long Island Regional Championships continue today at Hofstra University, in Hempstead, L.I., with the open pairs at 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M. The Swiss teams event, which concludes the tournament tomorrow, is scheduled for noon and 7 P.M. (The times given in this column yesterday were wrong.)

title: 7 Racing Figures Sentenced in Fixes
description: Five jockeys and two trainers, convicted last December of fixing horse races at Garden State Park four years ago, received sentences yesterday of up to three years in prison.

title: Nuclear Critics Plan Political Moves and Mass Protests
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  Critics of the nation's nuclear policy, galvanized by the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear generating plant near Harrisburg, Pa., and other recent developments, are preparing a series of legislative and political moves that they hope will capture a new mood of caution throughout the United States.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EXODUS INVITATION Handel's The Messiah is often done, but the public is seldom given a chance to hear the composer's Israel in Egypt, let alone join in the singing of the lesserknown oratorio. You can tomorrow afternoon, starting at 3 o'clock at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association, near Lexington Avenue, as Amy Kaiser conducts the Y Chorale in a rendition of the colorful music depicting the Biblical version of Israel's deliverance from captivity. The $3.50 admission includes use of the music.

title: EarlyCamp Giants Start From Scratch
description: EAST RUTHERFORD,N.J., April 6  Johnny Perkins, the receiver, came off the field after morning practice at Giants Stadium today and said, I've learned more in one day than I did all last year.

title: CON EDISON GRANTED RATE RISE OF 6.67%
description: The New York State Public Service Commission yesterday awarded the Consolidated Edison Company an increase in its rates amounting to $158.1 million year, or 6.67% over its present revenues. This is $70 million less than the utility applied for last May, but far more than consumer officials called warranted.

title: Books of The Times A Second Naivet
description: I KNOW YOUR HEART, MARCO POLO. By Henry Brunet'. 132 pages. Knopf. $7.95.

title: Herbie Cried, Hit the Immie and Win 10!
description: Sometime in May, Herbie Schnitzer would mysteriously disappear from the stickball game on West 180th Street in the Bronx and reappear about an hour later carrying a cigar box.

title: San Antonio, With MexicanAmericans in Power, Is at a Crossroad
description: SAN ANTONIO, April 3  The scene was straight out of the rich tableau of American ethnic politics, a tableau that stretches back to the Irish precincts of 19thcentury Boston, the Jewish and Italian districts of New York, the Polish and Hungarian wards of Cleveland and the black precincts of Detroit.

title: Barahona, Locicero Win Forum Fights
description: Although he was knocked down in the final round, Marco Barahona, a Nicaraguan lightweight, scored a majority decision over Ralph Racine, a hard hitter from Buffalo, in a 10round bout at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum last nieht.

title: Braswell Song Night, Dream World at Westbeth
description: John Braswell's Song Night in the City, a medley of popular songs and dancing, shimmers on stage at Westbeth, conjuring a magical dream world that is both elegant and romantic. Mr. Braswell, who conceived, directed and designed this show and also trained many or the performers who appear in it, never forgets that popular music is made for lovers. Song Night evokes memories of school proms, piano bar', jazz clubs, ballrooms and discos. The show draws on a diversity of styles, moods and tempos  and everything merges into a silky top hat of an evening.

title: Cut Cable Delays OTC Quotations
description: An accidental cut in a main telephone cable line prevented brokerage firms in the East from receiving automated quotations on overthecounter stocks yesterday morning.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In early editions of The Times yesterday an article on the New York State budget incorrectly identified Rosalyn Udow as a lobbyist against abortion. She is director of government policy affairs for Planned Parenthood of New York City, a group that favors Medicaid funds for abortions.

title: Pretoria Is Preparing New Restraints on the Press
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 5  Ever since confrontations between riot policemen and black demonstrators threw South Africa into turmoil three years ago, newspapers here have been bracing themselves for an assault on their tenuous freedoms.

title: Hamlet Sues Utility Over Storage of Nuclear Waste
description: The tiny South Jersey riverbank hamlet that will have one of the country's largest nucleargenerating complexes by the mid1980's filed suit yesterday against the facility's plans to enlarge its storage capacity for usedup, highly radioactive fuel rods.

title: In the Heart of Rio, a Busy and Amiable ArabJewish. Oasis of Shops
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 6  In the middle of downtown Rio de Janeiro there is a bazaarlike network of streets where Arab and Jewish merchants have created a common oasis. They call it SAARA, the Portuguese word for Sahara.

title: Associated Press
description: Associated Press

title: Associated Press
description: A TOURIST LEAVES HIS MARK ON PEKING WALL: Pasted above the Chinese posters on a wall near Tian An Men Square in central Peking was an I V New York sticker, evidently expressing the sentiments of a foreign visitor.

title: What They're Saying
description: Dennis Eckersley, after agreeing to a multimillion dollar contract with the Boston Red Sox: These days, they pay you for potential. They were smart to sign me. I would have been thinking about it while I was pitching if they hadn't.

title: MAN ON THE SPOT
description: The weathered face, framed by the soft red and white checked cotton of an Arab kaffiyeh, belongs to a survivor. The once cocky young smile circulates these days only on stamps and bank notes in the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. The dark eyes look sadder, more pensive. The clipped military mustache has given way to a full beard that seems excessively gray for its owner's 43 years.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The third set of the 1980 Olympiad coins from Moscow is now ready. The theme of this whole set is altius, or higher. (This was one of the ideals set up for contestants by Baron de Coubertin, the founder of the modern Games  citius, altius, fortius  swifter. higher. stronger.)

title: The Constituency for Getting Out of Vietnam Is Now Part of the Constituency
description: WASHINGTON  Twelve years ago, as the Vietnam War was intensifying, President Johnson sent three C130 transports flying off to the Congo, caught up in one of its episodic civil wars. That seemingly insignificant commitment of American military power gave an important nudge to the swinging pendulum of power between the executive branch and Congress.

title: How Hague Fell:
description: JERSEY CITY

title: Platonic Love
description: IN classical Greece, the relationship between males was of such cultural significance that any historian who failed to remark upon it should be unworthy of the name. And yet this phenomenon has been all but Ignored. That Jakob Burckhardt's four ex-

title: On Language
description: Politicians of all stripes and lilts like to put on a grim look and warn the Soviet Union that the United States will not stand idly by if the Soviets seek to take advantage of the turmoil in Iran.

title: Nassau and Suffolk Split by School Aid
description: AN unusual struggle over state aid that pitted many Nassau school districts against Suffolk districts will be fought out in the courts, even though the Legisla- ture attempted last week to smooth the split between socalled wealthy and poor school districts by giving almost all of them a piece of the schoolaid pie.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Herbert Benson is a well-respected Harvard medicine man who has become famous through his identification of the socalled relaxation re- sponse, achieved generally through meditative techniques and practices. In The Mind/ Body Effect he deals with what is probably the most important shift in modern medicine in America  the move away from technology and toward a more holistic approach. Books, seminars and papers are currently being produced prolifically on the subject by many experts in health and psychology. Stanley Reiser's book, Medicine and the Reign of Technology, is perhaps the most notable, but it is largely a specialized field.

title: Many Swedes Saw Holocaust
description: STOCKHOLM, April 7 (AP)  More than half of Sweden's population of eight million watched the American television series Holocaust last month, according to a poll published this week. The poll found that viewers rated the series highly.

title: 1975 Baltimore Nuclear Mistake Called Similar to Pennsylvania's
description: BALTIMORE, April 7 (AP)  An emergency cooling system at the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company's nuclear generating plant at Calvert Cliffs was accidentally shut down in 1975, a mistake virtually identical with the error at Pennsylvania's Three Mile Island plant 10 days ago, The Baltimore Sun said in today's issue.

title: Man Is Apparent Suicide At Police Headquarters
description: A 23-year-old Queens man apparently hanged himself at Police Headquarters early yesterday following his arrest in Greenwich Village for disorderly conduct, the police said.

title: Size Limits for Letters Co Into Effect July 15
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)  The Postal Service says that on July 15 it will put into effect size standards that will mean the end of small invitations sent through the mail and may cut the numberof large greeting cards.

title: Canadiens Triumph As Mondou Scores 3
description: MONTREAL, April 7 (UPI)  Pierre Mondou scored three goals for the second time this season and Guy Lafleur added two goals and four assists tonight as the Montreal Canadiens routed the Washington Capitals, 103.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: The Royal Lipizzan Stallions will be the feature attraction this afternoon at Princeton University's Jadwin Gymnasium. The performance, which begins at 3 o'clock, will include the Lipizzans renowned dressage routines, along with a number, of lighthearted moments.

title: A New Ft. Lee? Some Say It Is Happening In Edgewater
description: EDGEWATER, N.J.  Beneath the jagged skyline of Fort Lee, with its towering glass and brick apartment houses, beneath the gray cliffs of the Palisades, stands the borough of Edge.: water. population 4.987.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: LETTERS
description: Martha Foley

title: Job Corps Marks Its Birth As U.S. Weighs Its Value
description: MORGANFIELD, Ky., April 7  The Breckenridge Job Corps Center celebrated. the 15th anniversary of the Job Corps program yesterday and about 60 Federal officials and private consultants flew here, not to celebrate but to begin another of an exhaustive series of evaluations of the job training program.

title: Notes: A Varied Bouquet of Springtime
description: Spring is a wonderful time to kick up your heels, pick posies and fall in love again. It is also a good time to fly a kite, toss a boomerang, take a hike in the woods . . . or go off on a tangent and take a trip.

title: U.S. and Soviet Are Described As Equal in Earthquake Research
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)  The United States and the Soviet Union have achieved virtual parity in studying earthquakes, says Dr. Robert Wesson, chief of the United States Geological Survey's Office of Earthquake Studies.

title: GunLimit Advocates Are Critical of Carter And Look to Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, April 7  Last year President Carter enjoyed the strong support of the natonal lobby that advocates gun control  Handgun Control Inc., with 60,000 duespaying members. That support has now turned to bitter denunciation.

title: GOV. BROWN STARTS 10DAY AFRICAN TRIP
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 7  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., whose moves this year have been widely perceived as those of a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, began a 10day African visit yesterday. It was described by his staff as part vacation and part study tour but was seen by others as a trip designed to enhance his international reputation.

title: Elise Marcy Nissen Planning To Many
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Harold Nissen of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elise Marcy Nissen, to Bruce Jay Nathan, son of Mrs. Inge Sheer of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Mr. Norbert Nathan.

title: Mack Kanner, 93, Major Builder Who Developed Garment Center
description: Mack Kanner, a builder who was responsible for .developing Manhattan's garment center area more than a half century ago, died Friday in Merrick, L.1. Mr. Kanner, who lived at 4 Wellington Road in Merrick, was 93 years old.

title: Survey Shows Salaries in Alaska Almost Double Nation's Average
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)  Average salaries in Alaska are nearly double those of Americans as a whole, according to new Labor Depart'ment statistics.

title: DIKING OUT
description: FINALLY, almost 300 years after the Huguenots settled there, New Rochelle has a good French restaurant. It also has a fine new Hungarian restaurant. Most serendipitous the fact that both restaurants are actually one and the same  Le Cafe, two doors down from the old Ar- nold Constable and cattycorner to the new Conran's. New Rochelle's City Fathers have done everything encourage the owner, Narong Arjara (who is neither French nor Hungarian, but Thai), and John LaDue, the maitre d'h8tel, to set up shop on Main Street, and Le Caf should go far to restore the city's image. good restaurant is a good sign of civic pride.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: The Peoples Symphony Concerts organization ended its series at the Hunter College Assembly Hall last Sunday afternoon with a group called the Vienna Chamber Musicians, and by and large the ensemble wasn't up to the high standards of the Peoples Symphony Concerts.

title: Robert M. Crocker, 61; Newspaper Guild Aide
description: Robert M. Crocker, secretary-treasurer of the Newspaper Guild, died yesterday at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 61 years old.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Representative Joan R. Kemler's letter on Workfare (Feb. 11) included number of statements that require clarification if the reading public is to have the factual information necessary to make an informed judgment on this matter.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERJules, beloved husband of Suzanne. devoted father of Wendy Elizabeth and Geoffrey Nathan, dear brother of Leonard, and iris Wachtel, loving son of Doris Hussar. No service.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IREALIZED it just the other day: It had been years since I had passed another moving vehicle on the highway. A quick survey of family and friends confirmed this, although someone seemed to remember that I had passed a rather slownioving truck when we went to see Star, Wars in June 1977.

title: Public and College Radio Stations Nurture Jazz Others Neglect
description: Today at 2 P.M. on WNYCFM, one jazz pianist, Marian McPartland, will interview another, Barbara Carroll. Tonight, WKCRFM will present Jazz Alternatives at 6 P.M. Tomorrow, Newark's WBGOFM will begin its 113hour-a-day operation with 12 hours of jazz music each weekday.

title: Around the Nation
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., April 7 (AP)Everyday levels of oil pollution and other chemicals in the waters off some East Coast cities are killing the eggs of commercially important fish, according to scientists.

title: T.J. Digby Fiance Of Gail S. Wheeler
description: Gail Suzanne Wheeler and Timothy John Digby, seniors at Pennsylvania State University, plan to be married Nov. 22 in Darien, Conn.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: MASS MARKET

title: Happy Birthday, Susan B. Anthony
description: IN CELEBRATING the 159th anniversary of the birth of Susan B. Anthony, the Hudson County chapter of the National Organization for Women continues a tradition originally established by the suffragists of the 19th century.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 8, 1979

description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 7  A nurse educated in the Philippines has filed a complaint that foreigntrained nurses are denied pay credit and seniority routinely granted to United Statestrained nurses for previous experience, and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commissioner here is considering filing a farreaching classaction suit based on her charees.

title: A Guide to the Races
description: No central listing exists for the numerous publicly and privately sponsored races in the county. What follows is summary of a few of the most popular or innovative races this spring. Unless otherwise noted, information or entry forms can be obtained by sending a selfaddressed, stamped envelope to the Taconic Roadrunners Club, Box 99, Baldwin Place, N.Y., 10505. Most races have a nominal entry fee.

title: TV VIEW
description: Afew weeks ago, British television carried a live internationally linked discussion of the question Rhodesia: Is There a Solution? David Frost, the moderator of this Global Village series, stood on a bare set encircled by a studio audience and giant television monitors on which, courtesy of satellite transmissions, the various participants appeared. The lineup included Ian Smith in Salisbury, Joshua Nkomo in Lusaka, Andrew Young at the United Nations in New York and Senator S. I. Hayakawa in Washington. At one point, Harold Wilson, former British Prime Minister, began stressing how the English knew so much more than Americans about Africa. While not dwelling on the colonialist sources of that knowledge, Mr. Wilson skillfully needled U. S. ignorance, recalling that during his time in office American leaders, faced with one new development or another, would call him in the middle of the night and cry, We know nothing about Africa!

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Why is this night different from other nights? The question is one of the earliest memories of Jewish children, along with the taste of bitter horseradish, the crunch of matzoh, the salted water, the candles and the family around the table. The story of Passover and the seder feast that accompanies its celebration each spring will be told on film with live narration at 1:30 today in the Jewish Community Center at 1156 Chapel Street in New Haven.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Are cable television systems broadcasters, or are they common carriers? The answer has important implications for cable programming and constitutional lawyers. Under the First Amendment, broadcasters control the editorial content of their programs; under the law, common carriers must allow everyone to use their facilities.

title: Harvard Crew Wins San Diego Rowing
description: SAN DIEGO, April 7  The best crews from the East Coast met the best from the West today in the seventh annual San Diego crew classic, and the Eastern crews shone under the California sun. The result of today's racing left little doubt that the fastest collegi: ate crews will be rowing on the East Coast this season and that, as in seasons past, Harvard will be the crew the others will be trying to catch.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WASHINGTON  A jarring equation is gaining credence among the senior officials of the Carter Administration: Lack of progress in the fight against inflation equals a Republican President in 1980. And last week there was an almost palpable gloom within the Administration. The economic news was universally bad: producer prices at the wholesale level soared a full percent in March. bringing the first quarter increase in the index to 14.1 percent on an annual basis, the highest level since 1974. And the consumer price index averaged a 13 percent annualized increase for the first two months. That, as compared with a consumer price index of 9 percent in 1978 and percent in 1977.

title: Wife's Book Is Dogging Trudeau
description: VANCOUVER, April 7  In his fourth national campaign, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau is barnstorming across Canada preaching national unity and the need for strong central leadership. But he is being dogged at every step by a lurid tale of disunity in his own house told by his estranged wife, Margaret.

title: GARDENING
description: GARDENS begin to come alive in early April, making this good time to discuss the tasks that should be undertaken during the next few weeks.

title: FILM VIEW
description: At the very end of The Champ, the ever-surprising Faye Dunaway offers the only adequate response to Franco Zeffirelli's multi-milliondollar, flamingodappled remake of the 1931 Wallace BeeryJackie Cooper melodrama. Miss Dunaway surveys the hysterical scene being played around her and, after a laserlike concentration on the matter at nand, produces one tiny tear, a sort of quartercarat tear, a tear so minute it would hardly qualify as dew. Even then, it's more than the movie deserves.

title: South Africa Is Said to Have Offered Cash to The Trib
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 7 (AP)South Africa spent more than $1.5 million to buy an interest in a United Statesconnected television news film service and offered to help finance a nowdefunct New York newspaper, The Trib, to compete with The New York Times, a South African newspaper reported today.

title: Watson Accepts Golf Bid
description: DUBLIN, Ohio (AP)  Tom Watson, professional golf's 1978 player of the year, has accepted an invitation to play in the Memorial Tournament May 2427 at Muirfield Village. Ed Sneed, second to Watson in the recent Heritage Classic, also will play at Muirfield.

title: The World
description: The President is not feeling well. The wind is starting to blow in his head. The medicopolitical appraisal of President Idi Amin was offered last week in his deserted capital, Kampala, by a senior Uganda official whose plain speaking was itself a local sign of cataclysm. President Amin announced Friday on Uganda radio, that we have come to a critical phase. Reminding his citizens that he had brought them color television, health, and factories, [taken from 40,000 Asians he ousted in 1972], he added, I tell you, brothers and sisters, there is do need to be afraid of the enemy's cowardly bombardment.

title: Sunday Observer
description: People are always asking me how I get the newspapers read and still find the time left over to catch a little sleep each week. A good question it is, too. Since newspapers began swelling with directions on how to buy an artichoke, where to find a patchwork quilt in Khartoum and what to do if your face lift falls, reading the paper can use up 48 hours of the day, leaving little time for fun, much less sleep, unless it is done with cunning.

title: Norwalk May Take Its Neighbors to Court

title: Bright Spots of Time Past
description: AT the opening of James McConkey's fine new novel, the 50-year-old narrator (a modestly successful, happily married newspaperman named Peter Warden) has recently committed the most bizarre act of his life. Every day, all summer long, in response to a vision he experienced during the death of his mother, he has climbed into a child's abandoned tree house to compose a memoir that would interpret his revelation and give shape to his existence. The fourpart narrative that emerges is his treehouse confession and Mr. McConkey's intelligent and delicate book.

title: Grand Prix Rouses Long each
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 7  For 51 weeks a year this quiet seaside city 20 miles north of Los Angeles is disturbed chiefly by the squawking of seagulls on their flights from the nearby Pacific. Sailboats speckle the neighboring bay where visitors eat lunch on the Queen Mary, the ship that has been permanently moored and converted into an elegant hotel and tourist attraction.

title: Australians Prohibit All Whaling Within Their Territorial Waters
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, April 7 The Australian Government has announced a ban on whaling within Australia's 200mile territorial limits. Importing of whale products into Australia will also be prohibited beginning in 1981, a Government statement said.

You can choose them for early bloom, midseason or late. And the best part, they are longlived.

title: Default Avoided
description: The full consequences of a default by the U.S. are impossible to predict and awesome to anticipate. The quotation comes not in the pages of some bygone crisis but in a letter just last week to the House Speaker from Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal. The United States, amid all its other problems, narrowly avoided default when the House finally voted to raise the ceiling on the national debt.

title: Now, the Cleanup
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa.  The series of failures that started at 4 A.M. on March 28 in the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant led to a flash release of energy that caused some fuel elements in the reactor to rupture, contaminating the coolant water with highly radioactive fission products. was said to the point of litany by the nuclear industry before the accident that the containment vessel, if called upon, would contain. It didn't. Instead a score or so of highly radioactive elements spawned by the accident have been released into the Pennsylvania Dutch countryside  as gases, as minute particles, as weak solutions in water.

title: How to Discover How to Avoid The Fire Next Time
description: The meltdown did not occur last week at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Middletown, Pa. In meltdown, the core's cooling system would have been unable to remove enough heat from the fuel elements to prevent them from melting and fusing into an everhotter puddle.

description: Madewood, a plantation house near Napoleonville, La., is one of the restored temples in the cane fields that grace the Southern landscape and attract increasing numbers of tourists each year.

title: Mulder, Once a Possible Prime Minister, Was Expelled From the National Party Last Week
description: JOHANNESBURGSouth Africa's Information Ministry scandal Is providing ammunition for racial hardliners within the ruling National Party who could hardly disagree with the nowdefunct ministry's efforts to buy foreign support for apartheid. Each headline in The Rand Daily Mail that points to more improprieties by subordinates of Prime Minister P.W. Botha and his predecessor, John Vorster, encourages rightwing hopes of recapturing the party  and the Governmentfrom those who have compromised, however grudgingly, with the enemies of white rule.

title: Insurors Pay Over $500,000 to 7,000 Evacuated Near Nuclear Plant
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 7  An accident alert last year at the Fort St. Vrain nuclear facility in Colorado caused the closing of an access road for several hours, during which time a pet elk was not fed. The elk died, the owner filed claim and an autopsy indicated that the elk had died of nonrelated causes.

Ms. Greene is a Speech Language Patholo. gist for United Cerebal Palsy Association of NYS. Mr. Luba is the gourmet food and candy buyer for Abraham and Straus.

title: U.S. Employees Angered by Carter's Parking Curb
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  It was lunch time, and the seven regulars were playing a heated game of dirty hearts at the Defense Department's Defense Logistics Agency in Alexandria. Va. Cards were fanned around the table, picked up and scrutinized intently until someone, adding a little light conversation to the silent group, mentioned President Carter's move to cut Federal employees free parking privileges.

title: FOOD
description: HOW do you like your Easter bunnies? Dark and bittersweet? Mellow milk chocolate? Pink or white or bearing wreaths of Jellybeans and baskets of marshmallows? If you live in the Huntington area, you can take your pick at a trio of new shops where the showcases are now decked out with Easter confections.

title: McEnroe And Borg In Final

title: A Correction

title: The Region
description: The New York State Legislature finally passed a $12.6 billion budget last week In a clear victory for Governor Carey. It did not give him everything he wanted, but it apparently left him with little he would have to regret next year. His success was mostly due to the fact that RepUblicans, fearful of tax increases and program cuts as they head toward the election year of 1980, helped him every step of the way. First there was the question of it ??? -- depending en aid funds for abortions for indigent women. It was the Republicans who ftnally gave in after Senate Majority Leader Warren M. Anderson persuaded his colleagues that it was a nowin situation.

Connor of New Vernon, N.J., and Cotuit, Mass., was married at Pleasantdale Farm in West Orange, N.J., yesterday afternoon to Fredric Patton Postle, son of Doanne Young Postle of Inverness, Ill., and the late Merton French Postle. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Rev. John F. Corr, assisted by Msgr. Harrold Murray.

title: A Contemplator on the Steps of Rome
description: The official center of Rome, the Centro to which the white-on-azure directional signs point, is still, where it was in ancient times. It is now dominated not by the Capitoline Hill, but by the Vittorio Emanuele II monument, that stupendous pile of dazzling white Brescian marble that Americans learn to call, jocosely, the Wedding Cake.

description: THE musical Brigadoon dates back to 1947, and while its score is still enchanting, its book has aged to its disadvantage. It concerns two American hunters lost in the Scottish highlands who

title: For Working Women, Buying Clothes
description: Whether she's in her 20's or her 50's, whether she lives in city or suburb, whether she's married or singleif she's a working woman in New York, the way she looks is important to her but she doesn't have enough time to shop for clothes. And she often finds that department stores don't meet her needs.

title: Scientists Prepare Hunt for Ship John Paul Jones Lost in Victory
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., April 7 (UPI) - John Paul Jones won the most famous naval battle of the American Revolutionary War but a short time later was forced to abandon his sinking ship off the northeastern coast of England.

title: Energy Choices Are All In Column B
description: WASHINGTON  If last week's developments the politics of energy served no other purpose, they at least functioned as a vivid reminder of the paucity of energy options. By all accounts  perhaps most graphically the President's own on Thursday  the nation's energy health is failing. Yet only a variety of somewhat discredited remedies stand close at hand.

description: HAVE you seen a bluebird this spring? If you have, count yourself lucky, for these delightful birds are becoming rarity in the Northeast. And they are greatly missed.

Start feeding vegetable seedlings indoors with halfrate watersoluble fertilizer.

title: Football Rams Still a Rosenbloom Team
description: Carroll Rosenbloom's 34-year-old son, Steve, will take full charge of the Los Angeles Rams in place of his late father, who drowned last Monday in Florida. The effect on one of the National Football League's strongest franchises should be minimal  the or- ganization is souna ana tne younger Rosenbloom already had been running the club for several years in his quiet, selfeffacing way.

title: Libraries in U.S. Caught in Money Squeeze
description: Staff members at the El Paso public library are donating their own money for new books because the library's budget was cut from $200,000 to $100,000.

description: An old muckraker sheds fresh light on the 2,500-year-old mystery and reveals some Athenian political realities that Plato did his best to hide.

title: Police Seeking to Improve Innovative Bookings for Minor Offenders
description: Last month in the Times Square subway station, an obviously intoxicated man approached a young woman and threatened to throw her off the station platform. A Transit Authority police officer witnessed the incident and arrested the man, who, it was discovered, had a record of 14 arrests and five convictions.

title: Coast Guard Becomes Advocate
description: In recent years, some state and Federal regulations and laws affecting recreational boatmen have obscured the idea that landbound pressures can be escaped simply by pushing off to sea. Compliance with some of the laws and regulations, boatmen discovered, was impossible.

title: Rock by Twisted Sister
description: The logic of Twisted Sister Is absolutely straightforward: Act like idols and that's just what you'll become. They already are on Long Island, where the hardrock quintet has been cultivating a rabid following for three years, and on Friday evening they sold out New York City's Palladium Theater  an unprecedented accomplishment for a group that doesn't even have a recording contract. (Such drawingpower guarantees that when they do sign with a label, it will be for a great deal of money.)

title: A Navel Does Not a Universe Make
description: HARRIET, my flaky friend of many years, phones me at midnight. She was married the first time in a wildlife preserve and wore a clover chain on one ankle. The marriage proved to be less refreshing than the wedding.

description: ANTIQUES .

title: Music Notes: Gedda Sings of Spring
description: perhaps no one appreciates the coming of spring as much as do the Scandinavians and those who live in the north of the Soviet Union. Their winters are long, and the healing warmth of the spring sun arrives late. This is not quite the reason that Nicolai Gedda, who has both Swedish and Russian blood in him, is giving a recital of songs about spring in Carnegie Hall tomorrow night, although it may have partially inspired him. Rather, the tenor chose the theme because there are so many beautifully written songs about it.

title: Teamster Strike Impact Muted
description: The longfeared strike by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters became a reality last Sunday, but with some noteworthy and painful exceptions. few Americans were affected.

title: Greenburgh G.O.P.: Can Nothing Help?
description: T HERE is hardly a political ty leader in the county who  wouldn't bet his party position that he could parlay a 21 per. cent tax increase by an administration controlled by the opposition into at least some modest political gains in an upcoming election. At a time of Propo. sition 13 fever, such an issue is the stuff of a party leader's dreams.

title: Park's Sheep Meadow Lives Up to Its Name as Herd Dogs Compete
description: What happens when an immovable object meets an irresistible force? If the object is a large Dorset sheep playing dead and the force is a border sheep dog, the crowd gathered in Central Park has a wonderful time.

title: To Pave or Not? A Thorny Road
description: AS SURE as the spring thaw that turns dirt roads into muddy ruts, the annual debate is recurring in Westchester's rural towns between people who like dirt roads and those who want them Paved,

description: MONTIVIDEO, Uruguay, April 7 (UPI)  The International Olympic Committee voted today, 3628, to recognize China while at the same time retaining Taiwan as a member.

title: Something Old, Something New
description: I'M HOPING for amnesia after all this is over, said Theodora Sirota. All this refers to the remodeling work currently under way on the Sirota family's Fed. eral Colonial home in Alpine, in Bergen County. The work began last September, and the Sirotas are hoping that it will be finished by June.

title: OffDuty Detective Kills Suspect In Robbery at Fulton Street Shop
description: One robber was shot to death but an accomplice, possibly wounded, escaped after they staged a holdup yesterday afternoon at a downtown appliance and gift store where an offduty city detective was shopping, the police reported.

title: Associated Press
description: ALL IN VAIN: Lee Mazzilli of Mets dived into second but was out stealing anyway during fifth inning of game against Cubs in Chicago yesterday. Mets won second straight, 94.

title: Key Meetings Next Week Inspire Moscow Rumors
description: MOSCOW  Take one fact: the lastminute postponement of French President Valery Giscard d'Estaing's trip Moscow because Soviet President Leonid I. Brezhnev had influenza. Add another: the entire Soviet leadership scheduled to meet in secret conclave and in public session beginning next week. Spice with Mr. Brezhnev's age (72), lack stamina and apparent coolness towards Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin, and what you have is the perfect Moscow recipe for rumors of imnendinn chance in the Kremlin.

title: EGYPT TO OBSTRUCT ARAB LEAGUE'S SHIFT
description: CAIRO, April 7  Egypt said today that it intended to block attempts to transfer the Arab League headquarters from Cairo to Tunis, an action decided upon by opponents of Egypt's peace treaty with Israel at a meeting in Baghdad a week ago.

title: L.I. Girl With a Reattached Leg Is Taken Home After 15 Weeks
description: SMITHTOWN, L.I., April 7  Let's go home, said Elizabeth McFadden as her father lifted the 11yearold girl from her wheelchair and into the back of their blue Ford station wagon, easing into place the brace that protected her right leg.

title: A Window on the American Economy
description: Inflation has come to a boil, a recession still lurks in the statistical fog, the President wants to take the lid off the price of gasoline  and yet the rite of buying a car this spring has the air of a binge. Consumers feel they have to buy now, and they're paying whatever they must. Some of them have been shoonine at Major Chevrolet, one of a score of dealerships along Northern Boulevard in Queens, and what they are saying sheds some light on the American economy and how consumers are trying to live with it.

title: Could Westchester Cope With a. Major Nuclear Accident?
description: THE accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant 11 miles south of Harrisburg, the Pennsylvania capital, has inescapable implications for Westchester County. It raises a number of fundaMental safety questions.

title: IN BRIEF

The decision held that the Federal Communications Commission lacked the authority to issue regulations that, in effect, reduced cable television to the status of common carrier

title: Realty News.
description: The Bank Leumi Trust Company has purchased 564 Fifth Avenue and 3 West 46th Street from Aer Lingus and leased the Fifth Avenue retail frontage to Hallmark Cards, which plans to open a new showcase retail store this spring in the space.

title: Astros
description: HOUSTON, April 7 (UPI)  Ken Forsch didn't sound like a pitcher with a 5562 wonlost career record tonight. But then again, he didn't pitch like one.

title: Harvard Places Its (R) on a Film
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 7  Ten years ago, demonstrators who took over an administration building in Harvard Yard were forcibly removed from the campus by an Angry Harvard administration. This week, an equally angry administration threw out the crew and cast of A Small Circle of Friends for disrupting life on the now serene campus.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Lively lilliputlans. It's just a year since we made an exploratory tour of one of Publishers Row's leastknown neighborhoods  the nest of the tiny publishers whose paperbacks you'll find in some massmarket racks beside the books of giants like Bantam, Fawcett and Dell, but whose names you'll never hear men- tioned when hot properties are being auctioned of for sixfigure advances. Last spring we found these lilliputians full of life and great expectations. How are they doing now, at a time when the massmarket business is showing signs of crunch and strain?

title: FollowUp on the News

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: EDINA, Minn.  In this quiet suburb of Minneapolis lives 62-year-old Percy Ross, one of the happiest  and most flamboyant  of millionaires. He throws parties. He gives to charities. He gambles in Las Vegas. He loves publicity. Money, he says. is the root of happiness.

title: Pilot Was Trained to Keep Cool
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 7 (AP) Thirtyone years of flying experience and training to keep cool helped Harvey Gibson, a Trans World Airlines pilot, regain control when his jetliner with 80 passengers on board turned two 360degree rolls and hurtled down into a fivemile nose dive.

title: Score One for Mr. Carter in Essex County
description: PRESIDENT CARTER may be having trouble slowing inflation or solving energy problems th4,se days, and his Middle East negotiations may get only mixed reviews, but in Essex County he has scored a clear, if unheralded, victorY.

title: Horror Shocker
description: FOR reasons that perhaps will be clear only posterity, evil  whether in the form of Nazi revivals, witchcraft, demonic possession, the Manson family or mass suicides in Guyana  fasci- nates the bookbuying public. But in those quarters where serious literary reputations are made, such topics are usually considered rather vulgar. In writing Ghost Story, his third novel, Peter Straub quite clearly wishes to have it both ways: to make a hit at the checkout counter and in the English department as well. For besides nightmares, apparitions, werewolves, bloodsetting viragos and hosts of the undead, Mr. Straub has summoned up the literary shades of Hawthorne, Poe and Henry James in an attempt to dignify and provide a respectable context for his long and complicated book.

title: HONE CLINIC; On Keeping a Roof (a Dry One, That Is) Over Your Head
description: THE galeforce winds that have swept this area during the last fewinonths have caused more thanaVerage damage to many shingled roofs, especially those that are more than 15 years old. Even there is no evidence of a leak, repairs should be made as soon as possible to prevent the condition from getting worse and water from seeping in under the damaged shingles.

title: New ProfessionalLicensing Plan Backed in Albany
description: ALBANY, April 6  Faced with mounting number of requests from groups.whose members wish to be certified as licensed professionals, an AssemNy committee has adopted strict guidelines that are expected to make it more difficult to attain such status.

title: PROBLEMS PLAGUING CANADIAN PARADISE
description: DAUPHIN, Manitoba  When the first farmers began trickling into this virgin area of Canada almost 100 years ago, they were fleeing the droughts, rebellions and other troubles of life elsewhere.

title: In Europe, The Nuclear Debate Looms Even Larger
description: PARIS  The expansion of nuclear energy installations in the world is slowing down compared to earlier plans, according to experts at the International Energy Agency (I.E.A.) and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (O.E.C.D.). No doubt, they say, the tendency will be reinforced by the repercussions of the Three Mile Island accident near Harrisburg, Pa., now a household word throuehout the televisionviewine world.

title: Pennsylvanians Given Assurances
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., April 7 Gov. Dick Thornburgh and Harold R. Denton, chief of operations for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, toured the area near the Three Mile Island nuclear plant today to report to local residents that conditions here were cooling down and that residual radioactivity was extremely small.

title: MUSIC
description: 0 NE of the happier seasons of chamber music in Connecticut will be winding up with the last of four concerts on Wednesday at the University of Bridge- port. The Idea of Robert Preston, the young head of the piano division at the university, the series has thus far brought to the campus such extraordinary artists as members of the Cleveland String Quartet and the New York Woodwind Quintet, all in free concerts with Mr. Preston as hostperformer.

title: Tanzania's Nyercre Seems to Have Emerged as a Giant Killer
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Black Africa will not rue the evident downfall of Idi Amin, but it may come to regret the way it happened. How much better, said West African diplomat, if it had come six months ago with a quick bullet from an assassin's gun.

title: 700 Bahama Isles: A Visitor's Choice
description: It's better in the Bahamas, the Government there says, and maybe it is and maybe it isn't. But certainly that country of 700 islands, extending from 50 miles east of Palm Beach, Fla., southeast toward Cuba, has something to please almost every type of vacationer.

title: Merger Fever in Adland
description: John deGarmo is the president of the 65th largest American advertising agency, and like many of his peers, he has no taste for the wave of mergers that has been sweeping over his industry. Last fall he warned the Advertising Club of New York that mergers could sap the industry of its best people, make individual agencies too powerful, and deprive advertisers of the better service a smaller agency could provide. But the pressure to merge is strong, as Mr. deGarmo is the first to admit. Five months before he made the speech, he himself had engineered his agencys purChase of the smaller Cox & Company agency.

title: Emily Louise Gaul Married to Luther Daniel Prescott Jr.
description: The Atonement Lutheran Church in Wyomissing, Pa., was the setting yesterday evening for the marriage of Emily Lobise Gaul, daughter of George B. Gaul of Wyomissing and the late Emy Lou Worrilow Gaul, to Luther Daniel Prescott Jr., son of Mrs. Prescott of Fort Worth and the late Mr. Prescott. The Rev. Richard W. Lundin performed the ceremony.

title: So Far So Good on Oil
description: President Carter's decision to phase out price controls on domestic oil  with or without a tax on the accompanying windfall profits  is drawing fire as unfair and inflationary. These criticisms have some merit. But given the gravity of America's energy problem and the lack of other politically feasible ways to reduce oil imports, the President made the right choice. It is now up to Congress to tax the new oil profits.

title: Foster Hens for Rare Crane Eggs
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 7 (AP) Sabrina is gentle, devoted, fussy and protective  an ideal foster mother. That's why she and five other bantam jungle fowl have been entrusted with six extremely rare whooping crane eggs by the San Antonio Zoo.

title: Barbara L. Kaplan Married to Dentist
description: Barbara Lynne Kaplan, daughter of Barnett Kaplan of Bayside, Queens, and the late Rosalyn K. Kaplan, was married yesterday to Dr. Mitchell H. description: Depositors with less than $10,000 are missing out on a chance to earn higher interest rates these days, and the Government has been under pressure to do something about it. You are welcomed by a FrenchAmerican family, the Baxters, whose place, La Champagne, evokes an earlier France, a France when cooking was still domestic an familycentered instead of jetpropelled and celebritycentered.

title: Mrs. Byrne Sets Election Mark
description: CHICAGO, April 7 (AP)  The official election canvass shows that Jane M. Byrne piled up a record 82.05 percent of the vote in winning the Chicago mayoral election last Tuesday. The results, issued yesterday, showed Mrs. Byrne received 700,874 votes.

title: President Is Opposed To SchoolPrayer Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 7  I think the Government ought to stay out of the prayer business, President Carter told group of editors yesterday at the White House. A transcript of the President's remarks was released today.

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 7  In 1977, when Gen. Mohammad Zia ulHaq seized power here in a coup, he insisted that he was going to govern for only a 90day transition period, until new elections.
