description: The engagement of Susan Ide to William Stuart Symington 4th has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Lucien Waterman :de of St. Joseph, Mo., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Symington Jr. of St. Louis and a grandson of Stuart Symington, the former Democratic United States Senator from Missouri.

title: The UtilityTax Debate (Continued)
description: THE proposed revision of the publicutility gross receipts and franchise taxes to meet the immediate needs of deteriorating cities and the state's poor, elderly and handicapped citizens is, as Mayor John K. Kitchen of Branchburg Township recently indicated in an Opinion Page article, fraught with inequities.

title: PRESIDENT PLEDGES TO FIGHT OIL LOBBY FOR TAX ON PROFITS
description: RICHMOND, April 7  Warning that the oil lobby will be all over Capitol Hill like a chicken on a June bug in opposition to his proposed tax on windfall profits, President Carter vowed tonight to fight to get the key element of his energy package through Congress nonetheless.

description: Susan Carol Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore G. Walker 3d of Woodbridge, Conn., was married there yesterday to Michael McKee Monahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Monahan of Fort Myers, Fla. The Rev. George M. Milne performed the ceremony in the Congregational First Church of Christ.

title: Goldin Asks Revamping Of ElderlyCenters Plan
description: Complaining that New York City's senior citizen centers were serving only 37,000 people a day out of an elderly population of 1.3 million, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin has called for establishment of smaller satellite facilities and expansion of the meals on wheels concept.

description: IF you signed a petition asking the State Legislature to put a constitutional limit on spending, you may be wondering what happened to it.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: ALMOST immediately after Joanne and Joseph Bucki inherited a decaying Victorian house on William Street in East Bridgeport from Mr. Bucki's father two years ago, they were thinking of selling it and using the $25,000 which they had been assured they would get  toward buying a newer house in the suburbs.

title: Nuclear Power: The Bottom Line Gets Fuzzier
description: In the 1950's, when scientists were first dazzling the public with their arcane schemes for making electricity from the atom, the popular belief was that nuclear power would be too cheap to meter. Although that notion died soon enough, utilities, reactor manufacturers and other proponents of atomic power still rest their case essentially on economics: Electricity from nuclear power plants, they argue, costs some 60 percent less than electricity from oilfired plants and about 25 percent less than electricity from coalfired plants.

title: Letter TO THE EDITOR
description: As a Middle East analyst working in the Defense Department, I have followed the developments in Iran with great interest. It is my personal view that Iran: Heart of the Matter (by R.W. Apple Jr., March 11) represents a good starting point for understanding how the Shah was overthrown. However, much as we in the West have tended to downplay or overlook the importance of religion as a political force in the past, we must now be careful not to exaggerate or simplify Ayatollah Khomeini's role in Iran's revolution. Ideological and economic factors, neither of which were adequately addressed by Mr. Apple, must be examined in order to under-

title: 3,000 Demonstrate Against Trident at Christening
description: GROTON, Conn., April 7  An estimated 3,000 people staged a peaceful fivehour protest at the launching this morning of the Trident submarine Ohio.

title: How Fares the Met Museum in the PostHoeing Era?
description: At the Metropolitan Museum of Art, they are referred to sotto voce as Cucumber and the Count of Monte Cristo. It is nearly a year since the team of William B. Macomber Jr. and Philippe de Montebello replaced the flartiboyant oneman directorship of Thomas Hoving, and some diehards, who object to the very idea that two heads are better than one at running the mighty Met, still wish they would go away.

description: NEW ORLEANS (UPI)  The Sugar Bowl organization has paid $975,109 to both Alabama and Penn State, whose football teams met on Jan. 1 in the 45th Sugar Bowl game. Alabama won the game, 147.

title: Design
description: For a successful firm like BraySchaible Design Inc., it was hardly an unusual assignment: A single man with a modest budget telephoned to ask if they'd please design his onebedroom apartment. But, confesses Robert Bray, When I got that phone call, could feel immediate pressure. And no wonder: The client was Allen Tate, head of the Department of Environmental Design at Parsons School of Design, Robert Bray's and Michael Schaible's alma mater. Back in the 60s, they had been Mr. Tate's students, and they considered him their mentor. It was so flattering that he wanted us to do his apartment, Mr. Bray recalls. But I kept thinking, What on earth does he have in mind?

title: Ivy Leaguers Excel At More Than Sports
description: There was a time when college athletes talked like Jack Keefe, the protagonist in Ring Lardner's You Know Me, Al, and sportswriters could discern no difference between such speech and the King's English. Even today's sportswriters, most of them also collegeeducated, often gasp in awe at the sound of studentathletes speaking in complete sentences.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: With its permanent collection including works by such notable 19th- and 20thcentury artists as Asher B. Durand, Arthur Dove, Stuart D. Davis, Thomas Eakins, George Illness, Thomas Moran, George Luks and George Grosz, Huntington's Heckscher Museum has, since its founding in 1920 as the home. for August Heckscher's private collection, developed into a major small museum. To commemorate the publication of the Catalogue of the Collection  an endeavor that has taken several years of intensive art detective work  the museum is currently devoting all four of its galleries to showing off just what it owns. The Heckscher Museum Collection: From Private Benefactor to Public Realm will run through May 13 and can be seen from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays; 1 to 6 P.M.

title: Agriculture
description: Next week, the University of California must respond in court to what seems on its face a bizarre lawsuit. The university is being sued to make it stop research on laborsaving machinery. But the machinery is agricultural equipment, and the suit being pressed by a legalaid group that seeks to arrest the sharp decline in jobs for farm laborers.

title: Pakistan Can Hardly Afford Its Latest National Trauma
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  As the hangman's rope snapped the spine of the patrician former Prime Minister inside the grim walls of the Rawalpindi District Jail at 2 a.m. last Wednesday, a troubled and divided Pakistan abruptly entered a new era in the nation's confused politicsalready dubbed the postBhutto period.

title: How to Be Fair About the Property Tax
description: The very existence of New Yorks real property tax system is threatened by decisions of the state's highest court. Unless the Legislature intervenes wisely, these decisions could force an immense shift of real estate tax burdens from business property and apartment houses to homeowners. Moreover, business and apartment house owners will have grounds for substantial tax refund claims against local governments.

title: THEY'RE STILL SINGING
description: The blues run through American music like a mighty river, their rich, brooding mystery flowing into jazz, rock, pop, countrywestern and even some classical music. They began when black slaves transformed the ballads and hymns of their white masters with syncopated rhythms and the eerie, flattened blue notes of traditional African scales. Out of this metamorphosis came the field hollers  slow, mournful, unaccompanied chants that made working under the hot sun seem easier. In the 1920's, artists like Mississippi's hardsinging Charley Patton and the Texas guitar wizard Blind Lemon Jefferson took the blues out of the fields and turned them into a form of exorcising entertainment as they sang stories of sickness, death and nogood women.

title: CARDENING
description: HAVE you seen a bluebird this swing? If you have, count yourself lucky, for these delightful birds are becoming rarity in the Northeast. And they are greatly missed.

title: Employment, In New Favor As a Gauge of The Economy
description: WASHINGTON  With forecasts of slower growth for the American economy in 1979 seemingly established by the lackluster performances of retail sales and industrial production in January and February, higher unemployment may be ahead. In the past, that has been a signal for the Government to pump more Federal money into the econ- omy, and for the Federal Reserve to ease credit. But times have changed. With inflation pushing to doubledigit rates, economists, business leaders and politicians will urge Washington to hold fast to tight fiscal policies.

Garp is a heritage of New England bluebloods, a mother who was a feminist when such women were considered black sheep, a fondness for wrestlers and wrestling, aspirations to make it as an artist and family man. John Irving's fourth novel is both dark and lively, with an abundance of violence, comedy, tragedy, radical feminism and militant homosexuality. It was a best seller in hardcover and one of this Book Review's Editors Choices for 1978.

title: HUSSEIN AND HIS QUEEN
description: The harshest blow that King Hussein has suffered in his uneasy 26year reign was probably the death of Queen Alia in a helicopter crash on Feb. 9, 1977. Two earlier marriages had ended in divorce but King Hussein remained devoted to Queen Alia. The trauma of her death submerged him and he visibly aged. His solitariness frightened some acquaintances who recalled his father's losing bouts with depression. He was really a man all alone in the world, one Jordanian remembered.

title: Nets Top Celtics, 126112
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., April 7  The best thing about this weekend for the New Jersey Nets is that it is not the last weekend. It still matters that their field goal percentage should be higher; that the number of turnovers should be lower, and that Bernard King should make more free throws. It matters be- cause there will be playoff games, starting on Wednesday. In the last weekend of the regular season, it matters not whether they win or lose, as long as they keep playing the game.

Reynolds Industries, the parent company, since the first of the month. Mr. Hunter, who is 50 years old, said he had been presented with an opportunity that I simply must accept, adding, the deal isn't ready to be announced yet. William B. Hobbs, chairman and ohief executive of Reynolds Tobacco, will take over the duties of president and chief operating officer until a replacement is named.

title: Late Talks With Allen Tate
description: ALLEN TATE, the poet and critic,. died last February at 79. He was one of the Fugitives, the group that guided and influenced the Southern literary renaissance in the 1920's. His reputation was at its peak in the 40's and 50's; his best poems, particularly Ode to the Confederate Dead, Seasons of the Soul and The Mediterranean, are a permanent part of American letters. The following piece is fashioned from five visits with Tate in the last two years of his life. William Boozer, who lives in Nashville, is the author of William Faulkner's First Book: The Marble Faun Fifty Years Later.

title: Pan Am and Attendants In Marathon Bargaining
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI)  Faced with a midnight strike deadline, negotiators for Pan American World Airways and its flight attendants kept to a roundtheclock bargaining schedule today.

title: CAMERA
description: Today's electronic flash units, often called strobe units, are one of the great technological achievements of photography. Packed inside a small plastic housing that is usually smaller than the camera is powerhouse of light as bright as the summer sun. Fortunately, the quality of light that emanates from this mighty midget is better than sunlight for taking pictures. It is perceptibly softer, and because the light flashes at a speed of about 1,000th of a second the sub. ji:ct's eyes remain wide open a14any movement is indelibly frozen in time and space.

title: Homage to the Art Of Isaac Stern
description: Isaac Stern has played father figure to so many young musical careers of late, in addition to his other influential activities as a maker and shaker in New York's musical circles, that sometimes people tend to forget that he also plays the violin. Columbia Records has just reminded us of that fact with a big allStern release, ive brand new disks as well as six reis,ues of performances that go all the vay back to 1945. There is no special event being celebrated here, except the nicest one of all  homage to an important musician who has contributed a great deal to the quality of our musical life over the years.

title: BOOK ENDS

Well, for one thing, they were all published by Farrar, Straus and Giroux. For another, they were all featured in recent weeks on the front page of this journal. The boy, Travis Lloyd Fry, was killed last Sunday when he leaned his bicycle against the electrified trash can.

title: YUGOSLAVIA MOVING AGAINST DISSIDENTS

Tully planned apartment development with more greenery than: construction, an area surrounded, by :small private homes and disrupted only when the wind blows the airplanes bound for Kennedy over the television antenna, causing on the home screen the only unsightliness we have witnessed in our years here.

title: THE MARKETS

title: A 1,000Mile Tour of West Texas

Now, after a first visit to Texas, I realize the old crack was less exaggerated than I thought. Driving 1,000 miles in two weeks, my wife and I saw only one, rural corner of the big state.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Good general managers have always been .a scarce commodity, but today the supply is rapidly drying up, and many of those remaining are being organized into impotence. Just as bad money has always driven out good, so the talented general manager the person who makes a company go  Is being overwhelmed by a flood of socalled professionals, textbook executives more interested in the form of management than the content, more concerned about defining and categorizing and quantifying the job than in getting it done.

title: In Pakistan, the Making of a Martyr
description: To a short, unhappy history already scarred by assassination, coups and national dismembermemt, Pakistan last week added another trauma, the execution of its most charismatic leader. The death of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto hoisted yet another danger signal for a region made edgy by Marxist takeover in Afghanistan and Islamic revolution in Iran.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR

He wrongfully implied that the real reason I voted with the majority of the Montclair City Commission to have Essex County widen Bloomfield Avenue was to assist the school I was associated with to obtain a traffic light and a leftturn lane.

title: Marchi Begins Inquiry Into State Handling Of Abortion Payouts
description: ALBANY, April 6  After the defeat of an effort to bar the use of Medicaid funds to finance abortions for poor women, State Senator John J. Marchi, the chairman of the Finance Committee, announced that he would investigate how the state administered the money it spent for abortions.

title: Chamber Concert With a Mix
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center offered its usual mix of the offbeat, the familiar and the not so familiar in Alice Tully Hall on Friday night. How many concertgoers have ever heard Beethoven's Variations on Mozart's La ci darem la mano from Don Giovanni'? This piece for two oboes and English horn was only first published 65 years ago, and the odd instrumental combination has surely discouraged performances since then.

title: What's Doing'in WASHINGTON
description: SPRING A friend said it: spring is what Washington does best. Spring in the Nation's Capital is a jewel and a song, a ray of sun glinting off the river, a red cardinal chirping against a blue sky. Spring is as light as a kite on the Mall, as clean as the freshly scrubbed steps of the Lincoln Memorial, as soft as the nose of a doe at the National Zoo.

He did not leave the Yankees because of Martin. Rather, he departed for the security of notrade contract, which, it is said, is for five years and will bring him $2 million as it runs its course. title: Equal Sentences for Equal Crimes
description: Mere chance, rather than the rule of law, often governs the way we sentence criminals today. That the conclusion of a 1,000page study by a blueribbon committee on sentencing practices in New York State. If the panel, headed by Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau, has its way, New York will abandon the tradition of judicial flexibility and move clearly drawn sentencing guidelines. Now it is up to the Legislature to enact the committee's oronosals.

title: Fuller Planes and Healthier Profits
description: Airline deregulation works. That must be the conclusion of millions of travelers who have traded a little elbow room for bargain rates, and of airlines that have turned full planes into healthy profits. Plane fares will increase this year because of skyrocketing jet fuel costs, but the cost of flying in 1979 will still be less than than it would have been under the old system.

title: Mexico Land Rush: Of Pipe Dreams and Nightmares

Think what it would cost in California! Three times as much. And for $80 a month, you can hire a maid or cook.

On Sept. 14, 1978, Taub officially became the president of the New Jersey Nets, a team that had nearly gone defunct two months earlier because its previous owner, Roy L.M. Boe, was in such serious debt. The National Basketball Association's board of governors recommended that he sell the franchise before the league was forced to dissolve the team entirely. Matters had reached that point.

description: A sportswriter in Hartford recently wrote that the city had at last become major league with the absorbing of the New England Whalers of the World Hockey Association by the National Hockey League. Bill Lee, sports editor emeritus of The Hartford Courant. urged that the team's name be changed to the Hartford Whalers, although no whale or whaling ship has ever come within 70 miles of Hartford.

Gray is the prevailing hue, relieved only in a few places by the green of one of the loftier palm trees projecting above the buildmgs.

description: Oil companies, smarting from President Carter's repeated barbs, have issued a chorus of complaints about his suggestion that Congress pass a windfall profits tax once oil prices start on their way to decontrol.

title: The City

Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, warned yesterday that the $1 billion Battery Park City project faced financial disaster because of what he charged were poor management and deceptive fiscal practices in the past. Mr. Schumer, who is chairman of the Assembly Committee on Legislative Oversight and Investigation, said that a threemonth study by his committee had uncovered the alleged abuses at the 11-year-old project.

title: Ethnic Bloc Loses in San Antonio
description: SAN ANTONIO, April 8  A coalition of five MexicanAmericans and a black lost control of the City Council yesterday as one of its members was defeated in a close race for reelection.

title: Floridians Flee Fumes From Spill

title: Nuclear Protest in Jersey

The demonstrators milled about on Route 9 outside a chainlink fence surrounding the nuclear plant, chanting slogans and carrying handpainted signs. About 20 children accompanied the protesters, the police said.

title: Blacks in Rhodesia Apprehensive As Historic Biracial Election Nears

description: CHICAGO, April 8  The recent accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania has rekindled the debate over whether Illinois, which has seven such plants operating, more than any other state, should continue with its plans to build 17 more.

title: AT HOME ABROAD Autonomy In Gaza?
description: GAZA, Occupied Gaza Strip- In the next planned stage of the Middle East peace process, the negotiation of autonomy. a vital role may be played by a 70yearold Arab businessman turned politician. He is Rashaa alShawa, the Mayor of this city and probably the most influential figure in the Gaza Strip.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Saudi Arabia Is Reported to Plan Establishment of Nuclear Center
description: JIDDA, April 8 (Reuters)  Saudi Arabia plans to set up an atomic energy center as the first step toward the creation of a nuclear industry, press reports said today.

title: Credit Line Given To Homequity
description: PHH Group Inc. announced the completion of $90 million in domestic and Eurodollar credit line facilities for Homequity, its relocation-management subsidiary. Homequity offers homepurchase and homeselling services to large corporations for their employees.

title: TV: Death of a Family
description: THE old and unfairly maligned device of talking heads is used with new vigor in tonight's Death of a Family part of Bill Moyers Journal, which can be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock. With Mr. Moyers as narrator, the hourlong film, produced and directed by William Peters, skillfully assembles the anatomy of one of those crimes that inevitably leave bystanders puzzled and shaken.

title: Viola: George Taylor
description: SATURDAY afternoon's benefit recital for the Housing Authority Symphony at Carnegie Recital Hall served as a showcase for George Taylor, a 23-year-old violist who has been associated with the group for some time. A student of Burton Kaplan, among others, he was heard in works by Telemann, Bratms, Martinu and Philip Hough.

title: 11 Sing at Met Audition, And All 11 Ale
description: ONE by one, 11 young singers stepped on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon to sing two arias apiece. They received this rare opportunity as finalists in the annual auditions conducted by the Met's National Council, and this year, rather than awarding first, second and third prizes, each one was a winner, equally dividing the total prize money of $34,000.

title: Coaltion Finds Errors Cause Food Problems For Welfare Families
description: Welfare recipients have been waiting around the schools in East Harlem for the garbage to be set out so they can go through the bags, pick out halves of sandwiches and whatever else the kids have thrown out, according to a coalition of nine socialservice groups in the metropolitan area.

title: Pan Am Attendants Reach a Pact
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI)  After 17 months of negotiations and a fourhour walkout, the union representing flight attendants for Pan American World Airways reached tentative agreement with the carrier early today on a new threeand-a-half-year contract.

title: Giants
description: CINCINNATI, April 8 (AP)  Rick Auerbach doubled and Joe Morgan drove him home with a single to give the Cincinnati Reds a 10inning, 76 victory over the San Francisco Giants today. It was the Reds first victory after three straight losses to the Giants.

title: Autos: Villeneuve First at Long Beach
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 8 Gilles Villeneuve took a leisurely Sunday drive in his Ferrari 312T4 today and won the fifth running of the Long Beach Grand Prix. Showing a mastery of the 2.02mile, 12turn track, the 27year old FrenchCanadian won his second consecutive Formula One Grand Prix in stunningly easy fashion.

title: Musings of Local Poets to Greet Hardened Riders of the L.L.R.R.
description: Ten Long Island poets. some of whom have never had their works published. will soon have their work read by hundreds of thousands of people.

title: Rocket Attack Forestalled
description: TEL AVIV, April 8  A Palestinian Arab led police to a rocket launcher aimed at Tel Aviv from a suburban hillside today. The rocket was dismantled about 15 minutes before a timing device was to have launched it, according to Menashe Golan, deputy police commander of the Jerusalem area.

title: QE2, Unassisted By Harbor Tugs, Docks Smoothly
description: At a pace the captain described as brisk walk, the Queen Elizabeth 2, without the aid of tugboats, slid toward her berth early yesterday morning at Pier 90 at too sharp an angle.

title: Hudson's Bay Backs New Bid
description: TORONTO, April 8  The directors of the Hudson's Bay Company have thrown their weight behind Kenneth Thomson, the Toronto newspaper publisher, in his battle with George Weston Ltd. for control of Canada's largest denartment store chain_

title: Deaths
description: BORODINLeo F., beloved husbare of Gabrielle, devoted father of Bet

title: World News Briefs
description: TOKYO, Monday, April 9 (AP)  Conservative or centrist candidates won or were leading in 14 of 15 elections for prefectural governors in Japan, ousting leftist governments from the major prefectures of Tokyo and Osaka, according to early returns today.

title: Paris Fashions Unveiled In Super Bowl Style
description: PARIS, April 8  The greatest fashion show on earth opened here this weekend with all the delicacy of a heavyweight champion boxing bout.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Although the siege atmosphere that prevailed in the nuclear energy industry last week has largely disappeared, unanswered questions persist about the future role of reactors.

title: BILLY CARTER LINK TO LIBYA REPORTED
description: ATLANTA, April 8  Billy Carter's expensepaid trip to Libya last September - the genesis of his escorting of the Libyan group that toured the United States later was also the beginning of plan for a corporate association with the Government of Cot. Muammar el-Qaddafi. according to persons who went with President Carter's brother to Tripoli.

title: Keep the E in H.E.W.
description: The Senate has revised the bill to establish a cabinetlevel Department of Education which the House leadership last year tried wisely but unsuccessfully bury. The pressure to establish such a department comes mainly from the National Education Association. As the teachers largest trade organization, the N.E.A. has an understandable interest in being represented within the Cabinet. But that is exactly why a department with such a special base is unwise. It threatens to distort the broad and complex interests that more truly comprise education.

title: P.L.O. to Step Up Attacks in Israel
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 8  The central council of the Palestine Liberation Organization endorsed measures today to intensify guerrilla and political action aimed at undermining Israeli plans for moves toward autonomy on the West Bank and in the Gaza Strip.

title: Integrated Suburbs Now Fearful Of Not Drawing Enough Whites
description: PARK FOREST SOUTH, Ill.  When this placid suburban village was carved out cf cornfields 30 miles south of the Chicago Loop eight years ago, every effort was made to open it to all races.

title: KOCH ASKED TO STOP NEW CONSTRUCTION, CLOSE 200 SCHOOLS
description: The New York City Planning Commis sion called on Mayor Koch yesterday reject all major new capitalconstructior projects in preparing his 197980 exec tive budget.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: . Yeelorday's Weether al 1 P.M.: Nationel Oesenc and Almemphric Adminestrstiort /UPI

title: Ceausescu Begins African Tour
description: LONDON, April 8 (Reuters)  President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania arrived in Benghazi, Libya, today at the start of his third African tour in seven years. Mr. Ceausescu, who was accompanied by his wife, Elena, will also visit Gabon, Angola and Zambia. during his twoweek tour.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Gallows Humor Covers More Than a Nuclear Reactor
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 8  While the antinuclear demonstration was underway on the Capitol steps here today, Jaron Phillips wandered through the crowd with her 3-year-old mongrel, Patches, which bore a placard on its back asking: How do I evacuate?

title: Good News
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., April 8  The lowering of pressure in the reactor coolant system  a step toward cold shutdown that one Nuclear Regulatory Commission official described as similar to letting out the bubbles in a bottle of champagne  continued for the second day at Three Mile Island today with only minor and easily correctable difficultiec

title: Dr. Aura Severinghaus, ExDean At the Columbia Medical College-
description: Dr. Aura Edward Severinghaus, associate dean emeritus of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died Saturday at the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. Dr. Severinghaus, who lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, was 84 years old.

title: Anna Spector Wed To Harris Decker
description: Anna Spector, a communications manager with the international banking group at Citibank, and Harris Andrew Decker. treasurer of the Municipal Assistance Corporation for New York City, were married last evening at the Aventura Country Club in Miami. Rabbi Leon Kronish perfipmed the ceremony.

title: Lawmakers Act to Ban Head Shops
description: Until a couple of months ago, youngsters could walk into the Record Mill in Millburn, N.J., and, besides records, buy such drugculture paraphernalia as rolling papers and roach clips, with which they took surreptitious drags of marijuana at school.

title: Floyd Triumphs With Closing 67
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., April 8 (AP)  Ray Floyd capped a comeback from a sixshot deficit with birdies on the last two holes, finishing with a five-underpar 67 that lifted him to a oneshot victory today in the Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.

title: Knicks to Get 3d Draft Pick
description: The Knicks will have the third pick In the National Basketball Association's June 25 college basketball draft. In trading Bob McAdoo to the Boston Celtics, New York got three firstround draft choices  Boston's and those belonging to the Golden State Warriors and Seattle SuperSonics, which the Celtics acquired in previous deals. The Celtics finished with a 2953 wonlost record, the third worst in the league.

title: The Race Is on in New Hampshire To Copy Carter Formula
description: CONCORD, N.H., April 7  Like generals preparing to fight the next war with lessons learned from the last one, Presidential hopefuls are already flocking to New Hampshire in imitation of President Carter's early and successful primary campaign here in 1975.

title: Arms for Yemen. Qualms for Us.
description: President Carter announced his decision on March 7 to sell Yemen $390 million worth of arms. Since this consignment includes sophisticated weaponry, he also announced that the arms would have an appropriate escort of American military advisers. Whatever the merits of the Yemen policy, the mode of making it raises serious questions.

title: Rhodesian Rebel Chiefs Meeting African Heads
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April (Reuters)  Rhodesian guerrilla leaders were meeting the heads of black nations bordering the whiteruled country today in an apparent move to forge greater unity before this month's Rhodesian elections.

title: The ArmamentsFactory Worker
description: I cannot influence the fate of the globe. Do I start wars? Now can I know whether I'm for or against?

title: The Region
description: A New Jersey Superior Court judge last night ordered striking tugboat operators to begin immediately to haul out to sea tons of sewage sludge that has been piling up at treatment plants in northern New Jersey since the work stoppage began a week ago.

title: Soccer: Cosmos Win, 32
description: WASHINGTON, April 8  Seninho played the opportunist for the second straight game today when his shootout goal gave the Cosmos a 32 victory over the Washington Diplomats before 24,862 fans at Kennedy Stadium.

title: Carter Figures on Big Oil Shortfall at Issue
description: WASHINGTON, April 8  In his speech on energy last Thursday, President Carter said that the United States had been dangerously exposed to sudden interruptions in oil supplies and that the upheaval in Iran again cut world suonlies.

title: Suns, Sonics Primed for Playoffs
description: This week's team power ratings, The New York Times's final computerized ranking of National Basketball Association teams, reveal some interesting trends in the performances of playoffbound clubs.

title: 75 Robbed in a Brooklyn Club
description: Eight robbers, their pistols blazing, burst into a Brooklyn social club early yesterday morning, forcing 75 patrons to strip. One who refused was shot. The gunmen crashed past the door of the Ozone Layer Disco at 846 Flatbush Avenue at A.M. yesterday shooting into the ceiling. witnesses said. They made the patrons lie on the dance floor as they rummaged through their clothes and stripped off their jewelry. When one patron, 38-yearold Winston Ricketts, refused to cooperate the robbers shot him, wounding him slightly in the head.

title: Singapore Airlines Orders Airbuses
description: SINGAPORE. April 8, (Reuters) - Singapore Airlines plans to buy eight Europeanbuilt A300 Airbus aircraft, an airline spokesman said today.

title: Tiller, 31, Captures Santa Anita Race
description: ARCADIA, Calif., April 8 (UPI) Tiller outdueled Exceller in the stretch today and captured the 40th running of the $200,000 San Juan Capistrano Invitational Turf Handicap, the closingday feature of the Santa Anita meeting.

title: Piano: Miriam Brickman
description: BILLED as an unprecedented pianistic, poetic and visual experience, Miriam Brickman's Music in Images recital in Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night was indeed an unusual event. The aLdience was greeted in the lobby by an exhibition of contemporary painting and sculpture, all of it presumably re lated to the music to be heard later at the concert, which itself consisted pri manly of works inspired by poetry. Miss Brickman, who has also pursued career as an actress, recited the relevant literary sources in the original languages and then proceeded to play the music.

title: Pakistan Denies It Plans ABomb; Denounces Washington Aid Cutoff
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 8 Pakistan denied today that it was trying to develop nuclear weapons and denounced Washington's decision last week to terminate American aid on the suspicion that such a nuclear program was under way.

title: TEHERAN ANNOUNCES 4 MORE EXECUTIONS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Monday, April 9 Three former officials of the Shah's regime and an expoliceman were executed after secret trials today as Iran's revolutionary authorities disregarded criticism of yesterday's execution of former Prime Minister Amir Abbas Hoveida.

title: Mayors Are Taking a New Look At Problems of America's Cities
description: Our biggest problem, Mayor Henry Maier of Milwaukee said, slamming the conference table with the flat of his hand, is communicating the essence of the urban problem. We live in a society where minutiae is paraded as important.

title: Dance:
description: BETH SOLL AND COMPANY, a moderndance group from Boston, came to the Merce Cunningham Studio on Saturday night and offered eight works by Miss Soll that resembled glinting shards of movement

title: New Oil Rise to Spur Petrochemical Spiral
description: Prices of plastic wi ip, photographic film, nylon stockings and other products made from petroleum derivatives will inevitably rise as a result of recent increases in the price of oil, according to industry spokesmen.

title: Tennis: Borg Beats McEnroe in Final
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 8 (UPI)  Bjorn Borg of Sweden defeated John McEnroe, 6.4, 62, in hour 13 minutes today to win the $175,000 World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: 23 Hurt and 50 Homes Destroyed As Tornado Hits Arkansas Town
description: CAMDEN, Ark., April 8 (AP)  At least 23 persons were injured and about 50 homes destroyed today when a tornado touched down in this southern Arkansas community, state officials said.

title: Politically Split Elections Board Teams Up to Do jot
description: When the Staten Island Republican County Committee met to pick a candidate for the Assembly, Adelaide Brescia voted against the county leader's choice. The next week she was called in and dismissed from her $92.75aweek parttime clerk's job at the Board of Elections.

title: The Apprentices in the Masters
description: THE Masters, the congenial company of friends that Bobby Jones and Clifford Roberts established in 1934, inspires an abiding affection and admiration among the likes of Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer, Ben Hogan, Sam Snead, Gene Sarazen and a long line of other great golfers. Its effect on newcomers. thouuh. is somethine eke

title: Radical Arabs Win Fight to Punish Egypt, but Can They?
description: DAMASCUS, April 8  On the surface, the decisions made last weekend in Baghdad by 19 members of the Arab League appeared to be a victory for the radicals led by Iraq, which demanded a total rupture with Egypt for signing a peace

title: The New York Times/Paul Hosefros.
description: Celebrates Palm Sunday and 100th Year of Baptism

title: Bangladesh Wooing Businesses
description: DACCA, Bangladesh  After an unsuccessful experiment with socialized industry, Bangladesh has begun courting private enterprise, both foreign and domestic, in an effort to stimulate its economic growth and development.

title: Geneva Trade Meeting
description: HONG KONG, April 7  Hong Kong will attend the concluding session of the Multilateral Trade Negotiations in Geneva on April 11 but will not initial any of the documents, Lawrence Mills, director of trade, said in a statement. He said Hoag Kong needed more time to consider whether it should participate in the trade agreements.

title: Calgary Thrives on Oil to Become the Houston of Canada
description: CALGARY, Alberta  Calgary, says Al Ross, is the headquarters city for booms.

title: Pakistan Regains Calm After 4 Days of Turmoil
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 8 Calm returned to the streets of Pakistan today, following four days of angry demonstrations by supporters of Zulfikar All Bhutto.

title: Nunez Again Takes Junior Tennis Event
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 8 Hugo Nunez of Rockaway, N.J., became the first twotime winner today by repeating last year's victory in the 12th annual junior indoor tennis tournament here.

title: Opera: Daughter of the Regiment
description: THE NEW YORK CITY OPERA gave Donizetti's Daughter of the Regiment twice Saturday, and for the matinee an entirely new cast of principals took over the opera. Making his debut with the company was Dan Sullivan in the role of Sulpice, and singing their parts for the first time with the company were Gianna Rolandi as Marie, Alan Kays as Tonio and Jane Shaulis as the Marquise of Berkenfield.

title: Koch's Hope of Aid Dealt Heavy Blow in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, April 8  New York City's No. I legislative priority this year a measure designed to channel $68 million to help close Mayor Koch's budget I deficit  ran into heavy opposition in Congress last week, even before efforts planned by the city to lobby for it got under way.

title: The Editorial Notebook Whither the Civil Rights Movement?
description: The news that James Farmer. founder of the Congress of Racial Equality, plans with friends to establish a new civil rights organization prompts an obvious question: What will it do? Indeed, what should be the business these days of such venerable groups as the N.A.A.C.P. and the Urban League?

title: John Tops Brewers In Debut
description: Sal Bando, who joined Milwaukee two years ago as a free agent, telephoned and wrote Tommy John last November in an attempt to lure the pitcher to the Brewers as a free agent. But yesterday Bando and the rest of the Brewers found themselves facing John, pitching against them in his Yankee uniform.

title: TEXAS CAPITAL BACKS ATOM PLANT FUNDS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April S  Supporters of nuclear energy won a victory here yesterday when voters approved continued participation in a 25M-1-r 7Trtwatt.. nuclear power plant.

description: Demonstrators marched in front San Francisco's city hall yesterday to denounce a Pacific Gas & Electric Company nuclear plant scheduled to start operation this year near San Luis Obispo. Ralph Nader, the consumer activist, address the crowd. estimated at 7.000.

title: When Spring Comes In, Siberians Go Ice Fishing
description: ON THE VILYUI RIVER, U.S.S.R.  What do Siberians do in the springtime? They go ice fishing.

title: Shelling Gives Kampala Its First Real Night of War
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 8 (Reuters) Heavy fighting was reported over the weekend in and around Uganda's besieeed capital of Kampala.

title: A.C.C. Coaches Like Basketball Clock
description: DURHAM, N.C., April 8 (UPI)Seven Atlantic Coast Conference basketball coaches say they would like to try a shot clock for A.C.C. games next season and would vote for it at a conference meeting next month.

title: Around the Nation
description: PAXTON. Ill., April 8 (AP)  Five persons, including two police officers and two brothers of a wounded civilian, were killed last night in a highway battle after the officers stopped a car for speeding. The police were searching for alarmed

title: Down Yonder in New Orleans
description: ONE of the first things a visitor sees on the way into New Orleans from the airport is a highway sign reading Slidell, with an arrow pointing left. If he is 50 years old and has any interest in boxing, the name rings a bell, for this town just north of Lake Pontchartrain was the birthplace of Tony Canzoneri, one of the busiest and best of all the little men.

description: Energy

title: 27 Tank Cars Involved
description: CRESTVIEW, Fla., April 8 (AP)  The Louisville & Nashville Railroad freight train that derailed over the Yellow River scattered 27 tankers and one car of livestock feed along the tracks at the edge of the river, said Bill Heffren, a spokL.sman for the railroad in Louisville. Kv.

title: Wedge Group Pact With Merchants Inc.
description: Merchants Inc. announced it had reached an agreement in principle for the cash sale of substantially all of its assets and business to the Wedge Group, a private investment group with headquarters in Houston.

title: Southern Pacific Takes on Bell
description: BURLINGAME, Calif.  In C. Gus Grant's office at the Southern Pacific Communications Company hangs a large cartoon showing him attempting to slay the giant Ma Bell.

title: Cowens Is Quitting As Coach of Celtics
description: The Boston Celtics will have a new coach and a new owner next season. Dave Cowens, the playercoach, said yesterday he would not return as coach, and Harry Mangurian, who owns 50 percent of the team, said that the managing partner, John Y. Brown, had agreed to sell him the other 50 percent.

title: RCA Assembles Fare For First Video Disks
description: For 12 years, in his various capacities at the National Broadcasting Company ranging from program executive in Hollywood to president and chief executive, Herbert S. Schlosser had been engrossed at this time of year in the preparation of the network's fall prom cchpdule_

title: Music: Philharmonth Meets the Moderns
description: AGOOD deal of the most interesting contemporary music of the last 15 years has involved the repetition of simple elements. Such simplicity seems simpleminded to some, but often it attains profound meditational ends. The fourth and final Meet the Moderns concert by Lukas Foss and the Brooklyn Philharmonia on Friday night at the Brook- lyn Academy of Music, entitled Repetition and Meditation, couldn't hope to explore all the ramifications of this fascinating interrelation between Western music and Eastern religion. But it at least made an honorable stab at it.

title: Hess to Curtail Store Hours
description: Hess's Inc., a departmentstore chain based in Allentown, Pa., announced over the weekend that, in keeping with President Carter's energy directives, it would curtail some of its spring and summer sh000ine hours.

title: Ballet: Haydn Premiere
description: THE EGLEVSKY BALLET is presenting increasingly eclectic bills these days. On Saturday at Hofstra University's JohII Cranford Adams Playhouse in Hempstead. L.1., the company presented a model program that had something for everyone on both sides of the stage.

title: Sandra Post's 70 Beats Miss Lopez
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 8 How much closer could it have been? They both had firstround 68's, secondround 70's and thirdround 68's.

title: Government Is Unseen Editor in Magazine Offices
description: MADISON, Wis., April 6  For nearly two weeks now The Progressive magazine has had the distinction of being the only publication in the nation's history operating under the prior restraint of a Federal court in iunet inn

title: Phyllis Beth Witzel Bride Of Mark Speiser, Student
description: Phyllis Beth Witzel, who will graduate next month from the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, was married yesterday to Mark Alan Speiser, a master's candidate in corporate law at the New York University Law School. The ceremony %, as performed at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I., by Rabbis Louis Bernstein and Judah Washer.

title: TV: Two Variety Shows Precede Oscar Awards
description: AS leadins to the Academy Award cermonies tonight, ABC is presenting two variety shows that are apparently calculated to make the naming of the best special effects and sound recording seem galvanically exciting.

title: Lorrie Taylor, a Student, Is Bride of Joshua Blank
description: Lorrie Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Taylor of Lynn, Mass., was married yesterday to Joshua Blank, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Irwin M. Blank of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The ceremony was performed at Temple Shalom in Newton, Mass., by the bridegroom's father, chairman of the board of ministry of Harvard University.

title: Issue and Debate Con Ed and the Burning of Dirtier Fuel
description: Five times in the last six years the Consolidated Edison Company of New York has petitioned the state and city environmental authorities for special permission to burn cheaper but dirtier highersulfur oil in place of the increasingly expensive imported lowsulfur oil required by law. Twice the company was turned down. Emergency approval was granted once  for four months during the Arab oil boycott of 197379, and later it was partly extended.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 10, 1979

title: Technology Spreading in Third World
description: THEY have invented an inexpensive solar heater, made with burnedout fluorescent tubes, that pasteurizes water, assuring a supply of safe drinking water for poor families in the tropics.

title: Mets to Try Once More For Opener
description: ATLANTA April 9 (AP)  Torn Seaver and Johnny Baw.h belted home runs tonight as the Cincinnati Reds trounced Atlanta, 94, in the Braves home opener.

title: U.S. Soccer Team Gains Despite Shuffled Lineups
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 9 Walt Chyzowych, the coach of the United States soccer team, spent a hectic week here worrying as much about airline schedules as games. Today he called it a minor miracle that his team had survived.

title: two Chinese Provincial Officials Are Purged for Links to Radicals
description: PEKING, April 9 (Reuters)  A former Hunan Province official has been expelled from the Communist Party and arrested for his ties with Mao Zedong's purged radical associates, a provincial broadcast has reported

title: Excerpts From the Papal Letter
description: ROME, April 9 (AP)  Following are excerpts from the official English text of Pope John Paul's letter to priests of the Roman Catholic Church in which he addresses the subject of priestly celibacy. The ongtnal was in Polish.

title: Convict in Alabama, Fighting Death Law, Still Wants Execution
description: ATLANTA, April 9  The decision by John Louis Evans 3d to challenge the constitutionality of the Alabama death statute that took him within six hours of his execution last week in no way alters his wish to die, his personal lawyer said today.

title: Starting to Protect Privacy
description: The Carter Administration may well deserve the praise it is giving itself for being the first administration to develop a comprehensive national policy on individual privacy. That policy, manifested in bills just

title: Marcel Jouhandeau, 90; Eminent French Writer
description: PARIS, April 9  Marcel Jouhandeau, a noted French writer, died in his home in RueilMalmaison Saturday evening, his family said. He was 90 years old.

title: Garrett Price, Artist, 82, Dead; Did Covers for The New Yorker
description: Garrett Price, an artist and cartoonist for The New Yorker magazine, died Sunday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and a longtime resident of Westport, Conn.

title: About New York
description: The score is 1 to 1 when Sister Marguerite turns on her car radio after finishing her classes at St. Francis Prep.

title: Rangers Open vs. Kings
description: The Rangers, the fifthbest club in the National Hockey League, will play the 10thbest club, the Los Angeles Kings, tonight at Madison Square Garden in the opener of the two-of-threegame Stanley Cup playoffs. The teams met four times during the regular season, and the Rangers won three and lost once. Sounds good for Ranger fans, doesn't it? it might not be.

title: Where to Hang George and Martha
description: Civil strife seems imminent between Boston, Mass., and Washington, D.C., over a pair of unfinished Gilbert Stuart portraits of George and Martha Washington. In 1831, three years after the artist's death, his widow sold the works to the Athenaeum, a private library in Boston, for $1,500, and for more than a century they have been on loan to that city's Museum of Fine Arts.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERJules A loving and devoted husband, father, friend, and master teacher has left us too suddenly, too soon. We mourn with Sue, Wendy, Geoffrey, and their family, the tragic loss of our dear Jules, giver of wisdom and the knowledge of lute to so many young people whose own lives have been so deeply enriched and made purposeful by his mind, his heart, his hands. He is gone yet he lives

title: Yanks Set to Activate Beniquez Soon
description: Twentysix players will begin the Yankees first road trip of the season tonight in Baltimore. Only 25 will finish it next Sunday in Chicago. Juan Beniquez will be one of the 25. Paul Blair most likely will not.

description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, April 6, 1979

title: Clues to Fetus Found in Mother's Blood

title: Baston Takes Archery
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.. April 9 (AP)Rodney Boston of Baton Rouge won first place in the national indoor archery championships Sunday. The women's victor was Janet Dobrman, an East Stroudsburg State student. Linda Magratten of Brooklyn, New York placed third.

title: House Acts to Cut Syria From Economic Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)  The House of Representatives voted today to suspend aid to Syria, which was criticized in debate as a radical nation trying to destroy President Carter's Middle East peace effort.

title: Blue Law Ruled Invalid by Court In Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, April 9  The Connecticut Supreme Court today upheld a lower court ruling declaring the state's Sunday closing law unconstitutional.

title: Bridge:
description: A stunning turnabout marked the concluding session of the Long Island Regional Knockout Team Championship in Hempstead Sunday night. At the midpoint of a threeteam final, a four- some composed of Bill Pollack and Frank Mirchin of Teaneck, N.J., Amalya Kearse of New York and Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn., appeared to be coasting to victory, after building a massive lead against each of the nval teams.

title: 5 Killed on Road to Florida Keys
description: MIAMI, April 9  Five persons were killed in a headon collision on a busy twolane highway leading to the Florida Keys last night. The 30mile stretch of Route from Florida City to Key Largo is known as being the scene of a high number of fatal auto accidents.

title: 79 Inflation Rise Seen In Germany
description: BONN, April 9  The leading eca nomic institutes of West Germany said today that recent oil price rises would push up the annual rate of increase in consumer prices to 3.5 percent this year from 2.6 percent in 1978.

title: TaxFree Housing Bonds Boom
description: REDONDO BEACH, Calif., April 9In this pleasant coastal community near Los Angeles, more than 200 condo.. minium units are rising next to a boatfilled marina. The new homes will offer buyers ample space, spectacular views of the Pacific, prices ranging from $100,000 to $175,000, and mortgages priced at a bargain rate of 8.71 percent.

title: China Beats U.S. Squad In Basketball by 10496
description: PEKING, Apnl 9 (AF)  Led by 7foot2mch Mu Tiezhu, the Chinese Army basketball team scored a 10496 upset victory over a United States allstar college squad before 18,000 spectators tonight.

title: Korea Plans More U.S. Purchases
description: Gak Kyu Choi, South Korea's Minister of Commerce and Industry, said yesterday that his country planned to reduce its growing dependence on imports from Japan by, among other things, shifting to exports from the United States.

title: Poll Shows Sharp Rise Since 77 In Opposition to Nuclear Plants
description: Public opposition to nuclear power plants, apparently stirred by the recent accident in Pennsylvania, has sharply increased since 1977, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Deaths
description: POUCIDowninIck. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Dominick Pouca, associated with The Times from 1956 until retiring inI972.

title: Pope, in Letter to Priests, Reaffirms Celibacy Rule as Holy Commitment
description: ROME, April 9  In a letter to all Roman Catholic priests, Pope John Paul II urged today that they keep faith with their commitment to celibacy and not ask to be released from their vows at moments of crisis.

title: CivilPlane Trade Pact Is Reported
description: GENEVA, April 9  An agreement to eliminate by Jan. 1, 1980, all customs duties and similar charges on sales of civilian aircraft and parts has been reached at the world trade negotiations here, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: While bond traders and investors pondered whether the Federal Reserve would soon tighten monetary policy, interest rates rose sharply yesterday morning. The Treasury sold three- month outs at an average aiscount rate of 9.65 percent, secondhighest on record, and traders predicted that 15year Government bonds might yield 9 percent when sold today. This would be the highest rate ever paid on a longterm Treasury bond issue.

title: Around the Nation
description: Army Eases Standards To Attract More Women

title: Post Editor Testifies About Plans To Photograph Berkowitz in Jail
description: The picture editor of The New York Post testified yesterday that she had bought a compact spy camera to have illegal pictures taken of David Berkowitz, the socalled Son of Sam killer, while he was in fail

title: Syrians Predict EgyptIsrael Rift
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 9  Synan leaders are convinced that the EgyptianIsraeli peace will fail within a year and that the only viable alternative then will be to return to a collective approach to peace through the United Nations.

title: Islanders
description: The New York Islanders, who finished with the best record in the National Hockey League, will probably face the Chicago Black Hawks in the quarterfinal round of the Stanley Cup playoffs at Nassau Coliseum next Monday.

title: Charles E. G. Lloyd; Head of Trust Group In Bank Association
description: Charles E. G. Lloyd, former executive manager of the trust division of the New York State Bankers Association, died Saturday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 66 years old and lived at Woods End Road, New Canaan, Conn.

title: Machine-Shop Owner Shot Dead, Fourth in Basque Area in 3 Days
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, April 9 (AP)  Gunmen shot and killed the owner of a machine shop today near this northern city, the police said. He was the fourth shooting victim in the Basque country in three days.

title: Stage: FunVerse Lunch
description: WHAT a splendid and simple idea it is, to take two visiting British actors with marvelous voices and have them do poetry readings at lunchtime at the cozy Subplot Cabaret of the American Place Theater.

title: Laotians Wilt Under the Burden Of Long Indoctrination Sessions
description: VIENTIANE, Laos  If a Laotian is not yet fully familiar with the contents of the Sixth Resolution, it is certainly not for lack of having its interminable text hammered into him, again and again, at sammina after sammina.

title: Cosmos Hope to Sign Cruyff's Teammate by July
description: The Cosmos acknowledged yesterday that they had talked to Johan Neeskens, the Dutch soccer star, but denied that they had signed the 27-yearold member of the Netherlands 1978 World CUD team.

title: Study Sees Health Risks To Copper Workers
description: Exposure to such hazardous substances as arsenic and sulfur dioxide poses health risks to coppersmelting workers, an environmental research organization said yesterday.

title: AcrossBoard Bets Draw 13,231 to Big A
description: Horse racing returned to across-theboard normalcy at Aqueduct yesterday as union parimutuel clerks went back to work after a 52day strike.

title: Vernitron Buys Unit of Ogden
description: The Vernitron Corporation, a diversified producer of electronics goods, scientific equipment and healthcare products, has acquired the Better Built Machinery Corporation, maker of industrialgrade washers, dryers and sterilizers, from the Ogden Corporation for an undisclosed amount of cash, it was announced yesterday.

title: A No. 2 Man on the Move
description: Morgan V. Hunter dropped the other shoe yesterday with the announcement that he would become president and chief operating officer of the Scott Paper Company on May 1. He will succeed Charles D. Dickey Jr., 61 years old, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: College Admission: Confronting the Tensions Between Student and Parent
description: NEW HAVEN  There is a day in the life of many high school seniors known as Bloody Monday, when the envelope from that prestigious college of first choice arrives in the mailbox, in- stantly signifying by its girth whether or not the student has gained the coveted admission. A fat envelope, which contains all the necessary information regarding registration, means acceptance. A thin one simply announces rejection.

description: Morning

title: Assocsated Press
description: UGANDAN REFUGEES crossing into Kenya on Sunday to escape fighting near Kampala. Forces of President Id Amin of Uganda have resisted assault by Tanzanian

title: Pennsylvania's Governor Says Area Is Now Safe for Pregnant Women
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 9  Harold R. Denton of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission declared today that the crisis at Three Mile Island was over, and Gov. Dick Thornburgh said it was safe for pregnant women and young children to return to their homes.

title: Dance: Russian Festival at the Beacon
description: VERY good dancers and faststepping ones too are part of the program called A Festival of Russian Dance, which opened last night at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 79th Street, for run through Sunday.

title: High Rates of Cancer Found Near Nuclear Arms Plant
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 9  People who live downwind from the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant near Denver have substantially higher cancer rates than Denverarea residents who are not exposed to the plant's plutonium emissions, according to a report made public today by the director of the health deparment of Jefferson County, where Rocky Flats is situated.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO CURB KILLER SATELLITES
description: WASHINGTON,- April 9  The United States is mounting a quiet effort to conclude an accord with the Soviet Union on limiting antisatellite weapons in time for the signing of a strategic arms treaty. White House officials said today.

title: 8 Skiers Killed on Swiss Slopes; 5 Others Escape From Avalanche
description: SION, Switzerland, April 9 (Reuters) Eight skiers, four of them foreigners, died in mountain accidents over the weekend, the police said today, while five others escaped an avalanche unhurt.

title: U.S. Confirms It Will Sell to Israel Planes From Canceled Iran Order
description: WASHINGTON, April 9  The Defense Department confirmed today that F16 fighter planes originally purchased by Iran, which has canceled its order, would be delivered to Israel as part of a previously approved sale.

title: Big Board Directors
description: Robert S. Hatfield, chairman of the Continental Group, and Donald B. Smiley, chairman of R.H. Macy & Company, have been nominated as new directors of the New York Stock Exchange. Eight current directors were renominated for twoyear terms on the board of the nation's largest securities exchange and will also be voted on at the annual election on May 14.

title: 5 Stuarts Go to U.S. Gallery
description: A set of portraits of the first five American Presidents by the American painter Gilbert Stuart (1755-1828) has been acquired by the National Gallery of Art in Washington. The portraits, painted by Stuart between 1810 and 1825, are known as the GibbsCoolidge set, and have been owned by the Coolidge family of Boston since the 19th century.

title: North College Five Wins Jersey AllStar Contest
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 9Pat Morris, a 6foot3inch senior from Ramapo, hit a 3point play with six seconds left in overtime Sunday night to lift the North to a 112111 victory over the South in the third annual New Jersey Collegiate Basketball Coaches Association allstar game at Seton Hall University.

title: AnheuserBusch To Sell German Beer
description: ST. LOUIS, April 9 (AP) AnheuserBusch Inc. said today that it would begin testmarketing a West German beer in Atlanta, Boston and Hartford on April 30.

title: Hentyk W Szwarce, 48, Architect in New York
description: Henryk W. Szwarce, an architect who designed numerous homes and public buildings in New York City and New York State, died Saturday of cancer in New York. He was 48 years old.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MAN AMONG MEN Einstein's deep interest and active involvement in humanist and Jewish affairs is the focus of an exhibition of 50 items on view through May 31 at the Leo Baeck Institute, 129 East 7341 Street. Numer- ous letters, photographs and statements attest to facets of the scientist's life not stressed in other observances planned during this centennial year. The display at the documentation center specializing in the history of Germanspeaking Jews has received the coopertion of the Einsten estate and is supported by the New York Council for the Humanities.

title: Koch Says He Agrees With City's Planners On Capital Spending
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he agreed in principle with the City Planning Commission that New York City should cut its new capital spending as it prepared to serve a smaller population.

description: Several leading American banks are lending at less than what they say is their lowest interest rate, according to banking sources.

title: 5 in Stock Case Deny Charges

title: EDUCATION
description: ONE of the clearest challenges to the Federal Government's authority to regulate private higher education is quietly making its way through the courts, pitting a small liberal arts college in the hills of western Pennsylvania against the vast Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

description: Pacific Coast Holdings, a savings and loan and insurance brokerage company, said the proposed merger of the company into a unit of the State Mutual Savings and Loan Association of Newport Beach, Calif., had been approved by shareholders. Completion of the merger remains subject to approval by Federal and state regulatory agencies and to the receipt of favorable tax rulings.

title: Stage: Eadyhouse Blues
description: KEVIN O'MORRISON'S Ladyhouse Blues takes place in St. Louis in August 1919, and the year is as imvortant as the locale. The Maddens  a young widowed mother and her four daughters  are waiting for the various men In their lives to return from the war in France. As they converse in the family kitchen, sequestered against the heat of a scorching summer day, they demonstrate the solidarity of family. At the same time, we feel their world changing. The nation is in transition, not only emerging from a world war, but also moving into an age of industrialization and enlightenment. Houses are switching on to electricity, the labor movement is rising, and women are beginning to assert their independence.

title: Kahn Reaffirms Support For Voluntary Guidelines
description: WASHINGTON. April 9  Alfred E. Kahn, President Carter's thief adviser on inflation, said today that the Administration would persist in its program of voluntary price and wage standards to check inflation because the alternatives, mandatory controls or a bruising recession, were unacceptable.

Ford was indicted last September on charges that the auto maker recklessly designed the Pinto's fuel tanks.

description: A new breed of inventors, scientists, and engineers is emerging in the Third World. Many of them espouse the philosophy of appropriate technology, an approach born in the industrialized world to meet people's needs with simple hardware and processes. Article on Page 2.

title: WILLIAM A. DRAKE
description: William A. Drake, a former painter of sets and backdrops for Broadway shows and television productions, died Sunday at his home in Bergenfield, N. J. He was 87 years old.

description: Roderick C. Lankier yesterday was named special New York state anticorruption prosecutor, succeeding John F. Keenan, whom he had served as chief assistant.

title: Scientists Flock to Study Beached Whale
description: THE first signals of a whale stranding on Long Island reached the Scientific Event Alert Network in Washington at 9 A.M. on Tuesday, March 6. Word was immediately forwarded to Dr. James Mead, assistant curator of mammals at the Smithsonian Institution and one of the leading whale biologists in the United States.

description: A Canadian company said it wanted to buy F.W. Woolworth for $1.1 billion, in what would be one of the largest corporate takeovers successful. Woolworth directors said they would meet tomorrow consider the proposal from Brascan Ltd. [Page Al.]

title: Loans for Colombia
description: The Chemical Bank, as lead bank, announced the signing of a $600 million financing for Colombia and for Ecopetrol, the stateowned Colombian oil company. The financing consists of two 10year loans  $400 million for the Colombian Government and $200 million for Ecopetrol, which the Government guarantees.

title: Battles Erupt in Nicaragua Cities

title: Callaghan, Opening Campaign, Depicts Tories as Outdated
description: GLASGOW, April 9  Prime Minister James Callaghan opened the Labor Party's general election campaign tonight by depicting the opposition Conservative Party as a relic of the 1930's that offers yesterday's answers to yesterday's problems.

description: ROME, April 9 (AP)  The Bank of Italy announced today a set of moderately restrictive ceilings on bank credit at a time when an economic pickup and the Government's own hints had suggested that an easier policy could be expected.

He helped negotiate the company's first national agreement with the United Automobile Workers union and has been involved in negotiating such contracts ever since.

title: Recital: Gedda Sings of Spring
description: SINCE his first appearance in this country a little more than 20 years ago, Nicolai Gedda has carved out an enviable niche for himself in the pantheon of tenors. He has been the complete singer, as much at home in recital or in oratorio as on the opera stage, a musician of impeccable taste and musicality, as his dozens of recordings will attest. That he is no longer as satisfying vocally as he was a couple of decades ago ought to be no surprise, but somehow the realization proved disconcerting last night to this Gedda enthusiast of long standing.

title: Opera: Queler Orchestra Presents Verdi's Aroldo
description: IF you do not count several revamped and retitled works, Verdi wrote 26 operas, of which more than half hold firm places in the repertory, a remarkable survival rate. Among the others, perhaps halt a cozen have found their way onto stages with some consistency in recent years as a result of a Verdi fever that has set off explorations of obscure corners of his output. Possibly the most obscure of these corners is the one inhabited by Aroldo, which stands chronologically between Simon Boccanegra and Un Ballo in Maschera and is certainly the least known of Verdi's later works. Why this should be so was evident in a concert performance by Eve Queler's Opera Orchestra of New York at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night. In spite of fascinating patches, Aroldo sounded too much of the time like parodized Verdi.

Jolaine Mighton of Bohemia, L.I., was next with 72.25, and Karen Walsh of Johnson City, N.Y., finished third with 71.60.

title: Toys R Us Net Is Up by 39.5%
description: Toys R Us, the world's largest toy retail chain, earned more money in its fourth fiscal quarter ended Jan. 28 than it did in the full year, the company reported yesterday from its Saddle River, N.J., headquarters. The larger earnings were attributed to the heavy volume of Christmas business.

title: 2 Propose an Antidote To Cigarette Smuggling
description: ALBANY, Apnl 9  Two state legislators suggested a new approach today to curb the smuggling of cigarettes into the New York. The smuggling, believed to be controlled by organized cnme, denies the state $50 million in taxes each year.

title: Jersey Moving To Curb Arson In Urban Areas
description: TRENTON, April 9  The New Jersey Insurance Commissioner, in a move against landlords who fail to maintain their property or who are suspected of arsonforprofit, today approved a plan allowing quick cancellation of the subsidized fire insurance on such buildings.

title: TV: Channel 13 Offering a Documentary on Library of Congress
description: IT is probably inevitable that a firstrate documentary on a major American institution should be written by a Briton or, more precisely, a Welshman  who is also host for it. Americans generally are partial to exploring events and personalities. Sir Huw Weldon is fascinated with institutions (his ninepart Royal Heritage, a portrait of the British monarchy through its accumulated treasures, will be repeated on WNETTV beginning next Monday).

description: EDUCATIONAL detectives may be on the way to unraveling the elusive mystery of the effect of class size on student achievement, and the clues point to large classes as the villain.

title: COMPANY NEWS

title: Piano: Robelyn Schrade
description: ROBELYN SCHRADE received the Josef Lhevirme Pnze in 1976, when she graduated from the Juilliard School, and she was the last pianist to be given this award during the life of Rosina Lhevinne. As program notes for Miss Schrade's appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday afternoon pointed out, the late Madame Lhevinne bequeathed several shawls to her former pupil. The young pianist, possibly in the hope that a shawl is the same as a man- tie, has taken to wearing one of the bequests when she comes onstage, in memory of her great teacher This extramusical gesture, coupled with a demeanor and costume right out of Louise May Alcott, might have raised any suspicious listener's guard against Miss Schrade

description: LONDON  The expression labor movement is a general and emotional term that evokes certain ideas: the fight against poverty, hunger and degradation; the raising up of working people from their status as mere labor, as an abstraction, a factor of production; a recognition of their equal dignity and pnde in their function. The humanitarian purpose of the labor movement gave it the moral power of a crusade.

title: Wayne and Olivier Hailed by Academy
description: LOS ANGELES, April 9  That The Deer Hunter won best picture at the 51st annual Academy Awards tonight was almost incidental to the tact that John Wayne presented the award. Mr. Wayne, who underwent a ninehour operation for stomach cancer three months ago, answered the audience's applause with, That's the only medicine fellow really needs. Thin and slightly hoarse, Mr. Wayne continued: I'm mighty pleased that I can amble down here tonight. Oscar and I have something in common. Oscar first came to the Hollywood scene in 1928, and so did I. We're both a little weatherbeaten, but we're still here and plan to be around for whole lot longer.
