title: Operator May Be Misled by Pressure Readings, Advisory Unit Warns
description: WASHINGTON, April 9  The Government's senior advisory committee on reactor safety has concluded that the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear station indicates that it would be very difficult for the operators at 43 of the nation's 72 reactors to understand and properly control similar kinds of accidents because it is possible that their pressure gauges are misleading.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Iran's Closed Open Trials
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 9  Qasr Prison, like most prisons, is a grim, drab building surrounded by thick walls with watch towers, gun posts, steel doors and barred windows.

title: Researchers Tracking Brain's Own Tranquilizers
description: SIMPLE substances that may be the brain's natural means of controlling anxiety have been discovered recently in the course of research that is opening whole new realm of understanding of the chemistry of emotion. Whether the brain's natural tranquilizers have indeed been discovered is still a matter of debate among scientists, but there is widespread agreement that such internally produced anxiety controls exist and will be found.

title: Rates Rise On Home Mortgages
description: Interest rates on home mortgages are climbing again.

title: Events
description: Music

title: Of Law, Life and Death
description: The komitehs of revolutionary justice are working round the clock in Iran, executing the Shah's ministers and agents for crimes of state and violations of divine law. To put it more simply, the new rulers are killing off their predecessors, avenging the uses and abuses of power in the past and trying to preserve their own power in the present. It is not, alas, an uncommon phenomenon.

title: U.S. Moves to Provide More Jobs for Those It Trains
description: WASHINGTON, April 9  In a effort to make sure there are more jobs available for those who complete Federal job-training programs, the White House an,nounced today that local governments seeking economic development money from Washington would get preference from now on if they had projects that would create jobs for the chronically unemployed.

title: Brenner Berates Garden, Announces Leonard Bout
description: Teddy Brenner announced yesterday that he had made a match for Sugar Ray Leonard with Adolfo Viruet and had sold it to television.

title: EUGENE MALEK
description: Eugene Malek, director of the Jewish Philharmonic Chorus, died Sunday at Beth Israel Hospital in New York City after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: New SchoolBus Bids Providing Job Security Seen a Hope in Strike
description: Top publicschool officials and leaders of the striking schoolbus drivers union yesterday discussed a possible solution to the nearly-eight-week-old strike. Under the plan, new schoolbus bids would be thrown out and rebid with some provision for job security for the workers.

title: A Key Lukens Trait: The Personal Touch
description: COATESVILLE, Pa.  Fred Smith, the general supervisor of casting at the Lukens Steel Company's basic steel plant, watched admiringly as an operator dipped a huge magnet into railroad cars loaded with different types of scrap.

title: Miss Bellamy Urges Cutting 150 City Police Managers
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy charged yesterday that the Police Department was top heavy with managers at headquarters.

title: Teamster Talks Resume; Some Progress Reported
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 Negotiators for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the trucking industry made some progress toward a settlement of their contract dispute after 10 hours of negotiating today, according to Wayne L. Horvitz, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

title: Leonard Whitcup, 75, Lyricist, Composer of I Am an American
description: Leonard Whitcup, first vice president of the American Guild of Authors and Composers, died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital following a stroke. He was 75 years old and lived at 215 East 68th Street in New York.

title: Stockholders Back Sale of A. B. Dick
description: Stockholders of the A. B. Dick Company have voted to sell the business machines manufacturer to the British General Electric Company for $16.50 for each common share and $100 for each preferred share  a total of about $103 million. British General Electric, an electronics concern, is not connected with the General Electric Company in the United States.

title: Woman Studying at Columbia Found Slain in Apartment
description: A 23-year-old Columbia University graduate student was found stabbed to death yesterday morning in a West 76th Street room where, detectives said, she had visited a fellow student the night before.

title: Foster M. Coffin, 88, First Head Of the Student Union at Cornell
description: Foster M. Coffin, a former administrator of Cornell University who helped develop the Association of College UnionsInternational, died yesterday in a hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 88 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

title: Rhodesian Rebels Confer but Appear Not to End Feud
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 9 A conference called to unify the two wings of the guerrilla alliance before the elections in Rhodesia ended here today with no evidence that its aims were achieved.

title: Big Board Cites Dividends Increase
description: A record $41 2 billion in cash dividends were paid to holders of common stock last year by 1,373 companies that make up 883 percent of those listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Suns Playoff Prospects: Little Team That might
description: After the Phoenix Suns were beaten by the Boston Celtics in six games for the 1976 National Basketball Association championship, a book called, The Little Team that Could ... and Darn Near Did, became must reading throughout Arizona.

title: U.S. SAYS NEW YORK MAY SET ASIDE FUND TO OPERATE HOUSING
description: $100 MILLION IN AID INVOLVED

title: Australian Truck Men End Protest Blockade
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 9 (Reuters)  Truck drivers agreed today to end an eightday blockade of main roads after state governments promised to abolish roadmaintenance taxes and investigate low freight rates. The move lifted a threat of severe shortages of food and industrial supplies in major cities.

title: CPC to Settle Sugar Suits
description: CPC International Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to pay Se million to settle all the antitrust class actions, and most of the individual actions. against the company relating to its former sugarrefining business. CPC said it denied liability in the cases but agreed to the settlement to avoid the uncertainties and costs inherent in a jury trial of complex economic issues concermng 3 business the company sokl m 197A

title: Afghanistan Charges, But Pakistan Denies, A CrossBorder Raid
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 9  In another round of charges and countercharges by radio, Pakistan today denied an accusation by Afghanistan that Pakistani troops had crossed the Afghan border

title: Few Blacks on South Panels
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) civil rights group that surveyed 146 decisionmaking boards and commissions in 10 Southern states found that 60 percent had no black members and 51 percent had no women.

title: Theater: `Umabatha; ZuluFolklore Macbeth
description: UMABATHA is a version of Macbeth done in terms of Zulu folklore. Its author, Welcome Msomi, has used a troupe of black South Africans to reenact the main incidents of Shakespeare's play as if it were a tribal legend.

title: Athletes Playing Hard Also at Making Movies
description: Julius Erving headed for the sky, his left hand thrust out like Superman's, smacking a shot from Kareem AbdulJabbar's fingertips back toward the earth.

title: Florida Derailment: A Slow Return Home
description: CRESTVIEW, Fla., Apnl 9  About 3,000 people cautiously returned to their homes today in the pine woods north of here as workers continued efforts to stop the leakage of poisonous gases from the wreckage of 27 railroad cars derailed yesterday morning in a fiery crash that forced evacuation of a 300squaremile area.

title: Johns Hopkins Remains No. 1 In Lacrosse
description: The Johns Hopkins lacrosse team, perhaps the best in the country this season, is preparing for its sternest tests.

title: New York's Retail Sales Up by 6.7%
description: Sales of New York City's largest retailers, which advanced seasonal promotions in order to offset a later Easter this year, increased last month an average of 6.7 percent over those of the corresponding month in 1978, according to a spot check yesterday. The check showed a 6.3 percent advance in the metropolitan area.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What are neutrinos?

title: 1,158 Persons Queried After Computer Choice
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted last Thursday, Friday and Saturday with 1,158 adult men and women around the United States.

title: Evacuations of 20,000 Linked to Derailments
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI)  Al. most 20,000 people were evacuated in the first nine months of 1978 because of derailment of tank cars carrying deadly chemicals ranging from nail polish remover to liquified petroleum gas, Federal officials said today.

title: CANADIAN CONCERN SEEKS WOOLWORTH
description: $1.1 Billion Takeover by Brascan Would Rank With Largest

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 10, 1979

title: Sadat Awaits Calm in Storm
description: CAIRO, April 9  Although he apparently did not reckon on the breadth of Arab opposition to Egypt's peace treaty with Israel, President Anwar elSadat seems in no mood to encourage any reconciliation with his Arab critics ex-

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, April 9 (Reuters)  More than 30,000 Vietnamese soldiers are involved in the new offensive in western Cambodia against guerrillas loyal to Pol Pot, the ousted Cambodian leader, diplomats here said today.

title: Impresarios of Fashion Preside at Les Halles
description: PARIS, April 9  Karl Lagerfeld is genius. He can do anything he wishes in the world of cloth. His show for Chloe, staged in the largest tent in the Forum des Halles, was full of marvels. It also encansulates what is wrong with the Paris showings. Runways the length of football fields and cavernous spaces make spectacular displays the norm. Any relation between the clothes shown and the styles women might wear to small dinner party or to work is hard to grasp.

title: Can Islanders Win as Favorites?
description: Now that the New York Islanders are the National Hockey League's best team statistically, perhaps such status will help them become the best team artistically. Winning the regularseason championship should inspire them to win the Stanley Cup playoffs. But the Islanders must break a bad habit. As a favorite, they often are a flop. They were expected to eliminate the Toronto Maple Leafs the playoffs last year, but they lost. They had a 4point lead over the Montreal Canadiens nearly three weeks ago but

title: IN THE NATION Brown v. Budget
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif.  I can be pragmatic when I have to be, a leading California legislator says. I work with people who are usually pragmatic. But Jerry Brown is totally pragmatic.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday. API1110. 1979

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: EARNINGS United Technologies Net Climbs 33.8% in Quarter
description: The United Technologies Corporation reported yesterday a 33.8 percent firstquarter profit rise to a record $70.8 million, or $1.54 a share, from $52.9 million, or $1.39 a share, in the initial three months of 1978. Sales rose 21 percent to a new quarterly high of $1.79 billion from $1.47 billion.

title: Deaths
description: DOE PEL Henry W. Age 78, on April 10. 1979. of Newtown. CT, formerly of Mt. Vernon, NY. Beloved husband of Leslie Howe Doepel. Services Honan Funeral Home. 58 Main St, Newtown. CT Thursday, 11 AM. Interment Woodlavm cemetery. 1 PM.

title: Around the Nation
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 10 (AP)  A state appeals court today upheld the validity of 11thhour grants of clemency by former Gov. Ray Blanton to 14 prisoners.

title: Citicorp Note Auction
description: Citicorp reported yesterday that the average rate in its weekly auction of 91day notes rose to 10.178 percent from 10.116 percent last week. The bank holding company received $670 million in orders for the $100 million issue, with accepted bids ranging in rate from 10.150 to 10.230 percent. It took 80.8 percent of the bids made at the high rate.

title: Theater: Earnest at Equity Library
description: IT must be at least fourscore years since Oscar Wilde wrote The Importance of Being Earnest, and it is still a charming, if precious, piece with epigrams oozing over it as tastily as the jam spread over the scones  if indeed jam goes over sconesat teatime.

title: Best Buys
description: LAST week Bruce Ratner, New York City's consumer affairs commissioner, advised consumers to support his move for Beefless Wednesdays, a miniboycott designed to restrain soaring beef prices.

title: 3 Killed, Hundreds Flee In Bucharest Store Fire
description: BUCHAREST. Rumania, April 10 (AP)  Fire swept through Bucharest's Victoria department store today, killing three persons and forcing hundreds to flee through thick smoke, the official press agency Agerpres said.

title: Peak Yield On 15Year U.S. Bonds
description: The Treasury sold 15year bonds yesterday at an average yield of 9.14 percent, the highest rate ever paid on longterm Government bond issue.

title: Pop: Gong at CBGB's
description: THE name Gong may not be very well known to most popularmusic fans, but for its cult, it's a name to reckon with. Of course, just what it means is a subject for debate. Gong was originally an anarchic. communal European progressive jazzrock band. But the personnel has shifted continuously, and various more or less canonical Gongs have sprung up here and there.

title: U.S. Limits PriceRule Exceptions
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  In two decisions handed down today, the Council on Wage and Price Stability began to define the circumstances in which a company will be allowed to depart from the Administration's basic formula for price deceleration.

title: ILLEGALITY ON LOANS IS DENIED BY CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  President Carter said today that there had been no illegal action involving loans made to his family's peanut warehouse.

title: Russian and Guest From Bulgaria On Way to Visit 2 in Space Station
description: The Soviet orbiting station Salyut 6 has become an international meeting place in space, with Czechoslovak, Polish and East German astronauts working there from time to time with their Russian counterparts, and now a Bulgarian astronaut is on his way for a visit. He was launched yesterday aboard Soyuz 33.

title: Pickets Greet Rights Group Move
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 The board of directors of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference was picketed late today by dissident employees and members after the board's refusal to rescind the recent dismissal of its executive director, Hosea L Williams.

title: COMMODITIES Gold and Silver Futures Dip in Cautious Trading
description: A cautious mood pervaded the metals futures markets yesterday as the trade anticipated the President's news conference that took place after the close.

title: Deaths
description: SOLOMON  Florence. beloved wife of the late Samuel, devoted children Alfred and Alice, Martin and Lil, lian. Herbert and Judy. dear sister  Frances Lass, loving grandmother of Mark, Ilene, Howard. Jan. Lloyd. Barbara. Sharon and greatgrandchildren. Services Wed. 11:15 A.M. Schwartz Bros. Chapel, Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd.

title: Late Rally Lifts Dow to 6Month High
description: Spurred by a late rally, the Dow Jones industrial average pushed ahead yesterday to a sixmonth high. Certain glamours and an assortment of specialty issues posted the best gains.

title: Market Place
description: Insider Question On Woolworth

title: Nino Rota, 68, Writer Of Godfather Music
description: Nino Rota, who wrote the music for Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather and for nearly all of the films of the Italian director Federico Fellini, died yesterday of a blood clot in a Rome clinic. He was 68 years old.

title: Egypt Bars Apology to Israel for Private Speculation on Aiding Syria
description: CAIRO, April 10  Egypt said today that recent remarks by Prime Minister Mustafa Khalil on the conditions under which his country would give military aid to Syria had been widely misinterpreted and that there was no need for an apology, as demanded by Israel.

title: Deaths
description: WEIXELBAUMJesse W. of Westhampton Beach. NY, on April 10, 1979. Fattier of Gail Britt. David & Martin Weixelbaum. Also survived by 6 grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, 10am. at the McFarland E. Carman Memorial Chapel. Westhampton Beath. Interment to tollow at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, East Farmingdale. NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Temple Israel. Riverhead. NY. or Sloan Kettering Memorial Hospital, Cancer Care Center. NYC. would be appreciated.

title: Kennecott Reports Curtiss Fight Cost
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation disclosed yesterday in its annual report that it had spent about $2.4 million on legal and other expenses in last year's hectic battle with the CurtissWright Corporation over control of the Kennecott board.

title: Chicago Suit Says Mental Patients Were Used as Surgery Guinea Pigs
description: CHICAGO, April. 10  The Cook County public guardian has charged in a suit filed here that an undetermined number of mental patients were involuntarily subjected to experimental surgery at a University of Chicago hospital in the 1950's and 1960's.

title: Pop: 2 Black Groups
description: BLACK popmusic acts that came o prominence before the advent f the disco fad have their probems, and those problems were made manifest Monday night at Town Hall. First Choice and Crown Heights Affair, both of which fit into that category, played two shows on a rainy Monday night in an unfashionable locale. The crowd was thin for the first show; one wonders if anybody at all came for the second.

title: How Surcharge on Fuel Affects Monthly Rents
description: Following is an example of the effect of the fuel surcharges set by the Rent Guidelines Board yesterday. The hypothetical case concerns a $500 apartment whose tenant renewed an existing lease for one year. The lease also contained a rider permitting additional charges.

title: Transit Agency to Seek Bond Issue For 500 Subway and Railroad Cars
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will ask the New York State Legislature to ask the voters to approve a bond issue that would pay for 500 new subway and commuterrailroad cars and the rebuilding of 550 others.

title: Alice M. Goodman Is Dead at 76; Benefactor of Higher Education
description: Alice Matz Goodman, a philanthropist and the mother of State Senator Roy M. Goodman, Republican of Manhattan, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 76 years old and lived on Fifth Avenue.

title: Musica Sacra: St. Matthew Passion
description: THE Saint Matthew Passion is 250 years old this month Bach himself led the first performance in Leipzig on Good Friday. April 15. 1729 so the Musica Sacra's uncut presentation under Richard Westenburg's direction at Avery Fisher Hall Monday night carried an extra measure of significance.

title: An Old Testament Southpaw
description: The first pitch to a New York batter in New York's National League baseball season was low and outside. It was thrown by William Francis Lee 3d, regarded with distaste by Lee Mazzilli of the Mets and called a ball by Lanny Harris, an umpire up from the International League.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: POWER AND IMAGINATION. CityStates in Renaissance Italy. By Lauro Martines. 368 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Boy, 17, Seeks to Take Male Date to the Prom
description: CUMBERLAND, R.I., April 10 (AP)  A boy who wants to take a male escort to the junior prom at Cumberland High School was greeted with jeers and shouts today when he went to class.

title: Road War Sees Ticket Barrages By Bergen Police
description: MAHWAH, N.J. April 10  The yearold border feud over heavy trucking on the New JerseyNew York State line escalated again today as the Bergen County police began issuing $50 tickets to interstate truckers using the newly posted Main Street here, a short cut into New York's Rockland County.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IHAD rarely dined on Italian cooking before I came to the United States in 1939. I had never eaten pizza (they tell me that the pizza craze in this country is relatively recent, at least since World War II), and the only time we served pasta in France was as a garnish for a foreign dish such as veal Milanese.

title: Chess:
description: Counterattack is not the answer to every defensive problem. It may be appealing to take arms against a sea of troubles, to strike out actively, but there are situations where the glorious dynamic course results in drowning.

title: TESTS OF RADIATION FIND NORMAL LEVELS
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 10 (AP) Scores of people who live in homes or on farms near the contaminated Three Mile Island nuclear generating plant near Middletown received free radiation tests today and were told the computer checks confirmed that the radiation levels in their bodies were normal.

title: Jackson Moves To Bar Oil Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, chairman of the Senate Energy Committee, introduced legislation today to block President Carter's plan to phase out price controls on domestic oil.

title: Procter Payout Up to 85
description: Procter & Gamble Inc., producers of soaps, detergents, toiletries, processed foods and industrial products, raised its quarterly dividend yesterday to 85 cents a share on the common stock, payable May 15 to holders of record April 20. Shareholders had received 75 cents a share a quarter for the last year.

title: Italian Leftist Writer Is Reported Implicated in Aldo Moro Slaying
description: ROME, April 10  Investigators here say they have evidence, including a voiceprint, implicating an ultraleftist writer in the abduction and murder of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro last year.

title: Truck Indus fry And Teamsters Agree on a Pact
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  The teamsters union and trucking industry negotiators agreed on a new master freight contract tonight and announced that the 10dayold strike and lockout that has shut down much of the nation's truck traffic would end immediatedly.

title: Fellow Student Seized as Slayer Of Woman, 23
description: A 32yearold graduate student at Columbia University was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of a 23yearold woman in his room at 125 West 76th Street. The victim, Sheryl McCormick, also a graduate student at Columbia's School of International Affairs, had been stabbed and beaten.

title: Private Lives
description: MOST of the time here we are content let the culture take care of itself. We can get along without the culture, and often goes away if we waitlong enough. ,Engines of publicity drone by overhead; a hard rain of advertising messages pummels people in the streets; we are safe inside, out of fasthion, sucking on an orange. My house is my hot tub and My idea of nice evening is to stay home with new books and old music. I think of Proverbs (26:14): As the door turneth upon its hinges, so doth the slothful upon his bed.

title: Nuclear Plant Shutdown: Possible Blessing
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 10  One attempt at humor heard here in the last frenetic fortnight was that every radioactive cloud has a silver lining.

title: The City
description: Andrew Floyd caught a cab near Lincoln Center Monday night. When he arrived home, he realized he had left in the taxi an expensive attach case crammed with important papers.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Blacks and Mayor Talking, But Result Is Still in Doubt
description: The dispute between Mayor Koch and important elements of New York City's black leadership has settled into a battle for political support from influential but normally nonpolitical blacks.

title: France Blacks Out News on Blast At Plant Building Atomic Reactors
description: PARIS, April 10  French authorities have clamped an information blackout on their investigation into the bombing of a plant that produces nuclear reactors.

title: Holiday Recipes: At Home Abroad
description: Kulich

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AIR PORTS Many New Yorkers hurriedly walk past the pool of scholarly silence that is the Pierpont Morgan Library, at 29 East 36th Street just east of Madison Avenue. To read, browse or merely rest inside this magnificent retreat, amid so many rare and historical writings, is a Big Apple joy and a world apart.

title: Passover Feast Begins When Sun Sets Today
description: Passover begins at sundown today. The Jewish feast takes the form of a gathering, or seder meal, that features special foods and participation in the telling of the Passover story by use of a Haggadah, a book of scripture and song.

title: An Easter Memory: Ham a la Motel
description: My attempt one year to bring back the Easters of my English childhood turned a close friend into a vegetarian.

title: News Summary
description: A terrorist bomb exploded in Tel Aviv,  killing one person and injuring 36 as Passover Eve shoppers were teeming through an outdoor market. Six hours later, Israeli jets streaked across the Lebanese border and bombed two targets described by Israel's military command as training bases and staging areas for terrorist attacks against Israel. [Page A1, Columns 23.)

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Rangers Beat Kings in Playoff Opener, 71
description: The Rangers came up with the breaks, the goaltending and the goals last night in their opening game of the National Hockey League's firstround playoffs. That potent combination produced a 71 trouncing of the Los Angeles Kings before 17,372 cheering fans at Madison Square Garden and a 10 lead in the twoofthreegame series.

title: Trade Mission to Mideast
description: WASHINGTON. April 10 (AP)  President Carter will send a trade mission to Egypt and Israel next week, the White House announced today. Robert S. Strauss, the President's special trade representative, will head the April 1620 mission, which will spend two days in Cairo, then go to Israel. Members of Congress. Administration officials and industry and labor representatives will accompany Mr. Strauss.

title: TEHERAN EXECUTES 11 TOP EXOFFICIALS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Wednesday, April 11  A secret revolutionary court executed 11 major figures of the old regime early this morning, including two Cabinet ministers, the Mayor of Teheran and five generals.

title: Bank Earnings Results Listed
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) the American Exchange and (O) Overthecounter.

title: Blumenthal Vows Fight
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) Vowing not to panic, Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said today that the Administration would continue to stick with its antiinflation economic policy despite the risk of recession.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, April 10 (Reuters)  Foreign students at the Peking Language Institute have been told that they will no longer have Chinese roommates during the coming year, student sources said today.

title: Customer's Property: Who's Liable for It?
description: HARRY SAVESKI left his car in a Meyers selfpark garage on West 31st Street. The car was stolen. Who's responsible  Mr. Saveski or Meyers Parking Systems?

title: Egyptian View of Israelis: Old Stereotypes of Jews Cling
description: CAIRO, April 10  Antoine Nagar, a 24yearold Cairo graduate student, was asked what he knew about the nextdoor neighbors with whom Egypt had recently made peace.

title: Deaths
description: SAPORTA  Abraham The officers and Board of The American Friends of the Hebrew University mourn with deep sorrow the passing of Abraham Saporta, father of Sam and Hy Saporta and Mrs. Julia Rousso. wife of Eli L. Rousso. To his family, long time benefactors of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem we extend our sincerest sympathy. American Friends of the Hebrew University

title: Why Woolworth Is Attractive
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company, the retailer that introduced the nation to variety stores a century ago, is a mixed bag of obvious weaknesses and quiet strengths.

title: 170,000 Detroit Homes Are Still Without Power
description: DETROIT, April 10  About 170,000 homes in the Detroit metropolitan area were still without power today after a blackout that began Sunday with when an ice storm snapped Iceladen tree branches onto power lines throughout southcentral Michigan.

title: RainShortened Game To Be Replayed in Full
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (AP)  Commissioner Bowie Kuhn told the Philadelphia PhiHies today that Sunday's rainshortened game, in which they were leading the St. Louis Cardinals, 32, would have to be replayed in its entirety on June n.

title: Easter Feasts, From Marrakesh to Manhattan
description: THE British have always carried their culinary customs with them, no matter how far from home. We have breakfasted solemnly on porridge and kippers in Cyprus, set our knives to work on steak and kidney pie in Barbados and consumed tea and crumpets after cricket in Port of Spain, Trinidad.

title: James Clement Dunn, U.S. Diplomat in Europe
description: James Clement Dunn, former United States Ambassador to Italy, France, Spain and Brazil, died of a heart attack yesterday in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he was vacationing. He was 87 years old.

title: Trudeau Offers the U.S. Oil Pipeline Routes
description: CALGARY, Alberta, April 10  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau offered the United States two alternative routes today to deliver crude oil from Alaska to the other states through Canadian territory.

title: Q&A
description: Q In the dim recesses of my memoty, I recall having read once that peacocks are a great delicacy, but have never seen them on any menu. Are they really great and does no one cook them, since they're an endangered species?

title: Music: Lyrics of Andy Razaf
description: THE Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., which usually focuses on wellknown lyric writers (Oscar Hammerstein 2d, Cole Porter and Lorenz Hart were its most recent subjects) turned its spotlight Sunday night on a writer who is relatively unknown even though he created most of the lyrics for one of Broadway's current hit musicals.

title: Mets Bow to Expos In 14th Inning by 32
description: Only 10,406 of New York's faithful went to Shea Stadium yesterday for the local opening of the National League season. But they were treated to three and a half hours of often tingling baseball that ended when the Montreal Expos finally edged the Mets, 32, in 14 innings.

title: Bid to Launch a Trident Missile From Submarine Proves Failure
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 10 (UPI)  The first underwater launching of a Trident missile from a submarine failed today, and the rocket had to be destroyed by remote control after 30 seconds of flight.

title: Korea Buys Boeing 747 Jetliners
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)  Korean Air Lines agreed today to buy 10 747 jumbo aircraft from the Boeing Company and took options on another eight 747's.

title: Israeli Aircraft Attack Lebanon After Tel Aviv Market Bombing
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 10  A midday bomb explosion in Tel Aviv killed one Israeli and wounded 36 today, and Israel retaliated several hours later with air attacks on two Palestinian areas in Lebanon.

title: Giving Methadone Patients a Chance
description: The Supreme Court has upheld the constitutionality, but hardly the wisdom, of the policy by which the New York City Transit Authority excludes from all jobs anyone participating in a methadone maintenance program. That decision last month overturned the sensible and sensitive ruling of Federal District Judge Thomas Griesa, who held that the authority must more reasonably tailor its job qualifications to public safety standards. The lower courts condemned a policy that barred workers who were successfully shaking off the heroin habit through methadone from even the most innocuous tasks in the subway and bus systems.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: Farcalled, our navies melt awayOn dune and headland sinks the fire La, all our pomp of yesterdayIs one with Nineveh and Tyre!

title: City Business Agency Post Filled
description: William Woodward, the 34yearold former deputy banking superintendent who ran for the State Senate on Manhattan's East Side last year, was named yesterday the executive director of the Business Marketing Corporation, the city's agency for attracting businesses.

title: Miss Goolagong Wins in Comeback
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., April 10 (AP)  Evonne Goolagong won her first tennis tournament match in more than nine months today.

title: A MineralWater Rush Out West
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: AMIN FOES CONVERGE ON UGANDA CAPITAL
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Wednesday, April 11  Tanzanian troops and Ugandan rebels converged on Kampala from five points yesterday afternoon and Kampala residents reached by telephone today said they could hear scattered smallarms fire in the downtown area.

title: Yankees Turn Back Orioles, 76
description: BALTIMORE, April 10 In a game that had enough excitement for a pennant playoff, the Yankees hung on for 76 victory over the Orioles tonight before a small but vociferous freecoupon crowd of 16,721 at Memorial Stadium.

title: Merger Plans Rose in Quarter
description: CHICAGO, April 10 (UPI)  Merger and acquisition announcements in the first quarter of 1979 increased 14 percent from the yearearlier period, W. T. Grimm & Company, the merger specialists, said today.

title: Plans to Convert Hotel On West Side Rejected
description: The City Planning Commission yesterday rejected a proposal to convert an empty former hotel on the Hudson River into rental apartments.

title: Hoveida Brother Says Premier Gave Millions In Iran Funds to Islam
description: The brother of former Prime Minister Amir Abbas Hoveida, who was executed by the Islamic revolutionary regime in Teheran on Saturday. says that when in office Mr. Hoveida made unannounced payments of about $11 million a year in Government funds to Islamic clergymen and institutions in Iran.

title: Flyers, Sabres, Flames Upset in Home Openers
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (AP)  Two rookies, Thomas Gradin and Stan Smyl, scored their first National Hockey League playoff goals as the Vancouver Canucks upset the Philadelphia Flyers, 32, tonight in the first game of the preliminary round.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Paris dispatch by The Associated Press on killings of Moslems in Chad, published in The Times yesterday, incorrectly identified a secessionist leader, Jules Toura Gabe, as a former ambassador to Washington and Bonn. Chad's present Ambassador to Washington, Pierre Toura Gaba, formerly served in Bonn. He is not connected to the secessionist movement.

title: Hooker Company Knew About Toxic Peril in 1958
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 The Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Corporation knew as early as 1958 that toxic industrial chemicals that it had dumped into the Love Canal site at Niagara Falls years before were seeping into surrounding areas containing private homes, a school and playground, according to documents made public today by the House subcommittee on oversight and investigations.

title: A Newborn Infant Is Found In Bag on Queens Doorstep
description: Edna Webb found on her doorstep Monday what seemed to be a bag of laundry. Half an hour later, it began to cry.

title: Jews in Crown Heights Make Room for Iranian Children
description: The newly purchased mattresses were lifted from hand to hand and onto the loading truck for distribution around Brooklyn's Crown Heights as the Jewish Orthodox cornnumity there braced for the arrival last night of 90 more Iranian Jewish children from a processing center in Rome. The new Wave brought to 630 the children who have joined this community, mainly in the past month, on student visas to the local yeshivas.

title: Nuggets Top Lakers By 110105
description: DENVER, April 10 (UPI)  Dan Issel scored 30 points and David Thompson had 27 tonight to lead the Denver Nuggets to a 110105 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers in the opening round of a National Basketball Association playoff series.

title: PRESIDENT ASKS USE OF NEW OIL PROFITS FOR ENERGY SEARCH
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  President Carter warned the oil companies today that they might face new restraints if they failed to plow back the windfall profits they would receive from the decontrol of domestic oil prices into additional oil and gas exploration.

title: Morgan's Operating Net Up 16.5% in First Quarter
description: Firstquarter operating earnings of J.P. Morgan & Company amounted to $69.4 million, or 16.5 percent above those of the first quarter of last year, the company reported yesterday. It was the first report for the quarter from a major bank holding company.

title: Deaths
description: ANDREWS Mary (nee O'Rourke) Beloved wife of the late Joseph E. Loving mother of Deborah Connolly, Marie Chiftriller, Edward Andrews, & the late Joseph Andrews Jr. Loving grandmother of 17 grandchildren & 3 great grandchildren. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave & 81 St, Wednesday. Blessing St Stephen's R.C. Church. 28th St. bet. Lexington & 3rd Ave. Thursday 11AM.

title: TaxFree Bond Prices Decline
description: Taxexempt bond prices declined yesterday as Oregon marketed $150 million in highgrade bonds that failed to stir much investor enthusiasm.

title: The Day They Made Four Dozen Turkeys That No One Ate
description: N ext bird, please, the director kept calling, next bird ... Like a chorus line, dozens of plump and pretty turkeys rolled onto the stage and into the hot glare of the television camera lights. One bird had bad legs. Another bird jiggled too much when carved. But mostly they were knockouts, these Rockettes of the barnyard, all weighing precisely 18 pounds, all basted to the same shade of golden brown, all dressed in matching garnishes of parsley, grapes and orange slices.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: OF all the fine ways of cooking fish, not one is so nearly perfect as poaching. Take a whole fish, simmer it in a liquid that can be as primordial as sea water or as refined as a stock of wine and vegetables, and the result is a dish that is moist, delicate and pure in flavor.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  In his press conference today, President Carter was very careful to avoid making any dogmatic promises about the future. He sternly defended himself and his family against charges of improper or illegal financial manipulations for political purposes, but otherwise he played it cool, with prudent answers to both domestic and foreign questions.

title: $1.80 OIL SURCHARGE BY IRAN IS EXPECTED
description: Iran will announce today an oil price rise that, according to industry sources, will heighten the possibility of a new round of increases by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Wine Talk
description: FOR more than 100 years, someone or other has been trying to change the 1855 classification of the wines of Bordeaux, that famous some say infamous  ranking of what was then considered the major vineyards in the Bordeaux region. In 1867, little more than a decade after the Bordeaux Brokers Association put together the Classement des Grands Crus de la Gironde, Charles Cocks, the author of the first and still most authoritative guide to the chateaus, wrote:

title: As Israel's Military Turns to Negev, Treatment of Bedouins Sets Off an Outcry
description: LAGIYA, Israel, April 10  With the signing of the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty, the vast redeployment of military installations from Sinai to the Negev is about to begin and has spurred fears about Israel's treatment of its Bedouin pepulation.

title: President Contends It Is Impossible To Abandon U.S. Nuclear Energy
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  President Carter said today that it was not possible to abandon nuclear power in the foreseeable future and indicated that he would continue to press his efforts for speeding up the procedure for licensing nuclear generating plants.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: TicketSale Study Brings ANTA Box Office Shifts
description: An investigation into alleged Maccuracies in ticket counts by the producers of Whoopee! has resulted in changes at the box office of the ANTA Theater, where the musical is playing.

title: Hospital Leader Fights Carey Bid To Cut Teaching
description: The head of one of the city's most prestigious teaching hospitals said yesterday that a proposal by the state to penalize hospitals that train too many surgeons and other specialists, at the expense of general practitioners, could have a potentially catastrophic effect on the city and seriously jeopardize New York's standing as a medical leader.

title: Soviet Affirms Atom Power Need
description: MOSCOW, April 10 A ranking Soviet scientist said today that opposition to nuclear power in the United States was caused and encouraged by fuel monopolies afraid of losing their oil profits.

title: News of the Theater There Were to Have Been 3, but . . .
description: MONTHS ago, Stephen R. Friedman and Irwin Meyer set April as the stage for a theatrical tripleheader. They announced that they planned to produce, through their newly formed joint venture with Warner Communications, a musical, a comedy and a drama  all opening on Broadway within a week's time. But as often happens before a Broadway opening, this scenario is not unfolding according to plan. Warner Communications has just pulled out of what was announced as a longrange affiliation with Mr. Friedman and Mr. Meyer, and now the producers have only two, instead of three shows headed for openings this month.

title: Fashion Report From Paris
description: PARIS, April 10  After the space cadets and the beaux arts costumes seen earlier in the week, Yves Saint Laurent's collection moved softly into the frenetic fail readytowear scene today.

title: Mets Grant: Forgotten but Not Gone
description: M. Donald Grant was present at the creation of the Mets, and he had been at the 17 previous home openers. But, talking to Ed Kranepool during spring training, he said he was not sure he should be at Shea Stadium this season for No. 18.

title: Tracks in Florida Inspected by U.S. Shortly Before L.&N. Derailment
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  A 204mile stretch of track used by the Louisville & Nashville Railroad was inspected and approved last Friday, just two days before a 122car train derailed on it, exploded and released poisonous fumes in the morning air of north Florida.

title: TigersRoyals Rained Out
description: KANSAS CITY, April 10 (AP)  Tonight's Detroit TigersKansas City Royals game was postponed because of rain. A spokesman said it would be made up as part of a doubleheader during Detroit's series here Aug. 1012.

title: Cut in Public CableTV Barred Despite Ruling
description: Although the Federal requirement for public access to cabletelevision systems was struck down by the Supreme Court of the United States last week, cable companies in the metropolitan area say they plan no reduction in the number of channels they have dedicated for use by local governments, educational institutions and private citizens.

title: CARTER SEEKING RISE IN HELP FOR TURKEY
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  President Carter announced today that he was asking Congress for $150 million in emergency economic and military aid for Turkey to help it cope with internal problems.

title: Adelphi Is 1613 Victor Over Cheadle in Lacrosse
description: GARDEN CITY, L.1., April 10 — Pat Burke scored three goals and Bob Engelke added two and got three assists to lead Adelphi University to a 1613 victory over Cheadle Lacrosse Club of England today in an exhibition match at Stiles Field.

title: Bridge:
description: The trend to youth in recent tournaments was reversed at the Long Island championships in Hempstead Sunday. In the Swiss teams, which attracted 222 squads, one of the winners was Herman Horowitz of New York. He is 81 years old and is believed to be the oldest man to win a regional title in the metropolitan area.

title: Chamber Music: New Calliope Singers
description: THE New Calliope Singers, a vocal chamber ensemble, grows a little in size each year. On Monday night, in Alice Tully Hall, the group numbered 26, more than it has in its three previous annual programs. Under the direction of Peter Schubert, it offered music typical of its repertory, madrigals as old as those by Monteverdi and as new as a set by the 29yearold Maurice Wright, works by Debussy and Brahms and a novelty such as 27yearold Michael Beckerman's setting of an ancient Hebrew wedding text, which he wrote for his own marriage ceremony.

title: The Region
description: ALBANY (AP)  A state investigating body recommended yesterday the removal of an Ilion Village Court justice, Frank Manion, for an alleged shortage of more than $8,000 in court funds he was supposed to have deposited in the bank. The Commission on Judicial Conduct sent papers to the Court of Appeals to initiate removal proceedings against Justice Manion.

title: Geneva Trade Talks Reaching Final Stage
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  After five years of tough negotiations, the curtain is dropping on the postwar period's most ambitious undertaking to liberalize trade.

title: Advertising
description: BECAUSE it wants to make an impact with the start of its new corporate campaign, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation will use a blockbuster sixpage ad in business magazines. The campaign, by Edwin Bird Wilson Inc., breaks this week.

title: At a Varmint Banquet, the Menu Goes Wild
description: DURHAM, N.C.

title: Consultant Is Queried About Wife's Murder And GemDealer Case
description: Murder and missingpersons investigations by city detectives and Federal agents were focusing yesterday on Philip Drelich, a 28yearold financial consultant, in connection with both the stabbing death of his wife last week and the disappearance of a diamond merchant with $500.000 in gems a month ago.

title: Senate Panel Votes Plan to Balance Budget in 1981
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  The Senate Budget Committee today approved a fiveyear fiscal plan for the Federal Government to achieve a balanced budget in 1981 and reduce taxes substantially beginning the following year.

title: Associated Press
description: WAITING FOR A DECISION: Larry lbsie of Milwaukee and Boston catcher Mike O'Berry glancing toward umpire daring a play at the plate in Milwaukee yesterday. Call went against the Brewer. but his team won anyway, 30.

title: Deaths
description: KATZBenlamin beloved husband of Celia. Devoted father of S.Irving the late Gerald. Adored grandfather of Adrieme & Mark Feur. Eugene, Alice, George & greatgrandfather of Eden & Aaron Feur. Services Wednesday 10em at Nassau North Chapels 55 North Station Plaza (celo.R.R. sta.) Great Neck, L.I.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Carter's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: U.S. Cites Bias in Chicago Schools
description: CHICAGO, April 10  The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has detailed what it says is a comprehensive pattern of deliberate student segregation in the Chicago school system.

title: What a German Urban Guerrilla Learned
description: Following are excerpts from the forthcoming book Terror or Love? The Personal Account of a West German Urban Guerrilla by Michael Baumann. Once a leading member of the socalled June 2d movement, one of the most active urbanguerrilla groups in West Germany, Mr. Baumann, still a fugitive, is sought on bankrobbery charges among others. The book was published in West Germanyin1975.

title: British Electric Train Record
description: LONDON. April 10 (UPI)  A British electric passenger train set a new speed record today, 111.7 miles an hoar on the 94mile rim from London to Chippentram. a railroad spokesman said.

title: Files Show Many Prior Problems at Three Mile Island
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  Although the omens went publicly unnoticed and were officially accepted as normal at the time, an examination of the Government safety inspection file on the Three Mile Island nuclear reactor suggests that the accident there two weeks ago might have been predicted.

title: Careers
description: A Demand For Fire Engineers

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: After 40 years of keeping the books on saltwater fish world records and setting the standards under which such fish should be captured, the International Game Fish Association has now embraced freshwater angling and marine fly fishing.

title: France Will Continue ATests
description: CANBERRA, Australia, April 10 (Reuters)  France will carry out regular underground nuclear tests on Mururoa Atoll in the Pacific indefinitely, the High Commissioner of French Polynesia, Paul Cousseran, said here today. Mr Cousseran is an a twoweek visit to Australia.

title: Economic Scene
description: A Moderate Downturn Seen

title: Award Night on TV: Stars, Sighs, Cheers, jokes and Causes
description: IN his opening remarks for the 51st Annual Academy Awards Monday night, Johnny Carson, the master or ceremonies, promised two hours of sparkling entertainment spread out over four hours, That was somewhat unfair. The proceedings televised by ABCTV consumed only 3 hours and 20 minutes, ending at 1:20 in the morning, New York time.

title: How to Make Railroads Solvent
description: America's railroads are in trouble. For decades they have been losing freight  and profits  to trucks, barges and pipelines. Only recently, however, has the seriousness of the problem struck the nation. Unsubsidized freight service died in the Northeast with the collapse of the Penn Central. And unless something is done soon, many other railroads also could become unwelcome wards of the Federal Government.

title: St. Patrick's Cathedral Is Spruced Up for Easter
description: Workmen were busy giving the facade of St. Patrick's Cathedral a spring cleaning yesterday, hoping to have it ready in time for Easter Sunday. The landmark cathedral is celebrating its centennial year.

title: 2 Met Sopranos Plan Concert
description: Two highly acclaimed Metropolitan Opera sopranos, Joan Sutherland and Marilyn Home, will appear in concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Oct. 15 in a program that may be televised as part of the Live From Lincoln Center series on PBS.

title: Woolworth Stock: Trading Inquiry
description: The New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that it had begun an investigation of trading in Woolworth stock, centering on the week before Brascan Ltd., the Canadian conglomerate, made a $1.1 billion offer for the retail giant.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Cloud cover can be seen over New England. Broken cloudiness extends westward front the Tennessee Valley to the Mississippi Valley and over portions of the Missotrl Valley. Another large area of cloudiness blankets much of the Rockies, the pletesu region and the Plains States. More clouds can be seen over the Pacific Northwest.

title: A Cocaine Trial Is Ruled Unfair by Appeals Court
description: An appeals court ruled yesterday that a defendant had been unfairly convicted of conspiracy to possess cocaine after he had been acquitted of the related charge of actual possession of the cocaine.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln Center String Group Getting Two New Members
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will have two new members next season: Ani Kavafian, who will replace Jaime Laredo as coviolnist with James Buswell, and AndreMichel Schub, who will replace Richard Goode as copianist with Charles Wadsworth, the society's artistic director.

title: Slain Student Wrote on China For the Mayor
description: To most of Sheryl McCormick's acquaintances and colleagues, the path from her rented room on West 113th Street in Manhattan to her school nearby, to the library, also nearby, seemed to form the boundaries of her life. Few friends knew how deeply ambitious she was and how much the 23yearold Columbia University graduate gtudent, who was found stabbed to death last Monday, yearned to break out of those boundaries.

title: Senator Says Egyptians Want U.S. Force in Gulf
description: CAIRO, April 10  A visiting American Senator said today that President Anwar elSadat wants military aid as soon as possible from the United States and would welcome some kind of American naval presence in the Persian Gulf.

title: Companies List Their Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: RENT BOARD ALLOWS SURCHARGES ON FUEL IN STABILIZED UNITS
description: The New York City Rent Guidelines Board added fuel surcharges yesterday to the maximum rent limits of some rentstabilized apartments, increasing substantially the rent limits it set last week.

title: Deaths
description: F I SCHERAlvin. Greenburgh Hebrew Center of Dobbs Ferry sorrowfully announces the passing of its devoted member Alvin Fischer, husband of Ruth. Heartfelt condolences are extended lo the family Paul Neustadt, President Lyle Fishman. Rabbi

title: Rent Rise in Controlled Buildings Sold by City Is Voted by Council
description: A measure that would increase base rents in rentcontrolled and rentstabilized buildings taken over by the city and then resold to private owners was passed yesterday by the New York City Council by a vote of 24 to 16.

title: OPEC Denies Plan To Give Discounts
description: VIENNA, April 10 (AP)  The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries did not decide at its March meeting in Geneva to grant wholesale discounts on oil to developing nations, the secretary general, Rene Ortiz, said today.

title: Staats Cotsworth, 71, Is Dead; Acted on Stage, Radio and TV
description: Staats Cotsworth, the Broadway, radio and television actor, died Monday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 71 years old.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY. APRIL 10. 1979

title: Big Ideas for the Vegetable Patch
description: ONCE upon a piece of ground there was a cucumber that measured 10 feet long. The remarkable growth took place in New Hampshire in 1896, but today there are still plenty of gardeners who are proud of their ability to cultivate a whopper. For many years Britons were the main fanatics, with their autumnal competition for the longest carrots, heaviest marrows (squashes) or largest leeks. These competitions are still important events on the rural calendar, particularly in the northern counties; last year a major television network sponsored a search to find the biggest cabbage in the land.

title: Abrams Charges Esposito on Link To an L.I. Track
description: Robert Abrams, the State Attorney General, charged yesterday that Meade H. Esposito sold $12 million in insurance to a Long Island quarterhorse race track while he was serving as the Brooklyn Democratic county leader.

title: Personal Health
description: LAST week an expert panel of the National Academy of Sciences confirmed what sleep specialists have been saying for years  that the sleeping pills swallowed nightly by millions of Americans are potentially dangerous and largely ineffective. There are far better and safer ways, the experts say, for insomniacs to overcome their difficulty.

title: MIMI GOLDEN
description: Mimi Golden, a retired secretary to editors at The New York Times, died at her home in Manhattan on Monday. She was 71 years old.

title: Gov. Brown Criticized in Labor Dispute
description: LOS ANGELES, April 10  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., on the eve of his trip to Africa, interceded in a labor dispute in behalf of the only major union that has offered him support in a bid for the Presidency, the attorney for a California race track charged today.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are me top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday. April 2. to Sunday. April 8). listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A C. Nielsen Company A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: House Votes to Move Peace Corps to New Aid Agency
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  Hours after Richard F. Celeste, directordesignate of the Peace Corps, testified before a Senate committee today that the Peace Corps should remain a part of Action, an umbrella agency of volunteer programs, the House voted, 276 to 116, to remove it.

title: 45 Pupils and 5 Adults Are Killed In a School Bus Plunge in Spain
description: ZAMORA, Spain, April 10 (AP) A school bus taking pupils home after an Easterweek trip went out of control and plunged into a river in northwestern Spain today, killing 50 of the 60 people aboard, the police said.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Easter Extravaganzas

title: Rose Bats in No. 3 Spot, Sparks Phiis With 3 Hits
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (UPI) Pete Rose, switched to the No. 3 spot in the batting order by Manager Danny Ozark, celebrated his Veterans Stadium debut as a member of the Philadelphia Phillies tonight by stroking three hits in four times at bat to trigger a 73 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Real Estate
description: Alan S. Oser

title: Notes on People
description: The Hope of a Chicano Mother Is Fulfilled

title: Ohrenstein Is Opposed To Manhattan as Site For Gambling Casinos
description: Five days after the administration of Mayor Koch promoted New York City as a potential site for gambling casinos, the Democratic leader in the State Senate, Manfred Ohrenstein, declared that casinos would turn Manhattan into a honkytank Rambling town.

title: Karpov Heads a Field of 10 in Montreal Chess
description: MONTREAL, April 10 (Reuters)  Ten of the world's top chess players, headed by Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the world champion, will be playing for $110,000 in Canadian dollars (about $95,000) in a monthlong tournament starting here tomorrow.

title: Bella Abzug Taking Women's Message to the Nation in Whirlwind Tour
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa., April 6  The audience rustles and murmurs, waiting for the program to begin. Most have never before seen the speaker in person, although they have seen her on television and read about her in the newspapers, and they are curious, wondering how she will compare with her reputation.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Cente ??ovsky's Eugene Onegine. 8.

title: Violinist: L. Shankar
description: SOUTH Indian classical musicians are not often heard in New York  it is the North Indian idiom of Ravi Shankar or Ali Akbar Khan that most Americans think of as Indian music  but in the last few weeks, two exceptional South Indian violinists have given recitals in New York. Strangely enough, they are brothers. L. Subrarnanian was at the Center for International  Arts a few weeks ago and, last Thursday night, L. Shankar gave a performance at Carol Hall.

title: Associated Press
description: YANKEES BEAT ORIOLES, 74: New York's Roy White sliding into first as Baltimore's Eddie Murray leaps to catch high throw on pickoff attempt in third inning. Page An.

title: Klein Suffers a Setback In Suffolk's Legislature
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., April 10  In a political setback for County Executive John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Legislature today rejected his proposal for a June public referendum on measures to cut county taxes.

title: 2 Vietnam Films Cast Aside Ghosts on Way to Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES, April 10  To win five of the six major Academy Awards last night, The Deer Hunter and Coming Home had to defeat more than the pictures nominated against them. They had to conquer a number of Hollywood ghosts and truisms, Chief among the phantasms was the movie industry's fear that nobody would go to see a movie about the Vietnam War.

title: Topics Travelers
description: After the first of June, the best underground bargain win probably become a bit more expensive. But for the next few weeks at least, people can continue to ride in graffitifree subway trains from West 34th Street to Christopher Street in Greenwich Village for only 30 cents.

title: Boston City Officials Go to Court To Keep 2 Washington Portraits
description: BOSTON, April 10  The war between Boston and Washington over where George and Martha should spend the next few centuries  amid this city's storied cultural heritage or in the brash new bureaucracy of the nation's capital  will produce its first real battle in court here next week.

title: 34 Food Establishments Cited in Code Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 34 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code. The department also named six restaurants that had corrected earlier violations and four that had been closed for failing to do so. It also cited one restaurant that had reopened after correcting earlier violations.

title: White House Installs A Solar Water Heater For President's Office
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  President Carter and his senior advisers are trying to save energy by installing a solar hotwater heater for their office. But whether it will save the taxpayers money is not clear.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: HOUSTON, April 10 (UPI)  A second Exxon Company USA exploratory well in the Baltimore Canyon has produced no sign of oil or gas, and the company announced today that the hole, 100 miles east of Atlantic City, would be plugged and abandoned.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter warned oil companies that they might face new restraints if they fail to plow windfall profits from the decontrol of domestic oil prices back into exploration for new oil and gas supplies. The President said the nation had a right to expect the estimated $6 billion that the industry might reap from decontrol, even after a windfall profits tax, to be used for exploration. [Page A1.]

title: BellIssue Yield Off; Sales Slow
description: Bell System bonds  the best measure of the highgrade corporate bond market  were priced yesterday to yield 9.58 percent, slightly lower than similar issues marketed in February and March, and the new 8200 million offering got only a lukewarm reception from investors. Late yesterday, an estimated $80 million remained unsold.

title: Retail Sales Surged 1% In March
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)  The Government reported today that consumer spending rose 1 percent last month. It was the largest gain this year and a signal that economic growth remains strong.

title: Deaths
description: MACKSOUDRichard, of Madison. New Jersey on April 10. 1979 Be loved husband of Muriel Hempstead Mocksoud and father of Richard Jr. of West Millington and Miss Gloria Macksoud e home. Also survived by a sister Miss Afitie Mackscud. A church blessing will be held at Saint Vincent's Church, Madison. Thursday April 12 at 9:30 AM. A committal blessing at Chapel of Saint John's Cemetery Middle Village N.Y. at 11:45 AM. Friends may call at the Burroughs and Kohr Funeral Home 106 Main St. Madison, New Jersey Wednesday 24 and 79 PM.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: I WAS talking to a woman named Deborah, who lives in an area reputed to be a center for organized crime, writes Barbara Huff. We were not, however, talking about crime but about my field  children's books. And when two women discuss children's books, as inevitably as the mornine sun. Nancy Drew comes up.

title: Technology
description: The Promise Of Fiber Optics

title: Norma Brustein, 50, Actress and Teacher Of Drama at Yale U.
description: Norma Brustein, an actress and a teacher at the Yale School of Drama, died late Monday evening in YaleNew Haven Hospital following a massive cardiac arrest. She was 50 years old. She was the wife of Robert Brustein, director of the Yale Repertory Theater and dean of the Yale Drama School.

title: Deaths
description: GOODMAN  Alice Matz. Beloved wile of the late Dr. Bernard A. Goodman. devoted mother of Roy M. Goodman and mother In law of Barbara F. Goodman. loving or andmother of Claire. Leslie, and Randolph Goodman, dear sister of Ethel M. Edelman. Services 12 noon. Wednesday, April 11th, at Frank E. Campbell. corner 81st St. and Madison Ave. Interment private.

title: Subway Crime, and Injustice
description: A wave of subway murders. last winter focused public attention on the New York City Transit Authority Police Department and its chief, Sanford Garelik. Among other things, his management of the department has brought sweeping reductions in the bloated senior ranks and a notable increase in effective police decoys..But he has been criticized for the department's methods of reporting crimes.

title: Iran Troubled by Traditional Resistance of Its Minorities
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 10 Iran's ethnic and tribal minorities are posing a serious problem for the new revolutionary provisional Govement.

title: Bronx Strangling Linked by Police To Earlier Rapes
description: Shortly after 8 P.M. on Monday, Herman Crose, a resident of a declining sevenstory apartment building across the street from Fordham University in the Bronx, received a call from a New Jersey woman worried about her 78yearold mother, a neighbor of Mr. Crose.

title: Scenes Around Uganda Airport: Smoldering Planes and Looting
description: ENTEBBE, Uganda, April 8 (UPI) The bumedout hulks of Idi Amin's air force, including MIG fighters, Boeing707 and a Libyan C130 transport, lay smoldering on the runways of the international airport here today, within view of a huge portrait of the Ugandan dictator.

title: Nuclear Power Goes Forward in Virginia
description: RICHMONDThe Virginia Electric and Power Company has had it share of the problems associated with nuclear power generation  problems highlighted by the accident at the Three Mile Island plant in Pennsvivania.

title: Rockwell's Sale Of Admiral Gains
description: PITTSBURGH, April 10 (AP)  The Rockwell International Corporation said today that it had signed a definitive agreement to sell its Admiral domestic appliance business to Magic Chef Inc. of Cleveland, Tenn.

title: Auditing The I.R.S.
description: SEATTLE  The Internal Revenue Service is pursuing an auditing policy that is likely to undermine public confidence in the fairness and effectiveness of the taxadministration system. It is doing so to please Congress.

title: Jolmcamp Realty Extends Offer
description: Johncatnp Realty Inc. said it had extended its offer to buy any and all outstanding shares of beneficial interest of Prudent Real Estate Trim at $7 net a share to the seller until 9:30 A.M. today, unless further extended.

title: Two Ski Centers Open in Vermont
description: Continued light snowfalls last week and a major storm on the weekend that produced up to 26 inches of powder on the slopes have caused the operators of Vermont's Stowe and Jay Peak ski areas to reopen.

title: Afghan Rebels Report Inflicting Heavy Casualties on Government
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 11  A spokesman for an Afghan rebel organization declared here today that dissident forces had inflicted heavy casualties on troops of the proSoviet Government in Afghanistan.

title: Deaths
description: SEROTARobert Utopia Lodge ? 480 K. of P. & its Welfare Association mounts the passing of a distinguished Past Chancellor & dedicated Vice President. His loss is deeply felt. Funeral services Friday. April 13, 1pm at the I.J. Morris. Inc. Funeral Home, 1895 Flatbush Ave Bktyn.

title: Marine Midland Lifts Earnings
description: Marine Midland Banks Inc. reported yesterday that its earnings in the first quarter nearly doubled from the yearearlier level.

title: Boston Bans 5 South Africans
description: BOSTON, April 11 (Reuters)  Five South African runners have been barred from competing in the Boston Marathon after the race organizers received a warning from the Amateur Athletic Union, Will Cloney, the marathon's director, announced today. The marathon is to be run next Monday.

title: New Mortgage Guidelines Set
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)  The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation announced new credit and appraisal guidelines today intended to make it easier for thousands of Americans to buy houses.

title: Market Place
description: NVESTORS who were disappointed by the firstquarter earnings of International Business Machines sold shares yesterday and caused the price to retreat to below Tuesday's levels. On Tuesday I.B.M. set a 12month high of 322, largely because the quarter earnings were expected to bring smiles instead of frowns.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Bally Manufacturing Company, the pinball and slot machine maker, announced yesterday that it might sell a minority interest in its hotelcasino complex in Atlantic City to shareholders.

title: Store's Show Is a Tour of Italy
description: IT'S a game, said Carl Levine, who plays it very well. Mr. Levine, the senior vice president of home furnishings, paused for half a second to observe another customer slink guiltily beneath the dropcloth that cordoned off Bloomingdale's newest model rooms.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) Flames raged through a halfway house for the mentally ill today, trapping elderly women on upper floors with no fire escape. Nine women died and six were injured in the inferno of fire and smoke.

title: John Roland New Anchor Of WNEWTV News
description: John Roland, a coanchor of the 10 P.M. news program on WNEWTV, Channel 5, has become the newscast's new anchor.

title: Rep. Crane Builds Debt In His Bid for President
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Representative Philip M. Crane, the conservative Republican from Illinois and the first candidate to enter the Republican Presidential race, has built up a debt of $820,222 in just over seven months of campaigning.

title: 14 Strikers and 11 Police Officers Are Hurt in Clash As Brooklyn Daily Brings In Tank Truck of Raw Milk
description: A clash between striking teamsters and the police injured 14 strikers and 11 officers yesterday as a Brooklyn dairy made an effort to bring in raw milk through massed pickets.

title: Kuwait Raises Oil Surcharge
description: KUWAIT, April 11 (UPI)  Kuwait said today that the price of its all for the second quarter of 1979 woukl be ?? a barrel, which represents both the 9 percent rise decided by oil producers in Geneva last month and an increased surcharge.

title: Defeat Seems a Certainty For Scottish Nationalists
description: LOSSIEMOUTH, Scotland, April 10 Winifred Ewing is a genuine Scottish eccentric who once suggested in all seriousness that if Scotland was given its independence, the same thing would make sense for the Shetland Islands and the county of Fife.

title: Rate Change Asked
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  The Federal Trade Commission, in a step that could advance the movement to deregulate the trucking industry, has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to let companies set their own rates within a zone of reasonableness.

title: Therapy for Psoriasis Can Produce Nonfatal Skin Cancer, Study Finds
description: A widely available therapy combining a drug and ultraviolet light that can dramatically relieve disabling psoriasis has been found to produce a nonfatal and usually mild form of skin cancer in small percentage of patients.

title: Oral Roberts Hires Coach
description: TULSA, Okla., April 11 (AP)  Ken Hayes, the New Mexico State University basketball coach, was named coach at Oral Roberts University today. Hayes will succeed Lake Kelly, who resigned after two years.

description: The final portico of the transcript of President Carter's news conference in Washington Tuesday was inadvertently omitted from yesterday's late editions of The New York Times.

description: TORONTO, April 11  Edper Equities Ltd. has shelved, at least temporarily, its efforts to take control of Torontobased Brascan Ltd.

description: with Alonzo L. McDonald Jr.

title: The New York Times/Robert Levin
description: O Nplans of some of the great English country houses, there was often a room marked flowers, where cut flowers from the garden were arranged and set in vases. These days, shrinking city apartments and efficiently planned houses don't have rooms set aside for such activities. Florists usually do the flower arranging, and often the vase is tossed out with the faded flowers. Despite all this, a variety of oversized vases are proliferating in shops across the city. One explanation is that even flowers have their fashions. We are in the era of the big bloom. The neighborhood florist is selling branches of forsythia, quince and dogwood, and the single, albeit expensive, longstemmed flower is making a comeback. The bigger, the better, said a Manhattan retailer who can't keep the oversized containers in stock. It used to be difficult to get a vase that would have the right proportion to hold a fivefoot branch, added Christian Barclay, who opened his own flower shop last October. Now, people don't have to cut the branches down. But what does one do with these giant vases when they are flowerless? Small closets or narrow cabinets can hardly accommodate them. That's part of the point, explained Robert Fleischer of The Glass Store. These vases are large enough to make a statement; even empty, they can sit on the floor or the piano. And, as one architect remarked: If it's big enough, you can't accuse it of being a tsatske.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: John T. Grigsby has been observing, advising and critiquing the management of Food Fair Inc. since last November as a member of a consulting group from Touche Ross & Company, the accounting firm.

title: Home Beat
description: WILLIAM TURNER, far left, an interior designer, and Kenneth Wyse, an assistant vice president at KayserRoth International, are neighbors in Greenwich Village. One day, Mr. Wyse planned to have some friends over for dinner but didn't have enough chairs. He remembered that in 1959, when his sister had gotten married in Cleveland (his hometown), she had chairs with slipcovers at her reception. Why can't I find those in New York, he wondered. He called every party rental company he knew of, but the search was futile. Thus began what Mr. Wyse calls my fiveminute idea; my lunchhour business, now known as Turnerwyse Incoporated. Mr. Wyse and Mr. Turner decided to produce the kind of slipcovers Mr. Wyse remembered. The partners divided the tasks: Mr. Wyse shopped around town to find the folding wooden chairs they would need. He settled on a classic type, called the Circus chair  similar to those used in traveling circuses. Mr. Turner worked on designing the slipcover. They both agreed that white canvas would have a universal applicability; it is just like the material used for circus big tops. They also agreed that quilting the fabric would make it more comfortable to sit on. Finally, they hired a lawyer, found a fabricator, and worked out the final design. The channelquilted slipcovers are made in 9ounce, offwhite, 100 percent cotton duck with a polyester lining. Mr. Wyse is especially proud that both chair and cover are entirely made in the United States. At BaileyHuebner at Henri Bendel, chair and chair cover come packaged together and cost $70; at Blooming. dale's, it's $67.50. The slipcovers, which will fit a number of similar chairs, are available there separately for $50 each.

title: Auditor for a Nuclear Accident
description: The first time John G. Kemeny got involved with nuclear energy, he got lost on his way to join the Manhattan Project at Los Alamos, N.M. Now, 34 years later, he has accepted another assignment involving nuclear energy, but this time the President of the United States has a stake in making sure that Dr. Kemeny finds his way to the site.

They acted despite a bitter 11thhour attack by developing countries charging the pact did too littie for the world's poor.

description: LOS ANGELES  The old clich that blacks all look alike to whites still has more substance than it should. title: Planning Your Aerial Garden

But a terrace or balcony owner can compensate for this and insure a thriving summer garden.

But the measure is no less ugly now that it has been attached to another bill. We deplore the proposal because it is confusing, assaults the Supreme Court and, since it pertains to prayer, is none of the Government's business.

He urged the Carter Administration to negotiate away his reservations by further talks with the Soviet Union.

title: Art: Rembrandt and the Bible at Met
description: REMBRANDT is the perfect religious artist for an age of secular sensibility. His sense of spirituality is always firmly tethered to the emotions of earthly existence. He does not burden his art with difficult challenges to commonsensical belief. His biblical figures have a powerful human appeal. This is true even in his many depictions of Christ and the Holy Family. He cared little for the Annunciation, writes A. Hyatt Mayor, because the Virgin Birth contradicts the human condition.

title: Vintage House Becomes a TV Star
description: F OR the pioneer modernist Le Corbusier, a house was a madilne to live in; for others it is a place to hang one's hat; for most, a house is a home, the stage where the drama of life is played. But some houses are central to the drama, or at least have a strong supporting Design Notebook role. The drawing room of the house at Eaton Place in Upstairs. Downstairs was more than a background against which the characters came and wentit was the familiar constant in war and peace and Joy and grief; its changes signaled deeper changes in time and the family. When the house was sold, the series ended.

title: U. S. Considers Prosecuting Hooker Chemical for Dump
description: WASHINGTON, April 11The Justice Department has been investigating the Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Corporation for more than a year and expects to decide soon whether to prosecute the company for dumping toxic chemicals in the Love Canal site at Niagara Falls, N.Y.

title: Overturned Truck Snags Traffic
