title: SOCIALISTS IN FRANCE KEEPING TIE TO REDS
description: PARIS, April 11  The French Socialist Party, weakened but still in one piece, has emerged from a furious internal struggle still committed to its policy of electoral alliance with the Communists, at least until after the 1981 presidential vote.

title: Billy Carter Asserts No Loan Funds Were Used for Brother's Campaign
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 11  Billy Carter said today that though there might have been slight delays in notifying the National Bank of Georgia about collateral movements, the Carter family peanut business was not behind in its loan payments in 1975 and 1976. And not a dime of the loan money was diverted to his brother's Presidential campaign, he said.

title: Screen: 'Hurricane, From Bora Bora:Love Affair of the Eyes
description: WHEN Dino De Laurentiis, the producer, set out to build a movie called "Hurricane," which opens today at Loews State 1 and other theaters, he also built a hotel, the 60-bungalow Marara, on the island of Bora Bora, to house his cast and crew and which is now open to the public. I hope the hotel runs better than the movie."Hurricane" is wet and windy, the sort of expensively foolish enterprise that suggests that everyone connected with it needs either a new agent or a legal guardian. It enhances the reputation of no one and discovers unexpected deposits of second-rateness in such people as Lorenzo Semple Jr., who wrote the screenplay; Jan Troell, the Swedish director of "The Emigrants"; Sam O'Steen, the editor, who has saved far worse movies than this; Sven Nykvist, the cameraman, and such cast members as Jason Robards, Mia Farrow, Max Von Sydow, Trevor Howard and Timothy Bottoms. A Hawaiian surfer named Dayton Ka'ne makes his debut in the film, as a young Polynesian chieftain who falls in love with a white woman, played by Miss Farrow. Mr. Ka'ne doesn't act, but he does look like John Travolta, beefed up with a bodybuilding course.The film is based on the same Charles Nordhoff-James Norman Hall novel that served as the basis for the 1937 Sam Goldwyn-John Ford film starring Dorothy Lamour and Jon Hall.Mr. Semple has set his adaptation in the 1920's and updated the tale by making it an interracial love story with hilariously clumsy subsidiary suggestions of an incestuous relationship between Miss Farrow and her father, the United States Naval Governor of Pago Pago, played by Mr. Robards. The scenery is pretty, but the geography mystifying. This is the sort of South Pacific where it takes a powerboat one day to get to a nearby island and a rowboat, through a raging storm, a few hours to reach the same destination.The love affair between the governor's daughter and the island chief is communicated visually in terms of the meetings of eyes and in dialogue about eyes. There is so much emphasis on eyes that when Miss Farrow picks up a seashell you expect her to stare into it, but no, she puts it to her ear. Some clichs are sacred.The island dances are sexy in the manner of nightclub choreography, and the climactic storm is very noisy. What one remembers most vividly, though, are not the dances and the special effects, but the way Miss Farrow walks  slightly stiff-kneed, like a Broadway ingenue of the 30's  the fact that one character succumbs in the hurricane to what seems to have been a bad earache, and the dialogue, which sometimes sounds as if it had been written by someone under the unfortunate influence of Ben Jonson. Says the island chief to Miss Farrow, when he suggests that they elope, "Come to the altar with the white flower  I will be there with the red.""Hurricane," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some partial nudity.

title: SouthWest Africa Mine Kills 3

Because of Holy Week services will be held at QuatllebaumHollemanBurse Funeral Home, 1201 South Olime Ave. W. Palm Beach, Fla. 10am Sat 4. Reposing at funeral home.

title: LUCRETIA DAVIS JEPHSON
description: Lucretia Davis Jepbson died Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 93 years old and lived in Cazenovia, N.Y. Mrs. Jephson was the daughter of Robert Benson Davis, founder of the R. B. Davis Baking Powder Company. She leaves no survivors.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Saudi Economy Up 11% in Year
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, April 11 (AP)  Saudi Arabia's gross national product has increased 11 percent in the fiscal year 197778, reaching a total of 222 billion riyals, equal to $62.1 billion at current exchange rates, the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency reported today.

title: The Plant Space Problem
description: No gardener has enough room for everything he wants to grow. At the same time, he usually ends up growing more things than he has time to keep at their showiest. Nowhere is this more true than in balcony and terrace gardening.

title: Marine Asserts a Smuggled Note Finally Got Him Out of Vietnam
description: ADAMS. Ind., April 11 (UPI)  Pfc. Robert Garwood of the Marines says he waited for years until he found a nonVietnamese to smuggle out of Vietnam a message that eventually led to his return home after nearly 14 years.

title: Expos Top Mets, 32, on Perez Clout in 11th
description: Associated Press

title: Legislation to Curb Big Mergers: Round 1
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Spectacles precariously balanced on the end of his nose, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, introduced a bill on the Senate floor early last month with the innocuous, almost comical and somewhat deceptive title: The Small and Independent Business Protection Act of 1979.

title: 26 Hurt in Tornadoes in Arkansas
description: As cleanup efforts were under way yesterday in Wichita Falls, Tex., and three other towns where tornadoes killed 57 persons Tuesday, several other tornadoes struck in Arkansas, injuring at least 26 persons in the Polk County communities of Grannis and Wickes.

title: Cancer From the Radiation
description: It appears that the risk of a major catastrophe at the Three Mile Island nuclear facility has been narrowly avoided. The public should understand the longterm human consequences of the accident so that it may be in a position to consider intelligently the many complex issues it raises. The conclusions it reaches will involve medical, economic and social factors. I address my remarks only to the first.

title: Embassy in U.S. Occupied
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  In a festive mood, two dozen antiAmin Ugandans oc cupied their country's embassy today.

title: Music: Blues Concert at Carnegie Hall With Willie Mae Thornton
description: THERE were many things right with Tuesday evening's Boogie n Blues concert at Carnegie Hall, and a few things wrong, too. Unfortunately, the right things came toward the end of the fourplushour concert, when a lot of people had already gotten pretty disgruntled.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: On Tuesday, the Expos beat the Mets by the same score in 14 innings. Perez shortened the game this time for those of the 5,980 fans still around at Shea Stadium on a sunny day with the gametime temperature in the low 60's.

title: ASTRONAUTS CANCEL LINKUP WITH SALYUT
description: LONDON, Thursday, April 12 (Reuters)  Moscow Radio said today that the Soyuz 33 spacecraft's docking mission with an orbiting space station had been canceled and that the two astronauts on board Soyuz were preparing to return to earth.

title: U.S. Sees Arabs Keeping Aid Vows To Egypt but Refusing Future Help
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the United States expected that Saudi Arabia and other Arab states would keep their previous aid commitments to Egypt but would refuse to give any new assistance because of Egypt's signing of the peace treaty with Israel.

title: Begin and Sadat Talk on Phone, Agree To Delay Withdrawal a Day
description: TEL AVIV, April 11  President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin talked by telephone today and agreed to delay the Israeli withdrawal from El Arish for 24 hours in deference to the Jewish Sabbath.

title: Calendar of Events
description: An Exhibition About Architecture for Youngsters, Hudson River Museum, 511 Warburton Avenue, Yonkers, N.Y.

title: Inventories Up 0.9 % In February
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)  Inventories held by manufacturers and wholesalers rose at substantial rates in February, but retailers cut back on their stocks, the Commerce Department announced today.

title: Alcan's Brazil Unit To Expand Smelter
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. announced that its Brazilian subsidiary, Alcan Aluminio do Brasil S.A., would begin construction immediately of an expansion of the company's Aratu aluminum smelter in the Salvador region of northeastern Brazil.

title: Sorrowing Wichita Falls Combs Tornado's Rubble
description: WICHITA FALLS, Tex., April 11  By sunup this morning rescue workers had begun pulling bodies from beneath the 20 blocks of rubble that had been the most densely populated area of this north Texas town, and the residents of Wichita Falls, stunned and grieving, were waking up to begin coping in their own ways with the tornado's destruction.

title: British Soldier Killed in Ulster
description: BELFAST. Northern Ireland, April 11 (Reuters)  One British soldier was killed and one seriously wounded today when gunmen suspected of being members of the Irish Republican Army ambushed an armored car in Ballymurphy, a Catholic suburb of Belfast.

title: 76ers Set Back Nets by 122114; Loughery Ousted From Opener
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 11  There were two confrontations tonight at the Spectrum. In the first one, the Philadelphia 76ers never trailed in handing the New Jersey Nets a 122114 setback in. the opener of their twoofthree game preliminary series in the Eastern Conference playoffs.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Black & Decker Manufacturing ComWY, Towson, Md., a manufacturer of portable electric tools, has appointed Brian J. Heidtke to the new post of vice presidentfinancial resources.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Forsch Yields 10 Hits But Astros Win, 103
description: HOUSTON, April 11 (AP)  Cesar Cedeno cracked a threerun, tiebreaking homer and Ken Forsch scattered 10 hits in his first appearance since his nohitter last Saturday as the Houston Astros topped the Los Angeles Dodgers, 103. tonight.

title: Iran's First Passover TV Show Helps Ease Jews Fears of Future
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 11  The twostory house of Yedidiali Shofet, Iran's chief rabbi, glowed with lights. Uncles, aunts, cousins, daughters and sons were gathered there. Children filled the place with light and happy noises. The grand oval table sparkled with crystal glasses and shiny plates, neatly arranged on a spotless white lace tablecloth. It was the first night of Passover.

title: G.E. Net Gains 22.4%; Westinghouse Up 25.7%
description: The General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, two of the nation's largest manufacturers of electrical equipment and appliances, reported strong earnings gains yesterday for the first quarter of 1979.

title: Judge Bars Destruction of Records In Chicago Mental Patient Surgery
description: CHICAGO, April 11  A Cook County Circuit Court judge issued a temporary restraining order today forbidding the Illinois Department of Mental Health to destroy any records pertaining to surgery In the 1950's and 1960's in which the adrenal glands of mental patients were allegedly removed in unauthorized and secret experiments.

title: Riot Incitement Is Charged to Six In Bus Walkout
description: Six striking schoolbus drivers, attempting to block nonunion drivers from leaving a Queens garage to transport handicapped children to school, were arrested yesterday and charged with inciting to riot after a melee with the police. Union officials said several bus drivers had been injured, but the police said there had been only one.

title: Yankees Waste 3Run Lead, Fall to Orioles
description: BALTIMORE, April 11  The way the Yankees and Orioles are going at each other this season, their fans may be suffering from nervous exhaustion before the end of April.

title: V.A. Is Hopeful Bronx Hospital Can Open in 79
description: After having failed a fire test, a metal clip used in the installation of ceilings has been replaced by spotwelding at the new 702bed Veterans Administration hospital in the Bronx, and officials said yesterday that they hoped to be able to move from the old building by late summer or early fall.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Powder StorageArea Explosion Kills 36 Pakistanis and Injures 43
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, April 11 (UPI)  An underground gunpowderstorage area exploded today in the heart of Rawalpindi, killing dozens of people.

title: Yunich Role Seen In Brascan Offer
description: David L. Yunich, a former vice chairman of R.H. Macy & Company and before that president of the Macy New York division, has reportedly been retained as a consultant by Brascan.

title: National Magazine Awards Given to 8
description: New West magazine won a National Magazine Award for public service yesterday for an article by Moira Johnston on dangerous defects in the Firestone 500 steelbelted radial tires. The article was one of the factors that led to the eventual Governmentordered recall of the company's steelbelted radials, which the Government contends caused 41 deaths and 65 injuries.

title: Stocks Tumble on I.B.M. Report
description: Disappointing firstquarter profits for International Business Machines, Wall Street's favorite glamour issue, placed a damper on the entire stock market yesterday and sent prices broadly lower.

title: President of Georgia Bank Reports Its Recovery From Inquiry's Effects
description: ATLANTA, April 11  The President of the National Bank of Georgia, in his annual addrets to shareholders and in a separate discussion with reporters today, sought to reshape the bank's image and move the institution from under the cloud of numerous investigations arising out of the earlier presidency of Bert Lance.

title: Advertising
description: IF an editor creates a magazine that is so on target that subscribers refuse to part with it, that's bad.

title: S. SYRJALA, 74, DIES; STAGE SET DESIGNER
description: S. Syriala, the inventive theatrical designer, was found dead of natural causes Tuesday in his apartment at 375 West End Avenue. He was 74 years old.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The slump in the credit markets moved into its fourth day yesterday as bond prices declined and hovered near their lows of the year.

title: Business Records
description: BANK RUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT wednesday. April 11,1979

title: EXU.S. AIDES ASSAIL SOVIET ARMS TREATY
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Several former defense officials and retired military officers attacked the projected strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union today, asserting that the accord would lock the United States into a position of military inferiority for years to come and that Senate ratification would be exceedin ply dangerous and foolish.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: Crew Will Testify Today On NearFatal Jet Plunge
description: Members of a Trans World Airlines crew are scheduled to give their first public accounting today of the nearly disastrous, 30,000foot dive of a Boeing 727 jet over Michigan last week.

title: U.S. Welcomes New Regime
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) United States officials welcomed the ouster of President Idi Amin today and said the United States planned to establish a normal relationship with the new Government quickly.

title: Peking's Envoy Says New York Will Get First China Trade Office
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 Piloting red Big Apple to his gray Mao jacket, the Chinese Ambassador to the United States declared today that New York City was the economic center of the world and that China intended to establish its first American office for international trade there.

title: Nuclear Plant Poll
description: When public opinion shifts as dramatically as it has on nuclear power, national politicians usually follow not far behind, or else make a forceful show of standing their ground despite the public. But thus far the more typical attitude has been one of jogging in place. tentatively gauging both the depth of the public mood and the energy alternatives to more atomic power.

title: Q&A
description: Q.The house we moved into two years ago has a problem with the paint in the living and dining rooms. The ceilings develop fine cracks, then the paint starts to peel. The plaster underneath is not cracked. There is evidence that the previous owners had the same problem. Do you know what we can do to solve this before we repaint? Mrs. P.R., Hatboro, Pa.

title: I.R.S. TaxReturn Help Called Fairly Prompt
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)  The Internal Revenue Service does a fairly good job of providing taxpayers with prompt tax assistance at its walkin service offices, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: The Athenaeum: Quiet Refuge Becomes Center of Storm
description: BOSTON. April 11  One does not speak above a whisper in the reading rooms of the Boston Athenaeum, whose long, elegant chambers are filled with Persian carpets, polished antiques. fine China vases, silver candelabras, bowls of fresh flowers and shelves of ancient and forgotten lore.

title: Bridge:
description: Comprehensive and uptodate descriptions of bidding, written by player of the highest rank, have been relatively rare in the literature of the game. A notable addition to this short series is Standard Bidding, by Bill Root, this country's leading teacher.

title: Jazz, in Surprise Step, Ask to Leave New Orleans
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 11 (AP) The New Orleans Jazz, beset by booking hassles in the Superdome, announced a surprise plan today to move to Salt Lake City next season if the National Basketbari Association approved.

title: U.S. Wins in Field Hockey
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, April 11 (AP)  The United States women's field hockey team scored a 10 victory over Scotland today for its first triumph during a 14game Olympic qualifying tour of Europe. The goal was scored by Beth Anders on a hand stop from a penalty corner at 63 minutes 12 seconds.

title: Key Scientist Favors Elimination Of Saccharin Use Within 3 Years
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)  The leader of a National Academy of Sciences panel studying the health risks of saccharin told Congress today that he now believed the artificial sweetener should be phased out within three years.

title: Black Caucus Assails Carter Oil Policy
description: CHICAGO, April 11 President Carter's plan to decontrol domestic oil prices Is inflationary, inequitable and ineffective, the 17member Congressional Black Caucus says in a statement to be released tomorrow.

title: Bonn Monetary Reserves Drop
description: FRANKFURT, April 11 (AP)  Net monetary reserves of the West German central bank fell by 1.4 billion marks, or about $727 million, to 85.9 billion marks, or $45.2 billion, in the week ended April 7, the Deutsche Bundesbank said in its weekly statement today.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Vientiane Succumbs to Gray
description: VIENTIANE, Laos  For those who know the East European capitals, Vientiane appeared to be the least likely town to acquire the traits that in the decades since World War 11 have created strong similarity between such disparate cities as Moscow and Budapest. Prague and half of Berlin.

title: The Meaning of Three Mile Island
description: At last, Federal officials have declared the crisis at Three Mile Island over. The reactor must still be eased to a complete shutdown, and it will be months before radioactivity has subsided enough to permit inspection of its damaged core. But the nation's worst nuclear power accident has finally been brought under control. How should a perplexed nation react to this hairraising event? Plunge ahead bravely with more nuclear power? Impose yet another layer of safety reviews on this heavily regulated industry? Refuse to license any more nuclear plants? Junk the plants now operating?

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Talmadge Said to Admit To Some Rule Violations
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)  Senator Herman E. Talmadge has agreed to admit to what were described as minor violations of Senate rules but will contest fully the major allegations of financial misconduct lodged against him, his attorney said today.

title: Home Improvement
description: POWERDRIVEN tools  lawn mowers, garden tractors, edgers, hedge trimmers, chain saws and other motordriven outdoor equipment  can save the homeowner and the gardener many hours of hard work each year. But these tools must be sensibly handled and properly maintained if you want to avoid accidents.

title: And Now, the First Days of Pompeii
description: W E'RE calling these weeks The First Days of Pompeii,' reported a weary aide at the American Museum of Natural History. What she referred to were the massive preparations under way for Pompeii A.D. 79. the archeological extravaganza that, after a year's tour in Boston. Chicago and Dallas, opens at the museum on April 22. Museum officials are already predicting an attendance of 750,000 during the show's 101day appearance (it closes July 31), somewhat less than the 1.3 million drawn by the Tutankhamun show at an institution right across the park, but still a respectable crowd.

title: Dance: Pops by Judith Hook
description: THE Judith Hook Dance Company presented a choreographic pops concert Tuesday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. Like the musical fare at many summertime orchestral pops concerts, Miss Hook's choreography for her group from Rochester was bright and lively, yet not terribly conseauential.

title: Sam G. Adler, 86, ExChairman Of Savannah Dry Goods Company
description: Sam Guckenheimer Adler, retired chairman of the board of the Leopold Adler Company of Savannah, Ga., died yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Savannah. He was 86 years old.

title: CAPITAL OF UGANDA TAKEN BY INVADERS; NEW REGIME FORMED
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 11 An invading force of Tanzanian soldiers and Ugandan exiles captured Kampala, the capital of Uganda, early today as thousands of residents poured out of their homes shouting and weeping for joy.

title: Airport to Get Cab Hearing Room
description: A hearing room for cab drivers accused of mistreating riders will be set up at Kennedy International Airport as part of a joint effort by the city and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to combat abuses against taxi passengers at the city's to major airports.

title: A. &
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company reported yesterday a loss of $36,890,000 for the fiscal fourth quarter ended Feb. 24, against a profit in the yearearlier quarter of $895,000. Sales rose to $1.9 billion from $1.87 billion in the similar quarter the year before, the company said.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: JERUSALEM  The air here is always charged with the emotions of history, but there have not been many moments of symbolism as overpowering as this Passover. To celebrate the Exodus from Egypt, 3,200 years ago, at a time when an Israeli state is actually making peace with Egypt . ..

title: News Summary
description: International

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: International

title: Coast Guard Tug Watches For Trouble During Strike
description: The Coast Guard tugboat Manitou traveled the periphery of New York Harbor, the only moving vessel in sight early on a blustery morning. Surging on her 1,000horsepower engines she cut through the whitecaps and began her patrol of the gray, watery highway.

title: Woolworth Spurns Bid By Brascan
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company, girding for an intensive legal battle, yesterday rejected a $1.1 billion takeover bid by Brascan Ltd., a littleknown Canadian company based in Toronto,

title: Discount Flowers
description: FARMERS arrive at the Bronx Terminal Market at 4 in the morning, park on a large triangle of concrete behind the white Art Decostyle buildings and set out their flats of flowers, vegetable seedlings and house plants on the paving. It is agreeable to be reminded that New York is still a market town and that people still grow things around its edges.

title: Deaths
description: TILZERJudge George, beloved father of our esteemed Vice President James A. Yilrer. Neighborhood Division. Hearttelt condolences are extended by all our employees.

title: Kennedy Leading Carter by 2 to 1 In Poll of New Hampshire Voters
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) While former President Gerald R. Ford and former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California are running neck and neck, New Hampshire voters pick Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts over President Carter by a 2to1 margin, a new poll shows.

title: Israelis Clash With Palestinians All Along the Lebanese Frontier
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 11  Violence increased today along the full length of the IsraeliLebanese border as Palestinians fired rockets at an Israeli border town and exchanged heavy artillery fire with Israeli forces.

title: Merger for Allstate Fund
description: Shareholders of the Allstate Enterprises Stock Fund, meeting yesterday in Northbrook, III., approved a merger of their fund into the W.L. Morgan Growth Fund, a member of the Vanguard Group of investment companies.

title: Disks: Gould Performs Bach Toccatas
description: THIS is not the first time Glenn Gould has recorded music he says he doesn't like. Mr. Gould has written disparagingly of his greatgrandfather's first cousin, Edvard Grieg, yet he is one of the few pianists to have recorded Grieg's Sonata in E minor. Mr. Gould's own album notes for his recording of Beethoven's Appassionata Sonata call it a piece that does not work. His feelings about Bach's harpsichord toccatas are set down in an essay he wrote about the WellTempered Clavier. Interminably repetitious, he called them. Rudimentarily sequential, desperately in need of an editor's red pencil. He singles out the D minor Toccata for special attention; the first fugue subject, he complains, is reiterated on no less than fifteen occasions in the home key alone.

title: TOP POP RECORDS
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets, singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON (AP)  Attorney General John .J. Degnan's request that the state be allowed to decontrol liquor prices May 1 was denied yesterday by the New Jersey Supreme Court. The court, by a 6to0 vote, denied Mr. Degnan's request that it vacate the stay issued by the Appellate Division of Superior Court pending a resolution of the appeal. Justice Mark A. Sullivan did not participate in the decision.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The name of the Virginia Electric and Power Company was given incorrectly yesterday in a chart accompanying an article in Business Day. The chart also incorrectly identified the location of the company's Surry nuclear power plants, which are south of Williamsburg, Va., . and of its North Anna plants, which are north of Richmond.

title: About New York
description: After 36 hours of artillery fire, German troops took the town of Warta in western Poland on Sept. 4, 1939. Wolfgang Landau, a watchmaker's son, smart enough at 16 years of age for the gymnasium but strong enough for the Nazi slave labor camps, escaped dragnets twice. Then he was trussed and shipped out, beginning a new life of wily and miserable survival in a total of 21 camps and prisons.

title: Gallup Poll Shows 63% See Nuclear Plant Need
description: Although nuclear power as a future energy source in the United States continues to be supported by a majority of the public, two out of three Americans feel that operations at nuclear power facilities should be cut back until safety regulations are made more stringent, according to a Gallup Poll comparing public opinion since the accident at Three Mile Island with a similar poll in 1976

title: Alexander H. Mossman, 81, Dies; Executive in Travel Advertising
description: Alexander Hyde Mossman, an advertising executive with more than 30 years experience in the travel industry, died Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. He was 81 years old and lived in New York City.

title: Last 88 Transit Officers Laid Off in 75 Crisis Rejoin Force
description: The last 88 of nearly 500 Transit Authority police officers who were laid off during the city's 1975 rascal crisis were rehired and sworn in yesterday  and one came back in the uniform of a Marine Corns first lieutenant.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of metals futures were battered yesterday as traders rushed to liquidate or cover positions before the long holiday weekend. But live cattle futures soared to records as cash cattle and beef prices bounded upward.

title: Deaths
description: SMITH  Maryreposing Williams Funeral Home 5628 Broadway at W 232 Street, Brone until 8:30AM Saturday.

title: Doctors Offer Help in Suits Against City for Malpractice
description: The organization that represents interns and resident physicians in municipal hospitals said yesterday that it would help victims of alleged medical malpractice by giving supporting evidence and testimony in lawsuits against the city.

title: Decoy Tax Filers Give Pros a Test And They Flunk
description: The facts were simple enough. She was 25 years old and separated from her husband. She was supporting a 4yearold child. Last year she earned $7,320 as beautician. She had $2,404 in itemized deductions. How much should she pay in Federal, state and city income taxes?

title: The City
description: Motorists using the seven bridges and two tunnels operated by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority handed over more than $189 million in tolls last year, the authority announced yesterday.

title: Mary Piatek, Giammalva Jr. Gain at Tennis
description: EDGEWATER, N.J., April 11 Mary Lou Piatek of Whiting, Ind., made an impressive debut today on the first day of the 12th annual Easter Bowl junior tennis tournament at the Binghamton Racquet Club.

title: Mayor Will Seek Agencies to Run Seized Dwellings
description: Mayor Koch is seeking, for the first time, to hire managers from private realestate agencies to handle the vast amouri,t of property the city has acquired through foreclosures.

title: South Carolina Bars Two Trucks With Three Mile Island's Wastes
description: BARNWELL, S.C., April 11 (UPI) South Carolina has closed its borders to two trucks carrying nuclear waste from Pennsylvania's Three Mile Island power plant until it is determined whether the waste came from the reactor damaged in last month's accident.

title: Notes on People
description: In Helena, Mont., Gov. Thomas Judge has declared a range war on what he calls arrogant Easterners in New York City. His beef with New York Is over the beefless Wednesday campaign proposed by Bruce C.Ratner, Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, to protest high costs of meats.

title: EARNINGS
description: Teledyne reported yesterday a firstquarter profit jump of 64.5 percent on a sales gain of 14.9 percent, and attributed it to lucrative insurance operations

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: After four days of declining prices and rising interest rates, the credit markets yesterday recovered slightly as they waited to see if the Federal Reserve tightens monetary policy at its Open Market Committee meeting next Tuesday.

title: Desmond Grealy, 56; A CBS News Producer
description: Desmond Grealy, a CBS news producer, died Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital of complications resulting from severe pancreatitis. He was 56 years old and lived in Spring Valley. N.Y.

title: State Agency Grants WaterQuality Permit For Westway Project
description: ALBANY, April 12  The State Environmental Conservation Department issued a waterquality permit today for the dredging and filling portion of the proposed Westway project in New York City.

title: Television
description: 5:55 (4)NOAA's Work

title: Companies List Their Sales and Earnings Reports
British Prices Up 0.8%
description: LONDON, April 12 (AP)  Retail prices in Britain rose eighttenths of 1 percent in March, matching February's gain, the Department of Employment reported today. The department said that prices were up 9.8 percent from March 1978. It was the fifth consecutive month that the yeartoyear increase grew and was the biggest such gain since January 1978.

title: Market Place
description: COOK UNITED INC., a Middle Western chain of discount stores that has long been considered a merger candidate, suddenly has two suitors. The company's shares rose yesterday in active trading after word reached Wall Street that there was interest in a takeover. Cook closed at 7, up , on volume of 128,900 shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: In a Makeshift Court in Teheran, The Koran's Law Metes Out Death
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 12  It is not the individual who is on trial, the short, roundfaced mullah who sat in judgment on Maj. Bijan Yahyahi said over and over again. It is the regime.

title: Soccer League Poses a Strike Threat Today
description: There were strong indications yesterday that the North American Soccer League Players Association would announce a strike at a news conference in Washington this morning.

title: 4 Milk Trucks Inch Past Police And Deliver to a Dairy in Queens
description: A total of four tank trucks, each carrying 6,000 gallons of raw milk, arrived without incident at the Elmhurst Milk and Cream Company in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday after inching through long lines of helmeted New York City police officers.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, April 13

title: Determined Woman Vows To Seek Mishap Answers
description: MIDDLETOWN. Pa., April 12 (AP)  Anne D. Trunk is a quiet housewife who conceded today that she did not know the difference between a millirem and a reactor vessel before the Three Mile Island accident March 28 just 2 miles from her home in this city.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 12, 1979

title: Economic Scene
description: WHEN the representatives of 99 nations assembled in Geneva yesterday to initial the huge trade package that has been five years in the making, Robert S. Strauss, the President's special representative for trade was home in Washington, leaving his deputy, Alonzo L. McDonald Jr., to handle the formalities in Switzerland. Mr. Strauss knew where he belonged  on the home front, trying to make sure that Congress does not torpedo this huge and painfully constructed trade pact.

title: Philharmonic: Mehta Leads Choral Program
description: ZUBIN MEHTA put together a New York Philharmonic program for this holiday time that was a model of judicious balance: the Old Testament against the New. He even offered a nondevotional prelude for those in last night's audience who might not have been deeply committed one way or another. The orchestra's music director offered Leonard Bernstein's Chichester Psalms, sung in Hebrew, before intermission and finished off the night with Verdi's Four Sacred Pieces, in Italian. Schubert's Unfinished Symphony set the scene, wordlessly but perhaps no less meaningfully, for all that it could not call on the splendid services of the Westminster Mir as Mr. Bernstein and Mr. Verdi did.

title: Japanese Buddhist Wins Award
description: LONDON, April 12 (Reuters)  A Japanese Buddhist leader, Nikkyo Niwano, has been awarded what is described as the Nobel prize for religion. The $160,000 prize was given to Mr. Niwano, 73 years old, for being a bridge in interfaith understanding, the sponsors, the Templeton Foundation, said. The award was set up by John Templeton, an American banker.

title: A Suspect in Robbery At Lufthansa Is Held As Violator of Parole
description: James Burke, regarded by investigators as a key suspect in last December's $5.8 million robbery at the Lufthansa cargo building at Kennedy International Airport, was arrested at his home in Queens yesterday on charges of having violated his Federal parole. He has never been charged with a role in the Lufthansa robbery.

title: CITY IN NORTH TEXAS HELD DISASTER AREA
description: WICHITA FALLS, Tex., April 12 (AP)  President Carter has declared this ravaged city a disaster area and city officials have instituted a dusk-to-dawn curfew and a pricefreeze in the aftermath of one of the most devastating tornadoes in the nation's history.WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)  An orbiting satellite relaying messages from two Air Force Jeeps is a major link to the outside world for Wichita Falls.

title: Sweden Jails 3 in Hijacking
description: STOCKHOLM, April 12 (UPI)  Three members of the Ananda Marge Indian religous sect who hijacked a MoscowboundAeroflot airliner Feb. 27 were sentenced to jail terms ranging from 18 months to 3 years today. A 27yearold Swedish man and a 42yearold Brazilian woman each received 3 years in jail, while a 22yearold West German woman was sentenced to 18 months. The three, who were armed with Molotov cocktails, were overpowered by members of the crew.

title: Experts Say the Accident Will Prompt New Rules and Structural Change
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Nuclear experts believe that the accident at the Three Mile Island reactor will bring significant changes in how the Government regulates nuclear power and could prompt reconsideration of the way. American utilities own and operate their. reactors.

title: IN THE NATION
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif.  Gov. Jerry Brown of California ran ahead of Jimmy Carter in five late primaries in 1976 and stayed in the Presidential race until the nominating roll call at the Democratic National Convention came to his state. Mr. Brown then switched his California delegates to Mr. Carter  save for two that seemed to be unaccounted for. When the chair inquired what had happened to them, the young Governor said that he'd the young Governor said that he'd just leave those two floating around the hall.

title: Quick, Before They Hatch
description: The judges  Andy Warhol, the artist and entrepreneur; Robin Parkinson, an exhibition designer at the CooperHewitt Museum, and Pat Prescott, a disk jockey at WRVR  assembled promptly at 1:30 P.M. and made their way to a podium in the atrium at the Citicorn Center. Their task: to judge the 221 entries in the first annual Conran's Easter Egg Painting Competition, and select 14 winners (who would receive modest gift certificates to the home furnishings store) from four age groups.

title: Pope's Message on Celibacy Gets Mixed Reaction From U.S. Clergy
description: Mixed reactions have greeted this week's message to priests by Pope John Paul H reaffirming mandatory celibacy and discouraging priests from forsaking the clergy in order to marry.

title: Suspect Seized in Bank Robbery
description: A 29yearold Bronx man was arrested yesterday and charged with the armed robbery of a Manhattan branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank in which approximately $8,030 was taken, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported. The suspect, Richard Mickens, accused of being one of three men who robbed the bank at 62 Ninth Avenue last Aug. 15, was charged with one count of bank robbery following his arrest outside his home, at 770 Theriot Avenue, shortly after 9 A.M., by F.B.I. agents and New York City police. His alleged accomplices, Michael McClanahan and Wayne McClanahan, were arrested earlier.

title: The City
description: Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan charged that officials of the New York City Transit Authority had proposed an illegal, unsafe and fiscally unsound program to repair the undercarriages of 754 of the newest cars in the subway system.

title: Study of Salem Atomic Reactor Is Challenged
description: TRENTON, April 12  A consultant's study of the Salem No. 1 nuclear reactor in Salem, N.J., did not address the question of control room facilities but focused on essential pumps, piping and cooling system in the basic reactor itself, Dr. Glenn R. Paulson, assistant commissioner for science of the New Jersey, Department of Environmental Protettion, said today. He added that the study, which has not yet been released, did not focus on such details as the design of the control panel.

title: 3 at Ford Earn Over $1 Million
description: DETROIT, April 12  Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, and two other top executives at Ford passed the $1 million mark in salary and other benefits last year while top officers of the General Motors Corporation kept their pay just below that level, confirming again that automo- tive executives are among the most highly paid in American industry.

title: Screen: Crime Fighting In the Disney Style:Crusading Minister
description: THE new Walt Disney comedy, "The North Avenue Irregulars," that opens today at Loew's 83d Street and other theaters, is about an energetic young Presbyterian minister who mobilizes the women of his parish to fight organized crime in his small, otherwise ideal community.His unlikely mob includes Barbara Harris, as one of those suburban mothers whose station wagon is always stuffed with children who are late getting somewhere else; Cloris Leachman, as a divorce with time on her hands and spectacularly long finger-nails, and Patsy Kelly as a housewife who lives on a thin edge between fury and despair. They make do-gooding a cheerful, predictably risky adventure.Edward Herrmann, who was seen as Franklin D. Roosevelt in television's two "Eleanor and Franklin" shows, plays the minister with the sort of earnest near-sightedness that requires him to wear glasses and frequently look aghast. Don Tait wrote the screenplay, which is based loosely on the real-life story of the Rev. Albert Fay Hill, of New Rochelle, as recorded in his book.The film is the first theatrical feature to be directed by Bruce Bilson, who has completly absorbed the Disney style. "The North Avenue Irregulars" transforms energy into optimism and ends with an automobile chase and pileup that is as exhilarating as a demolition derby."The North Avenue Irregulars," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains a discreetly violent scene in which a Presbyterian church is fire-bombed.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Hollywood, which gave us The Green Berets in support of the Vietnam War, has now, with its Academy Awards for The Deer Hunter and Coming Home, acknowledged that there is more to war than swashbuckling heroics. On the screen and in books, the postVietnam message is that war is grim and has few redeeming features.

title: Advertising
description: SUZANNE DOUGLAS, who chose magazine space peddling as a career, may now, because of an enlightening personal experience, become a magazine publisher. And a bit of a cupid's helper.

title: Business and the Law
description: IT was an overcast, muggy afternoon, Saturday, May 1, 1976, and Ronald Chin, a young supervisor in the longlines division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, spent it at a political demonstration at Herald Square in Manhattan.

title: Inquiry Set on Wright's Freeing Of Suspect in Assault on Officer
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would ask his Committee on the Judiciary to investigate Judge Bruce Wright's decision to parole without bail Jerome Singleton, who is accused of the attempted murder of a decoy police officer.

title: Thomas A. Duffy, Retired in 1976 As Judge of Civil Court in Queens
description: Thomas A. Duffy, who retired as a judge of the Civil Court in Queens in 1976, died Wednesday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He lived at 3332 75th Street, Jackson Heights. Queens, and had marked his 73d birthday last Friday.

title: Dance: 3 by Weidman
description: BECAUSE dance is an evanescent art, choreographic revivals are always welcome. Therefore it was admirable for the Theater Dance Ensemble to devote part of its Wednesday evening concert at the Theater of the Riverside Church to revivals of three works by the late Charles Weidman. a choreographer known for his social conscience and compassion.

title: P. H. Bilhuber Is Dead; ExSteinway Executive
description: Paul Henry Bilhuber, a former vice president and director of Steinway and Sons, the piano manufacturers, died of a heart attack Monday while visiting friends in Cocoa Beach, Fla. He was 90 years old and lived in Buck Hill Falls, Pa., and in Basin Harbor, Vt.

title: A Remarkable Step Forward on Trade
description: After five long years of negotiations in Geneva, 99 countries have agreed to a new set of rules for liberalizing international trade. Their agreement falls short of resolving every serious issue dividing the parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), and it has yet to be shown that the new rules can be enforced. But with unemployment, sluggish growth and financial instability all pushing the world backward toward protectionism, these measured steps forward are a remarkable achievement.

title: Art: Modern Mounts Big Catch in Lobby
description: THE late James Thrall Soby (190679) was one of those privileged people who had the means and developed  at an early age  the taste to buy works by the best names in modern art at a time in this country when it was still considered adventurous to do so. In 1930 when he was 24, for example, he acquired works by Picasso, Matisse and Derain; a little later he began to mine a Surrealist lode of de Chirico, Dali, Ernst and Tanguy, and still later he branched out to Klee, Bacon, Dubuffet and even Ben Shahn.

title: String Band From the 30's In Brooklyn
description: HOWARD ARMSTRONG, a black country and jazz fiddler who also paints murals and speaks seven languages, including Mandarin Chinese, was reflecting the other day about his start in music. He grew up in Eastern Tennessee and started on mandolin, later transfering the technique associated with that instrument to the violin, which helps account for his rich, exceptionally personal style. I've been around oldfashioned blues players, he said, and that's where I picked up a lot of my style. But I never did copy too many. You know, they say every dog barks loudest in his own yard.

title: FarLeft Groups in Italy Mount New Wave of Attacks
description: ROME, April 12  Bombs exploded and terrorists siaged raids on offices here and in other parts of Italy today in a new wave of violence.

title: First $3.2 Million Man in Flushing
description: Who's in Locker No. 14? a visitor asked Danny Ozark. Same guy named Rose, the Phillies' manager said. This was a few minutes past noon in the visiting team's clubhouse in Shea Stadium. The guy named Rose  Peter Edward Rose  was pulling on his blue and red traveling uniform and answering questions from a semicircle of people with ballpoints and tape recorders. Pete Rose has been play- ing baseball in Shea every summer since the joint was built but always with the Cincinnati Reds until yesterday. Never before had a first baseman worth $3.2 million planted spikes in the soil of Flushing, Long Island. He made two great plays last night, Ozark said. A la Hodges. Ozark was a first baseman on farm teams of the Brooklyn Dodgers when Gil Hodges was

title: InsulinProducing Cell Transplants In Rats Buoying Hope for Diabetics
description: By transplanting insulinproducing cells that survived 100 days in rats, researchers in St. Louis believe they have taken a step toward the ultimate goal of transplanting pancreatic cells to a diabetic person.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  The most engaging character in Washington these days is the man with the most thankless job  Alfred Edward Kahn of Cornell University, the President's chief inflation adviser. He is the sort of a guy who can make failure seem attractive.

title: Woolworth Sues to Bar Takeover
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company yesterday accused Brascan Ltd. of Canada and its principal bank, the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, of an attempt to perpetrate a massive fraud in connection with Brascan's attempt to acauire Woolworth.

title: Where to Savor Spring in Town and Country
description: The legstretching season, cele- brated by poets in terms of zephyrs and romance, is upon us. In town and country, spring lures us out of doors to fill the lungs and spirit with air and sun.

title: A Master of the Oboe in Recital at Y
description: The flyer reads: Oh Boy! /Hautboy/ Hautbois/Oh Bert/Oboe! What this is all about is a recital on Sunday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. by Bert Lucarelli on the oboe, an instrument that in other times was known as hautboy (pronounced oh boy), the latter name being derived from the French hautbois (high wood). Clear?

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Two commercial bankers, Frederick H. Schultz and Emmett J. Rice, were named yesterday by President Carter to be members of the Federal Reserve Board. If confirmed by the Senate, they and the two previous Carter appointees would be a majority on the sevenmember governing body of the nation's central bank.

title: Bus Terminal Disrupted in Protest By Officers Over Contract Dispute
description: Operations at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan were intermittently disrupted during yesterday's evening rush hour by several hundred offduty authority police officers who are locked in a labor battle with the bistate agency.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. White Sox, at Chicago. (Television  Cablevision. 2:15 P.M. (Radio WINS, 2:15 P.M.)

title: Publishing: Foreigners Flock to Rare Book Fair
description: THE XV International Antiquarian Book Fair, which will be held from Thursday through Saturday of next week at the Sheraton Center (Seventh Avenue and 52d Street) will have a much higher incidence of foreign dealers than in previous years. This influx, those in- volved say, is due to a number of fac tors, including the fall in the value of the dollar, the deaccessioning activities of librarians in search of maintenance funds and a certain nationalism that would like to restore native treasures to their home base.

title: Tenants to Fight Fuel Surcharges For Apartments
description: A statewide tenant organization announced yesterday that it would initiate court action to stop landlords from collecting fuel surcharges in rentstabilized apartments in New York City and from increasing rents where leases are already in effect.

title: Mobil to Market Indonesian Gas
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 12 (UPI)  The director of Pertamina, the stateowned oil company, said today that the Mobil Corporation was ready to market Indonesian liquefied natural gas produced by the Arun natural gas field in north Sumatra.

title: Zachry, Mets Beat Phils, 32
description: Last July 24 in Shea Stadium, Pat Zachry gave up a seventhinning single to Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds that enabled Rose to tie the modern National League consecutivegame hitting streak at 37.

title: A Gourmet Dish That Was Just What His Doctor Ordered
description: Pierre Laverne had prepared his famous striped bass fermire hundreds of times before. But never under such primitive conditions.

title: Deaths
description: HOHENSTEIN  Ruth. Died April 11, 1979. Widow of Jacob Hohensten of Weehawken New Jersey. She is survived by a sister, Bernadine Fahn, a daughter, Tina Stiefel, and two grandchildren, Richard and Nancy Stiefel. Memorial service will be held for both Jacob (died June 1, 1978) and Ruth at the Community Church of New York, 40 E 35 St, on Thursday, April 19, of 11 am.

title: Around the Nation
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 12 (AP) The Florida Supreme Court opened the state's courtrooms to cameras and recording equipment on a permanent basis today, thus giving electronic news media and press photographers their broadest access to legal proceedings anywhere in the nation.

title: Cabaret: Robin Williams, LifeSize
description: IT'S extraordinary that anyone as funny as Robin Williams can also create the impression of being so nice. As he demonstrated at the Copacabana Wednesday evening, beginning a soldout engagement that will run through Sunday, Mr. Williams doesn't need sex, malice or selfdeprecation to round out his repertory. He doesn't even need real experience, or even real jokes.

title: The Region
description: NEWARK (AP)  A fire that killed 10dayold baby and her parents early yesterday started in a television room downstairs from the family's secondfloor apartment in a building in the Ironbound section, officials said. Fire Director John Caufield said the cause of the fire in the twostory, concreteblock building was being investigated.

title: Red Sox Outslug Brewers, 1210
description: MILWAUKEE, April 12 (AP)  Jim Dwyer's first American League hit, a tworun pinch single with two out in the ninth inning, lifted the Boston Red Sox to a 1210 victory tonight over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Restaurants
description: THE twomonthold Bistro Pascal on 63d Street, just east of Third Avenue, is a transformation rather than a completely new restaurant. Owned by Robert Pascal, who still operates Chez Pascal, the Bistro's premises were formerly part of his Le Premier, the luxurious, soigne and expensive restaurant that occupied two floors. Now Le Premier functions on the upper level

title: SOUTH AFRICA OUSTS 3 U.S. EMBASSY AIDES, CHARGING AIR SPYING
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, April 12 Prime Minister P. W. Botha announced tonight that South Africa had ordered a number of United States Embassy personnel expelled for allegedly using the Ambassador's aircraft to conduct aerial espionage over wide areas of the country, including what Mr. Botha described as sensitive installations.

title: President, Vacationing on Island In Georgia, to Read, Sleep, Fish
description: BRUNSWICK, Ga., April 12  Jimmy Carter, embarking on a 10day vacation, arrived here this morning and promptly disappeared from sight.

title: C.A.B. Lets Airlines Raise Fares
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board gave the nation's airlines permission yersterday to impose a 4 percent acrosstheboard increase on domestic air fares starting May 15.

title: Deaths
description: ARONOWITZ  Ida, beloved mother of Gertrude Seiko, Frances Bienenfeld and Sylvia Weisman. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Services Friday 10AM at Gutterman's ??000 Jericho Turreilke. Woodbury, L.I.

title: Freighter Sinks Off Spain
description: LA CORUNA, Spain, April 12 (UPI) A Panamanian freighter sank off northern Spain early today. One crew member was reported missing, naval authorities said. The Ellis, with a crew of 13, went down 24 miles north of La Coruha.

title: Commissioners Deplored a Lack of Information, Meeting Records Show
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  In long, secret meetings in the first days after the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant, some members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission expressed fear that the horse race against a calamity might be lost. Repeatedly, the of- ficials struggled with a decision on whether to recommend evacuation of the population.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Andrei Belgrader, who was forced to leave his native Rumania two years ago because of artistic differences with the government, is working at Yale this spring. His production of Shakespeare's As You Like It opens tonight at 8 at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven. Since leaving Rumania, Mr. Belgrader has also worked in New York, where he directed Off Broadway productions of Shakespeare's Troilus and Cressida and Buechner's Woyzeck. As You Like It, the Yale Rep's final production for this season, will play through May 9 in repertory with Edward Bond's The Bundle. Performances Monday through Friday at 8 P.M. and Saturday at 2 and 8:30 P.M. Tickets range from $3.50 to $8. Reservations: (203) 4361600. From New York, take Interstate 95 to exit 47. The theater is at the corner of Chapel and York Streets.

title: New F.C.C. Rule Urged On Stations
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  The Carter Administration's top authority on communications urged the Federal Communications Commission today to adopt a new licensing procedure for radio and television broadcasting that could give preference to minorities.

title: Toronto Is Victor In Series
description: TORONTO, April 12 (UPI)  Darryl Sittler scored two firstperiod goals 12 seconds apart and Ron Ellis connected 11 seconds later tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Atlanta Flames, 74, to win their preliminary National Hockey League playoff series in two straight games.

title: Tight Market in Labor Is Wichita's Problem
description: WICHITA, Kan.  This bustling city of 270,000 has a problem that sends its principal employers crying, as the saying goes, all the way to the bank.

title: The Klansman and His Prisoners
description: The New York State Court of Appeals ruled last week that a prison guard cannot be fired merely for belonging to the Ku Klux Klan. It is somewhat unsettling to think of a Klansman guarding black and Hispanic prisoners, but the court's adherence to the right of free association cannot be faulted.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Special Committee Against Apartheid  1:15 P.M.

title: Deaths
description: SEROTA  Robert. Utopia Ledge a 400 K. of P. & its Welfare Association mourns the passing of a distinguished Past Chancellor & dedicated Vice President. His loss is deeply felt. Funeral services Friday, April 13, 1pm at the I.J. Morris, Inc. Funeral Home. 1195 Flebush Ave. Bklyn

title: Schlesinger Would Spend 2.5 Billion on Solar Power
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger has recommended to President Carter that the Federal Government spend $2.5 billion to stimulate the developmem of solar energy in the mid1980's, with the aim of having the nation get about 12 percent of its energy from solar power by the year 2000.

title: Ceremony At Geneva Boycotted
description: GENEVA, April 12  Developing countries boycotted the signing ceremony today for the new agreement to liberalize world trade that was hailed by the United States and the world's other industrialized nations as a major victory against protectionism and the threat of worldwide economic recession.

title: TV Weekend
description: ACOUPLE of weeks ago, CBS had a TV movie about young mentally retarded lovers. No Other Love starred Richard Thomas and Julie Kavner. Tonight at 9, ABC has a TV movie about young mentally retarded lovers. Like Normal People has Shaun Cassidy and Linda Purl. Obvious comments on broadcasting and this seeming trend will be withheld in the interest of avoiding tastelessness.

title: U.S. and U.N. Renew Efforts for Namibian Elections
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 12 United Nations and United States officials have engaged in renewed diplomatic efforts to persuade South Africa to go along with arrangements for a ceasefire and supervised elections in SouthWest Africa.

title: Fine Lifted in Labor Election Case
description: An appeals court decided yesterday to lift a $10,000 fine on the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board for his refusal to disclose confidential union membership cards that had been subpoenaed for a criminal trial.

title: At the Movies
description: I FELT ashamed of myself for watching, Glenda Jackson said the other day, speaking of the Academy Award ceremonies. No one should have a chance to see so much desire, so much need for a prize, and so much pain when was not given.

title: Surrendering to Recession
description: It is sad to note that the nation's answer to inflation is still recession. The Carter Administration has said is not necessarily so. Its economists hope the overheated United States economy will slow down without actually shrinking. But the Government's controls over economic policy are not so finely adjusted that they can assure such a safe course. Thus, the Government is starting to hedge its bets. With doubledigit inflation hand, the Administration now wants to err on the side of recession rather than risk a continuation of unexpectedly rapid growth.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE fathers of rockandroll haven't done too well lately. Some of them can muster up charming performance when they want to  Chuck Berry, above all. But none have managed a really interesting new record in years.

title: Peking Terms Architecture Impractical and Heavy
description: HONG KONG, April 12  Architecture in China is impractical, overly concerned with grandeur and still too influenced by the heavy Stalinist style, an unusual article in The Peking Daily has charged.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TEANECK, N.J., April 12  Vince Draddy, coming off a brilliant indoor track season, started his outdoor campaign impressively yesterday by winning the mile in 4 minutes 12.1 seconds at the Memorial Relay Carnival at Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: Nations Reach Rubber Accord
description: GENEVA, April 12  Major producer and consumer countries of natural rubber agreed here today on the key elements of a market stabilizing accord they expect to conclude before August.

title: Consumer Advocates Skeptical About President's Oil Proposals
description: The President is acutely aware of the impact of energy policy and inflation on the poor, people with fixed incomes and the elderly, Anne Wexler, the Assistant to the President for liaison with specialinterest groups, said last month when she

title: Holiday Closings
description: Securities and commodities exchanges in the United States, Canada and Europe will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. Banks in New Jersey and Connecticut will also be closed, but some banks in New York State will remain open. Federal Government offices will also remain open.

title: Carter Campaign Fund Audit Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Several persons who participated in the Federal Election Commission's audit of the finances of Jimmy Carter's 1976 Presidential primary campaign say the audit had such a narrow focus that it was highly unlikely the audit staff could have uncovered any sophisticated mishandling of campaign funds.

title: HEAVY RUSSIAN TOLL IN AFGHANISTAN SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  United States intelligence officials said today that as many as 100 Soviet military advisers might have been killed in Afghanistan in the last month in fighting between Government troops and guerrillas.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE TREE HOUSE CONFESSIONS. By James McConkey. 214 pages. E. P. Dutton. $8.95.

title: French ReadytoWear: The EverChanging Message
description: PARIS, April 12  If you haven't yet invested in a skinny skirt with a devastating slit at the side or back, maybe you won't have to. The same goes for coats or jackets with shoulders that look stuffed with baby pillows. Pads haven't exactly disappeared, but they're far more moderate in size than when they first appeared. There's a movement among the trendy designers to show them with pointy edges, slightly upturned, but you don't really have to be the first on your block to sprout them.

title: EXDIRECTOR ASKED TO HEAD '80 CENSUS
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  The Carter Administration has asked a former direct for of the Census Bureau, a Republican appointed by President Nixon, to take over the troubled agency again.

title: Met Opera: Nevin Eugene Onegin
description: TATYANA in Eugene Onegin can be a dream role for a soprano whose gifts as a singing actress extend far enough beyond the purely vocal requirements to force the listener to be caught up in Tchaikovsky's sentimental version of the Pushkin tale. People who can watch with a certain detachment as characters in other operas are stabbed, tortured or otherwise mistreated, find themselves growing outraged or weteyed as that foppish rake, Eugene, tears apart the tender heart of the gentle country girl. Every new Tatyana, therefore, must prove that she can touch emotions as well the right notes.

title: Serious Politicking in '80 Could Last for 10 Months
description: The politicking in the 1980 Presidential election year in New York is likely to start and end in the snow. Republican legislative and party leaders have decided that they want an April primary election for delegates to the na-

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation yesterday confirmed a report that the company was negotiating the sale of its French, subsidiary, Claude S.A., a manufacturer of light bulbs, to the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation.

title: Radio Singer of the 30's Takes a Bow at Ballroom
description: Patti Pickens, the youngest of the Pickens Sisters, the singing trio that rivaled the Boswell Sisters in popularity in the early 1930's, is resuming her professional career at the age of 62 this weekend at the Ballroom in SoHo. She is doing it, she admits quite candidly, for money.

title: Studio 54's Coowner, Bouncer and TV Crew Arrested for Brawling
description: Steve Rubell, the coowner of Studio 54, one of his bouncers and two members of a television camera crew from Baltimore were arrested early yesterday bn crosscomplaints stemming from a brawl that allegedly erupted inside the midtown discotheque and spilled into the street.

title: EXECUTIONS IN IRAN DENOUNCED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  The Un States denounced the wave of executi in Iran today as a violation of inter tionally accepted standards of justice.

title: Amin's Photo Falls at U.N. Office
description: A photograph of Idi Amin was taken down at Uganda House yesterday, and the headquarters of the Ugandan mission to the United Nations was handed over to representatives of the new Government.

title: Mondale Confers With Icelanders And Notes Absence of Problems
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, April 12 (UPI)  Vice President Mondale, who is on a tour of northern Europe, held talks with Icelandic leaders today.

title: Misses Goolagong, DuPont Gain
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S. C., April 12  Nothing seems beyond Evonne Goolagong's grasp now. Her left foot finally feels no pain, daughter Kelly is as feisty as ever and husband Roger thinks a final fling at No. 1 is just fine.

title: Nuclear Agency Issues New List of Warnings To 34 Power Stations
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission told operators of 39 atomic power plants today to beware the kinds of mistakes and breakdowns that caused the accident at the nuclear plant at Three Mile Island.

title: The Other Blacks
description: LOS ANGELES  Black leadership has come disproportionately from two highly atypical groups  descendants of blacks free before the Civil War and West Indian immigrants. Thus, much of the black leadership speaks in the name of a black population from which it differs socially and economically further, that population has been long despised by the groups in which the leaders have their own roots.

title: Art Theft Reported in Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE, April 12 (AP)  A Picasso etching valued at $9,000 and two original Chagall lithographs, each valued at $5,000, are missing from the Village of Cross Keys art gallery. According to the police, the thefts from an unlocked storage cabinet occurred between 6 P.M. last Friday and 10 A.M. Tuesday, when they were discovered.

title: Pol Pot Unit Sits on Border, Possibly a Last Camp
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, April 12  The path that leads for 20 minutes from a country road through fields of stubble and sparse woods turns sharply to the left near the malodorous remains of a cow that stepped on a landmine a day or two ago. Then the path descends sharply toward a narrow stream.

title: A Correction
description: In an article in The Home Section yesterday on planning a balcony garden, part of the instructions for preparing neutral pH soil were dropped. The paragraph should have read: To make about 30 pounds of neutral pH soil enough to fill a cubicfoot container mix together 23 pounds of loamy topsoil, rich in rotted organic material, four quarts of peat moss, four quarts of vermiculite (or perlite), half a cup of fine lime, half a cup of bone meal and half a cup of dried blood.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 13, 1979

title: Lietzke Leads Masters With 67
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 12  By universal agreement, the impeccably prepared Augusta National Golf Club course was in the best shape it ever has been for an opening day of the Masters Tournament, and the spring weather was perfect. Thus it was that the first round of the 43d Masters today produced 23 scores under par, and 10 at evenpar 72.

title: Miss Caulkins, Vassallo Excel
description: MONTEREY PARK, Calif., April 12  Cynthia Woodhead, Tracy Caulkins and Jesse Vassallo, all world champions and world record holders, won national titles tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's shortcourse swimming championships. So did David Larson, who had never won any kind of title before.

title: Zambia Reports Raid By Rhodesian Troops On Nkomo Residence
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Friday, April 13 (Reuters)  A Rhodesian commando force attacked the residence of Joshua Nkomo, the Rhodesian blacknationalist guerrilla leader, and other buildings in Lusaka used by nationalist officials today, Radio Zambia said.

title: Elizabeth Hands Out Alms Amid the Glitter of History
description: WINCHESTER, England, April 12 In a ceremony commemorating Christ's act of humility in washing the feet of His apostles on the night before He died on the cross, Queen Elizabeth II presented alms to 106 elderly people this morning in Winchester's 900yearold cathedral.

title: Broadway
description: ROMANTIC COMEDY. the third joint enterprise between Bernard Slade and Morton Gottlieb, will open on Broadway on Oct. 18, and Joe Hardy will be its director. Who will be its stars? Mr. Gottlieb, the producer, says the ideal stars would have been Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn. while Mr. Slade, the playwright, says he would have been happy with Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne. But will Romantic

title: Gulf Unit Seeks 30% Of Taiwan Concern
description: The Gulf Oil Chemicals Company, a division of the Gulf Oil Corporation, anthat it planned to purchase a 30 percent equity interest to the Taita Chemical Company of Taiwan.

title: Pilot Says Extending Landing Gear Was Near Last Resort to Stop Dive
description: INGLEWOOD. Calif., April 12 Trans World Airlines pilot whose Boeing 727 went into a twisting plunge over Michigan April 4 testified today that was only when he saw the moon glowing in the distance that he knew with certainty that he had pulled out of the perilous dive.

title: KOCH BUDGET UPSET ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: New York City's municipal hospital system was ordered yesterday to add 7,700 employees to Federal Social Security coverage, which will require retroactive payments of $38 million for the period from 1975 through last year. It was also directed to keep 20,000 previously covered employees in the program at a cost this year of $35 million.

title: Stage: Public's Nasty Rurnors
description: FOR Susan Miller's new play, very appropriately entitled Nasty Rumors and Final Remarks, the Old Prop Shop stage at the Public Theater has been divided into white antiseptic corridors.

title: Invaders Establish Control in Kampala and Call on All Ugandans to Hunt Amin
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 12  As Tanzanianled troops consolidated their hold on Kampala, the capital of Uganda, Tanzania quickly announced recognition today of a new Ugandan Government made up of exiles from the rule of President Idi Amin.

title: Events and Openings
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA. Lincoln Center. Bellini's Norma, 8.

title: Where to Take the Kids For the Easter Holidays
description: From Central Park's manicured Shakespeare Garden, with its tiny walks and blossoming pink and white tulip tree, to Connecticut's acres of wooded glens and trails, children and their parents can enjoy one of nature's grandest shows of all, the arrival of spring. The timing is perfect for the school vacation period.

title: Dance: Andy deGroat, Chic in Brooklyn
description: ANDY deGROAT's new Red Notes, seen on Thursday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Lepercq Space, has all the accouterments of chic. There's a score by the experimental trance music composer Philip Glass. A spoken Gertrude Stein text also serves as accompaniment. There's a Lucite altar and even a meltdown dance. Dancers puff on occasional cigarettes. Several shoes are thrown onstage from the wings. There are dabs of dervish spinning, an experimental form perfected by Mr. deGroat, a former member of the Robert Wilson theatrical commune, and by the avantgarde choreographer Laura Dean.

title: GEORGE TILLER DIES; EXJUSTICE WAS 79
description: George Tilzer, a former justice in the Appelate Division of New York State Supreme Court, died Tuesday in his Manhattan apartment after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Auctions
description: AMERICAN art sales have almost as large a following in this country these days as auctions of modern and Impressionist paintings. So a sale next Friday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, is bound to stir more excitement than usual. The occasion, billed as one of the finest sales of American art in many years and the most important auction of its kind not from a single owner, offers a previously unknown work by William Harnett, the 19thcentury trompe l'oeil artist, who fooled the eye with great skill, and a recordbreaking Eastman Johnson oil, Washington Crossing the Delaware. The Harnett novelty, Still Life With Violin, is dated 1885 and was painted in Paris, where it was purchased in the late 1800's by Charles James Hook, father of the consignor. The oil painting on panel is a tightly conceived, far more detailed gem of this genre than two other Harnett still lifes in the sale. In addition, the presale estimate of $100,000 to $150,000 reflects both the $100,000 to $150,000 reflects both the work's importance and the fact that it was previously unrecorded. The other Harnetts are expected to bring at most $40,000 and $50,000.

title: Moody's Reduces Chrysler Ratings
description: Moody's Investors Service lowered its ratings of the Chrysler Corporation's debentures and commercial paper yesterday, citing the auto manufacturer's recent adverse operating results.

title: Police Assert L.I. Man Kidnapped Wife, 26, Who Managed to Flee
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 12  Frank Cossano, a 31-year-old salesman from Valley Stream, L.I., was released in his own custody today after being charged on Wednesday with the kidnapping of his estranged wife, Margaret, 26.

title: Long Island College Builds New Image
description: OLD WESTBURY. L.I.  The old stories linger about the State University College here. There's the one about the student who received one semester's credit for writing a poem on lovemaking, another about the student whose project was called Creative Candle Making and the one about the students who earned credit for planning the college itself.

title: Modified Sentences for Croatians in 1976 Explosion Stir Bitterness
description: Lieut. Terence McTigue yesterday underwent what he thinks was his 13th operation  his count is no longer sure since a bomb planted by Croatian terrorists in a Grand Central Terminal locker almost three years ago exploded in his face, leaving him halfblind and permanently disfigured.

title: Chinese Army Quintet Beats U.S. Team, 7269
description: PEKING, April 12 (UPI)  The Chinese army basketball team, with its 7foot2inch center, Mu Tezi, forcing the Americans to shoot from outside, defeated a United States allstar team, 7269, today before 18,000 spectators.

title: From Teacher to Uganda Leader
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 12  When Yusufu K. Lule left his home in London last month, he told his wife he expected to be away for a few days. Now, as chairman of the executive committee of the Uganda National Liberation Front, the 67yearold Mr. Lule has emerged as the leader of the new Government proclaimed in Kampala. And, as he puts it, three or four days has now been extended for I don't know how long.

title: Harlem Club Cyclists Following Path To Olympic Competition
description: Early most Sunday mornings, intense young riders from the Harlem Cycle Club tear around the roadways of Central Park in a training program geared to prepare them for international amateur competition.

title: S. Valentine Mitchell, 82, Is Dead; A Novelist, Poet and Playwright
description: S. Valentine Mitchell, an author and poet, died Monday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. She was 82 years old.

title: Arms Pact Friends and Foes Rally for Senate Battle
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Not long ago, a State Department Soviet affairs expert named Sherrod McCall visited Cincinnati and sought to persuade the World Affairs Council there of the virtues of the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union. Later in the day he promoted the treaty with the editorial board of The Cincinnati Enquirer and viewers of a local television show.

title: Malcolm Johnson, 80, An Orchestra Leader
description: Malcolm Johnson, an orchestra leader, died Tuesday at his home in Long Branch, N.J. He was 80 years old.

title: A Rare Gorky And Prints Of Prendergast
description: ONE of the most appealing classics of American painting in the present century is the double portrait of The Artist and His Mother by Arshile Gorky that reposes in the permanent collection of the Whitney Museum of American Art. In this painting are conjoined many of the emotions that gave Gorky's life its special quality. There is the element family piety  the picture is based on a photograph taken when Gorky was a boy newly arrived in America from Armenia  and there is the deep love of painting that for the mature Gorky was the governing passion of his existence. It is a painting that sings.

title: Baltimore's Clipper Ship Reported Missing at Sea
description: BALTIMORE, April 12 (AP)  The twomasted wooden schooner Pride of Baltimore was missing at sea today with a seasoned captain and a crew of 10 sailors. But city officials said they hoped the incident was just an echo of a hazard that has always plagued sailing ships  the whim of the weather.

title: Stocks Slip in Slow PreHoliday Trading
description: Shares of Cyprus Mines jumped sharply yesterday in response to a takeover agreement, and numerous other issues responded to firstquarter earnings reports, as the stock market closed slightly lower in slower trading.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  On the ground of enhancing a tree exchange of ideas, the United States last week waived its rules and allowed a high official of the Palestine Liberation Organization into the country. It turned out that the official, Shafik alHout, had to agree not to make any public statements during his threeweek trip.

title: Art: Twombly Writ On Whitney Walls
description: WHEN is the writing on the wall not bad news? When it's by Cy Twombly.
