Belshazzar may have lost his appetite when he saw what was interrrupting his dinner, but when Cy Twombly does the writing, it portends nothing but happiness, even if he is a master of the poignant quotation from authors elsewhere given up for dead.

title: New System Urged in Presidential Primary Voting
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  A 38yearold political scientist is trying to persuade New Hampshire to change its election laws so that voters in the 1980 Presidential primary can register their support for more than one candidate of the same party.

title: Bridge:
description: A list of women players who have won two regional pair titles in one New York weekend would be a very short list indeed. It became slightly longer in Hempstead, L.I., a week ago when Rozanne Mimi of New York, a talented young player who is a sociologist by profession, won both the women's pairs and open pairs championships on consecutive days. The diagramed deal il- lustrates her considerable skill in card play.

title: Jazz: MainieriBernhardt
description: MIKE MAINIERI, vibraphonist, and Warren Bernhardt, pianist, have been recording and performing as a duo for several months now. They will be at the Bottom Line on Monday and Tuesday, opening for John Abercrombie. Earlier this week, they were at Seventh Avenue South. Both men display considerable facility on their instruments and their work together generates some surprises, for, despite their occasional associations with fusion and studio work, they are essentially mainstream players, at home with standards and samba and bluesily classical material that recalls the Modern Jazz Quartet.

title: As Recess Begins, Many in Congress Fly to China, Europe and Africa
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Melvin H. Evans could have had a nice free Easter trip to the lovely Virgin Islands. But instead Mr. Evans, the Republican who represents the islands in Congress, boarded an Air Force jet this morning for Peking.

title: Rangers Top Kings To Sweep Playoff
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 12  Phil Esposito of the the Rangers scored the tying and winning goals, the latter in overtime, tonight as New York defeated the Los Angeles Kings, 21, to sweep its two-of-three game National Hockey League playoff series.

title: Notes on People
description: The touring company of First Monday in October has had to close in Chicago because Henry Fonda had to withdraw as the star with what was described as an acute condition in the left hip which is totally incapacitating. Mr. Fonda had been eager to continue even on crutches or in a wheelchair, he said, and the producers and director were plotting new staging to accommodate that possibility.

title: New York Bank Loans Up $168 Million in Week
description: Commercial and industrial loans on the books of the major New York banks rose $168 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the comparable week last year, the increase amounted to only $13 million.

title: About Real Estate
description: In an example of what might be called impact rehabilitation, a builder is restoring abandoned buildings that fill nearly the entire south side of a block of Harlem's West 135th Street and is turning them into modern apartments.

title: Amtrak Testing a New Engine
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)  Amtrak said today that it was testing a new Frenchbuilt turbine engine that gets 41 percent more power than engines now used in Amtrak's turboliner trains. The engine would allow Amtrak to use one engine instead of two to power its turbine trains, resulting in a 25 percent fuel saving. The new engines arebuilt by the Turbomeca concern of Brevets. France.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: ART (GR37914)

title: Old Williamsburg Is Given Plantation of Rockefellers
description: A 545acre plantation with a twostory 18thcentury home, gardens and outbuildings has been given to the Colonial Williamsburg historic restoration project in Virginia as a result of the will of John D. Rockefeller 3d, who died in an automobile accident last July.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Fantasy in D minor (K. 397), Mozart; Six Dances and the Bransle tie Baurgogne, Gervaise; Sonata for 2 Organs in D, Danzi.

title: Canada Prices Show 1.2% Rise
description: OTTAWA, April 12 (UPI)  Higher food prices last month increased the cost of living by 1.2 percent in Canada and raised the annual inflation rate to 9.2 percent, Statistics Canada reported today. The Government agency said in its consumer price index for March that higher food prices accounted for about half the latest increase.

title: Carlson Gets 92.6% Of Wasko Gold
description: The Carlson Companies said it had squired 92.6 percent of the Wasko Gold Products Corporation's outstanding stock as a result of a tender offer scheduled to expire at the close of business yesterday.Carlson noted, however, that the offer was being extended to May 2 with terms remaining unchanged at $13 a share net in cash. As a result of the tender offer and previous purchases of Wasko stock from principal shareholders, Carlson said it now held about 1.3 million shares, with about 105,000 shares remaining outstanding.

title: Around the City on an April Day
description: New York City has many things to offer to residents and visitors alike. At the Central Park Zoo a newborn zebra stayed close to its mother as she contentedly munched on hay. Downtown, members of the Salvation Army band performed on the steps of Federal Hall in the Wall Street area. Waiting for the matinee of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus to begin was Harry Neimeth, a retired radio newsman now living in Florida, who was joined by nine of his 13 grandchildren.

title: RolePlaying Is Used as Therapy To Treat the Sexual Aggressor
description: With the aid of roleplaying, video-taping and therapists acting out vignettes of good social behavior between men and women, a federally financed research unit has been working with habitual rapists and child molesters in an effort to treat their sexual aggression.

title: Jazz Ron Carter Quartet
description: A NEW subterranean jazz club opened this week in a room at Third Avenue and 17th Street that has a long tradition of conviviality. It is currently the Downstairs Room at Tuesday's, the bar and restaurant on the street level, and, for its jazz incarnation. is being called Fat Tuesday's, a dose translation of Mardi Gras. For many years the room was a focal point for college beer drinkers, known as Joe King's Rathskeller during World War II and, before that, as simply The GermanAmerican.

title: Afghan Grave Said to Rival Tut's
description: MOSCOW. April 12 (UPI)  An ancient royal burial ground in north Afghanistan has yielded thousands of pieces of gold and jewelry that may rival the treasures of King Tutankhamun.

title: Maxwell M. Lochs, Former Aide Of American Jewish Congress
description: Maxwell M. Luchs, former director of welfare funds for the American Jewish Congress died Tuesday at Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 86 years old and a resident of Queens.

title: Life Drug Terms for 4 Commuted
description: ALBANY, April 12  Governor Carey today commuted the sentences of four state prison inmates serving life sentences for drugrelated crimes.

title: A Paschal Supper in the Ecumenical Spirit
description: When several of her Jewish co-workers discussed plans for Passover, Alejandro Solera may have startled them by disclosing that she, too, would be attending a seder of sorts  organized by the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Quarterly Net Rose 11.2% At Chemical New York
description: The Chemical New York Corporation yesterday reported firstquarter operating earnings of $30.7 million, an 11.2 percent increase over its operating earnings in the comparable period of 1978. Chemical New York is the parent holding company for the Chemical Bank, the nation's sixthlargest commercial bank.

title: Money
description: THURSDAY. APRIL 12, 1979

title: John and Yankees Stymie Orioles, 50
description: BALTIMORE, April 12  The Yankees and Orioles finally played an unhysterical baseball game tonight, with Tommy John methodically pitching New York to a 50 victory.

title: New Curbs On Lending Abroad Set
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  The Comptroller of the Currency approved today a formal interpretation of the law that places a limit on lending by national banks to foreign governments, their agents and statecontrolled entities.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The international trade liberalization agreement will slow inflation, reduce the massive trade deficit and increase employment this country, American negotiators said. President Carter called the pact the most farreaching and comprehensive trade agreement in three decades. [Page D1.]

title: 1/365th of the Year for President Jefferson, Too
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  Today is Thomas Jefferson's birthday, a state holiday in Alabama. Banks and libraries are closed and government employees have the day off with pay to relax or to work on the state tax forms due Monday. A few will reread a document of taxpayer rebellion, America's Declaration of Independence, principally the work of Jefferson.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: Source American Petroleum Institute

title: Russian Dance At the Beacon
description: SIXTEEN years ago, when Mikhail Godenko moved Krasnayarsk to start his own folk dance company that Siberian city, he had to go as far afield as Moscow and Leningrad for his dancers. But he found them, and this weekend the Krasnayarsk Dance Company of Siberia may be seen at the Beacon Theater, one of seven companies participating in Mr. Godenko's Festival of Russian Dance.

title: 2 ASTRONAUTS LAND AFTER LINKUP FAILS
description: MOSCOW, April 12 (AP)  The Soviet and a Bulgarian astronaut team returned safely to earth tonight after aborting an attempted linkup with an orbiting space laboratory, the Moscow radio reported.

title: Screen: 'Love at First Bite,' Dracula's 'Plaza Suite':Full-Blooded Humor
description: QUITE unexpectedly, George Hamilton's Dracula turns out to be  pardon the expression  a scream. Mr. Hamilton's knack for comedy has been a well-kept secret until now, but he's certainly funny in "Love at First Bite," a coarse, delightful little movie with a bang-up cast and no pretensions at all. "Love at First Bite" opens today at the National, Loew's Cine and other theaters.Poor Dracula! As the story begins, he is forced to leave his Transylvanian home. The Rumanian government has designated his castle a training center for young gymnasts, and a delegation warns that "In 48 hours we'll be back with trampolines, parallel bars, swings and Nadia Comaneci. Don't be here." So off he goes to New York, accompanied by his small, faithful servant, played by Arte Johnson. They take up residence at the Plaza Hotel, where Dracula sleeps in his coffin by day and his servant  who feeds on live insects  glumly watches Raid commercials on television.The premise of Robert Kaufman's screenplay, which contains both good jokes and awful jokes but is never slow, is that New York has gotten jaded since Dracula was last heard from. He doesn't scare anybody any more  except for one man, who sees the vampire in his bat incarnation and is reminded of his first wife. But Dracula isn't interested in frightening people this time, partly because Mr. Hamilton is so caught up in the fashion-plate aspect of the role and partly because he's supposed to be in love, with a Very Famous Model (played by Susan St. James). She likes him because he's kinky. At this model's apartment, about which she casually remarks "I hate housework, it killed my mother," the refrigerator contains champagne, two dead gardenias and a kitten.Complications ensue, since the model already has a boyfriend, who also happens to be her psychiatrist. Played hilariously by Richard Benjamin, the psychiatrist embarks upon a one-man campaign to warn New York that a vampire is haunting its discos and hot spots. New York is not impressed.Stan Dragoti, previously an advertising executive, directs with a lot of bluster. The timing between sequences is occasionally shaky, though, and it's too bad the concluding car chase, which is supposed to take place in New York, was so evidently filmed in California. Sometimes tackiness works to the film's advantage, however. If you're going to show a bat on screen, it might as well be a silly-looking stuffed bat suspended from obvious wires.Some of the film's ethnic jokes skate by on very thin ice. They seem witless rather than mean-spirited, but that's not much of an excuse."Love At First Bite" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains a few humorous sexual references and some comically colorful language, mostly from the model played by Miss Saint James.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A client represented by Kidder, Peabody & Company and Goldman, Sachs & Company was incorrectly identified yesterday in an article in Business Day. The two investment banking firms are jointly representing the F. W. Woolworth Company.

title: Art People
description: FROM the anxiety front comes news that making art is at least as dangerous as eating, drinking and breathing. Creativity can, depending on its medium, lead to aplastic anemia, silicosis, cancer, various kinds of poisoning and lesser complaints.

title: Steinbrenner Quits Policy Unit
description: In an apparent bid for more freedom of expression, George Steinbrermer resigned yesterday as a member of major league baseball's influential Executive Committee. He wag appointed to the group only last ober.

title: AFGHAN INSURGENCY THREATENING REGIME
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 12  A spreading armed rebellion in various parts of Afghanistan is seriously challenging the country's yearold, strongly proSoviet Government.

title: M.T.A. Rules Out 25 Transfers
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority cannot finance a 25cent transfer program on its own and does not know of available Federal funds to do it, its chairman said yesterday. It therefore would be a hoax on the public to institute such a program now, according to Harold L. Fisher, the authority chairman. He said current estimates placed its cost at $30 million a year.

title: Marcos's Imprisoned Rival: A Growing Embarrassment
description: MANILA, April 12  He has become a meticulous housekeeper, a bookworm, a poet, and a hotplate gourmet  the habits a man develops living alone under guard in a windowless room in a military cornpound for 2,392 days.

title: Trade Pact Seen Paring Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  American negotiators said today that the sweeping agreement to liberalize trade signed in Geneva today would mean slower inflation, a reduction in the huge trade deficit and increased employment for the United States.

title: What Now for Rhodesia?
description: Like the internal settlement of which it is a part, the.election that began in Rhodesia this week is biracial but segregated. Whites alone ratified the constitution creating a new national assembly. They and other minorities voted last week to fill 28 assembly seats. Blacks will vote next week for 72 representatives assigned to them.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table accompanying the Taxes column in Business Day Wednesday gave an incorrect figure for employees' taxable income under the net salary method of paying Social Security taxes. The correct amount is $9,962.

title: Appeal Planned on Bomb Article
description: MADISON, Wis., April 13 (AP)  The Progressive magazine has filed notice that it will appeal a Federal District Court decision barring the publication of an article on the hydrogen bomb.

title: Shindig Rollicks in 60's
description: Packaging the popular music of the 1960's as nostalgia is not going to be easy. But some of the difficulty of the project hasn't prevented several attempts, the latest of which, Shindig, opened Thursday evening Downstairs at City Center, 131 West 55th Street.

title: Stadium Workers Support Umpires
description: PITTSBURGH, April 13 (AP)  Leaders of 40 service unions, whose members work at Three Rivers Stadium, threw their moral support behind the National League baseball umpire's work stoppage tonight.

title: Nunez Upsets Siegler, 76, 63
description: EDGEWATER, N.J. Apri1 13 Hugo Nunez of Rockaway scored the biggest upset of the 12th annual Easter Bowl junior tennis championships today by defeating David Siegler of Hidden Hills, Calif., last year's winner, in the third round of the boys 18 division of the tournament at the Binghamton Racquet Club.

title: Bridge:
description: In many competitive activities, and perhaps in life, there is a sound general rule: If things seem to be going badly, try to do something different that will enable you to escape impending ruin. In bridge, a defender will sometimes be able to judge that the declarer is coasting home and that some imaginative effort is needed.

title: Deaths
description: MACDONOUGHCornelia (nee Ruhland). Services Saturday 10 AM at St. Mary's, Classon Willoughby& Aves, Brooklyn.

title: Police and Pilot Units Oppose Modified Sentences for Croatian Hijackers
description: The New York City policemen's union and the international airline pilots' association joined yesterday in denouncing a Federal judge who agreed to modify the sentences of four Croatian terrorists, making them eligible for parole next Dec. 31. The four had been sentenced to 30years to life for hijacking a jetliner on Sept. 10, 1976, and for planting a bomb that killed one policeman and maimed another.

title: Solaris Dances 2 by Henry Smith
description: The stage was littered with impalpable artifacts of other cultures on Thursday when Solaris, a theaterdance company, appeared at the Dalton School in two works by its director, Henry Smith. Mr. Smith has been bitten by the mythological approach of the choreographer Jean Erdman, with whom he once worked. Martialarts movement and the stylization and ritual aspects of traditional Japanese theater have influenced him. And there is a strain of American moderndance technique, possibly from his days with Anna Sokolow. But none of these influences appear to have gone much below the skin.

title: Players' Association Calls N.A.S.L. Strike
description: The North American Soccer League Players Association called a strike against the owners yesterday, but all 24 clubs scheduled to play today and tonight announced plans to stage their games.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: EARNINGS
description: The Honda Motor Company, a major Japanese automobile producer and the world's largest motorcycle manufacturer, yesterday reported an 8.6 percent decline in profits in the fiscal year ended Feb. 28, despite an 8.6 percent gain in sales. The results are for the parent company only.

title: Private Jobs for the Public Good
description: David Mahoney, chairman of the Norton Simon Company, a conglomerate that includes such wellknown companies as Avis car rental, Max Factor cosmetics and Hunt's foods, wants to do something about the alarming rate of joblessness among minority youths. His company will hire 250 unemployed young people, increasing Norton Simon's work force by one percent. And Mr. Mahoney is urging other major firms to do likewise. By his estimate, the effort could generate 200,000 new jobs, substantially reducing unemployment among black youths before the summer dog days are upon us.

title: Entertainment Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Wagner's Parsitat. 1; Tchaikovsky's Eugen Onegin, 8.

title: Teacher Faces Ouster After Assigning Study Of Brave New World
description: MATHEWS, Va., April 13 (AP)  A teacher who asked his 11thgrade students to write book reports on Aldous Huxley's Brave New World, a novel first published in 1932, said today he was being dismissed because of the assignment.

title: City Challenges Social Security On Order to Pay
description: City officials said yesterday that they would ask for a review of a decision by the Social Security Administration that would require the continuing coverage of 20,000 municipal hospital employees as well as add coverage for 7,700 others the city believes are not eligible for benefits.

title: Warning on Meltdown Causes a Belated Scare
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (AP) Startled television viewers flooded WKBSTV here with telephone calls today after an inadvertent broadcast of a twoweekold special report warning of the possibility of a meltdown at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant near Harrisburg.

title: A.T.&T. Trying to Lift Morale
description: Craig Hinckle came drifting into the phone system 18 years ago, in search of a direction for his life. He had dropped out of college because of complications after an appendectomy and was kicking around, just spinning my wheels.His father was a phone worker and told him that it was a good outfit, to give it a try. He applied and was hired. The pieces began to fit into place.

title: It's Good to Rein In and Be Creative
description: STONY BROOK, L.I.  I think we have become much more creative in the kinds of things we do, said Thomas E. Brownworth, a mathematics teacher at the Stony Brook School in this pleasant community on Long Island's North Shore.

title: Your Money
description: THE annual migration season for mobile Americans is almost here and millions of families are preparing to uproot and move to new homes.

title: 22 Die in Thai BusTruck Crash
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, April 13 (UPI)  A headon crash between a bus and a rice truck killed 22 people on their way to traditional Buddhist new year celebrations, the police said today.

title: T.W.A. Names Ogilvy To $30 Million Account
description: Ogilvy & Mather International has been named to handle the worldwide, $30 million advertising account of Trans World Airlines, a spokesman for the carrier said yesterday.

title: Dedicated Nuclear Worker Goes the Limit on Radiation
description: HARRISBURG, Pa. April 11  Ron Fountain, 41 years old, lives quietly with his wife and children, a settled man who likes to fish and garden when not working at the plant. He is also a cautious man, who shuddered when he heard about the tank car that derailed in Florida this week, spreading chemical fumes. He says he would not allow his family to live close to aging railroad tracks.

title: Shah Calls Executions Barbarism
description: MIAMI, April 13  The Shah of Iran, breaking silence for the first time since he went into exile, expressed sorrow and revulsion today over the execution of former aides by the Islamic revolutionaries now holding power in his homeland.

title: Lundquist Sets Mark In 200 BreastStroke
description: MONTEREY PARK, Calif., April 13  Two days ago, Steve Lundquist deeply dented the notion that success comes only from hard work. Tonight, he demolished it.

title: Uganda Regime Assumes Office Amid Jubilation
description: KAMPALA, April 13  Yusufu K. Lule's new provisional Government assumed office here this afternoon, with pledge for a rule of law and an expression of gratitude to Tanzania, which helped overthrow the regime of Idi Amin.

title: Deaths
description: ADAMOFF Cecille beloved wife of the late Dr. Leonid Adamoff. Dear cousin & friend of Tamara Kostellanetz. Services Sunday, April 15, 12:45pm Riverside 76th St &Am>sterdam Ave.

title: Outside Engineers Urged in Oil Audits
description: The trade association for the nation's certified public accountants has recommended that auditors rely on the opinion of independent engineers when they audit the oil and gas reserve information in the financial statements of oil companies.

title: Kentucky Suspends 8 Players
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 13  Eight players, five of them projected as regulars on the University of Kentucky's football team next fall, have been suspended for one year because of violations of dormitory rules.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Industrial production climbed eighttenths of 1 percent in March, the strongest performance of 1979, the Federal Reserve Board reported. Recovering from the effects of bad weather, the gain was led by a rebound in automobiles, steel and coal. While reflecting stronger overall activity, the sharply higher figures added to the Administration's concern that the economy is not slowing fast enough. The Fed indicated it was considering new plans to restrain economic activity by increasing the cost of bank credit. [29.]

title: POPE, AT COLOSSEUM, SPEAKS OF MARTYRS
description: ROME, April 13  Pope John Paul II in a Good Friday rite near the Colosseum tonight carried a wooden cross, and in a homily compared presentclay believers suffering hardship because of their faith to the early Christian martyrs.

title: Queens Cloth Cutter Proves He's a Baronet
description: Jean Ivor Dunbar  of the Long Island City Dunbars, that is  has just had a new calling card printed up.

title: White Sox Homers Rout Yanks
description: CHICAGO, April 13  On the Yankees' flight from Baltimore early this morning, a voice in the back of the plane called out confidently, We're gonna be nasty in Chicago.

title: Possible Role of Mideast Agents In Toulon Reactor Blast Studied
description: LASEYNESURMER, France, April 13 (Reuters)  The French security forces are investigating the possibility that Mideast agents were responsible for explosions that wrecked nuclear reactor equipment in the Mediterranean port of Toulon a week ago, informed sources said today.

title: Rain Hinders Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13  Thundershowers interrupted the second round of the 93d Masters for two hours today, forcing tournament officials to improvise a catchup schedule for tomorrow and possibly for Sunday  depending on the weather.

title: Telephone Rate Decision Termed Stopgap
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  One of the principal beneficiaries of a Federal Communications Commission decision affecting longdistance telephone rates said today that it was only an interim solution to the problem of competing with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: James Naughton Dead; American Jesuit Official
description: ROME, April 13 (AP)  The Rev. James Naughton, a leading American in the Society of Jesus headquarters here, died in a hospital today, a Jesuit spokesman announced. He was 64 years old.

title: Fed Move Held Peril For Credit
description: A reduction in the availability of credit to finance business and consumers may result from the Federal Reserve Board's proposals to apply reserve requirements to certain nondeposit funds, banking analysts said yesterday after examining the central bank's announcement.

title: More Pay, No More Private Schools
description: In the last five years Elizabeth and William Wells have solved some of the problems inflation was creating for them.

title: Of Inflation, Heads And Hearts
description: President Carter made it official a few months ago, but we really didn't need the Government to tell us that the most pressing and depressing issue in this country is inflation, though even inflation has its beneficial effects. I've been told it enables Americans to live in more expensive neighborhoods without the trouble and expense of having to move.

title: A New Easter Bonnet: No Restrictions Upon It
description: They said the jig was up for Easter bonnets. Only a dumb bunny would wear one, they said. But what did they know? This week, for the first time in ages, a number of bright young women were seen buying what once was called an Easter bonnet, not that they would use the term.

title: Deaths
description: GREENFIELDCharles Congregation EmmanuEl of the city of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member Charles Greenfield. To his family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May his memory be for an eternal blessing. Maxwell M. Rabb. Pres. Herbert C. Barnard, Secy

title: U.S. Said to Plan a Superambassador for the Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  The Carter Administration intends to choose a prominent public figure as a super ambassador to handle Middle East negotiations, officials said today.

title: Army Is Trying to Reverse Drop in Strength of Reserves
description: The Army is making a vigorous but thus far marginally successful effort to bolster the Reserves, which need more than half a million soldiers to reach full strength.

title: GAS PUMP SHUTDOWN STIRS TOURISM FEARS
description: As the springsummer season of tourism and holiday driving begins this Easter weekend, there is less and less gasoline in the country's service station pumps. Thousands of stations are closing on Sundays and almost as many close early on Saturdays.

title: Radio
description: 89, WNCN. Six German Dances witth Trios (K. 509)), Mozart; French Dances for Lute, Ballard; Konzertstuck in F, Weber; Toccata and Fugue in D minor. Bach; Sonata No. 12, Marcello.

title: Congress and Its Fiscal Role
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  The Congressional effort to assume responsibility for the Federal budget is a lot like Samuel Johnson's dog walking upright: It is not done well, but you are surprised to find it done at all.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI)  The Supreme Court today unanimously terminated an eightday stay of execution that saved the condemned murderer John Louis Evans 3d from the electric chair in Alabama.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NYC  1930's The photography display is a modest one, the kind you might expect to happen upon inside a Greenwich Village store  30 vintage photographs of New York, in black and white and sepia, neatly mounted on a brick wall. Stand there a moment and they will get you, and you'll be moving in closer to study the clear details and artistic perspectives of these vignettes from the past.

title: U.S. Is Seeking To End Outlays In Olympic Aid
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  The Carter Administration has quietly agreed to contribute $7 million to $11 million more to help bail out the deficitplagued 1980 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid, N.Y., on the condition that New York State or the local sponsors cover the balance of the cost overruns.

title: George Marton, Literary Agent In Europe and the United States
description: George Marton, a literary agent in this country and in Europe, died of cancer in Los Angeles yesterday. He was 80 years old.

title: Cunningham Company Schedules 4 Dance Events
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company will present four evenings of events, dances made up of excerpts from a wide range of works by Mr. Cunningham, next Saturday and on April 22, 28 and 29 at the Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune Street.

title: Clark Sets Hurdles Record In C.W. Post Relay Meet
description: GREENVALE, L.I. April 13 Randy Clark of Adelphi shattered the meet record for the 400meter hurdles today in the seventh annual C.W. Post College Relay Carnival at Hickox Field.

title: Man Freed Again, on Bond
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire denounced Judge Bruce McM. Wright yesterday for attacking the Police Department and suggesting its police officers were racists and killers.

title: Merger Order for 2 Tennessee Campuses Is Upheld
description: NASHVILLE, April 13  A Federal District Court order to merge two stateoperated university campuses in Nashville, one mostly white and the other predominantly black, was affirmed today by a 2-to-1 vote of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth District.

title: Arab Envoys in Athens Complain Over the Showing of Holocaust
description: ATHENS, April 13 (Reuters)  Ambassadors from Arab countries except Egypt have complained to Greece about the showing of the television series Holocaust, an authoritative source said today.

title: 3 Korea Bank. Chiefs Are Ousted
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 13 (AP)  The presidents of three commercial banks were dismissed today and placed under criminal investigation on charges of graft in connection with the recent bankruptcy of the Yulsan Group. a big conglomerate.

title: Racism Protest Slated Over Title of Art Show
description: In the wake of a controversial show by a white artist entitled The Nigger Drawings, a group of artists, art historians and their supporters will stage a demonstration today at Artists Space, a nonprofit, publicly financed gallery at 105 Hudson Street.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, April 14

title: Michael McKinley Sillerman, 79, A Retired TV Program Executive
description: Michael McKinley Sillerman, a retired former president of Television Programs of America, a forerunner of I.T.C. Entertainment, the movie and television programdistributing concern, died Wednesday at his Manhattan residence in the Dover Hotel. He was 79 years old.

title: TAXPAYERS IGNORING CAMPAIGN CHECKOFF
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Despite its being at the top of the tax form and despite televised endorsements from Eric Sevareid, the retired CBS commentator, the Presidential Election Campaign Fund is being ignored by more and more taxpayers this year.

title: 76ers Eliminate Nets In Playoffs, 111 to 101
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., April 13  The New Jersey Nets' first venture into the National Basketball Association playoffs ended tonight in quick elimination.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON AN inventor in Florida has developed an electromagnetic water purification system that separates minerals and other solids by causing them to fall into a series of tanks. The apparatus is offered to cleanse water from rivers and ponds for irrigation and to provide material for fill. It can also be used in homes.

title: Richard Anthony Leonard, 79, A Radio Programmer for NBC
description: Richard Anthony Leonard, who had been a radio programmer for the National Broadcasting Company and was associated for many years with the production of the NBC Symphony of the Air, died Thursday at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 79 years old.

title: The School Nurse: Beyond the BandAid
description: DENVER  She was once a seldomseen figure in starched white whose work was limited to applying BandAids to scraped knees, examining small heads for lice once a year and receiving parents' notes when children returned from a prolonged absence.

title: Parish Outraged by Crime Reenacts Passion of Jesus
description: JERSEY CITY, April 13  The bells high in the steeple of All Saints Roman Catholic Church began tolling at 9 A.M., summoning worshipers to a reenactment of Jesus' torture and death, a reenactment that would follow a path through the poor and crimeridden streets of the Lafayette section of this old riverfront city.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Brascan Ltd., a Canadian concern attempting to buy the F.W. Woolworth Company, told its stockholders in a letter yesterday that the Brazilian Government had paid the final $170 million installment due on its $380 million purchase of Brascan's utility operations in Brazil.

title: Nader Asks CarSafety Guarantee
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI)  The General Motors Corporation has asked dealers to repair nine defects in its new front-wheel-drive cars before the new models go on sale next week.

title: Siberia Is a Place for Roughing It, and Getting Rich Quick
description: BERKAKIT, U.S.S.R.  For centuries, Siberia was built largely with the labor of political prisoners and exiles  a land of death and chains, Maxim Gorky once called it.

title: George Marton, Literary Agent In Europe and the United States
description: George Marton, a literary agent in this country and in Europe, died of cancer in Los Angeles yesterday. He was 80 years old.

title: Bobby Bland Blues Have Swing
description: Bobby (Blue) Bland has never attained the broadbased success of such other blues artists as B.B. King and Muddy Waters. Nor is he quite venerable enough (he was born in 1930) or overtly funky enough to appeal to the usual sort of bluesnostalgia audiences. But he remains one of the finer blues singers around.

title: The Sucker Factor
description: WASHINGTON  The time has come to bring an end to the politics of selfishness.

title: A Love Canal Warning No One Can Recall
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., April 12 After a former official of the Hooker Chemical and Plastics Company told a Congressional subcommittee that local school officials had been warned in 1958

title: Mrs. Reid, Quarterfinal Victor, Seeks Elusive Winning Touch
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., April 13  She has always been around the fringe, a shot or two from the top. But this weekend, Kerry Reid is wondering if maybe the winning touch finally has arrived.

title: Atlanta Advances In Playoffs
description: ATLANTA, April 13 (AP)  Terry Furlow, a reserve, sparked an Atlanta rally in the fourth quarter, and the Hawks went on to beat Houston, 10091, tonight. The loss eliminated the Rockets from the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: Japan Imports Increase 19.2%
description: TOKYO, April 13 (AP)  Japan's licensed imports in March totaled $9.36 billion, a rise of 19.2 percent from February and 31.9 percent from the yearearlier month, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry announced today.

title: PRETRIAL DETENTION STIRS INDIA PROTESTS
description: With India's courts clogged with millions of cases, nearly 110,000 of the 185,000 people currently in Indian jails are awaiting court action. About half of these wait years for trial, and large numbers are too poor to put up bail.

title: Oil Activity Picking Up in Southeast Asia
description: SINGAPORE  After a threeyear slump, petroleum exploration and production are on the rise again in Southeast Asia. But oil industry officials based here say a return to the boom days of the early 1970's is highly unlikely. They forecast only modest growth.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, April 13 (UPI)  China accused Vietnam today of sending armed vessels to the disputed Paracel Islands in the South China Sea, and said that Vietnamese craft opened fire on a Chinese patrol boat.

title: News Summary
description: Rhodesian commandos were sent into Zambia and Botswana to attack centers of guerrillas who have vowed to disrupt elections to be held in Rhodesia next week. The attack in Lusaka, Zambia's capital, by commandos disguised as Zambian soldiers, was apparently aimed at capturing or killing the guerrilla leader Joshua Nkomo, who escaped. At least 10 people were reported killed and 12 wounded. [Page 1. Column 6.]

title: The Region
description: SYRACUSE (AP)  About 200 guests were removed safely when fire broke out in the downtown Holiday Inn here.

title: Nimuraat Rites on Wednesday
description: A memorial service will be held next Wednesday for Yeichi Nimuraat at the Buddhist Church of New York, 332 Riverside Drive, at 6:30 P.M. Friends and colleagues of the late modern dancer and founder of the Ballet Arts Studio, who died April 3, will speak at the Buddhist service.

title: Notes on People
description: Not that any more examples are needed to show how bureaucracy flirts with the absurd, but evidence of a singular nature arrived in the case of Andrew Bavas. Mr. Bavas works for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in Chicago, but under a special program he is involved with urban affairs projects at Northwestern University, with H.E.W. paying his $40,000 salary.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Iran Executes More Former Officials
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Saturday, April 14 (AP)  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic courts sent five more officials of the Shah's regime to their deaths early today, the Government radio announced.

title: About Somers
description: SOMERS, N.Y., April 13  There is a certain slowness, as of sowers pausing at the earth, and a curious stare, but then sparks of friendliness from the farm crew  David, Ken, Norman and John  who seed peas, onions and radishes into the broken ground.

title: Offering Broadcast Decontrols In Exchange for Airwaves Fee
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Since the dawn of commercial broadcasting, station operators in this country have never been charged for the use of the airwaves. Complying with the web of Federal regulations that govern the industry has involved considerable expense, of course, but there never has been an explicit fee.

title: U.S. Studies Bank Trade In Dollars
description: The Justice Department has opened a civil investigation into the foreign exchange trading activities of a number of major American banks, including Citibank. the Chase Manhattan Bank, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Bank of America.

title: MAGAZINE LOSES BID AGAINST C.I.A. CURBS
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 13 (AP)  A Federal judge rejected today Oregon Magazine's request that he prevent the Central Intelligence Agency from censoring a humorous article by a former C.I.A. agent about his experiences as a spy in Uganda.

title: ThreeCornered Arms Talks
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  As the United States presses to conclude its controversial arms talks with the Soviet Union, the Carter Administration sometimes appears to be caught in threecornered negotiations  the man in the

title: Life Down in Cajun Country, U.S. of A.
description: James Daisy fishes oysters for nine months of the year. And the rest of the year he traps muskrats. Fiftyyearold Daisy  a Cajun with, as he laughs the loudest, an Irish last name  lives in a remote settlement of Terrebonne Parish, a fertile, good earth section of Louisiana's subtropical delta fan that is larger than the entire state of Rhode Island. He leases a thousand acres of Terrebonne's brackish public lake water bottoms to raise oysters, plus another four hundred acres in partnership with his brother, who lives next door. Together with his son and a nephew, plus three other men, Daisy's oyster crew works two boats eight hours a day, five days a week, in the temperate cycle's best months, March through

title: Women's Drug Ring Called Broken
description: An alleged drugsmuggling ring composed entirely of women, whose couriers were said to have ferried more than $1 million a month in cocaine into the United States, has been smashed with the arrest of 17 suspects in New York and seven others in Bolivia, Federal authorities announced yesterday.

title: Bail Controversy Revived
description: Once again, Judge Bruce McM. Wright has become the target of criticism for an unpopular bail decision. Setting bail when a serious crime has been committed and the suspect appears to be a relatively good bail risk is one the toughest tasks any criminal court judge faces.

title: The City
description: Delivery trucks fanned out from the Elmhurst Milk and Cream Company in Queens with the first milk processed at the dairy since a strike shut down operations seven weeks ago. And tanktrucks carrying 6,000gallon loads of raw milk arrived at the plant for processing before deliveries scheduled for today.

title: Envoy to Caribbean Named
description: BRUNSWICK, Ga., April 13 (AP) President Carter announced today that he was nominating Sally Angela Shelton, a former aide to Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, to be Ambassador to Barbados, Grenada and the new commonwealth of Dominica. A 31yearold native of San Antonio, she will also will serve as the first accredited Minister to St. Lucia if confirmed by the Senate. As envoy to Barbados and Grenada, she is to succeed Frank V. Ortiz Jr., who is being reassigned.

title: Two Suspected Robbers Die In a ShootOut in the Bronx
description: Two of three suspected holdup men were killed and two members of the family they were allegedly seeking to rob were wounded in a shootout in a Bronx apartment building at about noon yesterday, the police said.

title: Communists' Victory in Spanish Village Revives Civil War Memories
description: PARACUELLOS DEL JARAMA, Spain, April 9 History has come full circle in this drab village of a little more than 2,000 people, perched on a steep green bluff that commands a fine view of the big jets coming and going from Barajas Airport at nearby Madrid.

title: Vacationing Carters Visit Beach On a Secluded Island in Georgia
description: SAPELO ISLAND, Ga., April 13 (UPI)  President Carter, vacationing with his family on secluded Sapelo Island, strolled along the beach and walked through the woods yesterday.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, April 13, 1979

title: U.S. Expelling 2 South Africans After Ouster of American Aides
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  The United States ordered two South African military attaches today to leave the country in retaliation for South Africa's expulsion yesterday of three American attaches on charges of having conducted aerial espionage in the American Ambassador's plane.

title: 2 Rights Groups to Seek to Settle Their Differences
description: The top leaderships of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. will meet next month to discuss problems growing out of their competition for funds and for public recognition for winning the Supreme Court decision in 1954 that outlawed segregation in public schools.

title: Angels Oust Stars by 9384
description: HOUSTON, April 13  The Houston Angels advanced to the championship series of the Women's Basketball League by defeating the New York Stars, 9384, tonight in the Eastern Division playoff.

title: The Regional Planners at 50
description: The halfcentury mark has been hitting a lot of 20thcentury institutions lately. Suddenly, such generatons of progress as the Regional Plan Association are finding themselves in their 50th year. This private, volunteer group was established to promote the First Regional Plan in 1929. Since then, it has seen a remarkable number of its prophecies fulfilled and objectives achieved. But the belief in a perfectible world that spurred the association's founding and attracted its trendsetting talents is no longer with us. This is a time of considerably diminished optimism and vastly enlarged problems.

title: Rainstorms in Mississippi Force Train Passengers to Shift to Bus
description: CANTON, Miss., April 13 (UPI)  Amtrak's Chicagobound Panama Limited passenger train was halted by swirling flood waters today in this small central Mississippi town and passengers were put aboard buses to continue their trip north.

title: Brooklyn Tenants Keep A Vigil Against Vandals
description: Radford Petty, who lives in a sixstory apartment building at 985 Park Place in Brooklyn, usually stays up until about A.M. Several times during the night, while his wife and five young sons sleep, he stands silently for a few minutes in the hallway. At other times he peers for long moments out the windows.

title: C. P. Boner, Physicist And Expert on Naval Weaponry, Dies at 79
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 13  Dr. C. Paul Boner, internationally known physicist and acoustical consultant, died here Wednesday. He was 79 years old.

title: Golf's Ed Sneed  That's Sneed
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13  His fiveunderpar 67 had been posted on the scoreboard. With a nineunderpar 135 for two rounds, Ed Sneed was leading the Masters golf tournament. But outside, it was raining. Heavy hard drops were bouncing off the green tin roof of the Quonsethut press room where Ed Sneed was Talking about how some people still confused him with Sam Snead and J.C. Snead, even out on the Augusta National course today in the middle of the most significant round of his career. One leader board, he remem-

title: Holiday Closings
description: Securities and commodity markets in the United States, Canada and Europe were closed yesterday for the Good Friday holiday, Banks in New Jersey and Connecticut were also closed, although some banks in New York State remained open.

title: Output Up; Fed Plans Credit Curb
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Output of the nation's factories, mines and utilities surged by eighttenths of 1 percent in March, the Federal Reserve Board reported today and it immediately announced fresh plans to restrain economic activity by selectively increasing the cost of bank credit.

title: Income Plan Eases Impact Of Redwood Logging Loss
description: EUREKA, Calif.  The wages were high and the unions were strong. The housing boom in the 1950's was creating a great demand for lumber. The mild coastal climate had produced thick redwood forests whose prized timber, in turn, was creating plenty of jobs in this small town 285 miles north of San Francisco.

title: Bad. Bad. Bad. Bad. Bad. Bad. Bad.
description: EL CAJON, Calif.  They sing few paeans these days to the American way of life.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: RHODESIANS STRIKE AT ZAMBIAN CAPITAL IN BID TO GET NKOMO
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 13  Rhodesia sent raiders into neighboring Zambia and Botswana today to attack command centers of guerrillas who have vowed to disrupt elections in Rhodesia next week. At least 10 people were reported killed.

title: Reporters at City Hall Find Tasks Lightened
description: After listening to complaints for six weeks about reduced lighting in City Hall. Deputy Mayor Peter J. Solomon ordered the lighting restored to its original intensity  but only in the press room.

title: Baltimore Schooner, Missing at Sea 4 Days, Runs Aground off N.J.
description: BALTIMORE, Saturday, April 14 (AP)  The Pride of Baltimore, a tallmasted sailing vessel that had been missing for four days, ran aground and began taking on water late yesterday hours after it returned to Delaware Bay, the Coast Guard said.

title: Legacy of U.S. Envoy's Killing in Kabul: Anxiety Among the Foreigners
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 12  An American diplomat who had become very involved with the lives of the local people here now confesses that he just can't feel relaxed any more in the presence of Afghans.

title: Hispanic Arts Festival Plans Citywide Events
description: There are probably more Latin Americans  Spanishspeaking persons from the Caribbean, Central and South America  living in New York than In any other, city in the United States, and many organizations representing their various national cultures are participating over the next two weeks in the fourth annual Hispanic Arts Festival.

title: Dance Is Play on Words
description: To say that at Thursday night's concert by the David Gordon/Pickup Company Mr. Gordon investigated choreographic form, theatrical reality and relationships between words and movement would be true enough. But saying only that would ignore something important about this program, in a studio at 541 Broadway.

title: Wichita Falls Buries the First of 44 Tornado Victims
description: WICHITA FALLS, Tex., April 13 (UPI)  Survivors of the tornado that devastated the southern part of this oil and agriculture center began burying their dead today while city officials tried to keep sightseers and looters away.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: Astronauts Say 2 Days In Space Seemed Longer
description: MOSCOW, April 13 (UPI)  The two astronauts whose mission to a Soviet orbital space lab was aborted by failure of a guidance engine returned to the Baikonur launching site today and said that their 48 hours in space felt more like a month.

title: Bells and Blooms Mark Holiday Weekend
description: Observance of the Easter wrekend of religious holidays began yesterday under a hazy but bright spring sky that helped bring forsythia and daffodils into bloom and turn fields green for young baseball players. Good Friday church services ended with the tolling of bells to mark the Crucifixion of Jesus.

title: WBAIFM to Mark Shakespeare's Birth
description: WBAIFM radio will celebrate William Shakespeare's birthday on April 23, with 14 hours of special programming, including a live broadcast of Much Ado About Nothing.

title: Social Security Official Named
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)  Margaret M. Rhoades, chief spokesman for the United States Office of Education since 1977, was named today to a similar position with the Social Security Administration.

title: Karpov of the Soviet Union Gains In World Chess Play in Montreal
description: MONTREAL, April 13 (AP)  The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, beat Jan Timman of the Netherlands in secondround play yesterday at the Man and His World Chess Challenge Cup.

title: Letter: On Casino Gambling
description: To the Editor:

title: Television Networks Program More Educational Shows for Children
description: The three commercial television networks have announced their schedules of children's programming for next season and, although the bulk of it appears to be the same as the programs previously shown, the broadcasters stress the introduction of more material designed to inform or educate.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as Shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchontw and (O) Overthecounter.

title: Brewers Turn Back Orioles, 93
description: MILWAUKEE, April 13 (AP)  Don Stanhouse's controversial balk triggered a fiverun seventh inning that helped the Milwaukee Brewers beat the Orioles, 93, tonight in a game in which three Orioles were elected.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 24.

title: Excerpts From Nuclear Mishap Talks
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  The accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear station began on Wednesday, March 28. But for the first 48 hours the Federal agency responsible for assuring the safety of the reactors was reasonably confident that the public was not seriously endangered.

title: Home Again, Home Again Closing Out of Town
description: Home Again, Home Again, the new Cy Coleman musical that was to have started previews at the Mark Hellinger next Thursday and to have opened there on April 26, will instead fold tonight at the Royal Alexandra Theater in Toronto, where it has been trying out. It starred Dick Shawn, Ronny Cox and Mike Kellin.

title: Fearful Juror Robbed, Just as She Predicted
description: Four times 65yearold Adelaide Wisser was relieved of jury duty after telling officials she would be in danger on the subway to and from court.

title: QUAKE HAZARD SEEN FOR COAST FACILITY
description: LIVERMORE, Calif. April 13  Earthquake hazards and the strong possiblity of increased cancer rates in the Livermore Valley resulting from radioactive emissions were prominent among criticisms of the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory at a public hearing convened here by the Federal Department of Energy.

title: Canton Trade Fair to Open
description: PEKING, April 13 (Reuters)  The 45th Canton trade fair opens Sunday. and China is expected to promote the sale of light industrial products to increase needed foreign exchange earnings.

title: Ad Men Can Help America
description: In 1960, the purchasing power of a consumer dollar was about 91 cents (on a 1967 base of 100). Now, it hovers around 50 cents.

title: Rebels Still Hold Nicaraguan City
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 13 (AP)  Leftist guerrillas held the northern Nicaraguan city of Esteli for the seventh day today despite heavy fire from Government artillery and planes.

title: Eastern Airlines Reaches Accord With Union for the Machinists
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) Eastern Airlines and negotiators for mechanics and ground crew workers announced agreement on a second tentative contract today while a strike by similar workers against United Airlines ended its second week with no talks scheduled.

title: Lady Lonsdale and One Sum Take Divisions of Bed o' Roses
description: Pic Stable's Lady Lonsdale, a filly who was the pacesetter throughout, and Charles T. Wilson Jr.'s One Sum, a mare who took her time in becoming contender, each captured a division of the onemile Bed o' Roses Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHAT ARE FRIENDS FOR? By John Jacob Clayton. 239 pages. Little, Brown. $9.95.

title: Negotiator's Next Job: Selling Trade Pact
description: GENEVA, April 12  When Alonzo L. McDonald Jr. initialed the trade liberalization agreement this week, it marked the end of one job and the beginning of another.

title: Blast Near German Atom Plant
description: BRAKE, West Germany, April 13 (AP)  Two homemade bombs damaged a mast carrying a hightension line from nuclear plant in northern Germany but the line remained intact, the police said today. Two other bombs failed to go off. The explosions apparently were set off Sunday at the mast, 10 miles from the Esensham nuclear power plant on the lower Weser River and near Bremerhaven.

title: FINAL STEPS STARTED FOR SAFE SHUTDOWN OF ATOMIC FACILITY
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 13  The final process to bring the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant to a safe, cold shutdown was started today. Federal nuclear experts said they did not know how long it would take.

title: Boston University Reaches Accord With Faculty on a 3Year Contract
description: BOSTON, April 13  Boston University officials and members of a faculty union attempting to win a contract at a major private university for the first time reached agreement today after a nineday strike.

title: Workshop to Make A Point of Order
description: DOES the thought of conducting, or even participating in, a formal meeting make you uneasy? Would you draw a blank if asked to distinguish a privileged motion from a subsidiary one?

title: Up Front in the Battle for the Shoreline Bill
description: POLITICS

title: EAST GERMANS PUSH ATOM POWER EFFORT
description: EAST BERLIN, April 14  Undeterred by the shock and public debate that the Pennsylvania nuclear accident caused in the West, East Germany is proceeding with plans for rapid development of nuclear energy.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: WNETHER you are replacing an old fence post that has cracked or rotted or are putting up a new fence, the strongest way to erect any post is to set it in a concrete footing or base. However, when a wood post is set in concrete, caution is required to prevent premature weakening due to rot that starts below the ground level line. In almost every case, this can be avoided if three simple steps are taken when buying the lumber and installing the posts in their concrete sleeves.

title: End of Compulsory Retirements For State Aides Urged by Carey
description: ALBANY, April 14 (AP)  Governor Carey proposed today the repeal of mandatory retirement ages for most state employees, declaring that gray power must provide some of the energy for the future.

title: Matching Students And Their Interests
description: WHITE PLAINS ELLEN OCHS needed a paying job last summer but did not think that she could find one working with retarded persons, an avocation that may become her career. Miss Ochs, one of thousands of students who find themselves in similar straits each summer, found employment at the Westchester Association for Retarded Citizens through a countyadministered summer jobs program that matches charitable agencies in need of manpower with students in need of jobs and precareer experience.

title: South Africans Say Seized Film
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, April 14  South African officials said today that film seized from the United States Ambassador's plane 10 days ago proved that the aircraft had been used to conduct a systematic aerial survey of strategic installations, including a topsecret uraniumenrichment plant at Pelindaba west of this capital city.

title: Rent Controls Gain in the Nation
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 14 Rent control, for decades a New York phenomenon, has begun to make significant inroads elsewhere in the nation, especially in the West.

title: Falgel Dies at 79
description: Joseph Faigel, one of only 28 arbiters eligible to judge all 124 breeds registered with the A.K.C., died of a heart attack at the Detroit airport nine days ago, on his way to judge at the Ocala and Gainesville shows in Florida. He was 79 years old.

title: Grisman at Bottom Line
description: Plinking away at nearly the speed of sound, David Grisman is the Paganini of the mandolin. His skittering solos make a jackrabbit seem like a slowpoke, and at the Bottom Line on Friday evening, he was in the fleetest form imaginable.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: FOR 25 years or so, I had for my operating headquarters a shelter where I could walk naked without offending anyone and compose novels out loud. I ironed into a thousand shirts the dialogue of heroic persons I had created.

title: A Toast to the Art And Also the Science That Is Architecture
description: WESTCHESTER County, the site of many a gingerbread Victorian mansion, will pay tribute to contemporary architecture Thursday night. A benefit for the Hudson River Museum is planned as a namedropping occasion.

title: Crafts as Art Flourish in Park
description: PETERS VALLEY

title: John Hull Minehan And Marcia Radley To Wed on May 26
description: Marcia Louise Radley and John Hull Minehan, New York lawyers, will be married on May 26 in Cooperstown, N.Y. Their engagement has been anbounced by the bridetobe's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Grover W. Radley Jr. of Ilion, N.Y.

title: Secret Kaifu Memos Could Be Political Dynamite for the Liberal Democrats
description: TOKYO Since the New Year, Japan's ruling conservatives have been mired in a scandal that begins to outrank even the Lockheed Affair, after which exPremier Kakuei Tanaka was indicted on a charge of taking over/4 million in bribes.

title: Catherine Stirling To Become a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. Tillman Stirling of Chevy Chase, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Stirling, to Hans Jurgen Gruss, who teaches law at the University of Augsburg in West Germany.

title: Jane Carangelo Engaged To Richard John Slagle
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Carangelo of Hartford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Julia Catherine Carangelo, to Richard John Slagle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Slagle of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Biltmore Closes Cafe Fanny, Men's Bar Successor
description: Cafe Fanny, the pseudoViennese restaurant that replaced the old Men's Bar at the Biltmore Hotel, has closed. The site, a few steps below street level at the comer of Madison Avenue and 43d Street, will become a bank or will revert to a retail business. Before it became the Men's Bar, a firstaid station for nervous advertising men and thirsty commuters, in 1936, it was a drugstore.

title: World Record for Nehemiah
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 19 (AP)  Renaldo Nehemiah set a world record of 13.16 seconds in winning the 110meter high hurdles at the first Bruce Jenner Classic track meet today.

title: Major Concerns Lagging On InflationDrive Vows
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) Nearly six months after President Carter unveiled his antiinflation drive, the Government yesterday said that 18 of the nation's largest petroleum and food companies had not made an unqualified pledge of cooperation with the program.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERICAN LEGEND (U.S. Lines). Rotterdam April 20. Bremerhaven 30 and LeHavre May ); sails from Um: land Hook. Staten Island.

title: SENATE PANEL WARNS
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  Future output of Saudi Arabian oil will be far less than predicted, adding urgency to the need for revised American energy policies, a report released by a Senate subcommittee said today.

title: Myra Handy Engaged to David Brautigam
description: Mr. and Mrs. John L. Handy of Huntington, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Myra Handy, to David Russell Brautigam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh M. Brautigam of South Glastonbury, Conn.

title: Marcos Critics Assail U.S.Manila Accord on Bases
description: MANILA, April 13  Domestic critics of President Ferdinand E. Marcos have started calling a threemonthold agreement with the United States on its military bases here the 50 percent solution.

title: Cosmos Ignore Strike, Triumph
description: ATLANTA, April 14  Despite a ruling by the Immigration and Naturalization Service this afternoon that a strike existed in the North American Soccer League and that foreign soccer players could be subject to deportation if they played in any league games, the foreign stars of the Cosmos took part in tonight's 32 triumph in a shootout here over the Chiefs.

title: $3,000 Value Placed On a Pile of Beer Cans
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., April 14 (UPI)  Dennis Brodeur, a barkeeper, has to get rid of his winter store of 30,000 empty beer cans before the horses return to this resort island, where automobiles are banned.

title: New FundRaising Drive Planned To Help Widow of Private Slovik
description: DETROIT, April 14 (UPI)  Supporters of Antoinette Slovik have announced new fundraising drive to help the ailing widow of Pvt. Eddie Slovik continue her battle for her husband's G.I. life insurance.

title: A Dirty Business
description: THIS book comes highly praised. Most of it appeared originally as two articles in The New Yorker and in that form won a $500 prize from the National Association of Science Writers; so a screening committee of journalists and a jury of scientists have judged this an outstanding piece of investigative and analytical reporting.

title: Birth Notice 3 -- No Title
description: Briths

title: Elizabeth Fielding To Marry Sept. 22
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Alice Fielding, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Fielding of Dallas, Pa., to Peter William Oliver, son of Mrs. William F. Oliver of New York and the late Mr. Oliver, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: Woodland Wildlings for Backyard Taming
description: Wildflowers suit the shaded garden splendidly, if you plan it properly. Too many novices concentrate on spring's display and summer is a void. Yet,smmer in the shaded garden can be as satisfying as this time of year. Many, wildflowers have ornamental berries and leaves as well as blooms. Plans can be made now. Planting can begin when the ground is ready and the plants at hand.

title: Anveilings
description: RUBINRuth. Unveiling AprII 29th at 12AM rein or shine at Mount Heberon Cemetery.

title: Exuberance Plus Serenity Equals YoYo Ma
description: At the age of 23, YoYo Ma is already a major cellist with a thriving career. He regularly turns up in New York's important halls most recently, at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., where he will appear with the Y Chamber Symphony this afternoon. Next month, he will play the Beethoven Triple Concerto with Herbert von Karajan and the Berlin Philharmonic. Concerto dates with leading orchestras in London and Paris are also pending, as well as with the New York Philharmonic and Chicago Symphony Orchestra.

title: Blue Jays 8, Royals 6
description: TORONTO, April 19 (UPI)  Rick Cerone lined a basesloaded single in the eighth inning today to drive in two runs and lift the Toronto Blue Jays to an 86 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: TaftHartley Finessed in Truck Strike  Deliberately
description: WASHINGTON  Days before the March 31 expiration of the old master freight contract between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and longhaul trucking companies, Labor Department lawyers were brushing up on the procedures for obtaining a Federal Court order to send the drivers back to work for 80 days under the TaftHartley law.

title: MUSIC
description: CHAMBER music is now big business, says Peter Small, president of Friends of Music Inc., which is about to wind up its silver anniversary season. But when we started, it was difficult attracting even 100 people to our concerts.

title: Some More Equal Than Others
description: SOCIALISM POLITICS, AND EQUALITY

title: 96TH CONGRESS IS OFF
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  New Congresses are not famous for early bursts of speed, but the 96th, which convened in January, appears to be off to the most sluggish start in recent memory.

title: After the Strike: The Big Truckers Are Getting Bigger
description: During the 10day strike against the trucking industry by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which ended last Tuesday, the owner of a $55 million Midwestern trucking concern placed a desperate can to the Staunton, Va., offices of Roy R. Smith, chairman of Smith's Transfer Corporation. The strike had wreaked havoc on the shaky finances of the caller; his company was up for sale.

title: FifthGraders Go to Jail for a Short, Harsh Lesson in Life
description: Marcy Stecker had her fifthgrade class locked up in jail the other day. She wanted to teach them something they could not learn in school, and it turned out to be a stark, brutal lesson.

title: Temperatures Holding In Core of Nuclear Plant
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 19 (UPI)  Dropping temperatures in the damaged core of the Three Mile Island reactor were permitted to stabilize again today as officials pondered their next step in cautious cooling process to end the nation's worst nuclear plant crisis.

title: Special Tiger Scores As Choice Stumbles
description: Thousands of favoriteplayers moaned as Mister Brea stumbled coming out of the starting gate in the Excelsior Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct. They watched in despair as he puddled through the mud in last place, well behind the five other horses.

title: WOMAN IN MICHIGAN IS FREED IN SLAYING
description: GAYLORD, Mich., April 14  Six years after she married a former Detroit automobile dealer named Herman Isaac Smith, Jeannette Smith, 47 years old, has been acquitted of killing him with kitchen knife.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WASHINGTON  President Carter, like Presidents Ford and Nixon before him, has been casting about for ways to break the nation's reliance on imported oil. The latest was Mr. Carter's decision, announced in his energy speech 10 days ago, to remove price controls from oil produced within the United States.

title: DINING OUT
description: RISTORANTE SAN GIORGIO in Westbury is a small and lovely place, elegant in its tasteful simplicity. All it takes is white walls accented by dark wood, a few paintings and snowy table linen set off by good lighting. The service is professional and caring.

title: Evacuation Planning At Shoreham Studied
description: YAPHANK

title: Dana A. Halsey Engaged To Paul Gaston, Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Rittenhouse Halsey of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dana Anne Halsey, to Paul Edwin Gaston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Don Frederick Gaston, also of Greenwich. An August wedding is planned.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: POTHOLES can talk, as any driver who is conversant with them knows. What they say, mostly, is thunk, and the translation, mostly, is trouble.

title: CHARLES GREENFIELD
description: Charles Greenfield, the former administrator of the Shore Road Hospital in Brooklyn, died Thursday at his home. Mr. Greenfield, who lived in New York City, was 94 years old.

title: Leslie Quick 3d Is Fiance Of Eileen Marie Manning
description: The engagement of Eileen Marie Manning to Leslie C. Quick 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Quick Jr. of Laurel Hollow, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Manning of Lehighton and Lake Naomi. Pa.

title: ROBBER SHOOTS MAN IN AUTOMATED BANK
description: A 50yearold railroad conductor was shot in the side and robbed of about $90 shortly after noon yesterday as he was making a withdrawal inside a glassenclosed automated banking facility in deserted lobby of the Pan American Building.

title: Five Sons Spurn Rank, Count of Paris Reports
description: PARIS, April 14 (Reuters)  The Count of Paris. 71yearold pretender to the French throne, was quoted in magazine interview yesterday as having said that his five sons were indifferent to their heritage and had no royal ambitions.

title: U.S. Issues Clergy a Reminder
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)  The Government yesterday issued a reminder to members of the clergy who have changed their minds and want Social Security coverage,telling them that they have until midnight Monday to qualify. The statement by the Social Security Administration noted that those failing to take advantage of this onetime opportunity risked losing both Medicare and Social Security protection.

title: Bonnie Wyatt Sets Nuptials on May 12
description: Barbara Ann Wyatt, a nurse, and Frederick Wells Finn, a vice president of corporate development for the Microband Corporation of America in New York, plan to be married May 12.

title: Revaluation's Impact on the Homeowner
description: THE New York property tax system is in turmoil. Because of courtordered changes in assessment practices, municipalities are hurrying to revaluate property, and shuddering as they find that revaluation can bring with it large increases in residential property taxes.

title: According To Burgess
description: MAN OF NAZARETH

title: Liverpool Close to Title In English Cup Soccer
description: LONDON, April 19 (AP)  Liverpool took another stride toward the English First Division soccer title today by defeating Manchester United, a Football Association Cup finalist, by 20.

title: Kidnapped Italian Is Freed
description: MILAN, Italy, April 14 (Reuters)  A building contractor kidnapped near here on Jan. 17 was released last night after payment of an undisclosed ransom, the police said. Luigi Balzarotti, 53 years old, was left, blindfolded, in a suburban street and was being questioned by police.

title: Ohio Bombing Death Trial Set
description: CLEVELAND, April 14 (AP)  Anthony D. Liberatore, on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's mostwanted list for more than a year, is scheduled to go on trial on Oct. 1 in connection with the bombing death of a Cleveland rackets figure. Judge Harry Hanna of the Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court set the trial date Thursday. Mr. Liberatore, 57 years old, has been charged with aggravated murder and aggravated arson in the bombing death of Daniel J. Greene.

title: Cambodians in a Battle Near Border of Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 14 (Reuters)  Heavy fighting erupted today near the Thai border between Vietnameseled forces of the new Government in Cambodia and forces loyal to the ousted regime of Pot Pot.

title: The Kemeny Commission's Duty
description: The commission President Carter has chosen to investigate Three Mile Island is better than its assignment.

title: Yagla Wins 3d Straight A.A.U. Wrestling Crown
description: AMES, Iowa, April 14 (AP)  Chuck Yagla of the Hawkeye Wrestling Club of Iowa City won his third straight title today at the national Amateur Athletic Union freestyle wrestling championships.

title: If Connecticut Has a Nuclear Leak ...
description: HARTFORD IF a Harrisburgtype nuclear accident ever happened at Waterford, the First Selectman of neighboring East Lyme could be reached through a beeper in his home, and communications could be maintained through the eightchannel scanner and 30watt transceiver or through the fourchannel portable scanner that he has at his disposal.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: FOR the first time in many years, builders, especially in Fairfield County, are cutting. down on the sizes of the new houses they are putting up this spring. They are doing so, they explain, not simply because they are aware that most families are now smaller, but also because they fear that runaway costs may tip the price of even a modest home over what the average family can afford. There is also growing resentment that smaller houses cannot be built because of continued regulations favoring large lots and minimum square footage.

title: CLARENCE DILLON, FINANCIER, IS DEAD
description: Clarence Dillon, a leading financier in the investment field for almost half a century and the retired president of Dillon, Read & Company, died yesterday at his home in Far Hills, N.J. He was 96 years old.

title: DINING OUT
description: WESTPORT ALL may not be completely shipshape at The Ships, in Westport, but this small restaurant is pleasant enough nonetheless for lunch and a light supper. Right smack in the center of town, practically next door to the Fine Arts Theatre, it is an agreeable place for a premovie or postmovie repast.

title: Peking, in Reversal of Its Position,
description: HONG KONG, April 13  In a reversal of the relatively open policy of the last few months toward the outside world, China is taking a more xenophobic approach, warning people against fraternizing with foreigners, asking for Westernstyle democracy or becoming too dependent on foreign technology.

title: The Best Golf Hole Nobody Sees
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 14  Golf holes are like people. Some have character. Some don't.

title: Christians in India Condemn Bill
description: NEW DELHI, April 14  Christians in India are unhappy with a bill introduced in Parliament that would ban the use of force or inducement to bring about conversions from one faith to another.

title: RELIGIOUS BOORS
description: THE original French title of this work calls it a history of beliefs and ideas. That choice is a strange one, for Mircea Eliade has spent four decades helping resurrect the notion that symbols, rites and myths matter most in the study of religion. And in this book, which deals with the earliest human religious traces and works through Mesopotamia and Egypt to Israel, India and even beyond the Greeks the scope is dazzling  the author concentrates on what most Westerners think of as religious ideasystems.

title: They Get His Name Wrong, but They Don't Get it Funny; What Is the Difference Between Califano and Carolina? Plenty!
description: WASHINGTON  Bumper stickers in North Carolina read, Califano is Dangerous to Your Health. As Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Joseph A. Califano Jr. is the point man in two battles raging between Washington and Raleigh. By leading a nationwide campaign against smoking, the secretary is threatening the tobacco industry, one of the state's economic mainstays. And by demanding the desegregation of the state university system, he is challenging North Carolina's reputation for racial enlightenment.

title: Sandra Kiely, Martin Kolb Plan Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Procter Kiely of Rumson. N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Ivins Kiely, to Martin Robert Kolb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Kolb of Rochester.

title: Anthony Dowell Likes It Here Now
description: It was a severe loss for the Royal Ballet when Anthony Dowell joined American Ballet Theater last fall. IHe was Britain's first homegrown international male star and had been with the company his entire working life. But there were no major new ballets slated for the year, no out side choreographers scheduled and a policy of no guest artists.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WNETHER you are replacing an old fence post that has cracked or rotted or are putting up a new fence, the strongest way to erect any post is to set it in a concrete footing or base. However, when a wood post is set in concrete, caution is required to prevent premature weakening due to rot that starts below the ground level line. In almost every case, this can be avoided if three simple steps are taken when buying the lumber and installing the posts in their concrete sleeves.
