title: PEOPLE
description: The opportunity that Morgan V. Humor said recently he simply must accept but wasn't ready to talk about was announced last week by Mr. Hunter. He is leaving the Li. Reynolds Tobacco Company, a divison of Li. Reynolds Industries, to become president and chief operating officer of the Scott Paper Company May 1. Mr. Hunter has held the same titles at Reynolds Tobacco for 17 months. His official election by the Scott board of directors will not occur until next Tuesday, but he was willing to talk about it. The difference, he said, Is that Reynolds Tobacco is a subsidiary of Reynolds Industries. Scott is an independent company itself.

title: Caribbean Volcano Erupts Again
description: KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, April 19 (Reuters)  A violent eruption shook Soufriere volcano today and sent stones raining down on parts of this Caribbean island. A cloud of smoke and ash blocked out the sun after the eruption just before noon.

title: Show Business on the Rails
description: Building on the success of trial runs last year, a Toronto travel agent has organized a series of transcontinental train rides for travelers who like to be entertained on a train. Nineday Show Train excursions are being run between Toronto and Vancouver with nightly entertainment on board plus shows during stopovers in cities. We're trying to approach travel in Canada in a novelty way, says the 25yearold agent, Sam Blyth. So far a majority of bookings have been made Californians, who, he says, are more open to new experiences.

title: Kristine Mari Johnson Bride Of Alan Scheuer, Executive
description: Kristine Mari Johnson and Alan Scheuer were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Scheuer of Greenwich, Conn. Justice of the Peace Eugene Waggarnan of Old Greewich performed the ceremony.

title: ART
description: KATONAH MANY Westerners have difficulty appreciating Oriental art. Its formality is often inaccessible to them. Its rigid forms, its hieratic poses and artifice escape them. They do not grasp the cultural significance of this art, its religious and social importance. Its subject matter and its spirit often remain alien their sensibilities.

title: Jane Adrian Carlson Married
description: Jane Adrian Carlson and Elston Hunt Bergen 9th were married yesterday in the Unitarian King's Chapel in Boston by the Rev. Stephen R. Treat. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eric A. Carlson of Richmond. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bergen of West Hartford, Conn.

title: Autos Take Toll of Joggers in Metropolitan Region
description: Scores of joggers were killed and injured in the New York metropolitan area over the last year, according to safety officials in New York and New Jersey, many because they simply could not be seen by motorists.

title: Laurie Anderson Offers
description: Laurie Anderson has been doing performance art of one sort or another on the SoHo wene for several years, now, but this writer hadn't encountered her in some time. Friday night she offered a major showcase of her work, a full program (only one hour long but full, nonetheless) entitled Americans on the Move: Parts One and Two with several collaborators at the Kitchen, repeated last night. It was a fascinating, charming and telling occasion, and it suggested that Miss Anderson has become a really important force on the American avantgarde scene.

title: ART
description: LOCUST VALLEY VISITING the Country Art Gallery for the current exhibition is like finding an old friend who has not been around much but still looks as vital and impressive as ever. The old friend is drawing, which makes an occasional appearance in a gallery or museum these days but is not in our presence nearly so much as we would like.

title: 7 Pounds, 5 Ounces
description: THAT redoubtable fisherman Ernest Schwiebert, author of Matching the Hatch and Nymphs, has finally brought his longawaited work Trout to publication. After many postponements, this tour de force is now between covers in two boxed volumes, and if a subject of such infinite variety as trout fishing can be said to be defini tively treated in one work, then Mr. Schwiebert has written that book. It seems likely that because nobody ever has, nobody ever will write as complete a book on trout and trout fishing as this formidable twovolume work.

title: Illinois Crash Kills Six in Family
description: KANKAKEE, Ill., April 14 (UPI)  Six members of one family were killed and seventh person was seriously injured last night in a fourcar crash on Illinois 50 four miles north of Kankakee. The police identified the dead as Dennis Allen, 30 years old, of Bradley; his wife Brenda, 31; sons Jeff, 7, and Jason, 2, and daughters Casey, 4, and Jody, 6.

title: WITH THEM, IT'S ALWAYS STRICTLY KOSHER
description: A thousand angels can dance on the head of a pin, but the laws of kashrut what is kosher. or permitted to Jews. according to the dietary laws  could hardly fit into the beads of a thousand angels.

title: Ban on Ladoga Seal Is Lifted
description: MOSCOW, April 14 (Reuters)  Soviet ecologists have lifted a ban on hunting the rare Ladoga seal now that its numbers have risen to 12,000 under protection, the official press agency Tass reported today. The new ruling limits the number of animals killed for their valuable darkringed fur to less than 500 a year. The seals, which live in Lake Ladoga in northwest Russia, faced extinction until scientists imposed the hunting ban as part of a conservation program.

title: Philadelphia Police Face
description: PHILADELPHIA  Mayor Frank L. Rizzo has sworn under oath that there is no police brutality here.

title: Yukon Gets Closer to Goal
description: WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory  As Quebec campaigns to withdraw from the Canadian Confederation, the Yukon Territory is taking significant steps toward getting in.

title: Living as Moslems In Greater Hartford
description: HARTFORD AISHE RAHMAN, age 4, sits at her blackboard counting and spelling out words for her proud parents and guests.

title: Susan Thomas Is Betrothed To Perry Marshall Matz Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Herrmann of Mount Vernon, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hemnann's daughter, Susan Thomas, to Perry Marshall Matz Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Matz of Shellington, Pa.

title: The Egg and Us: An Economic Tale
description: CORTLANDT THE egg, a symbol of fertility and procreation for the ancients and still honored in today's exchange of gaily colored Easter eggs, has long been praised by Charlie Krause's customers, who come from places as diverse as Brooklyn and New Jersey to buy lots of eggs from his farm.

title: Diane Waldgeir Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Max Waldgeir of Douglaston, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Waldgeir, to Mark Craig Perlberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Perlberg of Wyckoff. N.J.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris, in an Actor's CafTheater production. Thursday 28).ueSaturday, 8:30 P.M. (through April 5045.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: Finns, Driving a Mercedes, Are Ahead in Safari Rally
description: MOMBASA, Kenya, April 14 (AP) Hannu Mikkola of Finland led the field today as the survivors of the fiveday, 3,018mile Safari auto rally left here for the night run into the Kenyan capital of Nairobi.

title: Nigeria Announces Elections
description: LONDON. April 14 (Reuters)  Elections leading to civilian control in Nigeria are to be held this summer, the Lagos radio, monitored here, said yesterday. It said elections to the Senate would be held on July 7, followed by elections to the House of Representatives on July 14 and to state legislatures on July 21. State governors are to be elected a week later and the president on Aug. 11. The military Government of Lieut. Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo set up an electoral commission in 1976.

title: College Applicants Brace for the Word
description: THIS week's mail deliveries will be particularly important for thousands of high school seniors across the Island: It is the season in which many college and universities, particularly those in the Ivy League and others of equal reputation, begin notifying applicants of their acceptance or rejection.

title: S. Africa Charges U.S. With Spying
description: Beset by domestic scandal over bribery of foreign legislators and opinion leaders, and rising international pressure for selfdetermination in SouthWest Africa, Prime Minister P.W. Botha of South Africa picked a new fight last week with Washington. He went on television to charge that a United States Embassy plane was secretly photographing his mtry. The plane was seized and three American military aides were given one week's notice to depart.

title: Strains Between City and Suburb
description: FOUNDED in 1971, the Westchester Foundation is a privately financed, nonprofit organization dedicated to the continued economic development of Westchester. Governed by a group of 14 senior members of the building and construction industry, it serves. as a catalyst for a number of programs designed to accomplish its major objectives.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 14 (Reuters)  Women and children were evacuated from Esteli today during a pause in the fighting between National Guard troops and the Sandinist guerrillas who control parts of the city. NEW DELHI, April 14 (Reuters) Nearly 100 people have been reported killed in the last three days in Jamshedpur in India's worst HinduMoslem riots in nine years. TOKYO, April 19 (Reuters)  Engineers began to shut down an Americanbuilt nuclear power plant today to check HONG KONG, April 19 (Reuters) China will soon reimburse Tibetan estate owners whose property was confiscated in 1959, the New China News Agency said today. SEOUL South Korea, April 19 (Reuters)  Twentysix coal miners were killed and 40 were injured today when explosive charges they were carrying down a mine shaft ignited, the police said. It was South Korea's worst mining disaster.

title: TV VIEW
description: As television copes with what more and more observers describe as a state of crisis, two theories begin to dominate the inevitable analyses. One is that the industry is being increasingly paralyzed by frantic competition as the networks concentrate on shortterm gains rather than tongterm development. That version was bandied about by assorted producers and former network executives on The David Susskind Show a couple of weeks ago. The second theory is that the crisis is largely illusory, that television operates in cycles and the medium is currently on the downside of one of them. Over a recent lunch, this reading was discussed, though not entirely endorsed, by Anthony D. Thomopoulos, the 40yearold president of ABC's Entertainment Division.

title: Carters Join in a Picnic Given by Amy on Isle
description: SAPELO ISLAND. Ga., April 14 (AP)  Despite a threat of rain, President Carter ventured out this afternoon for a picnic today that was organized by his daughter. Amy.

title: Tracking Down Budget Motels
description: Like most other prices, the rates charged by hotels and motels across the United States are rising this year. is still possible in some areas, however, to find decent though modest accommodations for as low as $10 a person a night, $15 for two and $17.50 for a family of four.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BEDFORD HILLS  Crane and the Tortoise and Mountain of the Fiery Tongues, Chinese folk tales performed by Yueh Lung Chinese Shadow Theater, Jo Humphrey, director. Presented by Katonah Gallery. Saturday at 1 P.M. Free. Bedford Hills Community House. 2324988.

title: Glut of Giant and let TV Games Facing Local Fans This Season
description: The Giants and Jets both need to have successful, interesting and entertaining football teams this coming season to sustain the interest of local television audiences whose selection of games to watch on Sunday afternoons will be limited because of altered circumstances.

title: Other Ideas &
description: The timing must have dismayed Soviet officialdom. Last week, while fireworks were lighting the Moscow sky to celebrate the 18th anniversary of the Soviet Union's first manned space flight, Soviet television viewers were learning of the failure of the latest space mission. Maj. Georgi Ivanov, the first Bulgarian in space, and Nikolai Rukavishnikov, Soviet commander of the Soyuz 33 mission, were forced to return to earth without linking up as planned with the orbiting Salyut 6 space laboratory. The reason: a malfunction in the approach correction powe unit of the Soyuz space capsule.

title: For Those Who'd Like to Do It Up Blue
description: GARDENING

title: Philip Davis Fianc of Sara Almond Ewing
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Tucker Ewing of Rockville Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Almand Ewing, to Philip John Davis of Arlington, Va., son of Mayor and Mrs. Sigel Davis of Bellwood, Ill.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: A DOORMAN is someone who greets people; a security guard is a guy with a nightstick, according to one definition. As Westchester becomes more security conscious, the man with nightstick is supplanting the doorman. Also widely seen today are uniformed men at gate houses, guards from private security companies (sometimes dressed in blazers and gray flannels) and closedcircuit television surveillance systems.

title: Westminster Picks New Superintendent
description: After 51 years, the Westminster Kennel Club is going to have a new superintendent. The husbandandwife company of Neal and Carmen Visser of Irvine, Calif., is replacing the Foley Dog Show Organization, which handled America's most prestigious show continuously since 1928. In those days the blueribbon fixture was a threeday event. Since 1941, it has been two days.

title: SHOP TALK
description: PORT JEFFERSON THE Nesconset Shopping Center on Route 347 in Port Jefferson is the kind of place you might be inclined to overlook because it is an undistinguished little man surrounded by gas stations fastfood chains. However, on closer inspection it is well worth the time and effort of any serious, costconscious shopper.

title: CAMERA
description: your camera is an important tool that can be a great help in providing positive proof when you have to identify objects of yours that may have been stolen; or when you need proof to substantiate claims to an insurance company or to the IRS for loss or damage.

title: Deaths
description: HOFFMANRuth. dear mother of Richard, Barbara and Gary. loving sister of Joseph Sitkin. Irma Hoff. men and Betty Coven. Services Sunday, 1 PM, at Guttemian's. 8000 Jericho Turnpike. Won:bury, L.I.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Four Seasons Farm, Hillcrest Road, Readington, N.J. Green, amateurowner, junior, children's and adult amateur working hunters; open jumpers, ponies, equitation. 8 A.M.

title: 500 Fewer Uniformed Policemen Termed Likely in Next Fiscal Year
description: The New York City Police Department will have at least 500 fewer uniformed policemen in the upcoming fiscal year even though more than 400 additional police officers are scheduled to be hired or rehired during that period, the city's budget director said last night.

title: Few Traces of the Big Spill Remain on Breton Beaches
description: A year after the Amoco Cadiz shipwreck produced the biggest oil spill in history, few traces of the disaster are visible along the coast of Brittany, in western France. I made this discovery on a recent visit when, prospecting for a summer vacation site, I found myself captivated by the wild beauty of the landscape, the picturesque towns and, yes, the beaches and seafood, imperiled only a short time ago.

title: A.I.A.W. Plans Protest To Protect Title IX Gains
description: Delegates of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women will stage a demonstration at the White House next Sunday to generate support for the Title IX law that assures equal sports opportunity for women in Federallyfunded colleges.

title: NONFICTION IN BE
description: I understand that visitors may no longer lean against the brutal stones of Stonehenge, or walk between the puzzling 35centuriesold uprights. They are required to stand across the road that cuts through the Salisbury Plain and to examine the monuments from a distance. This new study will provide the curious reader with a closer view, as well as a wedge into the enigma of Stonehenge: why it was built, by whom, exactly when, and for what purpose.

title: Energy Instructions
description: In hot pursuit of his plan to save energy by making domestic petroleum costlier, the President warned oil companies last week that they would face new restraints if expected gains in profits were not used for exploration. As the President attempted to sell his domestic program, more bad news loomed on international oil prices. According to oilindustry sources, Iran planned an oil price rise that could touch off a new round of increases by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Meanwhile, prospects for new energy supplies brightened as Prime Minister Elliott Trudeau proposed two routes to deliver crude oil from Alaska through Canadian territory to the Middle West.

title: Aussie Skating Victor
description: JACA, Spain. April 14 (AP)  Australia's Robin Burley won the prof sional world figure skating title f women today. Candy Jones and Don Fraser of Canada took the pairs crown.

title: collecing
description: From Easter to eggs to Faberge is a word association that's easy to make. But it's an association that's almost impossible to accomplish in concrete fact.

title: U.S. Legislators in Soviet Union
description: MOSCOW. April 14 (UPI)  A delegation from the United States House of Representatives met today in Tbilisi, the capital of Soviet Georgia, with Pavel G. Gilashvili, the republic's president, the press agency Tass reported. The group. headed by John Brademas, an Indiana Democrat, arrived in the Soviet Union yesterday for a nineday visit.

title: The New A55 Tries to Work Plain English Into the Lease
description: The of A55 is not what it used to be.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Unfortunately, Sylvia Levin, in her recent Opinion Page article, These Are My Children From 8 to 3, was so involved with drama that she omitted the essence of what she had to say. Her position was made clear by the note following the article, and herein lies the rub. She is obviously concerned for her job, but nowhere does her article give any justification to the fact that only a school nurseteacher could become the savior of the students she encounters.

title: The Unloneliness of the Runners
description: ENGLEWOOD

title: M.D. Bransfield 3d Is Fianc Of Alice Margaret Guillemette
description: Alice Pauline Guillemette of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Alice Margaret Gulllemette, to M. Declan Bransfield 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Declan Bransfield Jr. of Norfolk, Va.

title: Locker Rooms: Equality With Integrity
description: Last fall, just a few days before the World Series would return to New York City, baseball's lawyers were back in court. This time their mission was to ask the threeman Court of Appeals for a stay that would prohibit female reporters from having access to the locker rooms at Yankee Stadium during the three Series games.

title: Deaths
description: MARTI NOVincent J.. beloved husband of the late Shirley. father of Carol, Dorothy and Phyllis. Brother of Mayo Farinella, Thomas, Mary Pecoraro. and Samuel. Grandfather of %Verdi. Scott. Eric, Stephanie. and Adam. Family will receive friends from 25, 79, at Williams Funeral Home. 5628 Broadway at 232nd St., Bronx.

title: In Some Minds Vietnam Goes
description: WASHINGTON  To judge from much of television and the movies, the Vietnam combat veteran is a ticking time bomb, apt to explode in crazed frenzy. The Deerhunter, the movie about insanity among former prisoners of war that won several Academy Awards last week, sharpens that image, although another awardwinning film, Coming Home, softens it somewhat by presenting a sensitive portrait of a veteran's readjustment.

title: Whatever Became Of the Most Likely...?
description: As I noticed the first tiny points of crocus shoots poking through the earth, I fled inside to weigh myself; for following spring this year, along with the Island's many proms and graduations, will be many high school reunions  my high school reunion, the Lawrence High School class of 69.

title: U.S. and Soviet to Resume Talks On Killer Satellites on April 23
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)  The Arms Control and Disarmament Agency announced today that SovietAmerican talks on banning antisatellite weapons were scheduled to resume April 23.

title: Eight Robbers Force 100 To Strip in a Queens Bar
description: Eight robbers fired several shots inside a Queens bar Friday night and forced its more than 100 patrons to disrobe, according to the police. A woman was sexually assaulted before the robbers escaped with an undetermined amount of cash and personal jewelry, authorities reported.

title: some City Taxpayers Facing Closer State Scrutiny
description: The more complex an incometax return, the more likely it is to be selected for an audit, according to state budget and tax officials, who are gearing up to expand their oversight of New York City taxpayers.

title: Flyers Trounce Canucks, 72, to Win Series
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP) Bobby Clarke's firstperiod goal started the Philadelphia Flyers toward a 72 victory over the Vancouver Canucks tonight and into the quarterfinals of the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: WASHINGTON A Minority Report
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  The majority opinion in Washington at the Easter recess seems to be that President Carter is in deep political trouble and is likely to be defeated if he runs for reelection in 1980.

title: News Summary
description: Idi Amin's troops hardly resisted  troops sent by Uganda's new President, Yusufu Lule, into what he described as unliberated areas of eastern and northern Uganda. The Uganda radio said that 200 soldiers of former President Amin had surrendered, and the Ministry of Defense appealed to other troops of the Amin regime to hand in their weapons. The Government ordered Ugandans not to seek revenge by taking the law into their hands. [Page 1,Column 6.]

title: California Amends Its Complaint On Worldwide Church's Finances
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14 (UPI)  The California Attorney General's office has filed new charges of misappropriation of funds against officials of the Worldwide C71, urch tf God.

title: Mary Henningsen Plans Nuptials
description: The engagement of Mary Francis Henningsen to Christopher Minturn Collins has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Victor W. Henningsen Jr. of Pelham Manor, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. Mm.. turn Post Collins of Princeton, N.J., and the late Mr. Collins.

title: A Tale of 2 Cities And of 2 Budgets
description: NEWARK

title: DINING OUT
description: WHEN one speaks of a basic American restaurant serving good, honest food, the emphasis is often on the basics rather than on the variety of American regional cooking. The Alps, opened Bronxville in 1927 and maintained under the same watchful owner for the last 14 years, has always served fresh, impeccably cooked American basics a warm, convivial atmosphere.

title: MUSIC
description: AFEW weeks ago, we reported on the festival at the University of Bridgeport honoring Howard Hanson. On April 23, the Yale School of Music will begin toasting another of the grand old men of American composition, 82yearold Virgil Thomson. The occasion marks Yale's acquisition of the huge collection of Mr. Thomson's correspondence and autograph scores, spanning more than 70 years. There is no body of correspondence I can think of, Harold Samuel, head librarian, said, that covers American musical life so thoroughly.

title: What's Doing in PALERMO
description: SUN CITY  A soft climate the year round, with plenty of sunshine even in the mild winters, splendid parks full of palm trees and exotic plants, a spectacular seafront, fascinating ArabNorman architecture attesting a long and checkered history, picturesque surroundings and a lively people  all these assets have earned Palermo the Italian title La Felice  the Happy One.

title: Patti Lyons on Way to Boston
description: If knowing the course is any, criterion for victory, Patti Lyons could easily be the first woman to finish in the Boston Marathon tomorrow. Living just a quick jog away in the suburb of Quincy, Miss Lyons has had ample opportunity to become totally familiar with the route's topography, from the bucolic streets of Hopkinton to the infamous hills of Newton and the seemingly infinite last miles down Beacon Street.

title: Trucking War Hits Home (and Business)
description: RIVER VALE

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Collectors of oldtime paper money will be happy to hear of the recent new edition of Hodges's American Bank Note SafeGuard, first published in New York in 1863 by Edward M. Hodges, and a valuable reference work for all specialists in this field.

title: Music Notes: Skrowaczewski Hopes to Compgse More Now
description: On Friday and Saturday, the Minnesota Orchestra will give concerts in Carnegie Hall. They will be conducted by Stanislaw Skrowaczewsld, marking his last appearances here as music di.. recurr of the ensemble. He has held the position for 19 years. Some comments seemed in order from the 55yearold Polishborn artist, who made his American debut in 1958 and received his Minneapolis appointment two years later. A call was put in to him at his home in the Midwest.

title: Elizabeth M. Farley Is Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hugh Farley of Garden City, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Marie Farley, to Bradley James Quin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Wyndham Quin of River Vale, N.J.

title: S.E.C. INVESTIGATING U.S. SECURITIES SALE
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  The Securities and Exchange Commission has started an informal inquiry into whether major New York banks and brokerage houses conspired to pricerig the $3.34 billion auction of oneyear Treasury securities on April 4. according to agency sources familiar with the investigation.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: DIX HILLS  Stone lithography by Dan Welden's Workshop; through April; Half Hollow Hills Library, 55 Vanderbilt Pky. For hours, 4214530.

title: Private Businesses Turn to Making Their Own Energy
description: Two months ago, Curtis Beusman cut himself off from the Consolidated Edison Company and its $60,000ayear bill for electricity and heat for his Saw Mill RiverTennis Courts in Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Westchester County businessman installed his own electrical generating system, which also provides heat for the massive complex of tennis sheds.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: ART

title: Miss Dubow Plays Ives
description: Marilyn Dubow's recital at Alice Tully Hall Friday night was played as a tribute to Charles Ives on the 25th anniversary of his death. Miss Dubow is no inger to Ives's violin sonatas, for has performed them in concert and recorded the Second and Third for the Musical Heritage Society.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Sperry Division of the Sperry Rand Corporation of Great Neck has been given the job of assembling the final designs of the Island's $30 million traffic control and surveillance system, which the Federal Highway Administration and the State Department of Transportation have been planning since 1973. Sperry is expected to complete the designs by March 1981.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: On behalf of New Jersey Common Cause, I would like to reply to Martin Waldron's recent article on gubernatorial courtesy.

title: INVESTING A Study of the Treasury Yield Curve
description: If the Treasury yield curve is telling the truth, lower interest rates lie ahead.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Last call to lime, patch Seed and fertilize lawns. . . . Apply crabgrass controls anytime now before the lilacs bloom. . .Spray peaches with ferbam before buds swell to prevent leaf curl. . . . Follow fruit tree spray schedules for control of pests and diseases. These are available from Cooperative Extension offices.

title: BEHIND TEE BEST SELLERS
description: Samm Sinclair Baker is not a ghostwriter. He has never been at the other end of an as told to or with. Call it coauthorship, Mr. Baker says pleasantly, but firmly, of his work with Dr. Herman Tarnower on The Complete Scarsdale Medical Diet. I won't write unless it's a 5050 partnership in every way, with the names the same size and always an and in between.

title: Catherine Jane Beimfohr Wed to Robert J. Wilson
description: Catherine Jane BeinIlfohr and Robert John Wilson were married yesterday afternoon at the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J., by the Rev. Kenyon J. Wildrick.

title: Barbara Ann Grosso Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael B. Grosso of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Grosso, to George Bixby Jr. son of Mr. and Mrs. Bixby of Riverhead, L.I. The bride is attending the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York. from which her husband was graduated. He is with Ted Bates Advertising Company in New York. Mr. Grosso, a New York lawyer, is executive vice president of the Fifth Avenue Association. Mr. Bixby's father is an electrician with Grumman Aerospace Corporation in Calverton.

title: Petraglia Wins, 214200, To Capture P.B.A. Event
description: PALATINE, Ill., April 14 (UPI) Jam Petraglia of Staten Island won two matches today to capture a $100.000 Professional Bowlers Association tournament. Petraglia beat topseeded Steve Cook, 214200, in the final game for the $15.000 first prize.

title: GARDENING
description: HIGH school students will be in great demand as soon as the grass turns green, that is, if they have a power lawn mower that works and know a few basics on lawn care.

title: Corporate Names: A Tendency Toward Alphabet Soup
description: Next month, Allegheny Airlines takes on a new name: USAir.

title: Compensation for No Coffee
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 14 (Reuters)  The Rhode Island Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a worker was entitled to compensation for an injury be suffered when he struck a coffee machine that did not dispense a cup of coffee after he put money into it. Michael Denardo, a former foundry worker. suffered a 10 percent loss in the use his right hand because of the blow.

title: Sam Milliken Weds Karen Sue Hopper
description: The chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan was the setting last evening for the marriage of Karen Sue Hopper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Witt Hopper of North Little Rock, Ark., to Sam Milliken, son of Elizabeth M. Farrell of New York, and the late Maj. Samuel Alger Milliken, U.S.M.C., retired. The Rev. Andrew Jackson Mullins 3d performed the ceremony.

title: Notes: A Selection of Travel Bargains
description: Although international airline fares are scheduled to rise next month, an occasional travel bargain can still be found and there are a few other encouraging developments to ease the strain on the traveler's pocketbook.

title: In Diversity, a Signal Success
description: His public relations staff objected mightily, but not for the first time, Forrest Shunaway, president and chief executive officer of The Signal Companies, went his own way. The decision: to sponsor a controversial documentary about a prison program aimed at juvenile offenders. Last week, Scared Straight!  presented without commercial interruption by Signal and produced by a TV station half owned by Signal won an Academy award.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Old prints and old photographs have a wonderful power to evoke the longago and faraway. The simpler and closer they are to being mere transcriptions of what was once a commonplace reality, the more evocative they are. The rutted, unpaved streets in Piranesi's engravings say more about 18thcentury Rome than the grand palaces, temples and churches that are his principle subjects. If old photographs are sometimes a little more evocative than old prints, it is because the camera blindly records some little detail that the draftsman or engraver would omit.

title: THE MARKETS
description: By last Tuesday, the Dow Jones industrial average finished just below 879 to register its highest closing In six months. But the stock market, it seemed, just enuldn't stand nrosneritv.

title: It's Lyrics by P. B. Shelley
description: Percy Bysshe Shelley, who died at age 30 in 1822, was not into showbiz, and yet here is the poet as lyricist, more than a sesquicentennial later, of an Off Off Broadway musical about himself, show called Shelley currently running weekends at the Carter Theater at 250 West 43d Street.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE chances of finding a real mom and pop restaurant nowadays are about as remote as finding butter churned by hand. At The Butterchurn in Vincentown, at the edge of the Pine Barrens, the mom and pop are real, even if the butter is churned and packaged in a factory.

title: Umpires Moving Protest to Boston
description: BOSTON. April 13 (UPI) Major league umpires involved in a walkout, who have been picketing stadiums throughout the country since opening day, are targeting Fenway Park for tomorrow.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Simultaneous novels. Wouldn't it be a great idea, many Americans used to ask back in the years when the youthful contemporaries of Scott Fitzgerald and Ernest Hemingway were making the scene in Paris, to do in our country what the French do  publish new fiction in moderately priced, wellprinted, wellbound papercovered editions?

title: Joy of Easter and Passover
description: Every day for the 40 days of Lent, Stella Zelozzi went to morning mass at Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church in Queens Village. Today at 7:45 A.M. she will go again. Then, in midafternoon, she will give her family an Easter feast of lasagne, roast beef, Italian meat pies, cheesecake and pastries.

title: GARDENING
description: ONE of our most useful garden aids got its start in a Norwegian kitchen during World War II. With their country occupied and their usual livelihood interrupted, two young Norwegians were attempting to harness the steam from a tea kettle to mold children's toys from wood pulp. During their experimentation, they struck upon the idea of molding pots for growing plants.

title: ART VIEW
description: The Lehman Wing at the Metropolitan Museum caused quite a stir when it was first opened in 1975. That any one collector, dead or alive, should be allocated quite so large a fief within so great a museum seemed wrong to many people. It represented an abdication of sovereignty over a panicularly covetable interior space, and it set a thoroughly bad precedent. It is one thing for the Met to have the Wrightsman Rooms, which confine themselves to a specific historical period and cover it with a prodigious distinction, and quite another to agree to keep a markedly miscellaneous collection together with every appearance of permanency.

title: Ideas &
description: Diabetes is among the most discouraging of diseases because it cannot be cured, only controlled, and control demands a punishing degree of selfdiscipline by its victims. To stave off such diabetic complications as blindness, kidney ailments and cardiovascular disease  and indeed to stay alive all of the country's 6 million diabetics must live on a rigid diet. Two million of them must also take antidiabetic pills, and more than a million have to inject themselves with insulin daily.

title: Overcoming the Detours on the Road to Prosperity
description: THE conclusion is inescapable that the Byrne administration, deliberately or not, is orchestrating a civil war between the state's developing communities and its large urban centers. The administra

title: Fashion SPRING FOR A HAT
description: Who would have thought a year ago that buying a hat for spring would be the thing to do? After all, hats  as fashion  were out then, just as they are now very much in.

title: Correction
description: In the article Nuclear Power: The Bottom Line Gets Punier, in last Sundays Business/Finance section, it was reported that National Economic Besearch Associates, a consulting firm, had concluded that for power plants coming on line in 1990, the total cost of producing power from nuclear fuel will average about 11 percent less than that of producing power from nuclear fuel. The firm actually concluded that coal power will average 11 percent more than nuclear power.

title: Ellen Louise Hall Sets Aug. 4 Bridal
description: The engagement of Ellen Louise Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Hall of Rye, N.Y., to Kevin John McEllin, son of Elizabeth McEllin of Waltham, Mass., and John McEllin of Brighton, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents. Plans have been made for an Aug. 4 wedding at the Resurrection Roman Catholic Church in Rye.

title: Future Events
description: Woody at the Whitney

title: JOHN J. LAMULA
description: John J. Lamula, a former New York State Assemblyman, died yesterday following openheart surgery. He was 67 years old.

title: The Time of the Wounded Hero
description: In Brian Clark's Whose Life Is It Anyway?, which opens Tuesday at the Trafalgar, Tom Conti plays a sculptor who ruptured his spinal column in an automobile accident and is permanently paralyzed. He can move only his head, which he thrashes in fits of anguish from side to side on his pillow.

title: Fusion Power: Is There Still An Eldorado for Energy?
description: Nearly half a century ago, the bright dream was born that man could harness the inexhaustible power of the atom to light his life, power his industries and build a brave new world.

title: ANTIQUES;No 138YearOlds Need Apply
description: Apumpkincolored clapboard house built into the side of hill in 1795 in Haddam will be the beneficiary of the Connecticut Spring Antiques Show to be held Friday through Sunday at the State Armory in Hartford.

title: Reopening of FamilyRun Stores Brings Relief to Tourists in Spain
description: MALAGA, Spain, April 19 (Reuters)  Familyowned restaurants, cafes and bars reopened today after closing for 24 hours in support of striking hotel and catering workers. The action brought some relief to tourists on Spain's Costa del Sol, who had lined up at grocery shops to buy food.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: It is 20 years this week since Frank Lloyd Wright died at 91 in an Arizona hospital, and it is no exaggeration to say that the United States has had no architect even roughly comparable to him since. Not Louis Kahn, not Eero Saarinen, not Kevin Roche, not I.M. Pei, not Philip John. son, nor even au or these men together have had the impact on the art of architecture that Wright did in his extraordinary 72year career. It began with the shingled Hillside Home School in Spring Green, Wisc., of 1887 and extended through more than 400 built buildings, hundreds more unrealized designs and dozens of books and articles proclaiming that Wright's socalled organic architecture would emerge as the style of the future.

title: A Legend in the island's Natural World
description: WHEN the life's work of a prominent artist is sought by a foreign buyer, his countrymen invariably rally to preserve such a visible symbol of their culture. Roy Latham of Orient

title: Retired Civil Rizhts Lobbyist Recalls U.S. Leaders
description: WASHINGTON  Lyndon B. Johnson was the greatest American President on civil rights, according to Clarence M. Mitchell Jr., the recently retired civil rights lobbyist. But he added that I had been greatly opposed to his nomination for the Vice Presidency in 1960.

title: Urnps and Champs
description: TOM GORMAN, retired National League umpire, begins his reminiscences: An umpire can work the plate in a pitcher's perfect game, and nobody's going to come up and shake his hand. In Gorman's Three and Two! as told to Jerome Holtzman, he recalls working the leftfield line at Yankee Stadium in 1956 when Babe Pinelli called Don Larsen's perfect game, the last pitch nicking the black for a called third strike. Everyone congratulated Larsen, of course; no one said a word to Pinelli  except to complain that the last strike was really ti ball.

title: Emily George Fiance of W.E. Williams 3d
description: The engagement of Emily Preston George to William Edwin Williams 3d has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Henry George of Gates Mills, Ohio, parents of the bridetobe. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Williams of Cleveland Heights and Catawba Island, Ohio.

title: Chinese Fly to Hanoi to Discuss Rifts in Wake of War
description: HONG KONG, April 14  An 11member negotiating team from China arrived in Vietnam this afternoon to begin talks on a range of disputes in the wake of their monthlong border war.

title: Sarah A. Kennedy To Be Wed Sept 22
description: Sarah Anne Kennedy, a member of the faculty of St. Aloysius Academy in Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Dr. David J. McGroarty, who is completing his residency in internal medicine at Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia, plan to be married Sept. 22.

description: Dr. and Mrs. Howard Paul Serrell of Greenwich, Conn. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Wainwright Serrell, to John Emile Schmeltzer 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Schmeltzer, also of Greenwich.

title: Administration Considers Tighter Credit to Cool the Economy
description: President Carter last week, once more, with emphasis, said that mandatory price and wage guidelines were unacceptable. He has no authority to impose them, he told a news conference, and he would not accept any standby authority should Congress grant it.

description: YONKERS

title: Emergency Plans Sought for Indian Point
description: MURIEL MORABITO is not only the Town Supervisor of Cortlandt, but she is also a resident of Buchanan, the village that lies in the shadow of the Indian Point nuclear power plants. Last week, in the aftermath of the reactor accident at the Three Mile Island plant in Pennsylvania, Mrs. Morabito appeared to be speaking more as a resident than an elected official when she said, What we need is someone to help us out and assure us that everything is all right at Indian Point.

description: MOSCOW, April 14  Handel's Messiah was presented here this weekend in what may have been its first performance in the Soviet Union since the Communists came to power in 1917.

description: .The marketing division of the New York Telephone Company is taking major space at One Astor Plaza on the west side of Broadway between 44th and 95th Streets.

description: Major corporations reported solid firstquarter profit gains last week: General Electric, $303.4 million, up 22.4 percent .. . Westinghouse, $83.2 million, up 25.7 percent . . . United Technologies, $70.8 million, up 33.8 percent . . . Teledyne, $86.7 million, up 64.5 percent ... Kaiser Aluminum, $56 million, up 128.6 percent. . . . The international Business Machines Corporation reported an earnings increase of 13.2 percent to $666.8 million. But Wall Street had been expecting a better performance, and I.B.M. stock plunged 8 points... RCA's profit rose 13 percent to $62.1 million . . . title: Evacuation in Florida Ends
description: CRESTVIEW, Fla., April 14 (AP) Six days after a derailed Louisville & Nashville train began spewing lethal fumes from chemicalfilled tank cars, residents had returned home with no further evacuations in prospect. Everybody is back home, said Lieut. Everette Helms of the Okaloosa County Sheriffs Department. Roadblocks were removed yesterday, allowing the last 1,200 evacu eeste return

title: Nuerburgring Auto Track To Be Made Safer
description: BONN, April 14 (UPI)  The Nuerburgring race track, boycotted by the world's Formula One drivers since Niki Lauda crashed and was burned there in 1976, will lose 159 of the 174 curves that made it what many considered the toughest and most dangerous course in the world.

title: The Earlier Joy on American Campuses Has Been Dissipated
description: WASHINGTON  "Haman ash va haman kase, the young woman said, sadly shaking her head, before she translated the Iranian phrase into its American equivalent: The more it changes, the more it remains the same.

title: Finally, His Play Makes It to First
description: MASSAPEQUA WHEN the lights dim Friday and the thrust stage at the PAF Playhouse comes to life with Good Night Grandpa, two firsts will be registered at the Huntington Station theater: For the first time, PAF will offer a play by a Long Island playwright, and this playwright, Walter Landau, will see his first play professionally produced.

title: A Feast of the Arts From Japan
description: With the economic frictions between Japan and the United States potentially very dangerous, former U.S. Ambassador to Japan Edwin Reischauer believes We can use a deeper base of intellectual and cultural understanding if these problems are not going to blow up in our face.

title: Around
description: VENTURA, Calif., April 14 (AP)  An unexplained series of explosions rocked a petrochemical plant here today, seriously burning one worker, fire officials said. WEST CHESTER, Pa., April 14 Bruce Johnston Jr., whose father and two uncles are charged with killing five mem bers of a burglary ring and conspiring to have him killed, told a Chester County judge this week that he had left the protection of Federal marshals to return home because he felt safe with his relatives in jail while awaiting trial. WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)  A Government ban on virtually all aerosol products containing fluorocarbons goes into effect tomorrow at the end of a twoyear program to eliminate the use of the substance, which is believed to threaten the earth's protective ozone shield. DETROIT, April 14  The Detroit News has been sued by a group of present and former women employees who alleged a variety of sex discrimination practices by the management. MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 14 (UPI)  Attorney General Charles Graddick will ask the Alabama Supreme Court Monday to reschedule the execution of John Louis Evans 3d, now that the United States Supreme Court has ended its temporary stay.

description: NEIVERTaatrice. In cherished and everlasting memory of my beloved Mother. Always in my heart And sadly missed. Daughter.

title: Action Against Ford Cars Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)  The Center for Auto Safety is sending several hundred letters to Ford owners who have. complained to the Government, Ford or the center itself of defects in their cart. The public interest group wants to force the Government to act on allegations that certain Ford cars have defects that cause them to jump from park into reverse.

description: There's not much of the oldtime fiveanddime left about Woolworth's.

title: A RELIGIOUS LEADER
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 14  One of Iran's most respected religious revolutionary leaders has dropped out of sight after a mysterious incident in which two of his sons and his daughterinlaw were arrested by revolutionary militiamen.

title: East's Last Major Violet Grower Giving Up as His Business Wilts
description: RHINEBECK, N.Y.  The last majcr commercial grower of violets in the East will close down six of his seven remaining greenhouses here tomorrow, the day after Easter, and the violet corsage and nosegay, symbols of romance in bygone days, will fade like the flower into nostalgia.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: In 1947, when Rosamond Bernier was European feature editor of Vogue, she arrived one hour late at the home of a very grumpy Henri Matisse, who had delayed his lunch. After the interview he demanded payment of $38, explaining that before the war Vogue had reproduced a work of his and never paid him. When Mrs. Bernier told him in astonishment that she didnst have $38, he produced his checkbook and stood over her, dictating what she was to write.

title: Can UConn Make a Better Grade in Its Centennial Decade?
description: WEST HARTFORD

title: Virgin Islands Governor Urging 4th Try on Charter
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., April 14  Given a goahead from the Library of Congress in Washington, Gov. Juan Luis has asked the Virgin Islands Legislature to start a fourth attempt to write a new constitution for this unincorporated territory of the United States.

title: Overlooking a Potential Grant is a Firing Offense
description: TRENTON  A national survey of mediumsized cities has labeled Trenton a trendbucker among old, industrialized urban centers for its ability to hold down taxes and debt and attract revenues. Mayor Arthur J. Holland likes the praise but says it should be tempered with understanding. I'm happy to show that report to anyone because it indicates we've been fiscally conservative, he said last week, but we still have all the problems of older cities.

title: Devane Goes to War Again
description: Under the bright, hot overhead lights, the stage setting at the Playhouse Theater resembled a craggy lunar landscape. It was, in fact, meant to represent a hillside torn by war, and starting tomorrow night its inhabitants will be the cast of G.R. Point, David Berry's play about 1960's Vietnam, a subject rarely dealt with on Broadway. In the semidarkness of the orchestra, watching the stagehands hammering and heaving things into place, stood the play's director, William Devane. Mr. Devane, who is better known for his work as an actor, moodily took in the action and occasionally called out advice to the lighting crew.

title: Brown U. Accepts 2,664
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 14 (AP) Brown University announced yesterday that it would send out acceptance letters today to 2,664 of the record 11,441 persons who applied for admission to the freshman class. Students have until May 1 to notify Brown that they intend to enter the class in the fall. University officials are planning for a class of 1,280 students.

title: CoWinners in Race
description: Art Hall and Tom Cuffe finished together in the sevenmile Riverdale Ramble yesterday, clocking 37 minutes 30 seconds. The race, over a hilly course in Riverdale, drew more than 350 entries. Marie Roach of the Long Island Golden Spikes led the women with a time of 45:27.

title: Miss Solbert, J. S. Sheldon Wed on L. I.
description: Elizabeth Abernathy Solbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter O.A. Solbert of New York and Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I., was married in Cold Spring Harbor, LI., yesterday to John Sevier Sheldon, son of Col. George C. Sheldon, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Sheldon of Jarrettsville, Md. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Wilder's Movie 'Fedora' Opens:The Cast
description: Billy Wilder's "Fedora" is a fabulous relic, a grand old villa fallen slightly into disrepair. And if it seems outmoded, well, that is very much Mr. Wilder's intention. "Fedora" is old-fashioned with a vengeance, a proud, passionate remembrance of the way movies used to be, and a bitter smile at what they have become.It is rich, majestic, very close to ridiculous, and also a little bit mad. It seems exactly what Mr. Wilder wants it to be, perfectly self-contained and filled with the echoes of a lifetime; no one could mistake this for the work of a young man. Indeed, it has the resonance of an epitaph. That, too, seems a part of Mr. Wilder's design."Fedora" opens today at Cinema Studio, where it is liable to have a very short run. Preview audiences have been laughing in the wrong places  understandable, perhaps, in light of the plot's outlandishness. A woman throws herself in front of a train in the first scene, and we learn that she was Fedora, a great foreign-born movie queen who has long been in seclusion. Then we see Fedora's body lying in state, as weeping fans file through her mansion in Paris. One of the mourners is Dutch Detweiler, played by William Holden. Mr. Holden narrates "Fedora" just as he narrated "Sunset Boulevard," the Wilder film that "Fedora" most eloquently recalls.The film flashes back to Corfu, where Dutch visited Fedora two weeks earlier. He had known her 30 years before, when he was an assistant director and she was a great star; they even had a one-night romance, which she no longer seems to remember. Now he's down on his luck in Hollywood, and hoping he can interest her in his script, a new version of "Anna Karenina." But Fedora isn't available for a comeback; she's a virtual prisoner in a waterfront retreat. Her captors are an aged Polish countess (Hildegarde Knef), an unsympathetic servant (Frances Sternhagen) and the doctor (Jos Ferrer) responsible for the treatments that keep the actress looking so amazingly, unbelievably young.Midway through the story, a bizarre secret about Fedora is revealed, and it's a lulu. The rest of the film is devoted to denouement, and this is no mere case of "The butler did it." No, this is where the screenplay, by Mr. Wilder and his long-time collaborator, I. A. L. Diamond (from a story by Thomas Tryon), goes wild, piling twist upon incredible twist with a giddy bravado, until even the overstatement becomes exhilarating. It's impossible to describe this part of the film without betraying Fedora's mystery. But the loose ends tie up into a coherent picture, a Hollywood reckoning of the price of art, the sacrifice worth making for the sake of a grand illusion.Marthe Keller, in the highly demanding leading role, is particularly resourceful, and Mr. Ferrer reads his lines with a witty understanding of the screenplay's intentional corniness ("To pump out the stomach, that is easy. The mind, that is another thing"). Michael York appears, playing himself, the actor Fedora hardly knows but has fallen hopelessly in love with. (This perhaps provides some indication of how improbable things become.) Henry Fonda arrives to present Fedora with an Oscar, in his supposed capacity as president of the academy, and to tell her how much he always envied Fredric March, Charles Boyer, Ronald Colman and all of her other costars."Fedora" is full of references to Hollywood personages, not just for the sake of bitchiness but for purposes of scale. It ranges from California to Greece, from Dutch and Fedora's golden youth (the young Dutch is played by Stephen Collins, who imitates Mr. Holden to a T) to times less full of promise, as it demonstrates the kind of scope we don't readily see from "the kids with the beards," as Dutch describes Hollywood's new generation. The compactness and symmetry evident in "Fedora" aren't easily achieved these days without a good deal of self-consciousness. Mr. Wilder achieves them naturally."Fedora" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It includes one brief incidence of partial nudity.

title: After The Fall
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  For the rest of the world, the dethroning of Idi Amin creates ripples, but for the countries of East Africa Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda itselfIt is like a tidal wave in a bathtub. The three nations are more tightly bound than any other exouning in Africa. They share similar contours of British colonial history and white settlement, common languages in English and KiSwahilie an interlocking system of commerce and transportation; and marginal tribes that straddle the borders and move freely back and forth.

title: Letter TO THE EDITOR
description: Reading Catching Joseph Heller (by Barbara Gelb, March 4) reminded me of the following incident. Two years ago, a friend and I were walking along Broadway going toward Lincoln Center when I spotted Joseph Heller. I said to my friend, I'm going to go over and thank him for his novels. Then I had second thoughts. Having met many writers (I teach literature), I decided not to be a sycophant. But a few blocks later, I said, What the hell, the man's books have given me such pleasure, I'll do it anyway.

title: Statement From Foreign Minister
description: WASHINGTON. April 14  The South African Embassy issued a statement from Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha today criticizing press reports that an unnamed American official had suggested that South Africa planned to use the spyplane charges in a scheme to reject a United Nations plan for the independence of SouthWest Africa, also known as Namibia. This allegation is false and reprehensible and is a comment not on my Government but on the callousness of the unnamed official who suggested the linkage, Mr. Botha said.

title: Donna Marie Knight Fiance Of First Lieut. John E. Davis
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lucian Jack Knight of Huntington. W.Va., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Donna Marie Knight, to First Lieut. John Eric Davis, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Matthew Davis of Glen Cove, L.I. Plans have been made for a May 12 wedding at the Main Post Chapel, Fort Bragg, N.C., where the prospective bridegroom is stationed.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS The Arms Habit
description: An alarming number of thirdworld governments have become addicted to armaments. Their nationalsecurity establishments crave modern weapons, become the captives of suppliers, and display paranoid and violent behavior, especially when threatened by withdrawal. Understandably, the most avid thirdworld consumers of arms head Amnesty International's list of humanrights violators.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Peter McCutcheon, a 22yearold guitarist from Montreal, made his New York debut in Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday night. Presently a professor at the University of Montreal, Mr. McCutcheon studied at the Paris Conservatory with Alexandre Lagoya, graduating in 1975, and has since performed extensively throughout Canada, as well as in Spain, France and the United States.

title: Brita Ann Sardella Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Richard Sardella of Wakefield, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Brita Ann Sardella, to John Lansing Reed, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Lansing Reed of Hanover, N.H. The future bride, a magna cum laude graduate of Dartmouth, and her fianc, who was graduated cum laude from the college, will be married June 9.

title: Events Have Left Eurocommunism Behind
description: PARIS  There are posters in Paris and other cities these days showing the Winged Victory of Samothrace and the slogan Euroright, an effort of marginal farright parties to seek a place for themselves as campaigning warms up for the first direct European parliamentary elections in June. They are unlikely to make any dent.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The American motion picture Industry is a large lump in the belly of the python called television. Most of the time one doesn't notice this. This python has a voracious appetite, eating regularly, digesting as it goes, but then, once a year, the Oscar show comes along and there is no way to disguise what's been happening during the past 30 years.

title: CHESS
description: When a Winawer Variation French Defense goes badly for White, his advanced attacking pieces are slowly driven back, weak square complexes become permanent In his position, and all attempts at counterplay founder the rocksolid slack pawn chain. When it goes badly for Black, the White attack strikes with a blistering intensity, overturning the relied upon tactics of the defense with sudden smashing sacrifices, and the French Defense gets a bad name.

title: Six Works of New Music
description: The Composers Guild for Performance got together a rather forbidding program of new music Thursday night at Columbia University's McMillin Theater. Most of the six works were cast in an unrelentingly grim, spare, postWebern mold and, to this listener, at least, worked over that familiar terrain with a minimum of imagination, expressive urgency or fresh ideas.

title: Dana Isaacson Is Affianted To Leslie Feldman, a Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard B. Isaacson of Greenville, Del., and Palm Beach Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dana Isaacson, to Leslie Charles Feldman, a lawyer in New York and son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Feldman of Brookville, L.I., and Palm Beach.

title: Iraq Severs Air Links to Egypt
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 14 (Reuters) Iraq decided today to close its airline office in Cairo and to suspend flights between Baghdad and the Egyptian capital, the Iraqi press agency reported.

title: Musical Grab Bag From California
description: It seems fatally seductive for non, Californians to make sweeping generalizations about California, and about Los Angeles in particular..As a transplanted Californian who still retains a good deal of affection for his home state, this writer has always been amused or annoyed by such generalizations, depending on their nature and tone.

title: What They're Saying
description: Tommy John, who won his first two starts for the Yankees, recalls what he said to the club's principal owner, George Steinbrenner, when he was signed: I told him I can't guarantee 20 wins or 15 wins. I can only promise I'll pitch to 150 percent of my Godgiven abilities.

title: Other National Events
description: A huge tornado ripped along the TexasOklahoma border last week, killing 94 persons in Wichita Falls, Tex., and at least 14 other deaths elsewhere. President Carter declared the stricken region a disaster area, and dispatched a special assistant, Jack H. Watson Jr., to help coordinate plans for Federal assistance and reconstruction. Property damage in Wichita Falls alone was estimated at $200 million to $300 million.

title: Pirates Win as Umpires Protest
description: PITTSBURGH, April 19 (AP)  Ed Ott drove in four runs with a homer and a triple to back the pitching of Ed Whitson as the the Pittsburgh Pirates took a 74 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.

description: IF, 30 years ago, New Jersey had developed a conscious plan to destroy its cities, it would not have been more successful than has been the case.

title: Interns and Residents Begin New Bargaining Drive
description: Young interns and resident physicians in hospitals around the country are organizing a new collective bargaining drive as a result of a United States Court of Appeals decision that upheld their contention that they are professional hospital employees rather than students completing their medical education.

title: Barriers Just About Gone for Black Travelers
description: At longago family gatherings, after our stomachs had been soothed by Mama's cooking and the summer sun had relented at dusk, I would sit on the porch with the grownups and listen to tales of their adventures in the vast world of whiteonly America.

title: YachtRacing Safety Is Key Issue of Suit
description: The 100 members of the Lloyd Harbor Yacht Club on Long Island cannot be found lingering at the club bar after races or socializing among yachts moored at the docks. Compared with the bastions of yacht racing on Long Island Sound, with their elaborate facilities, Lloyd Harbor seems more like a state of mind.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHETHER you are replacing an old fence post that has cracked or rotted or are putting up a new ferice, the strongest way to erect any post is to set it in a concrete footing or base. However, when a wood post is set in concrete, caution is required to prevent premature weakening due to rot that starts below the ground level line. In almost every case, this can be avoided if three simple steps are taken when buying the lumber and installing the posts in their concrete sleeves.

title: Facing Forty and Other Fun
description: FROM materials so unpromising that only a newcomer would dig into them, Philip F. O'Connor has written a novel of wondrous surfaces and startling depths. It's his first, and it's going to be a hard act to follow.

description: 1 IF LIFE IS A BOWL OF CHERRIES WHAT AM I DOING IN THE PITS? by Erma Bombeck. (Fawcett/Crest, $2.50.) More domestic drolleries.

description: GOING STEADY, by Pauline Keel. (Warner, $2.50.) Reviews of 75 films that Pauline Kael wrote during her first years (196869) as critic for The New Yorker, and an essay on Trash, Art, and the Movies. This 1970 book, now returned to print, shows Miss Kael typically entertaining, acidulous form, more concerned with social significance than esthetics.

title: Miss Caulkins: Another Record
description: MONTEREY PARK, Calif., April 14  Sixteenyearold Tracy Caulkins of Nashville, the world's best swimmer in 1978, is on her way to becoming the world's best swimmer in 1979.

title: Rhodesia Raids Bases Of Black Nationalists In Zambia for 2d Day
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 19 (AP)  Rhodesian planes attacked black guerrilla bases in Zambia today, military officials announced, and inside Rhodesia 90 guerrillas were reported killed in some of the heaviest fighting of the war.

title: The World
description: When Egyptian and Israeli leaders spoke to their separate Arab and Jewish constituencies last week, the threeweekold peace zigged into trouble. But then Prime Minister Menachem Begin and President Anwar elSadat tried out their new hotline, and a fiveminute phone chat zagged the agreement back on the track.

title: A Music Teacher Takes to the Stage
description: IGUESS I'm the latest of the bloomers, said Michael Ingram. You see, back in the days when Michael Harvey Ingram was an undergraduate at Hofstra, people like Francis Ford Coppola, Lainie Kazan and Madeline Kahn were on the campus. And while they were making names for themselves in places like Hollywood or on Broadway, Mr. Ingram was mainly spending his time as a teacher of choral music in the Sachem School District in Lake Ronkonkoma.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: ST. CROIX, V.I.  Antilles Air Boats threw a 15th anniversary party for itself in February; each employee was asked to bring a favorite dish. That kind of homey touch, right out atone of those old Western films starring Maureen O'Hara and John Wayne, was typical of the Virgin Islands commuter line that bills itself as the world's largest seaplane airline. And no wonder, considering the downhome flavor of the company and the person of its chairman, president and chief executive  Miss O'Hara, herself. She took over after the fatal crash last fall of her husband, Capt. Charles F. Blair, who founded the airline with one Grumman Goose, a Navy surplus plane that he acquired while he was still the chief pilot for Pan American World Airways. But the airline's style may soon becornea bit less homey.

title: Mets Washed Out; Injury Idles Maddox
description: One new problem and one old one cropped up at Shea Stadium yesterday as the New York Mets postponed their game with the Philadelphia Phillies because of rain. The two clubs are to resume operations with a regularly scheduled doubleheader this afternoon. No makeup date was announced for the rainedout contest.

Yehuda Amichai, Israel's leading poet, has won wide recognition In America and England for an originality that is manifest even in translation; Dahlia Ravikovitch,

title: Greenwich Church Has Southern Accent
description: GREENWICH JUDGING from appearances, the Greenwich Baptist Church is as native to Fairfield County as the soil it stands on. Standing on the crest of a snitill hill in a wooded residential area near the Cos Cob Pond, it is a group of simple brick and clapboard buildings that are barely distinguishable from the neighboring homes. It is only upon closer inspection that one finds signs  such as the inclusion of blackeyed peas and ham hocks on the Wednesdaynight dinner menu, the roster of visitors from such cities as Chattanooga, Nashville and Birmingham, and gospel music at the Sundaynight service that the spirit, if not the body, of the Greenwich Baptist Church. lies somewhere south of the MasonDixon Line.

title: The Resounding Impact of ThirdWorld Music
description: The Mongolians started it, and now it's all over town. No, it isn't a new strain of influenza, it's a peculiar singing technique, developed by Mongolian nomads, that allows a vocalist to sing a duet with himself. The vocalist sings a primary tone, then tenses his throat and adjusts the shape of his mouth cavity, thus producing a delicate, flutelike overtone high above the original tone. On a recent weekend, one could hear the Harmonics Choir using this technique in concert at the La Mama theater, the Natural Sound Workshop using it in a loft concert on Eighth Avenue, and the composer and choreographer Meredith Monk using it in one of her Songs From the Hill in a performance at The Kitchen.

title: Miss Austin, Mrs. Reid in Final
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., April 19  The ease with which Tracy Austin overwhelmed Evonne Goolagong and Kerry Reid's first career victory over Martina Navratilova were the stunning developments in the semifinals of the $150,000 women's tennis tournament today.

title: The First American Pope
description: WALTER F. MURPHY, a professor of jurisprudence at Princeton, has tried with only partial success  to produce in The Vicar of Christ a synthesis of the American dream and the definitive Catholic novel. The story. conceived in heroic proportions, traces the rise of Declan Walsh. from a Marine officer who wins the Congressional Medal of Honor in Korea to Chief Justice of the United States. Eventually he becomes a papal knight representing the President at the Vatican, and then is elected Pope himself. Reduced to its bare bones, the story must seem bizarre; but as constructed by Mr. Murphy, it is a meticulously written saga with authentic detail about the Vatican. Some editorial pruning would have made it a firstclass novel.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Alma Shapiro calls herself an audiovisual aid. A piano teacher for 20 years, her recitaltalks on music have become a popular feature in Scarsdale. Instead of written program notes, I talk and answer questions, she says. Thursday at 1:30 she will play Chopin and provide some insights into his life. The theme of the series, called Biographies in Music, is the dissimilarity between composers lives and their music. Chopin was a tubercular, selfexiled dandy who seemed to fritter away his energy in partying. But his music is bold, virile and full of purpose, compensating artistically for his physical weaknesses, Mrs. Shapiro believes. Mrs. Shapiro took her degree in music education at Columbia Teacher's College. The onehour program will be given at the library, Post and Olmstead Roads, and it is free. Call 7232005 for further infoi mation.

title: Shipping Hot Stuff  Straight Through, or Straight Up?
description: WASHINGTON  The accident at the Three Mile Island power plant has spawned at least a dozen investigations by Federal and state regulatory and legislative groups, as well as a Presidential Commission. A week later, another accident caused by hazardous materials also led to the evacuation of several thousand people but received comparably little attention. Last Thursday, when one Senator sought to delve into the reasons for the mishap, the hearing room was almost vacant.

title: BRIDGE
description: This year of 1979 may be remembered as the year of youth, judging by the results of the Spring National Championships in Norfolk, Va. Two major national pair titles were determined in 12 days of play, and both of them went to young players with considerable futures ahead of them in the game.

title: Health ACNE HAS NO
description: The characters in the commercial are usually a young girl talking breathlessly about blemishes to a friend, or a girl and her brother telling it like it is by referring to their affliction as zits. Alternatively, a Frankensteinvoiced pharmacist halfmockingly, halfportentously intones the chemical names of the ingredients in the medications he is selling to a clearly younger audience. These commercials would have you believe that acne is a blighted province inhabited only by teenagers.

title: EARTHRISE:
description: At 75, Joseph Campbell, New Yorker by birth, affection and the softest of accents, is considered to be the foremost American scholar in the field of mythology. Although the word is popularly used to denote falsehood, myth is actually a perennial vehicle for expressing truth. Human beings have always told, in mythic forms, the stories they want to be remembered and passed on  such as the Arthurian legends or the enduring biblical tales  to distinguish them from fashions, fads or the constantly changing facts of almanacs or the Guinness Book of World Records. Myth and symbol are fundamental and essential properties of all religions; they are the special language of religious experience.

Scott, twice elected Attorney General of Illinois, is so esteemed by his peers that last year the National Association of Attorneys General named him their outstanding member. Last week, a Federal indictment charged Mr. Scott with five counts of income tax evasion. Mr. Scott, a Republican, lost no time in denying the charges, and said United States Attorney Thomas P. Sullivan, a Democrat, was a paid lackey for the very people we were fighting.
