title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: WRILE gasoline prices seem to be raised with increasing frequency these days, consider the problems of the Shell Oil Company in trying to raise a tree in the middle of its gas station in New Canaan.

title: SELECTION: From Easter Vigil and Other Poems
description: HE Selection below is reprinted from Easter Vigil and Other Poems by Karol Wojtyla (Random House, $5). Wojtyla is, of course, Pope John Paul II. But another name enters into the history of the poetry; it was first published between 1950 and 1966 in two Polish Catholic magazines under the byline Andrzej Jawien, a penname chosen to keep the two vocations distinct. Jawien in Polish suggests someone realizing himself or coming into the light, as indeed the poet/priest did in 1978, when he was elected to the papacy. The translation is by Jerzy Peterkiewicz.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: POTHOLES can talk, as any driver who is conversant with them knows. What they say, mostly, is thunk, and the translation, mostly, is trouble.

title: Laurie Sue Nelson Is Affianced
description: Laurie Sue Nelson, a legal assistant with the New York law firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler, and Dr. Edward M. Pocius, a dentist in Channahon, Ill, plan to be married Aug. 12.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: The Jerusalem Inter national Book Fair, starting Thursday and continuing for a week, is the first fair in the Middle East since the signing of the peace treaty ! between Egypt and Israd.

title: Walkout by the Newspaper Guild Shuts Daily Journal in Elizabeth
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., April 14 (UPI) Editorial and business employees of the state's oldest newspaper, The Daily Journal of Elizabeth, staged their first strike in the publication's 200 years today in jurisdictional dispute with management.

title: Edward Childs Jr. Fianc Of Susan Crease, Student
description: Susan Crease and Edward P. Childs Jr., graduate students at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, will be married on May 12 in Tenterden, England. Miss Crease is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Crease of Tenterden. Her parents are dentists. Mr. Childs is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Childs of Edgartown, Mass. His father is a retired New York physician.

title: Tom Gorman, Umpire
description: Willie Mays of the New York Giants was batting against Sal Maglie of the Brooklyn Dodgers, whom they called The Barber because he shaved hitters so close. The first pitch brushed Willie back and the second lowbridged him. Tom Gorman, the plate umpire, went to the mound and spoke to Maglie. The pitcher gave the customary explanation: The ball had got away from him. The umpire made the customary re sponse, meaning, Tell that to your confessor.

title: How to Choose the Right Architect and Vice Versa
description: I. M. Pei will probably say no, and Philip Johnson may refer you to a colleague. Charles Gwathmey may accept, but only if be likes you. Finding an architect to design a home can be a challenge.

title: Sneed Takes FiveStroke Lead in Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 14  They don't concede putts in professional golf, but sometimes they do concede tournaments. As Ed Sneed completed the third round of the Masters today at 12 under par and with a fivestroke lead over Tom Watson and Craig Stadler, the consensus among his closest rivals was that he would be a shooin tomorrow.

title: Are 76ers on Verge Of Promised Goal?
description: There was Lloyd Free, who was allWorld on earth, and Darryl Dawkins, who was allWorld on Lovetron, his very own planet. There was Collins, the

title: Gambling on the Facts in New York
description: Although the temporary commission to Investigate casino gambling has not yet made even an interim report, prominent New Yorkers, including Governor Carey and Mayor Koch, are already squabbling over where the gambling goose will be invited to lay her golden eggs. They should instead be making sure the goose is capable of laying them anywhere.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The 197879 season of the Metropolitan Opera ended yesterday, and it's statisticflinging time again. The season saw five new productions. There were ten operas in Italian, seven in German, four in English, two in French and one in Russian: 24 in all, for a total of 214 performances. Of the operas in English, only one  Benjamin Britten's Billy Budd was originally intended to be thus sung. The others were translated operas: Humperdinck's Hansel and Gretel Poulenc's Dialogues of the Carmelites and Smetana's Bartered Bride. The most frequently performed opera was Tosca, with 13 performances. The least was Parsifal, with four.

title: IN THE NATION Oil And Snake Oil
description: Our nation's energy problem is very serious and it's getting worse, President Carter insisted in his recent speech on the matter. The energy crisis is real.

title: 8 Years of Terror Comes to an End In Battered Uganda
description: As a new Provisional Government in Kampala was sworn in last week, Radio Uganda called on the citizenry to hunt down deposed President for Life Idi Amin and validate his selfproclaimed title by stringing him up. But crovenunent commandos were unable to find the elusive General whose private escape plane and Libyan crew were reported awaiting him.

title: A New Era for Cultural Programming on TV
description: Two booms are occurring at once in this country, one cultural, one technological, and each holds implications for the other.

title: Public Endorses Bulletproof Vests
description: The other day a New York City police officer, Robert D. Perry, who was assigned to the 79th Precinct in Brooklyn, was startled when his landlords, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Villano, handed him $100 to buy a bulletproof vest. The officer explained that he could not accept such gift personally and offered to forward the money to the Vest Fund Drive of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: Letters: New Input on Pocket Electronic Translators
description: To the Editor:

title: Having It Both Ways On the Economy
description: With inflation running at an annual rate of 15.4 percent so far this year, the cost of rosecolored glasses is climbing along with everything else. Not Only did the Administration claim victory for its wageprice standards in last week's International Brotherhood of Teamsters settlement, it has found in the brevity of the shutdown  it lasted 12 days  a justification for considering a boost in interest rates above their already historic highs, to try to slow down the economy.

title: Drew Casertano Fiance of Linda O'Connor
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hartley O'Connor of Brorucville, N.Y., and Shelter Island, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Linda Sturges O'Connor, to Drew Jon Casertano, son of Nicholas Casertano of Woodbury, Conn., and Mrs. Dolores Casertano of Cheshire, Conn. A June 23 wedding is planned on Shelter Island.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Of Special Interest

title: Simplifying the State Courts Has Never Been a Simple Matter
description: The Court of Special Sessions, the Magistrates Courts, the Children's Court  these New York institutions have faded from memory, the victims of past attempts to simplify the state's court structure.

title: Steve McQueen Goes for Ibsen But Hollywood Doesn't
description: HOLLYWOOD

title: 3 TeenAgeis Accused OfSetting 11 L.J. Fires
description: Three teenagers have been charged with separately starting 11 fires, part of what the police describe as a wave of arson that has badly damaged more than a hundred unoccupied homes in North Bellport, L.I.

title: East Berlin Curbs Access to News
description: EAST BERLIN, April 14  East Germany today announced new restrictions on foreign journalists, forbidding them to interview people without official permission.

title: POLITICS
description: RONALD BLACKWOOD stood before the 79 Republican district leaders in Mount Vernon last Tuesday with an expression of calm and determination as be made a case for why the party's city committee should designate him, black man, as their candidate for mayor in November.

title: Maoists Slay 4 in Philippines
description: MANILA. April 19 (Reuters)  Maoist guerrillas of the underground New People's Army shot and killed four persons, including two soldiers, this week in the far southeastern province of Davao del Sur, military sources said today.

title: GHANAIANS REPLACE
description: ACCRA, Ghana  After initial panic, Ghanaians have reacted with cautious optimism to the introduction of the new, improved cedi, the national currency.

title: Georgia Dent, P. A. Knisely Plan to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Dent Jr. of Lewiston, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Georgia Louise Dent, to Patrick Allen Knisley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen H. Knisley of Fairborn. Ohio.

title: Susan Gregory To Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Gregory of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Faith Gregory, to Ermilo Hamra Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Barera of Park Ridge, III., and Merida, Mexico. A July wedding is planned.

title: Jersey Cicadas Emerge, but They're a Far Cry From Biblical Locusts
description: It may be the season of Passover, when the biblical plague of locusts is remembered, but the oneandahalfinchlong insects now emerging from narrow holes in some New Jersey lawns, though locustlike, are hardly of biblical proportions.

title: The Stakes For New York: A Dialogue on Legal Casinos
description: Casino gambling, long talked about in New York, once again a hot issue, spurred by the apparent success of the first casino in Atlantic City. If the New York State Legislature approves a bill this spring to legalize casino gambling, the question will be put before the voters at a referendum in November. Last month, Bernard Rome, chairman the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation, ran afoul of Mayor Koch by announcing his opposition to legal casinos, a view that cost him his job. Mr. Rome has now become chairman of People Against Casinos Inc. A panel named by Governor Carey to study casino gambling is scheduled to make its report tomorrow, but the odds are that its conclusion will only fuel a new debate, not settle the old one. Neither Mr. Koch nor Peter J. Solomon, Deputy Mayor for Economic Policy and Development, would agree to debate Mr. Rome face face, so the two sides were interviewed separately by Lee Dembart, City Hall bureau chief of The New York Times. Mr. Rome and Mr. Solomon both dwelled on the issue of anticipated revenues. Following are excerpts from the inter

title: Guest Observer Carnival
description: GIBSONTON, Fla. The Giant is gone now, and so is Casper, the midget police chief of the place that show people have nicknamed Gibtown, the winter residence of traveling carnivals. Unsus petting motorists zipping along Route 41, a few miles south of Tampa, used to catch their breath if the Giant suddenly loomed at the edge of the highway outside the motel he ran with his wife, Jeanne the HalfLady. Eight feet 4, and weighing 365 pounds, he was something of a landmark.

title: The Region
description: Whenever industrial waste goes astray and an expensive cleanup is called for, the companies involved often blame an act of God or the innocent mistake of a hired hand. But there were fresh reminders last week that not all industrial pollution is accidental or innocent.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: POTHOLES can talk, as any driver who is conversant with them knows. What they say, mostly, is thunk, and the translation, mostly, is trouble.

title: Middletown Diner Fare: Pie and Hindsight
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., April 12 Karl Kupp Sr. bounded into Kuppy's Diner beside the railroad spur near the corner of Poplar and Brown Streets. He waved to a son and grandson behind the counter who were waiting on custom. ers and, in a style that Texas Guinan might have envied, shouted, Hello, suckers!

title: ANTIQUES
description: When the International Antiquarian Book Fair opens in New York Thursday afternoon, there will be thousands of books available that represent varying degrees of rarity. scarcity and value. And when the largest annual gathering in America of rarebook dealers ends Saturday evening, and,the 128 participating dealers pack up their unsold treasures and leave the Sheraton Center, Seventh Avenue at 52d Street, they will probably have no better understanding than they do now of why the public responds the way it does to that what is rare, scarce or valuable.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Brian Friel's Faith Healer ends with James Mason Marching heavily toward us in the weak first light of an Irish September morning. He is measuring out his breath to match his effortful steps,.but his eyes are beginning to smile. He is on his way to perform a miracle that he knows he cannot perform. He also knows that if he does not perform it, he will be killed. The certainty relieves him. Speaking himself in the past tense, because the play is all memory, he tells us that at long last! was renouncing chance.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: The news story began: LONDON, Feb_ 8 (AP)  The United States Army is paying $12,000 to a British social scientist to find out whether American soldiers would like to join unions. That was a year ago, and Gwyn HarriesJenkins, a lecturer at Hull University, was said to be doing the 15month study.

title: What the Army Learned From Business
description: It has been fashionable since the introduction of the allvolunteer army in 1973 to note with favor the extent to which the United States Army has incorporated a number of techniques and practices first developed by business. Actually, the military's tendency to imitate the trends, tactics, values and even the vocabulary of American business began sometime ago, only reaching a peak during the Vietnam conflict and the start of the volunteer army.

title: A FgronardFestival At theFrick
description: The great French painter and draftsman JeanHonore Fragonard was a man of pleasure and a man of peace. He lived through a revolution, but he would never have started one. The amiable Frago was his nickname, and he enjoyed living up to it.

title: Rebecca Fish Will Become Bride
description: The engagement of Rebecca Elizabeth Fish to Arthur K. Watson Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John H. Fish of Rowley. Mass., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mrs. Stuart Symington of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Watson. who was chairman of the board of the International Business Machines World Trade Corporation and Ambassador to France under President Richard M. Nixon.

title: STAMPS
description: The finest of early American toleware or decorated tinware is depicted on a block of four that is coming out this Thursday. This is the latest in the ongoing American Folk Art Series,

description: THE FUTURE OF INTELLECTUALS AND THE RICE OF THE NEW CLASS

title: Michael Rourke Rogers Will Marry Anita Lippitt
description: Dr. and Mrs. Deverewc Haigh Lippitt of New Bern, N.C., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Anita Walthour Lippitt, to Michael Rourke Rogers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Charles Rogers of Reading, Mass. A June 30 wedding is planned.

title: The Nation
description: The crisis at the Three Mile Island power plant in Pennsylvania was declared ended last week, but not the crisis , of confidence. As radiation levels dropped and evacuees began returning to their homes in the area along the Susquehanna River, President Carter named an 11member commission, headed by Dartmouth president John G. Kemeny, to find ways to prevent similar nuclear reactor accidents in the future.

description: Mr. and Mrs. John D. DelVecchio of Cheshire, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia DelVecchio, to Jeffrey A. Newfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Newfield of West Hartford, Conn. A May 13 wedding at the chapel of the Loomis Chaffee School in Windsor is planned.

title: Rubber Workers Confront Strike Decision Tuesday
description: DETROIT, April 14  With ratification of a new contract between the teamsters union and trucking industry apparently certain, the attention of industry and labor is shifting to talks between the nation's major rubber products manufacturers and their workers, whose contract expires next Friday.

title: Cauthen Tastes English Justice
description: KEMFION, England, April 14 (UPI)  Steve Cauthen, the young American jockey, was deprived of his first major success in Britain today when, after finishing first in the Easter Stakes, his horse was relegated to second place after a stewards inquiry.

title: Henry Devin Fiance of Alessandra Hillinan
description: Mrs. William Hillman of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Alessandra Anna Hillman, to Henry Cave Devine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Devine of Wilton, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Winterthur Museum, Gardens in Spring Show
description: Through May 27 Winterthur Museum and Gardens Winterthur, Del., is presenting its Winterthur in Spring showing every day but Monday in two sections  the Washington Wing, which offers a chronological look at the things Americans lived with in their homes from the 17th century until 1850, and the Main Museum, normally seen by reservation only, which has turrusnings mom the Queen Anne, Chippendale, Federal and Empire periods. Furniture, glass, ceramics, textiles, needlework, paintings, prints, silver and other metals are displayed in rooms paneled with architectural elements taken from homes that once stood along the Eastern Seaboard.

title: Jailed Fugitive of West Germany To Ask U.S. Judge for Release
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)  Lawyers for Kristina Berster, a West German fugitive jailed for nine and a half months since she illegally entered the United States, say they will now ask a Federal judge to free her pending a decision whether she will be deported.

title: Dena Hofkosh Sets Bridal for May 27
description: Dena Hofkosh and Jay Weiskopf, seniors at the New York University School of Medicine, will be married on May 27. Mr. and Mrs. Jack M. Hofkosh have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jessie Weiskopf of New Rochelle. N.Y.

title: Changing Committee May Make Difficulties for the President's Program
description: WASHINGTON  At first, 1979 had seemed like a quiet year for the Senate Finance Committee  two important health matters, a trade package, a few other interesting items, but no wrenchingly controversial tax issues. Then came the President's new energy proposals, for which Mr. Carter campaigned hard last week, and the Senate's most powerful committee was back on center stage.

title: Johnstone's Slam Wins for Yanks
description: CHICAGO, April 14  Fantasy gave way to reality for a nearcapacity crowd of 43,373 at Comiskey Park today when Jay Johnstone hit a pinch grandslam homer in the eighth inning that propelled the New York Yankees to an 85 victory over the Chicago White Sox. Ron Guidry nailed down the victory with three pitches to the only batter he faced.

title: New G.M. Cars Boon For N. Tarrytown
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN THE new frontwheeldrive compact cars  the socalled Xbody design  that General Motors is placing on sale at dealers across the country beginning Thursday, are in many instances a Westchester product: more specifically, the product of G.M.'s Assembly Division plant in this Hudson River community.

title: Hilda Fishbein Bloom Is Bride
description: Hilda Fishbein Bloom of Riverdale, the Bronx, widow of Howard Bloom, was married last evening to Robert Cole, a widower of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi H. Leonard Poller performed the ceremony at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club. The bride, an elementaryschool teacher, was graduated from Hunter College, from which she also received an M.A. degree. Her husband is a graduate of the University of Wisconsin.

title: ART
description: STORRS ROBERT MOTHERWELL is not easily designated a Connecticut artist, and his work, alighting at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, looks like some large, exotic bird blown off its accustomed course. Nevertheless, filling the William Benton Museum to capacity, this artist of international renown has never seemed more complete or his contribution so distinct.

title: Miss Everard Sets Nuptials For Sept. 29
description: Dorothy Mary Everard, daughter of Mrs. C. Clifford Everard of Sheffield, Yorkshire, England, and the late Dr. Everard, and John Dexter Laupheimer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Laupheimer of Philadelphia and Palm Beach, Fla., plan to be married on Sept. 29 in Sheffield.

title: Blacks and the Klan Clash Again in Selma, After Decade of Peace
description: SELMA, Ala., April 14  Racial conflict returned to Selma today when a Ku Klux Klan march led to a rockthrowing and shouting confrontation with blacks on the city's streets, shattering a decade of relative harmony between the races.

title: Dropouts in Sharkskin Suits
description: JUST as you've always suspected, crime pays. Not the twobit burglaries, purse snatchings and subway muggings that inflate statistics and clog the courts, but the sort of crime described as organized. Twenty years ago, one of the organizers, Meyer

title: At 75, John Gielgud Looks Back and to the Future
description: WOTTON UNDERWOOD, England, April 14 Isn't it odd? the tall man asked. When we were young, the actors in my generation, we all had thin faces. Now we're fat.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WNETHER you are replacing an old fence post that has cracked or rotted or are putting up a new fence, the strongest way to erect any post is to set it in a concrete footing or base. However, when a wood post is set in concrete, caution is required to prevent premature weakening due to rot that starts below the ground level line. In almost every case, this can be avoided if three simple steps are taken when buying the lumber and installing the posts in their concrete sleeves.

title: Charlotte Vernon Lewis Is Fiance of Dawson Glover 3d
description: Charlotte Vernon Lewis and Dawson Coleman Glover 3d plan to be married May 19 at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in Lafayette, La.

title: A New Poll Last Week Contained Some More Bad News
description: WASHINGTON  Polls have been bid news for President Carter for months, revealing with a thudding persistence that the American public does not like the way he handles his job, thinks he lacks leadership qualities and believes he cannot cope with inflation. Last week, he even managed to get discouraging news from a poll that never once asked how he was doing.

title: Melissa Ann Meell Slates Nuptials on June 9
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Meell of Drexel Hill, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Melissa Ann Meell, to Dr. Stephen Brendan Richardson, son of Dr. Thomas Richardson of London and the late Eileen Margaret Richardson. A June 9 wedding is planned.

title: Carey Will Be Queried On TV on Wednesday
description: Governor Carey will answer telephoned questions for an hour starting at 10 P.M. Wednesday on New York State's public television stations.

title: Supreme Court in Utah Is Asked To Allow Cameras in Courtrooms
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 19 (AP) The Society of Professional Journalists has asked the Utah Supreme Court to allow limited the use of cameras and tape recorders in courtrooms in a oneyear exneriment.

title: Bullets Loaded for Defense of Crown
description: In the midst of the Washington Bullets run to the National Basketball Association championship last season, Coach Dick Motta sounded the lone sobering note.

title: Yale, Navy Eights Triumph in Rowing
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 14  The Yale and the Navy varsity eights won their races here today in a 16event rowing regatta on Carnegie Lake. The Elis routed Northeastern and Rutgers in the fastest race of the day, 6 minutes 20 seconds for the victors, while the Midshipmen held off a Princeton rally to beat the Tigers by a second over the rainswent 2.000meter course.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: If the fact that there are children in this world without shoes and private beds isn't a basic fact about the world, what is? ("Enfield Ponders the World's Ills, April I) One of the more basic fact of life and the world is that although we are all human beings, we come in different shapes, sizes, colork and socioeconomic classes, etc.

title: Chatty, Witty, Brilliant, Sad
description: WHAT do you want to be, little girl, when you grow up? a patronizing visitor asked 3yearold Edith Sitwell. A genius, she snapped, without hesitation.

title: Feud Splits S.C.L.C.; Leader Vows to Keep Headquarters Secure
description: ATLANTA, April 14 (UPI)  The president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, which has been torn by a feud within the national leadership, said today that he would continue to keep guard at the organization's national headquarters, where a scuffle erupted last night.

title: Kathleen Kelly McNulty Wed
description: Kathleen Kelly McNulty, who as Kelly McNulty is manager of Bloomingdale's video studio, was married yesterday to Philip A. Brandmeier, who on May 1 becomes vice president for realestate planning at the American Express Company. The Rev. Joseph F. O'Rourke, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations. Mrs. Charles H. McNulty of Bayside, Queens, is the mother of the bride, whose husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Brandmeter of Rochester.

title: Galindez Regains World Title
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 14  More in pain than in defeat Mike Rossman's reign as lightheavyweight champion ended after seven months today when he was unable to answer the bell for the 10th round of his rematch with Victor Galindez because of a possible fractured right wrist.

title: Persecution Was an Old Story
description: IN 1942, Albert Camus, then living near the town of Le Chambon in southeastern France, started work on The Plague. In that novel, Dr. Rieux organized the citizens of Oran to fight a mysterious plague, which represented man's mindless need to kill. In essence, the novel concerned a leader devoted to saving lives in a time of calamity, life being the supreme value.

description: Milwaukee In Program Of Sibelius

title: Fiddler Returns, Still a Delight
description: WESTBURY ONE might assume that Fiddler on the Roof is by now a victim of overexposure, that Tevye, the Dairyman, could use a little rest, and that everyone has seen it at least twice, in one of its multilingual versions or another. Wrong.

description: DUBE

title: Nunez Reaches Tennis Final
description: EDGEWATER, N.J., April 14  Unseeded Hugo Nunez of Rockaway. N.J., celebrated his 18th birthday today by beating Mike DePalmer of Palmetto, Fla., in a 2hour55minute semifinal in the boys 18 division of the 12th Easter Bowl junior tennis tournament at the Binghamton Racquet Club.

title: Papal Essay Asks Analysis to Deal With Terrorism
description: ROME, April 14  Pope John Paul II, in an essay published yesterday, expressed his dismay over terrorism and violence, especially in Italy, and called for social analysis of their causes.

description: Today

title: Winning the Game With a Hot Theory
description: Early in June, at Harwich Port on Cape Cod, the Boston Consulting Group will conduct its annual conference for chief executive officers. The quality of the crowd  the chief executives of Digital Equipment, American Standard, Memorex and Standard Oil of Indiana will be among those in attendance  says something about the vast groundswell of interest that has developed in the last few years in corporate competitive strategies. But it says more about B.C.G.'s chief executive, Bruce Henderson, and the role he has played in creating and exploiting one of the most influential theories in the field.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: IT seems safe to record that the first of Westchester County's new buses has gone into regular passenger service. After many missed deadlines and false starts  the latest problem being what the county said were defects in the first group of buses delivered by General Motors the buses are winding through city streets carrying riders.

title: A TwoDay Tour Of Edinburgh's HistoryRich Hinterland
description: Ruskin was wrong. He did not like Edinburgh (he found the symmetry and the starkness of the Georgian squares oppressive) but I consider it one of the three most beautiful cities in Britain. along with London and Bath.

title: Trade Liberalizing Pact Signed, Could Help Combat Inflation
description: After five years of balky negotiations among the world's trading nations, trade officials for the industrialized countries initialed a sweeping agreement to liberalize trade in Geneva.

title: Maureen J. O'Brien To Be Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. O'Brien of Franklin Lakes, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maureen Joan O'Brien, to Michael Edward Zmuda, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Zmuda of Elk Grove, Ill. A June wedding is planned.

title: NEGOTIATORS REACH PACT IN OTB STRIKE
description: A tentative settlement of the 20dayold strike of 1,000 Offtrack Betting Corporation workers was announced last night by their union president, Victor Gotbaum, raising the prospect of the betting parlors resuming full operations tomorrow.

title: Mexico's Agrarian Revolution Yields to Industrial Future
description: MEXICO CITY, April 14  In a brief ceremony marking the 60th anniversary of the murder of Emiliano Zapata, President Jose L6pez Portillo this week raised a white flag outside the ruins of the Chinameca hacienda where the revolutionary hero was shot down.

description: NEWARK

title: The Satisfactions of Adopting
description: MARK is a 9yearold potential Olympic runner. Ask his father, who times him with his stopwatch. Noth1, 4 unusual, except that Mark is black his father is white.

title: Pope Reaffirms Celibacy Rule
description: Ecclesiastical celibacy is not a dogma, Pope John MCIII once remarked to a visitor. The Scriptures do not impose it. It is even easy to effect the change. I take up a pen, I sign a decree and, the next day, priests who wish to may get married. But he could not bring himself to do it, he said, even though the thing that distressed him most as Pope was the thought of those young priests for whom celibacy is a martyrdom.

title: Euripides With Spirit
description: PORT JEFFERSON Well, it was a little catharsis. This was a line Mike Nichols and Elaine May once improvised tosharply satiric effect. Theater Three's production of Euripides's The Trojan Women recalls it, though not so flippantly.

title: GARDENING
description: HIGH school students will be in great demand as soon as the grass turns green, that is, if they have a power lawn mower that works and know a few basics on lawn care.

title: Blumenthal and Wife to Separate After a Trial Reconcilation Fails
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)  W. Michael Blumenthal, Secretary of the Treasury, and his wife, Eileen, have agreed to separate after a year's attempt at reconcilation, an aide to Mr. Blumen that said today.

title: On Language The Word From Eejay
description: Eejay  or E.J. stands for electronic journalism, a phrase coined two decades ago by Eric Sevareid, and used today to denote a new, portable television camera that records on videotape and broadens the scope of television news coverage. BY synecdoche the term describes the wide world of television journalism which is developing a lexicon of its own:

title: A Macaroon Called Sarah Bernhardt
description: AT the height of her astounding career, the actress Sarah Bernhardt had received every honor and award possible, including Oscar Wilde's lasting appellation, the Divine Sarah. But if legend be believed, one of the most treasured rewards of her eccentric life was a small chocolate macaroon she enjoyed on her first trip to Denmark.

title: Dollar Diplomacy in the Middle East
description: As far as we can determine, the dowries that President Carter promised Egypt and Israel for their peacemaking would cost the United States an additional $500 million a year for the next three years. Most of that will be gifts. The rest will generate huge loans for military purchases, largely in the United States, but these will be repaid with normal commercial interest. If peace can truly be served at these amounts, it's a bargain.

title: A New Judy Collins Sings Pop Without Her Guitar
description: These may be Hard Times for Lovers  that's the title of Judy Collins's latest album  but they seem to be good times for Miss Collins, who was at Avery Fisher Hall Friday night. A metamorphosis has taken place. Miss Collins, who began as a folkie, sang protest songs, and then took up the cause of various popart songwriters, from Jacques Brel to Leonard Cohen, is loosening up. She did quite well during her first set Friday night without her acoustic guitar, and while her soprano was as sweet as ever, there was a new toughness to her singing and, especially. her presence.

title: Himalayan Adventure In Sikkim
description: From ShangriLa to Trouble in Paradise  that almost sums up the way Westerners have changed their views two decades about the tiny Asian kingdom of Sikkim, tucked away high in the Himalayas above India, below Tibet, between Nepal and Bhutan.

title: The Date of His Choice
description: From Penrod to Andy Hardy, anxiety over the junior prom has been a staple of American teenage lore. Boys suffer over not being able to capture the most copular girl in town, and the less popular girls suffer over not being captured. But 17yearold Paul Gilbert, of Cumberland, R.I., had no trouble getting a date. His problem is that his father says he can't go to the prom because his choice of partner is unconventional: Paul has asked another boy.

title: Reflections on a Marathon
description: I always cry after I run a marathon race. It does not matter whether I have run well. I feel the emotional climax so intensely that I find myself in tears after the 26mile385yard distance has been completed.

title: Caren Stunner Betrothed To Randall M. Rosenthal
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Morton Feldman of East Rockaway, L.I., of the engagement of Mrs. Feldman's daughter, Caren Stunner, to Randall Marc Rosenthal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Rosenthal of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: NEW UGANDA LEADER
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, April 14  Yusufu K. Lule, who was sworn in yesterday as Uganda's new President, said at a news conference today that his troops were meeting very little resistance as they moved into what he called the unliberated areas of eastern and northern Uganda.

title: Muted Trumpets for World Trade Accord
description: When the United States and some 40 other nations initialed new agreements on reducing barriers to imports last week, five years of negotiations were concluded on a lessthantriumphant note. President Carter bailed the negotiations for bringing a new order to world trade, but disap. pointed developing countries  the majority of the 99 participants  held off signing. The agreements aimed to expand world trade now totaling an estimated $1.3 trillion a year.

title: Music by N.Y.U. Players
description: Friday night's concert by the New York University Contemporary Players at Carnegie Recital Hall included compositions by three N.Y.U. faculty members  Dinu Ghezzo, Brian Fennelly and John Gilbert  as well as selections by Bruce Saylor, Virgil Thomson, Luciano Berio and Edgard Varese.

title: Wood, Field. and Stream Proposal Advanced To Aid Striped Bass
description: A laudable effort to replenish rapidly dwindling stocks of striped bass along the east coast of. the United States has been launched by Rhode Island's Sena. tor John H. Chafee.

title: SelfAbandoned SelfService
description: ALL I wanted was cottage cheese and a pint of yogurt. An hour and a half later and 534.83 poorer, I left the market, pushing the usual crippled cart (with one intractable wheel) loaded with four brown bags plus a 25pound sack of kitty litter, a 40pound sack of fertilizer, an eightpound bag of potting soil and a big yucca.

title: According To Lattimore
description: THE gospels of Mark, Matthew, Luke and John are surely the most frequently translated literary texts. Through their nearly 2,000year life, they have undergone repeated honor, travesty ana assault at the hands of individuals and committees intent upon converting their extreme originality of content and form into virtually all human vernaculars. In English the supremely successful version has been the one authorized by James I and published, with the remainder of the Hebrew and Greek Bible, in 1611. In its latest revision  the Revised Standard  it remains the most reliable of committee versions (its famous eloquence being largely a function of a dedication to literalness on the part of the men who produced and revised it).

title: Motocross: The Ordeal on Wheels Is Revving Up
description: BARRY KRUPOWICZ is determined to be shape when this year's motocross schedule opens Saturday at the Bridgehampton Race Circuit. Since early winter, the 35yearold autobody repairman from Brentwood has been lifting weights, running several miles daily and doing special calisthenics. He has also quit drinking beer and smoking.

title: 41 Cars Derail on Freight Line
description: VAUGHN, N.M., April 14 (UPI) broken roller bearing on a Santa Fe Railway freight car was blamed today for 91car derailment and a fire in a sparsely populated area of eastern New Mexico. The fire, which erupted when one of the cars loaded with lubricating oil burst into flames, was still burning late today.

title: Nuclear Firemen
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The Three Mile Island accident has given new meaning to the saying that the world seems tiny when your enemy is loose. In an age of extreme nuclear interdependence  when, for example, a radiation leak in Bombay can conceivably cause serious illness in Los Angeles  a global approach to potential atomic disaster is imperative. Yet the international community has hardly begbn to think collectively about the problem, let alone plan coordinated action in the event of an emergency.

title: Melissa Fast Becomes Bride of Alexander Bozuslawski
description: Melissa Fast and Alexander Boguslawski, graduate students at the University of Kansas, were married in the Danforth Chapel on the university campus in Lawrence yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Eldon Fields of the Unitarian Fellowship performed the ceremony.

title: 3 Vermont Judges Bar Prosecutor, a Nonlawyer, From Courtrooms
description: NEWPORT, Vt., April 14  The county prosecutor here has been barred from the courtroom by three judges.

title: Deaths
description: FORDHowells Townsend. On April 13, 1979, at White Plains HospitalWhite Plains, N.Y. Beloved husband of Nancy Turner Ford. Devoted father of Cornelia Ford ColasGrandfather of Charles F. Coles. Jr. Memorial service Tuesday. Neil 17 at The Brick Presbyterian Church, 915? and Park Ave,N.Y.C.. at 12:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers. contributions may be sent to Memorial Hospital, 1775 York Ave. N.Y.C. 10021

title: Food
description: In Germany, Austria and Switzerland. spring blossoms forth first and most abundantly not in parks and gardens, but in the whitelace and organdycurtained windows of the KonditoreiKaffeehaus, that parties ular North European institution that combines the functions of a retail bakery and candy shop with those of a cafetearoomrestaurant.

title: Terrorism Inquiry in Italy Finds
description: ROME, April 14  In a broadening inquiry into a new wave of terrorism, the Italian police and secret services are being urged to step up their search for 150 ultraleftists, mostly young people, who have dropped out of sight and are believed to have gone underground.

title: China's Sensuous Gardens
description: To the untutored Western eye, the first impression is chaos. The Chinese garden  contrasting with the contemplative, serene, orderly and more easily grasped Japanese garden  appears to be a restless, anarchic, crowded place, with jumbles of pockmarked, grotesque rocks, buildings, bedless plantings and no lawns at all.

title: Hundreds Are Killed in Yugoslavia's Strongest. Quake
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 15 An earthquake rolled across the southern Adriatic coast of Yugoslavia today, leveling villages and killing and injuring hundreds of people.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Iran announced a 13 percent increase in its oil prices to $16.57 a barrel for light crude and $16.04 for heavy and suggested that OPEC would raise prices again when it meets in June. Iran also disclosed its output had climbed to 4.7 million barrels on April 13. [Page A1.]

title: Michigan Is a Battlefield Over Spiraling Health Costs
description: DETROIT, April 15  Southeastern Michigan, long a leader in developing broad healthcare services and benefits, is turning into a battleground over containing the resultant spiraling costs.

title: Zoeller, in Playoff, Captures Masters On First Attempt
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 15  Fuzzy Zoeller, a cheerful 27yearold extrovert who likes to exchange wisecracks with galleries, won the 43d Masters today on the second hole of a suddendeath playoff with Tom Watson and Ed Sneed.

title: Miss Austin Wins, 7-6, 7-6
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., April 15  The malady that afflicts almost all tennis players  choking  gripped Tracy Austin for the first time today, but she still managed a 76, 76 victory over Kerry Reid in the final of a $150,000 women's tournament.

title: New York as Landlord in Tax Foreclosures
description: In fiscal terms, it was a victory for Mayor Koch that the Carter Administration authorized the use of $100 million in community development money to help operate taxforeclosed property. But in housing terms, the fact that New York

title: Last Week's Active Issues
description: For the week ended April 12, 1979.

title: TwoCar Collision Near Brewster Kills Couple and TeenAge Driver
description: BREWSTER, N.Y., April 15 (UPI)  A couple driving to a sunrise Easter church service and the 19yearold driver of second car, all of the Putnam County town of Patterson, were killed in a headon collision near here early today, the state police reported.

title: A Midtown Center Restores SelfEsteem in ExConvicts
description: Every weekday morning, 19yearold Glenice Pearson wakes up in his room on 110th Street near Lenox Avenue as dawn is breaking through the gray over Central Park. At just about the same time, Gloria Dudwick is waking up in her house on Sprain Valley Road in Scars. dale.

title: Outdoors
description: MOST anglers who pursue striped bass and bluefish are content to catch them in any way possible, but this, I believe, is self deprivation.

title: Deaths
description: SCHREIBER  Louis. Young Israel of Flatbush records with deep sorrow the passing of Louis Schreiber. father of its esteemed member Avram H. Schreiber. May the mourners be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHAT is the New Class that is taking over? According to Alvin W. Gouldner, Max Weber Professor of Social Theory at Washington University in St. Louis, the New Class consists of scientists, educators, managers, communicators, publicity agents, maybe even literary critics and other professionals, whose business it is to run the culture. Culture  knowledge and skills  is in fact the capital of the New Class.

title: Deaths
description: FORD  Howeth Townsend. On April 13, 1979. of White Plains HospitalWhite Plains, N.Y. Beloved husband of Nancy Turner Ford. Devoted father of Cornella Ford ColesGrandfather of Charles F. Coles, Jr. Memorial service Tuesday. April 17 at The Brick Presbyterian Church. 91 St and Park Ave.N.Y.C., at 12:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, con tributions may be sent to Memorial Hospital. 1275 York Ave. N.Y.C. 10121

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: When an article embracing numerous Moroccan dishes appeared, the opinion was printed that the cuisine of Morocco is. to my taste. one of the 10 greatest.

title: POPE MAKES APPEAL FOR WORLD'S POOR
description: ROME, April 15  Pope John Paul II, in an Easter message today, appealed for peace and human rights, and strongly reminded a great throng at St. Peter's of the plight of poor people and especially the sufferings of destitute children.

title: LOUIS L. HORCH, 90, FOUNDER OF MUSEUM
description: Louis L. Horeb, a specialist in international exchange and the founder of the Master Institute of United Arts in New York City, died last week at his home in Hallandale, Fla. He was 90 years old.

title: Columnist Asserts Libyan Leader Tried to Buy ABomb From China
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)  A Washington columnist says that Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the Libyan leader, sent an aide to China in 1971 in an effort to buy a nuclear bomb from the Peking Government.

title: Yagla Again Victor
description: AMES, Iowa, Apnl 15 (AP)  Chuck Yagla of the Hawkeye Wrestling Club of Iowa City won his third straight title Saturday at the national Amateur Athletic Union freestyle wrestling championships.

title: Advertising
description: THE leaders of 10 of the country's largest ad agencies are unanimous in their personal belief that agencies should not pursue accounts that conflict with those they already have. That, however, does not mean it never happens.

title: Concert: Mahler Second
description: SERGIU COMISSIONA and the American Symphony Orchestra offered an Easter program yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall that ended with a really inspiring account of Mahler's Symphony No. 2 in C minor (Resurrection).

title: Washington Watch
description: NEW confrontations loom between Congress and the White House over the legislative veto. That is a provision that allows Congress  at times both chambers and at times only one  to veto new regulations issued by various Federal agencies. Congress has contended that the provision is an important part of legislative oversight and has been adding it to new laws with increasing frequency.

title: Notes on People
description: This is an important day for 17yearold Paul Guilbert of Cumberland, R.I. He expects to find out today whether he'll get a hearing before the town's school committee on his request to take a male escort to his high school junior prom. Since Mr. Guilbert made his wishes known, school officials have turned him down, other students have taunted him, civilliberties lawyers have come to his aid and one more test of changing social standards has been created.

title: Billy Carter Confirms Libya Paid For His '78 Visit to Arab Country
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 15  Billy Carter has confirmed that the Libyan Government paid for his trip to Rome and Tripoli last fall, but he steadfastly denies the suggestion that he had any business dealings with the Government of Col. Muammar elQaddafi.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a box accompanying the Personal Health column on sleeping pills in The Living Section last Wednesday, the wrong address was given for the place to write for referral to a sleep clinic. The correct address is American Association of Sleep Disorders Centers, Sleep Disorders Program. SUNY at Stony Brook, Health Sciences Center, Stony Brook, N.Y. 11794.

title: Edward S. Reddig, Retired Head Of Consolidated Industries, at 74
description: CLEVELAND, April 15  Edward S. Reddig, retired board chairman of White Consolidated Industries Inc., died today in University Hospitals here. He was 74 years old.

title: Bond Baking Cuts Back
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15 (UPI) The financially troubled Bond Baking Company has closed its distribution centers in northern New Jersey, a company spokesman has confirmed. The centers in Edison, Asbury Park and Clifton were closed Tuesday when the entire company was threatened by a lack of cash. Bond got a $500,000 loan from the Philadelphia National Bank and reopened its Philadelphia baking operations and its distribution centers in southern New Jersey Thursday.

title: Israelis Kill Palestinian Guerrillas Who Mounted Raid From Jordan
description: JERUSALEM, April 15  An Israeli Army force killed four Palestinian guerrillas who crossed the Jordan River into northern Israel this morning, according to a military spokesman. He said there were no Israeli casualties.

title: Rangers Gird for Flyers
description: If ever a National Hockey League series was destined to go the full seven games, it is the quarterfinal matchup between the Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers that starts at 8:05 tonight in the Spectrum. The winning score will probably come in the second overtime period, when a clearing pass caroms off a defenseman's skate, hits a goal post and trickles off the stick of an unlucky goalie and into the cage.

title: Age ot Anxiety
description: An economic setback, whether it be inflation or recession, is commonly described only in economic terms: rising prices, falling profits or increased unemployment. Rarely are there graphs or charts to show the effect of these cold statistics on people's lives.

title: The Salaries Are Just Fine
description: DURING the summer of 1976, when Americans celebrated the Bicentennial of Mr. Jefferson's Declaration, the barons of baseball still ran a feudal state. Far from the tall ships, I spent the summer wandering baseball fields from Oregon to San Juan. On one particular July night a prominent major league executive offered me an extraordinary document. The papers were marked confidential, but the executive, filling my glass with ballclub liquor, said I was free to cull anything I wanted. His terms? They seemed modest enough. I had only to promise not to identify him by name.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: AMMAN. Jordan, April 15  Jordan was for years the closest Arab friend of the United States, a reliably moderate state in an area of shifting extremes. Since Camp David and the EgyptianIsraeli treaty, the relation ship has come on hard times. Jorda nians and American diplomatboth speak of strain.

title: G.M.Chrysler Equipment Pact
description: DETROIT. April 15 (UPI)  The General Motors Corporation has agreed to help the Chrysler Corpora tion by selling safety and pollution control equipment to the financially ailing automaker, but a Washingtonbased or- ganization, the Center for Auto Safety, is fighting the plan, charging that it violates a Federal court order that restricts the exchange of emission control technology between automakers.

title: Economic Sag in East Germany
description: LEIPZIG, East Germany  East Germany, celebrating its 30th year as nation, is faced with an economic future that does not look bright.

title: Around the World
description: CAIRO, April 15  President Anwar elSadat said today that he had ordered the police to shoot on the spot anyone who tried to destroy public or private property, the official Middle East News Agency reported.

title: Arbour to Alternate Goalies in Playoffs
description: As confident as ever of the alternatinggoalie system that helped his New York Islanders post the best regularseason record in the National Hockey League, Coach Al Arbour has told Glenn (Chico) Resch and Billy Smith that they will take turns in the net during Stanley Cup play.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Colin Fowles, a defender for the Fort Lauderdale Strikers of the North, American Soccer League, was once clocked in 9.9 seconds for the 100yard dash when he was a student at Long Island University. Fowles thus believes that he is the fastest soccer player in the world. Whether he is or not, 9.9 ought to stand him in good stead. Unless he decides to become a race horse.

title: City Will Press This Week To Settle School Bus Strike
description: The New York City School Chancellor, Frank J. Macchiarola, and the union representing the striking school bus drivers may be nearing a settlement of the nineweekold wildcat walkout, the participants say. But the issue of job security, although now viewed by the Board of Education as negotiable, remains a major sticking point.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Bridge:
description: A bid that is redolent of drama, mystery and confusion is the jump in the middle of the auction in a suit as yet unmentioned. Can it be neutral? And if not, what does it mean?

title: SOVIET GOLD MINING IS UNDER TIGHT LID
description: USTNERA, U.S.S.R.  If you could figure out how much gold the Russians produced in this northeast Siberian mining town, you would probably be thrown into jail for spying. So secret are the figures that the posters outside the mine headquarters do not say how many tons were produced in January and February  they just say, Plan fulfilled.

title: Phils Sweep Mets, 32, 63
description: When the Mets scored 19 runs in their first two games of the year, the offseason trading that had sacrificed pitching to gain offensive punch seemed successful. Yesterday at Shea Stadium, however, the Mets showed little of their early offensive authority as they dropped a doubleheader to the Philadelphia Phillies. 32 and 63.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BOSTON, April 15 (AP)  Carlton Fisk, the Boston Red Sox catcher, was placed on the 15day disabled list today because of a chronic right elbow problem.

title: Deaths
description: AMBROSEAlphonse F. Aged 68. of 983A Heritage Village, Southbury. Conn., formerly of New Rochelle, on April 14, 1979. Beloved husband of Adeline (nee Hager). also six children. Mass 11 A.M. Tuesday, Sacred Heart Church. Southbury. Visitation Monday 24 and 79. Burial 1:30 Gate of Heaven, Hawthorne, N.Y.

title: MISSISSIPPI'S CAPITAL IS FLOODED BY RIVER; 15,000 LEAVE HOMES
description: JACKSON, Miss., April 15  The Pearl River, enlarged by last week's heavy rains, sent murky flood waters into this capital city today, leaving businesses abandoned and forcing an estimated 15,000 people from their homes.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ON THE MOVE Greenwich Village's Westbeth Theater tonight rings in the second season of Mainly Mime, a potpourri of new material by professional mimes, clowns, mask specialists and dramatic acrobats. The en- tertainment is scheduled for Mondays at 8 P.M. through May 28. Tonight's performers are Mark Weiner, who has appeared at the Improvisation and Catch a Rising Star; Ron Little, an avantgarde multimedia comedian, and Jackie Wildau and Kate Bentley, organizers of the mime series at 151 Bank Street.

title: New LightsOut Policies Save the Lives of Migrating Birds
description: The annual spring bird migration, just now getting under way with millions of birds heading north for their summer breeding grounds, has often ended in death for small birds, which tend to crash into lighted structures on cloudy nights.

title: Makeshift Boundary in Uganda Marks Off Freedom and Chaos
description: Makeshift Boundary in Uganda Marks Off Freedom and Chaos

title: IRAN LIFTS OIL PRICE 13% BEYOND OPEC'S
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 15  Iran announced today that it was raising oil prices by 13 percent over the basic level set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Geneva last month. The new prices will be $16.57 for a barrel of Iranian light crude and $16.04 for a barrel of heavy crude.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 28, 2, 21, 8, 18 and 10. The supplementary number was 36.

title: A Victory for Tanzania, a Worry for Africa
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, April 15  The invasion of Uganda by the forces of President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania is a triumph for him personally and for Tanzania, and it has been greeted as welcome news over much of Africa and the world.

title: Strike Duty Chills Umpires
description: It was cold in Boston, and chilly and damp in Pittsburgh. But the major league umpires, who have been on strike since the start of spring training, were still out in force on the picket lines. Most were in Boston, where about 20, led by Richie Phillips, attorney for the Major League Umpires Association, marched outside Fenway Park in 42degree weather before the game between the Red Sox and the Cleveland Indians.

title: Death Toll in Uganda Increases In Wake of Battle for Kampala
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, April 15  The last of some 100 bodies were removed this morning from the headquarters of Idi Amin's secret police, and the Superintendent of Mortuaries continued his grisly task of collecting bodies scattered about the capital.

title: 4 MunicipalWorker Funds Cited In City Audit for Extravagance
description: The New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, reported yesterday that he had found numerous instances of extravagance and abuse in the way that travel expenses had been paid to the trustees of four municipalemployee welfare funds to attend outoftown conventions.

title: PUERTO RICO POLICE INVESTIGATED BY U.S.
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., April 13 A Federal grand jury investigation into the police ambush of two young leftists is roiling the political waters in Puerto Rico as the commonwealth heads toward another round of debate on the. statehood question.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  According to the Theory of Cognitive Dissonance propounded two decades ago by Prof Leon Festinger, the human mind tries to block out information not consonant with previous beliefs or actions: For example, a recent purchaser of a Panasonic videotape recorder tries not to read ads for Sony Betamax.

title: Supplementary OvertheCounter Listings
description: Week Ended April 13, 1979

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: 13 Die in South India Crash

title: Justice Dept. Sets Drive On White Collar Crime
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)  The Justice Department said today it planned to set up offices in 27 cities in a major drive against crime in the suites white collar crimes such as corporate embezzlement, fraud or theft of securities.

title: Life With Mailer: After Four Years, So Far, So Good
description: Norris Church is the kind of woman you always notice at a party. First, she is usually the most beautiful woman there, which is not easy in a city where seems every other woman looks like, or is, a fashion model. She is tall and slender, with almost eerie reddish brown eyes that match her auburn hair, and chalky white skin that seems to have no pores. An other reason you notice her is that the shorter man constantly at her side is Norman Mailer.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, APRIL 16, 1979

title: Connors Defeats Dibbs in 3Set Final
description: TULSA, Okla.. April 15 (UP1)  Topseeded Jimmy Connors, withstanding temperatures of almost 90 degrees, wore down Eddie Dibbs today to post a 67, 75, 61 victory and capture the $50,000 Tulsa Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: Sporting Gear
description: This is Patriots' Day in Massachusetts, and that means another running of the Boston Marathon, perhaps the most appropriate time take a look at some of the newest and most interesting items on the mar. ket for people who take their running seriously.

title: To Be on But Not in The Right
description: Today's selfstyled neoconserva tives are convinced (and some would say convincing) that liberalism  defined for the most part as the demand for Government intervention in social and economic life  is intellectually exhausted. More likely, liberalism is politically exhausted and exiled to the political wilderness where there is a hunger after ideas that have too small a following and spark too little popular responsiveness to constitute a political alternative.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: The Basic Issues in British Election Are Work and Money
description: LONDON, April 15  In the end, the British general election on May 3 may turn on one simple but nebulous question: How long is a voter's memory?

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: As a Norwegian stationed in the United States during World War II, I competed in 1944 on the old Olympic skijumping hill at Lake Placid. The 1980 Winter Olympics and Lake Placid are now a major topic in Norway, country of skiers, and I recently told my grandchildren that I had finished third in a jumping event there. My grandchildren refuse, however, to believe that their whitehaired blimp of a grandfather, now in his middle 60's, sailed through the air for a couple of hundred feet on a pair of boards. Would it be possible to supply proof from your files?

title: Raffle Flavors Berkeley's ProMarijuana Initiative
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 15  In an effort to promote its marijuana decriminalization initiative on the city's ballot Tuesday, a local political organization here is raffling one kilogram of a wellknown leafy substance imported from Colombia.

title: Lakers, Suns Advance
description: DENVER, April 15 (AP)  Kareem AbdulJabbar sank a hook shot with 12 seconds remaining, lifting the Los Angeles Lakers to a 112111 victory over the Denver Nuggets today in the deciding game of their twoofthree National Basketball Association playoff series.

title: Richmond's Harmon Easter Bowl Victor
description: EDGEWATER. N.J., April 15  Size seemed to make a big difference today as Rodney Harmon of Richmond defeated Hugo Nunez of Rockaway. N.J., in the final of the boys' 18yearold division of the Easter Bowl junior tennis tournament.

title: Helena Rubinstein: A Financial Facelift?
description: American cosmetic companies have long enjoyed a singular success in the difficult Japanese consumer market. The Japanese recently expressed their admiration when the KAO Soap Company, Japan's leading manufacturer of synthetic detergents, made a deal to acquire Helena Rubinstein Inc.

title: Where Wright Still Practices Architecture
description: SCOTTSDALE, ARIZ. THE 35 architects who work at Taliesin West, the desert home and studio of the late Frank Lloyd Wright, labor in a 96footlong drafting room that is dominated by a 5foothigh photograph of

title: The Grand Old Man Of the Marathon
description: BOSTON HE is at an age when many men who were once his athletic peers are dead or have long since retired from their sports. Still Johnny Kelley runs on.

title: Jazz: A MoreatEase Ella Fitzgerald
description: FROM year to year, Ella Fitzgerald's performances remain much the same. One can count on a few ballads, some uptempo numbers and some scat pieces, including Flying Home. The songs, when they are not the same from one year to the next, are interchangeable, and she sings with remarkable consistency.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, April 15 (AP)  Black homeowners in some Chicagoarea neighborhoods are paying higher property taxes than whites in comparable homes in other neighborhoods, a University of Illinois research team reports.

title: Rhodesia Mounts Huge Effort to Get Out Black Vote
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 15  The scene has been familiar in Rhodesia since white settlers arrived here in the 1890's: a white farmer standing in a grove of mango and eucalyptus trees addressing farmhands and their families in the Shona language, spoken by more than 80 percent of the country's 6.8 million blacks.

title: Deaths
description: KILVERT  Helen Foss. On Friday, April 13. Widow of B. Cory Kilvert. Mother of Janice Kilvert Murray and B. Cory Kilvert, Jr. Also survived by 11 grandchildren. MEmorial service Brick Presbyterian Church Chaise. Park Ave at 91 St., Tuesday, 3 P.M. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Reece School, 180 East 93 St. New York City, would be deeply appreciated.

title: FixedRate Schedule Lighter for Week
description: This week's volume of fixedincome financing will be down sharply from that of last week, when the Treasury sold a 15year bond issue at a record yield and a fairly large total of corporate and taxexempt bonds were marketed.

title: Clerks to Vote On Pact to End OTB Walkout
description: All 167 shops of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation will reopen in time for today's thoroughbred racing program if the more than 1,000 striking clerks who have kept most of the shops closed since March 27 vote this morning to ratify a contract settlement.

title: New Yorkers Say Farewell to Treasures of King Tut
description: Woman directed visitors to the Treasures of Tutankhamun exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday. It was closing day for the traveling collection of burial artifacts of an Egyptian king who died 3,300 years ago. The poplar show, on view three months in New York, will open next in San Francisco before leaving the U.S., and returning home to Egypt.

title: 2 Killed in 16Car Crash
description: CLEVELAND, Tenn., April 15 (AP) The state police said two persons were killed and at least 19 were injured today when 16 cars collided on a fogshrouded section of Interstate 75 about 30 miles northeast of Chattanooga.

title: U.S. Hockey Team Ties Finland, 11
description: MOSCOW, April 15 (AP)  Joe Mullen, a New Yorker who plays for Boston College, scored early in the final period to give the United States a 11 tie with Finland in the world hockey championship today.

title: Christie Wagner, Actress, Is a Bride
description: The chapel of the Georgetown Visitation Convent in Washington was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Christina Maria Teresa Wagner, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Francis Stephen Wagner of Kensington, Md., to Clifford Aaron Jones, a former Lieutenant Governor of Nevada. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. Ladislaus A. Iranyi, provincial superior of the Piarist Fathers, U.S.A., in Washington.

title: Mundal Gives Gala Welcome To Famed Son
description: MUNDAL, Norway, April 15  On a summer's day in 1856, a farmer named Fredrik Mundal, his wife and their sixyearold son, Ole, set out on a long and perilous journey from this remote village of 400 people, nestled beneath the mighty Jostedalsbre glacier along the spectacular Fjaerlands Fjord.

title: Judge Dismisses Whitmore's Suit Against the City
description: At the age of 19, George Whitmore Jr., became the wrong man in the notorious WylieHoffert career girl murders in New York City. Now, 15 years after he was arrested and six years after he was finally cleared of three murders and an attempted rape, Mr. Whitmore has apparently lost all hope of winning a penny from New York for false imprisonment.

title: An Easter Egg For Fuzzy
description: AUGUSTA, GA. WHEN he arrived at the Augusta National Golf Club Sunday, Fuzzy Zoeller was handed a blue Easter egg by a hometown friend. On it in white letters were the words Fuzzy Zoeller Masters Champ. But not many people took it seriously. Fuzzy Zoeller was then six strokes behind Ed Sneed as the final round of the Masters was about to begin. But he enjoyed his present.

title: TV SPORTS
description: 11:00 (M,T) Baseball. Cleveland Indians vs. Boston Red Sox

title: Music: Robert Thompson Offers Bassoon Pieces
description: ROBERT THOMPSON dug up some real novelties for his program of Baroque bassoon music Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, including sonatas for bassoon and continuo by G. Antonio Berton and Joseph Bodin de Bois- mortier; sonatas for two bassoons ana continuo by Biaggio Marini and bassoon duos by Boismortier. There was even a piece. Le Phenix by Michael Corrette, for four bassoons and continuo.

title: Critical Wall Posters On View in Shanghai Despite Officials' Ban
description: SHANGHAI, April 15  Despite a nationwide crackdown on political dissidents, some wall posters demanding more human rights in China and assailing the Shanghai police are still being pasted up here in the country's largest city.

title: Foreign Players Fear Loss of Visas
description: Renewal of visas, not deportation, the primary concern of many foreign players in the North American Soccer League after the strike by the players association.

title: Spurs Rout 76ers In Opener, 119106
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex. April 15 (AP)  George Gervin and Larry Kenon combined for 61 points today as the San Antonio Spurs routed the Philadelphia 76ers, 119106, in the opening game of the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference fourofsevensemifinal series.

title: Swimming: U.S. Shows Depth
description: MONTEREY PARK, Calif., April 15  George Haines smiled the smile of a poker player holding kings and queens but he wasn't claiming the pot yet.

title: Donald K. David Is Dead at 83; Led Harvard School of Business
description: Donald Kirk David, who had served as dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration and was one of the nation's leading business educators, died Friday at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis. Mass. Mr. David, who lived in Osterville. Mass., was 83 years old.

title: Metric Gasoline Pumps Studied
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)  The United States Metric Board will hold public hearings here May 2 and 3 on whether gasoline pumps should be converted to metric measurements. The board said most of the nation's more than 1 million pumps were incapable of computing prices above 99.9 cents a gallon. The board said it could cost $200 a pump to refit the pumps for a selling price of $1 or more. Pump conversion to price per liter would cost an estimated $50 per pump, the agency said.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Midnight Deadline Set for Filing Tax Returns
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI) Most taxpayers have until midnight tomorrow to file their Federal income tax returns, but holidays will give residents of North Carolina. the New England states and northern New York an extra day's grace.

title: Commodities
description: WHEN will the long climb in prices of basic raw materials taper off? According to the closely watched index of futures prices compiled by the Commodity Research Bureau, the rise in costs has been slowing for several weeks.

title: Senate Report Says President's ArmsSales Restraint Program Is Lagging
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee said in staff report today that President Carter's policy of cutting back on arms sales was running out of time and his efforts to get Moscow to agree to a formula for restraining weapons exports may be on the brink of failure.

title: Events Today
description: G.R. POINT, a play by David Berry; directed by William Devane; starring Michael Moriarty, at the Playhouse Theater, 359 West 48th Street. 6:30.

title: McCann Group's New Chairman
description: After a year at the United States headquarters of her agency, McCannErickson, Ann Burdus has returned to the McCann Group, Britain's largest agency, as one of its two leaders. She will be chairman, while Barry Day, a widely known creative man, will be president.

title: A Complex City Judge at the Center of a Storm
description: To a former head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, Bruce McM. Wright is the best friend criminals ever had. To the City Bar Association, his performance as a Criminal Court Judge has been decidedly better than average. To civilrights activists, he is, as one put it, an exasperating ally.

title: I.B.M. Unit Is Snarled By Computer Problem
description: ESSEX JUNCTION, Vt., April 15 (AP) One of the world's best known computer companies is tangled in a $1 million mixup in its credit union because of a computer problem.

title: Yanks Again Rally to Win
description: CHICAGO, April 15  For the second Y day in a row, the Yankees spotted the White Sox a sizable early lead and then caught and passed them with some longdistance hitting.

title: Ban the Bomb in South Asia
description: The Carter Administration was right to cut off economic aid to Pakistan for surreptitiously starting build a plant to produce nuclear explosives. But Pakistan was only doing what rival India did a decade ago, so trying to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons now requires effective measures against India as well.

title: Survey Finds Popularity Of Carter Leveling Off
description: President Carter's popularity, which had been declining in March, appears to have leveled off, but still more people disapprove than approve of his performance in office, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Groton Shipyard Labor
description: GROTON, Conn., April 15 (AP) Navy projections say that the work force of 18,600 at the General Dynamics Corporation's Electric Boat division in Groton, where the Trident nuclear submarines are being built, could be cut by onethird by the mid1980's because of ??ack of work, Representative Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said today. An Electric Boat spokesman, Joe Wornom, called Mr. Dodd's statement alarmist.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The announcement late last week of the planned retirement on June 1 of J. Edward Lundy from the Ford Motor Company scheduled the departure of the last of the 10 famous postWorld War II whiz kids from the giant automobile manufacturer.

title: Deaths
description: COHENDebra. Beloved wife of Samuel, devoted mother of Michael and Matthew, loving sister Of Betty Cutler. Services Monday 12:45 P.M. at Gutterman's Nassau Memorial Chapel Long Beach Road at Greystone, Rockville Centre, Lt.

title: Bullets Beat Hawks With Late Surge
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 15  The Washington Bullets, featuring the inside scoring of Elvin Hayes and Bobby Dandridge, opened the defense of their National Basketball Association championship today with a 10389 victory over the Atlanta Hawks at the Capital Centre.

title: Georgia Pastor Will Be Writer at White House
description: CALHOUN, Ga., April 15 (AP)  The Rev. Dr. R.L. Maddox, who says he is cut from the same cloth as President Carter, said today that he will leave the First Baptist Church of Calhoun to become a White House speechwriter.

title: Walking the Dog
description: We are in favor of pooperscoopers but we are also in favor of dogs. Manhattan was once the home of whistling swans and seals and mountain lions, and on spring days we remember this in our bones. Walking a dog, we feel occasionally that we are with a living ancestor, as children seem to do also. Children are born with a love for dogs; and when we are out with the dog, we seem to remember aptitudes of nose and leg that we no longer have.

title: Fraternities'Antics Turn Violent on Some Campuses, at Cost of Money and Privileges
description: Hijinks have given way to violence on few American campuses, keeping law enforcement officials busy, prompting neighbors to consider moving away and costing some fraternities their campus welcome and hundreds of dollars in damages.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY UNIT LEAVING ITS HOME ON COAST
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 15 The Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions, seeking to cope with changing times and a tight budget, plans to abandon its nolongerquiet hillside villa.

title: Fate of Faltering Mets Is Tied to Payson Family Drama
description: BEHIND the scenes at Shea Stadium these days a family drama is being played, and its outcome may determine the fate of the baseball franchise that once was the pride of New York. It has not yet reached the confrontation stage, unlike the unclenephew stalemate that embroiled Wellington and Tim Mara of the football Giants last winter. But every time the Mets take field  especially when they lose before 45,000 empty seats, as they did on opening day last week  they draw closer to the ultimate in soapopera pathos: one man's family at the moment of crisis.

title: Hussein to Confer With Hassan
description: RABAT. Morocco. April 15 (Reuters)  King Hussein of Jordan arrived here today for a private visit to Morocco with his wife, the Americanborn Noor alHussein. after a skiing holiday in the Aus- trian Alps. Officials said he was scheduled to confer with King Hassan of Morocco on Middle East developments following the signing of the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty. Jordan and Morocco were among 19 Arab states that decided last month to impose economic and political measures against Egypt for signing the treaty.

title: Merger Wave in Canada Stirs Antitrust Concerns
description: TORONTO, April 15  Canada's business world is being deluged by a nationwide wave of takeovers that is prompting more and more calls for stronger antitrust legislation.

title: A Schooner's Stormy Odyssey Ends in a Welcome Calm for 11
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 15  The youthful crew of the Pride of Baltimore and their dour captain lounged on board the docked ship this morning and answered questions from sightseers at the Wilmington Marine Terminal. It was the first time in 10 harrowing days that they had had nothing more urgent to do.

title: The End for Idi Amin
description: Idi Amin has been chased from his capital and the end of Uganda's eightyear nightmare seems at hand. The joy of a people liberated from murderous brutality is enough to overwhelm, for now, any misgivings about the role of Tanzanian soldiers in the final act and concern about the difficult task of reconstruction ahead.

title: Tudor City Residents Rally to Save Community Park
description: Seated in a park that they may soon lose, people listened to speakers from the Tudor City Tenants Association yesterday. The park, the northern most of two bounded by First and Second Avenues between 42d and 43d Streets, could become the site of a 30story apartment building that would be constructed by HelmsleySpear, the owner of Tudor City. The residents in the complex oppose construction that would eliminate open spaces.

title: Tourists Delayed Leaving Spain As Flights Are Cut by Controllers
description: MADRID, April 15 (Reuters)  Tourists returning from Easter vacations in Spain faced long delays today as French air traffic controllers stepped up a job action, Spanish airport sources said French controllers in Marseilles and Bor- deaux were restricting the number of flights from Barcelona and Madrid, the sources said.

title: TV: The RKO Years, Heyday of the Studio
description: LIKE the studio it is celebrating, The RKO Years is a disarmingly unpretentious, somewhat ragged documentary. The program, narrated by Joseph Cotten, who appears in a small studio with a few skimpy props, can be seen tonight at 10 on WOR/Channel 9, which happens to be an RKO Television station.

title: Cut in Bank Regulation Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  A highlevel Administration study group has virtually completed a set of recommendations that would result in substantial cuts in regulation for the nation's financial institutions.

title: Television
description: 5:55 (4)The New South

title: Jersey Facilities Face Ministrike
description: New Jersey's largest state employees union plans to conduct walkouts of several hours duration at 14 public institutions tomorrow to protest the state's offer of a 2.5 percent wage increase for this year.

title: Father and Son Drown, 2 Missing While on Overnight Camping Trip
description: GRAND ISLE, La., April 15 (UPI)  A father and his son drowned and two men were missing today on an overnight camping trip on Timbalier Island off the coast of Louisiana.

title: 5 Men Killed in Van Accident
description: OAK GROVE, La., April 15 (AP) Five young men died and three others were injured when they were trapped inside a van that slammed into a bridge abutment. leaped a creek and crashed, partially submerged, into the water on its side before bursting into flames, the state police said.
