description: ALBANY, April 17 (AP)  Governor Carey's office announced today that a special tollfree phone number was available for citizens to call in questions during an appearance by the Governor tomorrow night.

title: Dr. Carl Sagan to Be Host of PBS Science Series
description: Dr. Carl Sagan, the scientist and writer whose book The Dragons of Eden won a Pulitzer Prize for nonfiction, will write and serve as host of Cosmos, a new television series that will cost $8 million to make and will appear on the Public Broadcasting Service next year.

title: Heavy Rains Hindering Yugoslav Quake Relief
description: TITOGRAD, Yugoslavia, April 17 (Reuters)  Heavy rains hampered relief efforts today in the Adriatic coast area that was hit by a strong earthquake Sunday.

title: Carey's Casino Study Panel Supports Private Ownership
description: A state study panel recommended yesterday that any gambling casinos in New York State be privately operated, limited in number and confined to broadly defined resort areas that could include New York City and Buffalo.

title: Floods in Mississippi Force Thousands More to Flee
description: JACKSON, Miss., April 17 (AP) Thousands of residents downstream of flooded Jackson fled their homes today as the surging Pearl River defied forecasts and edged higher.

title: Joan Benoit Takes Her Victory in Stride
description: BOSTON, April 17  Joan Benoit's biggest challenge did not take place at Heartbreak Hill, where she took her final lead in the Boston Marathon yesterday. It was not at the Prudential Center, where she finished and set an American women's record with a time of 2 hours 35 minutes 15 seconds in the second marathon she ever ran. It was not even at The Eliot Lounge, the runners hangout located a number of limps from the finish line, the site of the prerace spaghetti dinner and postrace silliness.

title: Mets Lose, 54, in 12 to Expos
description: MONTREAL, April 17  Winning extrainning games seems to be coming naturally to the Expos this season.

title: Canadian Six Gains; U.S. Ties Czechs, 22
description: MOSCOW, April 17  The four favorites moved into the championship round of the World Hockey Tournament here today as Canada rallied to defeat Finland, 54, and Czechoslovakia gained despite an astonishing 22 tie with the United States.

title: Court Says Town and Its Residents Can Sue in a FairHousing Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The Supreme Court today upheld the right of town and its residents to bring suit under the Fair Housing Act when they believe that real estate agents are illegally trying to tip the racial balance of an integrated neighborhood.

title: Interest Rates Fall Sharply
description: Interest rates dropped sharply yesterday in a rally in the credit markets touched off by the spreading belief that the Federal Reserve would not tighten credit policy this week.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDON  What is one to think about the economic and moral effects of the black economy?

title: BestBuys
description: WHILE politicians and cattlemen debate the merits of meat boycotts and Beefless Wednesdays, consumers are voting with their pocketbooks. New Yorkers are buying less beef, but it appears that economic necessity, not a show of economic clout, is the reason.

title: Talks on London Times Snagged
description: LONDON, April 17  Hopes that The Times of London would soon resume publication were dashed today when management carried out plans to dismiss 3,000 workers it had temporarily rehired to get negotiations moving.

title: No Blood Found on Knife, Wright Bail Text Shows
description: The knife that the Manhattan District Attorney's office says was used to slash the throat of a decoy policeman had no blood on it, according to a transcript made available yesterday of the bail hearing last week before Criminal Court Judge Bruce McM. Wright.

title: 14 Killed by Blast in India
description: NEW DELHI, April 17 (Reuters) Fourteen people were killed and seven injured when lightning struck a but in which materials for rock blasting were stored, officials said today. The explosion occurred in the northern mountain village of Shogl.

title: Dr. Julia Apter, Ophthalmologist And Researcher, 61, in Chicago
description: Dr. Julia Apter, an ophthalmologist and researcher, died Monday after a brief illness at Billings Hospital in the University of Chicago Medical Cepter. She was 61 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: HOMELAND ATTRACTS SOME MOROCCO JEWS
description: CASABLANCA, Morocco  Slowly and cautiously, Moroccan Jews have begun to return to this Arab country to spend their vacations, see their families and do business. And a few are even returning to live.

title: State Report Criticizes CorporateTax Audits
description: ALBANY, April 17  A state audit of the state's Corporation Tax Section, which oversees corporate tax payments and returns, shows that it is inefficient in its processing and auditing of returns and its identification and assessment of delinquent corporatetax payers.

title: Hawks Even Series, Defeat Bullets, 10799
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 17 (AP)  John Drew and Wayne (Tree) Rollins, ineffective in an openinggame loss, combined to score 16 fourthquarter points tonight to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 10799 victory over the Washington Bullets in the second game of their National Basketball Association quarterfinal playoff.

title: From the Tables of Pompeii
description: Those who wish to know something about the ancient table cannot do without Pompeii, wrote Joseph Vehling, a Chicago chef whose visit to the ruins inspired him to translate into English the recipes of the Roman gourmet Apicius, The exhibition Pompeii A.D. 79, opening Sunday at the American Museum of Natural History, offers aficionados of the ancient table an opportunity to see wall paintings of banquets and bakers, ornate silver wine goblets and ordinary kitchen utensils preserved for 1,800 years under an airtight blanket of volcanic debris.

title: About Real Estate
description: Consider the mouseandelephant problem, as the city's Industrial and Commercial Incentives Board has been doing lately.

title: Beirut Sends Troops South, Warily, to Militia Area
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 17  To a sprinkling of cheers, rice and rosewater, a Lebanese Army battalion moved south from Beirut today in the first phase of a Government plan to restore control over southern Lebanon along the Israeli border.

title: Deaths
description: CAMPBELLBushrod Hill, age 85. Longtime resident of Boston. Died April 16, York, Maine. Services will be held at Goodwin Funeral Home, 607 Chestnut St, Manchester, New Hampshire, Friday 2:00PM. Gifts may be made to the Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, Mass. in his memory.

title: Citicorp Notes At 10.098% Rate
description: Citicorp reported yesterday that It sold 91day notes at an average rate of 10.098 percent, down from 10.178 percent last week. The bankholding company, which auctions such notes every Tuesday, said it received $784.5 million in bids and that it sold the entire $100 million issue at the 10.098 percent rate.

title: TV: A TeenAgers News Magazine
description: GENERATION is one of those wellmeaning projects that look promising on paper and turn out to be dreadful on television. The halfhour news magazine, produced and reported by teenagers, can be seen tonight at 7:30 on WABCTV.

title: Researchers Studying Wichita Falls Tornado
description: WICHITA FALLS, Tex., April 17 (UPI)  Victims still picking through splintered wood and twisted steel for salvagable items have been joined by researchers studying the halfmilewide tornado that struck the city last week.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: An economic slowdown is in progress, said G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, adding that he has no intention of tightening the nation's credit policy further. Preliminary figures on the gross national product indicate that real economic growth in the first quarter was less than 2 percent at an annual rate, Mr. Miller disclosed. He said he foresees a progressive slowdown through 1979 that could develop into a recession. [Page A1.]

title: America's Frenzied Madness
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Historians in the future may have to explain to skeptical audiences the passions that overcame the United States in the late 1970s. Nonsensical proposals for tax relief, quack remedies for economic stagnation, obsessive fears of the military strength of a declining enemy almost every aspect of the society, they would conclude, had been dominated by a frenzied madness.

title: Mayor Rizzo, in Familiar Form, Defends Police in Brutality Hearing
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 17  To those who have watched him over the years, was a vintage performance that Mayor Frank L. Rizzo gave today in his testimony before members of the United States Civil Rights Commission, which is investigating allegations of police brutality here.

title: Soviet Claims Joint Credit for Finding Jupiter's Ring
description: The Soviet Union, reacting to thediscovery of a ring around the planet Jupiter by the American spacecraft Voyager 1, has claimed joint credit for the discov ery, contending that a Russian scientist predicted the ring's existence as early as 1960.

title: Out of Gangs for Good
description: When I was 12 years old I saw a movie called Easy Rider. By the time I was 13 I was in my first street gang, the Henchmen. We were just a bunch of young punks looking for trouble, and most of the time, when we found it we had to run from it. Because it was more than we could handle.

title: The City
description: More than half of all New York City buses run behind schedule, Assemblyman Charles E. Schumer reported.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Fans of the SoHo boutique called Miya and Yoshi, which was responsible for many of the ombrdyed down coats seen all over town this past winter, are already lined up for spring and summer things. The shop's owners, Shiniki Miyazaki and his wife Yoskiko, import white cottons and silks from Japan and handdye them in their nearby factory. The colors are remarkable. When they use fabrics in patchwork, the effect is like stained glass. The spring star is a patchwork jacket (without the down lining) at $360 which brings to mind some of the Saint Laurent designs at much higher prices. The jacket goes over solid, ombre cotton skirts ($48 and $65) or skinnylegged pants ($65). If your budget stretches to an additional $245, check out the oneofakind silk shirts dyed with a Japanese technique called rope resistance, which produces wonderful, hazy stripes. The shop, which also does men's things, is at Broome Street and West Broadway, and is open Tuesday through Sunday from noon to 7 P.M.

title: Bruins 6, Penguins 2
description: BOSTON, April 17 (UPI)  Don Marcotte scored two goals and Peter McNab added a goal and two assists last night to lead the Boston Bruins to a 62 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Benzene Traced To Warwick Site By E.P.A. Aides
description: WARWICK, N.Y., April 17  Benzene, a known carcinogen, and at least two other suspected cancercausing chemicals have been seeping out of a 25acre mountainside dump here that is legally barred from accepting any such toxic or hazardous waste, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency disclosed today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Dreyfus, Ashby & Company, wine marketing division of Schenley Industries, has elected I. Richard Povill president.

title: Merrill Lynch, Hutton Post Gains for Quarter
description: Merrill Lynch & Company aid the E.F. Hutton Group Inc. both said yesterday that earnings for the first quarter of this year had increased sharply above the level of a year ago. A day earlier, Shearson Hayden Stone Inc. reported a similar rise in earnings.

title: Bus Falls Into River in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 17 (UPI)  A bus carrying sugarrefinery workers fell into the Paraiba do Sul River in eastern Rio de Janeiro state today and sank. A refinery executive said 15 to 17 men were believed killed, but other unofficial reports put the death toll at 25 to 30. The cause of the accident was not immediately known.

title: Dun &
description: At the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday, the Dun & Bradstreet Companies' shareholders approved changing the corporate name to the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation. They also ap- proved a proposal to increase the number of authorized common shares to 60 million from 40 million. There were 27.8 million shares outstanding on March 31.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M. WNCN. The Fairy Doll Ballet. excerpt, Bayer; Fugue in minor, Bath; Sentinella: Concerto a 3, Jarzebski.

title: Last Stop This Side of Kentucky
description: General Assembly, the most impressive son of Secretariat up to now, makes the 10th start of his life in Saturday's Wood Memorial at Aqueduct and probably will be the favorite for the eighth time. That's partly because he can run and partly because he looks so much like his flashy chestnut sire.

title: Ballet: Paul Taylor Offers A Baryshnikov Debut
description: IT is hard to think of any choreographer who can find so many new shapes for the body to fold and twist into than Paul Taylor. Perhaps this was the challenge that appealed to Mikhail Baryshnikov, who made his debut with the Paul Taylor Dance Company last night at the City Center 55th Street Dance Theater.

title: Stage: Mishima Drama
description: YUKIO MISHIMA'S Tropical Tree, now having its American premiere at the Open Space Theater Experiment, is the kind of play one would expect from this dynamic, heroconscious, enigmatic writer, wnose spectacular suicide by harakiri in 1970 caught the attention of the world. Shot through with Oedipal and Electralike strands, Tropical Tree is a play of unnatural lusts, homicidal jealousies and psychological cruelties; a play of a family riven by forces it barely understands.

title: Jorge Mantilla of Quito, Publisher and Diplomat
description: QUITO, Ecuador, April 17 (AP) Jorge Mantilla Ortega, a former diplomat and editor and publisher of the newspaper El Comercio, died last night after his car overturned in heavy fog southwest of Quito.

title: Red Sox Set Back Brewers, 65
description: BOSTON, April 17 (AP)  Fred Lynn slugged a tworun homer with one out in the ninth inning, his sixth of the season, as the Boston Red Sox rallied to beat the Milwaukee Brewers today, 65.

title: Arab Oil Group Ousts Egypt
description: KUWAIT, April 17 (AP)  The Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries announced today that it was expelling Egypt and imposing an oil embargo on it.

title: CHANGES SUGGESTED IN RADIATION CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Major changes in the Government's regulation of research and control of lowlevel radiation were suggested today by a special study group formed nearly a year ago by the White House.

title: 4 Arrested in Waterbury Holdup; Nearly All of Loot Is Recovered
description: WATERBURY, Conn., April 17  Law. enforcement officers, apparently acting on a tip from a gun salesman, arrested two couples today and charged them with shooting three Purolator Security guards to death in a $1.8 million robbery early yesterday morning. The police said they had found nearly all of the stolen cash, jewelry, checks and food stamps under a tarpaulin in the cellar of a house in Wallingford, where one couple lived.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation is in full spate in its attempt to attract more anglers to its freshwater lakes and streams.

title: Hattie Roach, 107, First White Born in a South Dakota County
description: YANKTON, S.D.. April 17 (UPI) Hattie K. Roach, the first white person born in Turner County, believed to be the oldest woman in South Dakota, died Saturday in a local nursing home. She was 107 years old.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: A Special Treat for Young Yankees Fans

title: New York's Plan To Help Renters Barred by I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  After months of deliberating, the Internal Revenue Service indicated today it would reject an unusual request by New York State to let apartment renters deduct share of their building's property taxes on their Federal incometax returns.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 17 (UPI)  Guerrillas and Government troops fought in the western city of Leon today, security sources said, and there were unofficial reports that at least six people had been killed.

title: Chess; The English? The English? My, How You've Changed
description: In the last five or 10 years, the English Opening has spawned more theoretical innovations than any other opening.

title: Fight Is Planned on Carter Move To Develop Area of Forest Lands
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)  Environmentalists plan an intensive campaign in Congress to block or delay the Carter Administration's decision to open 36 million acres of national forest lands to development.

title: SecretPolice Records Reveal Vast Paranoia Of Idi Amin's Regime
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, April 17  Hundreds of documents from Government offices here paint a portrait of the Idi Amin regime as a snake pit of fear and paranoia, dominated by a secret police that spent millions of dollars on sophisticated devices such as deadly exploding cigarette lighters but whose agents were barely literate.

title: Avon Bell Ringer: $4 Million Drive
description: Avon Products, the country's most successful bell ringer, is going to pour $4 million into advertising in the next five weeks in a cosmetics promotion that is bigger than anything it has done before.

title: Yamani Denies Ouster Rumors
description: Rumors were widespread yesterday that Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the oil minister of Saudi Arabia, was about to be dismissed, but no official word was forthcoming from the Saudis and the Sheik himself was said to have denied the reports.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  This year's Pulitzer Prize for public service by a newspaper went to The Point Reyes (Calif.) Light, a husbandandwife weekly, with a circulation of 2,700. It beat all the big city dailies and syndicates with its reporting on Synanon, a drugrehabilitation center in its neighborhood, which the editors believed had degenerated into an authoritarian cult.

title: Hot Line Spurred Gasoline Audits
description: The surprise audits of gasoline dealers suspected of price gouging, which were announced Monday by the Department of Energy, grew out of information collected by consumer hot line established in January, according to department officials.

title: Around the Nation
description: RICHMOND, April 17 (AP)  The full United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit agreed today to reconsider a decision by three of its members that overturned the racketeering and mail fraud conviction of former Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: F.D.A. CHIEF TO QUIT FOR STANFORD POST
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)  Donald Kennedy, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, is resigning this summer to take a top administrative post at Stanford University, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced today.

title: MORE U.S AID ASKED FOR BASIC RESEARCH
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Backed by new figures showing a decadelong decline in American investment in basic exploratory research, five top scientists and university presidents today banded together to call again for a renewed emphasis in this highrisk, longrange venture.

title: Big Spectator Sport: Watching the Whales
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., April 17  Aaron Avellar shut down the engine a mile from the Race Point light and let the steelhulled Dolphin III roll sickeningly in the troughs of a lead gray chop.

title: QUAKE AND VOLCANO HAVE COMMON ORIGIN
description: The forces deep within the earth that Move continents and thrust up mountains have made themselves dramatically evident in recent days on opposite sides of the planet, and in two very different ways.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: LOWELL SHUMWAY

title: KnightRidder Papers Will Test TV Information Service in Homes
description: MIAMI, April 17 (UPI)  KnightRidder Newspapers Inc. said today that next year it would start testing consumer response to a home electronic information service called Viewtron.

title: Caribbean Volcano Erupts Again But No One Is Reported Injured
description: KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, April 17 (AP)  Soufriere erupted again this afternoon, sending ash and sulfuric fumes thousands of feet into the air.

title: News of the Theater
description: THERE will be some fast footwork at the Longacre Theater in the next few days. Brian Friel's drama Faith Healer, which brought James Mason back to Broadway for the first time in 32 years, will close Saturday night after only 20 performances. Six days later, April 27, John Guare's new romantic comedy, Bosoms and Neglect, will start previews, prior to a May 3 opening.

title: Remains of Scottish Colony Are Found on Panama Coast
description: A team of professional and amateur archeologists, participants in a round-theworld expedition known as Operation Drake, has discovered a sunken trading ship and other remains of an illfated 17thcentury Scottish colony at Caledonia Bay on the Caribbean coast of Panama.

title: Corporations Report Their Sales and Earnings Results for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: 3Hitter Stops Orioles, 51
description: Before yesterday's game, Ron Guidry sprawled on the floor in his clubhouse cubicle and discussed the trouble he had had in his first two starts.

title: Amherst College Officials Blame CrossBurning on Black Student
description: AMHERST, Mass., April 17 (UPI) Amherst College officials said today that a black student apparently was responsible for the burning sixfoottall cross found on the lawn of the school's allblack dormitory early yesterday.

title: Topics
description: For all the neutral data it produces, the decennial Census is at root political. It is the basis for reapportioning seats in Congress among the states, which can sometimes involve delicate matters of detail and interpretation. No wonder that parties in power want to be sure about the political loyalties of whoever is appointed to rim the Census Bureau in census years. And all the more reason to be struck by the present goingson.

title: Legal Expert Urges Chile Court Not to Extradite Officers to U.S.
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 17  The Chilean Supreme Court received an important legal finding today against granting a United States request for the extradition of three army officers indicted in the murder of Orlando Letelier.

title: High Court Upholds Denial Of Teaching Posts to Aliens
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The Supreme Court of the United States upheld the constitutionality today of a New York law that requires publicschool teachers in the state to be American citizens.

title: Senator Urges Asbestos Check
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)  The chairman of the Senate Consumer Subcommittee urged today that the Government determine which consumer products besides handheld hair dryers conta in asbestos insulation.

title: Marlene, S.E.C. Reach Accord
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed an action yesterday in the United States Court for the Southern District seeking an injunction and other equitable relief against Marlene Industries, a New Yorkbased apparel manufacturer, and its principal officers and directors, Charles Meltzer, chairman and president, and Samuel Meltzer, treasurer.

title: Fire on Polish Ship Extinguished
description: COPENHAGEN, April 17 (Reuters)A fire aboard the 6,600ton Polish freighter Reimund in the Baltic last night that left two crewmen dead, one critically injured and 20 passengers in the hospital was put out today. Three Polish tugs were Standing by to tow the vessel to the Polish port of Gdynia, Danish maritime sources said. The ship caught fire while traveling from Gdynia to Rostock in East Germany with cargo of steel.

title: New York Students Vie for Film Award:
description: Future film makers who have already been putting their hand to the medium as college students will learn tomorrow evening whether they have won the New York Student Academy Awards.

title: Deaths
description: ECKHOUSE  Albert. The members of Ahead Achim of Fairlawn New Jersey deeply mourn the gassing of their dear member Albert Eckhouse, husband of Paula, fattier of Steve, Ralph and Bernard. May the mourners be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, April,1979

title: Deaths
description: PEYTONMary Louise, of Bronxville, N.Y., on Sunday, April 15, 1979; born in the District of Colum bia, the daughter of the late Col. & Mrs. James S. EasbySmith; widow of Paul L. Peyton. Services on Wednesday, April 18 at 11:30am at Christ Church, Bronxville.

title: Cambodian Refugees Offer Prayers for Homeland
description: On the fourth anniversary of the capture of Phnom Perth by Communist forces, Sichan Siv, a Cambodian refugee, yesterday recalled this song, The Cry of the Gibbon, in describing his feelings about his missing family.

title: The Rights of the Forgotten
description: Thousands of institutionalized Americans suffer from neglect and even brutality. They are the mentally ill, the retarded and others in state custody. The states are responsible for treating them humanely but violations are common. The courts have found that in some cases inmates are unlawfully deprived of liberty and subjected to cruel and unusual punishment.

title: High Court Says Single Permit Fee For TV Music Is Not Price Fixing
description: WASHINGTON. April 17  The Supreme Court ruled today that the system under which television networks are charged a blanket fee for the license to broadcast copyrighted musical compositions does not constitute illegal price fixing.

title: Chinese and Vietnamese Start Peace Negotiations
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, Wednesday, April 18 (UPI)  China and Vietnam began peace talks today despite angry exchanges of charges by each country's media.

title: William F. Dowling Jr., an Editor, Consultant and College Teacher
description: William F. Dowling Jr., an editor and consultant for the American Management Associations, died of a heart attack yesterday in his St. Marks Place home in New York City. He was 54 years old.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THERE is probably no popular human activity more beset with myth, assumption and misinformation than sexual interaction. Much of the misunderstanding about sexuality is a cause of apprehension, anxiety, misguided efforts and downright dysfunction, detracting from what might otherwise be a highly pleasurable event for the vast majority of people.

title: Elias H. Jacobs, Lawyer, 70, Dies
description: Elias H. Jacobs, senior partner in the law firm of Jacobs & Jacobs, Stamford, N.Y., died of a heart attack Monday at the Albany Medical Center Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: Israel Names HardLiner to Talks on Palestinian Role
description: JERUSALEM, April 17  The Israeli Government today appointed Interior Minister Yosef Burg, a hardline conservative, to head a negotiating team that will meet with Egyptian officials next month to discuss Palestinian selfrule on the West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip.

title: New Rules Issued on Price Standards
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The Council on Wage and Price Stability, pressing its campaign for better compliance with the Administration's voluntary pricerestraint standard, published new procedures today that require more companies to file more reports.

title: Subway Felonies Rise; Number of Arrests Up
description: The number of felonies committed in the subway system rose slightly last week, but the increase was offset by more felony arrests, the Transit Authority police chief, Sanford D. Garelik. said Yesterday.

title: Wine Talk
description: WINE enthusiasts spend a great deal time these days lamenting costs and praying for a couple of bountiful harvests in the vineyards of France, where, for better or worse, the prices of most of the world's wines are set.

title: ExCellO Dividend
description: A spokesman for the ExCellO Corporation announced yesterday that the company's chairman and chief executive, Edward J. Giblin, was planning to recom- mend an increase in the quarterly common dividend rate payable in July. The spokesman did not indicate how much of an increase Mr. Giblin intended to recommend. The company's most recent quarterly dividend increase was to 40 cents a share from 35 cents in April 1978.

title: Take Better Care of Less New York City
description: After World War II, city planners were intoxicated with the problems of growth. Expecting populations keep on increasing and fearing both overcrowding and obsolescence, they encouraged construction. Plans for physical growth endured even after economic growth stopped. Now it is the painful duty of the New York City Planning Commission to remind city officials that the problems of contraction can be even harder than those of growth, and that they require courage to solve. The commission reports annually to the Board of Estimate on the city's capital needs, this year it says the capital need is caution.

title: 1975 Hooker Study May Spur New Pollution Tests
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., April 17 The State Department of Environmental Conservation said today that it was considering whether to begin monitoring air and water here for traces of more chemicals than it does now.

title: Truck Blast Kills Florida Man
description: HILLIARD, Fla., April 17 (UPI) gasoline tank truck exploded at a Gulf Oil distributorship in downtown Hilliard today, killing the driver and destroying a nearby office and several other vehicles in the vicinity. Fire officials identified the driver as Charles Hill. They said that the truck apparently exploded when a park ignited the fuel while the driver as loading it at the Buchanan Oil Comapny.

title: COURT UPHOLDS CITY IN SCHOOLBIAS CASE
description: A court order requiring the desegregation of Andrew Jackson High School in Queens was reversed yesterday by a Federal appeals court, which refused to overturn an existing studentassignment plan.

title: Plan to Curtail Monitoring of Calls To U.S. Agencies Meets Resistance
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  When it came to power in 1977, the Carter Administration said it would end a practice common in the Presidency of Richard M. Nixon, the random monitoring of telephone calls from the public to Government agencies.

title: Net Up at Chase, Citicorp, Bankers Trust
description: Shareholders of three of the nation's largest banking organizations yesterday heard their chairmen report substantial increases in firstquarter earnings.

title: Brown Sees Pact To Curtail Arms Verifiable by '80
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Defense Secretary Harold Brown said today that it would take the United States about a year to regain the ability to verify adequately Soviet compliance with a new strategic arms limitation treaty.

title: 20 Years of American Gastronomy:
description: THE better part of a recent evening was spent in random research on the subject of American gastronomy, thumbing through various cookbooks that have quietly appeared in small communities across the country. They are published by village charities, church groups, Junior Leagues .... Some date from 30 years ago; others have appeared in the last year or so.

title: Careers
description: I THINK that in the last few weeks corporations have begun to realize the impact of the age discrimination laws, says Patrick J. Montana, president of the National Center for Career Planning. The center has been re- ceiving a lot of calls from companies asking how they can handle problems presented by older employees, he said the other day, and the companies indicate they are aware that they may be open to charges of breaking the law when they dismiss them.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Late buying advanced precious metals and sharply reduced earlier losses in copper futures yesterday. Brokers attributed the afternoon rally to unexpectedly strong bidding at the monthly gold auction held by the Treasury, as well as to a technical reaction to recent declines.

title: Utility Says Customer Should Share in Costs For Three Mile Island
description: HARRISBURG. Pa., April 17 (AP) lawyer for the Metropolitan Edison Company., the owner of half of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant, said today that the utility could be forced into bankruptcy in a matter of days if it was not permitted to collect higher rates from customers.

title: Atlanta Law Firm, in Turnabout, Will Open a Washington Branch
description: Reversing an earlier decision, King & Spalding, a major Atlanta law firm with close ties to the Carter Administration, is planning to open a threelawyer Washington branch office this summer.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 18,1979

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: WHEN it comes to gourmet cookery, there is no chef in the world who would put a price on the ingredients. That is to say that a fine omelet made when eggs are at a peak of freshness can be just as Seductive in flavor as a truffled pt or nightingales' tongues (a legendary dish that I never hope to try).

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Natomas Company announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Signal Companies Inc. on the basic terms for it to acquire Signal's 45 percent interest in the American President Lines Ltd., a major container ship and passenger ship operator.

title: P.L.O. Link Denied
description: BRUSSELS, April 17 (Reuters)  A spokesman for the Palestine Liberation Organization today disassociated the guerrilla group from an attempt to attack an Israeli airliner at Brussels airport yesterday.

title: Carey Praises I Love New York
description: ALBANY, April 17  Governor Carey today called the state's multimilliondollar I Love New York advertising campaign vastly successful despite a draft state audit that questions its value and recommends the campaign be suspended until studies of it are conducted.

title: 15Year Sentence for Robbery
description: A 54yearold Bronx man was sentenced Tuesday to a maximum term of 15 years in prison for robbery. Justice Morris Grey of State Supreme Court in the Bronx ruled that the defendant, Vinicio Del Rio, must serve at least seven and a half years of the sentence. Mr. Del Rio, along with 17-year-old Jose Martinez, was convicted of taking at gunpoint $25 in cash and 11 cartons of cigarettes from the candy store at 89 McClennan Street last Oct. 9.

title: Bridge:
description: Sponsorship has become a familiar feature of tournament play on both sides of the Atlantic in the last decade, but it has taken quite different forms. In this country, the sponsor is always a wealthy individual, but in Europe a company assumes the role, eager for the publicity that a modest investment can bring.unless East held both the ace and the queen. A much better chance was to play for East to hold the diamond king, leading a low diamond from dummy at the fourth trick.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (Tekviskm  Cablevision, 8 P.M. Radio WINS, 8 P.M.)

title: Plaintiffs in Case Dismayed
description: Neither of them had expected to make a home here. One was on a visit to New York from London. The other was a student in Helsinki. But fate had it that each would meet an American, decide to marry and move to New York.

title: L.I. Lightning's Nuclear Study
description: HICKSVILLE, L.I., April 17 Charles R. Pierce, chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company, promised shareholders today that there would be a rigorous reexamination of all elements of design and operation of the company's Shoreham nuclear plant, which is still under construction, as a result of the accident at the Three Mile Island plant in Pennsylvania.

title: Korea's Yulsan Scandal Unfolds
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The collapse of the Yulsan Group here and the arrest of its top official, Shin Sun Ho, appears to end what seemed to be one of the most remarkable success stories in recent Korean economic history.

title: E.P.A. Recalls 430,000 Pontiacs
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)  An estimated 430,000 Pontlacs have been ordered recalled by the Environmental Protection Agency because they may have faulty air pollution control systems. The problem involves a defective joint in the exhaust gas recirculation system. The part involved was made for General Motors Corporation by the Eaton Corporation, and has already figured in recalls of one million cars made last year by Ford Motor Company, and American Motors, who bought the same part from Eaton.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: This month's $1.1 billion tender offer by Brascan Ltd. for the F.W. Woolworth Company has placed John (Jake) Moore in an unfamiliar spot.

title: Sea Gate's People Enjoy a Safe Oasis Amid City's Perils
description: The dizzy joys and woes, the ups and downs of Coney Island stop with a shudder at the west end of Surf Avenue in a final huddle of burnedout, boardedup ruins. Beyond 37th Street, at the tip of Brooklyn's peninsula between the Atlantic and Gravesend Bay, lie the 43 square blocks of Sea Gate and they shall not pass who do not have a resident's or a visitor's permit.

title: Private Lives
description: IT has been years since the last time I saw him. I wish it had been centuries. Nor is he pleased to find me inflicted on a dinner party which he intends to dominate. The fault is mine for having left the house; the fault is his for not having left the country. There was never any reason to expect that he would change. Perhaps, in a windowless room Georgetown or Langley where they play war games, his scenario is hanging on a wall and growing old. Otherwise, he is ageless, an amalgam of sunlight and cunning, of sincerity and menace. He looks younger, in fact, than he did in the 1960's in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Tequila: The Straight Story
description: AMATITAN, MEXICO Most American visitors to Mexico toast their arrival here with perhaps the only Spanish words they know: Una margarita por favor. But at nearby tables, Mexicans turn up their noses. Margaritas are for gringos, tequila is for hombres.

title: TREE LOSS IN CHINA AFFECTING CLIMATE
description: HONG KONG, April 19  Despite repeated treeplanting campaigns, China's meager forest resources have been badly depleted in recent years by indiscriminate and illegal logging, recent articles in the Chinese press have reported.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: From Marlboro By Four Young Players
description: THE final Music From Marlboro concert of the season at Alice Tully Hall Monday night featured tour young players who had prepared their chambermusic programs at the famed Vermont music festival last summer: Yefim Bronfman, pianist; Shlomo Mintz, violinist; Paul Tobias, cellist, and David Jolley, hornist.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PIPE BREAK An hour of organ music by Bach, Vivaldi and Buxtehude is today's lateafternoon Twilight Interlude in the new series for homebound workers and visitors in the area of Lincoln Center. Playing on the fourmanual, 4,192pipe console at Alice Tully Hall, starting at 5:30, will be John Weaver. The organist heads the St. Andrew's Music Society at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church and also the organ department of the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia.

title: Housing Rebounded In March
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Housing construction, one of the most closely watched indicators of economic activity, rebounded in March, with starts 29.7 percent ahead of weatherdepressed February, but homebuilding activity was 12 percent below the levels of a year ago, the Government reported today.

title: Debate on Exposs Held Up a Pulitzer
description: A lively discussion on how newspapers should gather news and exposs marked this year's award of Pulitzer Prizes for journalism, and was reported yesterday to have helped block a prize for local investigative reporting for The Chicago SunTimes.

title: Stars' Night Out at Olympic Auction
description: Anyone who thinks that being part of the New York scene is all fun and games doesn't know the New York scene. Monday night, some unkind person called it a zoo, but that wasn't at all true because no animal, other than the human, would voluntarily spend a good part of an evening getting shoved, stepped on and, in some cases, screamed at. Actually, the being screamed at didn't matter a hoot because the general noise level was like a subway station at rush hour with all the trains coming in at once.

title: Potvin, Bossy Typify Spirit of Victory in Playoff Opener
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 17  It's a 20man game, but it takes everyone to be No. 1.

title: Guinean Send Soldiers To Aid Liberian Regime
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, April 17 (AP)A platoon of soldiers from Guinea was flown here today to help Liberian troops maintain order after weekend rioting.

title: Deaths
description: ABELOW  Phyllis M. Beloved wife of Ashe, devoted mother of Marcy and Jocelyn, loving daughter of Frieda Kestin, dear sister of Samuel Keehn. Services Thursday 1:15PM Boulevard Perk West 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Bally Concludes Pact For $80 Million Loan
description: The Bally Manufacturing Company announced it had completed an eightyear, $80 million revolving and term loan agreement with seven banks of which the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago is the lead bank.

title: Di Giorgio Seeking Its Niche
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18  Annual sales of the Di Giorgio Corporation are approaching $1 billion, but in some ways the company is still sorting out its place in the American business scene. In fact, it has been described as an association of marketing men looking for something to sell.

title: Obituary 11  No Title
description: Deaths

title: TV: The Benny Hill Show
description: IF your appetite for English high life has been sated by Upstairs, Downstairs, The Pallisers, Edward the King and The Duchess of Duke Street, try low life by watching The Benny Hill Show.

title: Rangers Roll, 71
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 18  Like an apt pupil, the Rangers learned from past mistakes tonight and held on to a lead. They were rewarded with a 7.1 trouncing of the Philadelphia Flyers at the Spectrum, which tied their National Hockey League series at one game apiece. The next two contests of the fourofsevengame quarterfinal playoffs are scheduled for Madison Square Garden Friday and Sunday nights.

title: Critics of Nuclear Power to March on Capitol May 6
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Motivated by the recent accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear reactor, a group of more than 90 diverse organizations and public figures said today that they would stage a march on the Capitol on May 6 to protest national policies that encourage nuclear power.

title: Home Improvement
description: WHEN roof gutters are doing their job, water that pours off the roof In a heavy rain should be safely channeled to the ground through vertical downspouts, or leaders. These carry the water harmlessly away from foundation plantings and basement walls. But if they are to work properly, these gutters have to be cleaned out at least once a year and checked for possible repairing.

title: Disclosures In Freedom Act Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that, because the purpose of the Freedom of Information Act was public disclosure of Government documents, a private party had no right under the act to go into court to block their release.

title: Lyle, at 37, Keeps Coming Back
description: Ron Lyle. as innocent as a reborn contender, has come back again. He once came back from the dead.

title: Art on Display  Art Put Away
description: HANGING a collecton of paintings is always a design problem. But imagine the dilemma for Gamal ElZoghby, an architect who is a pioneer in sculptural space. Paintings, he feels, would diminish his sculptural effects.

title: .Spain's Big Nuclear Energy Program Runs Afoul of Democratic Polities
description: MADRID, April 18  Mapped out in the autumn years of the Franco regime, Spain's ambitious nuclear power program appears to have become snagged in the country's newly vocal democratic politics, particularly at the local and regional level.

title: S. W. Halperin, Retired Professor And Author, Dead on Coast at 74
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., April 17 (AP)  S. William Halperin, author and retired University of Chicago professor, has died at his home in La Jolla, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: 50,000 Chevettes Ordered Recalled for High Emissions
description: WASHINGTON. April 18  The Environmental Protection Agency today ordered the recall of 50,000 1979 Chevrolet Chevette automobiles and said that it would shut down two General Motors Corporation plants 11 the company did not change the Chevette's pollution control system by May 4.

title: Utility Bond Yields Rise to 11%
description: Yields on mediumgrade utility bonds climbed yesterday to 11 percent, their highest level in three and a half years.

title: Excerpts From Opinions by Supreme Court Justices in HerbertCBS Libel Case
description: WASHINGTON. April 18  Following are excerpts from opinions by the supreme Court in the case of Anthony Herbert v. Barry Lando and the Columbia Broadcasting System Inc. Associate Justice Byron R. White wrote the majority opinion.

title: Notes on People
description: AmericanChinese relations are on the minds of many people, which is exactly where Han Suyin wanted them to be all along. In books and articles, Dr. Han has spent many of her 61 years explaining East to West, a chore not unfitting for someone born in China of a Belgian mother and a Chinese father.

title: Libel Simply Defined: Damage to Reputation
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) Libel, simply put, is damage to a person's reputation in print, writing, pictures or signs.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: ANNAMARIA DUVALL MARX

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE Clamping Down on Clutter
description: ANOVEL way to organize desktop clutter is to use accessories held in place by a special clamp. The Synthesis collection, designed by Olivetti, is a handsome set of modular units that can be used alone or combined. Made of durable plastic, the accessories come in deep red, black, gray or hazelnut. The clamp, available in gray or hazelnut for $29, can be used to support a set of the pencil holder ($10), ashtray ($14) and card holder ($7); or a letter tray/ file basket ($13). There is also a telephone tray and clamp ($36) that seems especially useful. The clamps can be mounted on a desk or shelf and are sold, with the accessories, at Manhattan Ad Hoc Housewares, 842 Lexington Avenue.

title: A Soccer Sideshow
description: LONDON, April 18 (Reuters)  The English Soccer League today fined Sammy Nelson of Arsenal $1,500 and suspended him for two games for conduct likely to bring the game into disrepute. Nelson lowered his shorts at the end of a game against Coventry. He scored both goals in the 11 draw  one into his own net.

title: Air Traffic Up On U.S. Lines
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) Firstquarter passenger traffic on United States scheduled airlines increased 18.6 percent over the same period last year, the Air Transport Association reported today. Traffic in March was up 20 percent over March 1978, the association said.

title: Music Hall to Be Restored
description: The master plan to make Radio City Music Hall a thriving entertainment center was announced yesterday, with the first order of business being a thorough restoration of the 6,000seat former movie palace to its pristine Art Deco freshness, followed immediately by a summerlong musical production on its giant stage.

title: Japan Joins International Efforts To Develop New Energy Sources
description: TOKYO, April 18 (Reuters)  Japan has agreed to international arrangements to help develop an advanced heat pump and geothermal energy, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Leo Hershfield, 75, Illustrator of Trials For Television News
description: Leo Hershfield, whose courtroom drawings were seen by millions of television viewers, died Tuesday after having been stricken by a heart attack while shrimping on a fishing trip in Sarasota, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived in Bradenton, Fla.

title: Suffolk County Gains Extension On Deadline for Disaster Loans
description: Suffolk County residents whose houses suffered damaged in last January's floods were given extended deadlines to file for loans from the Small Business Administration.

title: Holiday Inns to Add Restaurant Chain
description: Holiday Inns Inc. announced it had signed a formal agreement to purchase Perkins Cake and Steak Inc.. a privately held restaurant chain with headquarters in Minneapolis. A preliminary agreement in principle on the acquisition was announced in December.

title: Election Unit Is Ordered To Shift Stand on Labor
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  A Federal district judge has ruled that the Federal Election Commission must change its policy toward political fundraising committees of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations and its member unions.

title: About Princeton; SAT 's Are a (Chore) (Test) (Fun)
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 17Plethora was retired recently from the verbal section of the Scholastic Aptitude Test. This was a minor passing, but one that offers a multiple choice of emotions for the millions of Americans who can recall their own SAT days with all the cherished anguish of military induction or loss of innocence.

title: KLM Faces U.S. Inquiry On Payment Allegations
description: Allegations by a company auditor, who has since been dismissed, that KLM Royal Dutch Airlines kept secret books recording millions of dollars of irregular payments to travel agencies, employees and suppliers will be investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, lawyers for the auditor and KLM disclosed yesterday. The S.E.C. declined to confirm or deny the report.

title: Bridge:
description: If the bridge cognoscenti were offered a list of worldclass players and asked to rank them twice, in order of ability and in order of popularity, one man would have a good chance to finish first in both categories. His name is Gabriel Chagas, a 34yearold Brazilian who owns one world title.

title: Author Says, No, It's Not My Life
description: AT a little past noon yesterday, Brian Clark still looked half asleep. Don't ask me what time I went to bed  or how I got there. I don't remember the party, but my head tells me it was wonderful, the blearyeyed British playwright said with contentment as he sank into an armchair in his suite in the Algonquin.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Carter Nominating General Barrow To Be Marine Corps Commandant
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  President Carter announced today that he would nominate Gen. Robert H. Barrow, a threewar veteran who cracked down on training abuses, to become the 27th Commandant of the Marine Corps.

title: Wells, Rich Wins Diners Club
description: The recently repositioned Dnners Club International is moving its account to Wells, Rich, Greene, according to James M. Stetler, executive vice president, marketing. The advertiser says the total marketing budget is $12 million.

title: Pope Asks for Clemency In Clear Allusion to Iran
description: ROME, April 18  Pope John Paul II, in a clear allusion to the executions in Iran of supporters of the deposed Shah, denounced today the rekindling of punitive flames in the wake of recent upheavals. He pleaded for humane treatment of prisoners and clemency for the vanquished.

title: AFTERSHOCKS STRIKE YUGOSLAVIA, ITALY
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 18Aftershocks from Sunday's earthquake on Yugoslavia's Adriatic coast continued in northwestern Yugoslavia and northern Italy today, causing minor damage but no reported casualties.

title: India Riot Deaths Put at 110
description: NEW DELHI, April 18 (Reuters) Some 110 people were killed in religious riots in Jamshedpur in northeast India last week. Home Minister H.M. Patel said in Parliament today. Rioting broke out when a Hindu procession marched through a Moslem area.

title: Windfall Tax Backed By Ullman
description: SALEM. Ore., April 18 (AP)  Representative Al Ullman, chairman of the powerful House Ways and Means Committee, said today that he was in favor of a proposed tax on windfall profits of oil companies and he said he thought such a tax would be approved by the Senate if passed by the House.

title: Teamsters, in a Shift, Moving to Back Strike By 5,000 Steel Drivers
Advertising
description: JAPAN'S many camera companies have a nice little war going, not at home, where the market is pretty well saturated, but here in America where, 9 of the 10 topselling 35millimeter singlelens reflex cameras on the market are made in Japan.

title: Jersey Bus Service Declining Despite Big Subsidies
description: TRENTON, April is  New Jersey's bus system is slowly deteriorating, and government officials, transit experts and riders say they see no quick end to the pattern of unreliable service and rapidly rising fares that has cut daily ridership by 45 percent in the last decade. The drop in passengers, New Jersey officials say, has led to more losses, higher fares and worse service.

title: Market Place
description: THE fastest game in town is betting on takeover candidates  buying shares of companies the speculator hopes will be acquired. It can be highly lucrative approach to Wall Street profits. But things do not always work out. It certainly is not easy to make money on the basis of rumors, and profits can be elusive even when bids are actually laid on the table.

title: GARDENING
description: WHEN trying to provide a private garden retreat, whether in a suburban yard or on a city terrace, the first plant that comes to mind for a snug screen is privet. As ordinary and unimaginative as privet may be, it does the job well. Privet survives neglect and endures nature's adversities: low temperatures, drought, drying winds and relentless sun. The plants are easy to acquire and inexpensive and will grow in average soil.

title: Paris Leaning to Mobile and Air Strategic Missiles
description: PARIS, April 18  France will be ready to make a definite decision on its next generation of strategic missiles by the end of the year, and will probably choose mobile ground and airlaunched weapons, according to a Defense Ministry spokesman.

title: Air Carriers Show Loss In Quarter
description: American Airlines and the Trans World Corporation yesterday reported firstquarter losses of $6.8 million and $47.8 million, respectively.

title: Examiner Says Some Murder Knives Can Be Bloodless
description: New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Michael M. Baden, said yesterday that knives used to commit murders sometimes have blood on them and sometimes don't whether they are wiped off or not.

title: ESSAY Justice After Bell
description: WASHINGTON, April 18King and Spalding, the Atlanta law firm headed by Charles Kirbo, the President's closest adviser and trustee (and the firm soon to be rejoined by Attorney General Griffin Bell) has announced plans to open a Washington, D.C., office.

title: Waldheim Predicts Chaos at U.N. If U.S. Lets Spending Curb Stand
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 18 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim warned today that the foundation of the United Nations could be destroyed unless the United States Congress removed restrictions imposed late last year on American contributions to the United Nations budget.

title: Egypt and Israel Delay Peace Ceremony Again
description: CAIRO, April 18 (AP)  Egypt and Israel have postponed, for the second time, a ceremony for the exchange of ratified peace treaty documents and they have agreed on next Wednesday as a new date, the official Middle East News Agency said today.

title: TiredLooking Brezhnev Named To Another Term by Legislature
description: MOSCOW, April 18  Leonid I. Brezhnev, 72 years old and looking and sounding weak and weary, was reelected as Soviet President today, with five standing ovations.

title: Model Designed on Dreams of Utopia
description: FAIR LAWN, N.J.  At 50 years of age, Radburn, the town for the motor age as it was called in its early publicity, has an almost quaint air. It is in fine condition physically, with many of its houses undergoing renovation or expansion. But it has grownold Ideologically.

title: Thatcher Speech Warms Up the British Campaign
description: LONDON, April 18  After a bloodless beginning, the British election campaign has begun to generate some passion in the last 48 hours.

title: Edward Fields, Carpet Designer And Manufacturer, Is Dead at 66
description: Edward Fields, an internationally renowed manufacturer of custom carpets and a leading carpet designer, died Tuesday in the Safety Harbor Island Spa in Clearwater, Fla. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TWO WORLDS What does the elegant lounge of the Regency Hotel share with the earthy Lombardi's restaurant in Greenwich Village? A relaxing atmosphere. Both spots also have good pianists, and the one downtown is sensationally good.

title: Editors Concerned by Court 's State of Mind Decision
description: Editors and news executives around the country expressed concern yesterday about the United States Supreme Court decision that permits inquiry into the state of mind of reporters, editors or producers at the time they were preparing an article or a television show.

title: Assurance Given on Tariff Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Industries plagued by high imports, such as textiles, leather, steel, rubber and autos, are being shielded from the brunt of new tariff cuts under a trade agreement initialed last week in Geneva, American negotiators have told Congress.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Baltimere Orioles. at Yankee Stadium. River Avenue and 161st Street. the Bronx. 2 P.M. (Television  Cablevision, 2 P.M. Radio  WINS. 2 P.M.)

title: Judge Suspends Italy Bank Aide
description: ROME, April 18 (AP)  An investigative judge formally suspended Mario Sarcinelli, deputy director of the Bank of Italy, in a surprise turn in an inquiry involving top officials of the central bank, it was disclosed today.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: ADLERBLUm  Yens Deer sister Beloved aunt & grand aunt. Clear friend. Services Thursday, April I92 15 p.m. The Riverside. 76 St & Amsterdam Ave. Please omit flowers.

title: Lake Ontario Stocked With Fish Despite Water's Toxic Chemicals
description: ALTMAR. N.Y. April 18  New York State conservation officials put several thousand baby cotes and chinook salmon into the tributaries of Lake Ontario today, resuming a fishstocking program halted in September 1976, when tests showed dangerously high levels of toxic chemicals in the fish then being caught.

title: Kenya Says It's Holding Amin's BritishBorn Deputy
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 18  A highranking police official confirmed today that Robert Astles, the Britishborn aide to Idi Amin, is in custody in Kenya and is being interrogated. He was believed to have been arrested Friday as he crossed the border into Kenya, but the police official did not elaborate.

title: DESAI SETS ACCORDS ON BANGLADESH TRIP
description: NEW DELHI, April 18  Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai of India and President Ziaur Rahman of Bangladesh announced a series of agreements today that are expected to strengthen ties between the two countries.

title: Deng Tells U.S. Congress Group Technological Aid Is Still Sought
description: TOKYO, April 18 (AP)  The senior Chinese Deputy Prime Minister, Deng Xiaoping, told a group of members of the United States Congress today that adjust. ments in China's economic plan would not affect the introduction of advanced technology and capital from abroad, the New China News Agency reported.

title: Chinese Freighter Docks in Seattle, First in U.S. Port in Three Decades
description: SEATTLE, April 18  The Liu Lin Hai, the first Chinese merchant ship to sail into a United States port in 30 years, docked here today while a Navy band played Jesus Christ Superstar from the rock opera and political figures huddled in a chilly wind waiting to label the occasion as historic.

title: The Region
description: Six patrons of a Newark bar were shot last night during an robbery committed by three or four armed men, the police said. The robbers escaped.

title: Atlantic Avenue Shops: Eclectic Browsing
description: ATLANTIC AVENUE stretches from the edges of the East River straight into the heart of Brooklyn. Near the river, it divides the restored neighborhoods of Brooklyn Heights and Cobble Hill; a few blocks farther, its old storefronts and apartment buildings house Middle Eastern and Arab restaurants and food stores, and just before Atlantic crosses Flatbush Avenue, it traverses the Boerurn Hill neighborhood of small, turnofthecentury brownstones and town houses.

title: Peru at MidPassage
description: LIMA, Peru  We're sitting on a time bomb. A leading businessman  one of the bestknown figures in Peruvian public life before the military dictatorship took over 11 years ago  is speaking from the depths of an overstuffed chair in the lounge of his Londonstyle club in downtown Lima Whitegloved servants scurry to and fro, taking drink orders from the welldressed, wellheeled members in surroundings that would have made King Edward VII feel at home.

title: Crash of Copter in 77 On Pan Am Building Was the Area's Worst
description: The worst helicopter accident in the New York area occurred at the heliport on top of the Pan Am Building in midtown Manhattan on May 16, 1977. Five persons  four on the roof and a pedestrian on the street 59 stories below  were killed when a New York Airways helicopter keeled over on a broken landing gear, snapping off a rotor blade that flew through the air and slashed the victims.

title: Books of The Times
description: PARTLY to commemorate his 60th year of life, E.J. Kahn Jr., the veteran reporter for The New Yorker magazine, decided to keep a journal in 1977. He would address it as he used to do his Labrador retriever, Barge, Labradors being an ideal vehicle for the repository of confidences, being large, warm, soft, patient, and taciturn. About The New Yorker And Me: A Sentimental Journal is the 400page result. I have tried, off and on, over the years to keep a journal. A typical entry reads: Up at 9:00. Breakfast. Paper. Putter around. Read. Phone talk with (indecipherable). Dinner. Read. Brood late. Bed. But this man Kahn! He writes whole sentences and uses phrases like infra dig and inter alia. Everything that happens to him reminds him of 10 other things. He goes on and on. It's almost as if he had been writing with an eye to publication, though he nowhere admits it. Or else Barge was a singularly literate Labrador, if that is not to commit a redundancy.

title: Deaths
description: GIORDANO  Carmela, on April 17, 1979, beloved wife of the late Gerard, devoted mother of Gerard Jr., Robert and Ellen Helfer, dear sister of Dr. Michael J. Lamm, Antoinette Urban, Frank Levore, Anna Luon. go, Phyllis Russo and Lucille Russo also survived by four grandchildren. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 3rd Ave of 85 St. NYC. Mass of chrlstien burial. Fri, 9:30am Mary Manning Walsh Chapel. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Mary Manning Walsh Home.

title: Carnegie Study Finds Dishonesty Increasing On College Campuses
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 18 (AP)Cheating, theft and other forms of dishonesty are rising on American university and college campuses, the Carnegie Council on Policy Studies in Higher Education reported today.

title: Screen: Werner Herzog:A Personal View
description: MOVIE makers, like poets, painters, novelists and musicians, don't often talk very revealingly about their own works, which, as Werner Herzog says, are better experienced than analyzed. Nevertheless, prodded with the praise of a flabby interviewer named Laurens Straub, Mr. Herzog then goes on to talk at length about his work in "I Am My Films," the documentary that opens today at the Film Forum."I Am My Films" is not a great example of a film as an exploration of character, but it is an intelligent trailer for the Herzog filmography that includes such peculiarly brilliant and memorable films as "Even Dwarfs Started Small," "Fata Morgana," "Aguirre, the Wrath of God," "Kasper Hauser" and "Stroszek." It says something about the effectiveness of "I Am My Films" that, at the end of it, I came out of the theater wishing to see again "Fata Morgana," Mr. Herzog's feature-length, more or less abstract film shot in the Sahara, about life, death and the impermanence of all things. When I first saw "Fata Morgana" some years ago at the New York Film Festival, I thought I was losing my mind.The style of "I Am My Films" is self-conscious, shy and arrogant. Mr. Straub is the sort of interviewer who asks his subject what the subject would like to talk about and then doesn't listen to the answer, and Mr. Herzog is the sort of subject who keeps saying he doesn't want to talk about superficial things but is at his most interesting when he wanders off the great weighty subjects and remembers anecdotes. These include a story about the time he was 3 and met God (It was Christmas Day and God wore a brown suit and worked for the Electric Company), and a series of funny, hair-raising stories about Klaus Kinski and the shooting of "Aguirre" in the mountains and jungles of Peru.With Rainer Werner Fassbinder, Mr. Herzog is one of the two most exciting things to have happened in German films since World War II. Each of his films is an original. Though profoundly German and very much of his generation (he was born in 1942), he works outside of Germany more often than in it. He is fascinated by the unusual and exotic, whether it's an extraordinary talent, a dangerous obsession or a physical deformity or handicap. He calls psychiatry "the helplessness of our age," yet many of the images in his films are as dependent on Freud as they are on Edison.The best things about "I Am My Films" are the extensive clips from the director's work. These say more about the Herzog method than all of the hemming and hawing in the interviews. Two clips, especially, remain in the mind. The first, taken from "The Great Ecstasy of the Sculptor Steiner," is a slow-motion sequence showing Mr. Steiner making a record-breaking ski jump, which manages to define the ecstasy of very dangerous sport. In the second clip, from "Land of Silence and Darkness," the camera gives us a close-up of an old woman staring delightedly out the window while she's on her first airplane ride. The old woman is deaf and blind."I Am My Films" will be shown at the Film Forum tonight through Sunday at 7:45 and next week. Thursday through Sunday, at the same hour.

title: Newmont Copper Price
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation announced yesterday that its wholly owned subsidiary, the Magma Copper Company, was reducing the price for electrolytic copper fullplate cathode to 95 cents a pound from 98 cents, effective today. It said premiums for other shapes remained unchanged.

title: World News Briefs
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 18A demonstration by relatives of people reported missing after being arrested disrupted noontime traffic today in Santiago until the police arrested at least 50.

title: Newsmen Dealt Blow on Defense In Suits for Libel
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The Supreme Court ruled today, 6 to 3, that journalists defending their work against a libel suit can be required to disclose the opinions they held while preparing the material and their reasons for making specific news judgments.

title: 2 Ayatollahs Meet in Bid to Settle Their Growing Political Disputes
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 18  Ayatollah Matunoud Taleghani, the religious leader of Teheran, met with Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in Qum tonight to thresh out widening political differences between them. As the two met, their supporters were demonstrating in the streets of Teheran.

title: Japan Trade Surplus $20.6 Billion in Year
description: TOKYO, April 18  Japan rolled up its biggest dollarbased trade surplus in history in the fiscal year ended March 31, Finance Ministry officials announced today.

title: Oriental Rugs New Target for Burglars in Boston
description: BOSTON HOMEOWNERS are learning the hard way that their most valuable possessions may not be their paintings, their jewelry or even their silver chests, but the rugs under their feet.

title: U.S. SAYS ARMS TALKS HAVE NOW RESOLVED VIRTUALLY ALL ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Administration officials said today that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union had eliminated virtually all the major problems blocking conclusion of a new treaty limiting strategic missiles and bombers.

title: For 26th Newport Jazz, Take Many Trains
description: The Newport Jazz Festival will open its 26th season on June 22 and, during the next 10 days, will offer programs in New York City, Saratoga Springs, N.Y.; Waterloo Village in New Jersey and in Bellmore, L.I. George Wein, producer of the festival, made the announcement yesterday at a news conference at Michael's Pub.

title: Merger Clearance Seen By Marine Midland Chief
description: BUFFALO, April 18  The chairman of Marine Midland Banks Inc. told shareholders today that he expected New York State authorities to approve a takeover of the company by the Hongkong & Shanghai Banking Corporation.

description: THOMAS W. SICKAFOOSE

title: Nicaragua Expels Journalist
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 18 (AP)  The Nicaraguan Government expelled a Spanish journalist who was in Esteli in northern Nicaragua all last week while the town was occupied by leftwing guerrillas. Alfonso Rojo, a reporter for the Madrid newspaper Diario 16, was put aboard a plane for Guatemala Monday. The Government accused him of aiding the guerrillas, who were driven out of Esteli Saturday.

title: Letters
description: To THE HOME SECTION:

title: Talks to Avert Strike In Apartment Houses Pressed by Both Sides
description: Negotiators for apartment house owners and their service employees intensified efforts yesterday to negotiate a new contract and avert a strike threatened for Saturday.

title: An Ayatollah Who Must Be Reckoned With
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 18  Last October, when the Teheran newspaper Keyhan published a list of the six most prominent ayatollahs in Iran, the name of the 72yearold religious leader of Teheran. Ayatollah Mahmoud Taleghani, was not among them. But in a country where religious status is heavily influenced by political clout, the name of Ayatollah Taleghani is now second on that list  right after that of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Charges of Guinea Pig Surgery on Patients Denied
description: CHICAGO, April 18  Dr. Robert deVito, director of the Illinois Department of Mental Health, today denied that mental patients here were subjected to experimental and involuntary surgery in the 1950's and 1960's.

title: U.S. Six Wastes Early Lead, Ties Poland
description: MOSCOW. April 18 For a tirne this afternoon  exactly 39 seconds  it seemed as if the United States team was on its way to its first victory at the world hockey championship here.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Boston Edison Company, Boston, has elected Thomas J. Gallagher chairman. Mr. Gallagher will also retain the title of chief executive officer. He is succeeded as president by Francis M. Staszesky, who takes on the additional position of chief operating officer.

title: Appeals Court Gets KodakBerkey Case
description: A Federal appeals court heard three hours of arguments in Manhattan yesterday in a major antitrust case that resulted last year in a $ 81.4 million damage award for Berkey Photo Inc. from the Eastman Kodak Company.

title: Cauthen Wins Stake Race, Despite a Slipping Saddle
description: NEWMARKET, England, April 18 (Reuters)  Steve Cauthen showed his coolness under pressure at Newmarket today when he won the Earl of Sefton Stakes aboard Hawaiian Sound, even though his saddle slipped halfway through the race.

title: Militia in Lebanon Declares Border Area Independent
description: METULLA, Israel, April 18  The commander of the Lebanese Christian militia today declared the independence of the enclave held by his men on the Lebanese side of the Israeli border.

description: AN artist needs to know what he can do. An artist cannot do whatever he wants; only what he can.

title: Preparing to Back Them
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, in a sudden change of mind, prepared today to formally sanction a spreading wildcat strike by thousands of steelhauling teamsters as some steel mills began cutting production because of the work stoppage.

title: COMMODITIES Treasury Move to Halve Sales of Gold Lifts Prices
description: Prices of precious metals, which had been softening in recent weeks, rebounded sharply yesterday after the Treasury announced it would halve its monthly gold sales to 750,000 ounces.

title: Group Lists Complaints With USAC
description: Championship Auto Racing Teams Inc., a powerful group that walked out of the United States Auto Club last year, brought its heavy artillery of race car owners, drivers, mechanics, sponsors and track owners yesterday to an expensive luncheon at Tavern on the Green to present its case.

description: Q. What can I do to prevent the outside of my bathroom toilet tank from sweating?A. V., Brooklyn.

title: Theater: Manny, About Edward G. Robinson
description: IN scores of films, Edward G. Robinson  born Emanuel Goldenberg and nicknamed Manny  became the archtypical movie gangster. He was mean, tough and snarling, without even that hint of lovability that lurked behind James Cagney's contributions to the genre. As was true in so many Hollywood cases, this was strictly a screen image. Actually, Robinson was a serious, dedicated actor  with stage experience  and a cultured gentleman with a scholarly knowledge about fine art.

title: ThreePart Peace Plan Is Offered by Vietnam At Parley With China
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 18  Vietnam opened its conference with China in Hanoi today with a threepoint peace proposal and an angry attack.

description: The Dow Chemical Company of Midland, Mich., the nation's largest chemical concern, reported yesterday a 36.3 percent firstquarter profit increase.

title: First Boston Reports Profit
description: First Boston Inc. said yesterday that it earned $3.9 million in the first quarter, in contrast to a consolidated net loss of $685,086 in the first quarter of 1978. Revenues in the latest quarter were $32.5 million, the diversified investmentbanking company said, up from the yearearlier $16.8 million. The gains at First Boston parallel those reported by many Wall Street firms in the last few days.

description: ONCE, it is said, a gentleman named Peter Minuit stood upon the site with some Indians and traded $24 and trinkets for the island of Manhattan.

description: ALBANY, April 18 (AP)  New York State is raising the cost of new license plates by 25 cents.
