description: James P. Montgomery, president of the Great Western Savings and Loan Association and its parent corporation, the Great Western, Financial Corporation, has been named chief executive officer of both companies. Great Western, with total assets of $8.8 billion and 108 branches in California, is the nation's secondlargest savings and loan.

title: Allegheny Steel Charge Off
description: The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was withdrawing the surcharge on silicon steel products that it imposed in March and April. The company said that while the need still exists for a surcharge it was rescinding it because other domestic mill competitors have not charged a similar surcharge.

title: Profits of Borden And Nabisco Rise
description: Two of the nation's largest food producers, Borden Inc. and Nabisco, reported increased firstquarter profits yesterday.

title: Tutors to Help Pupils Prepare For Basic Test
description: While the city's schools have been closed this week for the Easter recess, the Board of Education has been preparing a citywide $200,000 crash program designed to tutor high school seniors who have not yet passed the Regents basiccompetency examination.

title: Kinard Is Patriot Aide
description: BOILING SPRINGS, N.C., April 18 (AP)  Billy Kinard resigned today as football coach at GardnerWebb College to become an assistant for the New England Patriots of the National Football League. He formerly coached Mississippi.

title: Mental Facilities In Bronx to Get Major Changes
description: A major reorganization of public mentalhealth services in the Bronx was announced yesterday. The state's Bronx Psychiatric Center received a new director and deputy director and is to undergo a $13.4 million renovation, while 60 new acutecare psychiatric beds will be added at three other hospitals.

title: SoHo Lofts Lead Off House Tour Season
description: THE spring house tour season gets under way next week, to the delight of those who enjoy the chance to peek in on a variety of living arrangements and styles of decorating. The following listing is a selection of notable tours through June.

title: 14 Hurt as Buses Collide
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 18 (AP) Fourteen persons were treated for injuries suffered when two buses collided at the morning rush hour today on the Missouri River bridge linking the downtown area with North Kansas City.

title: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS BREAKING AND ENTRY IN FEDERAL BUGGING
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution does not prevent Federal agents from breaking and entering in order to install otherwise legal electronic bugging equipment.

title: Islanders Subdue Black Hawks On Bossy's Goal in Overtime, 10
description: UNIONDALE, L.I. April 18  The top scoring line in the National Hockey League finally carried the New York Islanders to a 10 overtime victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: U.S. Charges Steel Dumping
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) Carbon steel plate manufactured in Poland is being sold at less than fair market value in the United States, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Burroughs Loses To Computer User
description: TUCSON, Ariz., April 18 (AP) A Superior Court jury has ordered the Burroughs Corporation to pay damages of $401,690 to a Tucson bottler, George Kalil, because a computer made by Burroughs consistently made mistakes.

title: 11 on School Bus Injured
description: WILSON. Okla.. April 18 (AP)  Ten children and a school bus driver were injured today when a bridge collapsed and their bus plunged a few feet into a shallow creek. One child was admitted at a hospi tal in nearby Healdton, and the nine other children were taken to an Ardmore hospital for treatment, said Eddie Davenport, a Highway Patrol dispatcher.

title: After Singer Met Lee Marvin, Her Life Was Never the Same
description: LOS ANGELES, Apri118  Almost 15 years ago, Michelle Triola, a singer, joined the cast of Ship of Fools. hoping that her small role as a dancer in the film would lead to more significant parts. instead of putting her name in lights, the role led to a tumultuous sixyear relationship with Lee Marvin, the actor. and a landmark court decision affecting the property rights of thousands of unmarried couples.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 19, 1979

title: Home Beat
description: AVID VANDERHURD, far left, is an antiques dealer who came to the United States from England six years ago. Last May he opened a store, Eastbourne Galleries, with the fabric designer Christine Van, a friend from London. Mr. Vanderhurd and Miss Van specialize in Art Deco pieces. When we saw what was available to collectors. Miss Van said. it was either expensive and signed, what we callMadison Avenue deco, or cheap mass production pieces. What they were looking for was lots of style, but reasonably priced, said Mr. Vanderhurd, who wanted his pieces to appeal to a younger collector. They travel to Europe about 10 times a year, looking for nice its. Their current wares, left, include an English Art Deco cocktail bar ($1,200), a Royal Dux polar bear ($380), an art glass hanging lampshade ($95) and airbrush paintings from the early 50's ($60$100). The shop occupies 2,500 square feet on the Lower West Side. We couldn't afford Madison Avenue, and needed the space, Mr. Vanderhurd explained. The store also offers their per sonal likes from the 50's; a bird'seye maple dining roomset, sideboards, carpets from the 1930's and English pottery from the 1920's. Eastbourne Galleries, at 130 West 26th Street (9293042), is open Monday to Friday, from 11 A.M. to 6:30 P.M., and Saturday, from noon to 6 P.M.

title: 4Year Cost of AWOL's Is Placed at $1.1 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  Absences without leave, the most prevalent crime in the nation's armed forces, cost the Government an estimated $1.1 billion from 1973 to 1977, according to a new report by the General Accounting Office.

title: Quakes in New England: Common but Mysterious
description: WESTON, Mass., April 18  Not too long ago New England earthquakes were considered just one more vaguely humorous facets of the region's notoriously quirky weather, like the annual spring tornado season or the thunder and lightning that sometimes accompany severe snowstorms here.

title: Bolivian Announces Candidacy
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 18 (Reuters) Former President Hugo Banzer has announced that he will campaign for the July 1 presidential elections as a candidate of the rightwing Nationalist Democratic Action Party. Mr. Banzer, who was overthrown in July after elections in which fraud was charged, was recently dismissed from active service in the army and was accused of having plotted to thwart a return to civilian rule.

title: John Wins His 3d for Yanks, 31
description: Throwing his groundball pitch with the mastery of a magician, Tommy John dazzled the Baltimore Orioles again last night. But this time they dented him enough to knock him out of a game that the Yankees won, 31, on towering home runs by Jim Spencer and Reggie Jackson.

title: Revlon Face Moisturizer, Found Contaminated, Is Being Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, April IS (AP)  The Govement today announced the recall of 4,000 jars of Revlon's Milk Plus 6 face moisturizer that it said might be contaminated with potentially dangerous bacteria

title: Ballet: Miss Julie Is Revived
description: CHOREOGRAPHERS often base ballets on famous literary works, and one can understand why. Literary plots provide choreographers with readymade narratives, and the familiarity of those plots makes it easy for audiences to follow the choreographic action.

title: Officials Pondered Shutting Down Reactors Similar to Three Mile Island
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission decided to permit the continued operation of reactors made by the same company that built the crippled Three Mile Island power plant even while several of the commission members were expressing concern that they did not understand the causes of the accident.

title: Seoul Plans Continued Export Aid
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 18  The South Korean Government will continue to offer lowinterest loans to the nation 's export industries to improve their international competitiveness, Kim Woun Gie, the Finance Minister, said today, despite the scandal involving the Yulsan Group, which has been accused of illegally obtaining about $300 million in export loans.

title: Backgammon:
description: Every game of backgammon is ultimately a race, and so high dice are generally favorable. There are times, however, when moving forward quickly is not advantageous. It may be necessary, for example, to maintain a certain defensive structure for several rolls. In such a case one hopes to advance as slowly as possible. Many players believe there is no way to control the rate of progress, and so feel entirely at the mercy of the dice. But a technique does exist that enables a player to slow himself down.

title: Satin, Chantilly Lace and Pearls
description: For too many years, Chris Evert has had to endure a persistent search of her psyche by strangers. Too often she has been described as icy, mechanical and metallic. But perhaps satin, lace and pearls are more like her. That's what her wedding gown was made of  white satin with 30 yards of Chantilly lace and 2,000 seed pearls. Most women, says Ted Tin. ling, the tennis couturier, know what they want their wedding gown to look like when they are little girls. I think Chris did, too. On or off a tennis court, Chris Evert has been as smooth as satin, as traditional as lace and as durable as all those pearls. Now she is on her honeymoon as Mrs. John Lloyd following a Tuesday evening wedding in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., that Ted Tinling describes as totally Chris  gracious, effi cient, no frills, but not severe. And not a circus. Only relatives and close friends were invited. Except for the wedding photographer, no cameramen were permitted inside St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church or at the reception at the Lago Mar Hotel.

title: Police Use of Radar Under Attack in Miami
description: MIAMI. April 18 Experts opposed to the use of highway radar detection units appeared in a Miami courtroom this week in an attempt to flag down the nation's traffic cops for exceeding the limits of technical reliability.

title: Bomb Injures 12 in Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL. Turkey, April IS (AP)  A bomb exploded in a movie house last night, injuring at least 12 persons, police sources said today. No group took responsibility

title: Obituary 9  No Title
description: Deaths

title: No NewsweekVision Tie
description: Peter A. Derow, president of Newsweek Inc., a subsidiary of The Washington Post Company, confirmed yesterday that the owners of Vision, the European business magazine, had terminated discussions looking toward the purchase of Vision by Newsweek.

title: Prosecutor Testifies He Could Not Prove Post Knew of Bribe
description: A member of the office of the special state anticorruption prosecutor testified yesterday that officials of The New York Post had not been indicted in the bribing of a prison guard to get pictures and other information about David Berkowitz, the socalled Son of Sam killer because there was no proof that the newspaper knew the money it paid for the material was to be used for a bribe.

title: Players End Strike In Soccer
description: The soccer players union ended its fiveday strike against the North American Soccer League yesterday afternoon, ordering players to return to their teams immediately.

title: Geodesic Greenhouse Grows in the Bronx
description: Twelve students at Fordham University erected the skeleton of a geodesic greenhouse on the university's Rose Hill campus in the Bronx yesterday to show how easy it is to put one up.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 19, 1979

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Industries plagued by high imports are being shielded from the brunt of new tariff cuts under the trade agreement initialed in Geneva last week, American negotiators have told Congress. They mentioned such industries as textiles, leather, steel, rubber and automobiles. New tariff schedules have not been published, but some the specifics were reported in a memo to legislators. [Page D1.]

title: Chain Sales Up 7% in February
description: Thirty of the nation's largest retail chains had an average sales gain in February of 7 percent over the yearearlier month and a sales increase of 9.6 percent in the first two months of 1979 over the same months last year, according to Chain Store Age, a trade publication.

title: U.S. Halving Gold Sales, Reflecting Dollar's Gains
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The Treasury announced today that it would halve the size of its monthly gold sales, thereby signaling its belief that the dollar had strengthened significantly in foreignexchange trading.

title: A. T. &T Sees Monopoly Periled
description: SEATTLE, April 18  Charles I Brown, presiding over his first annual meeting as chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, told stockholders today that he was confident that a satisfactory solution to the debate over telecommunications policy would soon be reached. He warned, however, that there was still a possibility that the Bell System could lose its monopoly grip on the nationwide phone network.

title: Design Notebook
description: PHOENIX NO one is absolutely sure who designed the Arizona Hiltmore Hotel here. The architect of record is Albert Chase McArthur, but he was known to have been given some assistance by a fellow practitioner named Frank Lloyd Wright. The hotel's official publicity releases play it sate and reter to the aesign as inspired by Frank Lloyd Wright, but Wright's role was so significant that the building is now generally considered to be all but officially a Frank Lloyd Wright creation.

title: Music: Composers' Forum Opens Spring Festival
description: THE Composers Forum opened a sixconcert Spring Festival Tuesday night at the Paula Cooper Gallery in SoHo. The series is divided into three concerts of combined videoart and music and three of new chamber music.

title: Expos Top Mets on 2 In 9th, 65
description: MONTREAL. April 18  The script that has provided the major theme for the dramas staged by the Mets and the Expos this season continued unchanged today as Montreal beat New York again by one run.

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 18, 1979

title: Pop: Fogelberg Sings and Plays
description: DAN FOGELBERG, who gave a oneman performance at Carnegie Hall Tuesday evening, is not the world's most original lyricist. Toward the middle of what seemed to this listener to be an evening of almost unrelieved tedium, he began jotting down some of Mr. Fogelberg's lines at random, just to see if they would sound as banal the next morning. They did.

title: Arabs Monetary Fund Votes to Suspend Egypt
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, April 18 (Reuters) The Arab Monetary Fund voted today to suspend Egypt from membership in retaliation for its having signed a peace treaty with Israel, the Emirates News Agency reported.

title: Choosing A Lawn Company
description: IN the summer of 76, John W. Jones of Leonia, N.J., declared himself independent of his lawn and treated it with Monsanto polyethylene  Astroturf. A less radical solution to the problems of lawn care is to have a lawn specialist shoulder some of the maintenance burden.

title: Militia Fires on U.N.
description: DERDGHAYA, Lebanon, April 18 Lebanese Christians fired on United Nations forces today, causing a number of casualties, as Lebanese Army units joined United Nations forces in the southern border area.

title: Rhodesia Auxiliaries Role in Vote Stirs Controversy
description: GOKWE TRIBAL TRUST LAND, Rhodesia, April 18  When Amos Chademwoyo walked into a clearing of thatched huts here today carrying a Sovietmade Kalashnikov assault rifle, an aging village woman greeted the 4yearold black with a handclasp and a gift of a ripe watermelon.

title: U. S. Seeks to Question Pretoria Scandal Figure
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (Reuters) United States officials are looking for Eschel M. Rhoodie, the central figure in the South African bribery scandal, to ask him about alleged payments to American politicians, the Justice Department said today.

title: Talking Business
description: Japan's wellpublicized goal of becoming a world power in computers  and by extension semiconductors  is causing concern among circuit manufacturers in the United States. They are worrying not so much because Japan's major semiconductor companies have banded together in a Governmentfinanced cooperative program to produce verylargescale advanced integrated circuits, but rather because the Japanese market is effectively closed to many types of semiconductor exports. Pointing to what happened with steel, automobiles and consumer electronics, many industry leaders say that their field is next on Japan's list of target industries.

title: Keep the Beef Boycott Within Bounds
description: The recent climb of beef prices is truly astounding. In the first quarter of 1979, overall consumer prices rose at an annual rate of 11 percent and food in general rose 17 percent. But the price of steak went up 23 percent, round roast soared 72 percent and hamburger rocketed 110 percent. It's no surprise, then, that many shoppers have begun their own personal beef boycotts. And for those who haven't yet gotten the message, the campaign for Beefless Wednesdays, launched by consumer advisers in New York, New Jersey and elsewhere, is an idea with merit  but only if it does not turn into a more sweeping vendetta against the cattle industry.

title: Berkeley Votes to Bar Its Funds From South Africa and Curb Marijuana Enforcement
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 18  Ballot initiatives that call for the withdrawal of an estimated $10 million in city funds from banks that make loans to South Africa and require the Berkeley Police Department to make enforcement of state marijuana laws its lowest priority passed by substantial margins in the municipal election here yesterday.

title: Lee Marvin Told to Pay $104,000, But Judge Prohibits Property Split
description: LOS ANGELES, Calif., April 18  Lee Marvin, the actor, was ordered today to pay $104,000 for rehabilitation purposes to Michelle Triola Marvin, the singer with whom he lived out of wedlock for six years.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: More Suspects Sought in Waterbury Robbery Murders.
description: WATERBURY, Conn., April 18 Law: enforcement officials said today that they were looking for as many as four more persons who might have been involved in the murder on Monday of three Purolator Security guards.

title: Nuclear Curb at Coast Utility Defeated
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18  Stockholders of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, the nation's secondlargest utility, today rejected by an 18to1 margin proposals to halt nuclear power construction and convert a plant under construction to solar or wind genera tion

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Draths

title: Calendar: City Walking Tour
description: Sunday Walking Tours, Museum of the City of New York, 1220 Fifth Avenue.

title: After Deficit, a Profit For Reynolds Metals
description: RICHMOND, April 18 (UPI)  The Reynolds Metals Company reported today firstquarter earnings of $38.3 million, or $2 a share, in contrast to a loss of $11.1 million in the opening period last year. Sales advanced to $775.68 million from $608.44 million.

title: 3 Killed and 12 Injured in Helicopter Crash in Newark
description: A crippled New York Airways helicopter crashed while attempting an emergency landing at Newark International Airport last night, killing three of the 18 persons aboard. Twelve of the 15 survivors were injured, four critically.

title: Living in Puerto Rico's Palace
description: SAN JUAN,PUERTO RICO  THE day we met, he invited me for lunch the next day. And the next day. And the next day. I started wondering when he'd invite me for dinner. Kate Donnelly de Romero laughed. When he finally did, he was 45 minutes late.

title: Hawks Thriving on Low Profile
description: Throughout the National Basketball Association season the image of the Atlanta Hawks has been a deceptive one They have been billed as a group of unknown, undertalented players who figured to be eliminated quickly from the playoffs by the bigger, stronger, more talented and higher paid Washington Bullets.

title: Stocks Climb on Profit Reports
description: Encouraged by interestrate prospects and glowing corporate profits, the stock market moved ahead yesterday after a string of four losing sessions. Energy and gambling issues ranked among the best gainers.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Special to The New York Times

title: $32 Million Net Earned By A.M.C.
description: DETROIT. April 18  The American Motors Corporation today reported record secondquarter earnings on sales and shed much of the gloom that had long surrounded the country's smallest car maker.

title: Income Up 1% in March
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  The personal income of Americans rose 1 percent in March after lackluster gains in the first two months of the year, the Commerce Department announced today.

title: Longtime Residency Mark of Its Success
description: FAIR LAWN, N.J.  If the various forthcoming observances will not interfere with the flourishing of his forsythia bushes, then William Roeder is all for celebrating the 50th birthday of Radburn, the historical planned town for the motor age.

title: Sven G. Thyrre, 80, Former Head Of F. L. Smidth, Civil Engineers
description: Sven G. Thyrre, former president of F. L. Smidth & Company, civil engineers of Cresskill, N.J., and executive vice president of the National Portland Cement Company when it was based in Philadelphia, died Monday of a heart attack in Cos Cob, Conn., where he lived. He was 80 years old.

title: Hers
description: ILOVE clothes. But sometimes I wish I had the kind of occupation that requires a uniform. As it is. I can spend 45 minutes getting dressed, change outfits a dozen times, and see myself reflected in a store window half an hour later, looking a mess. I have tried so hard to master this casual, throwntogether look I see in magazines. But my mascara smudges. My curls never last. Fashion eludes me.

title: Thais Attack Communist Camp
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 18 (AP) Thailand's armed forces have begun a campaign against a large Communist insurgent camp in the south, a military spokesman said today. Artillery and helicopter gunships were reported to be assisting infantry in the attack in the Sala district 350 miles south of here.

title: Sonics Set Back Lakers
description: SEATTLE, April 18 (AP)  Gus Wilhams scored 6 of his gamehigh 38 points in overtime tonight to lead the Seattle SuperSonics to a 108103 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers and a 20 lead in their National Basketbal Association playoff series.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Draths

title: Tanzanians Resume Drive in Uganda
description: MOKONO, Uganda, April 18  Led by In ancient Russian T54 tank, whose gunner sat in the turret strumming a guitar, Tanzanian troops marched out of Kampala today to begin a longawaited offensive to take over the rest of Uganda.

title: Waterbury Robbery Is Causing Misgivings in Security Industry
description: HARTFORD, April 18  The predawn attack on the Purolator Security Inc. branch in Waterbury on Monday used a new tactic that the armoredcar industry, which transports hundreds of billions of dollars a year in cash, is not prepared to meet, industry sources said today.

title: Chase Plans an Offering Of FloatingRate Notes
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation announced plans yesterday to sell $300 million of convertible floatingrate notes, an offering that would bring to $1.25 billion the volume of bankholding company financing so far In 1979.

title: Walkouts Start At State Prisons In Wage Dispute
description: ALBANY, April 18  Union officials for the state's correction officers said today that the officers are engaging in work stoppages throughout the prison system over the state's refusal to resume negotiations on a tentative contract agreement reached on April 5.

title: The Case for Casinos Is Still Not Made
description: Governor Carey's Casino Gambling Study Panel has now brought forth an interim report. It purports to duck the main question  should casinos be made legal in New York  and says that should be left to the Legislature and the people. But despite even this unconvincing neutrality, the report goes on to say that if gambling is approved, the state should license private casino operators, require them to locate in resort areas (including Manhattan), and supervise them strictly. The main trouble with all this is that it is sketchy; since the commission is barely two months old, the report could hardly be otherwise. Yet, having heard this counsel, legislators are expected to vote in favor. We hope they take their time.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: At the Pelham Bay police stable, a police officer shows Bryan Booth, 10, his technique for controlling a horse. Bryan was one of 50 members of the Horsemasters 4H Club from Greenwich, N.Y., who visited the stable, where police horses and riders are trained for duty in New York City. Most of the youngsters have their own horses.

title: The City
description: More than 2,500 angry union members circled City Hall yesterday to show their support for striking schoolbus drivers. They called Mayor Koch union buster.

title: Rights as Realpolitik
description: NEW HAVEN  The issue of human rights, when applied to United States foreign policy, cuts across two motifs deriving from the nation's Protestant heritage: The notion that moral duty should guide men in their behavior and the belief that men should also be practical in their actions. Few Americans seem to doubt that the cause of human rights is worthy of wholehearted support, but many doubt whether it is practical to become its champion.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, April 18. 1979

title: AT HOME ABROAD Corruption Of Power
description: HAIFA. Israel  A.B. Yehoshua is one of Israel's leading writers. His haunting novel, The Lover  about the feelings of husbands and wives, parents and children, Arabs and Jews  was critically acclaimed when it appeared in the United States last year.

title: Trial by Komiteh
description: Iran is learning that freedom can suffer as much from too little government as from too much. Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan and several of his cabinet colleagues have been unable to prevent the kangaroo trials that all too often end up in executions. Scrupulous respect for the due process of law may be too much to expect in a country that suffered so much repression. But the judicial terror is now undermining Iran's new Government and betraying the hopes many Iranians placed in their revolution.

title: New Yorkers in Protest For Imprisoned Russian
description: Zinaida Grigorenko. the wife of a former Soviet general who was given asylum in the United States last year, joined members of Amnesty International, a rights group, in a protest against the Imprisonment in the Soviet Union of 83yearold Vladimir Shelkov, a Seventhday Adventist minister.

title: Bronfman Unit Reopens Bid to Take Over Brascan
description: TORONTO, April 18  Edper Equities Ltd., an investment arm of the Bronfman family, today reopened its bid to take over Brascan Ltd., which itself is embroiled in a proposed takeover of the F.W.yoolworth Company.

title: Angels Beat Twins, 116, for 7 in Row as Carew Stars
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 18 (AP)  Rod Carew had four hits. drove in two runs and scored three today as the California Angels outslugged the Minnesota Twins, 116, for their seventh straight victory.

title: Carey Holds Phoneside TV Chat
description: Governor Carey told a television audience last night that the state needed games of chance to attract conventions that would otherwise go to New Jersey.

title: Corporations Report Quarterly Sales and Earnings Results
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Music: Juilliard's Oedipus Rex
description: STRAVINSKYS Oedipus Rex is a triumph of crossbreeding, a hybrid that is a fusion of two ancient varieties of music drama. For this reason and because the composer built formidable stylistic puzzles into a work that he labeled an operaoratorio, the odds are high against your encountering a convincing production anywhere, let alone at a student concert.

title: ABC Makes Disclosure On 2 Rulings by Court
description: In a rare breach of secrecy, two decisions of the United States Supreme Court were reported this week by ABC News before their official announcement.

title: Chimerine Will Head Chase Econometrics
description: Chase Econometric Associates Inc. will not have its new chief economist on board until July 1, but the appointment to the prominent post leaked out yesterday.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  The deadline for submitting bids has passed with only five cities competing for the 1980 Democratic Presidential nominating convention. The entries are Dallas, Detroit, Philadelphia, New York and MinneapolisSt.Paul.

title: Mondale Talks to Danes About Nuclear Worries
description: COPENHAGEN, April 18 (Reuters)Vice President Mondale voiced concern today about what he called an increase in Soviet nuclear weapons in Eastern Europe.

title: Entertainment Events
description: THE ELEPHANT MAN by Bernard Pornerance. Directed by Jack Hotsiss; starring Kevin Conway. Carole Shelley and Philip Anglin% at the Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street. 6:45.

title: Sound
description: WITH the arrival of spring stirring wanderlust and other seasonal urges, it's time to cock an ear at car stereo once again. Shaking their heads at their own findings, market researchers report that, for the last two years, car stereo has been the fastestgrowing segment of the audio industry. In the 18to34 age bracket  the marketeers favorite bit of the population  it is not uncommon to spend upward of $1,000 for car sound, proving that either prosperity or profligacy rules among the young.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Concerto No. 1 for Violin and Orchestra, Vivaldi Evening in Georgia, Musical Picture in G minor, IppolitovIvanov : Fanfare 4.

title: F.B.I. and Justice Agency Agree On Limit to C.I.A. Death Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Justice Department have concluded that the facts in the mysterious death of John Paisley, a former official of the Central Intelligence Agency, do not warrant a counterintelligence investigation, the Senate Intelligence Committee said today.

title: 2 Procedural Pleas by Talmadge Rejected by Senate Ethics Panel
description: WASHINGTON. April 18 (AP)  The Senate Select Committee on Ethics today refused to bar evidence taken from the office of Senator Herman E. Talmadge from being used in the panel's investigation of allegations of financial misconduct made against the Georgia Democrat.

title: Shirley Maclaine to Do Film Comedy
description: LOS ANGELES, April 18  Pursuing the new Hollywood trend toward movies frankly exploring the slippery surface of modern American marriage, Shirley MacLaine and Anthony Hopkins have signed to star in Consenting Adults, a $5.5 million comedy to be made in New England next fall.

title: Squash Racquets Under Way
description: A street kid from Queens who developed his quickness playing table tennis stole the show last night as five of the leading squashracquets players in the world began a roundrobin competition for a $3.000 first prize at the Uptown Racquet Club.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday. April 19,1979

title: Blue Wins 4th in Row For Giants
description: SAN DIEGO, April 19 (AP)  Marc Hill and Terry Whitfield drove in four runs apiece and Vida Blue notched his fourth victory without a loss today as the San Francisco Giants outlasted the San Diego Padres. 1410.

title: $90 Million Renovation At Lexington and 46th
description: A 16story office building in midtown Manhattan will be renovated and enlarged at a cost of about $90 million.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: U.S. Is Willing to Provide Funds For Refugee Camps in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA,Indonesia, April 19 (Reuters)  The United States is prepared to finance transit camps for Indochinese refugees waiting for resettlement, a special United States envoy said today.

title: 200 Attend a Service For Iran's ExPremier At N. Y. Islamic Cente,
description: Funeral prayers from the Koran sounded through the Islamic Center at 1 Riverside Drive yesterday at a memorial service for Amir Abbas Hoveida, the former Iranian Prime Minister who was executed April 7 by the revolutionary authorities m Teheran.

title: MAYOR NAMES CHOICE FOR CHICAGO POLICE
description: CHICAGO, April 19  Mayor Jane M. Byrne has named Patrick V. Murphy, former New York City Police Commissioner, as her top choice for chief of this city's 13,000member police force.

title: SENATORS CAUTIONED ON TAIWAN BY DENG
description: PEKING, April 19  Deputy Prime Minister Deng Xiaoping warned a delegation from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that Congressional legislation on Taiwan had impaired the United States relations with China.

title: Union Lawsuit Alleges Surveillance by Police
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)  The Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers sued the Mayor, police chief and other officials in Milledgeville, Ga., today for $600,000 over alleged police surveillance of union activities involving the J.P. Stevens textile plant.

title: Supreme Court Seeks Source of Disclosures on Rulings
description: WASHINGTON. April 19  Chief Justice Warren E. Burger's aides are questioning members of the Supreme Court staff to determine the source of two disclosures of the Justices secret preparation of decisions.

title: Kodak to Sell Film in China
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that its amateur color film will be available to tourists visiting China beginning this June

title: Mets Get Taveras From Pirates
description: Frank Taveras, the 28yearold shortstop of the Pittsburgh Pirates who stole 118 bases in the last two seasons, was acquired by the New York Mets yesterday in a trade for Tim Foli, another 28yearold infielder, and Greg Field, a minor league pitcher.

title: Now's the Time to Debate the Debates
description: Clearly, the most revealing moment of the 1976 Presidential campaign was the night the mikes went dead during the Great Television Debate. Jimmy Carter and Gerald Ford stood stiff and dumb at their rostrums for 27 minutes, too scared even to sit down or chat the time away. The scene was a clue to the leaden leadership these men in fact provided, but we evoke for another reason. A thoughtful committee assembled by the Twentieth Century Fund says it's time to think ahead to the Great Debates of 1980  and we suppose is. If only we could be sure of interpreting it properly, another unforeseen moment of truth is always worth planning for.

title: Carter Plan On Oil Tax Due Soon
description: JEKYLL ISLAND, Ga., April 19 The White House plans to send Congress next week detailed proposals, but not draft legislation, for the President's proposed tax on the windfall profits he says will be reaped by the oil companies as the result of the gradual lifting of price controls.

title: New Films Series Opening at the Modern
description: When it comes to novelty, the focus of attention this weekend is on the Whitney Museum of American Art, where an unusual exhibition called ReVisions: Projects and Proposals in Film and Video has just opened, and on the Museum of Modern Art, where the eighth annual New Directors/New Films series begins tonight.

title: For NonAgency Adoption
description: At a time when there is a severe shortage of adoptable children, there is what amounts to a movement throughout American socialservice agencies, the news media and district attorneys to extinguish independentplacement adoptions and force all adoptive parents and biological mothers to deal with authorized agencies.

title: U.S. Criticizes Polish News Fee
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)  The State Department criticized the Polish Government today for imposing a $350 fee on foreign journalists assigned to cover the visit of Pope John Paul II in June. A spokesman, Hodding Carter 3d, called the fee excesssive.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: Millions of barrels

title: Flyers Give Up HorneIce Edge
description: The law of diminishing returns begins working in the Rangers favor tonight.

title: ABRAHAM A. DESSERT A LABOR NEGOTIATOR
description: Abraham Albert Desser, a labor organizer in the Depression who later became a Federal mediator seeking peace in major industrial disputes, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. Mr. Desser, who lived at 150 West End Avenue, would have been 77 years old May 31.

title: Vance and Dobrynin Meet Again on Arms Accord
description: WASHINGTON. April 19  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union met today on the nearly completed treaty limiting strategic arms and there were signs that plans would be announced next week for a meeting between President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev. the Soviet leader.

title: Theater: Elephant Man Opens
description: ELEPHANT MAN, that haunting parable about natural man trading his frail beauty and innocence for the protection and prison of society, has made a splendid move to Broadway.

title: Ripple Effect Is Feared in Press Ruling
description: A cry went up from journalists around the country Wednesday when the United States Supreme Court ruled that the First Amendment's guarantee of freedom of the press does not protect journalists accused of libel from disclosing why they made specific news judgments in the course of preparing articles or television programs. The negative effect of the decision on the press, however, may be lessthan it seemed at first glance.

description: Deaths

title: Bank Earnings Results Listed
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

description: Deaths

title: S.&
description: Standard & Poor's lowered its ratings on the senior debt of the Chrysler Corporation yesterday to BB from BBB and also reduced its rating of the auto maker's preferred stock to B from BB.

title: Product Safety Panel Requests Voluntary Recall of Hair Dryers
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)  The Consumer Product Saftey Commission staff, citing public concern about the possible health hazards of hair dryers containing asbestos, asked the industry today to voluntarily recall millions of dryers.

title: Lawyers Troubled by Rehabilitation Concept in Marvin Decision
description: The concept of rehabilitation, which figured prominently in the award of $104,000 this week in California to Michele Triola Marvin in her suit against the actor Lee Marvin, is relatively new to family law.

title: Around the Nation
description: By The Associated Press

title: Okonite Officer Admits Perjury
description: Harry A. Penhale, vice president of the Okonite Company, pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to a Federal perjury charge involving a pricefixing investigation of powercable manufacturers.

title: Cosmos to Intensify Pursuit of Johan Cruyff
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 19  Johan Cruyff, the former captain of the national team of the Netherlands, will be at 75 Rockefeller Plaza in New York tomorrow, talking contract with the Cosmos.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company disclosed plans yesterday to offer $610 million, or $2,682 a share, for the Bodcaw Company, a forestproducts concern with headquarters in Dallas.

title: Nassau Sells $20 Million Issue
description: Nassau County sold $20 million of general purpose bonds yesterday, but it rejected bids for $16.6 million of sewer bonds because the low bid was submitted incorrectly. The issue was rescheduled for sale Monday.

title: NBC Dismisses 8 More Aides
description: Continuing investigations of embezzlement and expenseaccount fraud by the Federal Government and NBCTV have resulted in the dismissal of eight more NBC executives and the resignation of another, a spokesman for the network said yesterday.

title: Broadway
description: THAT CHAMPIONSHIP SEASON, Jason Miller's play about four basketball players and their old coach, will be revived on Broadway next season. Moreover, it will be done with black actors, although not a line in the script will be changed. No concession at all to color, Don Gregory, the producer, says. I think we'll turn a corner in theater with this one. Meanwhile, the actors who will turn the corner will be Moses Gunn, Cleavon Little, Georg Stanford Brown, Dick Anthony Williams and Glynn Turman. When That Championship Season was done in 1972, the actors were Richard A. Dysart, Charles Durning, Walter McGinn, Michael McGuire and Paul Sorvino. The next year, the play, which originated at the Public Theater, won the Pulitzer Prize for drama.

title: Art People
description: SEEMS odd, does it, that after its appearance at three leading art museums outside New York, the Pompeii A.D. 79 show will open here Sunday at the American Museum of  well, Natural History? Wouldn 't this assemblage of more real 300: Roman artifacts and art object from the buried cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum be more appropriate the blockbustering Metropolitan Mu seum of Art?

title: Watson's 69 Leads by Shot
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 19  Calm, cool and relaxing. These were the words used by several golfers to describe the Tournament of Champions held here one week after Fuzzy Zoeller won a threeway, twohole playoff to capture the Masters championship.

title: Short Interest on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 3.3 million shares in the month ended April 12 to a new high of 43.2 million shares. The previous high was 42.9 million shares on May 15, 1978. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 40.1 million shares.

title: Advertising
description: THE General Motors Building can boast of at least two wellknown ad agencies, Wells, Rich, Greene, and Leber Katz Partners. It also has Parkson Advertising and that's what this item is all about. Here we have a littleknown $75 million agency that is about to go public, not in the sense of selling shares, but rather opening its doors to other clients than the J. B. Williams Company and Nabisco.

title: National Black Political Convention Is Urged for 1980
description: ST. LOUIS, April 19  Leaders of the National Association of Black Social Workers have called for a national black political convention next year to develop national strategies to counteract the blatant racism in health, housing, employment and in the retrenchment of social proarams.

title: Woody Allen's Friends Were All There
description: Woody Allen's newest film is called Manhattan, it is about romance in Manhattan, it was premiered the other night in a Manhattan movie theater, and the blacktie party afterward was in a Manhattan art museum. And where was Mr. Allen? In Paris.

title: Arms Hurdle: Trust in Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  The latest skirmishing over the touchy issue of protecting against Soviet cheating under a new arms treaty has produced no winners this week. But it has pointed up a predicament inherent in the entire effort at arms control for the 1980's.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 20, 1979

title: U.S. Planning to Establish Force For Quick Mideast Intervention
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  The United States is forming contingency plans to establish a force of 100,000 troops, including 40,000 combat soldiers, for use in defense of American interests in sensitive areas, according to qualified Pentagon sources.

title: Mayor Presses Kibbee to Raise Tuition
description: Mayor Koch has urged Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, Chancellor of the City University of New York, to recommend a $150ayear tuition increase for freshmen and sophomores, warning that a failure to do so by next week would lead to a $5.2 million cut in the university's operating budget.

title: For Children
description: ?? MUSIC CONCERT, with Sandy and Caroline paton. of FolkLegacy Records, who Will sind about early settlers, migrant workers and otter AmoriCane. ?? br ?? and ?? musk. Saturday at 8:30 P.M., at the ?? ?? & ?? Center. 39 ?? Road. 3/4 of a mile north of Exit 35 on the Merritt Partway. Stamford. Can. Tickots.$3. ?? (303) 322.1646.

title: Publishing: Georgian, 29, Wins Poetry Award
description: A 29YEAR OLD Georgian, David Bottoms, has won the Walt Whitman Award of the Academy of American Poets, open to United States citizens who have not previously published a book in a standard edition. The judge was Robert Penn Warren, who this week was honored with his third Pulitzer Prize for his book of poems Now and Then

title: G.O.P. Contenders Begin Efforts Early in the South
description: ATLANTA, April 17  From Mississippi to Florida, in towns where Republican Presidential candidates have always been scarcer than breakfasts without grits, John B. Connally and Representative Philip M. Crane of Illinois are wooing Ronald Reagan's admirers with campaigns that portray the 68yearSold Californian as yesterday's hero.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the firstquarter earnings of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company_ The earnings, as reported by the company, were $1.36 billion, compared with $1.27 billion a year earlier.

title: BankAmerica Profits Up In First Quarter by 26%
description: Net operating earnings of the BankAmerica Corporation rose 26 percent in the first quarter of 1979 to $129 million, or 88 cents a share, it reported yesterday.

title: A Nevada Study Praises Jersey's Supervision of Gamblingi
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., April 19 Nevada officials said today that New Jersey had developed a comprehensive, effective government regulatory system to keep organized crime out of the gambling industry in Atlantic City by combining the best features of several systems, including those in Nevada and in England.

title: Rubicam Wins Ford Ad Account
description: In a surprise move yesterday, the Ford Motor Company announced that Young & Rubicam International would be the new ad agency for the LincolnMercury division and Wells, Rich, Greene, Inc., the new agency for its corporate advertising. Industry sources put the billings involved at about $75 million, making this the secondlargest account movement in advertising history.

title: $4.6 Million Awarded to Officials For Libel by a Hearst Newspaper
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 (AP)  A Superior Court jury ordered The San Francisco Examiner and two reporters yesterday to pay 94.56 million in damages stemming from an investigative series of articles the paper printed about the allegedly unjust murder conviction of a Chinatown youth.

title: Florida Execution Weighed
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 19 (AP) Gov. Robert Graham and his Cabinet will hear arguments tomorrow on whether John Spenkelink, a convicted murderer, should be executed in the electric chair. Mr. Spenkelink, one of 130 persons sentenced to death in Florida, could become the first person executed in the state since 1964 and the first in the nation to be unwillingly executed since 1967.

title: Books of The Times
description: THEY must have had fun  Isaiah Berlin and Stuart Hampshire and A.J. Ayer  lolling around Oxford in the late 1930's, wrangling over positivism and symbolic logic, verification and phenomenalism, wondering about linguistics.And it must have been more of an emotional wrench than Mr. Berlin, now Sir Isaiah, is willing to concede in his brief preface to this book, when he decided at the end of the war to look in another direction:

title: Fight Looms in Indiana School Drug Raids
description: HIGHLAND, Ind., April 18  A controversy has developed in this conservative and normally placid city of 26,000 people just outside Chicago as a result of a surprise raid in which 50 police officers, using German shepherds and Doberman pinschers, conducted a roombyroom search for drugs at the city's junior and senior high schools.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Printers at Closed London Times Reject Proposals for Arbitration
description: LONDON, April 19 (Reuters)  Printers for The Times of London, Britain's oldest daily newspaper, today rejected proposals to take their dispute with management to independent arbitration.

title: ANEW CITY SURPLUS MAY SAVE 4,000 JOBS FACING CETA CUTOFF
description: Mayor Koch and his fiscal advisers have discovered that there is more money for next year's budget than they had expected, raising the possibility that they can save 4,000 jobs. The jobs are now being paid for by Federal funds that will be cut off in the fall.

title: Dance: Paul Taylor Troupe Sparkles
description: IF any group has swept a fresh breeze  make that a gust of exhilaration  into the dance season it is the Paul Taylor Dance Company, which will he appealing at the City Center 55th Street Dance Theater through April 29.

title: Abrams Plans to Stress Role as a Public Advocate
description: Robert Abrams, the New York State Attorney General, yesterday announced a major reorganization of his office in an effort to strengthen its role as public advocate.

title: Pompeii Comes to Life Again; Pompeii Comes to Life at Museum; Tips on Tickets
description: IT is very good news that Pompeii A.D. 79 has arrived at the American Museum of Natural History, where it opens to the public Sunday and will be on view through July 31. By no stretch of courtesy could it be called a great exhibition, but as a documentary survey of a city that came to a sudden and dramatic end almost 1,900 years ago to the day, it offers much that is of enormous historical interest, much that has an exceptional immediacy and a minority of objects that would fire even the most sluggish imagination.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BuckbeeMears Company, St. Paulbased company engaged in the manufacture of ophthalmic lenses, color television aperture masks and precision metal and glass parts, has elected to its board of directors Robert W. Fischer, a financial consultant, and Charles S. Strauch, executive vice president of the Memorex Corporation.

title: G.S.A.'s Pittsburgh Unit Cleared in F.B.I. Inquiry
description: PITTSBURGH, April 19  The Federal Bureau of Investigation has found that, while some administrative irregularities have taken place in the Pittsburgh district of the General Services Administration, there has been nothing to warrant criminal prosecution.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Cattle Drop Seen Lifting Beef Prices
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  The number of cattle being fattened for market was down again at the beginning of this month, confirming forecasts that consumers will pay even higher prices for beef in the coming months.

title: With Deadline at Midnight, Union And Apartment Houses Seek Pact
description: Negotiators for apartmenthouse owners and their service employees focused on job security and wage issues yesterday as a special mediator began efforts to assist them in resolving their contract dispute.

title: 3,000 Buildings Facing a Strike
description: If buildingservice employees strike, an estimated 3,000 apartment houses, including some of the city's most lux. urious, would be affected.

title: GROWTH IN ECONOMY PLUNGED IN QUARTER BUT INFLATION ROSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  The growth of the American economy fell off abruptly in the first three months of 1979 to an annual rate of less than 1 percent, but price inflation accelerated, the Government reported today.

title: Country 's Biggest Bike Tour Wheels Off on Sunday
description: And some 10,000 cyclists will have Queens and Brooklyn as well this Sunday in the country s biggest bicycling event  a fiveborough, 36mile, allday tour on wheels of New York City. Pushoff is 7 A.M. at Battery Park, rain or shine.

title: Auctions
description: THE American Indian art assembled for sale tomorrow at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, rep resents the largest and most diverse collection ever offered at the galleries. This also the most important auction in the field since the sale of the George Green collection at the same house in 1971. The star lot in the sale is a Pacific Northwest Coast wood face mask, a work painted bright red by the Tlingit, an Alaskan people, which is estimated to sell for $20,000 to $30,000. Another Tlingit prize is an extraordinary bone, steel and leather knife  said to have been used to sacrifice slaves at tribal ceremonies  that may sell for up to $12,000. Highlights among the beadwork, pottery, textiles, Navajo blankets, Eskimo art and clothing include an Apache basket once owned by William Randolph Hearst, which might rewrite the $6,100 record; a deck of Apache playing cards, that may sell for $5,000 at the most, and a Germantown blanket once owned by J. Edgar Hoovwhich sell for up to $3,000.

title: U.S. Reports Radioactive Iodine Has Dropped at Three Mile Island
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 19 (AP)Levels of radioactive iodine leaking from the disabled Three Mile Island nuclear power plant have dropped, and a new filtering system is being employed to stop further releases, Federal officials said today.

title: LEBANESE SECESSION HAS LITTLE IMPACT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 19  A declaration of independence by Lebanese Christians for the area they control in the south beside the Israeli border does not change much in practical terms for the Lebanese Government  the region has not been under Beirut's control since 1975

title: Begin Rebuts Waldheim's Lebanon Charge
description: JERUSALEM, April 19  Prime Minister Menachem Begin sent a letter today to Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations denying that Israel was supporting armed Lebanese Christian resistance in the south against an advance by troops of the Lebanese Army.

title: Table Tennis Team Gains Upper Echelon
description: Though the State Department professes ignorance, a group of men and women armed with table tennis paddles left the United States yesterday for North Korea in the latest exercise in Ping Pong diplomacy.

title: EARNINGS American Express Increases Profits 12.1 %
description: The American Express Company reported yesterday a 12.1 percent rise in firstquarter earnings to a record $73.3 million, or $1.02 a share, from $65.4 million, or 91 cents a share, in the initial three months of 1978. The rise was less than the revenue increase of 16.7 percent to a new high of $1.07 billion from $916.9 million last year.

title: Work Halted on Rome Mosque
description: ROME, April 19 (Reuters)  Construction on Rome's first mosque has been halted by authorities pending an inquiry into complaints that the $35 million project violates environment protection laws.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: If the Council on Wage and Price Stability ever works off its backlog of pending cases, much of the credit will go to Sally Katzen, who in two weeks as its general counsel has already won praise for getting things done. Miss Katzen, a 36yearold lawyer, serves as alter ego for her boss, Barry P. Bosworth, the council's director, on the two kinds of cases that can make or break the Administration's voluntary wageprice standards: noncompliance and requests for exceptions.

title: Archdiocese Rates TV
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York yesterday issued an eightpage booklet strongly criticizing some of the nation's most popular television programs and movies as well as some bestselling music as morally objectionable.

title: Peru's Rocky Road
description: LIMA. Peru  It is not our intention to suppress the independent press .... with the exception of those [publications) that were suspended.

title: Net Soars At Alcoa And Alcan
description: PITTSBURGH, April 19  The Aluminum Company of America reported at its annual meeting today a 136.9 percent rise in firstquarter profits to $127.7 million, or $3.62 a share, from $53.9 million, or $1.53 a share, in the first quarter of 1978. Sales and operating revenues rose to $1.205 billion from $938.2 million.

title: Drivers Strike Cuts Steel Output
description: WASHINGTON, APRIL 19  Some steel manufacturers began laying off workers today and even bigger cuts in production were scheduled for the weekend because of the widening strike of teamster steel haulers.

title: Art: Mogul India, Portraits of an Age
description: EVER since they attracted the admiration of Rembrandt, who was amazingly prompt in making copies of them in the 1650 's, the Mogul portraits created in India in the 17th century have been among the most admired examples of Asian classical art in the West.

title: U.S. to Assess Egypt Air Defense
description: CAIRO, April 19  Egypt has asked the United States for 50 Hawk missile batteries to fill the gaps in its aging, Sovietsupplied air defense system, Western officials said today.

title: John Dexter May Leave Met Opera
description: The Metropolitan Opera 's director of production, John Dexter, is considering whether to resign so that he can resume his interrupted theater career or to accept another, probably diminished, role in the company.

title: World News Briefs
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, April 19  A court here acquitted four former Nazi SS guards today of charges that they participated in the murders of 250,000 Jews, setting off an an protest in which demonstrators briefly took over the courtroom.

title: Economic Light in the Regulatory Tunnel
description: Congress has delegated discretionary power Federal agencies to regulate almost everything: workplace safety, the price of imported golf carts, the wages paid on Governmentfinanced construction projects. But the regulatory agencies tend to have tunnel vision; their concern generally extends no farther than the immediate demands of the task assigned.

title: China Cuts Wheat Buying
description: WASHINGTON. April 19 (AP) China has canceled another order for United States wheat, stirring conjecture that it may be running into storage or payment problems. an Agriculture Department report indicated today. This cancellation involved 106.626 metric tons of wheat. Earlier this week China had canceled an order for 118,374 metric tons. and last month it canceled an order for 300,000 metric tons (of 2,205 pounds each).

title: Screen: 'Skin Deep':Jazz Mass at St Patrick's
description: WHEN Sandra Ray (Deryn Cooper), a city-trained masseuse somewhere beyond the first bloom of youth, arrives in the little town of Carlton to set up shop in the local health club, the men wink at one another, and the self-appointed guardians of public morals predict the worst."Skin Deep," a first feature by the New Zealand director Geoff Steven, is a nice, socially aware comedy of the sort that Hollywood might have made 30 or 40 years ago, when movies didn't have to be blockbusters and when movie makers were allowed to express some interest in the quality of the life around them.The film will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art tonight at 6 and Sunday night at 8:30 in the New Directors/New Films series sponsored by the museum and the Film Society of Lincoln Center."Skin Deep" recalls two recent films by Michael Ritchie ("Smile") and Jonathan Demme ("Handle With Care"), though in many ways its view of small-town life is much more bleak, its attitude toward hypocrisy more angry and its disgust with economic boosterism less satiric. I'm not sure that it is thus more honest, only that it is more inclined to worry.I also suspect that because Mr. Steven knows that small towns like Carlton are very easy to make fun of, he has made his film with care and given it characters he would like to respect, despite their short-sighted attempts to harness progress. He's also asembled a cast of excellent actors, particularly Ken Blackburn as the head of the local booster club and Grant Tilly as a hen-pecked husband for whom the easy-going Sandra Gray represents his wickedest dreams come true. Best of all is Miss Cooper, who has the look and manner of a woman who has been through everything once, at a very early age, and is not about to suffer twice. It's a secure, intelligent performance, strong without a bit of toughness. Like the New Zealand countryside in which the film is set, the character is both beautiful and utterly lonely.Also on the bill with "Skin Deep" is a 25-minute animated film from England, "Animation for Live Action" by Vera Neubauer. It's an extremely glum look at a film maker who is a woman and liberated. She sees herself being chopped up, ground up, decapitated and generally abused in other ways, all of which (as I read the images) is to be tolerated because of a liberated woman's Love of Film.

title: Bank Issue Yield Is Set At 11.05%
description: The floatingrate note issue of the Charter New York Corporation, which increased in size from $75 million to $90 million because of strong demand, was priced yesterday to yield 11.05 percent initially.

title: Struggling Monticello Wants Aid
description: MONTICELLO. N.Y., April 19Sapped of revenue by offtrack betting and hurt at the gate by dwindling tourism, Monticello Raceway began its 22d season tonight with hopes of coming up with a saver, the way many racetrack bettors get saver tickets as backups in case their first choice fails.

title: Market Place
description: A FEW fans of the Brown Company accepted without dismay Gulf and Western's announcement yesterday that it would not pay $19.75 a share for the Brown shares that Gulf and Western does not already own.

title: Carson Leaving Tonight Show
description: LOS ANGELES, April 19  Johnny Carson, host of The Tonight Show, one of television's most successful and profitable programs, has told the National Broadcasting Company that he plans to leave the show on Sent. 30. after 17 years.

title: Tito Says Two Peace Bids Failed
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 19 President Tito said today that he tried unsuccessfully to resolve the recent conflicts in Southeast Asia and Uganda. He said his attempts were made in an effort to prevent further divisions among nonaligned nations that threatened to destroy their movement.
