description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, April 21 DORIC (Home). Left Bermuda April 19; due!8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Henry Ford Said to Bar A High Post for Nephew
description: Henry Ford 2d does not plan to offer his nephew Benson Ford Jr. a high position in the Ford Motor Company, a source dose to the family said yesterday.

title: Bronx Program Offers ApartmentLiving Aid For Frail and Elderly
description: Elderly people who are frail will live in apartments with financial help from the state and with care by private sponsors under a pilot program that was presented yesterday in the Bronx.

title: For Mrs. Marcos, Growing Power but Declining Esteem
description: MANILA, April 14  The question seemed innocuous enough: Which Fill. pino do you admire most? Panorama, The Manila Bulletin's Sunday magazine, asked its college readers to reply, and 72 did so.

title: Carson Move May Add To RCA's NBC Woes
description: Johnny Carson is believed to be a profit center unto himself at the broadcasting subsidiary of the RCA Corporation. According to industry analysts The Tonight Show is estimated to account for 17 percent, or $23 million, of the pretax profits of the National Broadcasting Company. Last year NBC earned $122.1 million.

title: The Pop Life
description: IN just a short time the Village People have entered into this country's folk Mythology; if nothing else served to certify their place in the pantheon, the Village Persons parody on last week's Saturday Night Live would do it.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY. APRIL 19. 1979

title: ExRepublican Leader MI Is Found Guilty Of Lying in Drug Case
description: A former Republican chairman of Staten Island was convicted yesterday of lying to a grand jury about conversations he had had with a prosecutor dealing with a major narcotics case.

title: Economic Scene
description: IT was pure manbitesdog on the economic news front this week when the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, G. William Miller, parried the pressure from the Secretary of the Treasury, W. Michael Blumenthal, to raise interest rates and tighten monetary policy to slow down inflation.

title: When Homework Hurts, They Dial for Help
description: PHILADELPHIA. April 19 (AP) I 'm stuck. said the young caller. I can 't figure out how to do 25 times2?

title: SPEECH BY GISCARD HEATS POLITICAL ROW!
description: PARIS, April 19  The campaign for the June elections for the European Parliament has opened formally in France with a declaration by President Valry Giscard d'Estaing, made in terms that added fuel to the raging French political feud, that it has nothing to do with domestic politics.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Howard K Smith Resigns From ABC
description: Howard K. Smith yesterday posted notice of his resignation on the bulletin board of the ABC News office in Washington because, he said, he felt that his role as commentator on the nightly news show was being eliminated and that he would be left without a real function.

title: Greeks and Russians Celebrate Easter Rite
description: Eastern Orthodox Christians, observing a liturgical calendar that differs from the one followed by Western churches, prepare to celebrate Easter this weekend with rites and festivities designed to awaken the spirit and the senses.

title: IN THE NATION A Chilling Court
description: The Supreme Court has generally upheld the constitutional right of the press to publish or broadcast what it knows. But whether or not by design, the Court seems to be moving on two tracks toward a position that editors and reporters have little  if any constitutional protection when engaged in gathering the news.

title: Robert H. Dee, 46, End For the Boston Patriots
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H., April 19 (AP) Robert H. Dee, who was credited with scoring the first touchdown in the American Football League while he was a defensive end with the old Boston Patriots, died here yesterday. He was 46 years old.

title: Stage: Miller's Price Revived
description: THE Price, which is about the cost of ambition, compromise and cowardice  the price that people pay in pursuit of choice  is one of Arthur Miller's warmest and most human plays. John Stix's harmonious revival at the Harold Clurman Theater reminds us that for all Mr. Miller's acknowledged social consciousness he has often concerned himself with the problems of families.

title: U.S. to Study Maine Tremor Data Before Reopening Nuclear Plant
description: AUGUSTA. Me., April 19 (UPI)  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission says that data on the earth tremor near Maine's only nuclear power plant will have to be analyzed before the plant can be reopened.

title: Japan's Premier, Wary of Soviet, Favors a Stronger Defense Effort
description: TOKYO, April 19  Japan's Prime Minister, worried by recent aggressive Soviet military moves in the Far East, favors a bigger Japanese defense effort, closer military cooperation with the United States and a tough attitude toward Vietnam, the Soviet Union's only ally in Southeast Asia.

title: Hawks Facing 20 Deficit
description: For threequarters of the regular season. Clark Gillies teamed with Bryan Trottier and Mike Bossy to form the highestscoring line in the National Hockey League.

title: South Carolina Hearing Set on Bid for Woolworth
description: The South Carolina Securities Cornmissioner yesterday scheduled a hearing on April 27 to determine if the state's security laws have been violataed by the tender offer by Brascan Ltd. for the F.W. Woolworth Company's stock.

title: After 56 Years, Roy Larsen, 80, Retires as Executive of Time Inc.
description: Roy E. Larsen's first job was in a bank, and he hated it. He was 23 years old and had been out of Harvard for a year. Then he heard about two young Yale graduates who were looking for an aggressive salesman for their new magazine.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 20, 1979

title: A Touch of Byzantium In Greek Church on L.I.
description: Two workmen from Italy are installing a series of colorful mosaics in St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Hempstead, L.I., that are designed to become the most authentic examples of the Byzantine art style in any church in the United States.

title: Israelis on Golan Told It Won't Be Given Up
description: TEL AVIV, April 19  Minister of Agriculture Ariel Sharon told worried Israeli colonists at Golan Heights outposts today that they would soon be reinforced by four new settlements and he assured them that Israel would not give up the heights if there was peace with Syria.

title: The Matre d 'Htel Knows His Bordeaux
description: Le Lavandou 's wine list is better than average for a New York French restaurant, and Luc, the maitre d 'htel, seems to know more about his wines than some of his counterparts. The list is stronger in Bordeaux than Burgundies, which is not difficult to understand, given the current prices of Burgundies. Chteau HautBailly, 1970, on one occasion recently, was flat and uninspired. On another day, a 1973 Chateau Figeac was first rate. At $16, it was a fairly good buy for an East Side restaurant; certainly better than the HautBailly at $18.

title: A Health Emergency Declared in New York In 19Day Tug Strike
description: A citywide health emergency was declared yesterday in New York by the Board of Health as a result of the 19.day. old strike by tugboat operators.

title: The City
description: Eight patrons of a crowded punkrock club on the Lower East Side were burned early yesterday  two of them critically  when a combustible prop used by a performing band exploded prematurely during its act.

title: Film: 'Idlers' of Greece:Dolce Far Niente
description: A SELF-SATISFIED, benignly uninteresting, middle-aged widower and his three grown sons inherit a lovely country house from their brother/uncle and promptly move there from the city. With Sofia, the young housekeeper they've also inherited, the family settles down for what at first seems simply a life of great ease. They enjoy huge, cheerful, wine-filled lunches, after which they nap, take tea in the garden, nap again and dine at nightfall.So begins "Idlers of the Fertile Valley," the Greek film directed by Nikos Panayotopoulos that will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art tonight at 9 and again on Sunday at 6 P.M. in the New Directors/New Films series sponsored by the Museum and the Film Society of Lincoln Center."Idlers of the Fertile Valley" is, I'm afraid, an allegory about the decadence of the bourgeoisie and like many allegories, its charm wears thin once the system of equivalents becomes apparent. Yet Mr. Panayotopoulos is a talented film maker and often a witty one. He is also far more gentle than Marco Ferreri ("La Grande Bouffe") and his portrait of lassitude is not without its attractions.After the move to the country, one brother begins a frantic affair with a girl in the neighborhood. The other brothers take turns making love to the compliant Sofia. The trees are heavy with foliage. Ripeness has weight. The days stretch on. One by one, each member of the family gives himself up to an idleness that precludes even sex. It's as if the beauty that surrounds them were an intoxicant. If you breathe deeply you fall asleep.One morning the father wakes up and decides it would be simpler all around just to stay in bed and let Sofia bring up his meals on a tray. The brother who had wanted to marry abandons the idea, reasoning that a strange woman would spoil their perfect peace. The eldest brother also takes to his bed.Only Saki, the youngest, remembers the world outside. Between naps he suffers fits of sanity. He reads a history of the French Revolution and repairs an ancient alarm clock, which may not only be to awaken him but also a reference to poor old Louis XVI. When Saki decides to move away and get a job, the other members of the family stir themselves for what is probably the last time. "He is mad," wails the father, who wonders what he has done wrong.The beauty of the settings, the sense of well-fed purposeless, even the languor with which the camera pans across the dozing landscapes  all these things evoke a political outrage that is peculiarly soft, as if the director could not bring himself to face matters directly.The performers are attractive, though only Olga Karlatos, the actress who plays Sofia, is identified in the credits prepared by the museum."Idlers of the Fertile Valley" is at its best and funniest when the narrative doesn't seem to mean anything more than what it says, as when the put-upon Sofia is moving about the premises, methodically and quite happily attempting to cope with day-to-day chores in a household where the snore announces the absolute end of all human endeavor.

title: Obituary 8  No Title
description: Deaths

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Rogers C.B. Morton Is Dead at 64; Served in Nixon and Ford Cabinets
description: Rogers C. B. Morton, who held Cabinet posts under two Presidents and served as a Republican member of Congress and as the party's national chairman, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Easton, Md. He was 64 years old.

title: ATEST CONFUSION LAID TO EISENHOWER
description: SALT LAKE CITY,' April 19  President Eisenhower reportedly told the Atomic Energy Commission in 1953 to keep the public confused with its explanations of the kind of explosions that were causing radioactive fallout, according to recently decla,ssified commission records, released today.

title: Ayatollah Taleghani Backs Away From a Showdown With Khomeini
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 19  Ayatollah Mahmoud Taleghani, considered by many to be Iran's most liberal revolutionary leader, backed away tonight from a showdown with the powerful Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Carter Emissary Dissuaded Shah From U.S. Exile
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  A private American citizen was enlisted by the Carter Administration last month to go to Morocco to tell Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi that he was not welcome in the United States at this time because of the delicacy of IranianAmerican relations.

title: Two Railroads Post Net Gains
description: Two of the nation's largest railroads reported yesterday sharply higher profits for the first quarter, despite increased weatherrelated expenses in the period.

title: WASHINGTON Courts and the Press
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  The courts and the press in this country are fussing with one another again about the conflict in the Constitution between the right to a fair trial and the freedom of the press. This will have to be settled in the courts and the Congress, but maybe something should be said for a little more understanding between judges and editors on their different responsibilities and common ournoses.

title: At the Movies
description: HAVING stubbed his toe with two expensive films in a row, At Long Last Love and Nickelodeon. Peter Bogdanovich took a year off and then decided that his next production would be more modest financially. It turned out to be Saint Jack, which opens in New York next Friday.

title: Carbide's Earnings Rise 57.9%
description: The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday a 57.9 percent increase in first quarter earnings to $124.6 million, or $1.91 a share, from $78.9 million, or $1.22 a share, in the comparable 1978 quarter. Sales rose 19 percent to $2.16 billion from $1.82 billion.

title: Astoria Hub to Get $65,000
description: New York City has agreed to provide $65,000 in community development funds to design public improvements for the Astoria commercial hub in Queens, centered at Ditmars Boulevard and 31st Street.

title: Legislator Warns of Shift For Jersey Bus Subsidies
description: TRENTON, April 19  The chairman of the Assembly's Transportation Committee, John F. Cali, said today that it was abundantly clear that major changes must be made in New Jersey's costly bus subsidy program even if the state did not buy and operate the major lines, which are losing more than $50 million a year.

title: Film: 'Dawn of the Dead':Morning After
description: SOME people hate musicals, and some dislike westerns, and I have a pet peeve about flesh-eating zombies who never stop snacking. Accordingly, I was able to sit through only the first 15 minutes of "Dawn of the Dead," George Romero's follow-up to "Night of the Living Dead," which Mr. Romero directed in black and white in 1968. Since then, he has discovered color. Perhaps horror-movie buffs will consider this an improvement.At the beginning of "Dawn of the Dead," it was explained that the living dead were on the rampage, that there were a lot of them and that they were hungry. It was also graphically demonstrated that the only way to kill one of these zombies permanently was to blow his or her head off, preferably in a nice, tight close-up. The few living souls who still remained were obviously fighting a losing battle, since their idea of a safe hiding place was a gas station outside of Harrisburg, Pa.Mr. Romero is an acknowledged dean of this sort of thing, and he has been assisted this time by another red-meat magnate, Dario Argento. Mr. Argento, who most recently directed the less stomach-turning "Suspiria," has provided a lot of thumpity-thump music for the soundtrack, along with his combo, the Goblins. On limited evidence, though, "Dawn of the Dead" didn't seem like anything that would send an audience home humming its theme song.It was explained to me in the lobby, while a preview audience moaned and groaned, that this is the second installment in what Mr. Romero foresees as a trilogy, and that the bulk of "Dawn of the Dead" had been filmed in America's largest shopping mall and is full of satirical points about consuming. Whatever it may be full of, "Dawn of the Dead" opens today at the Gemini, the Rivoli, the U.A. 85th Street East and other theaters."Dawn of the Dead" has no M.P.A.A. rating, but no one under 17 will be admitted

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: About Real Estate Joint Venture for Speedup Of Housing in Westchester
description: ELMSFORD, N.Y.  It now takes three times longer, on the average, to get governmental approval of proposals for new housing than it takes to build the housing itself, says Robert F. Weinberg, chairman of the Robert Martin Company. And for every three projects proposed, two ultimately fail to win approval at all.

title: Issue and Debate Cities Ask: To Grow or Not to Grow?; The Background
description: From the nation's early days until quite recently, home, mother, apple pie and the flag ranked little higher in the American credo than the community shibboleth of BiggerBetterBusier. If Elmville could just get more people, more homes and shops, more industry, the conviction was, everyone would be that much happier.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Deaths

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Investment bankers tested the market yesterday to see whether they could sell mediumgrade utility bonds at slightly lower yields than were offered earlier this week, and they found little acceptance of the idea.

title: 32 Food Establishments Listed as Code Violators
description: The New York City Department of Health yesterday released the names of 32 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: CLARISSE M. BATES

title: Palmer Stays Calm, Orioles Beat Yanks
description: Jim Palmer is one of baseball 's best pitchers. He also is one of the most volatile pitchers, a sort of articulate, version of Mount Vesuvius. Defensive lapses especially trigger his temper.

title: Topics Rules and Regulations
description: Two weeks of the 1979 major league baseball season have passed but the umpires, seeking pay raises, are still on the sidelines. Minor league and amateur umpires have been making the close calls instead, and now fans and players are voicing concern about the longterm effects of bad ones. Still, the two leagues and the club owners remain unwilling even to talk.

title: Safety Board Tentatively Blames Jetliner,Crew for Midair Disaster
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  The National Transportation Safety Board tentatively decided today that the main cause of the midair collision in San Diego last fall was the failure of the airliner crew to keep the small plane in view and to inform controllers when they had lost visual contact.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Sonata for Violin and Guitar in A, Paganini; Cello Sonata in B flat, Vivaldi; Johnny Appleseed, song, Siegmeister.

title: Events Leading Up to Libel Suit Began a Decade Ago in Vietnam
description: The central event behind the controversy that has been swirling around Anthony B. Herbert for most of the last decade occurred on Feb. 14,1969.

title: Safety Officials Move to Ground 1,000 Sikorskys
description: NEWARK, April 19  Citing evidence that yesterday's fatal crash of a New York Airways helicopter occurred after a section of a rotor blade with a hidden defect snapped off in midnight, Federal safety officials moved tonight to ground more than 1.000 of the big Sikorsky S61's in operation here and abroad.

title: Four Months Added to Sentence Of William Harris in Hearst Case
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., April 19 (UPI)  The Community Release Board has set William Harris's prison term for kidnapping Patricia Hearst and other crimes at 10 years and eight months, four months more than had previously been set.

title: Music: Smith Singers
description: GREGG SMITH, a seemingly tireless choral conductor who has been especially attentive to American music through 20 years of concertizing and recording with his Gregg Smith Singers, organized a small twoevening festival of American choral works at St. Peter's Church in the Citicorp complex, which began Tuesday night.

title: jazz Concert: Mangione
description: WHERE'S HERE'S the melody? At some point during Chuck Mangione's career as a moreorless conventional jazz musician, somebody must have asked him that question. To a considerable extent, his commercial success in recent years  Grammy Awards, Platinum Albums, soldout concerts like the series of four successive evenings at Avery Fisher Hall that beganon Wednesday  has been a rebegan of playing the melody, and playing it, and playing it.

title: Rift Over Rates: Miller vs. Blumenthal
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  A sharp rift seems to have developed between G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and the senior economic policy makers of the Carter Administration over the conduct of economic policy.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar declined on currency mar kets in Japan and Europe yesterday but then started moving generally higher as news of a slowing of the United States economy buoyed traders hones.

title: 35 Are Injured in Dormitory Blaze At George Washington University
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) Thirtyfive students were injured, two critically, today when a predawn fire routed hundreds of residents from a highrise dormitory at George Washington University.

title: Califano Seeks Faster Approval Of Major Breakthrough Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)  The Carter Administration asked today for legislation to allow promising breakthrough drugs to move onto the market more quickly.

title: Hope Spurs 13 Entries For Wood
description: Grimy yellow and white plastic flowers still lined the walking ring at Aqueduct yesterday, but the real flowers of spring finally began budding in the Man o'War Room when a voice called out. No. 3 is Czaravich.

title: Bridge:
description: A tiny percentage of those who have heard of Dumas's Three Musketeers have actually read his novels and know that there were really Four Musketeers, a fact that provided a starting point for a delightful book. it is Bridge with the Three Musketeers, by Aksel Nielsen, available for $11.95 postpaid from Barclay Bridge Supplies, 8 Bush Avenue, Port Chester, N.Y. 10573.

title: Deaths of Three Security Guards Mourned at Funerals
description: HARTFORD, April 19  At separate funerals today, hundreds of friends, family members and colleagues gathered around flagdraped coffins to mourn three Purolator Security guards shot to death in a $1.8 million robbery before dawn last Monday In Waterbury.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Growth in the American economy fell off abruptly in the first quarter, the Commerce Department reported. It said the gross national product grew at an annual rate of only seventenths of 1 percent after adjusting for inflation, compared with the more robust rate of 6.9 percent recorded in the fourth quarter of 1978. G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the central bank would consider a more restrictive credit policy only if the rise in the G.N.P. in this quarter rebounded to above 2.5 percent. [Page A1.]

title: Guardsmen Begin Moving Into Prisons
description: Dozens of vehicles were damaged but no injuries were reported when violence erupted on picket lines at three New York State prisons last night as the first of 5,500 National Guardsmen mobilized by Governor Carey moved in to replace striking prison guards.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Copper futures led other metals lower yesterday after the Government reported an unexpectedly slow economic growth rate for the first quarter of the year.

title: Ballet Theater: Debuts In Some Major Roles
description: THERE were major cast changes in all three works offered by the American Ballet Theater on Wednesday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Murdered ShoppingBag Lady Cremated, a Mystery to the End
description: Irmgard Meyer, a shoppingbag lady who wandered the streets of midtown Manhattan homeless and alone, remained a mystery in death as in life.

title: Lou Rossini Is Dismissed By St. Francis
description: Lou Rossini was dismissed as head basketball coach at St. Francis College yesterday after four years at the Brooklyn school. No successor has been named, but the school is accepting applications.

title: TV Weekend Pair Ask How G. I. Son Died
description: THE weekend's drama schedule is dominated by Friendly Fire, a threehour television movie that will be presented on ABC this Sunday, starting at 8 P.M. Based on a true story. Fay Kanin's script has been adapted from a book by C.D.B. Bryan. Mr. Bryan became closely involved with Peg and Gene Mullen, an Iowa farm couple, and their search for the truth behind the death of their eldest son, Michael, in Vietnam.

title: Jack W. Ferguson, 48
description: Jack W. Ferguson, a senior vice president of the Chemical Bank. died Tuesday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 48 years old.

title: Business and the Law
description: HOW independent are boards of directors? Not very, concludes Lewis D. Solomon, a professor at the National Law Center of George Washington University. In sum, he says, corporate boards form a closed club of elites sharing similar experiences and views. These directors are disinclined to criticize and lack the. resources to do so. Board meetings are predictable  directors are expected to ratify management's decisions with a minimum of delay and unpleasantness.

title: Faulty Copter Blade to Be Tested
description: An aluminum tailrotor blade  identified as the faulty element in the New York Airways helicopter that crashed, killing three people, at Newark International Airport on Wednesday night  was sent to Washington yesterday for metallurgical analysis as experts sought to understand the cause of the accident.

title: C.I.A. Loses Attempt To Censor a Magazine
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 19 (UPI) Oregon Magazine went on sale today with the first half of a disputed article by a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency. Sixteen words that the C.I.A. wanted removed were still in it.

title: Lakers to Pick First in Draft
description: The Los Angeles Lakers won coin flip yesterday and will select first on June 25 in the National Basketball Association's 1979 college draft.

title: Milk Shipments Called Obstacle To Ending Strike
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 19  The eightweek strike by dairy workers has been prolonged, in part, because outofstate milk deliveries keep dairy counters filled, a State Senate committee was told yesterday. As a result, one dairy industry official said, public pressure for a settle. ment is at a minimum.

title: Restaurants
description: ONE of the more interesting and ambitious French restaurants in the city is Le Lavandou on 61st Street, just west of Lexington Avenue. Under the guidance of Jean Jacques Rachou, the chef and proprietor, this fouryearold restaurant has developed a following so large and loyal it is often necessary to call three or four days ahead for a luncheon or dinner reservation.

title: The Region
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  The latest survey of the cost of gasoline in Nassau County reveals incredible increases in the last seven weeks  one as high as 19 percent, Consumer Affairs Commissioner James E. Picken said yesterday. Price increases range from 8 percent to 19 percent since the week ending March 2, when the Iast survey was taken, with most jumps clustering at 12 or 13 percent, said Mr. Picken.

title: Old King Arthur Sings
description: Henry Purcell, the English. 17thcentury composer whose music is lavishly admired in print but for one reason or another not very frequently performed, wrote several operas toward the end of his 30year life. The bestknown of these, and the only one in which the music is uninterrupted by spoken dialogue, is Dido and Aeneas, recently given a new production by the New York City Opera. Another major example is the 1691 King Arthur, for which Purcell wrote the music four years before his death to alternate with a text by John Dryden. It is to be given a concert performance in the 92d Street Y. M. Y. W. H. A. 's Buttenwelser Hall on Sunday evening at 8. Presented by the 92d Street Y Chorale, King Arthur will enlist the services of a chamber chorus of 25 singers, a chamber orchestra of 15, 10 solo singers and two narrators, all under the direction of Amy Kaiser, a young conductor who began her association with the Y less than a year ago.

title: Columbia Strings to Play A Rare Belgian Work
description: In 1929, Eugene Ysaye, the distinguished Belgian violinistcomposer, wrote a piece for solo string quartet and string orchestra called Harmonies du Soir. The quartet that he headed and that bore his name took part in a private performance the following year for the King and Queen of the Belgians. Since that time it has not been played. Tonight, however, it will be heard in public in what is a world premiere, as part of a concert by Columbia University's String Revival. This ensemble, with Howard Shanet, its founder as director, will appear at McMillin Theater, Broadway and 116th Street, at 8. The event is free.

title: Carter Plans to Visit South Korea in June After Tokyo Meeting
description: JEKYLL ISLAND, Ga., April 19 President Carter intends to visit South Korea immediately after the economic summit meeting in Tokyo in June, the White House Press Office announced today.

title: A Bank Bridge Over State Lines
description: Several major bank holding companies have found a way to move into national consumer banking markets, despite the prohibition on interstate banking. They are doing so by acquiring socalled industrial banks.

title: Movie: Hungarian 'Just Like at Home':National Black Theater Plans Anniversary Benefit
description: MARTA MESZAROS'S "Just Like at Home," a Hungarian film that opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse, is handsome and evocative, even when it's a little more mystifying than American audiences may find useful. Like Miss Meszaros's "Women," which opened here last year, "Just Like at Home" is firmly rooted in the particulars of Hungarian life today, and some of it gets lost in translation. But Miss Meszaros's latest effort is filmed with a lovely precision and filled with radiant scenery and appealing actors. Even its elusive moments command attention.An unhappy, temperamental man, played by Jan Nowicki, returns to Hungary after a stay in the United States, and has trouble resuming his former life. His former lover in Budapest, played by the always stunning Anna Karina, has moved on to other things, and he's not altogether comfortable in the rural village where his parents are. Having lived, as he likes to boast, in an American apartment on the 44th floor, he has literally and figurally forgotten how to keep his feet on the ground.Then he meets a sad-faced little girl, a kind of Hungarian Tatum O'Neal (Zsuzsa Czinkoczy), and her wonderful shaggy sheepdog, a Hungarian puli. He demands the dog, but the little girl understandably clings to her pet. He visits the girl's mother, who has six other children and agrees to sell the animal for a high price. He goes back to Budapest, accompanied by the dog and trailed by the child, who clearly comes from the sort of family that will barely miss her. From then on, the movie becomes a gentle, bucolic love story between an adoptive father and daughter.It also follows the antagonism between Miss Karina, who changes her mind and resumes things with her old lover, and the child. Miss Meszaros devotes keen attention to the rivalry between the woman and the girl, even allowing them parallel romp-in-the-country sequences with Mr. Nowicki. The contrast is keen, and edifiying. Miss Karina's scene is funny, tender, tinged with softer feelings. The little girl's scene overflows with pure, uncomplicated love.All of the film concerns itself with varying notions of what a family can be, from the simple life of grape-stomping and harvesting that the hero's parents enjoy to the less traditional arrangement he invents with the child. At one memorable point, the man receives a depressingly sensible proposition from a pretty young woman from his parents' village. She's worried about being an old maid, she says, and since he's available, why not give it a go? He looks uncomfortable, even vaguely appalled and extricates himself as politely as he can. She's sorry, but not surprised. She just shrugs, straps on her crash helmet and bikes off into the night.

title: Nippon to Assist Wheeling on Plant
description: TOKYO, April 19 (AP)  The Nippon Steel Corporation, Japan's largest steelmaker, said today it had agreed to extend technological cooperation to the Wheeling Pittsburgh Steel Corporation in constructing and operating a rail production plant.

title: Marching Indian File Under Spring's Snowy Blossoms
description: Steady rain, followed by two days of clear skies and warming sunshine, have decked apple and cherry trees in Central Park in their springtime finery. It is baseball weather, as these youngsters on their way to play in baseball caps and Tshirts can tell anyone who asks. Today is expected to be clear, with temeratures in the middle 60's, a perfect day to indulge that new case of spring fever, or to dust off the old baseball glove and to head for the nearest diamond.

title: Union Says Uniroyal Reneged on a Tentative Accord
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 19  The president of the United Rubber Workers charged today that Uniroyal Inc. had reneged on a tentative contract agreement reached yesterday.

title: Egypt Votes on Treaty
description: CAIRO. April 19  Egyptians voted on the peace treaty with Israel today in a referendum called by President Anwar elSadat to demonstrate to Arab critics that the treaty has solid support in his country.

title: Notes on People
description: Albert Walter Lyle was running true to form. Most people probably know him better as Sparky, and he earns his living with his left arm, a marvelous instrument that enables him to come into baseball games late to save the day for failed starting pitchers. Yesterday, Mr. Lyle came in very late at the 21 Club, where a small, but noisy crowd waited to ask him one question after another about a new book, The Bronx Zoo, which he has written with Peter Golenbeck.

title: Rhodesian Blacks Vote in Hope of End to the War
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 19  I am casting the vote because I am hoping it will iust stop the war.

title: In the Ring With Joe and Marvis
description: Marvis Frazier, Eddie Harrell and another friend were watching The Brady Bunch on television in the sitting room of the hotel suite. At 6 feet 1 or better, Marvis is more than two inches taller than Ms thickset father, with a chassis that could carry substantially more than his 192 pounds. He wore a threepiece suit and a onepiece mustache, and from time to time he put on eyeglasses that gave him a gravely studious look. Meeting him for the first time, one is likely be struck immediately by his politeness, a quality that fits him as naturally and comfortably as his skin. In a moment Joe Frazier came out of a bedroom, his smile of welcome framed by a Silas Manner fringe of whiskers. The shrubbery did not disguise the strong facial resemblance of father and son, a resem blance that probably is emphasized by their physical dissimiliarities.

title: Experiment to Curb Blight: Let Tenants Run Buildings
description: On 126th Street, across from the Pentecostal House of Prayer and a partly abandoned building with a storefront proclaiming itself The House of Dreams, there is a modest, sixstory apartment house built of dark brown brick that looks just like scores of buildings put up in Jackson Heights in the 1930's. It stands by a narrow and worn portion of Fifth Avenue, just two blocks north of the fabled street's interruption by Marcus Garvey Park.

title: Bernard Meyer, Nassau Democrat, Named by Carey to Appeals Court
description: Bernard S. Meyer, a liberal Democrat from Nassau County described by his friends as a legal workaholic, was nominated for a seat on the Court of Appeals yesterday by Governor Carey.

title: A Murder in Brooklyn Of a DayCare Leader Held Execution Type
description: Horace E. Greene, a 54yearold community leader in Brooklyn's Bushwick section and a onetime candidate for the State Assembly, was shot to death yesterday in what a police source said appeared to be an executiontype killing.

title: Cynthia Gregory and Partners
description: WHO needs partners? Those who have seen Cynthia Gregory sail through the razzledazzle of the third act of Swan Lake, balance without a tremor in the Rose Adagio in Sleeping Beauty or flutter across the window sill from another world in La Sulphide might be pardoned for supposing that she could certainly just go it alone. But ballerinas, even one who is considered by many balletomanes to be the foremost American ballerina of her day, do need partners, and American Ballet Theater will be serving Miss Gregory up with quite a collection during its spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House. This weekend, in fact, will see the New York debut of Charles Jude, a principal dancer with the Paris Opera Ballet, who will dance Albrecht to Miss Gregory's Gisel le tomorrow afternoon.

title: Business Lending Grows; Money Supply Expands
description: Credit demand continued to show considerable strength in the week ended April 18, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Soviet Six Takes Lead in Tourney
description: MOSCOW, April 19  The Soviet Union moved into the lead of the world hockey championship tonight by defeating Canada, 52, after Czechoslovakia struggled to a 33 tie with Sweden.

title: Another Pullback For Market
description: Selected energy issues moved ahead yesterday, but the general market registered its fifth loss in six sessions. Several glamour stocks posted declines of more than 3 points.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: Rikers Prisoner Hangs Himself
description: A 21yearold prisoner on Rikers Island awaiting trial next week on robbery. weaponspossession and paroleviolation charges hanged himself in his cell shortly after midnight Wednesday. The prisoner, Alasheen Walker, who lived at 936 St. Nicholas Avenue in Manhattan. was the fourth at the Rikers Island prison to kill himselft this year.

title: 3 Gunmen Steal Furs Worth up to a Million
description: Three masked gunmen broke into a Manhattan fur processing company early yesterday morning, handcuffed four employees and for the next four hours systematically carted up to $1 million in unfinished furs on an elevator from the 11th floor to a waiting truck at the loading bay.

title: Andreotti Move Staves Off Bank of Italy Showdown
description: ROME, April 20  The lameduck Government of Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti approved today the reinstatement of a deputy director of the Bank of Italy whom an investigating judge earlier this week had suspended in an inquiry into alleged dereliction of duty by top officials of the institution.

title: Newspaper Guild Unit at Times Votes to Take Steps on Contract
description: Members of the Newspaper Guild unit at The New York Times voted overwhelmingly yesterday to begin a series of actions on May 3 to achieve a contract, such action to culminate, if necessary, in a strike. The resolution was approved by a vote of 530 to 90.

title: What to Do In a Strike
description: If buildingservice employees strike, about 3,000 apartment houses, including some of the city's most luxurious, would be affected:

title: Governor Byrne Seeks to Sell German Investors on New Jersey
description: Governor Byrne talking with Walter Seipp, left, chairman of the board of Westdeutsche Landesbank, in Dsseldorf yesterday as George W. Ball, former Under Secretary of State, listened. Mr. Byrne, who left the United States Sunday on a twoweek trip with a group of New Jersey businessmen to Britain, West Germany. and Switzerland, hopes to convince foreign investors that New Jersey is a very attractive place for new industry.

title: Films: 2 by Avant-Garde Director
description: "A Walk Through H" and "Vertical Features Remake," two 40-minute films by Peter Greenaway in the Museum of Modern Art's New Directors/ New Films series, are peculiarly counterproductive. Each features faintly satirical voice-over narration, supposedly by a pedantic disciple of an obscure  and fictitious  avant-garde artist and film maker named Tulse Luper. The work of Luper is discussed in exhaustive detail, particularly in "Vertical Features Remake," which focuses on Luper's fixation on the number 11.However, Mr. Greenaway, a British director, turns out to be pretty serious about the number 11 himself. And so a lot of "Vertical Features Remake" is given over to rhythmic counting  11 trees, 11 telephone poles, 11 what-have-you's. This is not altogether uninteresting, and the hypnotic effect it aims for is by no means out of reach. But Mr. Greenaway has already sabotaged himself with a would-be comic introduction, which isn't funny, but does make the more taxing parts of the film appear ridiculous."A Walk Through H" introduces Tulse Luper again, even though he has by now become more than tiresome. This time, the connection between 192 Luper drawings and a Luper volume on bird migration is explored. The same difficulties apply.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Automatic fund transfers between savings and checking accounts were ruled illegal by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. The ruling could limit current banking services and mean lost interest payments for consumers. But the court did not immediately suspend the transfers in order to give Congress time to consider changing the banking law. [Page 1.]

title: Farmer Mississippi Aide Is Killed in Plane Crash
description: CLARKSDALE, Miss., April 20 (AP) Former Lieut. Gov. Charles Sullivan was found dead yesterday in the wreckage of his twinengine plane. He was 54 years old.

title: Goodyear Reaffirms Position
description: CINCINNATI, April 20  At a negotiating session here tonight, representatives of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest, reaffirmed theft position that they would not agree to a wage package that exceeded the 7 per. cent guidelines called for by the President.

title: Resch Records 40 Shutout
description: CHICAGO, April 20 The New York Islanders continued their mastery over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight with an easy 40 victory in their Stanley Cup quarterfinal playoff series. But the victors, who have won the first three games of the fourofsevengame series, played the final period without their star center, Bryan Trottier.

title: Entertainment Events
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA. New York State Theater, Purcell's Dido and Aeneas and Strauss's Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme, 2, and Verdi's La Traviata, 8.

title: Yastrzemski Slugs Boston Past Royals
description: BOSTON, April 20 (AP)  Carl Yastrzemski drove in three runs with his 386th career homer, a single and a double to power the Boston Red Sox to a 92 victory today over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Pilots Group Attacks Safety Board For Citing Crew in San Diego Crash
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, by a 3to1 vote yesterday, formally affirmed its finding that primary blame for the fatal midair collision in San Diego last September must be borne by the crew of the Pacific Southwest Airlines jet

title: The Region
description: WATERBURY. Conn.  Jewelry worth $66,000 that the police originally said was missing from the loot recovered after Monday's robbery of an armored van belonging to Purolator Security Inc., is not missing after all, a spokesman said today.

title: Inventor Planning HydrogenPowered Car
description: LOS ANGELES, April 20  Sam Leslie Leach, the inventor of a controversial process that he contends can economically separate the hydrogen and oxygen in water. says he has refined his defagn and begun building a system that will be capable of running an automobile on hydrogen derived from water.

title: Gasoline a Crucial If for Amusement Parks
description: Easter weekend attendance at the nation's major amusement parks, usually a harbinger of the spring and summer tourist season, was generally strong, a spot check by The New York Times has shown.

title: Thai Election Tomorrow Stirring Both Violence and Voter Apathy
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 20  Two candidates and 13 political workers have been murdered so far in the campaigning for the election Sunday for the House of Representatives, and more violence is expected before the polls close.

title: Man Held on Carter Threat
description: CONCORD, N.H., April 20 (AP)  A Manchester man was being held today on $25,000 bond on a charge of threatening to kill President Carter and Senator John A. Durkin, Democrat of New Hampshire. Assistant United States Attorney Robert Lynn said. The man was identified as Charles Joseph Breton. Mr. Breton was accused of sending a letter to President Carter on April 6 and a letter to Senator Durkin two days later. threatening to kill them.

title: Gilmour Sentenced On Taxes
description: William (Buddy) Gilmour, a leading harness trainer and driver for more than two decades, was sentenced yesterday to three months in jail and fined $5,000 for evasion of Federal income taxes.

title: United Will Resume Talks
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) United Airlines and striking mechanics will resume contract talks Monday in Denver in an attempt to end a threeweek strike that has grounded the nation's largest air carrier, officials said today.

title: Dominicans Seize 5 on Launch
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 20 (AP)  Authorities rescued a disabled fishing launch off the south coast near the Haitian border this week, found two pistols, three rifles and 600 rounds of ammunition, and arrested the five men aboard, the military said.

title: Iran Protesters Condemn Khomeini's Committees
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 20 (AP)  Leftists shouting Purge! Purge! demonstrated today against Iran's Islamic revolutionary committees despite pleas by two Moslem leaders for a unified front.

title: Dow Sued for $12 Million
description: The Dow Chemical Company was charged in a $12 million civil antitrust suit yesterday with monopolizing the market for polyethylene foam plank and using predatory pricingcutting and other tactics to squelch competition.

title: Stores and Policemen Assaulted By Frustrated Boston Rock Fans
description: BOSTON, April 20 (AP)  Several hundred frustrated gate crashers broke store windOws and assaulted policemen on horseback last night after they were denied admittance to a rock concert at a downtown theater, the police said.

title: U.N. POST IN LEBANON IS STILL UNDER SIEGE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 20  Lebanese Christian militia forces today continued their siege of the United Nations peacekeeping force's headquarters in southern Lebanon for the sixth day, but they did not fire on United Nations soldiers.

title: New York Blocks Bid for Woolworth
description: Robert Abrams, the New York State Attorney General, issued a stop order yesterday prohibiting the takeover of the F.W. Woolworth Company by a subsidiary of Brascan Ltd., the Canadian holding company, until a full investigation is completed. Mr. Abrams also scheduled a public hearing May 10 on the Brascan offer.

title: The City
description: Justice Irving Kirschenbaum of State Supreme Court announced a conditional agreement to submit outstanding issues in the eightweekold milk strike to binding arbitration.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

description: THE easy credit that has become prevalent in affluent America is getting even easier with the spread of a new banking service known as loanbyphone.

title: Vice President Lands in Helsinki For Talks With Finland's Leader
description: HELSINKI, Finland, April 20 (Reuters)  Vice President Mondale arrived in Finland today for a oneday visit scheduled to include talks with President Urho Kekkonen.

title: First Chicago's Profits Rise
description: CHICAGO, April 20 (Reuters)  The First Chicago Corporation, parent company of the First National Bank of Chicago, today reported a modest increase in its firstquarter operating profit over the comparable yearearlier period.

title: Carter, Tanned and Rested, Leaves Secluded Island
description: PLAINS, Ga., April 20  President Carter came home today after eight days of seclusion on Sapelo Island, looking tanned, rested and somewhat thinner than when he left. PLAINS, Ga., April 20 (Reuters) President Carter will hold a news conference in Des Moines, Iowa, on May 4 on a twoday trip to Iowa and California, the White House announced today.

title: Peru's Time Of Transition
description: LIMA, Peru  The military regime that has governed this ancient, brooding land for nearly a dozen years has demonstrated at one time or another virtually all the faults of military regimes everywhere: government by decree, authoritarian political and economic controls, infringement of human rights, extravagance in arms purchases and parsimony in social services, hyperactive nationalism and soupedup quarrels with the neighbors.

title: Making the Scene At the Mudd Club
description: It's not a place that one simply happens upon. At 77 White Street, two blocks south of Dave's Luncheonette at the corner of Canal and Broadway, the Mudd Club is practically invisible on the ground floor of an anonymous loft building. But it has emerged as the latest watering hole for some of the city's night people.

title: StrategicArms Talks Continue
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The United States and the Soviet Union held highlevel talks again today on completing a strategic armslimitation treaty and scheduled one more round. Administration officials indicated that an announcement of a summit meeting for the second halt of May could come next week.

title: Comsat Lifts Net, Dividend
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation reported yesterday that firstquarter earnings jumped 53.5 percent and that its dividend would be raised by 15 percent.

title: Davis Knocks Out Usai in Third
description: Their paths had crossed at dinners and award presentations, but last night was the first time since that golden evening in Montreal in the summer of 1976 that both Howard Davis and Leo Randolph fought in the same ring.

title: Screen: Old Brazilian Release in New-Film Series
description: "Limite" doesn't exactly belong in the Museum of Modern Art's New Directors/New Films series, because it was first released almost 50 years ago and was directed by a Brazilian, Mario Peixoto, who is now almost 70 years old. However, its inclusion in the series can be explained by its relative obscurity, the praise it received from Sergei Eisenstein and its extraordinarily youthful energies. "Limite" is feverishly beautiful and desperately ambitious, even when it isn't clear.Mr. Peixoto, who is reportedly at work on something new, anticipated in "Limite" a great many camera movements that have since become commonplace, and the air of discovery is one of the things that keeps "Limite" exciting. His camera zooms in on a subject even if that means zooming out of focus, or executes a dizzyingly precarious 360-degree whirl. He shoots up at his actors from such a low angle that a telephone pole appears to hover over them, or devotes long sections of the film exclusively to the players' feet. His choices are flashy, impetuous and never less than interesting.However, "Limite" is of more technical than dramatic importance. Beginning with two women and a man adrift in an open boat, and following each of them through more-or-less imaginary adventures on land, the narrative is elusive at best. Despair is evidently meant to be the overriding sentiment, but despair is easily upstaged by the glorious Brazilian scenery. It's hard to share the misery of a woman contemplating suicide when the bay into which she may jump shimmers exquisitely and is bounded by a spectacular mountainside.Mr. Peixoto appears briefly near the end of the film, sitting mysteriously in a graveyard and announcing something  on one of the few title cards  about leprosy. He is gaunt, intense-looking and faintly diabolical, as befits the author of so solemn and furious a first effort.

title: Young Israeli Hero Rewarded
description: TEL AVIV, April 20 (AP)  A 12yearold boy whose alertness saved bus passengers from a terrorist bombing is going to ride buses free and all his school expenses will be paid. The B'nai B'rith organization announced it would pay the educational expenses of Shalom Mellul, who spotted a bomb under the seat of a Jerusalem bus on Tuesday and warned the other passengers to flee.

title: Watson, on 67135, Is Golf Leader by 3
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 20  The bigname champions dominated he second round of the Tournament of Champions today, while the lesser known of golf 's elite blipped a bit off the pace. Tom Watson, the firstround leader by one stroke over Ron Streck, shot a sixunderpar 66 today for a 36hole total of nineunder 135.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday said incorrectly that Governor Carey had appointed Judge Herbert B. Evans as statewide court administrator. Judge Evans was appointed by Lawrence H. Cooke, Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals.

title: Families Ousted By Fumes Face The Same Again
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., April 20 Three months ago, noxious gasoline fumes leaking from an Exxon service station drove John and Ann Cates and their four children out of their home here and into a motel. Cramped, living out of suitcases, the refugees have long since become fed up with motel life, but luckily they have not lost their sense of humor.

title: SlowMotion Conquest in Uganda
description: KINONI, Uganda, April 20  A Tanzanian soldier sat in the sun sewing buttons on a uniform. Another danced to rock music broadcast from Kenya over a Panasonic radio he said he had brought all the way from Dar es Salaam. Others chewed sugar cane, drank tea and posed for photographs in front of rifles and machine guns in a shaded camp that looked more like a picnic ground than a frontline.

title: Rubber Union Postpones Strike, Pending Further Talks
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The rubber workers union agreed late this afternoon to postpone a strike threatened for 12:01 A.M. tomorrow and to extend its contract with the Big Four rubber companies on daytoday basis pending further negotiations.

title: Nigerians Hail Rise in Oil Price
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  The oil business is booming here once again, so much so that the Government's decision to add surcharges of nearly $4 over the OPEC cartel price has met with widespread approval from Nigerians here. Better late than never, wrote Dr. Olu Akinmoladun, chief energy correspondent for the respected Business Times newspaper here.

title: Industrials Up 1.73
description: Selected glamour and specialty issues scored gains yesterday as the popular stock averages displayed a mixed pattern. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 1.73 points to 856.98, while the transportation and utility averages moved down slightly.

title: Letter: On Welfare Payments
description: To the Editor:

title: Reactor Fluid No Longer Boiling
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 20 (AP) Temperatures in the Three Mile Island reactor dropped below the boiling point for the first time since the nation's worst nuclear accident occurred on March 28, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.

description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered yesterday that stringent visual and ultrasonic inspections be made of the tail rotors on American commercial helicopters of the type involved in the New York Airways craft that crashed here Wednesday evening.

title: Errors, Wildness Prove Costly
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 20.  With the Mets liberally helping their rival's cause with poor control pitching and errant fielding, the Phillies coasted to an 80 victory tonight in the opener of a threegame series. It was the Mets fifth straight loss. HOUSTON. April 20 (AP)  Craig Reynolds reached third base on a throwing error by Pittsburgh's third baseman, Phil Garner, and scored on a sacrifice fly by Jeff Leonard in the 10th inning tonight to give the Houston Astros a 54 victory over the Pirates.

title: NBC Is Planning to Hold Carson To Contract as Host of Tonight
description: LOS ANGELES, April 20  The National Broadcasting Company said today that its contract with Johnny Carson, host of The Tonight Show, runs until 1981 and we expect him to honor it.

title: Gossage Hurt in OffField Scuffle
description: The Yankee turmoil that had been missing for the first two weeks of the season erupted on a new front last night with the announcement that Rich Gossage, the team's $2.75 million free agent, suffered a sprained right thumb Thursday in a clubhouse fight with Cliff Johnson. Gossage will be out for at least a week.

title: Japan Hints Phone Bids For U.S.
description: TOKYO, April 20 (AP)  The head of Japan's state run Nippon Telephone and Telegraph Corporation indicated today that he was willing to allow United States businesses to bid on Nippon Telephone's purchase of main components of communications equipment, apparently opening the way for a settlement of one of the knottiest trade issues between the two countries.

description: Morning

title: Execution Is Stayed in Alabama
description: MOBILE, Ala., April 20 (AP)  Federal District Judge W. B. Hand today stayed the scheduled April 27 execution of John Louis Evans III on the condition that the convicted killer continue his challenge of Alabama's death penalty law. The judge also reprimanded the Southern Poverty Law Center, which reoresents Mr. Evans, saying the organization is representing themselves and their consciences and only incidentally Mr. Evans.

title: Sharp Pay Cuts Proposed for City Education Board
description: Compensation and perquisites of the seven members of the New York City Board of Education would be sharply re duced under terms of legislation intro. duced yesterday in the City Council.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY APRIL 21, 1979

title: Seven South Koreans Are Seized On Suspicion of Spying for North
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 20 (AP) The national police say they have arrested seven South Koreans suspected of spying for North Korea and trying to reactivate an underground Communist Party.

title: Thais Seen Expelling Cambodians
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 20  Refugee officials and diplomats here say they fear that about 1,800 Cambodian refugees may have been forcibly returned to Cambodia by Thai authorities. The officials believe that refugees who are returned face almost certain execution.

title: EARNINGS Polaroid Net Up 18% And Tenneco's 14%
description: The Polaroid Corporation yesterday reported firstquarter earnings of $17.1 million, or 52 cents a share, an increase of 18 percent above the earnings of $14.5 million , or 44 cents a share, in the corresponding period of last year.

title: Rome Astir Over Sexual Blackmail Charge
description: ROME, April 20  Amid political unrest, strikes, inflation and the relentless onslaught of terrorism, Italians these days have found a welcome diversion in the predicament of a Government member whom a former woman aide is publicly accusing of sexual blackmail..

title: New Bond Issues
description: FRIDAY. APRIL 20. 1979

title: KOCH'S 1980 BUDGET AVOIDS CUT OF 6,000 IN CITY WORK FORCE
description: The Koch administration said yesterday that it would propose a $13 billiorr budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1. The budget, reflecting an expectation that revenues will exceed earlier estimates, would allow the city to retain 9,000 workers now paid for by Washington, hire about 2,000 others and still show a small surplus at the end of the year.

title: Morocco, Caught in Sahara Strife, Is Feeling Impact of War at Home
description: A??N. Western Sahara April 15 Three and a half years after King Hassan's spectacular unarmed march forced colonial Spain out of the Western Sahara, a steadily growing Moroccan expeditionary force finds itself begged dowr. in a costly and seemingly unwinnable war against guerrillas who have struck even into southern Morocco.

title: U.S. Chided On Altering Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The European Common Market has warned the United States that a new international trade agreement may be jeopardized by Congressional interpretation of a key concession made by American trade negotiators in Geneva.

title: Film: 'The Whole Shootin' Match' Shown in Series
description: Lloyd (Lou Perry), who looks like a younger Slim Pickens, and Frank (Sonny Davis), whose hair is receding with increasing speed as he approaches his mid-30's, are not losers in any tragic sense. They simply dream beyond their means. Though they live in rural Texas, they (like the rest of us) are subjected to a constant barrage of hype designed to make them dissatisfied with their lives. By the time that Eagle Pennell's "The Whole Shootin' Match" opens, they've already failed as farmers of frogs, of chinchillas and of flying squirrels, and they're ready to chance their fortunes once again, this time in the polyurethane business. As Lloyd points out, "there's money to be made from rich hippies who like to spread (polyurethane) all over their houses.""The Whole Shootin' Match," the first feature to be directed by the 25-year-old Mr. Pennell, is a loving, indulgent, funny, very casual movie about the ups and downs of a couple of innocent, self-defeating American clowns. It's almost the perfect movie for the New Directors/New Films series, which is presenting the film at the Museum of Modern Art today at 8:30 P.M. and Monday at 6 P.M."The Whole Shootin' Match" is often a technical mess, but never for a moment is it out of control. Even the clumsiness of the photography works as a reflection of the sort of lives led by its characters. When someone walks offscreen, it's as if the camera couldn't keep up or had been distracted by something of less importance. The sepia print is faded in the way of jeans that have been left too long in the sun.The outcomes of Lloyd and Frank's various get-rich-quick schemes are predictable enough, but far from predictable are Mr. Pennell's feelings for his characters and the performances he obtains from his actors. These are both surprising and invigorating.It may be that the director has some things to learn about comedy timing, but even when he inexplicably cuts short a very funny sequence, I can't be sure if it's an oversight or a subtle way of focusing our attention. If it's the latter, it works.Mr. Perry and Mr. Davis are fine as the bumbling entrepreneurs and Doris Hargrave is terrifically appealing as Frank's frequently forgotten wife, a former high-school beauty who suspects she married the wrong man, but makes do with a lot of good humor, sex and a newfound faith in Jesus."The Whole Shootin' Match" reportedly cost $30,000. It sometimes looks it, yet the movie has something 9 out of 10 far more expensive features don't have  a way of getting in touch with life.

title: Talks Begin in Strike by Prison Guards
description: ALBANY, April 20  Representatives of the New York State correction officers union continued their talks tonight with state officials and mediators in effort to settle a statewide strike as additional National Guardsmen were moved in to help staff most of the state's prisons.

title: Ruling in Canada
description: TORONTO, April 20  The threeway takeover struggle involving Brascan Ltd., the F.W. Woolworth Company and Edper Equities Ltd. continues despite a a ruling today by the Ontario Securities Commission that appeared at least temporarily to knock Edper out of the struggle.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: NATHAN LEWIS BENGIS

title: Coleman Offers $20 A Share for Stock
description: The Coleman Company announced an offer to purchase one million of its common shares at $20 a share net in cash.

title: TUG UNION ORDERED TO FERRY GARBAGE
description: The striking tugboat operators union was ordered yesterday to resume ferrying the city's garbage to a landfill on Staten Island.

title: Lakers Even Series
description: LOS ANGELES, April 20 (AP)  Kareem AbdulJabbar scored 32 points, including a pair of free throws with four seconds left in overtime, to spark the Los Angeles Lakers to a 118112 victory over Seattle tonight. The victory before 17,505 at the Forum, reduced the SuperSonics lead to 21 in the fourofsevengame N.B.A. playoff series.

title: 4 Injured in BasquePolice Clash
description: PAMPLONA, Spain, April 20 (Reuters)  Four persons were injured, one seriously, in clashes between several hundred leftwing Basquenationalist supporters and riot policemen last night, hospital sources said today. The demonstrators were protestmg the election of a Socialist mayor in Pamplona yesterday, and the loss of the Basque nationalist party's candidate.

title: Auction Records Toppled For American Artists
description: Auction records for American artists  from Winslow Homer to Norman Rockwell  were toppled over and over yesterday at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street. The $4.2 million sale established a new high total for American art at auction, eclipsing the $3.2 million record set at the Edith Halpert sale in 1973.

title: Israel Cool to Beirut Recovery of South
description: JERUSALEM, April 20  Israel is showing little inclination to help United Nations peacekeeping forces reestablish Lebanese Government control over southern Lebanon.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: FREDERICK MILLER

title: West Germany Tops U.S. In World Hockey Tourney
description: MOSCOW. April 20  The United States fell into a tie for last place in the relegation pool of the world hockey championships tonight when it lost to West Germany. 63. The American team has yet to win.

title: Bank Board Backs Rise In Lending
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) Federal financial agencies are taking steps to make it easier for families to borrow money to rehabilitate their homes or to buy cooperative apartments

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON THE Bell companies are beginning to install new telephone equipment designed to meet the special needs of relatively small companies. The Horizon Communications System, which is now available in 41 states, offers each business wide control over from 20 to 80 telephones.

title: Philip Anglim Turns A Freak Into Reality
description: In Bernard Pomerance's The Elephant Man, which opened to rave reviews Thursday night at the Booth Theater after a soldout run Off Broadway, a doctor, played by Kevin Conway, stands before a projection screen in a hospital in 19thcentury London. The doctor is lecturing, with the aid of coldly clinical, photographic slides, on a grossly malformed freak of nature named John Merrick. The slides leave nothing to the imagination; Merrick is a grotesque travesty of a human being.

title: Court Finds OutofWedlock Life No Cause to Bar Virginia Lawyer
description: RICHMOND, April 20  An unmarried woman is not morally unfit to practice law merely because she lives with a man who is not her husband, the Virginia Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.

title: Kennecott to Keep Carborundum
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation said yesterday that its directors had voted unanimously to accept a recommendation of aI committee that Kennecott's rundunq Company subsidiary be retained. The recommendation is understood to have been based on a long study by Lazard Freres, which said Kennecott would lose at least $100 million if it sold Carborundurn.

title: 68 Injured in Metroliner Collision
description: EDISON TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 20 A Washingtonbound Amtrak express train slammed into a Conrail selfpropelled work car on the old Penn Central main line shortly after noon today, throwing the nearly 200 passengers out of their seats and pushing the work car half a mile down the track.

title: Opera: Orff's Die Kluge Sung at the Encompass
description: Except for the ubiquitous Carmina Burana, Carl Orff's works have made little impression in this country, although his system of teaching music to children has exercised a strong influence here, as elsewhere. However, the German composer has a number of other stage works that are frequently presented in Europe, and one of them, Die Kluge (The Wise Woman), is being performed four times a week through May 20 at the Encompass Theater, 168 West 48th Street.

title: South Africa a Burden for Maree
description: PISCATAWAY. N.J., April 20  Normally, he sits in the stands or lingers along the sidelines to watch his Villanova athletes compete. But today, Coach Jumbo Jim Elliott was standing in the middle of the track while Sydney Maree won the 5,000meter run in 13 minutes 34.5 seconds during the Rutgers Relays.

title: Dance: Lar Lubovitch Introduces New Up Jump
description: The audience rose to its feet and cheered when a bespectacled Lar Lubovitch came out for a bow on Thursday at Carnegie Hall, following a performance of the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company. His reception and the fact that the house was so full  and so full of dance notables  on a night when the choreographer had competition from the major companies of Paul Taylor and American Ballet Theater is evidence of Mr. Lubovitch's unusual talents and their quiet hold on the imagination of New York dancegoers.

title: Typhoon Death Toll Rises to 29
description: MANILA, April 20 (Reuters)  The death toll from a typhoon that lashed the central Philippines earlier this week rose to 29 today, and more than 100 people were reported missing, officials said.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday. April 20. 1979

title: Why Carol Burnett Made Friendly Fire War a Waste
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  So what is that ultimate screwball, Carol Burnett, doing playing the television role of an anguished mother, radicalized by her son's senseless death in the Vietnam War?

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York The Sound of Silence on WFAT, Pirate Radio
description: For 16 months, WFAT was lucid and merry on the AM radio dial  Fat is where it's at. This is the nation's most listened to pirate station.

title: Instant Petite Sport Department; Instant Petite Department
description: An established sportswear producer has developed a plan to allow retailers to get into the growing field of petite sportswear by providing an instant department at a price that will probably not affect the bottom line.

title: Charles Shackford, 61
description: Charles Reeves Shackford, professor of music at Connecticut College, died yesterday following injulies suffered in an automobile accident in New London, Conn. He .was 61 years old, and had taught at Connecticut since 1955.

title: Wilderness Preservation
description: The ancient insoluble theological issue of how many angels can dance on the head of a pin has a modern counterpart in the centuryold national question of how much wilderness should be preserved in its pristine state. how much opened up to random public and commercial uses.

title: Israel Lets Pound Slip Downward
description: TEL AVIV, April 20,  In recent weeks the Israeli pound has been experiencing its steepest fall since it was floated in October 1977 to find its own level. This month the barrier of 22 pounds to the dollar was broken, and today it closed at 22.20 to the dollar.

title: Libyan Offensive Deep Into Chad Is Described as Military Disaster
description: PARIS, April 20  Reports reaching here from Chad say that a Libyan offensive deep into the northern region of the Central African country has run into serious trouble.

title: General Dynamics Awarded Contracts
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said it had received a $64.3 million Army contract for purchase of Stinger shoulderfired antiaircraft missiles.

title: The Saudis, on Reading This, Will Tremble
description: BALA CYNWYD, Pa.  My method for solving the oil crisis starts from scratch.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NOW YOU SEE IT It's that time again for magicminded New Yorkers, as the Society of American Magicians presents its annual salute to legerdemain tonight at 8 o'clock at the Hunter College Assembly Hall, 69th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues.

title: Hope of GreekAlbanian Thaw Turns to a Frosty Impasse
description: IOANNINA, Greece, April 19  Every Tuesday Olympic Airways Flight 115 takes off from here for Tirana, the capital of Albania. Of the 64 seats on the plane, fewer than a dozen are usually occupied, invariably by diplomats and some Greek businessmen. Although few people ride on it, the mere existence of this flight is an important link between the insular, hardline Stalinist regime of Enver Mucha and the rest of the world.

title: Billy Turner's Latest Sleeper
description: Billy Turner tapped his forehead with a finger and said, It's the mental seasoning he needs, not the foundation. Sixteen months after having been dismissed as Seattle Slew's trainer, the man who had guided Slew to thoroughbred racing's Triple Crown was talking about another 3yearold colt. An impish smile on the trainer's face suggested that a Turnerism was about to be delivered.

title: Amending a Faulty NoFault Law
description: New York's insured drivers will soon be getting $20 million in premium rebates  a result of the nofault auto insurance reforms adopted two years ago, which limit lawsuits to the most serious accident cases and scale down medical fees. New Jersey legislators now have a chance to apply the lessons of New York's experience.

title: 63,000 Gallons of Styrene Spills Into Mississippi in Barge Mishap
description: COTTONWOOD POINT, Mo., April 20 (AP)  The Environmental Protection Agency said today that an estimated 63,000 gallons of the chemical styrene leaked into the Mississippi River here after several barges hit a bridge.

title: Spurs Defeated By 123115
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 20 Darryl Dawkins, in an awesome display of scoring and rebounding in the final quarter tonight, paved the way for the Philadelphia 76ers 123115 playoff victory over the San Antonio Spurs at the Spectrum.

title: OBSERVER A Romp In The Skull
description: In its continuing struggle to force the press to shape up, the Supreme Court now states that journalists can be required to tell lawyers what opinions they held while preparing material that public men subsequently believe has libeled them.

title: Fed Policy Unit Rejected Tighter Credit in March
description: WASHINGTON. April 20  Deeply divided over whether recession or inflation was the greater danger, the top policymaking body of the Federal Reserve System defeated by a vote of 6 to 4 an attempt at its March meeting to raise interest rates, the Fed reported today.

title: Kings 111, Suns 91
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 20 (AP) Otis Birdsong scored 23 points and Scott Wedman had 22 to power the Kansas City Kings to a 11191 triumph over the Phoenix Suns tonight. The victory tied the playoff series at one victory apiece.

title: In Iran, to Veil or Not to Veil?
description: WASHINGTON  The months of transition between the Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's monarchy and Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic republic have exposed a new trend of thought. To the astonishment of the West, many young Iranian women who were born and reared in Teheran with no personal experience in wearing a veil are adopting the custom of their own volition. Purdah (from the Farsi word Parda meaning curtain), viewed almost unanimously in the West as synonymous with secondclass citizenship, is gaining favor.

title: Citizen Monitors Praise Job Program, but Want More
description: A private group of monitors reported this week that it was favorably impressed with the first 15 months of President Carter's yearround job program for disadvantaged young people in New York City. But it said that the program was far below what was needed and that Federal financing was already being cut to 93 percent of last year's level.

title: It Isn't Drugs That He's Pushing
description: He walks down the street with a swagger that suggests arrogance. The big white hat with a plume gently sways in the breeze; the threepiece white suit fits like a glove; the colorful handkerchief drapes from his jacket pocket; the highheeled shoes that tap out music as they hit the sidewalk are symbols of a dude on the make. To complete the image  one that has been so carefully arranged  there is a car. Not just any car, but a creamcolored Continental that is sleek, fast and an eyecatcher. The man has style; it is the style of the Harlem streets. When you have it, you flaunt it because it gives you instant influence.

title: COMPANY NEWS Kansas Utility Plans Nuclear Plant Stake
description: The Kansas Electric Power Cooperative announced yesterday that it would acquire a 17 percent share, valued at about $187 million, of the Wolf Creek nuclear generating unit, now owned jointly by the Kansas Gas and Electric Company and the Kansas City Power and Light Company.

title: Police Are Sued in Dock Strike
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 20 (AP)  The United Steelworkers of America, accusing the police here of a brutal physical assault on pickets, filed suit in Federal court today asking for damages and a court order restraining police activity. The action stemmed ficim a confrontation Monday between pickets and police officers outside the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, where the union is on strike. The police had no comment.

title: 6 CART Entries for Indy 500 Turned Down
description: INDIANAPOLIS. April 20 (AP)  A weeklong standoff ended today when the United States Auto Club notified six of the rival Championship Auto Racing Teams that their entries for the May 27 Indianapolis 500 had been rejected because they were not in good standing with USAC.

title: Sadat Gets Landslide Treaty Vote
description: CAIRO. April 20  The Government announced today that Egypt's voters had overwhelming approved President Anwar elSadat's peace treaty with Israel.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 21.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Rescuing the Reluctant Landlord
description: The Koch administration has moved swiftly to improve the management of cityowned apartment buildings now that the Department of Housing and Urban Development has approved the use of Federal cornmunity development funds to maintain them. With private landlords defaulting ever more frequently on property taxes, New York City is getting stuck with thousands of dilapidated buildings. The city already owns 5,000 of them, containing 35,000 apartments. By the mid1980's, the figure could exceed 75,000 apartments.

title: Plush New Y Built on Controversy
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The National Capital branch of the Y.M.C.A. is almost a year old now, but it still smells new. And it is remarkably quiet. No raucous cries echo through the building from the gym. The place seems nearly empty much of the time.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WQXR. Part I from Symphony No. 2, Mendelssohn; Violin Concerto in G, Haydn; Overture to The Tsar's Bride, RimskyKorsakov; Symphony Nocturne, Bristow; Suite No. 1 from Cydalise et Le ChevrePied, Pierne.
