title: Smith Hails Pretoria's Plans for a Fortress Southern Africa Alliance
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 20 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith today hailed as manna from heaven a South African proposal for a new grouping of nations in southern Africa that has been interpreted by some officials here as opening the way for much broader South African support of the Salisbury Government.

title: Chase Mortgage Reduces Its Losses
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust said it had pared its losses for the quarter ended Feb. 28 to $1.7 million, from $6.7 million in net losses reported for the similar quarter a year earlier. The trust also reported a net loss of $12.5 million for the nine months ended in February, down slightly from the $13 million ninemonth loss reported a year earlier.

title: Banks Automatic Shift of Savings To Checking Accounts Held Illegal
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The United States Court of Appeals here declared today that the automatic transfer of funds between savings and checking accounts in commercial banks was illegal. However, the court ruled that the practice could continue until Jan. 1 to give Congress time to consider changing the law.

title: Justice Dept. Critical of Aide in Wilmington 10 Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)  The Justice Department today sharply criticized a Federal magistrate who recently recommended against overturning the convictions of the socalled Wilmington 10 in connection with a firebombing incident in 1971 at a time of racial violence in North Carolina.

title: Morales Is Sentenced To 29Year Minimum On Weapons Charges
description: William Guillermo Morales, suspected of being a member of a Puerto Rican terrorist group, was sentenced yesterday to 29 to 89 years in prison on charges grow ing out of an explosion last July in a Queens apartment where he was allegedly making bombs.

title: Notes on People; A Word From Mrs. Halaby on Her Daughter, the Queen; Joining the Zoo; Whither Richard Harison?; A Long Commute Between Dance Partners
description: Tensions may have risen in the Mideast among the Arab nations opposed to the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty, but life goes on, Doris Halaby reported yesterday after talking on the telephone with her daughter Elizabeth, who has been Queen Noor of Jordan since she married King Hussein last year.

title: Ballet: Shadowplay Focuses on Dowell
description: By reviving Antony Tudor's Shadowplay Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, the American Ballet Theater has restored a provocative work to its repertory. Not only does Shadowplay grapple with serious ideas, but it is also a ballet with a moral. But that moral will please neither ascetic nor hedonist.

title: Texan Ordered to Pay $3.3 Million in Divorce Case
description: FORT WORTH, April 20  T. Cullen Davis. the industrialist, was ordered today to pay a $3.3 million divorce settlement to his wife Priscilla.

title: Times of London Plans a Weekly
description: LONDON, April 20  The Times of London, suspended since Nov. 30 because of a dispute over new technology, said today it was about to launch a new weekly to be sold overseas.

title: Witness Says Nuclear Lab Aides Joked About Company Accuser
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, April 20 (AP) Other KerrMcGee Corporation employees joked about the informationgathering activities of Karen Silkwood, the union activist whose estate is suing the company for $11.5 million in damages, one of her coworkers testified in Federal District Court today.

title: U.S. to Study Maze of Rules on Radioactive Shipments
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., April 14  For a quarter of a century a flatbed truck carrying nuclear wastes made regular, uneventful trips from the Brookhaven National Laboratories in Upton. L.I., to a Federal fuelreprocessing facility at Savannah River, S.C. Local officials generally gave its cargo, poisonous enough to kill hundreds of thousands of people if it escaped, no more notice than they would if it had been tomatoes or textiles.

title: BUILDING EMPLOYEES HOLD OFF WALKOUT
description: A threatened strike of 20,000 service employees in 3,000 apartment buildings was temporarily averted late last night when they and the Realty Advisory Board agreed to suspend a midnight deadline and continue negotiating over the weekend.

title: U.S. Aides Inspect Morgan Postal Plant
description: The opening of the Morgan Station facility of the Postal Service on Manhattan's West Side, already frequently postponed, cannot be expected before midsummer and perhaps not then, according to postal officials.

title: Take 21 Lead in Playoff
description: The fact that the Rangers had not beaten the Philadelphia Flyers in Madison Square Garden since the last game of the 1976 season, a 10 game span, did not bother Don Maloney last night. The Ranger rookie scored two goals in 26 seconds and led his team to a 51 conquest of the FLyers. The victory gave the Rangers a 21 lead in the the fourofseven game National Hockey league quarterfinal playoff series.

title: Books of The Times Irony and Flies
description: Africa is irony and flies. It is an elephants graveyard of ideologies, an immense ecological error, a museum of morbid beauty, a pyramid of fantasies piled on fantasies.

title: Royal Danish Ballet Stars To Perform at City Center
description: Soloists of the Royal Danish Ballet 11 dancers from the company based in Copenhagen's Royal Theater and three former members, Adam Lders and Peter Martins of the New York City Ballet and Peter Schaufuss of the National Ballet of Canada  will perform at the City Center from June 19 through July 1. The group's appearance here is part of an international tour that will include seven cities in the United States and Spoleto, Italy. and Monaco. Monte Carlo.

title: Suit Seeks Fee Paid By Westinghouse
description: A Westinghouse Electric Corporation stockholder has filed suit in Federal District Court in Chicago against the Chicago law firm of Kirkland & Ellis for the return of $2.5 million in fees Westinghouse paid the firm to conduct its uranium antitrust suit.

title: Bomb in Rome Badly Damages Michelangelo Building
description: ROME, April 20  A terrorist bomb seriously damaged the Palace of the Senators on the Capitoline Hill today. The building, which serves as Rome's city hall, was designed by Michelangelo and is a monument to the nation's cultural heritage.

title: Atlanta Streak Ends, 8977
description: ATLANTA, April 20  Wes Unseld, 6 feet 7 inches and as wide as a doorway, could not explain how the Washington Bullets won tonight. After splitting the first two games of the Eastern Conference semifinal series against the Atlanta Hawks, the Bullets won at the Omni, 8977, where the Hawks had taken 17 straight games.

title: A Babylonian Disneyland Offers Respite in Iraqi Capital
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq  There is nothing like it in the Middle East. Zawra Park in Baghdad offers astonishing flights of fantasy along with the downtoearth pleasures of eating and drinking.

title: World News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: CURB ON POLLUTION BY DIESELS ASSAILED
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The Council on Wage and Price Stability said today that proposed pollution controls on diesel engines were too stringent and too expensive.

title: Queens Man and Two Associates Accused of LoanShark Scheme
description: A queens man and two ?? associates were indicted yesterday for loansharking, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, announced.

title: Waldheim Assails Obstacles
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.. April 20 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim warned today that continued obstruction of United Nations peacekeeping activities in southern Lebanon could have disastrous consequences for Lebanon and for the Middle East in general.

title: The Losers in Suburban Segregation
description: Who suffers when real estate operators steer home buyers in ways that keep white neighborhoods white and turn integrated neighborhoods black? Everyone, the Supreme Court now rightly answers: Whites and blacks alike are hurt by sales practices that rob a residential area of its racial balance and stability. And to underscore that answer, the Court says that a community and its residents  not just the direct victims of bias  have a right to sue discriminatory real estate dealers under the 1968 Fair Housing Act.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the principal differences between traditional bidding and the modern, scientific style favored by most New York experts is the nature of a one notrump response. After a modernmajorsuit opening, promising at least five cards, one notrump is forcing. It can therefore be used on many hands worth a game invitation, as in the dia gramed example, played in a recent Regional Championship in Syracuse

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Aides to Mayor Draw Up a Plan To Tighten Bail
description: Aides to Mayor Koch are drafting state legislation that would make it harder for defendants charged with serious crimes to be released on bail before a trial.

title: A Public Park Is Offered In Dispute at Tudor City
description: A city park at the southeast corner of First Avenue and 42d Street has been offered as an alternative site for construction of a controversial skyscraper that Harry Helmsley, the developer, wants to build in the center of the Tudor City development.

title: Dance: Taylor Presents Nightshade Premiere
description: From time to time, Paul Taylor's dance works deal with man's dual nature. Perfectly proper citizens degenerate right before our eyes into properly imperfect sinners. Tea parties turn into orgies.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)  Thousands of callers are jamming telephone lines of manufacturers of hair dryers and the Consumer Product Safety Commission as a result of reports that some handheld dryers contain asbestos, which can cause cancer.

title: Atom Mishap a Rare Problem in Reporting
description: Fred Jerome was in Houston on Wednesday, March 28, when his secretary called to tell him that he was getting a lot of telephone calls from reporters at his Manhattan office. By Friday, when he got back to his desk, the phone was ringing off the wall.

title: Ballet: Giselle Danced With Miss Tcherkassky
description: American Ballet Theater presented its first Giselle of the season Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House with Marianna Tcherkassky in the title role and the Australian dancer John Meehan making his debut as Albrecht.

title: Capital's Population Falls 2%
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  Although population fell 2 percent last year in the District of Columbia, the number of whites and elderly persons is on the rise, officials say. Over all, the population fell to 676,100, according to a report released by James O. Gibson, the assistant city administrator. The white population in 1978 was 173,800, or 25.7 percent, and the nonwhite population 502,300, or 74.3 percent, down from a high of 77 percent in 1975.

title: Studio 54's Owner to Sue City
description: Steve Ruben, the owner of Studio 54, said yesterday that he intended to sue New York City for $5 million because he had to stay in jail 30 hours last week. Mr.

title: Hilary Ronner Wed to Dr. Reed Moskowitz, Psychiatrist
description: In the Versailles Room of the St. RegisSheraton last evening, Hilary Jane Rohner and Dr. Reed Craig Moskowitz were married by Rabbi Chaim Pearl of the Conservative Synagogue in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: An Alternative To Strike Action On the Campuses
description: MILITANT professors hijacked New Jersey's eight state colleges last month. Attacking at midsemester, the time when the colleges are most vulnerable, they seized 80,000 innocent students as hostages and sent Governor Byrne this ultimatum:

title: H.E.W. Finds Its Efforts Not Hurt by Bakke Case
description: WASHINGTON. April 21  The Department of Health, Education and Welfare reported today that its numerous civil rights and affirmative action programs for minorities and the disadvantaged were almost entirely unaffected by last summer's landmark decision by the Supreme Court in the Bakke case.

title: Press Unit Cites South Africa
description: LONDON, April 21 (UPI)  The International Press Institute says it will appoint a permanent observer in South Africa to keep the country under a magnifying glass in an attempt to preserve freedom of the press.

title: Compulsive Eaters Find a Way Out
description: THEY sit in a circle in a Central Jersey church and, except for the literature on the table the selfhelp pamphlets distributed by Overeaters Anonymous (O.A.)  there is no way that anyone could guess from looking at the 33 women that they are there because they are compulsive eaters.

title: Table Tennis Team Heads for North Korea>
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE ERIC and Scott Boggan of Merrick remember well the tales about China their father, Tim, told them after he visited that nation in 1971 as a member of the United States table tennis team, whose trip helped spur the normalization process between the two countries. But soon Eric, 15 Years old, and Scott, 17, will have stories of their own to tell about their roles in what may some day be seen as another example of table tennis diplomacy.

title: White Sox 6, Indians 5
description: CLEVELAND, April 21 (UPI)  The Chicago White Sox spoiled the 1979 pitching debut of Wayne Garland today by scoring a 65 victory over the Cleve landIndians.

title: Vandalism On L.I.R.R. Gets Worse
description: PASSENGERS at the Long Island Rail Road's Rockville Centre station thought there was nothing unusual about the youth on a ladder taking down publicaddress speakers: They believed he was an employee and suggested that he wait until the rush hour was over.

title: New York City's PublicEstate Administrators Must Be Both Lawyers and Detectives
description: Two months ago, during a bitterly cold winter night, Irmgard Meyer, a shoppinghag lady who wandered about midtown Manhattan, was slain as she sought shelter in a subway station.

title: Science Museums: DoItYourself Teachers
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: SOVIET NAVY WIDENS INDIAN OCEAN POWER
description: The Soviet Union is expanding air and naval activity in the Indian Ocean and adjacent land areas.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article on the Style page last Sunday, Fanny, a restaurant in the Biltmore Hotel, was incorrectly reported to be closed. It had stopped serving dinner, but the restaurant will continue serving breakfast and lunch through Saturday. It will then close completely.

title: Dodgers 2, Giants 1
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 (UPI) Manny Mota's pinch single with one out in the 10th inning scored Steve Garvey from second base and gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 21 victory over the San Francsico Giants today.

title: Dear Sir: In Reply to Yours of Years Ago...
description: I HAVE ghosts In my attic, hundreds of them. At night I can hear them shrilling, like frogs in the spring. Sometimes they talk to me in my sleep.

title: Oh, for the Good Old Days of Brand X
description: There was a time when the average advertising executive would sooner be caught with ring around his buttondown collar than mention a competitive product in a client's ad. If it were absolutely necessary to trumpet the superiority of one's own product, it could always be compared with that ubiquitous scapegoat, Brand X.

title: No Stamp of Approval for Chain Letters
description: MEMBERS of the New Jersey Psychologists Association met yesterday in Atlantic City to discuss the typical gambler. Is he, they pondered, a romantic hero or unfortunate victim?

title: Editors Choice
description: ALBERT CAMUS by Herbert R. Lattman. (Doubleday, &6.95.) This first biography of a French writer who was more a cult than a man offers an the facts but renders no Judgments.

title: Karin Marie Galluscio Is Wed To Thomas Molino in Queens
description: The marriage of Karin Marie Gailuscio, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Galluscio of Whitestone, Queens, to Thomas Molino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Molino of Fresh Meadows, Queens; took place yesterday in St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church in Whitestone. The Rev. Richard Dunne performed the ceremony.

title: More Damage Is Found in Rome Bombing.
description: ROME April 21  After thoroughly inspecting buildings on.the Capitoline Hill, experts said today that the damage caused by the terrorist bombing of the Palace of the Senators yesterday was even more extensive than was first believed.

title: Cosmos Will Play Home Opener Today
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 21 The unbeaten Cosmos, seeking to please their coach and their fans, worked hard all week in preparation for tomorrow's home opener against the Fort Lauderdale Strikers at Giants Stadium. Off the field, the Cosmos management worked hard in negotiations to add another soccer superstar, Johan Cruyff, to the roster.

title: Red Sox 10, Royals 4
description: BOSTON, April 21 (AP)  Fred Lynn extended his hitting streak to 10 games with his seventh homer, and Jim Rice and Dwight Evans contributed home runs today as the Boston Red Sox took 104 decision over the Kansas City Royals.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: MIDHURST, England  Those enchanting English scenes are enchanting as ever, and the depressing ones just as depressing. An unusually odious winter ended with a thump on Maundy Thursday. Suddenly the birds were in song and the lines of tiny handpolished cars stood outside the wellkept country pubs for Easter.

title: Lesley BushBrown Is Engaged To Thomas Gimbel, Executive
description: The engagement of Lesley BushBrown to Thomas Suffern Taller Gimbel has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Albert BushBrown of Locust Valley, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Fern Taller Denney of Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late David Alva Gimbel.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Julia Child is whipping up another cookbook. It's scheduled for publication by Knopf in December, in time to accompany her January television series. The book will be modeled on her current best seller, Julia Child & Company, and written as a companion piece for her latest series of 13 shows.

title: Reforms in Retreat In the High Schools
description: IN the early 1950's, with science and technology assuming an increasingly important place in modem society, the National Science Foundation set out to revolutionize the teaching of biology, chemistry and physics in American high schools. The goal was to transform the focus of learning from the results of science learning the names of the parts of frog's mouth, memorizing chemical formulas or reading about Newton's laws in textbooks  to the way scientists function.

title: Is The Core Curriculum on Its Way Back?
description: RECENTLY, the Harvard faculty voted a major undergraduate curriculum change: There would soon be a return to a version of the core curriculum, prevalent in many American colleges in the late 1950's and early 1960's, in which foundation courses in many liberalarts areas were required of all students.

title: Recollections of a GoodHumored Era
description: GOOD HUMOR trucks no longer roam the streets of Westchester, thus marking the end of an era. When our girls were old enough to talk, one of the first intelligible sounds they uttered was Good Humor.

title: Pensive in Central Florida
description: LARK BLAISE'S first novel covers some familiar ground both for him and for us. Mr. Blaise has published many a  story along similar lines in his two earlier, muchpraised collections of short fiction, A North American Education and Tribal Justice. And the growing up of a precociously observant, highly !mag1 native narrator in the South (or anywhere else) is tried and true, as is the alienation felt by such a character. But the ploy is not worn out, and Mr. Blaise does some original things with it.

title: A Schubert Anniversary Flowering
description: Last year was the 150th anniversary of Schubert's death, and we are still reaping the benefits of ongoing Schubert projects inspired by his anniversary year.

title: Music Notes: A Flutist Takes a Solo Flight
description: Like many anbther orchestra player, Carol Wincenc (prounced Winsense) became restless after five years as flutist of the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra. In the summer of 1977 she was at the Spoleto festival in Italy, and there the wife of the cellist Lynn Harrell mentioned a forthcoming flute competition in New York. It would be under the auspices of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation, which put it in the top bracket of contests, and it would be the first major one in the United States in its category.

title: Unsinkable Nellie Brown a Swimming Champion at 85
description: About 80 years ago, a young girl with polio almost drowned in Roanoke, Va. Today, at age 85, Nellie Brown is America's oldest swimming champion.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: More than 70 years after the first state law protecting the manitee was enacted, the Federal Government has finally become actively engaged in the program to help this large, aquatic and endangered mammal.

title: Undetected Heart Flaw Was Major Contributor
description: FRANCISCO RODRIGUEZ died because he was permitted to box when he should have been disqualified.

title: Marcia Anne Testa Bride of Physician
description: Marcia Aime Testa, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis John Testa of Waterbury and East Lyme, Conn., was married in Middlebury, Conn., yesterday to Dr. Donald Craig Simonson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Franklin Simonson of East Rockaway, L.I. The Rev. John G. Fanning performed the ceremony in St. John of the Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title: Beauty
description: Freshly brewed coffee, tea, a selection of fruit juices and a decanter of white wine are at the ready in the tastefully decorated waiting room. Seventyfive per

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Some new musicals are strange because they mean to be. Sweeney Todd, let's say. And other new musicals are strange because they're trying so hard not to be. Let Carmelina enter the lists here.

title: Best Sellers
description: This Week Last Week Weeks On List

title: Despite Rumblings in Iran, Khomeini's Word Is Law
description: TEHERAN, Iran  In one of his,last press conferences at NeauphleleChateau before his triumphant return from exile, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini was asked if he expected to be the strongman of the Iranian Islamic republic he had so stubbornly advocated. You may assume so, he said. I shall supervise and direct the Government.

title: Deborah Mayer and J.I. Frank Plan Marriage for September
description: The engagement of Deborah Jane Mayer to Jonathan Ian Frank, son of Mr. and Mrs. Selig Frank of Highland Park, N.J., has been made known by the bridetobe's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leo Mayer Jr. of New York and Bridgton, Me. A September wedding is planned.

title: The Outlook
description: According to the New York Region Econometric Model, the overall outlook for the region is promising because the strength of the suburbs is counterbalancing the virtual lack of growth projected for New York City.

title: Maine Indian Tribes Confronting .Era of Abundance
description: INDIAN ISLAND, Me., April 21 Aging frame homes, house trailers and unpainted wooden sheds crowd the tiny reservation of the Penobscot Nation here, where more than a third of the tribe's 1,918 members still live on 319 acres.

title: Entrepreneurship U.
description: I??E always been interested in aving a business for myself, rather than being part of a big organization, said William R. Bintzer, a secondyear student at the Wharton Entrepreneurial Center at the University of Pennsylvania. It presents an opportunity for more income  but more risk, too, as well as more independence. And it's probably more fun.

title: Court Removes A Libel Barrier
description: The Supreme Cant Wiled last week, 6 to 3, that the First Amendment does not protect journalists defending libel suits against having to testify on opinions, judgments and conversations they held while preparing atories.

title: Alynne Amkraut, Singer, Wed
description: Alynne Beth Amkraut, an actress and singer, was married yesterday to Albert Jay Krull, an architectural designer. The ceremony was performed in Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I., by Rabbi Kenneth D. Poplack. He was assisted by Cantors Boris Fisch and Kurt Silberman. The bride appeared with the national tour of Fiddler on the Roof. Her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Amkraut, live in Bethpage, L.I. Mr. Krull is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Krull of Englewood, N.J., and is with Becker, Bendixen & Murphy, architects and planners in Newark.

title: Grow Your Own Bouquet of Roses
description: It's spring. Longstemmed roses are $3 a piece at the florist. The alternative? Plant your own rosebush.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Just when the age of the plotless ballet had taught us that the danced play was a relic of the past, we were presented this month with two ballets based on two classics of dramatic literature. One was The Playboy of the Western World, choreographed by Joan Denise Moriarty for the Irish Ballet Company's version John Millington Synge's play of the same title. The other was Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme, by George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins, for a special program with the New York City Opera and based on Molire's comedy of the same name.

title: The Kind of Issue You Can't Wiry
description: ALTHOUGH party leaders do not usually intervene in legislative votes on such sensitive issues as abortion, the issue of Medicaid funds for abortions came close to being a partyline vote in the latest  but undoubtedly not the last struggle over the issue in the State Lesislature.

title: Playland Comes to a Crossroad
description: WHEN the Cross County Parkway was being planned in the 1930's, it was intended to be not just a connector for major northsouth arteries but a link between Westchester's crowded cities  Yonkers, Mount Vernon and New Rochelle  and Playland, the world's first architecturally designed amusement park, which had opened in the 1920's in Rye on Long Island Sound.

title: Events Today
description: Bike Tour: an allday. 36mile bicycle tour through all five boroughs; 7 A.M.; tour starts at Battery Park in lower Manhattan. (S1 registration. Call sponsor American Youth Hostels at 4317100 for further Intormatlon.)

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY When a Teacher Has the Wrong Degree
description: I KNOW the signs. My office is the last one before the custodian's closet. It's also the only one so close to a classroom that, as I write this essay, I can learn about New Jersey's plant pests.

title: Dollar's Dramatic Turnabout
description: WASHINGTON  Last fall, the value of the United States dollar was sinking perilously, tanning domestic inflation and making President Carter look like a man helplessly caught in economic tides. In a crisis atmosphere, advisers were summoned, some from Georgetown dinner parties, to a meeting in the White House basement to map a dollar defense that Mr. Carter announced on Nov. 1.

title: L.J. Podles Fianc Of Maidie Smith
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy Smith of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth Alexandre Smith, to Leon J. Podles of Baltimore.

title: The Action Critic
description: THE last book Harold Rosenberg completed before his death last year at the age of 72 was devoted to his old friend and colleague Barnett Newman. It is a physical object of exceptional beauty: Newman's work has never been so well reproduced. includes a lot or valuable documentary material, both by Newman himself and by his adversaries or interlocutors, and Rosenberg wrote it as someone who had made the long march within earshot of Newman (even if it does not appear from the bibliography that he had written on him before 1963). He is good on Newman himself, good on the controversies in which Newman often found himself embroiled, good on the titles of his paintings, and good on their critical reception. That his contribution is of. essay length only is not necessarily a defect; Rosenberg knew how to condense his thought.

title: Capitol Hill Serves As Their Classroom
description: GREENWAY, Va.

title: EXPERTS MONITORING RADIATION'S EFFECTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  When engineers released radioactive steam from the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear plant into the Pennsylvania air late last month, scientists began planning to study the effects of precisely measured doses of lowlevel radiation, although some scientists say that the doses may have been too small to show significant results.

title: Trompe L'Oeil: Games Artists Play
description: TROMPE l'oeil art has no ancient history beyond reports of birds pecking at painted fruit in classical Greece, and it may not count as art at all. But the genre must be at least as old as slapstick, shell games and the other forms of oneupmanship with which human beings gain the edge on each other.

title: New Canaan Women Build School Swimming Dynasty
description: NEW CANAAN WHEN Carol McVeigh and Peg Murphy launched the New Canaan High School girls swimming team as cocoaches in the fall of 1973, probably the best they could have hoped for was a slow building process. They were starting from scratch, with a nonexistent team, no experience as coaches, no money for expenses and no pool for practice or meets.

title: It's Time to Adopt Solar Power As Way Out of Nuclear Trap
description: THE accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania has forcefully demonstrated to us that nuclear accidents do happen and will happen in greater numbers as nuclear plants proliferate.

title: CRIME
description: As his Chance Awakening demonstrated, George Markstein is a writer who knows bow to create ingenious plots. But wnereas that book actually Buffered from its ingenuity, his newest novel. THE GOEKING TESTAMENT (Ballantine, $8.99), adheres to a straight story line. It is not without complications, but it follows a rather gripping story right through to a cynical ending. It is a British espionage novel in the finest Eric Ambler tradition.

title: Democratic Senators Showing Fears on 80
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  Surrounded by the sun and flowers of spring, the Democratic senators who face reelection next year are already feeling an uneasy chill of November.

title: Denise Farr Plans Marriage in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Farr of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Denise Farr, to Andrew Leith Isaac, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ren A. Isaac of Chapvaaua. N.Y.

title: CHESS
description: The double blunder, when two very strong players are involved, always comes as a shock. That two notable proponents of the game should be attuned to the same false note at the same time has to be highly improbable. And yet it happens.

title: Man Beaten to Death On West End Avenue; 2 Suspects Questioned
description: A shabbily dressed man in his 30's was chased down by four other men and clubbed to death on West End Avenue between 80th and 81st Streets late yesterday afternoon as several residents watched and a cab driver went for the oolice.

title: Brooklyn College to Honor Shaw, 9 Other ExAthletes
description: Brooklyn College will honor 10 former athletes, including Irwin Shaw, the author, and Joe Post, now the principal of Public School 138 in Queens, at its Hail of Fame dinner on May 17.

title: I. M. PEI WILL DESIGN CONVENTION CENTER
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Koch announced yesterday that I. M. Pei, one of the nation's premier architects, had been selected to design the $375 million New York Convention and Exhibition Center scheduled to use on Manhattan's West Side over the next five years as a keystone of efforts to revitalize the city's economy.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 2) Face the Nation: Senator John H. Glenn Jr. of Ohio.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: The three yellowed pencil sketches on the first pages of this autobiographical picture book are the talented work of the author's relatives. My father, his father, and his father's father all had drawing talent and all hoped to become artists: none of them did. Instead they bequeathed that calling to Erik Blegvad, their artistic heir. This book is a portfolio of his life seen through his work. There are bright landscapes and seascapes of his native Denmark, some charming loose drawings of Paris in the late 1940's, when he lived and worked there, views of America, where he moved with his American wife in the early 50's, book and magazine illustration. To both this art and the concise narration that accompanies it Mr. Blegvad brings quiet humor, a gifted hand and a generous spirit. He includes, too, the work of artist friends, in particular that of N.M. Bodecker, also an illustrator of great wit and facility.

title: Dale A. Peterson, Novelist, to Marry Wyn Kelley in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bayne Kelley of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wyn Kelley, to Dale Alfred Peterson of Woodside, Calif., son of Paul Gilbert Peterson of Rockford, Ill., and the late Mrs. Peterson.

title: A view of Manhattan from Liberty Park, Jersey City
Staten Island Is Leading State In NewHome Building
description: The Sun Belt it is not. But the place that is leading the state in the construction of new singlefamily homes and condominiums is Staten Island.

title: Pact at Pittsburgh Paper
description: PITASBURGH, April 21 (UPI)  Local 61 of the Newspaper Guild and the PostGazette Publishing Company, publishers of the daily PostGazette, reached tentative agreement today on a threeyear contract. The agreement, which covers 96 employees in the editorial department, will be voted on next week, averting a strike set for 3 P.M. today.

title: Wadkins Ties for Lead
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 21 (AP)  Bobby Wadklus, repeating his 1978 thirdround performance at the Tallahassee open, carded a 7underpar 65 today to tie Chi Chi Rodriguez at 202 going into the final round of the $100,000 event.

title: IRAN TRIAL BEGINS FOR UNION OFFICIALS
description: CAMDEN. N.J., April 20  Five officials of a New Jersey teamster local went on trial this week on Federal charges of using large union deposits as leverage to pry unsecured loans anti kickbacks from banks for themselves, business associates, friends and relatives.

title: Black Doctors Assert Race Is Factor at Alabama Hospitals
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  When Dr. Isaac C. Ravizee dropped by Carraway Methodist Hospital to pick up an application for staff privileges, he said, the chilly reception ended his dream of someday practicing in the 600bed hospital, which looms over the workingclass neighborhood where he grew up.

title: Pop: Medleys by Arthur Siegel
description: Arthur Siegel is a songwriter with a special interest in songs and a richly rewarding collection of them  funny songs, tender songs, silly songs  that leaves the listener astonished that so many delightful songs can go virtually unsung except by Mr. Siegel. He also has a special interest in songwriters, from the great names such as Irving Berlin and Jerome Kern to such lesscelebrated writers as Charlotte Kent. Nancy Hamilton and the team of Bert Kalmar and Harry Ruly.

title: In a Crystal Ball, Prosperity
description: PLUGGING 1,400 statistical variables into a framework of 1,500 complex equations, a recent economic study has come up with what is a relatively bright outlook for the Island's economy.

title: Discord as Usual in New Rochelle GOP
description: REPUBLICANS here are no longer troubled about admitting that the party suffers from internal discord. Discord has been a fact of life for the last 20 years, say a number of party officials, and few of them dare to dream about the intramural squabbling evolving into some sort of real unity.

title: Nabisco Gives a Gift of Art
description: EAST HANOVER

title: Bureaucracy Is Snagging Plans
description: WASHINGTON IT IS hardly a household name yet, but New Jersey's Liberty Walk already has been caught in some heavy bureaucratic traffic that could delay its construction by a year.

title: Term Minority Shunned By, Black Social Workers
description: ST. LOUIS, April 21  The National Association of Black Social Workers vowed today to stop using the term minority to describe black Americans and recommended that other blacks do the same.

title: John Leonard in the Imperial City
description: PRIVATE LIVES IN THE IMPERIAL CITY, 69 of John Leonard's Private Lives columns, which appear in The Living Section of The New York Times, will be published this week by Alfred A. Knopf at $8.95. Nora Ephron, whose most recent book is Scribble Scribble, interviewed Mr. Leonard at his home in New York City.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: SLATE and flagstone have been widely used by homeowners for many years as paving materials or floor coverings. They have been used indoors in kitchens, bathrooms, laundry rooms and dens or playrooms, and outdoors for patios and walks where a more decorative surface than ordinary concrete can offer is desired.

title: Fairfield Outlook: A Good Economy
description: PLUGGING 1,400 statistical variables into a framework of 1,500 complex equations, a recent economic study has come up with a relatively bright outlook for the economies of Fairfield County and the other northern suburbs of New York City.

title: Disabled Teachers Push for Acceptance
description: RELATIONSHIPS with other faculty members are difficult for me, said Judith Gurmankin, especially since I was forced on the Philadelphia school system by a court order.

title: The Bail Controversy And Black Politics
description: Basic political good manners require speaking up for your own people when they are in trouble. It is axiomatic: Politics starts in the neighborhood and the good politician protects himself by defending his home base.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: SLATE and flagstone have been widely used by homeowners for many years as paving materials or floor coverings. They have been used indoors in kitchens, bathroms, lagndry rooms and. dens or playrooms, and outdoors for patios and walks where a more decorative suface than ordinary concrete can offer is desired.

title: Defining Basics Is at Issue
description: WITH the interests of legislators, educators and parents shifting forcefully from elemental basics (earth, air, water, fire) to elementary basics (reading, writing, arithmetic), enthusiasm for science is rapidly waning in the classroom among both the students and the teachers. It's as if the 1950's surge in science never happened, said Donald McGehee, the Louisiana state science supervisor.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: PLAINVIEW HE used the word frightening. That is not a ward one would like to bear about the .state of public schools, but lt was the word used by Dr. Robert F. Savitt, who has been Superintendent in PlainviewOld Bet since 1958. Dr. Savitt is one of the deans, one of the most public and even publicityminded of Superintendents, a man who has not just stayed in his own district but who has worked with ,education groups from Europe to California. After 20 years as Superintendent, he is getting M..and the word he used was

title: Lakers, 76ers Have Centers of Attention
description: Kareem AbdulJabbar is 32 years old, and there is a bald spot developing on the crown of his head.

title: Many Queries, Few Replies in Bail Case
description: Though the epithets in New York City's bail ccatroversy were less inflamatory last week, the debate persisted over whether Criminal Court Judge Bruce McM. Wright should be called, as the police did, Turn 'em Loose Bruce, or, as 21 black and civilliberties groups suggested in his defense, Treat 'em Right. Wright.

title: All Smiles After Palimony' Ruling
description: Hollywood, more than most places, knows what it means to hitch your wagon to a star. A judge in Los Angeles last week ordered Lee Marvin, the Academy Awardwinning actor, to pay $104,000  $1,000 a week for two years  to Michelle Triola Marvin to help her reestablish an independent life, after six years with Mr. Marvin.

title: The Grand Tour: Memorandum From J. Pierpont Morgan
description: In 1859, a few days before his 22d birthday, J. Pierpont Morgan, who was to become the greatest American banker, financier and collector of his time, sent his future fatherinlaw a suggested itinerary for a tour of the Continent. His memorandum, recently discovered in the Morgan Family Papers, provides an interesting insight into what 19thcentury Americans thought worth seeing. Jonathan Sturges, also a banker, and his wife planned to visit Morgan's father, Junius Spencer Morgan, in London and to travel to other places in England and Europe.

title: The Right Bounds for the F.B.I.
description: Attorney General Griffin Bell has been offering up some pronouncements. First he said that unless he gets his way over the creation of a legislative charter for the F.B.I., he'll take his ball and go home. A few days later  whatever happens to the charter  he said he's going home, period. Mr. Bell has been a decent and conscientious Attorney General and we do not begrudge him his return to private law practice. But the taste  and the timing  of his F.B.I. remarks are exceptionally poor. The charter is important. It has a reasonable chance of enactment this year. We hope that the Attorney General's words do not mean that he has quit before he quits.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE name, Poor Lads may have a faint Dickensian Ong, but the food and dcor at this handily. located (near the Yale. Repertory Theatre) New Haven restaurant are more provincial French. The service? Well, that's dichotomous. (Dare we say bilingual?) In the evening we found it Frenchified, experienced, expert; at lunch it

title: Smallpox Virus Found In Lab Vials on Coast; Bottles Are Destroyed
description: ATLANTA, April 21 (UPI)  An overlooked batch of smallpox virus not previously known to exist has been discovered in a California laboratory, touching off concern among disease control officials that other unguarded stocks of the virus may be around.

title: Supreme Court Constricts Authority of Regulatory Agencies
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal bureaucracy, already on the defensive against deregulators in Congress and the White House, now seems to have lost a majority of its friends at the third branch of government, the United States Supreme Court. In several recent decisions, the Justices have not only invalidated actions by Federal regulatory agencies, but expressed a constricted view of the agencies authority. While it is too early to conclude that the High Court is embarked on the kind of philosphical turnaround it experiences every decade or so, the change in attitude is already significant both for the agencies and for other legal controversies. And although the Court decided a variety of constitutional cases last week as it began the final leg of the current term, it is the pattern of regulatory decisions that perhaps best illustrates the Court's function as a political institution.

title: Watson's Lead at 3; Pate Hits 7Under 65
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 21  Tom Watson retained a threestroke lead going into the final round of the Tournament of Champions, but Jerry Pate stole the show today in the $300,000 event with a sevenunderpar 65 over the 6,911yard Rancho La Costa course.

title: Students Continuing Protests at Columbia Over Nuclear Reactor
description: Despite Columbia University's decision not to activate a nuclear reactor on its Morningside Heights campus, opposition to the reactor continued to be vocal there last week.

title: Blue jays 5, Tigers 4
description: DETROIT, April 21 (AP)  Rick Bosetti drove in three runs with a twotun homer and a double today to lead the Tomato Blue Jays to a 54 triumph over the Detroit Tigers.

title: Moscdw Primes for Olympics
description: MOSCOW  Soviet officials are eagerly anticipating them. Some Muscovites are dreading them, while more than 20,000 members of the Young Communist League are building for them. The Olympic Games, scheduled to begin on July 19, 1980, are already changing life in the Soviet capital 15 months before the opening ceremonies.

title: State Is Asked to Pay $500,000 Marvin Fees
description: LOS ANGELES, April 21 (AP)  Michelle Triola Marvin's lawyer says he does not want attorney fees to chew up Miss Marvin's $104,000 award from Lee Marvin, the actor. He is asking the state to pay $500.000 for his legal servoces.

title: Peace Talks Began Last Week
description: VIENTIANE, Laos  At the beginning of last month, the Soviet Union accused China of massing troops on its borders with Laos. Two days later, Vietnam voiced the same charge. Then Mongolia echoed it. Finally, on March 6, Laos itself discovered the Chinese menace and protested.

title: Sharif Khan Still Unbeaten In Squash Racquets Event
description: Sharif Khan of Canada remained the only undefeated player in a fivecountry squash racquets roundrobin tournament as he defeated Stuart Goldstein of the United States, 1816, 159, 1417, 159, at the Uptown Racquet Club yesterday.

title: Carter Wilderness Plan Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, April 21(AP)  President Carter's plan to create new wilderness areas is being opposed by the American Farm Bureau, Federation. Allan Grant. president of the federation, said the pian represented a dangerous misuse of critically short energy, timber and mineral resources. Mr. Carter recommended that 36 million acres of roadless land be opened for multiple uses, such as mining, grazing, timber cutting, recre ation and oil and gas exploration. But he also asked that 15.4 million acres be designated as wilderness.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Visiting Distilleries on Scotland's Whisky Trail
description: Scotland's Whisky Trail is a 62 mile route through the Highlands that the British Automobile Association has signposted to show the way to four major distilleries. At each, after a full guided tour, visitors are treated to a wee dram of malt whisky, which is to runofthestill scotch what a Chateau Lafitte Rothschild is to a chianti.

title: The Nevi Phys Ed Benefits Everyone
description: THE oncedreaded gym class of hard calesthenics is rapidly giving way to a new approach that physicalfitness professionals call the new P.E. That can include a lot of jogging, such as students at the Dodgen Middle School in Marietta, Ga., do each day. By the end of the year, they have logged as many as 25,000 miles, and to make the mileage more meaningful they trace imaginative travels on a world map.

title: At Home: Replying to Ghosts in the Attic Is Complicated ... It Takes Time
description: I HAVE ghosts in my attic, hundreds of them. At night I can hear them shrilling, like frogs in the spring. Sometimes they talk to me in my sleep.

title: It's Their Sound, Not Just the Songs
description: HUNTINGTON

title: Missouri Sets World Mark
description: WACO Tex., April 21 (AP)  Missouri's sprint medley relay team set a world record of 3 minutes 13.66 seconds Friday night in the Baylor University invitation track and field meet.

title: Vandals, So Bold They Strike Publicly, Defy Solution on Long Island Rail Road
description: Passengers at the Long Island Rail Road's Rockville Centre station thought there was nothing unusual about the youth on a ladder taking down publicaddress speakers: They believed he was an employee and suggested that he wait until the rush hour was over.

title: The Media Event Comes of Age in British Politics
description: COALVILLE, England, April 20 In the last three days, Margaret Thatcher has reclined in an East Anglian pasture with a calf, operated a sewing machine in a Leicester garment factory and stuffed bonbons into boxes in a Birmingham chocolate plant.

title: Camps That Treat Learning Disabilities
description: WHEN John Lehman, now 13 years old, first went off to summer camp four years ago, he thought some things about his situation were downright unfair. He had to study math and reading and, even though he also swam and played ball and built campfires, he would have happily dispensed with the more bookish activities. Today, he is looking forward to his fourth season at the camp, because you have the greatest time there and you learn a lot.

title: War Story
description: SIDESHOW

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: WHATEVER happened to all those alternative mortgages? Almost a full year has elapsed since enabling legislation was passed by the General Assembly permitting statechartered banks to begin offering mortgages other than the conventional fixedinterest, fixedpayment and fixedterm loans. Many of these new types of loan were to be particularly tailored to the special needs of the young and elderly.

title: 28 Are Hurt After Bus Overturns Returning From Baseball Game
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (AP) University of Delaware student remained hospitalized in serious condition today afters bus returning from a Philadelphia Phillies baseball game overturned, injuring 28 pawns, the authorities said.

title: LeggeAutocrat Of the Turntable
description: Walter Legge, the English sound and music expert who died in St. JohnCap Ferrat, France last month, innovated a line of work which now has scores of imitators and inheritdrs all over the world. He was, though he rarely used the term himself, producer of innumerable recordings which will endure as long as there are people to listen.

title: How to Get There
description: Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge: Take Interstate 287 to the North Maple Avenue exit in Basking Ridge. At the blinking light, turn left onto Madisonville Road. Make the first right after the bridge onto Pleasant Plains Road and follow it into the refuge.

title: FORD ISN'T RUNNING BUT WON'T BAR RACE
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  Former President Gerald R. Ford says he would not duck the responsibility of becoming the Republican nominee for President if the party failed to reach agreement on a candidate by spring next year.

title: Mentally Disabled: Issue in Kinds Point
description: KINGS POINT WHEN Ira Cavrell of this affluent suburb decided last month to sell his large frame house near a corner of Station Road and East Shore Drive to a local organization establishing a residence for 12 mentally disabled young people,. he realized that not everyone would applaud his decision.

title: Rural Abuse
description: BAYOU SORREL, La. The stench came without warning three years ago, covering Bayou Sorrel like a blanket and bringing with it headaches, nausea and irritability. In the modest houses and fishing camps that line the Grand River just outside the Atchafalaya Basin, the huge cypress swamp which nourishes much of the nation's seafood, people often rose from their dinner tables gagging. Some woke in the night choking. Dogs out for an evening run came out the woods with parts of their'coats falling off. Deer disappeared from the woods; even river eels became scarce.

title: Forgotten by His Jailers, Austrian Nearly Starves
description: BREGENZ, Austria, April 21 (UPI) An 18yearold man jailed for questioning about an auto accident was forgotten by jailers for nearly three weeks and almost starved to death.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Supreme Court Decides Freedom of Information Case
description: The Supreme Court dealt a blow last week to the use of the Freedom of Information Act as a vehicle for industrial espionage.

title: IN BRIEF
description: In a surprise move, the Ford Motor Company announced that Young & Rubican International would be the new ad agency for the LincolnMercury division and Wells, Rich, Greene Inc.. the new agency for its corporate advertising. Industry sources put the billings involved at about $75 million, making this the secondlargest account movement in advertising history. Gloom turned to surprise at Young & Rubicam, because the company had earlier lost the ChryslerPlymouth advertising, with billings of about $50 million. when Chrysler switched its accounts to Kenyan L Eckhardt. Speculation had been that Ogilvy & Mather, which is the Ford agency in England, would get the Ford account.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: In what was a politically savvy article on Integrating a New Group: The Old [March 11], how could you come up with a change in William Ratchford's party affiliation to identify him as a Republican? With the Democrats holding five of our six Congressional seats, you must either be under the spell of Fairfield County, where there are a few Republicans, or you are blowing a Biebel Bubble to test the direction of the wind. Congressman Ratchford thought be did something big by demonstrating that the Fifth District seat had not been made safe for the Republican Party by its previous holder, Ronald A. Sarasin.

title: News Report
description: EARLY in this important and admirable book, an account of the recent history of four important American institutions in the business of gathering, disseminating and often manipulating the news  The Los Angeles Times, The Washington Post. Time Inc.

title: Albany Aide Cites Supplier As Marble Falls From Mall
description: ALBANY, April 21  Criticizing a private materialssupply company for shoddy workmanship, a state construction official says blocks of marble ranging in weight from 30 to 1,500 pounds had apparently become dangerously loose on two buildings in the $2 billion Albans mall complex.

title: Author's Query
description: For a biography of the late Kathleen Norris, I am interested in letters, personal recollections and papers.

title: World News Briefs
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, April 21 (AP) President William R. Tolbert Jr. ordered the University of Liberia closed today,accusing it of creating subversion that contributed to last week's food riots. The riots caused 29 deaths, more than 400 injuries dollars in damage.

title: Westbury Arts Group Protests State Refusal To Aid Poetry Project
description: A community arts council, deciding Long Island poets are too good to blush unseen, has protested a state decision not to pay $1,500 for the printing of poetry to be displayed in Long Island Rail Road cars.

title: Deaths
description: LICHTAlice Beloved wife of the late Charles, devoted mother of Seena Lowe and Dr. Emanuel Licht, dear sister of Sylvia Werbie and Clarence Minsk, loving grandmother of Jeffrey. Steven and Melanie, Suzanne and David. Services today, 12 Noon, Parkside Chapels, Jerome Ave near 170th Street, Bronx.

title: The Region
description: Mayor Koch and his fiscal advisers turned from wringing their hands to thumping their chests last week, as what looked in January like a $433 million deficit in next year's budget somehow became a $19 million surplus.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Relatively Speaking, the 1967 play that established Alan Ayckbourn as something of a British Neil Simon, opens at the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck Saturday at 8:30 P.M. under the auspices of the Westchester Regional Theater. The comedy of manners deals with an adulterous entanglement between two couples: one middleaged and married, the. other young and unfettered. Previews are Thursday at 8 and Friday at 8:30. Geoffrey Sherman is the British director and the cast includes Helen Harrelson, Robert Blackburn, Kevin Conroy and Pamela Lewis. One of. Ayckbourn's most recent efforts, Bedroom Farce, is currently a Broadway hit. Tickets for the Emelin production are $5 to $7.50. Reservations: 8355252 or 6980098.

title: Cleaning Up Toxic Waste: A Long and Dirty Road
description: WASHINGTON  The potential dangers of nuclear. waste are graphically demonstrated by the difficulties of cleanup at Three Mile Island. Congress has just started to look at another significant hazard the disposal of millions of gallons of toxic chemical and manufacturing wastes.

title: Brezhnev Wins Award for Books
description: MOSCOW, April 21 (Reuters) Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, has been awarded the Lenin Prize for Literature for three autobiographical volumes, Little Land, Rebirth and Virgin Lands, the press agency Tass reported today.

title: Course Shows Students How to Get and Keep a Job
description: You can't do anything right can you? the man on the television screen shouted, slamming a manuscript down on a table. Either shave up or net out.

title: RHODESIAN ELECTION EMDS WITH TURNOUT PUT AT 65 PERCENT
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 21 Rhodesia's parliamentary election ended today with a reported turnout of about 65 percent of the eligible voters; a figure ??at officials said was a definitive rebuff by blacks to guerrillas fighting the Government.

title: Marilyn Berger, a Reporter, Wed to Don Hewitt of CBS
description: Marilyn Berger, correspondent and anchor for WNET TV's Special Edition program, was married April 14 to Don Hewitt, a CBS News producer. The marriage was performed aboard the yacht La Belle Simone while cruising off Caneel Bay, St. John's, V.I.. by the yacht's skipper, Capt. Klauss Goetch. David J. Mahoney, chairman of Norton Simon Inc., and his wife, Hidegarde, attended the couple.

title: University of Guadalajara Draws Medical Students U.S. Schools Refused
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico  We all want to leave here as soon as possible, a young medical student from New York said. But no one is going to drop out. It's like serving out a prison term before we can become doctors.

title: The Growing Taste for Superior Audio Quality
description: A growing number of the 9.4 million American audio fans pay double the price of ordinary records for socalled audiophile disks. More often found in audio shops than in record stores, such disks are produced by a handful of small companies going by such unfamiliar names as Denon, Sheffield, Telarc, Gale, Umbrella, Levinson, and CrystalClear. As a group, they. promise  and often deliver  spectacular sound and quiet surfaces.

title: Cruise Missile Crashes in Test
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) Tomahawk cruise missile crashed today on a range at Fort Irwin, Calif., shortly after it was launched from a Navy A6 aircraft: the Defense Department anpounced. The missile caused no damage and there were no casualties, a spokesman said. It was the seventh failure in 41 test flights of the Tomahawk missile, Pentagon spokesman said. An investigation to determine the cause of the crash was under way.

title: Paterson In a War On Blight
description: PATERSON

title: Cotton Mather As Cult Hero
description: LINDENHURST THE 197879 repertory of Studio Theater  its 17th year in Lindenhurst  has comprised Equus, Seascape, The Homecoming and Fortune and Men's Eyes. You won't find pop-palaver at Studio, a press release assures us.

title: Other World Events
description: Where is democracy? read a wall poster last week in Shanghai's People's Square. Good question. The poster and others attacked new repression of human rights in China and assailed Shanghai police as the real cause of trouble. Authorities did not remove the posters.

title: Ethnic Arabs of Iran's Oil Region in South Worry Regime
description: ABADAN, Iran, April 17  The oilproducing southern region of Khuzistan has become a major focal point of both hopes and fears for Iran's revolutionary leadership.

title: Fossil Footprints Remind Anthropologists of What They Have Always Known
description: Longfellow exhorted us to make our lives sublime by leaving footprints on the sands of time. Metaphor sometimes turns concrete (literally in this case), for the oldest signs of human activity have been reported from Tanzania  footprints 3.6 to 3.8 million years old pressed into volcanic ashes that cemented within hours after an array of creatures from centipedes, to human ancestors, to elephants passed by.

title: Housing: Rezoning for 2Family Conversions
description: DICK and Eleanor Chapman used to rattle around and love it in their sixroom, fourbath house with a 30foot living room and terraces upstairs and down. They filled the place with books and gave a lot of parties, and the entire family enjoyed the space.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: We're asking about it now because we are finding more and more cases of thyroid cancer from such treatments, the doctor replied. The patient was silent, but then he asked: I wonder what is being done now that will prompt new questions in 30 years.

title: A Guide to Applying for a Passport
description: If you are planning to go abroad this summer, this is the time to arrange for a passport, if you do not already have one. Government officials expect a record number of nearly three and a half million Americans to be issued passports this year. While the State De, partment is confident it can cope with the load and is prepared to issue passports within a day in emergencies, it advises applicants to allow at least a month to get one and additional time before departure to obtain any visas that are required by countries to be visited.

title: Judge Suspends Abortion Law
description: LINCOLN, Neb., April 21 (AP)  A Federal judge has ordered Nebraska not to enforce portions of a recently passed abortion law until a trial can be held to resolve constitutional challenges to the measure. District Judge Warren K. Urbom yesterday suspended portions of the new law pending a trial July 18. One section suspended by the judge prohibits an abortion from being performed until 48 hours after a woman has given her consent.

title: Verification Arguments Aren't Only Technical
description: Washington  When the political upheaval in Iran accelerated six months ago, few American officials anticipated that one of the serious consequences would be to cast deep doubt on the ability of the Carter Administration to persuade the Senate to approve a new Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: Colleges Drawing on Retirees' Experience
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  Ira Wennik, who,retired after 30 years as a Defense Department personnel officer, is guiding University of Maryland students into jobs these days.

title: Fash. Force of American Design
description: American designers' views on fashion are as varied as the noodles in a can of alphabet soup. They range from those of Perry Ellis, who envisions women dressed in a delightfully haphazard way, to Bill Blass, whose woman is composed as carefully as if she were sitting for ber portrait in a dramatic ball gown. In between the two extremes, there are designers who create for every kind of woman from those with real personal style to those who just want to look nice and get on with it. Clothes designed and made in America have always been the most powerful factor in determining the way American women dress  for after all the hue and cry of fashion news from Europe, only a minuscule number of European clothes reach the stores.

title: State Seeks to Take The Profit out of Graft
description: NEWARK

title: Phils Blank Mets for 6th in Row
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 21  The Mets finally seemed to have set their infield earlier this week when they acquired Frank Taverns from the Pittsburgh Pirates. Their new infield held together for only four innings tonight in a 30 loss to the Phillies.

title: CAMERA
description: The ideal way to learn any craft is through actual experience, and photography workshops provide photographers with this kind of hands on training. Geared to students at all levels of photographic development; these workshops offer concentrated summer sessions in the art and craft of photography, often with individualized instruction and exposure to today's master photographers.

title: Reds 4, Cardinals 1
description: ST LOUIS., April 21 (AP)  Mike LaCoss held St. Louis to three hits over eight innings and George Foster broke a 11 tie with a single in the seventh to lead the Cincinnati Reds to a 41 victory tonight.

title: The Dispute Is Over the Effectiveness of Production Incentives
description: WASHINGTON  When President Carter unveiled his plan to decontrol crude oil prices, Department of Energy officials confidently predicted that the proposal would add 740,000 to 820,000 barrels a day to domestic oil production by 1985. That notinsignificant quantity would reduce oil imports by nearly 10 percent and save S4 billion (at current prices) in foreign oil costs.

title: Tanzanians Prepare for a Battle With Amin Forces
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, April 21 (AP) Tanzanian and Ugandan troops pushed toward a strategic power plant near the city of Jinja today and prepared to battle forces loyal to deposed President Idi Amin who hold the facility, military sources said.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: HITTING THE BEACH ON A WARM SPRING DAY, clammers raked the sand and a fisherman tried his luck along shore in Bayside, Queens. Temperatures reached upper 60's under sunny skies. Today will be mild and partly cloudy.

title: U.S. Medical Aid Eyed for South Fork
description: AMEETING will be held at Southampton College on Wednesday night in an effort to identify the most pressing health needs of the South Fork, which is eligible for Federarfunds as a result of its designation as a medically underserved area.

title: New Convention Center Carries West Berlin's Economic Hopes
description: WEST BERLIN, April 20  A sprawling aluminumsheathed structure that resembles a craft from outer space carries West Berlin's economic hopes for the future. The building is a new convention center that can seat 20,000, the largest in Europe.

title: BOOS ENDS
description: Stephen Spender came by the other day, talking about a couple of books that bear his name this season: Henry Moore: Sculptures in Landscape. with photographs by Geoffrey Shakerly. and America Observed, with drawings by Paul Hogarth. He has written interpretive texts for both artists. The Moore is already out. the Hogarth (yes, he is a descendant of the 18thcentury painter) is due in summer; both are published by Clarkson N. Potter/ Crown.

title: Dear Sir: Greetings and Apologies
description: I HAVE ghosts in my attic, hundreds of them. At night I can hear them shrilling, like frogs in the spring. Sometimes they talk to me in my sleep.

title: StaggeredBus Plan Stirs School Dispute
description: CEDARHURST WHEN the subject of school busing comes up, it usually involves the touchy question of whether to shuttle students around to achieve racial integration. But a busing dispute has broken out in the LawrenceCedarhust School District (District No. 15) that has nothing to do with race.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Once again the National Park Service was wrestling with what it called the burro management problem. About 300 wild burros remaining in Grand Canyon National Park were obliterating vegetation, the agency said last August, and William Whalen, director of the Park Service, suggested a final solution: The cheapest way is shooting them and leaving them on the grounds so they will be recycled into the chain of life.

title: Miss Yates, N.C. Thorne Bankers, Wed
description: The marriage of Margaret Ann Yates, an account officer with Citibank, to Nathan Comstock Thorne, corporate lending officer with Citi bank, took place yesterday in St. James Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Hays H. Rockwell, assisted by the Rev. Frederick E. Hill. It was followed by reception at the Colony Club.

title: Baby Gets Transfusion Despite Religious Pleas
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) Doctors have delivered a premature baby girl despite her parents religious protestations that blood transfusions not be administered to the infant.

title: The Allman Brothers Band Has Got It Together Again
description: A lot of those people out there came because they wonder if the Allman Brothers Band can still do it, said Gregg Allman matteroffactly. He was standing with some wellwishers in a dressing room at the Jacksonville, Fla. Coliseum, waiting to go onstage for the group's first performance in almost three years. (An Allman Brothers Band concert scheduled for Tuesday, April 24, at the Palladium in New York City was sold out an hour and a half after it was announced.) Mr. Allman was looking tanned, more heavyset than he was during the Allman Brothers's reign as one of America's most popular and innovative rock groups, and, one thought, more clearheaded. Outwardly, Mr. Allman and the other musicians  original members Dickey Betts, Butch Trucks and Jaimoe, and new additions Dan Toler and David Goldflieswere playing the part of relaxed professionals. But there was tension In the air. When a visitor in the dressing room leaned against a table and sent it crashing to the floor, everyone jumped, visibly shaken.

title: TUG UNION BALKING AT JUSTICE'S ORDER TO REMOVE GARBAGE
description: The striking tugboat bperators union refused to let its members carry out a court order to resume taking New York City's garbage to a Staten Island landfill yesterday.

title: Chinese Law Eases Divorce  Or Does It?
description: SHANGHAI, April 18  It could almost have been a tale out of an old Chinese novel. The irate woman, angered by her husband's filial devotion to his parents rather than to her and by her motherinlaw's scorn when she failed to give birth to a son, sued for divorce.

title: Searle Decade
description: Since 1946 Ronald Searle has published about 50 volumes, plus the new one at hand, RONALD SEARLE (Mayflower Books, $25), which collects work of the past 10 years. There are the familiar spindly legs, pot bellies and rheumy eyes; but there are also many wise and foolish animals with lessons for human beings, an occasional beguiling watercolor with no lesson but beauty, some drawings of Hamburg nightlife with Groszlike intentions. In two of these. one of lesbians and another of bar girls, Mr. Searle's manic line relaxes with unusual grace. The medals that Mr. Searle has been making recentlymostly homages to other artists  are shown; Thurber is best. The introduction by Henning Bock is highfalutin. The reproduction catches Mr.

title: Julia B. Churchman Is Wed in Virginia To William McCue
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Richmond yesterday, Julia Brooke Churchman, a legislative aide for Preservation Action in Washington, was married to William Allen McCue, who is a legal assistant with the Washington law firm of Hogan & Hartson. The Rev. Craig Biddle 3d performed the ceremony.

title: New Jersey in 1990: A Forecast
description: IT LOOKS like Elizabeth is going to continue to smell, an economist remarked recently as he inspected the results of a 10year economic forecast for the industrialized northern area of New Jersev

title: Which Marvin Won?
description: Lee Marvin, the macho actor, roared with delight over his court victory in California last week. He has pay his former mistress $109,000  a great deal less than the $1.8 million she had sought from him for failing to support her after their sixyear relationship ended. But did Michele Triola Marvin really lose?

title: Music: String Revival Presents Rare Works and Two Premieres
description: There were two genuine premieres in the program given by the String Revival at McMillin Theater. on Friday night, but everything that was played was almost as novel. Howard Shanet, founder and conductor of the 20member ensemble at Columbia University, had dug up works that are unaccountably neglected and put them together fora particularly attractive concert.

title: DINING OUT
description: LESS than two years ago, the longestablished Villa Pierre in Glen Cove changed management, was spruced up and was given a distinctly French personality at the hands of the new owners and chef, all to good effect. Last fall the chef left after what seems to have been a management dispute. So another review is in order.

title: FOOD
description: GLEN COVE TASTE in clam chowder, whether tomatobased Manhattan or creamy New England, is a regional affair. According to James and Jimmy Dunne, father and son who own Noe's (pronounced Nowee's) Fish Market in Glen Cove, this is the heart of red chowder country.

title: Dance: Emi Hatano's Japanese Homage to Stone
description: Emi Hatano, the modem dancer. choreographer and teacher, chose peculiarly Japanese conceit as the theme for her concert Friday at Japan House, which marked both her New York debut and the start of the Japan Today, a twomonthlong nationwide celebration of contemporary Japanese culture and custom. In her Homage to Stone. performed to a percussion score by Katsutoshi Nagasawa, Miss Hatano set out to express the Japanese soul by recreating the essence of stone and stoniness in a series of solos.

title: PEOPLE
description: Zoltai Merszei said he was looking for a challenge when he left Dow Chemical. Now, it seems, he has found one. The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced last week that Mr. Mersnri had been named its vice chairman, responsible for Stratestic planning policy and development. Included in his new position is the title of chairman and chief executive officer of Occidental's chemical operations, of which the Hooker Chemical Company is a part. He will serve under Armand Hammer, the company's chairman and chief executive, who is 80 years old. The same day the changes were announced, Occidental reported net income for the first quarter of 1979 of 987.9 million, nearly three times the the net it reported for the year ago quarter.

title: Lynne Weinberger Engaged
description: The engagement of Lynne Weinberger to Mark J. Schwitz has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Weinberger of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. Mr. Schwitz is a son of Mrs. Sydney Schwitz of Syosset, L.I., and the late Dr. Schwitz.

title: Old, New, Borrowed, Blue
description: ANUEL PUIG is an experimental realist from Argentina who, in his search for what he calls a new form of popular literature, likes to recount the ordinary melodramas of everyday life in novel ways, some

title: Postwar Japan on Film-- The Dark Side of Affluence:The Dark Side Of Postwar Japan
description: "Postwar Japanese Society Through Film," a series of 12 powerful films about a nation in moral and spiritual crisis, opens Friday night at Japan House as part of a three-month, nation-wide celebration called "Japan Today." The series will run through June 8, with each film being shown twice.These particular films are unusual selections because they uncover a little-known Japan facing problems of such magnitude that at times they seem destined to tear the entire social fabric asunder.Pictured here is not a nation of tea ceremonies and the gracious dignity of ritual restraint, but rather a society that has arisen phoenix-like from the ashes, a society summed up morally by a shot from the 1947 Ozu film, "Record of a Tenement Gentleman": Just after the war, orphans in rags are smoking cigarettes and scratching their lice-ridden bodies as they sit somnolently in Tokyo's Ueno Park under a statue of Saigo Takamori, a famous 19th-century advocate of Japanese expansion in Southeast Asia.From the late 40's through the 70's, the three decades encompassed by this series, Japan's problems grew both more far-reaching and ever more inaccessible to remedy. There was famine and unemployment in the immediate postwar years. Then, in the years of heady economic growth, there was an untraditional materialism fanned furiously into being by advertising methods of surreal ingenuity. Finally there has been, in the 70's, the exposure of collusions between government and big business that placed gargantuan sums of money into the pockets of a few.Whether harsh, gentle or bitterly ironic, the 12 directors whose films constitute this series indicate how disillusioned they are with the newly prosperous postwar Japan.On Friday the series will be inaugurated with the 1946 "No Regrets for Our Youth," a superb early work of Akira Kurosawa. The only film of this group set during the war, it explores the spiritual growth of a young Japanese woman named Yukie (Setsuko Hara), who discovers that "to live" (always a Kurosawa theme) she must give up piano lessons and flower arranging for a life of greater purpose. Moving from Kyoto to Tokyo  traditional past to hysterical wartime present  Yukie first becomes involved in anti-war activities. Later she renounces the genteel existence of the idle upper-middle-class wife for which she is destined, choosing instead the grueling life of a farm woman, living among less fortunate people to whom she hopes to be of service.No matter that Mr. Kurosawa happened simultaneously to be complying with two of the edicts of the American Occupation and General McArthur, the making of films which illustrated anti-war sentiment as well as the emancipation of women. "No Regrets," one of Mr. Kurosawa's most deeply felt films and one infrequently screened abroad, is fresh in its awareness that it is not enough to survive; living meaningfully may entail the sacrifice of a comfortable continuity for less certain paths.The most surprising and powerful of the 12 films are the biting satires which, had they been made by foreigners, might have even been termed "anti-Japanese": "Pigs and Battleships," "A Full-Up Train," "The Build-Up," "Night Butterflies" and "Solar Eclipse," all being shown in the United States for the first time.The most brilliant of these is generally acknowledged to be Shohei Imamura's 1961 "Pigs and Battleships." Set in the environs of the U.S. naval base at Yokosuka, the film reveals the effect of the American presence upon Japanese teenagers. The 1946 Constitution forbidding Japan to re-arm notwithstanding, the director portrays Japanese spectators admiring American Phantom jets: "Americans are so great. Different from our Self-Defense Army." The "pigs" of the title are Japanese gangsters, amateur and professional, who prey on the innocent no less than the intruding Americans. Petty gangsters raise hogs fed on the refuse of the American base  just as, says a bitter Mr. Imamura, the postwar Japanese have been force-fed the garbage of American culture. A child reads aloud from his school text, "The reason Japan developed so fast was that it adopted Western culture so effectively." But what we see is the culture spawned by the American base: A black market, prostitution and a resurgent militarism.If Mr. Imamura chastises with sardonic wit, Kon Ichikawa is mordantly hilarious. In "The Full-Up Train," the funniest of the 12 films, the director pulls out all stops. "The train's full," mourns Moroi, Mr. Ichikawa's hero, "but we have to take it, there won't be any other." The noise is so deafening it gives Moroi an incurable psychosomatic toothache. University graduates are lucky to get jobs as janitors. Overcrowding is so endemic that men line up in droves just to play pachinko, or Japanese pin-ball. Nepotism is rampant. On this full-up train that is Japan, madness and even suicide seem real options.No less broad in its humorous depiction of the inhospitality of contemporary Japan toward the Japanese is Yasuzo Masumara's 1958 "The Build-Up," in which a candy executive, gazing from his skyscraper window at the moving crowds below, remarks, "They all look like caramels." The executive longs for a natural catastrophe to stimulate profits: "If there's no ???disaster, there will be too much fruit, and ???rm kids won't eat candy." Nor are student demonstrators exempt from the exhortations of the advertising agency in the candy company's emplay: "Enjoy caramels while you're marching!"
