And meanwhile, someone bemoans that Japanese women prefer American boyfriends since Japanese men are skinny, have short legs and make less money."A Full-Up Train," "Pigs And Battleships" and "The Ceremony"  a 1971 Nagisa Oshima film in which old war criminals re-assume positions of power in government and industry  reveal that is the young who pay, whose future now seems hopelessly mortgaged and beyond their control.Often, like the 1957 "Night Butterflies," the films of this series are semi-documentary in impulse, buttressing their criticisms with factual information conveyed in authoritative voiceovers. "Night Butterflies" initiates us into night-town Tokyo, with its 5,000 bar girls competing for customers. Into this, Osaka entrepreneurs are forging their way. "We'll contribute election funds!" decides an Osaka merchant well-schooled in how things work.Equally sober in its unrelenting scrutiny of the "new Japan" is "Solar Eclipse," based upon a real-life scandal involving the awarding of a construction contract. Once again the victims are ordinary Japanese, the taxpayers who ultimately finance the bribes. The steady accumulation of incriminating detail in this film is breathtaking: Votes of Diet members are purchased. The newly elected Prime Minister sends a representative to a money-lender for funds to tide him over. A corporation executive explains, "It's usual to burn unnecessary documents." "A rotten apple is never alone," says the president of a semi-government-owned company which awards the construction contract; the man himself is about to accept a bribe.The journalist counterpart to our Woodward and Bernstein who would blow the whistle on all this corruption is murdered. And the chief prosecutor of the Watergate-style Diet investigating committee (seen taking a bribe even before the credits) is now told not to "stimulate peoples' distrust of politics." Offered a long paid vacation by his party to "study the world situation," be departs. Curtain after curtain is lifted as this formidable film exposes a Japan unknown to most. (Director Satsuo Yamamoto has also made a film about the Lockheed scandal.)Rarely shown and also part of the series is "Summer Soldiers," a 1972-work written and co-directed by John Nathan, an American Japanologist turned filmmaker. Exploring the attempt of the Japanese anti-war movement to shield American deserters from Vietnam, the film is based upon taped dialogues between often illiterate American conscripts from the South and their highly educated, articulate hosts, who took upon themselves the Quixotic task of assimilating these American G.I.'s into middle-class Japanese homes. What befell these Americans, who never learned the language, was disaster: Rape, theft, encounters with the Japanese police. Jean-Paul Sartre praised "Summer Soldiers" for conveying "the sheer agony of limited communication between people who have grown up in two different cultures, the existential agony of the foreigner in a foreign land."Closing the series is woman director Sachiko Hidari's "The Far Road," a 1977 film about the painful efforts of Japan's railway workers to create labor unions which speak to their needs. Miss Hidari's film deprives us of any illusion about this recourse for the besieged Japanese citizen.Under attack by all 12 films is an entire culture, a distorted value system in which things foreign are foolishly preferred, an unresponsive government and an unfair economy. No social institution escapes the satire of these directors as they lay bare an uneasy Japan racing without moral restraint toward postwar prosperity.Offering not a single avenue for reform, the films meticulously detail the inhumanities faced by the Japanese in their daily lives in which, as Heinosuke Gosho reveals in his gentle 1953 work, "Where Chimneys Are Seen," personal gratification is hard to come by.And solutions seem nowhere in sight. In "No Regrets for Our Youth," jail awaited Yukie and her activist lover, but at least their decision to oppose the war was clear-cut. It finds no parallel among characters facing postwar injustice. The evil seems too vast even to comprehend, let alone to combat. The demand that everyone accommodate to working hard in this overcrowded Japan requires acquiescence, as Mr. Masumua says in "The Build-Up": "We're in Japan. We must work hard or we can't live."Joan Mellen is the author of "Big Bad Wolves: Masculinity in the American Film" and a forthcoming novel set in Japan, "Natural Tendencies."

title: Burgering, 6 Other Divers Will Compete in Canada
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 21 (AP) Dave Burgering, the defending 3meter champion, and six other American divers will compete in the Canada Cup meet next weekend at Montreal, the United States Amateur Athletic Union has announced.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: EMILY LAUGEL delivers sandwiches and soft drinks to families and workmen on movein day. Her work also entails crawling around the basements of vacated bouses, looking for signs of dampness and mechanical problems.

title: Screen: Strick's Version Of 'Portrait of an Artist'
description: There's a marvelous sequence near the beginning of Joseph Strick's measured, almost stately film version of James Joyce's "A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man." The very young Stephen Dedalus witnesses an uproarious dinner-table battle between his father, Simon, and his governess, Dante, over politics, Parnell, the Roman Catholic Church, Ireland and the Irish, who, Simon Dedalus says, "are a priest-ridden race," to which Dante replies with the kind of scream that usually signals death, "If we are priest-ridden, we ought to be proud of it! They are the apple of God's eye...."The little boy listens enraptured. He is fascinated by the passion and the language, if not totally understanding the ideas. There are a number of other sequence???s in this film that capture the passion, language and ideas of Joyce's great autobiographical novel, which was first published in 1916 and marked the transition from the comparatively conventional Joyce of "The Dubliners" to the innovative Joyce of "Ulysses" and "Finnegan's Wake."These sequences, however, become increasingly rare as the movie proceeds from Stephen's childhood in turn-of-the-century Ireland, a time marked by momentous reversals in fortune, to his young manhood when the most important events are raging philisophical battles that are not especially dramatic or photogenic."A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man," which opens today at the Embassy 72d Street and Guild Theaters, is both worthy and maddening. It's worthy because Mr. Strick and his screen writer, Judith Rascoe, obviously admire Joyce enough to wish to share that admiration with a large cinema audience, and they have packed the film with great passages of the Joycean language. It's maddening because their task is an impossible one, as it was when Mr. Strick made his equally faithful, equally frustrating screen version of "Ulysses.""A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man" is not a long book, but it is not one that can be easily dramatized. Its substance is not events, but the language that evokes the steps by which its questing hero finally arrives at his decision to quit family, friends, homeland and church to go into exile to become the artist. Language heard is very different from language read. The trouble is not that Joyce's language is so literary  it's not  but that the vocabulary of ideas numbs the ear. The effect of the last half-hour of this film is to make Stephen Dedalus, who is one of the most courageous and adventurous heros in modern literature, seem a bore.Mr. Strick and Miss Rascoe skim across the surface of the book like agile water-skiers on a choppy sea. They never fall, but they never give us any sense of the density of the water itself.The film is carefully composed and beautifully photographed, mostly in Dublin, which, apparently, can recreate any era in its history, and its cast of Irish actors is superb.Bosco Hogan, who plays the grown up Stephen, has the toughest job because so much of the action is interior. A smooth-faced, bespectacled young man, he must forever be taking things in, reacting to others, or ruminating on the soundtrack about Life and Art, which is not easy. T.P. McKenna and Rosaleen Linihan, who play his parents, are funny and spirited, especially in the earlier scenes before the Dedalus family begins its descent into poverty, even though they never appear to age. Maureen Potter is awfully good as the outraged Dante and Terence Strick and Luke Johnston, who play Stephen at, respectively, ages 3 and 10, are most winning. John Gielgud makes a brief appearance as the priest, who, for a few minutes, inspires visions of hell and eternal damnation within Stephen, though the casting of Mr. Gielgud in this role has a way of deflecting attention from the effect of the sermon on Stephen to the man delivering it.This film version of "A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man" should, I suppose, be a valuable teaching aid if, indeed, schools and universities have not junked Joyce in favor of an in-depth course on Television Programming, 1950-60. The film's deficiencies testify not to the supremacy of the word over the image, but to the differences, which we should never forget and always cherish.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris, in an Actor's CafTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: Prison Delayed for Mutilator
description: SAN DIEGO, April 21 (AP)  A judge has delayed sending Lawrence Singleton, a merchant seaman, to prison for the rapemutilation of a teenage girl until plans can be made to insure his safety. If he is put in a normal prison settbut, it would amount to a death sentence, Robert L. Grimes, attorney for Mr. Singleton, said yesterday after his client was sentenced to a 14year 4month prison term. Judge Earl H. Maas Jr. ordered him sent to Chino State Prison in three weeks to allow prison officials to plan security measures.

title: LETTER
description: We were fortunate during World War II to attend Laurence Olivier's nevertobeforgotten, electrifying performances at the New Theatre in London (Talking with Olivier by Curtis Bill Pepper, March 25). When the Old Vic Repertory came to New York, we were again in the audience to be mesmerized.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Nancy P. Anderson To Be Wed June 16
description: Nancy Pamela Anderson, a student at the Boston University School of Medicine, and Robert Alexander Hughes, a senior at the Harvard Medical School, will be married June 16 in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: Atlanta Fans Learn To Care for Hawks
description: ATLANTA, April 21  Here is where you can find the Atlanta Hawks, the descendants  three locations removed  of the TriCities Blackhawks, the National Basketball Association franchise that played its games in Moline, Davenport and Rock Island.

title: Sadat Ends Parliament, Sets Elections for June 7
description: CAIRO, April 21  President Anwar elSadat dissolved Parliament today and ordered new elections for June 7.

title: William Seabrook, Gay L. Ludington, Lawyer, Are Wed
description: Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Gay Lucile Ludington and William Reginald Seabrook. Msgr. Vincent W. Jeffers performed the ceremony.

title: Summer Beyond Wish
description: A long time ago I lived in a cossroads village of northern Virginia and during its summer enjoyed innocence and never knew boredom, although nothing of consequence happened there.

title: Susan Gorman Becomes Bride
description: Susan ThomasAnne Gorman, daughter of Joan and William James Gorman, was married in Riverside, Conn., yesterday to Douglas Otis White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otis White. Both families are of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor performed the ceremony in St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Joseph Calvin Gengras, cousin of the bride.

title: Eileen J. Frawley Is Married To Dudley Edward Callahan
description: Eileen Josephine Frawley, a student at the University of California at Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Dudley Edward Callahan, a vice president of Schick Laboratories in Los Angeles. The ceremony was performed in St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Los Angeles by the Rev. John T. Carroll.

title: ART
description: OPPONENTS of abstract art don't bounce off the ropes the way they used to. The mode is, after all, about 70 years old and has long since been the object of state and corporate patronage. Moreover, little in daily life, from architectural and industrial design to advertising and movies, has escaped the influence of its maior exponents.

title: There'll Always Be an Eton . . .
description: ALONG the banks of the River Thames and just within the ghostly shadow of Windsor Castle lie the ageold redbrick turreted buildings of Eton  still regarded after 590 years as the most exclusive boys' boarding school in the British Isles.

title: Is It Time For Ad Clocks On Sidewalks?
description: And now we interrupt your sidewalk stroll for a commercial message at 9:07 A.M. and 46 degrees.

title: Kathleen Kebler Is Married To Leo Braun 3d, Sales Aide
description: At the Reformed Church of Bronxville yesterday, Kathleen Leonard Kebier, daughter of Mrs. Edward William Kloth of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late John Armstrong Kebler, became the bride of Leo Charles Braun 3d of Randolph, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Braun Jr. of East Falmouth, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Charles Copenhaver performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Msgr. James Connolly of Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: Paperbacks: New and Notworthy
description: THE SECOND RING OF POWER, by Carlos Castaneda. (Simon & Schuster/Touchstone, $3.95.) In this fifth book about his pilgrimages into Mexico to visit Don Juan, Carlos Castaneda finds that the shaman has gone into some other world but four women disciples are still around to offer fresh revelations. Our reviewer Robert Bly called this book fiction, giving capitalist college kids what they want  fantasies of gaining power without becoming more compassionate or more honest.

title: Fatalities Involving Motorcycles, Vans and Trucks Rising Sharply
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  Fatal traffic accidents are increasing dramatically, especially those involving motorcycles, trucks and vans, the Transportation Department has reported.

title: LETTERS
description: Language

title: Amy L. Atwell Plans to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Burton Atwell of Pittsburgh and Johns Island, Vero Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Louise Atwell, to Charles Rockwell Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Elmer Williams of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich.

title: Deaths
description: FIELDSEdward, Honorary FASID. The United Jewish AppealFederation of Jewish Philanthropies Joint Campaign wishes to enmress its sorrow at the passing of a distinguisted leader whom we had planned t0 honor at our annual Design,Soace Planning and Decorative Division dinner in June. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Eleanor & other members of the bereaved family.

title: Adequate Summer Water Supply Expected in Much of the Rockies
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  Much of the Rocky Mountains and the Southwest are assured of adequate summer water supplies because of a record snowpack, but prospects are not so bright in some other Western areas, according to the Agriculture Department.

title: Helping Chicano Kids
description: DENVER  For Hispanic children, school is a place of failure, frustration and hostility. Nationwide, for every 100 Hispanic children who graduate from high school, 51 drop out. In many school districts, the attrition rate is as high as 85 percent, making Hispanics the most severely undereducated group in the population. Only 40 percent have completed high school, as compared to 46 percent of the blacks and 67 percent of the whites.

title: Rahway Is Hoping To Preserve Theater
description: RAHWAY

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Siberian Husky Club of Greater New York specialty and obedience match, Eisenhower Park, East Meadow. L.I.; entries from 10 A.M.; judging noon.

title: A Word On Behalf of the Mexican Tomato
description: WASHINGTON  The tomatoes Americans find in their supermarkets every winter frequently taste like pasteboard.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: 10 Sentenced in Marijuana Case
description: WILMINGTON, N.C., April 21(UPI) Ten men, one from New York City, have been given sentences ranging from six months to 10 years for conspiring to smuggle 16 tons of marijuana into the United States last year. Federal District Judge Franklin T. Dupree Jr. handed down the harshest sentence yesterday to Pasquale Morgigno of New York, who was convicted of conspiracy to smuggle and aiding and abetting smuggling. Mr. Morgigno received 10 years and a $30,000 fine.

title: Pop: The Suggestive Plasmatics
description: Just a few years ago, a modestly talented punk band appeared on the CBGB'sMax's circuit. It featured crew of hardworking male instrumentalists, fronted by a woman who played overtly at her role as a sexpot. Now that band  Blondie  has established itself as a leading force in presentclay popular music, both commercially and artistically, and its singer, Deborah Harry, has long since proved herself in vocal as well as imagistic terms.

title: Stacy Mathas, 57, Dies; Led a Marketing Agency
description: Stacy C. Mathas, the president of Chenault Inc., a New York marketing and promotion concern, died Friday in St. Francis Hospital's heart center in Roslyn, L.I. He was 57 years old and was resident of West Hempstead, L.I., and Athens.

title: Letters: A Caution on Health Risks
description: To tie Editor:

title: STRIKING GUARDS ASK FEDERAL MEDIATION
description: ALBANY, April 21 Union representatives of striking prison guards asked Federal mediators today to intervene in their contract dispute with New York State, but state mediators said they would not allow Federal intervention.

title: Suburbs Lift Region's Outlook
description: According to the New York Region Econometric Model; the overall outlook for the region is promising because the strength of the suburbs is counterbalancing the virtual lack of growth projected for New York City.

title: Prizewinners on the East End
description: RIVERHEAD THE art gallery of the East End Arts Center, in a converted mid19th century home on Riverhead's main street, has its virtues and its flaws. On the plus side, the center's domestic setting, lovingly restored and adapted to provide muchneeded service to the community and the arts, has a warm and welcoming atmosphere. However, narrow hallways and cozy parlors with lots of windows and doors are not the easiest spaces in which to mount an art exhibition.

title: ART VIEW
description: Nothing shatters a cultural tradition quite quickly or as irrevocably as the lure of easy money. Before the juggernaut of the fat checkbook, tradition is virtually helpless to defend its fragile rights. Only the law, it seems, can effectively intercede against the threat of irreversible depredations.

title: How Not to Sell the Olympics
description: Soon, we shall see the United States Olympic logo adorning everything from Levi Strauss jeans to WhamO frisbees. Merchants have found a marketing bonanza while helping sponsor the 1980 Olympic team. The team needs money and to get it, the United States Olympic Committee has blurred the line between amateur and professional sports. It has overturned the late Avery Brundage's prohibition forbidding amateur athletes endorse products.

title: Badger of Cincinnati Will Coach U.S. Squad
description: CINCINNATI, April 21 (AP)  Ed Badger, the basketball coach at the University of Cincinnati, has been named to coach the 11player United States entry in the third InterContinental Cup basketball competition in Europe.

title: Have Study Plans, WillTravel
description: SUE HOSKINS followed the exploratory footsteps of Lewis and Clark. James Willis led 14 collectors of primitive art through Senegal, Mali and Upper Volta. Bea Herrmann sought out authors of children's books in the British Isles and South America. And Barbara Schwartz flew to Guatemala for a week's soulsearching seminar on Risking Change.

title: Notes: Vacation Alternatives to Paying for Gasoline
description: If the sight of gasoline pumps with 99centagallon signs upon them does not give the traveler a shock, the possibility of gasoline rationing probably does. By summer a number of vacation plans may be being trimmed to fit the cloth.

title: Peyton Morris, Advertising Trainee, Bride Of Mark Petty, Loan Officer, in Connecticut
description: Peyton Carr Morris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Morris of Southport, Conn., was married there yesterday to Mark Eliot Petty, son of Mr. and Mrs. William George Petty of Charlottes ville, Va., formerly of Cincinnati and Manila. The Rev. Averett Ray performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Marriage Announcement 5 -- No Title
description: Engagements

title: Carter Heads for Reunion
description: PLAINS, Ga., April 21 (AP)  President Carter traveled to Calhoun, Ga., today for a family reunion at the home of his eldest son, Jack. Before leaving his hometown after a 29hour visit, the President visited with his mother, went fishing in a farm pond and greeted local merchants in a stroll through town.

title: Princeton Women Win
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 21 Nancy Kraemer of Princeton earned 26 points, though she did not win an event, and led a wellbalanced Princeton team to victory in the third annual Women's Ivy League Track and Field championships at Brown University today.

title: Rhodesia Votes, The Others Wait
description: Millions of black Rhodesians marked ballots for the first time last week, heeding the whitecontrolled Government's contention that they would be voting for peace. Ragged, barefoot, illiterate, some practiced marking their x on the voting booth wall before choosing among party symbols  elephant, burning torch, spear and shield.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE state's Hispanic residents had high hopes that one of their number would become a judge of the Federal District Court. There are four vacancies in New Jersey, and a halfdozen Hispanic groups had been lobbying Senators Harrison A. Williams Jr. and Bill Bradley for one of those seats.

title: Holocaust, Deed and Word
description: Today marks the beginning of a week of remembrance of the six million Jews and millions of other Europeans who were systematically killed in World, War II for being racially incompatible with the Nazi design for a new Europe. Congress and President Car ter decided officially to commemorate this unparalleled tragedy next weekend, the 34th anniversary of the liberation of the concentration camp at Dachau, Germany, which revealed the enormity of the Nazi crimes. The Presidential Commission on the Holocaust extended the two days to the entire week.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: FOR the last four years, Suffolk County has led the state in the number of traffic fatalities, and one way that the county's Traffic Safety Division thinks this death toll can be cut down is by eliminating the junior driver's license.

title: Cleary Smith Is Bride of Lawyer
description: Cleary Joan Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip C. Smith of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Robert G. Thomas, son of Mrs. Robert Harry Thomas of St. Petersburg, Fla., and the late Lieut. Col. Thomas, U.S.M.C. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection by Msgr. Cornelius O'Brien, assisted by the Rev. Robert J. Robbins. There was a reception at the Apawamis Club in Rye.

title: Hyperbolic Hyphenated Harumphs
description: MARVIN MUDRICK is the all-pro middle line"backer of academic criticism. He does not"initiate the play, but whoever is carrying the"ball better not take a false step, or Mudrick will pul"verize him. His new book leaves bodies strewn and"twitching all over the primal ooze of American liter"ary scholarship.

title: A Time Capsule From Ancient Rome
description: Pompeii is one of the romantic stories of all time: the bustling town on the Bay of Naples, nestling all unsuspecting at the foot of Vesuvius, which was smothered in a sudden eruption and lay buried and forgotten for centuries. Yet as everyone knows. the rain of ashes which wiped out Pompeii that fateful day of August 24, 79 A.D., also  preserved it, to become the most famous archaeological site in the world.

title: One Dies, Three Hurt As Arab Terror Squad Strikes at Israeli Town
description: TEL AVIV, Sunday, April 22 (UPI)  A seaborne Palestinian terrorist squad attacked the northern Israeli resort of Nahariya before dawn today. Military sources said one Israeli was killed and at least three were injured.

title: Headliners
description: Garbo quit. Calvin Coolidge quit. Muhammad All quits all the time. So why shouldn't Johnny Carson quit? No institution, however sacred, keeps the sky from falling all by itself. Nevertheless, Mr. Carson's appearances on The Tonight Show may be all that is preventing a meltdown in the pressure chambers of NBCTV and its president, Fred Silverman. The Tonight Show is estimated to account for 17 percent  $23 million  of the network's pretax profits. NBC's parent company, RCA, will hold its annual shareholders meeting May 1 and Mr. Silverman is expected to have a hard enough time as it is explaining why he has been unable to bring NBC back from third place in the ratings. Now this. Meanwhile, back at Mr. Silverman's alma mater ABC, Howard K. Smith posted his resignation on the bulletin board. Mr. Smith said he felt his role as commentator on the nightly news show was being eliminated and he would be left with nothing to do.

title: Mailbox: Payson Purchased, Not Inherited, His Stock in Mets
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Crowds Imperil English Cathedrals
description: England's cathedrals, which have become a big tourist business, attracting more than 20,000,000 visitors a year, are urged in an official report to consider introducing admission charges, to run their souvenir shops more efficiently, to train their own guides, to set up visitor centers and to seize the opportunity to look upon each visitor as a possible pilgrim, drawing him into the spiritual dimension of the experience with more and better services.

title: Farmers Say They Will Set Aside Over 11.2 Million Acres This Year
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) Fanners have indicated they plan to remove more than 112 million acres of cropland from production this year under Federal programs aimed at holding down harvests of wheat and feed grains, the Agriculture Department said yesterday.

title: Mon treal Overtime Winner
description: TORONTO,April 21 (UPI)  Cam Connor, with two Toronto defenders draped over him, scored after 5 minutes 25 seconds of the second overtime tonight, giving the Montreal Canadiens a 43 victory over the Maple Leafs and a 30 lead in their fourofsevengame Stanley Cup quarterfinal playoffs. arryl Sittler 's second goal of the game at 17:40 of the third perlbd, which was deflected off Montreal's Guy Lapointe past the goalie, Ken Dryden, tied the score at 33 and forced the overtime.

title: Bruins 2, Penguins 1
description: PITTSBURGH, April 21 (AP)  Rick Middleton's powerplay goal in the third period gave the Boston Bruins a 11 victory today over the Pittsburgh Penguins. Boston now holds a 30 edge n the four-of-seven-game National lackey League quarterfinal playoff, mid could sweep the series by taking he fourth game here tomorrow night.

title: Halcyon Days for Science Are Over in the Schools
description: TWO decades after science became the favored child of American education  with hundreds of millions of Federal dollars at its disposal and a clearcut mandate to assure national security and lead American society into the technological age biology, chemistry and physics are once again fighting for their place in American schools.

title: Safety Official Suggests G.M. Recall Spare Tires
description: DETROIT, April 21 (UPI)  The new Xbody compact cars introduced last week by. the General Motors Corporation have run into another problem: a Federal traffic safety official's recommendation that G.M. recall the cars snare tires.

title: Officer's Death Ruled a Suicide
description: NEWARK, April 21 (AP)  A Port Authority police officer found dead in a locker room at Newark International Airport early today committed suicide by shooting himself in the chest with his ser vice revolver, the Essex County Medical Examiner's office ruled. The officer, Sgt. William Nisbet. 38 years old, of Wooddbridge. N.J., had been preparing a report on the emergency unit he directed. The unit was responsible for removing the dead and injured from the wreck of a New York Airways helicopter that crashelf at the airport Wednesday night.

title: Mamie Winston Is Married to Ian Macauley
description: Mamie Fertel Winston and Ian Thurston Macauley were married yesterday evening in Las Vegas, Nev. Rabbi Stephen E. Weisberg of Congregation Ner Tamid performed the ceremony in his home.

title: Without Financial Worries, The 3 R's Can Be Gilded
description: STAMFORD  Twentyfive years after the United States Supreme Court struck down the racial segregation of school children in Brown v. Topeka Board of Education, the methods used to finance public education have becomeagain by court order  the primary issue of educational equity in many states. In 1971, the California Supreme Court became the first to rule that use of local property taxes as the main revenue source for education was unconstitutional because it makes the quality of a child's education a function of the wealth of his parents and neighbors.

title: Shows and Events
description: Today  Flea Market and Antiques and Crafts Fair, DePaul High School, 1512 Alps Raod, Wayne. Hours: 10 A.M.5 P.M. Admission: Adults, 25 cents; children, free. More than 100 dealers. For information, call (201) 5Z5561.

title: Clocks From the Skillful Hands of the Dominys Win New Fame
description: OF the hundreds of craftsmen working on the Island during the 18th and 19th centuries, none are as well known as the several generations of the Dominy family of East Hampton. The cabinetmaking and clockmaking talents of Nathaniel Dominy 4th; his son, Nathaniel 5th, and grandson, Felix, spanned nearly a full century, and the varied products of their woodworking and clockmaking shops are highly prized today by descendants of the original owners, by collectors and by museums.

title: Sheila McBride Married To David Dundas James
description: St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Philadelphia was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Sheila McBride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. McBride of Franklin Lakes, N.J., and Westhampton, L.I., to David Dundas James, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. James of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James C. Ransom.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: The Nation
description: Braking the economy without throwing it into reverse seemed trickier than ever last week as Federal policymakers fought for the steering wheel and labor leaders chose not to go along for the ride.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE BONFIRE, which is situated at Exit 59 off Interstate 80, is a twofamily business. Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Diamond and Mr. and Mrs. Al Billias, who began with a hamburger stand 25 years ago, built up a steady clientele that now fills their fullscale, 175seat Paterson restaurant.

title: Jazz: Hailing E.Y. Harburg And His Songs
description: On the surface, a jazz celebration of a lyricist might seem to be a pointless exercise because instrumental jazz, which comprises the vast bulk of jazz, is not involved with the work of the lyricist, and jazz singers tend to improvise around the original lyrics. But the Jazz Portrait of E.Y. Harburg, presented Thursday night in the Highlights of Jazz series, at New York University's Loeb Student Center, managed to skirt both problems.

title: Charles Sherwood Jr. Weds Dawn A. Daniel in Queens
description: The marriage of Dawn Alicia Daniel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand Daniel of Frederickstead, St. Croix, V.I., to Charles Randolph Sherwood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherwood of Hempstead, L.I., took place yesterday. The ceremony was performed in St. Clement Pope Roman Catholic Church in Jamaica, Queens, by the Rev. Robert McCourt.

title: NBCTV Planning Special About Hermitage Museum
description: NBCTV, the network that will televise the 1980 Winter Olympics in Moscow, will broadcast a 90minute primetime special next season focusing on the Hermitage museum in Leningrad.

title: Revamping Adoption Policies
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Safety Steps Ordered At Three Mile Island And 5 Similar Plants
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) Operators of the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant and five similar facilities were ordered today to take precautionary steps to avoid conditions like those that led to the accident at the Pennsylvania plant on March 28.

title: On Language
description: An odd locution  Thank you much  has been spreading like tamefire. A query about it in this space a few weeks ago brought fierce replies from a legion of linguistic Inspector Javerts.

title: Honey and Bill and Dan and Celia
description: THE scene is a farm in the Catskills, the time is an exceptionally hot Fourth of July weekend in 1935. Two illmatched couples  Honey and Bill Hubbard, Dan and Celia (Silly) Zimmern  come to visit Anna King, the headmistress of a progressive school called Eastwind. Anna, who is a friend of theirs, had a secret affair with Dan Zimmmern 15 years previously. (She greatly insulted her lover by others in their moods, until, at a climactic party scene, the Hubbards and the Zimmeras, badly intoxicated, find themselves fighting one another  very much like children. The novel's real children, Mary Ann and Lolly, are witnesses and are appalled. choosing a job over him, and his pride has never quite forgiven her.) The Hubbards bring along their ugly duckling daughter Mary Ann, and the Zimmeras bring along Lennie, Dan's son from his first marriage (a sullen, troubled boy who asks mockingly to be excused for living), and their dreamy 9yearold Lolly, who is Mary Ann's friend at Eastwind. As the weekend progresses, Honey and Dan, involved in a crude flirtation, become more and more childish, involving the others in their moods, until, at a climactic party scene, the Hubbards and the Zimmeras, badly intoxicated, find themselves fighting one another  very much like children. The novel's real children, Mary Ann and Lolly, are witnesses and are appalled.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Peggy Anderson is the daughter of nurse. As a result, she said, she had always been irritated by the way nurses were portrayed in.books, movies and on television: They were either cruel, like Nurse Retched in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, or silly, like the nurses in M*A*S*H. They were never taken seriously.

title: State Acts to Curb Violence in Schools
description: DR. FRED G. BURKE, the state's Commissioner of Education, took the first step last week in what he hopes will be a twoyear program to reduce vandalism and violence in the schools, a problem that has been taking an increasingly heavy toll in lives and property.

title: A Prophet's Catalogue
description: Now 83, greatly accomplished and greatly honored, Lewis Mumtord has several times over earned the right to a major retrospective. My Works and

title: Pension Funds Found to Shortchange Themselves
description: Most New York City municipal employees who retire do not receive their full pension benefits for periods of from three months to nearly two years, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin reported yesterday.

title: To Prime The Pump, Decontrol
description: MIDLAND, Texas  Forget, for the moment, about Exxon. When it comes to finding new supplies of domestic oil and natural gas, the key man is Dick Gaddy. He and thousands of other small, independent oilandgas producers like him are responsible for an estimated 70 to 80 percent of aU wells drilled in the United States.

title: Claudia Oppenheim Wed To Dr. Duke Cameron
description: Claudia Oppenheim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Oppenheim of Barrington, R.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Duke Cameron, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Cameron of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Judge Donald Shea of the Rhode Island Superior Court performed the ceremony at Blithewold, historical mansion in Bristol, R.I.

title: The Special Touch Of Nonesuch
description: Nonesuch Records celebrates its 15th anniversary this year, quietly and without fanfare  unless one takes into account a batch of new disks that hew closely to the high standards this label has assiduously cultivoted over the years. Officially the classical record division of a large corporate structure, Warner Communications, Nonesuch has nonetheless always been run with the kind of personal touch that creates a flavor of autonomy and generates quality. Warner's enlightened hands off policy has no doubt helped encourage this salutary effect, for it means that Teresa Sterne, who has guided Nonesuch's fortunes for most of its 15 years, can more or less do things her way.

title: Urban Neglect
description: CHESTER, Pa.  Even in this cockpit of urbanindustrial decay, boxed in by Interstate 95, the evilsmelling Delaware River.

title: Dispute Lingers on Cemetery for Jonestown Bodies
description: SAN FRANCISCO. April 21  Controversy continues to follow members of the People's Temple, even to the grave.

title: Africa: Abidjan To Bouak
description: From a jet cruising at 35,000 feet over the undulating expanse of a great jungle, the cover looks se dense that I imagine I am looldng down on an endless field of tightly packed brussels sprouts. But one pleasant July morning with the temperature in the 80's, I was down there among the brussels sprouts, riding a remarkably smooth gazelle through the rain forest of the Ivory Coast and I discovered to my surprise that our swath through the jungle was wide and sunny.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 21 (AP) Championship Auto Racing Teams today gave an earlyevening Monday deadline to officials of.the Indianapolis Motor Speedway to clarify their position on 19 entries from six CART members for this year's running of the Indianapolis 500.

title: Opera: Manon Makes Return To City Troupe After 2 Seasons
description: Although New York has seen revivals of many longdormant Massenet operas over the last few years, Manon still gives every indication of remaining the French composer's most popular and durable stage work. Like all of his operas. though. Manon requires a delicate and sympathetic touch if it is to reveal all its charms, and the City Opera's production, which made a welcome return to the repertory Friday night after an absence of two seasons, has been admired for precisely these qualities ever since the work was first mounted for Beverly Sills in 1968.

title: Bible Colleges Go Forth and Multiply
description: IF you take a walk around Liberty Baptist College here, according to the campus wisdom, you are bound to get either snow, mud or dust on your shoes. There is construetion everywhere, with students living in old hotels, riding rickety buses, while waiting for the dormitories of the future. But at least there is a future. In a time of economic trouble for some of America's private colleges, a few religiousbased colleges are experiencing a boom.

title: Miss Bodell Has Nuptials
description: Adelaide Morton Bodell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Cozzens Bodell of Providence, R.I., and Wianno, Mass., was married yesterday to Peter Stuart Milhaupt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Joseph Milhaupt of Swoope, Va., and Grenada. The Rev. Livingston T. Merchant Jr. performed the ceremony in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Providence.

title: INTERVIEW
description: MOORESTOWN FOR David F. Norcross, chairman of the Republican State Committee, the baseball season holds some unpleasant parallels. Mr. Norcross, the only state G.O.P. chairman to start a year with both United States Senate seats held by Democrats, could be likened to the hero of Casey at the Bat': After successive losses in the gubernatorial and Senate elections, he has two strikes on him.

title: Spring Puts Great Swamp Into Focus
description: MORRISTOWN THE skunk cabbage has been up for a month, the pussy willows are out and coltsfoot, a dandelion lookalike, is blooming. Spring has come to the Great Swamp.

title: Rutgers Relays Draw a Protest; Villanova Captures 4 of 8 Races
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., April 21  As expected, Villanova dominated the Rutgers Relays today, winning four of the eight championship races.

title: Fallout Inquiry Moves
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 21 (AP) Congressional delegation on Monday is moving its investigation of nuclear testing to Las Vegas, which may have escaped fallout in the 1950's at the expense of Utah and Arizona communities. The hearing on possible compensation for those contaminated by openair tests follows one day of testimony here Thursday by a ninemember joint Congressional committee.

title: Dominion's Merger Timetable: Pay Dirt in 2 Years
description: HANOVER, N.H.  Ten years ago the Dominion Bridge Company, dowager of the Canadian steel industry, was earning only $4 million on sales of $168 million. An internal memo suggested that the company would be worth more dead than alive. It was time, clearly, to go back to the drawing board.

title: The Law Enforcement Intelligence Unit Keeps a Watchful Eye
description: WASHINGTON  The Law Enforcement Intelligence Unit is a fraternity of intelligence officers from 225 state and local police departments that gathers and exchanges information. It is a sizable organization, founded more than two decades ago. Part of its financing came from the Federal Government, and it now operates with state and local funds. Nevertheless, the unit is rarely mentioned in the piess and is unknown to most citizens.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Sunnyfield, Route 172, Bedford. N.Y. Local, novice, junior and children's working hunters; ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Basque Language Status Raised
description: MADRID, April 21 (Reuters)  The Basque language will be taught officially in the Basque country for the first time since the civil war of 193639 under a decree approved yesterday.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: SoonHee Lee, a Korean soprano and Juilliard School graduate whose former teachers include Jennie Tourel and Rose Hampton, presented a song program at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday afternoon. It was a program that testified at every turn to her good schooling and good taste, but whose success was undercut by vocal problems. A Vivaldi motet at the start seemed to lie too high for the soprano's comfort, although now and then she could produce a shining tone or even a series of such pleasing sounds. Unreliable intonation and occasional breathlessness made for difficult listening in a Liszt group and two Schubert songs, and it was not until the arrival of Schubert's Der Hirt auf dem Felsen, just. before intermission, that the recitalist began to locate the pitch with enough consistency to let one enjoy the music.

title: 3 Ways to Science Literacy
description: SCIENCE TEACHERS and other educators have generally advocated three basic approaches to the problem of promoting scientific literacy among nonscientists:

title: Bar Unit Assails Police In Philadelphia Killings
description: PHILADELPHIA April 21 (AP)Some 299 persons PHILADELPHIA, been killed illegally by Philadelphia police officers over the last nine years, according to a survey by a lawyers group.

title: Waldheim's Asia Itinerary Is Raising Some Hopes
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. April 20 Invitations to Secretary General Kurt Waldheim to visit North and South Korea along with Vietnam and China during a 10nation Asian tour beginning next week suggest to some diplomats here that these countries are willing at least to go through the motions of accepting outside mediation efforts in their disputes.

title: In Defense of the Television DocuDrama
description: In recent years, television dramas based on real people and actual events  such programs as Roots and The Ordeal of Patty Hearst, this evening's Friendly Fire (on ABC at 8) and next month's Ike, A Man Called Intrepid and Blind Ambition  have become an increasingly prominent and important part of network programming. They have also become the subject of an increasingly passionate debate between television writers and producers on the one hand and television critics on the other. The passion arises because writers and producers, or sonic of them, are accused of distorting history, of advancing their own prejudices and conceptions in reckless disregard of the facts, of inventing or rearranging characters and events and passing them off as truth. The charges usually carry one or both of the following criticisms: Thette programs are misleading the public and/or are damaging the reputations of people who cannot easily defend themselves.

title: Collecting
description: Silver is one of the noble metals. It has filled our treasure chests, our hope chests, our corner cupboards and our teeth. It fuels our legends, our metaphors, our G.N.P. In return, we anneal it, chase it, embellish it, polish it and admire it. Like the English diarist Samuel Pepys, we are inclined to show it off. After giving a dinner party in LonInventiveness and craftsmanship are the hallmarks of a new exhibition reflecting 400 years of the uses of silver in America. don in 1664, Pepys noted that his guests eyed mightily my great cupboard of plate, I this day putting my two flaggons upon my table; and indeed it is a fine sight, and better than ever I did hope to see my owne. The many ways we use silver will be demonstrated by Silver in American Life, a touring exhibition exploring the role of silver in four centuries of American history. More than 200 pieces, drawn from the Mabel Brady Garvan Collection and others at Yale University, and ranging from a 1600's dram cup and tankard through sleek 20century designs in jewelry and tableware, are included. The Yale collection consists of some 1,200 pieces of American silver; it is considered one of the finest and most comprehensive teaching collections in the country. Francis P. Garvan, a member of the Yale class of 1897, and his wife amassed more than 10,000 objects during their lives as collectors; they made their gift to Yale in 1930. The exhibition, which was jointly organized by Yale and the American Federation of Arts, opens April28 at the Museum of Art at the Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh. It will remain there through June 17 and then begin a threeyear tour toll cities.

title: IRANIAN WOMEN: LOOKING BEYOND THE CHADOR
description: One fine Monday morning this spring, a woman with seven children went down to a street gutter in south Teheran to do her family's wash. Balanced on her head was a plastic basket

title: Deaths
description: ANDERSONAugusta, in her 9th year, at Navesink House, 40 Riverside Ave., Red Bank, N.J., There will be a service in her memory at Navesink House on Monday, April 23. at 2 PM. She was the widow of James W. Anderson and Is survived by a son. James; and a daughter, Jean Kennison; six grandchildren; and six great grandchildren.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: TV VIEW
description: The Vietnam war is coming back into the living roomwith a difference. Nightly reports from the battlefields of the past have been replaced by increasingly frequent essays and dramas exploring the meaning of it all, then andnow, for the dead and for the living, for those who served and for those who stayed home, either supporting the war effort or protesting it. Tonight's Friendly Fire, an ABC television movie being given three hours of prime time, from 8 to 11, is only one of the more prominent examples.

title: APARTMENT DISPUTE IS STILL UNRESOLVED
description: Talks aimed at averting a strike by 20,000 New York City apartment building employees were recessed again yesterday with no substantive progress reported.

title: On Stage With Nureyev At Age Eight
description: On Tuesday, Feb. 27, at 9:15 A.M., the telephone rings: Do you think Meredith would like to be super in Petrouchka with Rudolf Nureyev and the Joffrey Ballet?

title: School Boards: No Place for Butterflies
description: WHILE Long Island school boards wrestle with financial and educational problems, and voters go to the polls, to decide on annual budgets, another phenomenon occurs  the election or reelection of school board members. Here are some musings from one who ran and got elected to one South Shore board, and has been involved in the school board campainns of others

title: For the Deaf, the Language Gap Is Unbridgeable
description: ALL children begin their education at birth. For the child born into a hearing home, as most are, however, there is profound difference. Hearing children are immersed in their language from the moment of birth. Without special training, they come to understand it within months and to speak it within year or so.

title: British and U.S. Politics More Than Oceans Apart
description: BIRMINGHAM, EnglandThey all ask the same question: How do our campaigns compare with yours? It's question that an Anglophile American correspondent has also asked himself in the midst of a British general election and from the perspective of having covered and occasionally understood four campaigns for the Presidency.

title: Guest Observer
description: I had Alfie killed not long ago. Put to sleep is the comforting term, of course, but you can't pet a euphemism. Nor did our veterinarian mince words, though he was gentle when he told us that the tumor he'd removed from Alfie's jaw augured incurable cancer and even worse misery than our goodnatured dog had been enduring  six tooth extractions for which I kept apologizing to him, and gum massages that sent us cringing into separate corners. But maybe I'm wrong, the vet said. Let's wait for the lab report.

title: Marriage Announcement 6 -- No Title
description: Judith Humber Sets May Bridal

title: U.S. Swimmers Dominate West Germans
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 21 (AP)  Jesse Vassallo and Cynthia Woodhead each won two individual events today, leading the United States team to a 11153 advantage over West Germany at an international swimming meet.

title: 10 Dead and 55 Injured In Iran Political Attacks
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 21 (AP) Political violence in southern and northwestern Iran killed at least 10 persons and wounded 55 in the last two days, official radio reports said today.

title: A Paul Taylor Dancer Explains
description: Paul Taylor surprises people with his choreography and he has been doing so for more than 20 years. He has surprised people with dances that are so odd that some commentators have been tempted to call him a Dadaist. But just when one starts expecting prankishness from him as matter of course, he may surprise audiences with dances possessing an almost classical elegance. And although his works are usually genial, he can turn surprisingly, even shockingly, savage.

title: Long, 23, Charters an America's Cup Sloop
description: Just like any other boats, they are being fitted out this spring with a fresh coat of paint, a new sail or two, and in one case a new deck. Although the America's Cup competition is a summer away, the season for fitting out never seems to end for 12Meter Yachts.

title: SPORTS
description: WEST HAVEN

title: Deborah R. Brown Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bailey Warren Brown have announced the engagement of Mr. Brown s daughter, Deborah Robbins Brown, to Peter Michael Procino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Procino. Both families live in BranxviIle. N.Y. Miss Brown is the daughter also of the late Barbara Worth Brown. A June 17 wedding is planned.

title: ON THE ISLE'
description: Tired of boasting about the big one that got away? Maybe the flyfishing clinic slated for Heckscher State Park today is for you. Using lectures, demonstrations and films, a string of experts will lead anglers through the mysteries of fresh and salt walt&r fishing and casting. The free clinic runs from 10 A.M. to 4 F.M. at Parking Field Three at the East Islip park. 6691000, Ext. 247.

title: Use of House by Disabled Group Stirs an Affluent L.I. Community
description: KINGS POINT, L.I.  When Ira Cavrell of this affluent suburb decided last month to sell his large frame house near corner of Station Road and East. Shore Drive to a Ibcal organization that was establishing a residence for 12 mentally disabled young people, he realized that not everyone would applaud his decision.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The role of banks in financing contested tender offers has come under scrutiny recently in some major acquisition attempts, among them Brascan Ltd.'s bid, financed by the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, for F. W. Woolworth & Company; the American Express Company's unsuccessful offer for McGrawHill Inc., financed by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, and Talley Industries's attempted purchase of the Washington Steel Corporation, using a loan from the Chemical Bank.

title: Marriage Announcement 3 -- No Title
description: Kimberley Allmon Is Betrothed

title: Milton Bradley Strike Ends
description: EAST LONGMEADOW, Mass., April 21 (AP)  Union members have voted to end a strike that has idled 1,900 workers at the Milton Bradley Company since April 1. The threeyear contract with the games company approved yesterday in creased the average hourly wage by 50 cents the first year, 90 cents the second and 95 cents the third. Under the old contract the average hourly wage was $4.40, said Richard Manegre, president of Local 229 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Workers Union.

title: Dance: Taylor Period and Kingdom
description: By reviving Piece Period and Cloven Kingdom on Friday night at the City Center55th Street Theater, the Paul Taylor Dance Company demonstrated that Mr. Taylor is one of our funniest choreographers. He's funny in ceveral ways.

title: Home Is Where The Teacher Is
description: ERIK SESSIONS never went to school to learn how to read. He did not learn math there either. Or history. Or science. In fact, Erik, who is 8 years old, has never gone to School to learn anything.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today  New York Region Sports Car Club of America lecture on introduction to road racing. at The Magic Pan Creperie, Northern Boulevard off Shelter Rock Road, Manhasset. L.I. All interested welcome.

title: Learning About China Is Becoming a Living Reality
description: THE China syndrome has hit American education, and postnormalization trips to the Far East never had it so good. Although trips to Israel, the Continent, Mexico and the Soviet Union were once de rigueur for eager students, under the premise that travel is broadening, the new friendliness between the United States and China has inspired scores of student visits from all social, economic and educational classes of American society. The new interest is now stretching into the elementary schools.

title: The Untutored Public
description: SOMETHING went badly wrong last month at the nuclear electricitygenerating plant at Three Mile Island near Harrisburg, Pa. No one was injured or killed, but before technicians brought the malfunctioning reactor under control, central Pennsylvania had suffered severe economic loss, and millions of Americans had begun to wonder who, if anyone, was to be trusted in the debate over the safety of nuclear energy.

title: The Numbers in Last Week's Rhodesian Election Were Impressive
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia  When he was British Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec DouglasHome called Prime Minister Ian D. Smith the world's best politician and worst statesman. As black and white Rhodesians went to the polls in impressive numbers last week to elect the country's first blackled Government the assessment looked as sage as ever, for the vote count of better than 60 percent was hardly in when Mr. Smith began edging toward a step  his continued presence in the Government  that could well undo much of the good the election has done the country's reputation.

title: DINING OUT
description: I HAVE never had less than a very good meal at La Crmaillre, sometimes a memorable one, but, curiously, never an extraordinary one. Service is impeccable; the captains orches- trate dinners with a professionalism all too rare these days, and the owners, Messrs. Meyzen, pre et fils, are tireless in maintaining control.

title: Disco Is Not Just for Dancing
description: Despite the stupendous publicity disco has received as commercial and sociocultural phenomenon, the actual music has been paid remarkably little critical attention. This is not so surprising inasmuch as disco music actively discourages critical scrutiny. When people are swept up and away by the beat, Sister Sledge sings in Lost in Music, the first [thing] to go is their mind. Analyze disco? You're supposed to get up and dance to it, dummy!

title: Performances Routine in Iona Relays
description: The weather was good, the track was new and the competitors were plentiful. But the performances in yesterday's 25th annual Iona College Relays at Downing Stadium were mostly routine.

title: Consumer, Resigned to Inflation, Is Learning New Ways to Hedge
description: Robert and Nancy T., a working couple in Washington, D.C., have two children in college and another who will soon be going. With inflation doing its work on tuitions, the family is feeling a bit pinched. Happily, inflation has also done its work on real estate: The family can take a bigger mortgage and pay for college with cash from the appreciation of their Cleveland Park home. They do not like the idea, but it is no longer unthinkable.

title: A Counterbalance in Jobs
description: According to the New York Region Econometric Model, the overall outlook for the region is promising because the strength of the suburbs is counterbalancing the virtual lack of growth projected for New York City.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR  Group exhibition of allmedia paintings, fabric hangings, soft sculpture mobiles, ceramics; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Mondays through Saturdays; through May; Gilliewrinkles, 28 Main St. Reception 2 toy P.M. today.

title: Soviet Presses Visiting U.S. Legislators on Arms Pact
description: MOSCOW, April 21  While the Carter Administration and its supporters have been trying to sell the nearly completed strategic arms limitation treaty to the Senate, the Russians have been busily trying to do the same to 18 visiting members of the House of Representatives.

title: Wines: How to Be a Savvy Shopper
description: WINE drinkers need all the help they can get these days. The prices of French wines are skyrocketing; unfamiliar California bottles are going for $12; Italian wines arrive in dizzying profusion, and the wines of South America have problems of consistency. What is a good buy? What is foolhardiness? Will the French back down? Do some stores have better prices than others?

title: ...But the Future of Britain's Comprehensives Is in Debate
description: LONDON

title: In a Crystal Ball, Steady Growth Through the 80's
description: PUGGING 1,400 statistical variables into a framework of 1,500 complex equations, a recent economic study has come p with a relatively bright outlook for the economies of Westchester and the other northern suburbs of New York City.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTOHESTER EDITOR
description: Michael Maiden's attack on the Teacher Dismissal Law [A License Not to Teach March 11] reveals a prejudice destructive to the public's understanding of tenure.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Padres 9, Braves 5
description: ATLANTA, April 21 (AP)  Dave Winfield singled home the tiebreaking run in a fourrun eighth tonight that led tbe San Diego Padres to a 95 victory over the ??? ???

title: Treaty Impact
description: An American negotiator took issue last week with a Congressional Budget Office assessment of the Geneva trade liberalization pact, which portrayed importsensitive industries as losers under the agreement and warned that urban areas in the North and East would be hit by layoffs.

title: Sohio Terminal Is Approved
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 21 (AP)A local environmental agency approved plans yesterday for a 1500 million oil tanker terminal under an arrangement by which the oil company will pay to help clean up emissions from a nearby tower plant it does not own. The intent is to keep the general level of pollution in the area down while allowing construction of the terminal for oil from Alaska. Permission for the terminal was granted to the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) by the South Gee Air Quality Management District.

title: Jane Kestenbaum Is Wed To S.P. Johnson, Student
description: Jane Kestenbaum and Stewart P. Johnson were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's grandmother, Mrs. Thomas M. Johnson of the Isle of Hope, Savannah, Ga. The bridegroom's uncle, the Rev. Harcourt E. Wallace Jr., an Episcopal priest of the Diocese of North Campina, performed the ceremony.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Home at the range. Victorian women in America suffered in shame from all manner of female complaints too intimate to name. Many of them were the fault of men (gonorrhea) or men doctors (prolapsed uterus), and women shrewdly kept shy of the ineffectual and often positively harmful doctors of their day. Instead, they doctored themselves with socalled patent medicines. The most famous of these was Lydia Pinkham's Vegetable Compound. Mrs. Pinkham actually existed. in Lynn, Mass., a center of the progressive spirit, hotbed of abolition and feminism.

title: Donna Storm to Be Wed July 14
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ream Storm of San Antonio have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Sue Storm, to Kenneth Thomson Barrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Davies Barrow of Greenwich. Conn.

title: Ann Bennett, a Lawyer, Wed to Charles Krueger
description: The Touro Synagogue in New Orleans was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Ann Bennett and Charles Z. Krueger. Rabbi David Goldstein performed the ceremony.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: To be able to see Grand Illusion without commercial interruptions is a treat. Although the English dubbing in this uncut print of the 1937 masterpiece directed by Jean Renoir tends to diminish the original trilingual scope of the film, the incandescence of the acting of Erich von Stroheim, Jean Gabin, Pierre Fresnay, Marcel Dalio and a superb supporting cast is not dimmed. The Wilton Library has a free screening at 2 P.M. today. The film is set largely in a German prison camp for officers during World War I, and its revelations of the ancient lovehate relationships of Western Europeans are as intriguing now as they were then. Phone 7623950.

title: Soviet Six Wins By 111
description: MOSCOW, April 21  The Soviet Union virtually assured itself of the world hockey championship tonight by routing Czechoslovakia, 111. The Russians, the defending titleholders, now have a 3point lead with three games to play.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: The Wages of Smoking... Trinity BellsPosh transport for sick pets in Fairfield; Trinity College's bells to ring out next Sunday; and Stewart B. McKinney received more help than he needed to stop smoking.

title: U.S. Park Service Offers Campers Reserved Sites
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  The National Park Service has announced that it will accept reservations for summer campsites at five locations that cari be reached by automobile.

title: A. I. duPont, Jill Greenwood Set June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald E. Greenwood of HastingsonHudson, N.Y., and Chilmark, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Greenwood, to Augustus Irne duPont, son of Rosamond Lee duPont of Lander, berg, Pa., and Francis I. duPont of Chadds Ford, Pa.

title: Cubs 4, Expos 3
description: CHICAGO, April 21 (UPI)  Ivan DeJesus capped a threerun sixthinning rally with a single that snapped a 33 tie today and propelled the Chicago Cubs to a 43 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: Pentagon Finds 3 Services Falter In Drives for Recruiting Women
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  Three of the four armed services fell short of their goals in enlisting women over the last six months.

title: POLITICS
description: THE structure of political protest is as established as a sonnet's. The demonstrators sing and carry signs. The police warn them about where they may and may not stand, and those who disobey they arrest. Eventually there are bail hearings, court arguments and sometimes short sentences. When it is all over everybody goes home. While the content and emphasis may differ, both sides have seen similar events before, and know what to expect.

title: Injuries Fail to Stop Motorcycling star
description: It is almost miraculous that 27yearold Kenny Roberts of Modesto, Calif., America's other world motorsports champion during 1978, will be able to compete in next Sunday's Grand Prix of Austria motorcycle race.

title: HighRisk Births: Help Is Far Away
description: WHEN Sean Harrington was five days old, he was kicking off his hospital blankets, an active, healthy baby. Seeing Sean in the nursery at United Hospital in Port Chester didn't hint of possible risks involved with his birth. His mother, Patricia, delivered him by emergency Caesarean section. After the birth, doctors discovered that Sean had a heart murmur. A specialist was called in from New York City and determined that it was not serious.

title: A Closer Look At Ocean Pollution
description: IN the three years since the massive summer fish kills along the New Jersey coast and the discovery of a 3,000squaremile dead sea offshore, water conditions in the New York Bight have not improved. In fact, they are the same as they were a decade ago, according to marine scientists and environmentalists.

title: More Funds Sought For OilSpill Work
description: THAT old clich about pouring oil on troubled waters has a new twist that anyone worried about huge oil spills off the coast should appreciate. The twist goes like this: What about troubled waters poured on oil?

title: Judith Gale Kaplan Is Married
description: Judith Gale Kaplan and Ronald Paul April were married yesterday at the Tumblebrook Country Club in Bloomfield, Conn., by Rabbi Allen Press of Haverhill, Mass. The bride is president of the Associated Woolen Corporation in Manchester, Conn., and owner of a subsidiary, Mostly Jeans, a retail shop in Newburyport, Mass. Mr. April is president and owner of the Letchmere Lithograph Printing Company in Rowley, Mass. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour B. Kaplan of Manchester. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustave April of Amesbury, Mass. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Fire in Mailbox Upsets Taxpayers in San Jose
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 21 (AP) Some San Jose taxpayers are going to have to calculate their income tax returns a second time.

title: What's Doing in HOUSTON
description: VITALITY  Houston is a young city, verdant and steamy, surrounded and bisected by overflowing freeways and bursting at the seams with commerce and construction. The wellspring of much of the city's economic vitality is the oil and gas industry, and many of the sleek new buildings that define the downtown area are a reflection of the giants of the industry Exxon, Shell, Tenneco and others.

title: Explosive Found in School Labs
description: BATON ROUGE, La., April 21 (AP) Picric acid has been found in 20 Louisiana schools and the state police are checking other school laboratories for the chemical explosive used in World War II bombs and hand grenades, the authorities said. The state police said supplies of picric acid, most of it unused for years, had been found in chemistry laboratories at 18 high schools and two colleges.

title: Twins 6, Mariners 5
description: Bloomington, Minn., April 21 (AP)  Roy Smalley drove in three runs with a single and a homer, and Mike Marshall recorded his fourth save as the Minnesota Twins beat the Seattle Mariners today, 65.

title: CALENDAR
description: Today. The Connecticut Spring Antiques Show. State Armory, Broad Street, Hartford. Take capital area exit from I91. 1 P.M. to 8 P.M. More than 100 exhibits of 18th and early 19thcentury American furniture and accessories.

title: Every Prologue Has Its Epilogue
description: WHAT do I tell him? asked my friend, whose 7-year-old son was not represented in the school magazine. He's been writing for three years, and I've always told him that his stories were good.

title: Science Is Holding Its Own in the Colleges
description: COLLEGES and universities report that, despite problems at the elementary and secondary levels, the flow of able science majors has continued, and they should have no serious trouble meeting the nation's needs for professional scientists in the years to come.

title: Beyond the New Math
description: BECKI PARRIS punched several at the Sewanhaka High School in Floral Park, Queens, and stared curiously Into the lighted screen. How many questions would you like to try, Becta? the computer printed out. Delighted at the machine's response, the highschool junior spent the next halfhour working through a drill and practice session on algebraic equations.

title: Wit and Whimsy in a Box
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: Tovah, That Latin From Scarsdale
description: TOVAH FELDSHUH, who plays Dona Flor in the current Broadway musical, Sarava, hurries into the restaurant looking radiant in a lowcut green dress and orders a pot of Sanka. She is still a little out of breath after rushing from Grand Central station and the 11:42 from Westchester to prepare for the night's show.

title: Lisa Bancala Sets Bridal on June 23
description: Mr. and Mrs. Aldo Bancala of Potomac, Md., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Bancala, to Christian T. Steinway, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Steinway of New York and Amherst, Mass. A June 23 wedding is planned.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BRIDGEPORT  Helene Brier, Beach People, oils and watercolors, Monday through Thursday 9 to 9, Housatonic Community College, 510 Barnum Ave. 5796400.

title: Warming Up To the Challenge Of Exercise Trails
description: Like giant game boards, exercise trails are zigzagging across America. Guided by the contours of the land, they thread their paths through shaded forest, open meadow, grassy slopes and wooded parks, emerging as the latest route to physical fitness.

title: Opening for Talpo Project Is Still Uncertain
description: The opening of the Taino Touters Fed. eral housing and community project in East Harlem, already delayed for more than three years, has been put off for several more months, and possibly indefinitely, because of what a Federal official said were many unanswered questions about the cost and method of operating it.

title: JAIL TERMS HARSHER UNDER NEW LAWS
description: Prison sentences rose sharply for the first group of persons convicted of felo. nies in New York State under new laws that restrict plea bargaining and that re. quire mandatory terms, according to a state report.

title: Rangers Curb Their Optimism
description: The Rangers have proved themselves a better team than the Philadelphia Flyers in the first three games of their National Hockey League quarterfinal playoff. They. have outscored Philadelphia, 12 goals to 2, in their last two victories and dominated the first contest, even though they lost in overtime.

title: She Wants to Change TV's Image of Blacks
description: I want to do something important in television that will make a difference, a change for black people. I want to expose parts of our multifaceted character that go beyond Dynomite!

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Only four of the roughly 3,000 big bands that toured the country in the mid1930's have continued to present live concerts. One of these  there are a few new faces, of course  is the Lionel Hampton band.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: SLATE and flagstone have been widely used by homeowners for many years as paving materials or floor coverings. They have been used indoors in kitchens, bathrooms, laundry rooms and dens or playrooms, and outdoors for patios and walks where a more decorative surface than ordinary concrete can offer is desired.

title: Julia Rhyne Mullen Is the Bride of Lewis Justice Hart Jr.
description: Julia Rhyne Mullen, daughter of Mrs. William Mauney Herndon of Kings Mountain, N.C., and Henry Spears Mullen of Santa Barbara, Calif., was married in Gastonia, N.C., yesterday to Lewis Justice Hart Jr., son of Mrs. Hart of Rosemont, Pa., and the late Mr. Hart. The Rev. Wilson West Sneed performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: Deaths
description: SABESONRose. Devoted mother of Vivian Jerome and Marvin. Dear sister of Philip, Samuel, and Her, man Bernstein. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Services today 1 PM at Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Gt. Neck. N.Y. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made In her memo ry to one's favorite Charity.

title: California Windmills Planned To Supply Power to 1,000 People
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 (AP) private company plans to build 20 windmills in a gusty California valley, supplying enough power for 1,000 people and saving 175,000 barrels of oil year.

title: Two Westerns
description: F there was ever a social victim, writes Eleanor Perry. It's a woman screenwriter. Holly

title: A Decline in Achievement
description: DESPITE television and radio weathermen and all the talk about the weather, barely two of every five of the nation's 17yearold students know what a relative humidity of percent means. And the situation seems to be getting worse rather than better.

title: ANTIQUES PreHefner Hutches at Southport Show
description: WESTPORT HENRY David Thoreau noted in his tramps in Maine in 1849 what he later described as a prevailing fashion in order to economize In room. Writing about the chairndtble combination that collectors today calla hutchtable, he said: The ditlhes were put on the table, late the armchair against the wall, from which one of the party was expelled. The arms of the chair formed the frame on which the table rested; then when the round top was turned up against the wall, it formed the back of the chair, and was no more in the way than the wall itself.

title: A Peking Letter Writer Worries About Culture
description: PEKING, April 21 (AP)  Dancing can have a bad effect on work habits, according to a letter to the editor published this week in The People's Daily.

title: Maryland A.C.C. Winner
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., April 21 (AP)  Renaldo Nehemiah captured the 100meter and 200meter dashes and anchored Maryland's victorious 400meter relay team as the Terps won their 25th team title at the Atlantic Coast Conference track and field championships today.

title: Orioles Set Back Brewers, 42
description: BALTIMORE, April 21 (AP)  Lee May. cracked a pair of twonun homers, the first following a Milwaukee error ()mills foul pop, to lead the Baltimore Orioles to a 42 victory over the Brwers today.

title: Where Troubled Boys Learn How to Learn
description: TOMMY was a bright 13yearold in one of the most soughtafter school systems in suburban Boston, but he had a violent temper, trouble with his peers as early as second grade, and a record of truancy. His parents had separated when he was an baby, and as he grew into adolescence his mother was less able to handle his temper and truancy.

title: How Giant Shiseido Bit the Bullet
description: In a move not intended to save face, Shiseido, a major Japanese toiletries and cosmetics company, announced in 1976 that it was cutting the number of department stores it serviced in America. In a year's time, it pared its outlets from 750 to fewer than 170, destroyed merchandise and absorbed about $2 million in losses, amid industry rumors that the company was packing up and retreating to Japan.

title: Health SETTING THEIR LIVES IN MOTION
description: Blythedale Hospital challenges and cheers handicapped children on their way to independence.Andy shakes his arms to loosen his shoulder muscles as he surveys the slalom course for the third time. He has watched the others make the run; now It is his turn. His team badly needs the five points he will earn if he wins. He moves purposefully to the starting line.

title: CarterBrezhnev Meeting Likely To Wrap Up SALT
description: The corner that a new SALT agreement had been Just around for several months was finally reached last week. Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin cleared most obstacles to completion of the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty, including the question of modifying existing missiles, and then turned to the details of a windup session between president Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: Mrs. Carner Tied for Lead
description: ORLANDO, Fla., April 21 (AP) JoAnne Carner posted a recordtying string of birdies and shot a sixunderpar 67 today to tie Debbie Meisterlin for the thirdround lead in the $100,000 Lady Citrus Golf Classic.

title: Meadowlands Gets Hospital for Horses
description: MILLIONS of television viewers watched as Ruffian, dragging her broken right forefoot, was loaded into a horse ambulance. Unbeaten in 10

title: The Merit System: Injecting a Virus Into a Sick Body
description: IT HAS been a month since college teachers in the state held a oneday job action, with the strike ending as quickly as it was called.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The paradox of Homosexuality in Perspective, the latest Masters and Johnson book, is that its scientific, nonjudgmental restraint may do more to win tolerance for homosexuals than the demonstrations and polemics of Gay Rights activists. But the actual findings of the book, to be published this week by Little, Brown and Company, are unlikely to be universally acceptedat least not yet  as the final word on the nature of homosexuality.

title: What They're Saying
description: Allen LaCombe, a publicity man for the Fair Grounds Race Track in New Orleans: If the crowds don't want to come, you can't stop em.

title: Jeffrey Eliot Tabak Is Fianc Of Marilyn Andrea Dickman
