description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin L. Dickman of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marilyn Andrea Dickman, to Jeffrey Eliot Tabak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Tabak of Edison, N.J.

title: A Museum in Rio Recalls Days of Carmen Miranda.
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 21 Paris has the Louvre, Madrid the Prado, Florence. the Uffizi, but only Rio de Janeiro, the city that moves at a carnival cadence, has the Carmen Miranda Museum.

title: Grown Free
description: JOY ADAMSON is the woman who coaxed a domesticated lioness name Elsa to give up board and keep in favor of the bush, and then wrote a book about it, Born Free, probably the most popular book to emerge from East Africa in recent years. Soon thereafter, a film and a television series

title: THEATER The Curtain Never Falls
description: NOT long ago, the state of theater in Connecticut was such that you had only to glance at a calendar to know what was going on. If the month was April or May, the regional theaters were still open but approaching the end of their seasons. If the calendar read June, the summer theaters were just about to start up. But those days seem to be gone forever. For example, it is still April, but the Hartman Theater Company in Stamford has already completed its season and closed its doors until next fall. On the other hand, the Long Wharf, which should be winding down, having just opened its next-tolast production of the announced season, has suddenly erupted in a burst of theatrical activity and news.

title: GARDENING
description: PLANTS are amazingly tough and resilient. Some of them come through weather adversities without turning a leaf or dropping a petal. Though the sudden chill and snow flurries two weeks ago on Palm Sunday sent shivers through most of us, the plants took it in stride.

title: Trottier Sings, Skates, Scores
description: He doesn't drink or smoke, said Clark Gillies about Bryan Trottier. But be likes Chinese food, and that's the worst of all.

title: Realty News
description: Farrell Lines Incorporated, the largest privately owned steamship company sailing under the American flag, is doubling its space at One Whitehall Street.

title: John Claghorn 3d To Wed Miss Jump
description: Mrs. Dudley B. Tenney of Sands Point, L.I., and William A. Jump Jr. of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Ellen Jump, to John Winthrop Claghorn 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Claghorn Jr. of Princeton, N.J.

title: Gossage Out 6 to 8 Weeks; Yanks Bow to Rangers, 50
description: The Yankees discovered yesterday that Rich Gossage, their No.1 relief pitcher, suffered a torn ligament in his right thumb in his clubhouse fight with Cliff Johnson and will be lost to the team for six to eight weeks, and perhaps longer. The absence of Gossage could have a devastating effect on the Yankees attempt to win their third straight championship.

title: Even Lincoln Had To Get It Together
description: WHITE PLAINS ALBERT EINSTEIN had difficulty with mathematics as a youngster and Walt Disney was told he had no talent. Abraham Lincoln failed at business, suffered a nervous breakdown after the death of a woman he loved and was defeated in 9 out of 11 elections over the next 24 years.

title: Aiding the Retarded: A New Approach
description: WHEN Jeremy Singer was asked what he felt about a group of mentally retarded children he had just met, the 10-year-old pupil at the W. L. Morse School in Tarrytown simply answered, They're people.

title: Despite Emotional Fallout, Atomic Energy Remains Safest
description: IN all its years of use over much of the world, the nuclear generating of electricity has not caused a single fatality; that is a better safety record than can be claimed even for the windmill. Even before the accident at the nuclear plant on Three Mile Island in Middletown, Pa., an environmentalcrisis mood hung over the industry like a heavy cloud, raising emotional, poorly understood questions that obscure accurate information about the control of radioactive emissions, safe disposal of radioactive wastes and the possible consequences of a nuclear accident.

title: No Business But Show Business
description: IF you believe there Is Iogic to life, then nothing makes more sense than the fact that Roy Rifkind of Bellmore is producing a disco musical on Broadway. Historians may argue, but Mr. Rifkind maintains that it was his father, Harry, who came up with the first discothque, some 35 years ago in Brooklyn.

title: Sparky and Goose
description: Sparky and Goose appear doomed to be connected forever in history; like Damon and Pythias, Ali and Frazier, Laurel and Hardy.

title: Barbara Cynthia Carlin to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hugh F. Carlin of Chatham, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Cynthia Carlin, to Fred M. Kirby 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kirby 2d of Madison, N.J.

title: With Guide, Cook and Horses On the Yellowstone Trail
description: I am too old and rickety for backpacking but too adventurous to see only roadside sites through the window of a camper. The answer is to get a horse. I got one for a week in the Yellowstone National Park back country from an outfitter named Ralph K. Miller in Cooke City, Mont. The horse, a strawberry roan called Lingo, was big (I had to get on the uphill side to mount), one eyed (he lost the other in his youth as a polo pony) and 18 years old. He was also calm, generous, brave and had a terrific sense of humor. When I said goodbye to him at the end of the trip, I gave him a box of his favorite chocolate cookies and cried.

title: Southport, Old vs. New
description: THIS historic harbor village has once again aroused the interest of developers, who envision office buildings and condominiums where there now are open fields and stately homes. But many Southport residents view the quiet village as an endangered species and they are opposing development.

title: ANTIQUES
description: The rediscovery of turnofthecentury American art pottery, under way for more than decade, has gained considerable momentum in the past year. It began last spring with the Delaware Art Museum's splendid exhibition American Art Pottery, 18751930, a show that went much further in its. exploration of ceramics than was possible in the pioneering, widerranging The Arts and Crafts Movement in America, 18761918, assembled by Robert J. Clark at Princeton University's Museum in 1972.

title: Rally Slated Today Supporting Title IX
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  The buses, filled with women athletes and coaches determined to let their voices be heard, will arrive from as far away as Connecticut and Massachusetts for a rally in support of the Federal law banninAsex discrimination in athletics.

title: Ferns: Flowerless,
description: THE rich, green beauty of fern fronds growing in dappled shade has enhanced gardens for many centuries. The beauty of these flowerless plants is more subtle than that of most flowering plants. Native ferns add more grace and distinction to a landscape over a longer period of time than any other herbaceous plant I know.

title: A HEALING HAND IN HARLEM
description: Last spring, on the morning of her 82d birthday. Dr. May Edward Chinn was back in practice. Because of an illness, she had closed her office in 1977, fearing that she was leaving medicine for good. But on April 15, 1978, as a sort of Birthday present to herself, she renewed her personal war against cancer.

title: Energy Department Charges Gouging at the Gas Pump
description: Federal Department of Energy investigators last week served a summons on the operator of a Mobil station on Manhattan's East Side. He was charged with overcharging, collecting an extra 575,000 in gasoline payments from his customers over five years.

title: Displaced Artist
description: THE seismic political events of this century have brought about a remarkable redistribution of the world's cultural wealth, the significance of which we can barely comprehend as yet. We are too

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Aquiet little backwater in the field of exonumia collecting is communion tokens, a specialty that really made news when one of the tokens from the Old Pine Church of Philadelphia

title: Governor and Cabinet in Florida Hear Condemned Killer's Appeal
description: MIAMI, April 21  Gov. Bob Graham of Florida and his Cabinet, sitting as the Executive Clemency Board, yesterday heard appeals by the attorneys for John Spenkelink, a condemned killer.

title: The Judge's Brief
description: NOT everyone who thought the worst about the Watergate gang thought well of Judge John J. Sirice. In his courtroom, it was suggested, the abusers of executive power were subjected to an abuse of Judicial Dower. To Set the Record StraightIs the judge's brief in his defense. It offers a clear view from the bench of the development of the case, beginning with the trial of the breakin team and concluding with the conviction of Richard M. Nixon's closest associates.. Judge Sirica does not pretend to be slow to anger, and his exasperation with the lying, stonewalling and hypocrisy with which the law was confronted often turns explosive: I found the whole thing disgusting. His disgust is easy to understand, and although he may have taken unbecoming glee in making life difficult for the conspirators, this account should get him off with, at worst, a suspended sentence.

title: GRIM LEGACY OF NUCLEAR TESTING
description: They told us we would be the closest human beings outside of Hiroshima to a nuclear blast, Martin Simonis says, recalling the events of a spring morning in 1955. As he and 12 other United States marines were ordered into a narrow trench an atom bomb sat on a steel tower just over a mile away, ready to unleash its fury on the desert floor.the United States Public Health Service (P.H.S.) completed a study in which he found excessive leukemia deaths in two Utah counties close to the Nevada Test Site. While he did not blame the testing for this excess, he noted that all the victims had lived in the area for extensive periods of time, and that he could find no other apparent causative factor. A.E.C. officials attacked the study, objecting that the

title: HOME CLINIC
description: SLATE and flagstone have been widely used by homeowners for many years as paving materials or floor coverings. They have been used indoors in kitchens, bathrooms, laundry rooms and dent or playrooms, and outdoors for patios and walkh where a more decorative surface than ordinary concrete can offer is desired.

title: F.M. Hartman to Wed Kathryn Harrington
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome F. Harrington of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Ann Harrington, to Frederick Mason Hartman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mason Hartman of Needham, Mass.

title: Some Rays of Hope for Budding Einsteins
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J. WHAT does a volcano do? the teacher asks a Mini Scientist class for gifted children. It erupts, 12 children, 5 and 6 years old, shout in a chorus.

title: Suburban Protest
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif. When Robert Presley, a Democratic State Senator from Riverside last month proposed that. the State Department of Health Services study cancer and birth defect rates among his constituents living near the Stringfellow quarry, state health offi- dials agreed it was a good idea. But it would, they said, cost $700,000 that was not available, though the department has been asking for money for just this sort of thing since 1963.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Lyn Sedergren Wed To David Kratovil
description: In the Center Church on the Green (United Church of Christ) in New Haven yesterday afternoon, Lyn Sedergren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erling D. Sedergren of Woodbury, Conn., became the bride of David W. Kratovil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil A. Kratovil of Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Samuel C. Walker.

title: Music: Iolanthe Is Conducted by Albert Bergeret
description: The New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players is a relatively new group operating on the Upper West Side. This season it has moved into Symphony Space, an ugly reconverted theater that nevertheless functions worthily as a nonprofit community auditorium. If somewhat primitive in its staging facilities, it is better than the group's former accommodations, and the new home helped to do justice to its most recent production. This was of lolanthe, which opened Thursday night. It will have two performances today, at 2 and 7.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Homosexual Denied Male Escort Plans to Picket Providence Prom
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 21 (AP) Paul Guilbert, the homosexual high school student who wanted to take a male date to his junior prom, said today that he would picket the affair this year and ask again next year for permission to go with a male date.

title: A Burly Finnish Bass
description: Maybe it's something in my body chemistry, Martti Talvela, the towering Finnish basso, confided recently, but when I do things, I do them with total Intensity. My friends tell me that I live be life of three or four people. It has been rich. In the United States, I am known mainly as an opera singer. However, l have done more than 100 recitals in Europe, and in the next four years I will do 40 more. It is not easy to switch from operatic singing to solo singing, and it takes a special interest in the song repertory to do it. As far as I know, I am the only bass in the world who sings recitals regularly.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: The economy grew at a surprisingly slow rate of seventenths of a percent in the first quarter, the Commerce Department reported last week. At the same time, inflation accelerated, creating a ticklish situation for the nation's economic policy makers.

title: IN THE NATION
description: DALLAS, April 21  The Republi. cans have decided to hold their 1980 national convention in Detroit, prl. marily because chairman Bill Brock hopes to show black voters that the G.O.P. is interested in weaning them away from the Democrats.

title: Virginia Suit Against StripMine Rules Nears End
description: BIG STONE GAP, Va., April 21  Gov. John N. Dalton is to testify Monday in what is expected to be the final day in a trial of the first suit to be brought against the Federal surface mining regulations of 1977.

title: On the Merger Front, Woolworth After Revco, Weyerhaeuser After Bodcaw
description: One major merger move was resolved last week; but two others hung fire:

title: PLAINTIFF PUNISHED FOR MALICIOUS SUIT
description: An investor and his lawyer have been assessed $50,000 in legal costs by a Federal judge who ruled that they had filed malicious lawsuit to publicize unsupported allegations that a financial journal had deliberately misinformed the public about a stock.

title: The Many Women In Koch's Public Life
description: Barbara Laub, the administrator of Gracie Mansion, sat at her desk the other day and smilingly recalled the way Mayor Koch once greeted her after she returned from a twoweek vacation.

title: ART
description: LINCROFT

title: INVESTING
description: Citibank can legally pay only 5 percent interest on daily passbook accounts in New York. But a Citicorp industrial bank in Utah pays 6 percent on daily passboook accounts.

title: Pop: Chubby Checker in Revival
description: Hard as it may be for us geriatrics to believe, it's been nearly 20 years since Chubby Checker popularized the Twist in the lexicon of America's popular social dances. Thereafter he continued to attempt to popularize new dances, although none ever really caught on as the first one bad. And more recently he has been playing the revival circuit.

title: Those Little Frills, Like Intramurals
description: THE other day, I had an interesting conversation with my neighbor Chuck. Chuck is an engineer by profession but, like a lot of other people, he has an instinct for solving some of education's most vexing problems.

title: HOSPICES GIVE HELP FOR DYING PATIENTS
description: NEW RAVEN, April 21  Much of the pain of death could be avoided, Kay Erickson says, if people came to terms with their feelings about it.

title: Cecotto Captures Pole
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, April 21 (AP)  Johnny Cecotto of Venezuela, the world champion, drove a lap of minute 34.5 seconds today to take the pole position for tomorrow's second mind of the 750 c.c. world motorcycle Championship.

title: SIELE OF U.N. FORCE IN LEBANON GOES ON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 21  The Lebanese Christian militia in the south today reversed an agreement to lift a blockade of the headquarters of the United Nations peacekeeping force, apparently angered by a report of the United Nations Secretary General, Kurt Waldheim.

title: Hairfor for Spring: Le Sexpot
description: A whole new look . . . fresh, feminine and ever so sexy . . . and what a look it is! The prettiest, tenderest, most delectable styles seen in over a decade. This Week Only  Let Michel Kazan select a sexpot style for you. Complimentary consultation with your appointment.

title: John Powers to Wed Virginia Lee McCray
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Winn McCray Jr. of Virginia Beach and Richmond of the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Lee McCray, to John McLeod Powers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel McLeod Powers of Jacksonville, Fla.

title: Nottingham Forest Victor In English Soccer by 20
description: LONDON, April 21 (AP)  Nottingham Forest warmed up for Wednesday's European Cup secondleg semifinal against F.C. Cologne of West Germany by defeating Birmingham City, 20, today in an English First Division soccer match.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS
description: Energy, glamour and gambling stocks took turns in leading the stock market last week, while corporations generally issued some eyepopping profits for the opening quarter of 1979. All of this, however, failed to show up in the Dory Jones industrial average, which fell 13.52 points to 856.98.

title: Trottier's Eye Injury Appears to Be Minor
description: CHICAGO April 21  There was no rest for the New York Islanders this morning as Coach Al Arbour put his squad through a hard onehour skate at the Chicago Stadium. But one of his stars  Bryan Trottier  was missing.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: THE MATURING OF WOODY ALLEN
description: The only time Woody Allen rises from his chair is to change the background music in his duplex penthouse living room: He switches records from Mozart to Beethoven, from Beethoven to Schumann. On the coffee table beside him, crowned with fresh spring flowers in perfect esthetic array, bowls of nuts and fruits  arranged with Czannelike care  look almost too good to eat. He doesn't eat. He doesn't peel a banana or nibble an almond. He doesn't smoke and he doesn't drink  not even a glass of water. He hardly even gestures. Not to put too fine a point on it, he hardly even moves.

title: Soviet Will Let Poet Visit the U.S.
description: MOSCOW, April 21  In what could be the first sign of dtente in the war the Soviet authorities have been waging against 23 writers who challenged censorship, the poet Andrei Voznesensky has been granted permission to go to Washington next week for a poetry reading.

title: The Phil and Charlie Story
description: The city of Oakland, Calif., known to some New Workers as Weehawken West, is San Francisco's poor relation across the Bay. A byproduct of the Gold Rush of 1849, it was settled by prospectors and squatters who crowd out the original inhabitants, Costanoan Indians. It has a present population of 330,651 immortal souls, most of them industrious, Godfearing, lawabiding individuals united by a common dislike for baseball.

title: Pinochet Acts to Keep the Junta's Grip on Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  With record high copper prices stimulating the economy and the danger of a border war with Argentina damped by papal mediation, Chilean President Augusto Pinochet Ugarte is preparing to launch an offensive for a new constitution to consolidate his regime.

title: Steelworkers Agree to Halt 12Week Shipyard Strike
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 21 (AP)  The United Steelworkers of America agreed today to suspend a 12week strike at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, a spokesman for the union said.

title: Article 6 -- No Title
description: Mr. Bacco and the third concierge, wno also asked to remain anonymous, declined because they thought it might jeopardize their careers.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: It is just a year ago this spring that Radio City Music Hall was declared an interior landmark by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Co on. It is also the first anniversary of Rockefeller Center, Inc.'s, response with a lawsuit challenging the designation and the landmarks law.

title: Mayer Reaches Net Final
description: HOUSTON, April 21 (UPI)  Gene Mayer continued his surprising surge today by toppling Manuel Orantes, 74, 63, and reaching the final of the $175,000 World Championship Tennis tournament. Jose Higueras will be Mayer's opponent in the final. The Spaniard defused Roscoe Tanner's mighty serve in a 62, 62 triumph on the River Oaks Club clay court.

title: Sarah Milburn Engaged to Stephen Moore
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Milburn of Winchester, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Stafford Milburn, to Stephen Thomson Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen A. Moore, also of Winchester.

title: Token Booth Alarms Expected This Year
description: A silent alarm system linking all token booths in the city's subway system to the transit police should be in operation before the end of this year, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was told yesterday.

title: ANTIQUES
description: RUMSON

title: Secret Service Studying Effects of Stress on Agents
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  The Secret Service, which watches over the wellbeing of the President and his family, is taking its first hard look at the wellbeing of its own agents.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Charles Ryskamp, director of the Morgan Library, has long felt a need for a Michelangelo exhibition in the United States, and after negotiations with the British Museum for an unprecedented loan of 91 drawings by the Renaissance master, is bringing it about. Michelangelo and His World, which opens at the Morgan on Thursday and runs through July 28, includes, then, the largest group of Michelangelo drawings ever to be shown on this continent. Among them are presentation works considered masterworks in themselves, studies for the Medici Chapel and the Sistine Chapel, and 17 doublesided drawings which will be mounted so that both sides may be seen. To further enrich the show, the Morgan will include from its trove of Renaissance material several letters and documents in Michelangelo's hand, poems written at the time of his death, along with master drawings, letters and documents by Raphael, Andrea del Sarto, Titian and others of the period. (See Art)

title: Community Effort
description: CHARLES CITY, Iowa The old gravel pit resting in an elbow of the Cedar River, looked innocent enough. Only a yellow stain leaching up through a freakish spring snow on one sloping bank gave evidence of the orthonitroaniline  ONA for short  found 65 miles downriver where Waterloo's 73,000 people get their drinking water. Trace amounts have been found in nearby wells and in the water supply of Cedar Rapids, a city of 109,000, 50 miles downstream. Costly efforts are now underway to seal off the site.

title: Philippine Rebels Said to Murder A Soldier, Then Get Away by Sea
description: ZAMBOANGA, the Philippines, April 21 (AP)  Moslemled rebels decapitated a soldier at an island outpost near here, then escaped by sea when a company of soldiers attacked, officers said this week.

title: Nancy Pistrang Married To Christopher B. Barker
description: Nancy Ellen Pistrang and Christopher Brian Barker were married yesterday by Judge Florence S. Bernstein of the Superior Court of Los Angeles, at the couple's home in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Gallup Poll Finds Little Change in Views on Abortion
description: The public's attitude toward abortion has changed very little in recent years, despite the intense and well publicized clashes between antiabortion forces and those who favor of abortions under certain circumstances, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: WASHINGTON AN INSIDER's GAME
description: Americans believe that the Washington apparatus has a life of its own, that it does not matter who is in or out of power. The Federal bureaucracy absorbs all invaders, spinning more soft silk about its cocoon.

title: Afterthoughts on the Death of an Amateur Fighter
description: Sickled Cells Not FactorD. MICHAEL M. BADEN, the chief medical examiner of New York City, has attributed the death of Francisco Rodriguez to cardiomegaly and sicklecell trait. A followup story in Francisco Rodriguez, a 25yearold machinist from Middletown, N.Y., had his first fight on Jan. 21 in Madison Square Garden. It was subnovice bout in the Golden Gloves amateur competition the Felt Forum: The fight was stopped in the second round when Rodriguez fell to the canvas from exhaustion rather than from punch. Four hours later, in the early morning of Feb. 1, he died.

title: Greeks Are Studying Techniques To Preserve Marble of Acropolis
description: ATHENS, April 21 (Reuters)  The Greek Government has decided to set up a laboratory to find ways to preserve the marble in the 2,500yearold Acropolis, the Minister of Culture and Sciences, Dimitrios Nianias, said at a press luncheon this week.

title: RIVAL POLICE FORCES A PROBLEM IN ITALY
description: ROME, April 21  As President Charles de Gaulle of France is supposed to have complained about the task of governing a country boasting 365 kinds of cheese, people here are often heard to ask how Italy can combat violence and terrorism with half a dozen different police forces.

title: Ecuador: Riobamba To Guayaquil
description: As trainfanciers know, it is how you get there that matters, and the most apt illustration of that truth I can think is the narrow gauge railway train ride that begins in Ecuador in the Andean town of Riobamba and ends in the seaport town of Guayaquil. The trip, which takes a good 10 hours, a voyage into the heart of Ecuadorean life, which American train commuters in their sealed airconditioned traveling coaches can scarcely imagine. Splendid snowcapped volcanoes, mountain villages nestled on the edges of spectacular abysslike valleys, the lush rampant growth of the South American jungle, each follows the other with astonishing rapidity; the life in remote villages offers itself to view in Manner both unexpected and pleasing.

title: American Press Institute's Chief Is Appointed to a New Position
description: The American Press Institute has announced the formation of a new executive position, director of development, which will be filled by Malcolm F. Mallette, the institute's director since 1975.

title: BRIDGE
description: The famous story, dating back a century or so, of the Englishwoman, newly arrived in Paris, who found that her ailing mother and their hotel room had totally disappeared, had bridge parallel last month. A woman player arrived at the Spring Nationals in Norfolk, Va., checked into a hotel, and vanished. Her husband tried unsuccessfully to telephone her, art the hotel found that her bags had reached the room but the owner had not.

title: Music: Schuman by Skrowaczewski
description: Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, music director of the Minnesota Orchestra for the last 19 years, is leading his last tour with the ensemble, which arrived Friday night in Carnegie Hall for the first of two nroerams there.

title: Politics Can Be the Lifeblood of an Ailing Hospital
description: New York has more hospitals than any other city in the world and, it generally is agreed, a lot more than it needs.

title: Amherst Blacks Continue Sitin Begun After Burning of a Cross
description: AMHERST, Mass., April 21  For the sixth day, black students at Amherst College carried on a sitin in administration offices that began the morning after a cross was burned in front of a dormitory occupied by blacks.

title: Rowing Cup Won By Penn
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 21  Pennsylvania's heavyweight oarsman defeated Princeton today and retained America's oldest rowing trophy, the Childs Cup, which was first placed in competition in 1880.

title: Maria Fredericks, William Harper 2d Set June 30 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Wayne Fredericks of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria Loring Fredericks, to William Hudson Harper 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Harper Jr. of New York and Lyme, Conn. A June 30 wedding is planned.

title: SHOP TALK
description: SAG HARBOR AG HARBOR is easily the most charming village In the Hemp tons. It is cosmopolitan and authentic. Both shopping and strolling along the wide sidewalks of its main street, which leads to the harbor here, are a pleasure.

title: Camaraderie on Wheels
description: HARRISON WHEN Texaco moved its corporate headquarters here from the Chrysler Building 19 months ago, a number. of employees elected to stay where'they were living and to commute to the suburbs rather than to uproot themselves and their families.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Reviewing Love on the Run, Franois Truffaut's fifth and (he says) last film in the Antoine Doinel series, which began in 1959 with The 900 Blows, is rather like reviewing a friend. It's as if one were to say, Well, I thought you were very funny this morning, very witty, and you were most appealing at lunch, but in the afternoon you sort of dragged, as if you'd run out of steam and, frankly, I couldn't understand what you were about, that is, if you were about anything. At five, however, you picked up your pace when you made several brilliant phone calls, though you went on too long. By supper I didn't believe you for a minute. All in all, you were very uneven today, but the way you ate that hamburger  comically yet vulnerably  was worth the price of admission ...

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Eugene List is at it again. On the evening of May 2 he will be the guide through a monster concert Carnegie Hall devoted mostly to the music of Louis Moreau Gottschalk. It will be the 150th anniversary, almost to the day, of the American composer's birth: he was born in New Orleans on May 8, 1829, and died in Rio de Janeiro on Dec. 19, 1869, at the age of 40. It fitting that Mr. List be the one to put this program together.

title: Dr. Lucy Cassebaum to Be Wed to Surgeon
description: Dr. Mary Elizabeth Cassebaum and Dr. Robert Henry Meyers plan to be married late next month. Dr. and Mrs. William Henry Cassebaum of Englewood, N.J., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Richard Meyers of Pompano Beath, Fla., and the late Mrs. Meyers.

title: Illegal Amounts of Sulfa Reported in Pork Supply
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  Illegal amounts of sulfa drugs, used by farmers in hog feed, continue to show up in the nation's pork supply, the Agriculture Department says.

title: The World
description: Ayatollah Mahmoud Taleghani was the first of Iran's religious leaders to denounce the reign of Shah Riza Mohammed Pahlevi in the 1960's; he was jailed for 12 years. Last week, Ayatollah Taleghani spoke out again, against the despotism of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and the Islamic councils. By the end of the week, after a humiliating apology, he was still free but his spirit was tortured. Perhaps more importantly, the administration of Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan had lost a gamble to become more than a Government in name.

title: New Forms Of Expressions in Teaching the Deaf
description: WHEN Christine LaCerva was exploring ideas for her senior dance project at the State University of New York at Purchase, she decided she wanted to use mime and wondered if the gestures of sign language might not be a useful movement source.

title: Jane Ellice Gural Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Gural of Woodsburgh, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Ellice Gural, to William Senders, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Senders of Philadelphia.

title: U.S. Search for Women and Blacks To Serve as Judges Is Going Slowly
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  A senator from North Carolina has recommended his former campaign manager for a Federal judgeship. A Texas senator has recommended a prominent supporter of his illfated 1976 Presidential campaign. A Georgia Senator has recommended the soninlaw of a key political supporter, And a Montana senator has recommended a former colleague who was defeated in last fall's primary. Such recommendations follow traditional patterns.

title: GARDENING
description: TWO planting areas present problems when it comes to selecting summer annuals  the very shady and the very sunny. There are annuals that are well adapted to both, arid, with one possible exception, these areas can be as colorful as any other.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: EASTCHESTER  Man of La Mancha, starring Michael Tarr, June Hinlicky and Doug Patterson. Presented by Town Hall Community Theater. Friday and Saturday at 8:30 P.M., next Sunday at 2. Through May 5. $4.50. William E. Cottle School, Crawford Blvd. 6935092.

title: Jan DuCharme Betrothed To Clyde C. Gunsaulus 3d
description: Mary Janice DuCharme of Boston, a corporate bond assistant with the Boston Company, investment managers, and Clyde Calvin Gunsaulus 3d, a marketing representative in Boston with the Chase World Information Group, a subsidiary of the Chase Manhattan Bank, plan to be married June 30 in Grosse Pointe. Mich.

title: STAMPS
description: The United Nations has proclaimed 1979 as the International Year of the Child as a reminder that tomorrow's world depends on today's children, and this is being marked by the U.N. on May 4 with an issue of four commemoratives that has features of special interest to collectors.

title: Food
description: LambStuffed Eggplant

title: 300 British Women Will Sue U.S. Birth Pill Makers
description: LONDON, April 21  About 300 British women who had strokes and heart attacks while taking oral contraceptives are planning to sue American pharmaceutical companies for damages.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Labels Are for Jelly Jars, They're Not for Children

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: 71 Instrument Landing Arts
description: For better or worse, Instrument Landing qualified yesterday as the New York horse for the Kentucky Derby by winning the $142,750 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct.

title: WIDESPREAD FAMINE IN CAMBODIA FEARED
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 21  Widespread famine may be imminent in Cambodia, according to diplomats who follow events in Indochina.

title: Study Says Solar Energy Could Employ 3 Million
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  A massive shift from oil and coal use to solar energy by 1990 would create almost three million new jobs for Americans, according to a Congressional study released today.

title: German Visitor Says He Lost Bag Holding $25,000 in Currency
description: A West German businessman vacationing in New York City told the police that he had left more than $25,000 in Deutsche marks in the taxi that brought him from Kennedy International Airport into Manhattan last Thursday.

title: Dwarves Abounding in Provence
description: IVE years ago Lawrence Durrell announced in his envoi to Monsieur that it was to be the first novel in a quincunx

title: New Football Gear May Reduce Injuries
description: The relationship established last year between Dan Pastprini, the Roston Oiler quarterback, and Byron Don. zis, an inventor, may create a revolutionary new football uniform  one that could significantly reduce injuries to players. The unusual flak vest produced by Donzis enabled Pastorini to play effectively at the end of the season despite severely damaged ribs.

title: A Poet's Feminist Prose
description: THAT Adrienne Rich is one of America's most Important and gifted poets is of course a known fact here; it is also known abroad, as a year of travel from Tokyo to Sydney to Paris informed this reviewer in 1978. Less well known is her quality as writer of prose. This fact alone justifies the publication

title: Philippines Abuse of Human Rights Said to Decline
description: MANILA  Martiallaw rule by Presi dent Ferdinand E. Marcos continues to cause serious violations of human rights, according to Roman Catholic Church and American Embassy officials. But cases of torture, abduction and murder of dissidents by military and police authorities are said to have declined sharply in the last year.

title: The Hold of Ireland on One of Its Poets
description: Although for Sheamus Heaney, the Irish poet, teaching this semester at Harvard, this is his third stay in the United States in less than a decade, nothing in these visits, he remarked, is to be seen as portending a move to this country. I have a base and commit. ment to Ireland, the poet said.

title: Revisionist History of Vietnam Will Be Published Next Month
description: A revisionist interpretation of American involvement in the VIetnam War that greatly pleases Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the retired Army commander who led the military forces there during the height of the escalation in the mid60's, will be published here next month after first coming out in Britain.

title: Birth Notice 1 -- No Title
description: Births

title: Making Bronze Come to Life
description: ROSLYN THE recent sculptures of Peter Rubino and the canvases of Jim Ceravolo, on view at the Bryant Library, have one common characteristic: Both demonstrate a strong interest in stylized forms. Mr. Rubino's bronzes have simple bold shapes, broad planes and large surfaces. Mr. Ceravolo's oils do not concern themselves with detail either, but deal with shapes that are uninvolved and flat and cover large areas.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  Tha most interesting development in this unusually early phase of the 1980 Presidential election campaign is the decline of the Californians  Ronald Reagan and Governor Brown. It cannot be demonstrated as a fact and it hasn't even come to the fore in the polls, but politicians live or die on hunches and influential members of both parties are beginning to say in private that Reagan is too old and predictable and Brown too young and unpredictable to play decisive roles.

title: Where Concierges Make All the Difference
description: After giving tenants a neon tunnel at 127 John Street and a fighter plane atop 77 Water Street, Melvyn Kaufman, an owner and developer of office buildings, is introducing concierges into three of his office properties.

title: Freeze on Rate Rise Praised
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  The Environmental Action Foundation, a citizens group,. has praised the decision by the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission to freeze a previously approved $49 million rate increase for the Metropolitan Edison Company, which owns the Three Mile Island nuclear reactor.

title: Jacqueline McEwen Becomes the Bride Of David E. Griffith
description: Jacqueline McEwen, daughter of Joseph McEwen of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., and Margaret A. McEwen of Springfield, Pa., was married yesterday morning to David Edward Griffith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Griffith of New Canaan, Conn., and John's Island, Fla. The Rev. James H. Hampson performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church in Huntingdon Valley.

title: GARDENING
description: PLANTS are amazingly tough and resilient. Some of them come through weather adversities without turning a leaf or dropping a petal. Though the sudden chill and snow flurries two weeks ago on Palm Sunday sent shivers through most of us, the plants took it in stride

title: Illegal Residues Found in 14% of Meat and Poultry
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  The General Accounting Office estimated today that 14 percent of all meat and poultry samples tested over a twoyear period by Federal agencies charged with protecting consumers contained illegal and potentially harmful residues.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: GREATER SNOW GOOSE Chen caerulescens

title: Flames Force Evacuation of 300 At Federal Hospital Near Capital
description: BETHESDA, Md., April 21 (UPI) More than 300 patients were evacuated this afternoon from the National Institutes of Health after a fire broke out. None of the patients was injured, the authorities said.

title: Television This Week
description: OF SPECIAL INTEREST

title: MinimumCompetency Tests Having Minimum Effects
description: SIXTEENYEAROLD Dennis Joiner sits nest to his teacher and reads a paragraph aloud, stumbling through sentences, sometimes bobbing his head toward the page as if to shake a reluctant word off his tongue Dennis, a high school sophomore in Gary, Ind., reads at a fourthor fifthgrade level, but he is not alone, according to the teacher, Vera Hooper. My first year here we had graduates who could not read, she said. I won't tell you the percentage. You'd be alarmed. Said Dennis, who wound up in Mrs. Hooper's remedial class because he failed a test of reading competency: If I stay in this class, I'll probably come out better.

title: He Stars Without Lifting a Finger
description: Art's no bloody good if it's dull. You can still do Ibsen and entertain, can't you? It doesn't have to be boring, but somehow it usually is. Even Shakespeare bores me.

title: Sporting Gear
description: The seasoned outdoorsman or boatman knows well the importance of emergency aid when a companion is stricken. Now on the market is a portable oxygen generator, a valuable complement to the wellstocked firstaid kit. The canister, which weighs three pounds filled and measures 10 by 4 inches, contains a solidstate chemical that you can convert to pure moisturized oxygen (enough of it for 15 minutes) by turning a knob. The unit comes with oxygen mask and three feet of tubing. It Cannot be refilled. Send $39.95, plus $2.25 for postage, to National Traffic Services, 454 Leverett Avenue, Staten Island 10308, (212) 3561161; or directly to Green Cross Solid State Oxygen, 1210 Stirling Road, Dania, Fla. 33004, (305) 9256060.

title: Pompeii A.D. 79 Opens: Looking Back 1900 Years
description: A visitor to the Museum of Natural History viewing courtyard garden in the eahit4tian, Pompeii. A.D. 79. The show consista of 350 examples of Roman art and arilfacts discovered in the ruins of the ancient resort city. Pompeii was preserved under the tons of void ash from Motmt Veanius that destroyed it Aug. 24, A.b. 79.

title: Malta Bars Military Attachs
description: VALETTA, Malta, April 22 (Reuters)  The Maltese Foreign Ministry has told foreign embassies that they cannot have defense or military attachs on their staffs. A United States naval attach due to errive during the weekend is td be given a new appointment.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Music

title: Petty Captures Virginia 500 Race
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., April 22 (UPI)  Richard Petty took advantage of fenderbanging between Buddy Baker and Darrell Waltrip to win the 5120,000 Virginia 500 today at Martinsville Speedway with a record average speed of 80.201 miles an hour.

title: Rubber Workers Union And Uniroyal Set Talks
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) Negotiators for the United Rubber Workers union and Uniroyal Inc. plan to meet for intense talks with a Federal mediator tomorrow in an effort to avert strike.

title: 72,342 See Cosmos Take Home Opener
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 22  For several reasons, the Cosmos home opener today will be remembered for some time to come.

title: Austrian Talks Snagged
description: VIENNA, April 22 (Reuters) Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria said at a news conference last week that negotiations with the Ford Motor Company on setting up an assembly plant in Austria had reached a difficult stage because of strong competition from Spain and France.

title: Women's Sports Backed in Rally
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  Chanting Hold the line on Title IX and We want to play, don't take it away, a crowd of several hundred women and a handful of men rallied today to oppose rumored legislation that amid threaten women's athletic programs.

title: ExSpeech Writer Views Carter as Arrogant, Complacent and Insecure
description: WASHINGTON April 22 (UPI) James Fallows, President Carter's former chief speech writer, says that Mr. Carter took office in profound ignorance of his job and had made matters worse, by a combination of arrogance, complacency and insecurity.

title: Chicago Suburb Expects Long Struggle on Racial Balance
description: BELLWOOD, Ill., April 21  The Mayor of this town of 22,000 people near Chicago says that its struggle against resegregation is far from over with its victory Tuesday in the United States Supreme Court. Town officials will move ahead with lawsuits against three realty agents accused of steering whites and blacks to different neighborhoods in the sale of homes here.

title: Spurs Defeat 76ers, 115112
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22  The San Antonio Spurs, led by George Gervin and Larry Kenon and helped by a hometeam mistake down the stretch, handed the Philadelphia 76ers a 115112 playoff defeat this afternoon at the Spectrum.

title: Jumbo Elliott: Ingenious Giant Of U.S. Track
description: VILLANOVA, PA.

title: The Horse Trials Are On !Ah, It's Spring in England
description: BADMINTON, England, April 22 More than 100,000 British horse fanciers converged on a muddy meadow here this weekend for an annual upper class rite of spring known as the Badminton Horse Trials.

title: Lincolnk Center, at 20, Sets Gala
description: Twenty years ago in May, President Eisenhower broke ground to start the construction of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. and to commemorate that event the center will give an anniversary party that will fill the plaza and most of the buildings with 2,500 celebrants and an outdoor soundandlight show designed to recall some highlights of the intervening years.

title: Michael Maso, Ph.D. Student, Marries Marcie Dale Begleiter
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., yesterday, Marcie Dale Begleiter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Begleiter of Woodmere, L.I., was married to Michael H. Maso, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Maso of New York. Rabbi Joel Zion performed the ceremony.

title: Soviet Official Concedes Accidents Have Taken Place at Nuclear Sites
description: MOSCOW, April 22 (AP)  A United States Congressman said here today that the Soviet minister responsible for energy had acknowledged what Western analysts had suspected for years, that there have been several accidents at Soviet nuclear power stations, including an explosion and a radiation leak.

title: 10,000 Cyclists Tour the Five Boroughs
description: Ten thousand strong they came  their silver bicycles and bright orange vests making the stream of marathon riders look from a distance like a long. glistening snake winding its, way through the city.

title: ISRAELI SNIPS SHELL LEBANON IN REPRISAL FOR GURRILLA RAID
description: JERUSALEM, April 72  Israeli ships shelled suspected Palestinian guerrilla bases in Lebanon today after four guerrillas, arriving by sea, attacked an apartment building in northern Israel. Four Israelis, including two small children, died in the assault.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: At the beginning of the second half in a college basketball game, each team takes the floor. promptly but faces the wrong basket. Team A wins the tap, and scores. The scoring desk stops the game and notifies the officials of the error. The officials then award Team B the 2 points, and Team B ultimately wins the game by 4. Does Team A have a legitimate reason for a protest?
