description: Partial list scheduled meetings tor week follows:

title: ArmsControl Aide Warns of NewWeapons Race
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  An armscontrol official said today that development of particlebeam and highenergy weapons that instantly destroy incoming enemy missiles could lead to a new strategic arms race with unsettling military and political implications.

title: Summaries of Rutgers and Iona Relays
description: SATURDAY

title: All Lebanese Factions Alert for New Attacks; Beirut Clashes Resume
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 22  United Nations peacekeeping forces in southern Lebanon were on alert today because of threats by Christian militia groups to attack the Moslem inhabitants of the region of Ibl asSagi.

title: Brents Ousts Beitler In Platform Tennis
description: UNIONDALE, LI., April 22  Greg Brenta of New York, seeded second, gained the quarterfinals of the first United States open platform tennis singles championship today by defeating Jim Beitler, a New Jersey player, 62, 61.

title: Advertising
description: SEVENTEEN years after starting his agency with two partners, Carl Ally, who's seen a lot of glory and a lot of grief, is tur over the direction and control of Ally Gargano to Amil Gargano, his longtime friend and partner.

title: Red Cross Has Exceeded Budget For Disaster Relief by $2 Million
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C., April 22 (AP)  The American Red Cross has already spent $2 million more than it budgeted for national disaster relief in this fiscal year, a Red Cross official said.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: Leontyne Price, Justino Diaz, center, and Jess Thomas opened the Metropolitan Opera in 1966 with Antony and Cleopatra.

title: Laborites Tough Election Battle Is Brought Home to David Owen
description: PLYMOUTH, England, April 22  The youthfullooking man stood in the stark stairwell of a housing project, huddled in a parka against the draft, and began his campaign pitch: Hello, I'm Dr. David Owen and....

title: Emissions of Iodine Are Reduced At Crippled Nuclear Power Plant
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 22 (UPI) The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that new efforts were under way to ensure a continued reduction of emissions of radioactive iodine from the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant.

title: Antitrust Damage, and Damages
description: When some communities in Illinois discovered that the price of bricks sold to private government contractors had been illegally fixed by the brick manufacturers, they sued for damages. But in 1977 the Supreme Court ruled that as indirect purchasers they had no right to sue. Only the middlemen  the contractors who actually bought the bricks  had any claim against the brick companies.

title: Fries Sailing Victor
description: MIAMI, April 22  Derrick Fries of Drayton Plains, Mich., won the first Force 5 sailing class world championship yesterday against 65 competitors in a race held off the Miami Yacht Club.

title: Miss Campbell Wins Net Title 2d Time
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 22 Princeton University's Debbie Campbell routed a teammate, Suzie Replogle, 60, 60, today to retain her singles title in the 37th Middle States Intercollegiate women's tennis tournament.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, APRIL 23, 1977

title: Mets Defeat Phillies, 42
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22  Hoping to get the Mets hitting with greater vigor and more telling effect, Manager Joe Torre had his players dispense with batting practice before today's game with the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Congress Is Opening a Drive to End Trade Sanctions Against Rhodesia
description: WASHINGTON, April 22The turnout of more than 60 percent of black voters in Rhodesia's parliamentary, election has touched off a drive in Congress to lift sanctions against that country, a move that could imperil the Carter Administration's strategy for southern Africa.

title: Newspaper Official Says Court Hurt Constitution
description: The entire First Amendment, which guarantees freedom of speech and assembly as well as freedom of the press, has been battered by the United States Supreme Court's ruling that journalists can be forced to reveal opinions they held while preparing articles or broadcasts, the president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association said yesterday.

title: Jane Blalock Wins L.P.G.A. Playoff
description: ORLANDO, Fla., April 22 (AP) Playing swirling winds to her advantage, Jane Blalock beat JoAnne Career on the second suddendeath playoff hole today to capture the $100,000 Lady Citrus golf classic.

title: Tentative Agreement Reported In 3Year Kentucky Mine Strike
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 22 (AP)  A tentative settlement has been reached in the threeyearold strike by the United Mine Workers at Stearns Mining Company's Justus mine, it was learned tonight.

title: Gymnastics: Miss Cassello Top Qualifier
description: NEW HAVEN, April 22  Jackie Cassello and Suzy Kellams, two very different girls personifying two different gymnastic styles, amassed 73.60 and 73.25 points, respectively, during three days of competition to become the top allround gymnasts at the second national elite championships for women at Southern Connecticut State College.

title: Long Island Boy Discovered Slain On Wooded Hill
description: A 13yearold Smithtown, L.I., boy who vanished on a neighborhood bicycle ride Friday night and was found dead in a nearby woodland Saturday was suffocated by an object that had been forced down his throat in a bizarre and apparently senseless murder, the Suffolk County Medical Examiner said yesterday.

title: Black Theater Fete Will Open Mav 1
description: Tickets ar on sale at the MItzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center for the Black Theater Festival U.S.A., which will open on May 1 with the Urban Arts Corps's presentation of When Hell Freezes Over Ill Skate and will run through June 3 with theater and dance productions and concerts.

title: TV: Dorothy Hamill's Corner of the Sky on Ice
description: EVEN viewers who, like this reviewer, think that ice should tinkle in highball glasses are likely to find at least a moderate degree of pleasure in Dorothy Hamill's Corner of the Sky. The show, starring the 1976 Olympic figureskating champion, will be presented from 8 to 9 o'clock tonight on ABCTV.

title: Goya: Spanish Flavor in U.S.
description: SECAUCUS, N.J.  The founder of the Goya dynasty was Prudencio Unanue, a food importer who had ventured from his native Spain to distant Puerto Rico. When the Spanish Civil War broke out, he found his supplies  and his livelihood  threatened.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: It's Legal, but Few Lawyers Are Prepared to Advertise
description: With their commanding view of Lower Manhattan and with their Oriental antiques, the offices of the law firm of Serko & Simon, on the 33d floor of One World Trade Center, exude prosperity and power.

title: Sharif Khan Victor In Squash Racquets
description: Sharif Khan of Toronto turned back Mohibullah Khan Jr., the Pakistan national champion, 1510, 1511, 1511, at the Uptown Racquet Club yesterday to win the $3,000 first prize in a fivenation squash racquets competition.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: In a recent article on the virtues of raw garlic, it was mentioned that a friend and cookbook author eats a goodly quantity of the seasoning each year to ward off attacks of hav fever. It was pointed out that he eats the clovesfinely chopped  over cooked vegetables, in salads and so on and that his ounce of prevention begins before the start of hay fever, on the theory that once the season is at hand, the eyes become watery and it is too late.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Penguins Lose
description: PITTSBURGH, April 22 (AP) Sean Ratelle scored two goals as the Boston Bruins beat the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight, 41, for a fourgame sweep of the National Hockey League quarterfinal playoffs.

title: British Couple Report Physical Mistreatment By Soviet Authorities
description: MOSCOW, April 22  The Moscow correspondent of U.S. News & World Report said today that Soviet authorities physically mistreated him and his wife during a reporting trip to the SoViet Central Asian city of Tashkent last week.

title: U.S. Income Gain Put at 0.5% in 70's
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) Inflation and recession during the 1970's have limited income gains of American families to levels far below those of the two preceding decades, according to a Government study released today.

title: Executives Plan to Borrow More
description: Businessmen have become more pessimistic about the economic outlook and are expected to increase their external borrowings, according to a survey released yesterday by the Conference Board, a business research group.

title: Squalor in Iranian Oil Area Resists the Revolution
description: KHURRAMSHAHR, Iran  Fifteen years ago, people here say. Prime Minister Amir Abbas Hoveida ordered a high brick wall built along Chehel Metri Street. Behind the wall lies the Arab shantytown known as Kefar ha Mostofi; the wall is to hide the shantytown from view.

title: U.S. to Seek New Rules On Some Student Loans
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)  The Government said today it would seek new regulations on loans to American medical students attending classes abroad.

title: Holocaust, Keeshan, Salant Win Peabodys
description: ATHENS, Ga., April 22 (AP) Holocaust, the television drama about the plight of Jews in Europe during World War II, received a George Foster Peabody Broadcasting Award, it was announced today. The winners are to be presented with medallions and certificates at a luncheon in New York City next month.

title: Commodities
description: CONFOUNDED by the Treasury's decision last Wednesday to halve the amount of gold bullion offered at its monthly auction to 750,000 ounces, the metals futures markets spent the rest of the week groping for direction.

title: U.S. Six Beats Finland In World Event by 62
description: MOSCOW, April 22  The United States team scored an important victory, S2, over Finland today in the world hockey championships, the first triumph for the Americans after two defeats and three ties.

title: De Gaulle's Art Objects to Be Auctioned
description: PARIS, April 22  Some 300 art objects, historical souvenirs and books belonging to the late President Charles de Gaulle will go on the auction block in Paris on June 7.

title: Song: Talvela Lends His Bass To the Somber
description: IT was a lovely spring afternoon outside Avery Fisher Hall yesterday, but inside Martti Talvela was dispensing liberal amounts of gloom, despair and thoughts of death. The bass voice seems fated by nature to sing about such things, and Mr. Talvela's program was inevitably weighted in that direction.

title: Some Tallies in Rhodesian Vote Raise Questions on the Turnout
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 22 Election officials in Rhodesia have reported voter turnouts in two provinces that exceed the listed number of eligible voters in the areas, raising questions about the figures given for the final turnout in an election that is to transfer power to a new blackled government.

title: Secretaries Deplore Dead Ends
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP)  A new poll shows that although only onefifth of the secretaries surveyed disliked their work, 60 percent thought they were in a deadend jobs and wanted a chance for advancement. Results of the poll, excerpted from a national survey of working women, were released today by the National Commission on Working Women in conjunction with National Secretaries Week.

title: Market Place
description: TORRAY CLARK & COMPANY, a littleknown Washington money manager, appears to have had better success with a large portfolio than other independent investment advisers in the first auarten

title: VALFRID REINHOLD PALMER
description: Valfrid Reinhold Palmer, retired owner of the Residence Construction Company of Summit, N.J., died yesterday at Holy Cross Hospital in Tamarack, Fla., at the age of 73. He was born in Stockholm and carne to the United States in 1928.

title: Rock: Joe Jackson Band
description: JOE JACKSON has been well spoken of by the rock press in Britain and in this country, where his Look Sharp! debut album has won both favorable reviews and extensive FM airplay. Mr. Jackson and his threepiece band have been in New York recently, appearing at such newwave haunts as the Mudd Club and Hurrah, and Friday and Saturday they showed up for a more formal debut at the Bottom Line. This writer saw the early show Saturday, which was broadcast live on WNEWFM.

title: A Home for the Shah
description: The dethroned Shah of Iran needs a place to live. The United States, along with most other Western countries, is trying to help himprovided he goes else, where.

title: Franklin Captures Crown By Stopping Johnson in 8th
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 22  After one of the best title fights in recent years, the winner was taken to a hospital today and the loser complained about the hometown officiating  and this was his hometown.

title: Bullets Win in Overtime
description: ATLANTA, April 22  Three times in their playoff series, the Atlanta Hawks have ended the third quarter tied with or ahead of the Washington Bullets, the defending champions of the National Basketball Association and the team with the highest winning percentage this season. Three times the Hawks have lost.

title: Returning Assemblymen to Debate Plan to Cut Some Electricity Rates
description: ALBANY. April 22  A lifeline measure that would reduce residential electric rates by as much as twothirds for small users is scheduled for consideration by the Assembly tomorrow, as the Legislature returns after a twoweek recess.

title: Bonwit's Final Sales: Chaos and Sadness
description: For 30 years, Sylvia Fabricant woke up every morning and went happily off to work at Bonwit Teller. She loved the store; she loved the people she worked with; she loved the customers.

title: Short Plays Are Sought
description: The fourth Off Off Broadway Short Play Festival, which seeks works by developing playwrights, will be staged at John Jay College, 444 West 54th Street, from May 21 through 27.

title: Ohira Worships at Tokyo Shrine Where Tojo Is Newly Honored
description: TOKYO, April 22  Whiterobed and blackhatted Shinto priests escorted Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira as he passed. rapidly from his car into the shrine, a stocky figure in a black morning coat.

title: 25 S.I. Strikers Draw Weapons On Guardsmen
description: A group of about 25 striking New York State correction officers with drawn guns surrounded an unarmed force of 60 National Guardsmen returning to their armory on Staten Island last night, according to the police, who managed to separate the two groups without violence. No arrests were made.

title: 2 STUDIES COMPETE ON PERIL AT HOOKER
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., April 20 New York State's Health Department and the Hooker Chemical and Plastics Corporation have begun health studies of the same group of Hooker employees to see whether they are developing cancer or other diseases at an unusually high rate. The workers were exposed to pesticides, solvents and defoliants made by Hooker here until 1975.

title: Brooklyn School Takes Relay Double
description: KEARNY, N.J. April 22  Boys and Girls High School of Brooklyn coinpleted a mile relay double at the fifth annual Krulik Memorial Relays today at Kearny High School stadium as its boys' team defeated Snyder of Jersey City in 3 minutes 22.5 seconds.

title: Man Killed in Elevator Shaft
description: ST. LOUIS, April 22 (AP)  The authorities said that Henry Woodberry, 30 years old, was apparently trapped between an elevator and a wall as he tried to board the elevator on the second floor of downtown building yesterday. He was dragged up to the seventh floor, the police said. He was pronounced dead at City Hospital. The police said that Alex Huntley, 34, was injured when he tried to aid Mr. Woodberry and fell two stories down the elevator shaft. He suffered chest injuries and a broken arm and was hospitalized.

title: Carey Follows Example Of Jersey on Casino Sites
description: Berore presenting the voters with ail amendment to the State Constitution to permit casino gambling, the Carey administration hopes to have enabling legislation enacted naming specific sites for casinos.

title: Five Die in Seoul Hotel Blaze
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 22 (Reuters)  At least five people were killed and more than 20 injured when fire swept through a 13story tourist hotel in Seoul today.

title: Betsy Stark Bride Of Barney Softness
description: Betsy Ellen Stark, daughter of Mr. and. Mrs. Kenneth N. Stark of Glen Cove, L.I., was married there yesterday to Barney Softness, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Softness, also of Glen Cove. Rabbi Laurence Kotok performed the ceremony at the North Country Reform Temple.

title: L.I. Store's Security Gate Opens Door to Dissension
description: NORTHPORT, L.I., April 19  As Thomas Bowman recalled it, Christmas Eve really opened my eyes.

title: Recital: Miss Guneyman, Pianist
description: MERAL GUNEYMAN, a pianist trained in her native Istanbul and at the Juilliard School, tackled a difficult standard program in Carnegie Recital Nall late Saturday afternoon and ripped through it as if it were child's play.

title: Leafs Bow, 54
description: TORONTO, April 22 (UPI)  Larry Robinson blasted in a 40foot goal at minutes 14 seconds of overtime tonight to give the Montreal Canadiens a 54 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs and a fourgame sweep of their quarterfinal Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: Around the Nation
description: HIGHLAND, Ind., April 22 (AP) More than 200 people marched in a cold drizzle here yesterday in support of surprise narcotics searches by the police at area high schools.

title: Utility's Chief Denies Misleading The Public on Nuclear Accident
description: READING Pa., April 22 (AP)  The president of READING, company that operates the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant says the concern was neither prepared for the March 28 accident nor aware of its scone for two on three days.

title: Concert: Minnesotans Play Bruckner
description: STANISLAW SKROWACZEWSKI is generally regarded as a sober conductor, one who avoids flamboyance and tends to understate. These attributes of the outgoing music director of the Minnesota Orchestra worked very well for him Saturday night in a performance of Bruckner's Seventh Symphony in Carnegie Hall.

title: Foli's Error Lets Astros Win by 32
description: HOUSTON, April 22 (UPI)  TIm Foli, acquired by the PIrates for his defensive ability, committed an error in the eighth inning today, allowing Craig Reynolds to score front second base with the run that gave the Houston Astros a 32 victory over Pittsburgh for a sweep of the threegame series.

title: 20,000 Cambodians Flee Across Border to Thailand.
description: ARANYAPRATHET. Thailand, April 22  About 20,000 Cambodians crossed iatn eastern Thailand during the weekend to escape a Vietnameseled assault, and officials here said today that the refugees were resisting attempts by Thailand to get them to return to Cambodia.

title: Chicago Port Investing To Regain Cargo Trade
description: CHICAGO, April 22After watching Middle Western cargo flow through ports on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts for nearly a decade, the Port of Chicago is beginning to spend in an effort to recapture some of that business.

title: Senator Hart, on Easter Vacation, Argues for Arms Treaty Before Voters in Colorado
description: DENVER, April 22  He told them new strategic arms treaty, however inadequate, was the only way to keep lid on the nuclear weapons race. He said that the Carter Administration might just be beginning to understand Colorado's need for water. He offered some hope for legislation to help develop oil shale.

title: New Source of XRays Observed
description: The first observation of a new, versatile source of Xrays having potentially important applications in chemistry and physics was reported today by a team of American scientists.

title: School Must Repay $750,000
description: WASHINGTON, April M (UPI)  A Florida vocational school that offered courses in truck driving, insurance adjusting and other fields will refund up to $750,000 to its former students, the Federal Trade Commission said today. The reimbursement grows out of a complaint filed by the commission against the school, Universal Training Service Inc. of Miami, that alleged that it misrepresented the jobs available and the money to be made, as well as its job placement assistance.

title: JOHN R. REITEMEYER,EXPUBLISHER, DEAD
description: BARKHAMSTED, Conn., April 22 (UPI)  John R. Reitemeyer, the former president, publisher and chairman of The Hartford Courant, died last night at his home after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: Jill Sue Zubof, Editor, Bride Of Frederick R. Conrad 3d
description: Jill Sue Zubof, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Zubof of Valley Stream, L.I., was married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. Luke in the Fields to Frederick R. Conrad 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad Jr. of Jackson, Mich. The Rev. Ledlie Irwin Laughlin Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Inflation Driving Young Couples To Purchase More and Save Less
description: LOS ANGELES  If inflation picks winners as well as losers, young families like the Sheppards and the Pointers would seem as well situated as anyone.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TODAY

title: A Properly Used Trout Nymph Is a Beauty of a Bug
description: THERE is scarcely a trout fisherman under 40 today who would be caught on lake or stream without a nymph. The nymph in this instance is not a golden girl of summer  although to this graying observer of the angling scene, at least, she seems to materialize under the dusky hemlocks with increasing frequency  but the trout fly designed to represent an aquatic insect in its early, underwater, stage.

title: Aiding Jobless Youth: A Bronx Experiment
description: From the aim and musty front section of the basement of an abandoned building on Kelly Street, a visitor can look out past old beams and see the April sun splashing off the red, yellow, blue and white hard hats of the 11 young men working in the rear of an old hulk that once housed eight workingclass Bronx families.

title: World News Briefs
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, April 22 (Reuters)Prince Abdullah, who is second in line for the throne, pledged his loyalty yesterday to his brothers, King Khalid and Crown Prince Fand, and dismissed reports from the United States of a split in Saudi Arabia's royal family.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times last Thursday gave an incorrect telephone number to call in New York City for a tutor to help students prepare for the Regents basic competency examination. The correct number is 5321100.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Although the Federal Open Market Committee last Tuesday decided not to raise interest rates any higher just yet, several leading credit market analysts predicted they would rise anyway.

title: School Integration Goals Elusive in Changing City
description: Deborah S. expects to graduate from a junior high school in Cambria Heights, Queer, in June. But the 13yearold black girl does not know whether she will have to attend virtually allblack Andrew Jackson High School, or will be able to go to an integrated high school in Queens next fall as she and her mother hope.

title: Uganda's 2d City, Reputed Stronghold of Amin, Falls
description: JINJA, Uganda, April 22  A brigade of Tanzanian soldiers swept through this city today in a predawn assault that met only ripples of resistance.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON MUCH of economic Washington is wondering whether the nation's economy is overheated. and much of the wondering is focused on business inventories. Economic memories are long enough to recall that in 197375, the nation was propelled into recession in part by an excessive buildup of stocks. This time around, every little jiggle in the monthly figures is being watched carefully.

title: Cabaret: Regards to Leicester Square
description: THE sentimental and comic songs that were popular in English music halls at the turn of the century are at the come of Give My Regards to Leicester Square, which is being presented Friday and Saturday evenings at the Top of the Gate, Thompson and Bleecker Streets. But the Affectionate Salute to English Music Hall, as it is subtitled, doesn't stop there.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Johnny Kelley is not sure where he fini bed in last week's Boston Marathon, the 48th he has run since 1928, when as a 20yearold he first competed in it. I was back in the thousands someplace, he said the other, day. I was timed in 3 hours 40 minutes by a friend, eight minutes slower than last year. I got tired the last couple of miles, but I never stopped running. I didn't feel as bad as I did last year.

title: Bonics Down Lakers And Lead Series, 31
description: LOS ANGELES, April 22 (AP)  Gus Williams and Dennis Johnson, Seattle guards, continued to excel against Los Angeles in their secondround National Basketball Association playoff series as they combined for 53 points today and led the Supersonics to a 117115 victory over the Lakers.

title: Dr. Howard Irwin Weds Anne Wolff
description: The marriage of Anne Lieb Wolff to Dr. Howard S. Irwin, president of the New York Botanical Garden, took place yesterday in the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory at the Barden in the Bronx. Dr. Matthew Spetter, leader of the RiverdaleYonkers Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony.

title: The City
description: The president of the Auxiliary Police Benevolent Association said yesterday that the group was advising its 1,500 members not to go on patrol because a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan ruled last week that it was illegal for them to carry nightsticks.

title: Monument to Einstein Is Dedicated in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  Widely heralded and criticized, the National Academy of Sciences' monument to Albert Einstein was unveiled today, 39 days after the centennial of his birth, to a fanfare of speeches, a chorus of ah's from the crowd, and the musical theme of public television's Masterpiece Theater.

title: DR. PAUL G. EDGAR
description: Dr. Paul G. Edgar, a child psychiatrist who was the first director of the Child Guidance Clinic in Nassau County, died yesterday at Bristol (Conn.) Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: New York Casinos A Disaster
description: If casino gambling intrudes on our immediate region, the results will be disastrous.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Patricia Mary Hayes, Nurse, Wed to Dr. Alfredo Axtmayer
description: The marriage of Patricia Mary Hayes, a nurse at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, to Dr. Alfredo Axtmayer, an orthopedic surgical resident at the YaleNew Haven Hospital, took place yesterday in New Hyde Park, L.I. The Rev. Charles Bierne performed the ceremony in Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  Buried in the verbiage filling this space one week ago was the revelation that the Director of Central Intelligence, Stansfield Turner. (dubbed by ornithologists The DoubleDipping Ringknocker) had spent a strange and tempestuous afternoon before a secret session of the Senate Intelligence Committee.

title: Bridge: Opponent's Miscue Is Root Of Some Brilliant Card Play
description: Many brilliant plays become possible only because an opponent has made an error. A case in point is the diagramed deal, from a recent tournament in Italy.

title: Study Finds Children's TV More Violent
description: Young people who watch much television are more apprehensive about their own safety and more likely to think that people are mean and selfish. according to researchers at the Universay of Pennsylvania's Annenberg School of Communications. They noted that violence in weekend children': television programming rose to nearly record levels on the three major net works in the fall of 1978.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: Over the River, Into the Wood
description: THE 55th Wood Memorial was both a rouser of a horse race and evidence of the New York horseplayer's respect for Billy Turner, the trainer who nursed Seattle Slew through the Triple Crown series unbeaten and then had the horse taken away from him.

title: Dance: Jude Makes Ballet Theater Debut
description: AMERICAN Ballet Theater's two latest performances of Giselle offered an eventful weekend at the Metropolitan Opera House. Lucia Chase, the company's codirector, made her debut as Berthe, Giselle's mother. An exciting debut came from Charles Jude, a star of the Paris Opera Ballet, as Albrecht to Cynthia Gregory's Giselle on Saturday afternoon. In the evening, the British star Anthony Dowell joined forces with Natalia Makarova to produce a great performance in the same ballet.

title: China Reassessing Its Liberalization Drive
description: PEKING. April 20  China's leaders say they are in the midst of a major reassessment of their experiment with allout modernization and liberalization of the country's political and social life after evidentally went too far too fast for them.

title: Higueras Captures Houston Net Final
description: HOUSTON, April 72 (AP)  Spain's Jose Higueras overcame a match point and defeated Gene Mayer in a controversial tiebreaker fora 63, 26, 76 Victory today in the final match Of the $175,000 World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: Banking Industry's Profitability
description: The nation's largest banking organizations have reported sharply higher earnings in the first quarter, but some analysts believe the industry's fundamental level of profitability has risen only moderately.

title: Neighbors Views on Atom Plants Unchanged by Accident
description: Blake Huttula can look out the back window of his pharmacy in the little Pacific Coast town of Elma, Wash., and see the concrete towers of the twin nuclear power plants that are being built two miles away.

title: Britons Attack Appeal by Carey For Pressure for Ulster Pullout
description: LONDON, April 22 (AP) British lawmakers reacted angrily today after Governor Carey of New York called for American pressure to forte of British troocs from Northern Ireland.

title: More on the SALT Cheating Problem
description: There has been another flap in Washington about whether the loss of two American monitoring stations in Iran will let the Russians cheat on the pending arms control agreement. C.I.A. Director Stanfield Turner told some Congressmen that it might take until 1984 to replace all the lost capacity. Defense Secretary Harold Brown then acknowledged that it would be at least 1983. But he also reported that enough capacity would be restored in about a year to verify adequately Soviet compliance with SALT II. Those who are not grasping at reasons to oppose the treaty should be reassured.

title: Trisha Ingersoll and Robert E. Rich Married
description: Patricia Dunham Ingersoll and Robert E. RIch were married yesterday at the Lake Mohonk Mountain House in New Paltz, N.Y. Town Justice Chester DuMont of Hurley, N.Y. performed the ceremony.

title: 2 French Car Makers Resist Ford
description: PARIS, April 22  France's two major automobile companies are stepping up their fight to stop the Ford. Motor Company from building a $1 billion assembly plant that would create 8,000 jobs in the depressed eastern region of France with the aid of generous Government subsidies.

title: Mexican Clinic Draws Americans Despite U.S. Doctors' Warnings
description: CALEXICO, Calif.  The Mexican hospitals aren't much to look at, said La Verne McCarville, who had come from his dairy farm in Wisconsin to get a new joint for his left knee. But they're clean and the food is Rood and the price is right.

title: Japan Plans ForeignBid Concession
description: TOKYO, April 22  In response to strong pressure from the United States, Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira announced over the weekend that, in advance of his May 2 visit to Washington to meet President Carter, Japan will make considerable concessions both in terms of quantity and quality on the issue of Japanese Government procurements abroad.

title: The Region
description: EDISON, N.J. (AP)  Human error probably caused last week's collision of an Amtrak Metroliner and a 32ton trackrepair vehicle, officials said.

title: David C. Radovsky Weds Deborah Post
description: Deborah Post and David Cort Radov. sky were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. Dr. and Mrs. Seymour C. Post in New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Morton Goldberg of Toledo, Ohio, the bridegroom's uncle.

title: Truck Industry Group Reports an Agreement In Steel Hauler Strike
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP)  Bargainers for the nation's big trucking companies said today that they had reached agreement with teamsters negotiators on a new contract for striking steel haulers, but there was no indication whether it would be accepted by the dissident union members.

title: Recital: Anna Teng, a Pianist
description: ALNNA TENG, a pianist from Japan, made her New York debut Saturday afternoon in Alice Tully Han. Since Miss Tang has played in many parts of the world for the last 10 years and apparently with success, perhaps this concert caught her on an off day.

title: Two Egos and Eight Weeks
description: UNTIL now, big egos of certain Yankees were obvi ous  George Steinbrenneras the big boss, Reggie Jackshon as the big bat, Thurman Munson as the big grouch and, when he was the manager, Billy Martin as the big brain. But every majorleague baseball player has a hig ego. It starts when he is small and the best ballplayer on his block. As he ascends to the big leagues. his eco ascends, too. It's almost a necessity. Formost players, it's positive element. Some people call it the pride of accomplishinent, but it boils down to ego. And more than anything else; ego is what created the clubhouse "stuffie, as the Yankees described it, between Rich Gossage and Cliff Johnson that will keep the husky righthanded relief pitcher out of the bull pen perhaps until midJune. He had surgery last night in New, York University Hospital to repair a torn ligament in bis right thumb.

title: Deborah R. Lebow Bride of Thomas Altier
description: Deborah Ruth Lebow, daughter of Estelle L Lebow of New York and the late Saul L. Lebow, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Read Altier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Altier of Rochester. State Supreme Court Justice Arnold L. Fein performed the ceremony at the New York home of the bride's mother.

title: Mondale Leaves for Washington After Parley With Dutch Leaders
description: AMSTERDAM April 22 (Reuters) Vice President Mondale left for home today after a 24hour official visit to the Netherlands and talks with Dutch leaders.

title: As Hair Dyes Change, Confusion and Complaints Abound
description: A tempest is brewing up in the dye pot. Since the National Cancer Institute released its 1977 report that certain chemicals in hair dyes caused cancer when fed to rats, the haircoloring companies have been quietly changing their forumulas, removing the suspected chemicals and substituting others.

title: The Stage: Beowulf, A Pageant, at La Mama
description: STAGESPACE, an experimental theater company from Boston, has brought a pageant based on Beowulf to La Mama E.T.C. It doesn't seem to be a very good idea. Even at its best, action on the stage is likely to embody the verbal images of an epic approximately as ashes embody fire.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Guy P. WyserPratte, the activist arbitrager for Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, vows to have a few things to say tomorrow at the annual meeting of McGrawHill Inc. And you can bet that most of it will concern the rejection by the big publishing company, headed by Harold W. McGraw Jr., of an acquisition bid made early this year by the American Express Company.

title: Rugby: Local Action Headed by Teacher
description: Five days a week during the academic year, Mike Liscovitz dons a suit. white shirt and tie and heads for Middletown (N.J.) High School, where he teaches English. But the weekends.... ah, that's another matter. The dress and demeanor associated with English instructors is left behind as he heads fora rugby field.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: L.A., the EnergySaver
description: WASHINGTON  America's loss of valuabl oil supplies from Iran has focused public attention once again on our pressing need to conserve energy. In response, the Department of Energy has asked for authority to impose mandatory controls on energy consumption, Including the possibility of closing gas stations on Sundays, regulating thermostats in public buildings and banning outdoor advertising lights.

title: 2 Die in Bosporus Ship Collision
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 22 (Reuters)  Two seamen were killed and five were reported missing when the 1,491ton Turkish cargo ship Kemal Kefeli sank last night after a collision with a Rumanian vessel passing through the Bosporus, the Turkish radio said today. The 16,604ton Rumanian ship, the Carpati, was on its way to the Black Sea. No casualties were reported among its crew.

title: U.S. Protests Treatment Of Reporter by Russians
description: MOSCOW, April 23 (Reuters)  The United States Embassy delivered strong protest to the Soviet Foreign Ministry today over the alleged drugging of a correspondent of an American news magazine in the Central Asian city of Tashkent last week. The protest was rejected.

title: O.E.C.D. Chief's 3d Term Tied to Turkey Aid Plan
description: PARIS, April 22  The United States and other major Western nations have agreed to reappoint Emile van Lennep to head the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development for a third term, thus enabling him to take charge of their joint plan to rescue Turkey from bankruptcy and the threat of political chaos, according to diplomatic sources.

title: Ishii Triumphs On Asian Golf Tour
description: TOKYO, April 22 (UPI)  Hiroshi Ishii of Japan shot a two-under-par 70 in the final round today to win a $100,000 international open golf tournament, the last on the Asian circuit.

title: Jane D. Bijur Is Married To Robert Rau in Jersey
description: Jane Dryfoos Bijur, widow of Justin H. Bijur, was married yesterday at her home in Elberon, N.J., to Robert Sturm Rau, a widower. Rabbi Joseph Goldman of Temple BethMiriam in Elberon performed the ceremony.

title: Opera: Two Fiddlers, For Children
description: WRITING a successful opera these days is difficult enough, but writing an opera for children is even harder. Some are too sophisticated, some are too simple, most are lust plain bad, and no one sees through thei r faults quicker than children. For some reason, British composers have found the right balance better than most Benjamin Britten, Malcolm Williamson and Gordon Crosse, for example perhaps because of the strong communityserving sense that runs through so much English music today.

title: Sports Briefs
description: The New York Athletic Club A team successfully defended its title in the Hughes Cup regatta yesterday. The 4mile event across Long Island Sound to the Orchard Beech Lagoon in the Bronx is the longest crew race in the United States.

title: First of FosterCare Forums
description: An 18member task force on fostercare Issues, set up at the request of Governor Carey, will hold the first of seven public forums statewide this Friday at Brooklyn

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: IN REMEMBRANCE: At St. Vartan's Cathedral, above, Armenian survivors commemorated massacre by Turks in 1915. At Temple EmanaEl on Fifth Avenue, candles were lighted at memorial for 1943 Warsaw Ghetto uprising.

title: Gasoline Drivers Authorize a Walkout; Tugs Still Idled
description: Another labor dispute threatened the New York metropolitan area yesterday as gasoline deliverers who refuel many local filling stations authorized their union to call a strike any time after their contracts expire April 30.

title: CARTER IS RETURNING TO FIGHTS OVER OIL, ECONOMY AND ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  President Carter returned here today after a 10day holiday, prepared to press his campaigns for a strategic weapons treaty with the Soviet Union and for measures to deal with inflation and energy.

title: Citizens' Panel Offers New Proposals to Aid City's Fiscal Situation
description: New York City has made significant progress in putting its fiscal house in order, but will require new approaches if it is to solve the problems and uncertainties it still faces, the Citizens Budget Commission said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS
description: The Economy

title: Golf: Watson Triumphs by 6 Shots
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 22  Tom Watson won the 27th annual Tournament of Champions today by shooting a twounderpar 70 in the final round fora 72hole total of 275.

title: It Was Clear Sailing Along the Hudson, All the Way to the Jersey Shore
description: A Sunday sailor navigated around Morton Street Pier in Greenwich Village yesterday, in one of many small boats taking advantage of clear skies and 70 degree temperatures. Visibility stretched for miles, and Hoboken's skyline was as clear as a view across the street. More fine weather is expected today.

title: Gunmen Rob Bus Passengers
description: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., April 22 (UPI) Three gunmen rubbed 19 passengers of more than $800 last night, shortly after the BiStats Transit Company bus departed from the Cabokia Race Track to return to St. Louis. The gunmen, who were among the the passengers, announced the holdup fired several shots into the ceiling of the bus. Susan Huegler, 21 years, of St. Louis, was slightly injured by a ricbocheting bullet, the police said.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 23, 1979

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: JERUSALEM  An official in Menacbem Begin's Government was talking about the Palestinians. The trouble Is, he said, that the good people, the ones we could trust with political responsibility, are not in the picture. If an Anwar Nuseibeh were there, we could make an arrangement in a minute ...

description: LOUISVILLE. Ky., April 22  The United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Kentucky will begin submitting evidence on the March 1976 Scotia Mine disaster to a Federal grand jury this week, according to an order by a Federal administrative law judge.

title: Letters

The sales, scheduied for today, are espected to be put off a least one week After receiving complaines from pro fessional liquidators holding the contract to dispose of the merchs6tdise, Federal Bankruptcy Coma ltlaim J. Galgay signed an other ?? retaking of inventeries.

title: Dance: Nina Wiener Presents Condor Material
description: WHAT do you think of when you thick of dancing? Some people may picture a ballerina in her toe shoes. Others may imagine a tap dancer clattering away or the bare feet of a modern dancer thumping the floor. These are certainly disparate images of dancing. But all suggest that dance is something for the feet.

title: Victor F. Obeck, 62; N. Y. U. Athletic Head, Was Football Player
description: Victor F. Obeck, a former professional football player and the athletic director at New York University for 10 years, died Saturday night after suffering a heart attack while visiting his family here. Mr. Obeck, who had homes in Manhattan and in Montreal, was 62 years old.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: PAGE PEOPLE At a new literary roundtable. series of discussions by writers and readers on 10 Monday evenings starting this evening at 5:30, a succession of authors, novelists, poets and reviewers will be guests in twohour meetings presented by the Academy of American Poets. The public is invited to the sessions at the Nathan Straus Young Adult Library section of the New York Public Library's Donnell Center, 20 West 53d Street, opposite the Museum of Modem Art. Carole Cook, poetry and fiction reviewer, will moderate the programs, which are titled New Books-Mostly New York.

title: Suns' Reserves Help Topple Kings, 10893
description: TEMPE, Ariz, April 22 (AP)  ThA Phoenix Suns, with their bench supplying 51 points, defeated the Kansas City Kings, 10893, in the National Basketball Association Western semifinal playoffs today.

title: Rodriguez Victor

title: Active Week for Treasury Borrowing
description: The Treasury will be active in the credit markets this week with plans to auction 13week and 26week bills today, twoyear notes tomorrow and 52week bills on Wednesday. In addition, it will disclose its quarterly refinancing plans on Wednesday.

title: The Hazards of Libel
description: The Supreme Count, whose libel decisions over years have given valuable protection to press freedoms, has now made it more hazardous to exercise those freedoms. It ruled the other day that when public figures sue for libel they can inquire deeply into the editorial thoughts and procedures of news organizations for evidence of bad motives.

title: Notes on People
description: It's no secret that Representative Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn is thinking about next year's Democratic nomination for United States Senator  along with many others  but she seems to be closer to removing the un from her status as an undeclared candidate.

title: Yanks Win; Goss age Has Surgery
description: Just a few hours after Ron Guidry defeated the Texas Rangers, 51, yesterday Rich Gossage had surgery on the torn ligament in his right thumb. The operation was performed last night at New York University Hospital by Dr. Charles P. Malone.

title: Visitors Wait in Vain at Some Prisons
description: STORMVILLE, N.Y., April 22 We are the victims, Pat Purcell was saying. Does anybody care about us? She was sitting on a lawn that slopes away from the Green Haven Correctional Facility here, having camped there since early morning after state troopers refused to let her enter the prison to visit a close friend.

title: Police in Northern Ireland Find 16 Bombs in an Electricity Plant
description: BELFAST. Northern Ireland, April 21 (Reuters)  The Northern Ireland police found a cache of 16 homemade bombs in the city of Londonderry late last night, a spokesman said.

title: Islanders Sweep, Gain Semifinal
description: CHICAGO, April 22  The New York Islanders got an outstanding effort from all their defensemen and from Billy Smith in goal; as they defeated the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, 31 and completed a fourgame sweep of the Stanley Cup quarterfinal hockey playoffs.

But neither really produced pieces that were up to their own best work.

title: U.S. Charges Dairy Coop
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) The Government has asked a Federal court to hold the nation's largest dairy cooperative in civil contempt for violating an antitrust settlement reached four years ago.

title: Port Police Tie Up Airport Traffic
description: Offduty Port Authority police officers, seeking a speedup of contract negotiations, staged trafficsnarling drive arounds at Kennedy International angla Guardia Airports last evening.Their protests added delays to takeoffs that had already been backed up by congestion on one of the busiest travel days of the year, and some travelers reportedly missed their flights.

title: Chess:
description: In the Louis D. Statham International Tournament in Lone Pine, Calif., Vikgor Korchnoi, the former world championship challeneer and the tourney favorite, was thrown for two losses and had to take a back seat to Grandmasters Vladimir Liberzon of Israel, Florin Gheorghiu of Rumania, Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia and Vlastimil Hort of Czechoslovakia. Each tallied 62 in the 73player Swisssystem event, dividing $35,500 in prizes.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Abbott Laboratories, Chicago, has named Robert A. Schoellhorn.chief executive officer, succeeding Edward J. Ledder, who continues as chairman. Mr. Schoelihorn will also remain president. Also announced was the appointment of James L Vincent as executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, April 24 GUGLIELMO MARCONI (Italian Line Cruises International). Left St. Thomas April 20: due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: KurdishTurkish Fighting Intensifies in Iranian Town
description: TEHERAN Iran, April 22  Fighting between Turkish and Kurdish minorities in the town of Naghadeh in western Azerbaijan Province intensified today, and the Government rushed troops to the area for possible use in the town.

title: Sanitationmen, Lacking Job Pride, Resign Themselves to Public's Scorn
description: A few nights ago, when Lou Formica was on his rounds collecting garbage, a heavy bag of trash sailed down from a high floor of an apartment house and crashed to the street, just missing him.

title: Penalties Weighed On Gossage, Johnson
description: While Rich Gossage lay in his bed in New York University hospital yesterday following surgery on his right thumb, the Yankees pondered two important matters:

title: ChineseAmericans Join Other Groups. In Campaign Against Opium Perfume
description: Will Yves Saint Laurent, Charles of the Ritz and the Squibb Corporation change the name of Opium, one of the country's bestselling fragrances, to Lotus or Enchantment or Jewel of the Orient?

title: June Griffith: Mature, and a Winner
description: For the last 10 years, quality quartermilers have been synonomous with Adelphi Universlty. This week at the Penn Relays, it will be a woman, June Griffith, Who is likely to be the center of attentions

title: EDUCATION
description: CHICAGO KARY HARRISON leaned over his desk the back row of a seventhgrade class at the May Elementary School here and dug into a series of short, mimeographed reading passages, including one about trained dogs and cats.

title: Illinois Man Is Held in Cleveland For Questions About 3 Murders
description: CLEVELAND, April 23 (UPI)  The police have arrested a Waukegan, Ill., man who was wanted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Illinois and Wisconsin authorities for questioning about three murders.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LEST WE FORGET The Friends' Meeting House at 15 Rutherford Place is one of the most handsome and tranquillooking landmark structures in lower Manhattan, dating from 1860. It is a restful sight indeed on a spring day, observed at leisure from a bench in the adjacent park at 15th Street and Second Avenue, an area where many older residents recall the horrors of World War II on European soil.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIP. NJ., April 23  John T. Connor, chairman and chief executive of the Allied Chemical Corporation, Called preposterous Federal charges,. that Robert E. Mulcahy; the company'd president, had conspired to defraud the Government with respect to income taxes owed for 1972 and 1973 by Chester Zabik, former purchasing manager of the General Tire and Rubber Company.

title: Orange Rain in the Crimea
description: MOSCOW, April 23 (AP)  Orange rain fell on the Crimean city of Yalta recently. Soviet scientists speculated that the clouds contained dust picked up in Turkey and carried across the Black Sea, the newspaper Trud said. It said about half an inch of rain left a thick layer of rustcolored dust.

title: Abrams Seeking $1 Million To Sue on Chemical Waste
description: ALBANY, April 23  Attorney General Robert Abrams said today that legal grounds exist for New York State to bring damage suits against companies whose dumping of toxic waste has created health hazards to the public. He asked Governor Carey for almost $1 million and subpoena power to pursue the legal action.

title: The Screen: A Vignette From India
description: "GHATASHRADDHA," an Indian film in the Museum of Modern Art's New Directors/New Films series, is set in the early 1940's and proceeds at a pace that might seem contemplative to a snail.A young boy, a Brahmin, is sent by his father to a Vedic school in southern India, where he is befriended by a beautiful widow, the schoolmaster's daughter. She is pregnant. The boy tries to help conceal her condition from the other students and the town busy-body. Finally, her secret is discovered and she undergoes an abortion, and the ritual of the title, an excommunication. She becomes an untouchable, the school closes down, and the boy is returned to his aristocratic family.All this is of considerably more anthropological than cinematic interest. The director, a 27-year-old Indian film school graduate named Girish Kasaravalli, offers considerable solemnity but few surprises. He uses outstandingly beautiful actors to play his admirable characters, and squat, shifty-eyed players for his villains. His command of the camera is at times barely rudimentary, and there is little visual variety to the film. Occasionally, the customs and the countryside on view are captured with admirable delicacy.But what sort of audience can a film like this expect to attract? The New Directors series is undeniably performing a worthy function in exhibiting a first film that would perhaps not be shown here otherwise, a film that could look a good deal better with hindsight some day.But for the time being, students of Indian cinema have at their disposal the masterpieces of Satyajit Ray, which turn up on the art-house circuit with great frequency, and the Bombay Cinema, which shows a wide spectrum of Indian commercial movies. "Ghatashraddha" demonstrates neither the artistry of the first nor the vitality of the second.

title: H.U.D. Sets 10% Mortgage Level
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) The Department of Housing and Urban Development has raised the maximum interest rate that will be allowed on Governmentinsured home mortgages to a record 10 percent. effective today.

title: Cash Prices
description: MONDAY, APRIL 23, 1979

title: Entertainment Events
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA, New York State Theater. Massenet's Mann, S.

title: Dissident U.M.W. Official Shot in Ohio
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  A member of the United Mine Workers' international executive board was shot and wounded this morning while driving here from Ohio to resist his ouster by the union's president. Arnold R. Miller.

title: Hospital's Chief In Bronx Ousted Following SitIn
description: Dr. Hugh F. Butts, director of the state's Bronx Psychiatric Center since 1974, staged an eighthour sitin at his office yesterday to resist a transfer. As a result, the State Mental Health Commissioner announced that Dr. Butts had been dismissed.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Cedar Point Inc., Sandusky, Ohiobased company whose properties include a summer resort and amusement park, marina, hotel and camper village, and gift shop chain, has named Robert L. Munger Jr. chairman, succeeding George A. Roose. Mr. Munger will continue as president and chief executive officer.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Why has the space shuttle been delayed, and when will it be launched?

title: Pianist: Karen Shaw
description: KAREN SHAW, who heads the piano department at Indiana University, has established her credentials as an admirable recitalist with several appearances here in the past. On Sunday afternoon she returned to Carnegie Hall, where she confirmed the reputation she has earned as a fully equipped technician and a persuasive interpreter of Romantic music.

title: Guards Against the Law
description: New York is a labor town. Local dairies have been closed for two months by a deliverers strike. The threeweekold tug strike has clogged the sanitation disposal system. Bus drivers still refuse to take the city's handicapped children to school. And there are now strike threats from gasoline deliverers and apartment maintenance personnel. But none of this adversity, even collectively, is as troubling as striking prison guards confronting National Guardsmen at gunpoint Sunday night on Staten Island.

title: Newspaper Publishers Cite Gains
description: Newspaper advertising revenues rose by 14 percent last year to almost $13 billion, daily newspaper circulation increased for the third year in a row and 200 weekly newspapers have started up since last year, members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association were told yesterday.

title: Dumb Aussies, They Say
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y.  While living in Australia, I discovered that banks do not return canceled checks. Having tossed away receipts on the assumption that our checks would come back, I asked the teller what evidence we would have for the tax department.

title: Blast at Jewish Center in Vienna Is Believed Work of Palestinians
description: VIENNA, April 23 (Reuters)  An exs plosion at a Vienna Jewish center last night, originally thought to be an attack by neoNazis, may have been caused by a Palestinian group, police sours said today.

title: Reitz of Cards Penalized $1,250 For Airport Event
description: ST. LOUIS, Apiil 23 (AP)  The St. Louis Cardinals third baseman, Ken Reitz, said today that his temper had cost him $1,250. The penalty stemmed from an incident that occurred April 11 during a 10hour rain delay at Lambert Airport here while the team was waiting to fly to Pittsburgh.

title: Appeals Court Reverses Westchester Housing Remedy
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday upheld a lowercourt finding that the northern Westchester town of New Castle had unconstitutionally excluded multifamily housing. But the court overturned a broad judicial order that the town allow the construction of 3,500 apartment units over the next 10 years.

title: Music: Apple Hill Group
description: FOR the last eight years. the Apple Hill Chamber Players have traveled to New York from their home base in southern New Hampshire for a series of concerts. The final one of the season took place Sunday night in Carnegie Recital Hall and it was notable for a number of reasons, not the least being the superior quality of the performances and the group's usual care in planning an interestingly diverse program.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, April 24

title: TV: What Made McCarthy Tick
description: THE phenomenon of Joseph R. McCarthy remains as disturbing as a mythic nightmare. Once again, tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13, the late Senator from Wisconsin is the subject of a biographical essay, and, once again, the story of his rise to terrifying power is fascinating.

title: Negotiators Intensify Their Efforts to Avert An Apartment Strike
description: Representatives of apartmenthouse owners and their service employees continued their contract talks early this morning in an intensified effort to avert a walkout at 3,000 apartment houses and cooperatives.

title: Surprise Winners Take National Book Awards
description: Any notion that the 30th National Book Awards would represent establishment thinking because of their sponsorship by the publishers' and booksellers' associations was shattered yesterday by the surprise winners and losersin the major categories.

title: Jets Defeat Nordiques, 63, In W.H.A. Playoff Opener
description: QUEBEC, April 23 (AP)  Bob Guindon scored twice in Winnipeg's fivegoal second period tonight, as the Jets posted a 63 victory over the Quebec Nordiques in the opener of their World Hockey Association semifinal playoff series.

title: Hancho Kim Pleads Not Guilty To Charge of Contempt of Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)  A Koreanborn American businessman pleaded not guilty today to a charge of contempt of Congress stemming from his refusal to answer a question from the House ethics committee, which was investigating the South Korean influencebuying scandal.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 24, 1979

title: Martin's to Close Fulton St. Store
description: Martin's, the 70.yearold apparel specialty store chain, will close its main store on Fulton Street in Brooklyn later this year as a result of longterm unprofitability, its parent company announced here yesterday.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Those who have raised questions in the past about the risks of nuclear power plants will not be surprised that the industry and its apologists have opened a counterattack following the nearcatastrophe at Three Mile Island. Theirs may be the most defensive special interest this side of the gun lobby.

title: Final J.M. Fields Sales Set
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge in New York yesterday approved an order setting Friday as the start of the fiveweek goingoutofbusiness sale for the 79 J. M. Fields Department Stores, a unit of Food Fair Inc. The start of the sale had been delayed because of a disagreement over the value of the inventory in the stores. Food Fair has been operating under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act since October 1978.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Leader of Rent Strike Finds His Home Gone To a Queens Thy Dock
description: John Boldt, who has led a rent strike of tenants at the 79th Streeploat Basin for the past six months, returhed from a trip to a Broadway selfservice laundry late yesterday afternoon to find that his abode  a 35foot, $25,000 fully equipped houseboat  had disappeared, along with his two. Siberian huskies and all the rest of his worldly possessions.

title: House Unit Sets Import Injury Rule
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  The House Ways and Means Committee announced today that it had voted to require domestic industry to show material injury before getting import relief. The action sets up a conflict with the Senate Finance Committee and raises prospects of a HouseSenate struggle over a key American trade concession.

title: ADULT SPECIALS SET FOR CABLE SYSTEMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  Ted Turner, Atlanta's flamboyant sportsman and broadcaster, announced today that he would present primetime adult programs on his satellite network for cable television systems and offer news and daily children's shows for the first time.

title: 3 Leave Turkish Premier's Party, Threatening His Narrow Majority
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 23 (AP) Three members of Parliament resigned from Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit's Republican People's Party today, seriously undermining the Government's slim majority in the 450seat National Assembly.

title: Quake Jars Much of Israel
description: TEL AVIV, April. 23 (AP)  An earthquake shook Israel today but caused no injuries or major damage, the Israeli radio reported. The tremor extended from Tiberias in the north to Beersheba in the south and from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, according to the Seismological Institute of Hebrew University.

title: Fink, Citing Study, Reconsiders Legalizing Casinos
description: ALBANY, April 23  Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink said today that he had second thoughts about whether casino gambling should be legalized in New York State, following a special study panel's report that gambling would provide the state government with relatively little new income.

title: $100,000 Art Theft at Church
description: Four tapestries from the 16th and 17th centuties, valued at more than $100,000, were stolen last week from the walls of St. Thomas Episcopal Church on Fifth Avenue at 53d Street. Thieves entered the church during the night after prying open a stainedglass window, the police said.

title: OBSERVER Groceries From Heaven
description: A raw potato fell out of the sky and shattered on the sidewalk. The sound of its impact and the tiny fragments into which it exploded suggested it came from considerable height.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN a recent Jules Feiffer cartoon strip, an assistant professor of Karl Marx is telling his class about Southeast Asia  the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia, the Chinese invasion of Vietnam and so on. In the last panel of the cartoon, the assistant professor explains: History will prove that none of this happened.

title: ISRAELIS HINT PLO. FACES NEW REPRISAL
description: QIRYAT TIVON, Israel, April 23As the victims of the latest Palestinian terrorist attack were buried today, Israeli leaders hinted that more reprisals would be made against Palestinian guerrillas. [United Press International reported from Beirut that Israeli gunboats bombarded Palestinian targets along the Lebanese coast Tuesday. The report, quoting Arab reporters on the scene, said three people were wounded in the attack. The Israeli Army refused to comment on the reported attack.]

title: Deaths
description: ALLENOlive Trowbridge. Capt, U.S. Army Ret, of East Sandwich, Mass. April 22. Aunt of Eleanor len Narkis of Louisville. Ky and Samuel Allen of Madison, Wisc. Funeral services Friday. April 27 at 11am in St Andrew and Holy Com munion Church. So. Orange, N.J.

title: For Spurs Kenon, Big Payoff Will Be After Playoffs
description: Eddie Donovan, Red Holzman and Fuzzy Levane were in Philadelphia last Friday to watch the National Basketball Association playoff series between the 76ers and the San Antonio Spurs. Donovan, the Knick general manager. said he was there: with the coach and the scout just to watch the game.

title: Phillies and Cardinals Triumph in 10 Innings
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (AP) Mike Schmidt's single with one out in the 10th inning scored Larry Bowe and gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 43 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight in the first 1979 meeting of last season's National League division champions.

title: Notes on People
description: Alvin Alley didn't mind confessing that he was well, nervous. I hate this kind of thing. It makes you assess, and all that kind of stuff.

title: Strikes in Brazil Test the Resolve Of Army to Restore Civilian Rule
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 23  Eleven thousand public school teachers in Brasilia walked off the job today, joining hundreds of thousands of Brazilians already idled in a series of strikes that are sorely testing the military Government's resolve to return the country to civilian rule and democratic institutions.

title: Clerc, Argentina, Takes South Africa Tennis Final
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 23 (UPI) JoseLuis Clerc of Argentina put on a controlled display of baseline power play today to defeat Deon Joubert of South Africa, 62, 61, in the final of the South African oven tennis tournament.

title: EARNINGS
description: Two tobacco industsy leaders reported higher profits yesterday. R.J. Reynolds Industries had a 38.3 percent rise, while American Brands Inc. had a 24.6 percent gain. Both said they had been helped by diversification outside the tobacco industry.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: After Gary L. Seevers, acting chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, announced his resignation yesterday, effective June 1, he said in a telephone interview that he did it for positive reasons, not negative reasons.

title: Trial Opens In Murder of Mayor And Supervisor in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23  Dan White, 32 years old, former policeman, fireman, paratrooper and San Francisco supervisor, went on trial today, accused of murdering Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk.

title: Jerseyan Seeks 2d Seat on Council
description: PASSAIC, N.J., April 23  In a move that could set a precedent for hundreds of municipalities throughout the state, a City Councilman here is running for a new fouryear termeven though he still has two years to serve on his current term.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 24, 1979

title: Princeton Poll Reports Over a Third Have Cheated
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 23  More than a third of Princeton University undergraduates have cheated on an examination at least once during their college careers, according to a controversial copyrighted poll conducted by The Daily Princetonian, a campus newspaper. The survey's methodology was immediately attacked by administrators and the student body president when it was released yesterday.

title: Life May Exist Only On Earth, Study Says
description: ASTANDING scientific assumption that the universe abounds With advanced, humanlike civilizations Is encountering a challenge from a small but growing number of astronomers.

title: After The Dam Broke
description: WASHINGTON  In the days before Vietnam and Watergate. Americans took on the world's problems with a selfassurance born of good intention. We were the world's innocents, idealistic in our viewpoint and charitable in our intent. We may not always have been right but we seldom faltered for lack of conviction.

title: American Express Meets
description: More than 500 stockholders of the American Express Company attended the company's annual meeting yesterday, but few asked questions in the twohour session and fireworks expected over an unsuccessful bid for McGrawHill Inc. failed to materialize. McGrawHill will hold its own annual meeting today.

title: First Iran Army Chief In Khomeini's Regime Is Slain by 3 Gunmen
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 23  Three unidentified gunmen today killed the Iranian general who was appointed the first army Chief of Staff after the revolution last February.

title: Woolworth Talks Ended, Revco Drug Chain Says
description: Revco D.S. Inc., the country's largest drugstore chain, said yesterday that the preliminary merger talks with the F.W. Woolworth Company that were announced last week had been terminated.

title: Pan Am Had Lower Deficit in Quarter
description: Pan American World Airways reported yesterday a net loss of $8,9 million for the first quater of this year, its lowest firstquater loss since 1968.

title: A Fiery Leader In Union Ranks.
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  Peter Charles Bonunarito is not easily scared. The White House is learning that.

title: Furs by the Numbers
description: The days are gone when a woman  any womanwill buy clothes that will Just last a season. If they buy a fur. it should last five years. maybe longer.

title: Plant Restrictions Voted
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 23 (UPI) A Pennsylvania Senate committee approved a bill today that would halt new nuclear power plant construction in the state until the Federal authorities could inspect and certify the facilities and develop a plan to dispose of radioactive waste.

title: Haig Urges New U.S. Leadership Role
description: The United States must provide a new kind of leadership to challenge Soviet intervention in the third world, General. Alexander M. Haig Jr. said yesterday.

title: 10 Mines closed by Pickets
description: STEARNS. Ky., April 23 (AP)  Ten mines in Kentucky and Tennessee were dosed today by pickets protesting tentative settlement of a threeyearold strike against the Stearns Mining Company. according to the Bituminous Coal Operators Association

title: John Wayne Is Hospitalized
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., April 23 (AP) John Wayne, the actor, was hospitalized last week for treatment of bronchitis, a spokesman for Hoag Memorial Hospital said today. The spokesman said Mr. Wayne, still recuperating from recent cancer surgery, was expected to be released in a few days.

title: Stage: BlackEyed Susan Wed to Enchanted Pig
description: IMAGINE if you can a cross between King Lear and The Frog Prince, with a slipper from Cinderella and a twist of The Three Sisters, and you have an approximation of The Enchanted Pig, Charles Ludlam's delirious new merriment. This comedy, which opened Sunday at the Ridiculous Theatrical Company's home at 1 Sheridan Square, is clean and campfree. R should appeal both to wideeyed adults and sophisticated children.

title: BRITISH UNDER FIRE BY IRISHAMERICANS
description: A number of IrishAmerican politicians in recent weeks have intensified their criticism of British policy in Northern Ireland.

title: Champion Soviet Skaters To Return to Competition
description: MOSCOW, April 23 (Reuters) Irina Rodnina, the Soviet figure skater, plans to return to competition with her husband and partner, Aleksandr Zaitsev, to defend their Olympic title at the 1980 Winter Games in Lake Placid, N.Y., it was reported today in Izvestia, the Soviet newspaper.

title: Prison Doctors Confront Stigmas and Stereotypes
description: He is a New York physician caring part time for city prisoners on Rikers Island. But he also has a promising private practice in Manhattan, and he did not want his name mentioned. He did not want to be stigmatized, he said. He was not going to risk losing any of his private patients or losing face with colleagues.

title: ArmsControl Aide Warns of NewWeapons Race
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  An armscontrol official said today that development of particlebeam and highenergy weapons that instantly destroy incoming enemy missiles could lead to a new strategic arms race with unsettling military and political implications.

title: Walkout at The Journal in Elizabeth Enters 10th Day
description: Bill Earls, foreground, a striking columnist for The Daily Journal, writing for interim newspaper in Elizabeth, N.J., yesterday. Strikers hope to make paper an alternative to The Journal, which continues to publish an abbreviated version despite 10dayold strike by 100 editorial and advertising personnel and drivers. Yesterday's Journal advertised for new employees, while union leaders claimed continued harassment by outoftown strikebreakers.

title: Deaths
description: DUFFYMary Ellen (nee McGarrell ), native of County Monaghan, Ireland. Beloved wife of Patrick J.. mother of Marie Heslin, Patricia McKeon and Kevin Thomas, sister of Katherine Judge, Thomas, Margaret Conroy and In Ireland, Michael. Also survived by 14 grandchildren and are greatgrandchild. Family will receive friends from 25 and 79 PM al Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232nd St., Bronx. Funeral Mass St. John's Church, Wednesday 10:30 AM. In ferment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Mets Get Hard Workout As They Brace for Giants
description: As if they didn't have enough trouble, the Mets came off the road yesterday and braced for the season's first wave of western power that arrives tonight with undefeated Vida Blue and the San Francisco Giants.

title: Coast Faces Newsprint Cuts Again
description: LOS ANGELES, April 23  West Coast newspapers, many of which have already been forced to cut their size and circulation because of a newsprint shortage, are bracing for a potential strike in Canadian mills that could restrict supplies even further.

title: Harrington Is Hofstra Coach
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 23  Joe Harrington, an assistant to Lefty Driesell at the University of Maryland for the last 10 years, was named basketball coach at Hofstra University today.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a local government can constitutionally forbid a charity to solicit funds unless the organization can prove that most of the money goes for charitable purposes.

title: Kennedy, Near a Defeat, Delays Antitrust Vote
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  In danger of losing a first major test of strength as chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Senator Edward M. Kennedy postponed today until May 8 a vote on an antitrust bill that shapes up as a major battleground between business and consumers.

title: As Population Nears a Billion, China Stresses Curbs
description: WUXI, China, April 18  A large pink chart on the wall of the clinic of the Xihung production brigade near this industrial city advertises how each local official is complying with what may be China's most important campaign, birth control.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The bond market, concerned that the Federal Reserve is not moving more forcefully against inflation and apprehensive about the impact of a possible 40year Treasury bond issue, lurched uncertainly yesterday toward higher vields and lower prices.

title: Movie: Feminist Film From Germany
description: "THE All-Round Reduced Personality" is the first fiction feature to be made by Helke Sander, the German director and actress who here is also her own star. The feminist film, as earnest and clear and chilly as its elegant black-and-white photography, is about Edda (Miss Sander), a still photographer in West Berlin, and her struggles both to support herself and her child and to realize herself as an artist and a woman. If that sounds a bit grim, it's meant to.Miss Sander apparently equates seriousness with a kind of pinched humorlessness that passes for irony. For much of the film Edda exists in an enclave within an enclave, dealing mostly with other women photographers and occasionally with male editors who are out to exploit feminism for profit. She has an affair with a young man named Werner whom she uses as a sex object, but it is as unsatisfactory as it is brief. Edda desires something more than a pretty face.The photography by Katia Forbert is the most interesting aspect of the film. As its heroine moves through her half of the divided city of Berlin, "The All-Round Reduced Personality" looks out at the scenery and, like Edda, often frowns at what it sees. The movie is very bossy in its displeasure. Watching it is like seeing the world through the disapproving eyes of Charlie Brown's long-time companion and critic, Lucy."The, All-Round Reduced Personality" is not unintelligent. It cares about the world but it is unable to communicate much except its own discreet superiority.Miss Sander, who looks a lot like Annie Girardot, is an attractive actress and is unexpectedly charming in her scenes at home with her child, which are not many since Edda must spend so much time away from home realizing herself.Also on the bill is a short, funny, irreverent Brazilian film, "Tropical Fruit," made by Joaquim Pedro de Andrade, the director of "Macuniama" and "Guerra Conjugal." A send-up of a certain kind of academe, "Tropical Fruit" is about a pompous graduate student who has one teeny-tiny quirk: He likes to make love to watermelons.As he confides to a sympathetic young woman, he is not "addicted" to watermelons, "just accustomed." Because his obsession is limiting (and because there are "seasonal problems"), the young woman tries to broaden his horizons by persuading him to test various other kinds of melons as well as vegetables. "Tropical Fruit" is that rare commodity  a movie with a happy ending.The program will be presented in the New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art today at 6 P.M. and tomorrow at 8:30 P.M.

title: Soviet Six Nearing World Title
description: MOSCOW, April 23  Two streaks continued at the world hockey championship today as Canada lost again and the Soviet Union cruised to another overwhelming victory.

title: Hobart Moves to No. 1 After Big Lacrosse Upset
description: Hobart College's lacrosse team came of age last ,Saturday. The Statesmen, characterized as young and inexperienced when the season began, crushed the most powerful Syracuse squad in vears.164.

title: Sol A. Pearl, Wrote Under Name S. Almazov for Morning Freiheit
description: Sol A. Pearl. who wrote under the name S. Almazov for The Morning Freiheit, a Yiddishlanguage newspaper, died Friday at Cabrini Health Care Center in New York after a long illness. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 8 Hurt in Upstate Blast Of a Dynamite Truck
