description: A truck loaded with dynamite caught fire and exploded at a quarry east of Buffalo yesterday, injuring about eight workers and blowing out windows of homes and businesses over an area of several square miles. Two of the injured were hospitalized but their conditions were described as not serious.

title: Coalition Forms Panel to Oppose Separate Education Department
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)  A coalition of education, research, labor and civil rights activists announced today the formation of a committee to oppose the creation of a separate education department.

title: United Airlines Talks Resume
description: DENVER, April 23 (UPI)  Negotiations between United Airlines and the striking International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers resumed today for the first time in nearly three weeks. The strike by 18,000 mechanics and other ground crew workers began March 31 and has grounded the airline, which transports about 160,000 passengers daily. All flights have been canceled through May 5.

title: CheckingInterest Hearings Planned
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)  A House Banking subcommittee announced today it would hold hearings to draft legislation providing clear authority for consumers to receive interest on a variety of checking accounts. Such interestbearing checking accounts were ruled illegal on Friday by the United States Court of Appeals.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY. APRIL 23. 1979

title: Billy Carter Says He's Reformed And Vows Never to Drink Again
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 23  Calling himself a reformed alcoholic who had gone without alcohol for 60 days, Billy Carter, President Carter's brother, said today that he expected to be discharged Friday from the Long Beach Naval Hospital's alcohol rehabilitation service.

title: Legislators Facing Battle Over Details of a Levy as Support Increases
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  Many members of Congress voiced strong support today for a tax on oil company profits that would flow in once prices are allowed to rise on June 1. But sharp divisions remained over how the tax should be applied.

title: Frisbees Fly at Special Olympics Luncheon
description: Eunice Kennedy Shriver, above, president of Special Olympics, demonstrating championship frisbee form at 8th annual luncheon yesterday at Tavern the Green. Participants in sports program, the largest in the country for mentally retarded youngsters, also received frisbees. Many sports personalities attended event, held as prelude to International Special Olympics in August.

title: The Catch in DoItYourself Power
description: Should industrial and commercial firms in New York City be allowed to drop out of Con Edison's electrical network if they can produce their own power more cheaply? A few office buildings. manufacturers and apartment complexes have already cut loose and are installing diesel generators to light, heat, and cool their structures. Con Ed fears that hundreds of big users of electricity will find such selfsufficiency seductive: Public officials have only begun to address the perplexing issues that the idea raises. There is reason to doubt the benefit of any extensive switch to onsite generation.

title: Science Watch
description: Paul A. Johnston, a geologist at the University of Alberta in Canada, has concluded from a study of the rings in dinosaur teeth that those enigmatic old reptiles were, in fact, coldblooded.

title: 3 Strikers at S.I. Prison Charged With Menacing
description: Three striking state correction officers were arrested on Staten Island last night and accused of brandishing their pistols during a confrontation with National Guardsmen there Sunday evening.

title: Aides at Nuclear Agency Favor Closing 4 Reactors
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  Two senior technicians of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission recommended today that the commission reverse an earlier decision and shut down nuclear power reactors made by the Babcock & Wilcox Company, which designed the reactor involved in last month's accident in Pennsylvania.

title: Gas Kills 3 Men, Fells 5 Rescuers In a Park on L.I.
description: ELMONT, L.I., April 23  Three construction workers were killed today in a gasfilled drainage hole in Elmont Road Park and five other men, including four policemen, were overcome in efforts to rescue them.

title: Bridge:
description: England's famed Grand National Steeplechase was once won, in fiction, by a piebald horse ridden by Velvet Brown, a determined girl disguised as a boy. But in real life there are few recorded examples of transsexual victories: The Gentleman's Singles in Wimbledon tennis has never been won by a woman.

title: America's Technological Lag
description: For years, American industry has dominated the world market for everything from passenger jets and computers to oildrilling equipment. But Government officials and industrial executives have been growing worried about technological development. Now, President Carter has ordered a comprehensive study of how official policies affect industrial innovation, and pleading with Congress not to cut his budgetary request for basic science research funds.

title: Nevada Woman Says Nuclear Fallout Made Family Guinea Pigs
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 23 (AP)  A woman whose ranch was in the path of fallout from nuclear tests in the 1950's stood before a joint Congressional committee today and declared that she and her family were forgotten guinea pigs.

title: Rent Board Bars Fuel Surcharges In Some Houses
description: The New York City Rent Guidelines Board, which twice this month has raised the level of allowable rent increases in 300,000 rentstabilized apartments, voted yesterday against the adding of fuel surcharges to rents in about 200,000 other apartments.

title: Rangers, Islanders Cash In on Defense
description: More than anyone, the Rangers  if they have a sense of their history at all should know that strange things happen in the playoffs.

title: U.S. Team Arrives in Pyongyang
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea, April 23  The 42member delegation of the United States table tennis team arrived in this spotless capital today, the first Americans to visit North Korea in nine years.

title: Amin Said to Stay in Iraq 2 Days, Then Fly to Unknown Destination
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 23 (Reuters) Idi Amin spent two days in Baghdad last week but has disappeared since then, Arab diplomatic sources said tonight.

title: HERBERT H. PENSIG, LABOR AYER, DIES
description: Herbert H. Pensig, a labor lawyer who was chairman of the Garment Trucking Industry, a bargaining and administrative association for employers and employees in the Garment District, died of pneumonia Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 63 years old.

title: World News Briefs
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 23 (Reuters)  Secessionist guerrilla groups fighting against Ethiopian rule said today that they had killed 1,100 Ethiopian and Cuban soldiers in separate battles.

title: Restaurant Tipping: More Questions, More Controversy
description: An article on tipping that appeared in these pages recently raised hackles , and some serious issues as well. The story dealt with the problems of tipping.in full service, deluxe restaurants, the kind that employ headwaiters , captains and wine stewards as well as waiters. Most people visit such places once a year or, as one reader put it. once in a lifetime:

title: Radio
description: 9:0610, WQXR: Piano Personallties. Piano Sonata in F. Sibelius; Passacaglia, Copland; Bagatelles, Nos. 10 through 14, Bartok.

title: OldTime Trainer Finds New Life in Old Trotter
description: WESTBURY, L I., April 23  There aren't too many of them left. the oldtime hardboot trainers who have kept from being swept up in the flood of dollars that Us engulfed harness racing for two decades.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, April 23, 1979

title: Indians Give and Take Citations Over Fishing
description: SWANTON, Vt., April 23 (AP) Abenaki Indians and wardens of the state Fish and Game Department have traded citations on the banks of the Missisquoi River in Swanton.

title: GROUP TAXI RIDING, 2STREET AUTO BAN PROPOSED BY KOCH
description: A transportation program that would close two midtown streets in New York City to all traffic but buses and taxis from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. and that would encourage group cab riding to and from city airports was announced yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: 4 Hurt in Du Pont Plant Blast
description: NEWPORT, Del., April 23 (AP)  An explosion at the Du Pont Company plant last night injured four persons, none seriously, and sent a red ball of smoke into the sky, company officials said. The explosion occurred in a piece of filtering equipment used to filter red pigment, the plant manager, Ralph Fortney, said. He said there was no extensive damage to the plant.

title: Corporations Report Their Sales and Earnings Results for the Quarter
description: See notes below for special items

title: 24 Seized While Trying  to Block S.I. School Buses
description: Twentyfour striking schoolbus drivers and matrons were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct outside the Staten Island Bus Company, a nonunion shop, yesterday morning. They had tried to block 75 vans from leaving the garage.

title: Armco Net Surges 93.4% for Quarter
description: Armco Inc., the nation's fifthlargest steel company, yesterday reported earnings for the first quarter of $58.4 or $1.27 a share, a 93.4 percent increase over last year's firstquarter earnings of $30.2 million, or 64 cents a share.

title: U.S. Uncertain on Implications
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  The United States had no official comment today on the decision by Kuwait and Saudi Arabia to break diplomatic relations with Egypt, and officials speaking in private expressed uncertainty about the implications of the moves.

title: Deaths
description: McCARTHYTIMOTHY. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Timothy McCarthy. associated with The Times from 1952 until retiring In 1973.

title: Recital: Viktor Tretyakov, Violinist
description: VIKTOR TRETYAKOV, that most elegant of violinists, found a novelty to open his Carnegie Hall recital last night. With the exuberant Mikhail Erokhin at the piano, he played the Brahms Violin Sonata No. 2 in E flat., Thus it was described on the program, and it was a bit of a shocker. An E flat Violin Sonata by Brahms? A newly discovered work?

title: Pyotr N. Pospelov, a Pravda Editor And Party Theoretician, Dies at 80
description: Pyotr Nikolayevich Pospelov, a principal theoretician of the Soviet Communist Party who led many of the cold war's verbal assaults on the West, has died at the age of SO, according to an official announcement in Moscow.

title: About New York An Anatomist Presses On in His Quest
description: The city's medical schools are planning for the fall term, gleaning applications and counting bodies, and the anatomy professors figure they are about 300 cadavers short for the coming year.

title: Memorial for Dr. Ettinghausen
description: A memorial service for Dr. Richard Etting,hausen, a leading authority on Islamic art who was consultative chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's department of Islamic art, will be held Saturday at 3 P.M. at the chapel of Princeton University, in Princeton, N.J. Dr. Ettinghausen died on April 2.

title: Market Place
description: DISCOUNT bonds, perennial stepchildren of the taxexempt municipal bond market, are finding new support in the wake of the Tax Reform Act of 1978.

title: Latins Cite Trade Barriers
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 23  Latin America's developing countries strongly condemned today what they perceived as the growing protectionist barriers to their exports raised by the United States, Europe and Japan.

title: AN AMERICAN MISSION ON VISIT TO UGANDA
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, April 23.A fiveman delegation representing the Government of the United States arrived here today from Kenya on a goodwill mission to the new Government of Uganda.

title: Bonn Said. to Try to Prevent a Feared Palestinian Raid
description: BONN, April 23 Antiterrorist experts from West Germany have met in Beirut with leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization in an unusual attempt to head off what they fearedwould d be a,terrorist attack against officials or property hire, aqualified West German said today.

title: Steel Haulers Pledge to Stay Out; 3 Strikers Shot by a Truck Driver
description: Three striking steel haulers were shot yesterday near Youngstown, Ohio, after they attempted to block a truck carrying steel. The incident occurred as rebellious steel haulers in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters vowed to remain on strike unless they were allowed to vote separately on contract terms for their category of drivers.

title: U.S. Swimmers Defeat A West German Team
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 23  Fifteenyearold Cynthia Woodhead set one American record in winning two individual events Sunday as the United States dominated West Germany in a dual swim meet.

title: Exxon Net Rose 37.4% In Quarter
description: The Exxon Corporation and the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), two of the nation's largest oil companies, reported sizable profit increases yesterday, stemming in part from the higher oil prices that resulted from the revolution in Iran.

title: Some Orange Juice for Bobby
description: Ten years ago Bobby Sheehan was a prospect. He still is. But maybe this time he'll stick. Maybe this time he'll escape his reputation as a hard drinker that has shadowed him throughout his hockey travels. After a long season with the minorleague New Haven Nighthawks, the 30yearold center is up with the New York Rangers, who can qualify for the Stanley Cup semifinals against the New York Islanders by eliminating the Philadelphia Flyers tonight in their fourofsevengame series. Bobby Sheehan has been in hockey for 10 years, but it wasn't until Sunday night's 60 triumph that he scored his first Stanley Cup goal. That's something to celebrate. But when he finally came out of the shower with a towel around his middle, he reached past several cans of cold beer and poured him self a big cup of orange juice. Perhaps that cup of orange juice tells;more about Bobby Sheehan than anything he tells about himself.

title: Computer Synthesizes Music of the Spheres
description: WILLIE RUFF, an associate professor of music at Yale University, sat a guest at the desk chair in his woodpanelled office and placed two small loudspeakers on her shoulders. He explained that with the speakers touching bone, the music he was about to play would go through your entire body, and that a speaker by each ear was a sure way to get the full stereo effect.

title: Research Finds Greeks Used Solar Energy
description: THE 1970's search for alternative energy sources had a counterpart some 2,500 years ago in Greece and Rome, according to three California researchers, who say the impetus for the search then was a shortage of wood not oil.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Slide
description: Rates on United States Treasury bills dropped unusually sharply yesterday in response to the Federal Reserve's apparent decision last week not to tighten monetary policy.

title: Explosives Found Near Soweto
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 23 (Reuters)  Explosives were found planted across four tracks of a main rail line near the black township of Soweto today, railway policemen said. They said a detonator was dismantled.

title: Jersey. Assembly Votes Rise in Mortgage  Cap From 9% to 10%
description: TRENTON, April 23  The New Jersey Assembly voted today to allow mortgage rates charged by State banks to rise to 10 percent in an effort to start home loans flowing again.

title: TV: How Fares the Grand Jury?
description: THERE ought to be an incometax rebate for watching a program like The Grand Jury: An Institution Under Fire, which is being presented from 10:30 to midnight tonight on Channel 13.

title: New York Golden Gloves Team Beats Chicago, 92
description: Chicagoans had a miserable winter this year with record snowfalls. And last night at Madison Square Garden, the city's amateur boxing team was also buried  in a barrage of punches  as the New York team won the 37th Intercity Golden Gloves competition, 9 bouts to 2.

title: JOBPROGRAM CURBS IRK CATHOLIC BISHOP
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)  A Roman Catholic official has expressed grave concern about proposed Federal actions that could drastically cut church participation in a major Government jobtraining program.

title: Calls Bid for Plowback of Profits an Attempt to Hoodwink Public
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  President Carter said today that public support of his energy plan had led Congressional opponents to try to hoodwink The American people by passing a windfall profits tax that is in fad a charade.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: The Region
description: MADISON, Conn.,  Two students were killed and a third severely injured early yesterday when fire swept through the dormitory at, the Grove School, a private school for boys with learning disabilities or emotional problems.

title: Fidrych Pitches 6 Innings As Tigers Win Exhibition
description: DETROIT, April 23 (AP)  Mark (The Bird) Fidrych gave up four hits and two runs in six innings for Detroit as the Tigers muted the Cincinnati Reds, 143, tonight in an exhibition game.

title: Amherst Suspends 72 Protesters
description: AMHERST, Mass., April 23 (AP)The president of Amherst College suspended 72 students today after members of the Black Student Union and sympathizers chained themselves inside the main administration building.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter said opponents of his energy plan had shifted their strategy from outright opposition to an effort to create enough loopholes to make the proposed oil windfall profits tax meaningless. He charged that the Congressional opposition was trying hoodwink the public with a tax that he called a charade. [Page AL]

title: Disks: The Planets Are Not Candidates For the Hit Parade
description: The cosmic heartbeat, the music of the spheres, Johannes Kepler himself reduced to computerderived intervals after his own formulas, can now be experienced on an LP disk. Two professors from Yale, helped by a computer, have set it all to music, sort of. They have brought out a record cm, appropriately. the Kepler label, on which the music of the planets in their orbits can be heard.

title: About Education
description: A ONEHOUR closedcircuit television program will be broadcast by satellite today to some 60 public television stations as a preview of a series in which 3 million fifthgrade and sixthgrade students in the United States and Canada will be taught how to think, reason and apply their classroom knowledge to the outside world.

title: Kriek Upsets Ashe
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 23 (AP) Johan Kriek of South Africa upset seventhseeded Arthur Ashe, 61, 63, today in the first round of a $250,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament. The 21yearold Kriek dominated the 58minute match as Ashe, 35, had problems with his service. Winds gusted up to 25 miles per hour during today's play.

title: GasPrice Ceiling Reportedly Studied
description: The Energy Department is leaning toward a fixed price ceiling on gasoline to eliminate overcharging at the pump, but the move could cost motorists 5 cents more a gallon, a petroleum newsletter said yesterday. The Lundberg Letter said that any uniform ceiling price Would tend to become the minimum price as well.

title: Eagles Appoint Gillman
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (UPI) Sid Gillman, a professional football coach for 18 years, has joined the Philadelphia Eagles as an assistant, the team said today.

title: Chinese Report Arrests Of Group in Vast Fraud
description: PEKING, April 23 (Reuter)  A gang of embezzlers who bribed scores of officials has been arrested in one of the biggest Chinese corruption scandals under Communist rule, the People's Daily said today.

title: 76 Vietnamese Head for U.S.
description: KUALA LUMPUR. Malaysia, April 23 (Reuter)  The last group of 76 Vietnamese refugees from a stranded freighter left today for Bangkok on their way to the United States for resettlement.

title: In France, a Rare Evening of Lavish Consumption
description: TROUVILLE, France, April 22Princesse Ghislaine de Polignac, who makes a business of getting people to parties, what she calls Custom PR, said that It was never so easy.

title: Dr. Archibald S. Dean, PublicHealth Official
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 23Dr. Archibald S. Dean, retired head of the Department of Public Health of Western New York State and former professor at the State University of New York at Buffalo, died Saturday following a short illness. He was 84 years old and had lived here since 1978, when he moved from Buffalo.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Taxes
description: WHEN an employer purchases a taxsheltered annuity for an employee and the employee then takes out a loan against it, is the loan considered income?

title: Advertising
description: HORIZON magazine is publishing issue by issue in the black, according to Gray Davis Boone, its editor and publisher since last September. It is a claim that her predecessors at the 21yearold magazine could rarely make as the publication went from a hardcover monthly magazine to a hardcover quarterly to a softcover quarterly to a softcover monthly, and from one owner to another.

title: Astronomy Is Puzzled By Oddity In the Sky
description: SOMETHING in the Milky Way that last December was described as.he Mast bizarre object in the sky, under further Observation appears to be even more outlandthh, simultaneously flying toward and away from die earth at speeds as great as 30,000 miles a second.

title: Kings' Ford Tops AllRookie Team
description: Phil Ford of the Kansas City Kings was the only unanimous choice for the National Basketball Association's allrookie team selected by the the league's coaches.

title: The City
description: The narcotics convictions of Leroy (Nicky) Barnes and 10 codefendants were affirmed by a divided appeals court. Mr. Barnes is serving a life sentence on charges that he headed a ring that sold millions of dollars worth of heroin in Harlem.

title: I.T.T. Cites Low Rates in New System
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation formally introduced its domestic longdistance telephone service yesterday at rates that it said were significantly below those of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company but comparable to those of two other competitors.

title: U.S. Protests Treatment Of Reporter by Russians
description: MOSCOW, April 23 (Reuters)  The United States Embassy delivered a strong protest to the Soviet Foreign Ministry today over the alleged drugging of a correspondent of an American news magazine in the Central Asian city of Tashkent last week. The protest was rejected.

title: Tugboat Union Reported Prepared To Carry Garbage to Staten Island
description: Sanitation Commissioner Normal Steisel said yesterday that the union of the striking tugboat crewmen had agreed to let its members comply with a court order that they resume taking New York City's garbage to a Staten Island landfill. But last night it remained uncertain whether the tugboat union had agreed to anything.

title: Study Shows Teen Years Are Easiest for Childbirth
description: ASTUDY involving 9,000 women who gave birth at a hospital in Copenhagen has concluded that, when given proper prenatal care, teenage women are better at giving birth than women of any other age.

title: Rubber Talks Set for Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  The United Rubber Workers and Uniroyal Inc., the tire maker, agreed today to resume contract negotiations tomorrow at the offices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service here.

title: 2 NEW SETTLEMENTS APPROVED BY ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  State Department officials said today that Israel had disregarded American warnings and gone ahead to approve the creation of two more Jewish settlements on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan.

title: Concert: Music of the Last 5 Years
description: ON Sunday afternoon the Criterion Concerts series at the Guggenheim Museum presented a program of music composed in the last five years that was extremely, implacably tedious. Four of the five pieces consisted of sequences of short movements strung together; the fifth, Doris Hays's Breathless for bass flute (1977), was one short movement in itself.

title: NBC Holds Private Talks With Carson on Contract
description: LOS ANGELES, April 23 (AP) Johnny Carson, his representatives and his employers met through the weekend trying to resolve Mr. Carson's differences with NBC TV.

title: Kimberly Division to Halt
description: General Mills Inc. announced yesterday it would discontinue its Kimberly vision,, s maker of seamen's appare. General Mills said that a review of Kimberly's operations indicated that while an improvement in its current unprofitable performance was project. ed. overall prospects are inadequate to warrant continuing the business.

title: St John's Nine Wins, 75
description: NEW HAVEN, Apr 23  Doug Latrenta and Bob Rovalsky had two runs batted in apiece to lead St. John's University to a 75 victory over the Univer sity of New Haven today.

title: Stocks Gain on Strong Energy Issues
description: Energy stocks posted some of the market's best gains yesterday, while the general list moved slightly higher on modest volume. Caesars World tumbled 6  points to 70 after selling as low as 66, placing a damper on other gambling stocks.

title: Canada's Tight Banking Ties
description: TORONTO, April 23  Within minute's walk of the junction of King and Bay Streets in this city's downtown area stand the actual or de facto headquarters of Canada's five largest banks huge, monied institutions that control fully 90 percent of the assets of Canada's 11 federally chartered banks. Recently, the power of one of these banks has reached into the United States and provoked conflictofinterest charges in the billiondollar attempted takeover of the F.W. Woolworth Company by Brascan Ltd.

title: Concert, Carol Wincenc, Flutist
description: CAROL WINCENC, who won first prize in last year's Naumburg Flute Competition, gave her award concert last night at Alice Tully Hall and it was a stunner. The Buffalo musician is no newcomer of course. She has been heard with many of the most respected groups in the world, either as a freelance or a guest soloist, picking up a surprising amount of experience for one whose official debut came only seven years ago. All that background and Miss Wincenc's indisputable inborn gift as well were impressively in evidence throughout this program, which she shared with five clairvoyantly sympathetic colleagues.

title: Rhodesian Election Called a Fraud By Black Leader Seeking Top Post
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 23The Rhodesian election received a major setback tonight when the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole, one of the two men vying to be the country's first black prime minister, denounced the voting as fraudulent and said his party would refuse to accept the result.

title: ABCTV Announces Fall Schedule
description: At the crest of its most popular season ever, ABCTV yesterday gained a jump on the other networks next season by being the first to announce its fall program schedule, one that will field at least seven new weekly series.

title: New Missile Is Placed In Europe by Soviet; 2 More Are Expected
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  The Soviet Union has begun to deploy a new nuclear. armed missile in East Germany, a step that Carter Administration officials described today as raising the risk of a steppedup arms race in Europe.

title: Durables Orders Off In March
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)New orders for durable goods received by the nation's factories fell 2.5 percent in March, the largest decline since nearrecord drop of 5.3 percent last July, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Conrail Trims Loss in Quarter
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (UPI)The Consolidated Rail Corporation re. ported today that it had narrowed its losses to $127.7 million in 1979's first quarter from $216 million in the year. earlier period. The Congressionally created rail company said the results showed a continued upward trend in the four years Conrail has operated.

title: Inflation Prolonging the Pressure On Budgets of the MiddleAged
description: CHICAGO, April 23  Coping with the cost of living has been a way of life for Edward and Josephine Ronczy since the day they were married, nearly 28 years ago. And like many other middleaged Americans, they have managed fairly well  as well, according to an expert on family finances, as they might reasonably have expected.

title: Bradshaw to Get Degree
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., April 23 (AP)  Terry Bradshaw, the Pittsburgh Steeler quarterback, will receive an honorary doctor of laws degree from AldersonBroaddus College on May 20. An official of the Philippi, W. Va., college said that Bradshaw is being recognized for his humanitarian efforts and his interest in people.

title: Milk Workers Reject Arbitration
description: Strikting Milktruck drivers and plant workers yesterday rejected a judge's proposal to return to work and submit outstanding issues to binding arbitration.

title: Heart Attacks Tied To Magnetic Change
description: AFTER analyzing six years worth of data, two geophysicists have concluded that there is a significant relationship between heart attacks and changes in the earth's magnetism.

title: Memorial for Norma Brustein
description: A memorial service for Norma Brustein will be held at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven next Monday at P.M. Mrs. Brustein, an actress and associate professor at the Yale School of Drama, died on April 9. A fund is being established in her name at Harvard University for the purpose of helping to support a young actor with the American Repertory Theater Company. Gifts may be made to the company, Loeb Drama Center, 64 Brattle Street, Cambridge, Mass. 02138.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, April 23 (AP)  A Federal appeals court today ordered a new trial in the $47.7 million civil rights suit over a 1969 police raid on the apartment of two Black Panther Party leaders, Fred Hampton and Mark Clark.

title: Saudis Break Links to Egypt but Do Not Mention Aid
description: CAIRO, April 23  Saudi Arabia, which has been Egypt's principal Arab financial backer, announced today that it had broken diplomatic and political relations with Cairo, but it said nothing about economic ties.

title: Police on Coast Say They've Solved 10 of 13 Hillside Strangler Deaths
description: LOS ANGELES, April 23  Law enforcement officials here said today that they had solved 10 of the hillside strangler murders and named a 27yearold man who professes to have a multiple personality as one of possibly two or more men allegedly involved in the deaths.

title: Fleeing Cambodians: A Delicate Problem for Thai Regime
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 23  Cambodian soldiers and civilians are flowing toward the Thai border and often across it In increasing numbers and for a variety of reasons. The Thai response is equally varied.

title: System of Foster Care For Children Assailed As Flawed and Costly
description: A commission created to find solutions to the growing problems surrounding the 500,000 children in foster homes or childcare institutions said, in a report to be released today, that it was possible for the majority of these children to be returned to their natural parents or placed in adoptive homes.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: ?? OF DEATHS ?? TELEPHONE TO 354 UNTIL 5:30 PM FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS UNTIL 2:30 P M ?? SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION ?? OFFICE ?? TO 4:30 P M MONDAY ?? FRIDAY ?? WESTCHESTER CO AND ?? NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES ?? WHITE PLANS ?? SUFFORK CO ??

title: Technology
description: A KEY component of the office of tomorrow is starting to emerge today. The intelligent printer  a highspeed copying machine that can be linked electronically to computers, wordprocessing typewriters and other automated office equipment  is making its way onto the market.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: ABC's Friendly Fire Drew 64 Million
description: Serious television dramas on depressing themes seldom attract large audiences. and they would seem to have even less chance of doing so on a Sunday night; when viewing is traditionally a family experience.

title: POSTAL UNIT OFFERS MAIL SCRUTINY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)  The United States Postal Service, prompted by a Federal court ruling, proposed new regulations today that would more clearly define the authority of law officers to scrutinize the outside of envelopes in national security cases.

title: Jets Austin Is Traded To Bucs for Draft Pick
description: The New York Jets traded an offensive lineman, Darrell Austin, to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers yesterday for an eighthround choice in next week's National Football League draft of college players.

title: The Scary Lesson of Scared Straight
description: Now that Scared Straight has won an Oscar, wellmeaning people seem determined to rush innercity youngsters through jail. The honored film is a chilling documentary in which longterm prisoners at New Jersey's Rahway Prison try to frighten youngsters away from a life of crime. Three prisons in New York State have now developed similar projects whose therapeutic value is thought to lie in exposing children to lurid accounts of prison life. We wonder.

title: For the Italians, Coping With Terrorism Is a Way of Life
description: ROME, April 24  The bus driver on an early morning run said over his shoulder: You mind if I turn on the radio? Let's hear who they killed last night.

title: Tiido PiiTimae, Architects Chief
description: Tiido Pirrimae, director of architecture for Rockefeller Center Inc., died of heart attack Saturday at his summer home in Lake Placid, N.Y. He was 95 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Call Is Disputed for 28 Minutes
description: In the biggest flap since the regular umpires started their holdout for more money, the New York Mets and the San Francisco Giants argued with four substitute Umpires for 28 minutes last night in the first inning of a game that both teams played under protest.

title: Rangers Defeat Flyers, 83
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24  The parkway series is on! The Rangers gained the semifinal round of the National Hockey League playoffs tonight by defeating the Philadelphia Flyers, 83, to capture the quarterfinal series, four games to one. They will meet the Islanders in a fourofsevengame matchup beginning at 8 P.M. Thursday at Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: THERE is something infinitely rewarding about working with inexpensive foods since saving money is a cheering challenge. have noted before that chicken is probably the least expensive all meats. Also, value for value, flavor for flavor, chicken livers are probably the least expensive part of the chicken.

title: Economic Scene
description: DESPITE slow growth in 1979's first quarter and; dour forecasts of a downturn ahead, there simply no smell of recession in the business atmosphere. The report of the Commerce Department last week that real gross national product  the economy's total output of goods and services, corrected for inflation - grew at an annual rate of only, seventenths of 1 percent in the first quarter came as a surprise even to those economists who had been predicting an early slowdown.

title: Topics
description: It started as a terminology problem, a decade ago, as Hispanics and American Indians followed blacks onto the political stage. Victims of many of the same prejudices, all were content with the umbrella term minorities. The only drawback seemed to be an occasional awkward usage, like majority minority schools  meaning schools in which more than 50 percent of the students were black, Hispanic, etc.

title: Begin Vows Tough Reprisals
description: JERUSALEM, April 24  Prime Minister Begin today vowed tougher measures against Palestinian guerrillas, and he said that Israel would never return the Golan Heights to Syria.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic ALEX STEPHENS (Waterman Steamship). Acaba, Jidda. Port Sudan and Assab sells from Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 24, 1979

title: Federal Judge Orders Black Students Bused Outside Indianapolis
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 24  A Federal district court judge today ordered some 8,000 black Indianapolis pupils transferred to predominantly white suburban schools in a oneway busing plan to be effective next September.

title: President Leads 1,000 in Capitol In Service for Holocaust Victims
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  As seven memorial candles in a brass menorah flickered in the Capitol rotunda, President Carter told a solemn ceremony today that to truly commemorate the death of six million Jews, we must harness the outrage of our memories to banish all human oppression from the world.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDEREvelyn. beloved wife of the late Henry, cherished aunt & great aunt. Services at Boulevard. Park West. 115 West 79th St. at Columbus Ave., NYC, today at 10AM

title: The Profits Are Fat For Nation's Cattlemen
description: GREELEY, Colo.  James Miller smiled as he leaned against a fence a few miles south of here and looked out over a feedlot full of cattle. Miles away, on his ranch in the Rocky Mountains, Charles Bradley was smiling too.

title: Carter Sees New Delhi Official
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (Reuters) President Carter conferred today with Mal Bihari Vajpayee, India's Foreign Minister, on world problems and economic and other relations between India and the United States. I am very proud of our relationship, Mr. Carter told him as they met in the White House.

title: Deaths
description: SCANTLEBURYEmma T. beloved wife of the late Coward Scantlebury. loving mother of Rev. John Scantlebury of Essexville, Mich, Mrs Mary Anna Ferraro of Richmond, Va. four grandchildren. seven greatgrandchildren. Memorial services will be held at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Richmond. Interment Green Wood Cemetery. Bklyn NY. She was a formorresident of NYC and for the last six wars of Garden City. L.I. Family requests memorials be sent to the Cathedral of the incarnation. Garden City, L.I.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: PHENOMENA tend to blind people to history. Give theatergoers excellence and they will act as though Shakespeare had never set quill to foolscap, the Mark Bellinger had never taken My Fair Lady to its boards and OffBroadway had, never nurtured The Iceman Cometh. Give hockey fans a Mike Bossy and they will forget there was ever a Maurice Richard. Give Yankee fans a Ron Guidry, and Whitey Ford will go the way of the LaSalle. Give us Roots and we will forget Uncle Miltie. Give us I.B.M. and we will forget the South Sea Bubble. Give us Studio 54 and we will forget the Peppermint Lounge.

title: Adoption Law Rejected by High Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  The Supreme Court of the United States today struck down a New York State law that allows an unwed mother to block the proposed adoption of her illegitimate child but denies the same right to an unmarried father.

title: Notes on People
description: This is a big week for hospitality by the occupant of Gracie Mansion. As an overnight guest, Mayor Koch had Gov. Thomas I.. Judge of Montana, whose unhappiness with New Yorkers over proposed beefless Wednesdays has been amply noted. The idea was to prove to the Governor that New Yorkers are fine folks, and not deserving of a tourist boycott that he has been promoting.

title: U.S. Aides Say Loss of Iran Sites Cuts Data on Soviet Missile Tests
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  The loss of two electronic listening posts in Iran has resulted in a setback to American efforts to monitor the earliest stages of Soviet missile development not directly related to the strategic arms limitation treaty, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Evolution Theory Is Challenged In Iowa Schools by Creationists
description: DES MOINES, April 22  Iowa has become a battleground for those who challenge the evolution theory of the origins of man and other species and who are seeking equal time for the teaching of scientific creationism in public schools.

title: Soviet Jews Arrive at Kennedy Airport From Italy
description: Fera Rosenwasser, foreground, crying with joy as she greeted relative who had immigrated from the Soviet Union, yesterday at Pan American terminal. More than 600 Soviet Jews arrived on three flights during the day, the largest oneday airlift of immigrants to America from Italy since World War II. They had been staying in Italy while awaiting admission to the United States.

title: BUILDING EMPLOYEES PICKET APARTMENTS AS WALKOUT STARTS
description: Building service employees at hundreds of apartment houses and cooperatives in New York City struck yesterday for higher pay and better job security. As the employees walked off their jobs, tenants in most buildings stepped in to replaCe them, organizing themselves to Inn elevators, sort mail and perform other chores, including maintenance and garbage disposal.

title: Q&A
description: Q.When recipes call for baking a food such as a cake in a loaf pan, they rarely specify whether the pan should be in heatproof glass or in metal. Doyou have a preference?

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: Whatever one's view of the movement that overthrew the regime of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, one cannot deny that a political revolution of lasting significance has occurred in Iran. Historians in viewing revolutionary upneavals of history will regard the revolution as unique. It may also prove a landmark in relation to future revolutions in the third world, for several reasons:

title: Priest's Transfer Indicates Strife on Homosexuality
description: BOSTON  The recent transfer of the Rev. Paul R. Shanley, who has gained a national reputation for his work with homosexuals and their families, and the resulting controversy are an indication of the degree of conflict within organized religion over dealing with homosexuality.

title: At Cornell School, No Expense Spared
description: ITHACA. N.Y. Four hundred students at Cornell University's Hotel School have just treated some of the biggest names in the hospitality industry to the annual grand opening of the Hotel Ezra Cornell. The comorate leaders, half of them Cornell alumni, came to learn from and enjoy the brief operation of the world's only Hotel for a Weekend, a studentrun workshop designed to show 350 invited guests that its operators have learned their lessons well.

title: Music: Amy Kaiser's King Arthur
description: ON those rare occasions when some musical archeologist decides to excavate the stage music of Purcell, what is dug out almost invariably is Dido and Aeneas, Mitch comes closest to what a modem audience recognizes as opera. But King Arthur, written two years later, in 1691, contains music that is at least as captivating as anything the 17thcentury English composer ever wrote. The work, however, is a problem, simply because in it music and drama are alternated, piled one on top of the other. The formal design, popular in its day, resembles that of a hero sandwich. In King Arthur, the hero who alternates with Purcell is Dryden, who provided a long, patriotic play about the welding of Saxons and Anglos into one puissant nation.

title: Sports Briefs
description: BOSTON, April 24 (AP) The Boston Celtics said today they had broken off negotiations for a multimillion dollar National Basketball Association contract for the Indiana State star, Larry Bird.

title: F.D.I.C. Rejects Permit for Bank; Redlining Cited
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  In the first action of its kind by a Federal agency, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has denied a permit to open a new branch to a New York City savings bank on the ground that the bank had granted too few residential mortgages in its community.

title: Tenants Run Elevators, Take the Garbage Out and Try to Stay Cool
description: The lobby of the Brevoort Apartments, just above Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village, buzzed with more activity than usual yesterday, as not one but four attendants worked the front desk.

title: The Screen: Woody Allen's 'Manhattan'
description: AS California is our idealized future, a place where there is no downtown because the suburbs have moved in instead of out, hip Manhattan represents our idealized present. Existence in Manhattan is so fleeting that one sometimes wishes one could postdate oneself, as do the weekly magazines, in this way to avoid life's litter basket, for a few days, anyway."Manhattan," Woody Allen's extraordinarily fine and funny new film, is about many things, including a time and place where fashion probably blights more lives, more quickly, than any amounts of booze, drugs, radioactive fallout and saturated animal fats. In this Manhattan, it's no longer a question of keeping up, but of staying ahead. The person on this week's cover is a leading candidate for next year's feature story that asks, "Whatever happened to . . . ?"To survive in alien landscapes, animals develop bizarre defense mechanisms, often at a certain cost. Ostriches can run fast, but they are unable to fly. Sharks have teeth like the slicing blade in a Cuisinart, yet if they take a stationary snooze, their lungs fill with water and they drown. They must always keep moving.This is pretty much the fate of a number of people who move through and around the Manhattan of Isaac Davis (Mr. Allen), a successful comedy writer who quits his television job to write a novel. As Isaac Davis is Mr. Allen's most fully realized, most achingly besieged male character, so is "Manhattan" his most moving and expansive work to date. It's as serious as "Interiors"  if one must use that often foolish word  but far less constricted and self-conscious. In "Manhattan," Mr. Allen is working in a milieu he knows well and with characters he understands and appreciates, especially when they are drowning.In addition to being the director and co-author  with Marshall Brickman  of the film, Mr. Allen is its most important presence. He gives "Manhattan" a point of reference just as he did 10 years ago when the character he played was named Virgil Starkwell in "Take the Money and Run." How Virgil and Woody have grown!"Manhattan" moves on from both "Interiors" and "Annie Hall," being more effectively critical and more compassionate than the first and more witty and clear-eyed than the second. There is a sense of applied romance here, especially in the soundtrack use of some of the lushest melodies ever written by George Gershwin, as well as in Mr. Allen's decision to have Gordon Willis photograph "Manhattan" in the kind of velvety black-and-white I associate with old M-G-M films like "East Side, West Side" and "The Bad and the Beautiful." The movie looks so good that it looks unreal, which, in this day and age of film and fashion, is to go so far out that you're back in."Manhattan" is, of course, about love, or, more accurately, about relationships. Among those who are attempting to relate to Isaac Davis are Mary Wilke (Diane Keaton), a journalist who carries on like an Annie Hall who has been analyzed out of her shyness into the shape of an aggressively neurotic woman doomed to make a mess of things, and Tracy (Mariel Hemingway), a beautiful. 17-year-old nymphet with a turned-down mouth and a trust in her 42-year-old lover, Isaac, that is also doomed. In addition, there is Yale (Michael Murphy), Isaac's best friend, who hands Mary over to Isaac for as long as it suits his (Yale's) purposes.On the fringe of the film, observing the events with the grim determination of someone who has made a decision that must be stuck by, is Isaac's former wife, Jill (Meryl Streep), who left Isaac and, with their small son, moved in with her feamle lover, in such circumstances to write a best-selling book about her life titled "Marriage, Divorce and Selfhood.""Manhattan," which opens today at the Baronet and other theaters, is mostly about Isaac's efforts to get some purchase on his life after he initiates a breakup with his illegal, teenage mistress  a marvelous scene set at a soda fountain, with Tracy slurping down a large malted while her life goes smash  and his attempt to forge a relationship with the deeply troubled Mary Wilke. Unlike all of his friends except the still-learning Tracy, Isaac believes in monogamy. "I think people should mate for life," he says, "like pigeons and Catholics."What happens is not the substance of "Manhattan" as much as how it happens. The movie is full of moments that are uproariously funny and others that are sometimes shattering for the degree in which they evoke civilized desolation.The screenplay is so vivid you may feel as if you've met characters who are only references in the dialogue. One of these is Mary Wilke's psychiatrist, Donny, who calls her up at 3 A.M. and weeps. The on-screen characters are beautifully played by, among others, Mr. Murphy and Miss Streep. Miss Keaton and Miss Hemingway are superb  the effect of Miss Hemingway's performance being directly responsible for the unexpected impact of Mr. Allen's penultimate moment in the film, which should not be described here.I suspect there will be much more to say about "Manhattan" in the future. Mr. Allen's progress as one of our major film makers is proceeding so rapidly that we who watch him have to pause occasionally to catch our breath.

title: Military Contracts Won
description: Navy contracts valued at $47.8 million were awarded yesterday to the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for Harpoon missiles, spare parts and related equipment.

title: Times Co. Profit Up 7% For Quarter
description: SANFORD, N.C., April 24  The New York Times Company, citing strong comeback from an 88day pressmen's strike last year, told its stockholders today that its net income reached a record $7.6 million in the first quarter of this year, 7 percent above the figure for the corresponding period of 1978.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of  livestock futures broke sharply yesterday, closing at or very near their daily permissible downward limits. Copper futures also tumbled, while soybean and grain prices advanced smartly behind strong supplydemand factors.

title: Rising Litigation Weighs on Publishers
description: A huge sign hangs over the dais of the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria this week proclaiming the right of a free press in illuminated, decorative lettering. The sign is more than a conventional symbol, however, because this year, in way that it never has before, the First Amendment to the Constitution is dominating the annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

title: Marvella Bayh Is Dead of Cancer; Senator's Wife Reassured Others
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  Marvella Bayh, wife of Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, died of cancer today. She was 46 years old and had been working as a special representative for the American Cancer Society.

title: U.S. Six Triumphs As Craig Stars, 51
description: MOSCOW, April 24 The United States team won its second game in the world hockey championship today, defeating Poland, 51, behind the goaltending of Jim Craig of Boston University.

title: Iran Islamic Committees Criticized By Premier as d Rule of Revenge
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 24  Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan, ending three.. weeks of silence, severely criticized the Islamic komitehs of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini tonight and called for an end to anarchy and what he termed the rule of revenge in Iran.

title: Income, Outgo, Anguish
description: SOME time ago, I read about an experiment in which two laboratory rats from widely divergent backgrounds were thrown into a large vat of water. Rat No. I had been raised with a silver spoon in his mouth. His maze was well lit. there was always enough cheese in the icebox, and until he was plucked from his maze altogether, he always had great faith in what lay around the corner.

title: Events Today
description: THE WOODS, by David Mamet, at the Public/Newman Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, 8.

title: Senate Defeats Attempt To Balance U.S. Budget
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  The Senate voted today against balancing the Federal budget in the fiscal year 1980, apparently fearing such a move would slow inflation only by bringine on a recession.

title: Corporations Report Their Sales and Earnings Results for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: RAIDS AGAINST P.L.O. INCREASED BY ISRAEL
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 24  Israeli planes and naval craft struck at Palestinians in southern Lebanon today in what appeared to be a sharpening campaign to deter guerrillas from raids into Israel. At least 10 persons were reported killed and 12 wounded in the attacks by the Israelis.

title: Fire Kills Man in Home for Aged
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)  A man died and four persons were hospitalized today after fire struck an apartment building for the elderly near downtown Washington. A police sookesmim. Gary Hankins, said that the flames were confined to one apartment on the eighth floor of the Roosevelt Home for Senior Citizens, but smoke spread through corridors and forced the 360 residents from their rooms. The identity of the victim and cause of the blaze were not determined immediately.

title: Loser in Historic Rhodesian Vote Is a Study in Frustration
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 24 When the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole denounced an election that he had described only a few days, ago as a great democratic experiment, there was little surprise among countrymen familiar with the bizarre shifts of policy and alliance that have marked many stages of the longtime nationalist's career.

title: Cubans Will Compete in U.S.
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24 (UPI) The Cuban national track team will compete in the United States for the first time in 18 years when it participates in the the University of California, Los Angeles, invitation meet May 6.

title: Soviet Missiles to Affect Carter Neutron Decision
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)  President Carter's press secretary, Jody Powell, said today that SS21 nuclearwarhead missiles being deployed by the Soviet Union in Eastern Europe would affect the President's decision on neutron weapons.

title: Speer, I11, Retires as Chief; U.S. Steel Reports Profit
description: Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, retired yesterday because of his health. He has been battling a severe illness since last year.

title: Harmonica: Tames Cotton
description: THE blues harmonica player, singer and bandleader James Cotton lost his longtime lead guitarist, Matt Murphy, to Hie Blues Brothers and other projects recently, and the loss must have come as something of a blow. The two men had been associates since the early 50's, and Mr. Murphy was widely regarded as one of the best lead players in the blues field. But Mr. Cotton and the latest edition of his band were at the Lone Star Cafe on Monday and Tuesday, and they were so tight and energetic that Mr. Murphy was hardly missed.

title: Bolivia Parley Gets Oil Appeal
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 24  The oilprice crisis afflicting most Latin American countries erupted here today in a regional economic assembly, with an appeal for relief directed at the major oil producers, Venezuela and Mexico.

title: Fish Containing Dioxin Removed At Lake Ontario
description: One week after New York State resumed a fishstocking program in Lake Ontario, the State Health Commissioner has disclosed that minute amounts of dioxin, an extremely toxic chemical, have been found in two fish taken from the lake.

title: Sirens Wail in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Israel, April 24 (UPI) Sirens wailed throughout the nation today and Israelis stood at silent attention to honor the memory of the Jews who died in the Holocaust. Normal activity stopped for two minutes when the sirens went off at 8 A.M. Many pedestrians stood at silent attention and traffic came to a standstill.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television Channd 9.8 P.M. Radio  WMCA. P.M.)

title: Iran's Monthly Oil Output
description: TEHERAN, Iran. April 24 (AP) Iranian crude oil production averaged 3.6 million barrels a day in the month ending April 20, the National Iranian Oil Company reported today. The figures contrast with production of 6 million barrels a day before the revolution began last year.

title: For the Afflicted, a Champion in Court
description: Harry Lipsig, who has done more for the lame and the afflicted than the Statue of Liberty has done for the tired and the poor, is .asked ,this question: Are juries not being eittravagant when they award millions of dollars to his clients?

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: An Administration proposal to close gasoline stations on weekends, during shortages was rejected by. the House Commerce Committee in a setback for President Carter's program to conserve energy. Another measure giving the President authority to require energysaving thermostat settings in public and commercial buildings was approved and sent to the floor of the House. [Page A1.]

title: Famous Book House Of 19th Century Revived
description: Ticknor & Fields, the 19thcentury publishing house that brought out books by Hawthorne and Emerson and printed Dickens and Thackeray for the first time in the United States, is being revived as a new publishing house called  ampersand & all  Ticknor & Fields.

title: Con Ed Reports Lower Net Income
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, continuing its profits slide, reported firstquarter net income of $80.3 million, or $1.12 a share, down 18 percent from $97.9 million, or $1.41 a share, in the first quarter of 1978. The report yesterday of the giant utility said operating income decreased $17 million from the 1978 opening quarter mainly because of a decline in revenues from sales of electricty.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Through Glass, Beautifully

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 25, 1979

title: Hardship Index Could Shift U.S. Aid
description: A national commission, established to improve the accuracy of the nation's employment statistics, will soon decide whether to recommend adoption of a new hardship index, intended to measure economic quality of life.

title: Van D. Truex, Designer, 75
description: Van Day Truex, a highly regarded figure in the field of fashion design, died yesterday at the age of 75. A former president of Parsons School of Design. Mr. Truex had returned from semiretirement in Europe this fall to serve as design director and divisional vice president of Tiffany & Co., a position he had held once before.

title: Correction Officer Fails to Show, Stalling BerkowitzPicture Trial
description: The case against James Mitteager, a freelance writer accused of bribing a correction officer to take photographs of David Berkowitz while he was imprisoned, was stalled yesterday because the officer failed to appear.

title: Careers
description: WHERE there are lawsuits, there are also often job opportunities.

title: Queens Man Seized
description: Federal officials announced that 16 persons from New York, New Jersey, California and Florida had been arrested and charged with a nineyear conspiracy to smuggle S30 million in narcotics from South America into the United States. The officials charged that the leaders were Donald Brown, 39 years old, of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Alan Seyfert, 39, of 8552 213th Street, Hollis, Queens.

title: Diabetes Group Urges Saccharin Availability Pending Safety Study
description: With the moratorium on the Government's proposed ban on saccharin nearing an end, the American Diabetes Association called yesterday for continued availability of the sweetener until Congress completes a study of food safety laws.

title: Hawks Top Bullets, Cut Series Deficit to 32
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 24  Dick Motta, the coach of the champions of the basketball world and a firm believer in percentages, is having a very difficult time making sense of the Washington Bullets or their National Basketball Association playoff series with the Atlanta Hawks. A very confusing series, he said tonight.

title: Discord Mars McGraw Meeting
description: Amid disappointment by some stockholders over the company's rejection of a $1 billion takeover bid from the American Express Company, directors of McGrawHill Inc. were reelected at the annual meeting yesterday with only 67 percent shareholder approval.

title: Aide Says Carter Plans To Enter Every Primary
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)  President Carter will enter every primary next year and seek delegates in every state caucus or convention, the President's campaign manaeer said today.

title: Audit Reports Costly Blunders at Cancer Institute
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  The National Cancer Institute repeatedly failed to see serious deficiencies in testing pro. grams for suspected carcinogens, the Congressional investigating agency charged today, and as a result many test results were thrown out at a cost of millions of dollars.

title: Congress Given $6.6 Billion Plan For Safe Airports and Air Traffic
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Transportation Secretary Brock Adams sent Congress a bill today calling for the expenditure of $6.6 billion to improve the nation's airport and airway safety system for the five years beginning Oct. 1, 1980.

title: Retirees searching for New Jobs As Rising Costs Erode Pensions
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Reluctantly, painfully, Joe Glickman found a strategy for Irving in retirement in an age of inflation: He went back to work.

title: Tugboatmen Won't Haul Refuse
description: While talks continued yesterday in the tugboat strike, the first violence was reported in the 23dayold labor dispute and the tugboatmen's union again ignored a court order that it temporarily resume towing the city's garbage to a landfill on Staten Island, despite reports to the contrary on Monday.

title: Family Calls Its Treehouse A Toy, Not Illegal Structure
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J.  To 6yearold Edward Self, the brown wood treehouse his parents, and brother designed and built for his fifth birthday in their backyard here is a place to draw and be by myself.

title: Best Buys
description: IN shopping around for best buys on food, one quickly realizes that it doesn't have to'cost more to go first class. And it may well cost less. Prices vary greatly from market to market, even within the same neighborhood, and those eggs selling for 79 cents a dozen at the greengrocer are generally of equal quality to those priced at $1.09 at the supermarket. A single head of garlic may sell for 33 cents in one grocery store, but another market may offer fresher garlic for $1.50 a pound, or about 9 cents a head. When purchased alone, such savings appear minimal, but when all are added up, they can be significant.

title: Stage: Intar Presents Eyes on the Harem
description: IN a way, it is female subjugation and male fear that Maria Irene Fornes is getting at in her comicalexplosive vaudeville about the degenerate low points in the 600year dynasty of the Turkish Ottomans.

title: Judge Dismisses Worker In High Court Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Chief Justice Warren E. Burger dismissed a typesetter from his job at the Supreme Court's print shop last week following two ABC News reports that gave premature word of Court decisions.

title: Harrisburg Faces High Interest Rate
description: Harrisburg. Pa., drew three bids yesterday as it moved to sell $16.4 million of bonds, all suggesting interest costs well above 7 percent. But underwriters said the relatively high rates did not reflect the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island, approximately 10 miles from the city.

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS (AP)  Irene Bauer, 41 years old, has been found guilty or firstdegree manslaughter and assault by a jury that heard her son tell how .they killed a 54yearold retarded man during a twoday orgy of sex and torture. The jury in Westchester County Court deliberated almost eight hours. before returning the verdict against the Yonkers woman Monday night.

title: Rubber Union and Uniroyal Meet For 10 Hours Before Calling Recess
description: WASHINGTON, Apikil 24 Differences between the.:. United Rubber Workers union and Uniroyal Inc. on an industrywide contract for tire manufacturers appeared to move a niche closer to resolution tonight as negotiators ended nearly 10 hours of talks.

title: Deaths
description: JOSEPHSONHerbert. On April 23. 1979. The officers and members of Palestine Ledge 204 F. & A. M. are requested to meet at the Riverside Funeral Home at 76th St. Amsterdam Ave. on Wednesday. April 25th, 12:30 to pay respects to our departed brother. Pietro Marmorato, Master Eugene J. Duca, Secretary

title: British Leaders Express Dismay Over Violence at Antiracial Rally
description: LONDON, April 24  Britain's major political leaders joined in expresions of dismay today over the violent demonstrations last night against a rightwing party that cost the life of a 33yearold teacher and marred the current election campaign.

title: State Rankings For Businesses
description: ALBANY, April 24  New York ranks behind all but two states in the continental United States as a place in which to do business, according to a study by a nationwide manufacturers group.

title: Dozens Are Injured in Derailment Of a Boston Troller, Speed Cited
description: BOSTON. April 24 (AP)  A new trotley car, apparently traveling too fast on an eleva track derailed and crashed into a retaining wall today in front of the Boston Garden, injuring dozens of commuters, the authorities said.

title: Peril From Snakes and Alligators
description: Residents of southeastern Louisiana, out of sandbags in their war against rampaging rivers and streams, armed themselves with rifles and shotguns yesterday to battle alligators and poisonous snakes.

title: Lemancyzk 1Hitter Downs Rangers, 20
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., April 24 (UPI)  Dave Lemanczyk, a righthander who had not won since July 29, allowed only one hit tonight  a thirdinning single by Pat Putnam, a rookie  in pitching the Toronto Blue Jays to a 20 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: Israel Digs Into the West Bank.
description: There seem to be three diplomatic emotions operating in Israel as the peace with Egypt is formally ratified this week.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows the past week (Monday, April 16, to Sunday. April 22), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating Is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: Chess
description: In his book The Game of Chess, which appeared in 1931, Siegbert Tarrasch railed against the symmetrical English Opening because he believed that both sides developed without coming into contact, thus producing bloodless draws.

title: Response To Utility Bonds Lags
description: Utility bonds carrying the highest yields available since October 1975 failed to stir much enthusiasm from investors yesterday, partly because of a general concern about nuclear power and partly because of speculation that longterm interest rates are still headed higher.

title: Jack Tarver Reelected A.P. Board Chairman
description: Jack W. Tarver, publisher of The Atlanta Journal and Constitution, was reelected chairman of The Associated Press yesterday at a reorganization meeting of the news cooperative's board of directors.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  Thirtyfour years after the Marines landed on Iwo Jima, the volcanic island in the Western Pacific that was the scene of a historic photograph of the raising of the American flag, an allblack Army support unit has received belated recognition for its exploits there.

title: Radiation Deaths: A Clarification
description: The health consequences of radiation exposure from the Three Mile Island nuclear accident are still not known for sure; nor are they likely to be known for weeks, months or perhaps even years.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday incorrectly reported the interest celling on New York mortgages. The present limit, according to the State Banking Department is 9.5 per cent. It is scheduled to rise May 1 to 9.75 percent and to increase by onequarter of a percentage pont every three months until it reaches a ceiling tow pionts above the monthly index of longterm Federal bond yields. Using the present index as a guide, the legal ceiling would be 11.12 percent, which would not be reached until the end of next year

title: Borg, McEnroe Victors; Fleming Beats Gerulaitis
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 24 (AP) Bjorn Borg recovered after a slow start today and beat Hank Pfister, 26, 63, 61, but Vitas Gerulaitis fell to Peter Fleming, 67, 64, 64, in the first round of the $250,000 Alan King/Caesars Palace tennis tournament.

title: DAVID M. STUDNER
description: David M. Studner, former president of D. M. Studner Inc., importers of rare documents and antiques, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Scarsdale. N.Y. He was 85 years old.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: THE surest way to save money. of course, is not to spend it. So in this issue devoted to the tight fist, I want to direct your attention to the human hand, a tool that costs nothing at all and is frequently superior to anything else available.

title: Wood,Field and Stream
description: A communication extolling the delights of this weekend's Empire State/ Lake Ontario Salmon and Trout Derby in Rochester sets my teeth on edge.

title: Murder Suspect Extradited
description: CLEVELAND, April 24 (AP)  Lawrence Dalton waived extradition today and was returned to Waukegan, Ill., for questioning in the slayings of two women and a 12-year-old girl. Mr. Dalton. 34 years old, appeared briefly before Municipal Judge Charles Fleming and left immediately afterward with the Waulegan police. He is also wanted in Kennosha, Wis, where he was charged yesterday with firstdegree murder and kidnapping in the srangling of Blanche Penna, 23.

title: Black Premier For Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 24 Almost 15 years after Prime Minister Ian D. Smith took over the leadership of their nation and embarked on a collision course with the world. Rhodesians

title: A New Inflation Strategy: Esting Better for Less
description: AS far as food prices are concerned, these are probably the good old days. The cost of food will never return to what it was five or years ago, and if it moves at all, the direction will be up. Learning to cope on this lofty new price plateau will be as difficult with the fuel we call food as it will with heatine oil and gasoline.

title: Opening Up Too Much Wilderness
description: How much of our still unspoiled national forests should be opened to development and how much preserved in pristine wilderness? After a twoyear study, the Carter Administration has concluded that most of the remaining lands should be devoted to multiple uses, such as logging, mining, grazing, oil and gas recovery, and recreational activities involving motorized vehicles. Only a minor portion would remain wilderness, without roads, improved campsites or permanent structures and accessible only by foot, horseback or canoe. In our view, the plan puts too much emphasis on exploitation at the expense of preservation.

title: Archbishop Francis James Furey
description: Archbishop Francis James Furey, a leading supporter of social causes among HispanicAmericans and head of the San Antonio Roman Catholic Archdiocese for the last 10 years, died of cancer Monday in San Antonio. He was 74 years old.

title: Great Meals on a Family Budget
description: NO WHERE is it written that the high cost of food means the death of great family, meals Or occasional dinner parties. But there is a knack to cooking well with little money, and it is the most accomplished cooks who suffer least on a tight budget.

title: Jazz Piano: Joe Albany
description: JOE ALBANY is a jazz pianist, who, after playing with Charlie Parker and Lester Young in the 40's, virtually disappeared. He made a record in 1957, played briefly with Charles Minus in 1963 and turned up in Europe in 1972. He was so elusive. such a willothewispm that even most of those who knew of him had never heard him play except on that 1957 record. Inevitably, as happened with Peck Kelley, the reclusive Texas pianist who refused to leave that state or to be recorded, the word legendary became attached to Mr. Albany.

title: Wine Talk
description: MOST of us who like wine are not aware of just bow much of it we drink..A household that consumes a bottle of wine at dinner every night will ruse through more than 30 cases of wine in a year. Since most familles who drink a bottle of wine a day are convivial people, it is not untoward to assume that their annual total would be closer to 50 cases. If the average bottle of table wine costs $4, then 50 cases represent a yearly outlay of some $2,400.

title: The City
description: All but 16 of 313 city auxiliary police officers scheduled for street duty Monday night refused it in protest against a prohibition on carrying nightsticks by auxiliaries.

title: Carter Can Expect Some Problems In His New Hampshire Visit Today
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., April 24 President Carter can expect to encounter at least two demonstrations, some sharp questioning about his energy policy and the first stirrings of an organized writein campaign for Senator Edward M. Kennedy when he arrives in New Hampshire tomorrow for a day of politicking.

title: Davis Gets Help Of Goldin in Bid For Aid to Parks
description: To publicize their contention that parks maintenance is inefficient, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin and Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis held a joint news conference yesterday at the sailboat pond in Central Park.

title: Red Brigades Reported in France
description: ROME, April 29  A clandestine strategic headquarters of Italy's Red Brigades terrorists has been found in Paris, and the French secret services helped gather evidence against them, a source close to an Inquiry into ultraleftist terrorism said today.

title: 86.8 Million Wisconsin Bond Sale
description: Wisconsin sold $86.8 million of tripleA bonds yesterday in the first offering of topquality state bonds in two weeks. Yields on the bonds showed little change, and the securities sold fairly rapidly.

title: EARNINGS
description: The American Broadcasting Companies, whose earnings from broadcasting have climbed under the momentum of its television network, while those of the RCA Corporation, owner of NBC, and CBS Inc. continue to lag, reported yesterday an 11.4 percent increase in firstquarter profits.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Concerto a 4, No. 2 in G. Galuppi; La Cetra: Concerto No. 4, A Marcello; Waltzes, Chopin; Sonata tar Flute and Harpsichord in D minor, Purcell.

title: More Rain and Rising River Imperil Grand Forks, N.D., and Sister City
description: GRAND FORKS, N.D., April 24 (AP)  Their bodies drained from days of slinging sandbags and their spirits sodden with cold, dirty water, residents along the Red River of the North were told today that their ordeal was far from over.

title: Private Lives
description: HIS behavior has been deplorable, no doubt about it. H even answered the telephone by barking, 7820559, which happens be his Library of Congress catalogue card number. Now.he is hiding in the liquor closet, hugging his slab of trapped words.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 24 (AP)Thai border officials said today that the Vietnamese had fired artillery into group of tens of thousands of Cambodian refugees in Thailand.

title: Anna Fisher Berrens, Headed Musk Concern
description: Anna Fisher Berrens, former president of the Fisher Music Corporation, died Monday at her home of Parkinson's disease. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TV: Thomas Wolfe
description: THOMAS WOLFE comes to television tonight at 9 o'clock on CBS, in an adaptation of his au tobiographical novel You Can't Go Home Again. Harold Robbins and Irving Wallace may have been showcased in television small series, stretched over several hours, but the sprawling Mr. Wolfe is stuffed into two hours. The familiar torrent of words overwhelming and perhaps enervating  has been reduced to a trickle, leaving only the bare scaffolding of a rather rickety plot.

title: Ford Drops New Plant For Europe
description: DETROIT, April 24  Ford of Europe, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, announced today that it was giving up plans to build an assembly plant costing hundreds of millions of dollars in Europe and would favor the expansion of existing plants there instead.

title: If the Shah Had Read Aeschylus
description: BELVES, France  Not so long ago, when the Technological Revolution was supposedly white hot, what was more'dead than the dead languages? Latin and Greek attracted few pupils; universities were topheavy with overendowed professors. Those of us who had studied the classics were the very instances of obsolescence. (Even now we know little about silicone chips and not much more about the Second Law of Thermodynamics.)

title: Bell's Chief Disputes Media Bills
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  The chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that the giant monopoly was now guided by a new realism, an awareness that competition, not monopoly, would mark the growth of telecommunications in the future.

title: Brooke Returns to Senate  as a Lobbyist
description: WASHINGTON, April 29  It seemed as if nothing had changed for Ed Brooke. lie stood smiling and erect in the hearing room, senatorial in his gray striped suit, bathed in television lights and bandying words with a cluster of eager reporters.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FRAMEUP Downtown visitors and workers interested in rare surviving woodframe houses can spend a lunchtime interlude today hearing an expert describe and illustrate the construction and decoration of these dwellings in the 18th and 19th centuries. The place is a historic reconstruction  the Fraunces Tavern Museum at 54 Pearl Street, where Robert Sutter will speak, starting at 12:30, with visitors invited to settle down with their own lunches. Coffee will be served on the house.

title: Real Estate
