description: THE World Trade Center, with 9.6 million square feet of rentable office space, has rested like a thirsty sponge over the downtown office market throughout the entire 1970's. The first tenants arrived in December 1970 and still the center is not completely filled.

title: Pop: Confrey Phillips
description: INDIA'S answer to Bobby Short, by way of England, a singer and pianist named Confrey Phillips, is making his American debut this week at Marty's, Third Avenue at 73d Street.

title: HELMS MOVES TO LIFT RHODESIA SANCTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  A promineat conservative Senator introduced a bill today that would require President Carter to end sanctions against Rhodesia, but an Africa specialist in the House said such an action would be precipitate, premature and extremely counterproductive for the United States.

title: Bridge:
description: Three's company, two's none, was Oscar Wilde's cynical comment on the married state. The original version definitely applies to bridge.

title: News of the Theater
description: LOOSE ENDS. the title of the play that Circle in the Square wants to present as its fourth and last production this season, also turns out to be an apt phrase for the current state of affairs at the theater. The clay. by Michael Weller. is supposed to go into rehearsal next Monday, begin previews May 25 and open June 14. But as a spokesman for the theater describes the situation, We still have not tied up all the pieces.

title: Sears, in Hiring Rift, Ends U.S. Orders
description: CHICAGO, April 24  Sears, Roebuck & Company, in renewed skirmishing over its own employment practices and its dispute over Federal laws concerning minority employment, said today it was immediately severing business relationships with the Government. The company says conflicting Federal laws actually restrict opportunities for minorities.

title: $250,000 Bogus BiIli Seized
description: BROOKFIELD, Ill., April 24 (UPI) Secret Service agents have confiscated $250,000 in $10 and $20 bills from a home that they said was the headquarters of a nationwide counterfeiting operation. A spokesman said yesterday that the false money and printing equipment were confiscated in a raid Friday on the home of Robert J. Rizzo. 32 years old. He apparently fled the house before the raid.

title: Citicorp Note Rate At SixMonth Low
description: Citicorp sold $100 million of 91day notes yesterday at an average rate of 9.838 percent, down from 10.098 percent last week and the lowest rate for this shortterm paper since Oct. 24, 1978. Accepted bids ranged from a low of 9.805 percent to a high of 9.845 percent; a total of $776.5 million of bids was submitted.

title: Olympic Site Faults Charged
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., April 24 Two Federal engineers charged today that some of the facilities now under construction here fora the 1980 Winter Olympics were structurally inadequate and that they could threaten the safety of spectators and athletes.

title: Recipes: Main Courses for About $1 a Person
description: 1. Scrub mussels well to remove beards.

title: Henry Brown, Chief of Medicine For New Rochelle Hospital, 60
description: Dr. Henry Brown, an internist, died Monday of a heart attack in. New Rochelle Hospital. where he was clinical chief of medicine. He was 60 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Massachusetts Liquor Ban Doesn't Fret Under20's
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 24Sud denly, at least to hear them tell it, not many people under the age of 20 are interested in having a drink any more.

title: CORWIN D. EDWARDS, EXPERT IN ANTITRUST
description: Dr. Corwin D. Edwards, an economist who had served the Government for many years and was professor emeritus of economics at the University of Oregon, died last Friday at Baylor University Medical Center in Dallas. He was 77 years old and lived in Lewes. Del.

title: Koch Yields Control of Restructured Antipoverty Offices
description: Three of New York City's largest antipoverty programs, which Mayor Koch took under his personal control when he assumed office 16 months ago, were turned back to the Human Resources Administration yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 25, 1979

title: Nets Surge For Oil Companies
description: A number of oil companies reported sharply higher firstquarter profits yesterday, bearing out earlier predictions that earnings would jump as a result of the tightened world oil market.

title: Court  Upholds Police Interrogation Without Explicit Waiver of Lawyer
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  The Supreme Court ruled today that a criminal suspect does not have to explicitly waive his constitutional right to consult a lawyer in order for the police to conduct valid interrogation.

title: Indian Holy Man's Fast Opens Drive to Save Sacred Cows
description: NEW DELHI, April 24  A resurgence in the perennial controversy over the welfare of the cow, a sacred animal to most Hindus, has gripped India at the beginning of an indefinite fast by a revered holy man, Vinobha Bhave, on behalf of its protection.

title: FLOWER IS DETECTOR OF SLIGHT RADIATION
description: Recent studies by a Japanese scientist indicate that the spiderwort, a common, roadside wildflower that is already known as an effective monitor of pesti eldest auto exhausts and sulfur dioxides, could also be an ultrasensitive monitor of ionizing radiation.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: During a recent business Hip to to Boston, writes Cortland Anderson, my riend left his downtown hotel early one mornings took the subway to Harvard Square and started his daily threemile jog. A Haryard graduate, he was enjoying his run through some parts of Cambridge he hadn't seen on foot for more than 20 years.

title: Dr. Joseph Brunilik, 82, A Teaching Cardiologist
description: Dr. Joseph V. Brtunlik, a leading cardiologist, died Sunday in St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center in Manhattan, where he taught cardiology. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Shortterm interest rates declined yesterday for the second consecutive day, while longterm bond yields continued to rise amid speculation that the Treasury would announce plans today to sell a 40year bond issue.

title: Market Place
description: IS it appropriate for the distraught hamburger buyer to hedge against higher beef prices by investing in cattlefeeding operations?

title: Woman Who Robbed Two Banks in Queens Charged With Holdup
description: A woman awaiting sentencing for two bank robberies in Queens was charged with another holdup yesterday morning after a Citibank branch at Columbus Avenue and 94th Street in Manhattan was robbed of about $5,000, according to the authorities.

title: BankAmerica Resignation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 24  A. W. Clausen, president of the Bank of America, told shareholders today that he had obtained the August resignation of Alvin C. Rice, a vice chairman once seen as his most likely successor, because of personal transactions that violated bank policy.

title: Syria Is Plotting Terror in Egypt, Cairo Says, Displaying 2 Captives
description: CAIRO, April 24  The Interior Minister of Egypt accused Syria today of directing a plot for terrorist bombings in Egypt to stir panic and discourage tourism.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CHICAGO, April 24  The proposed merger of the BorgWarner Corporation and the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, which would have become one of the largest combinations in American corporate history, was called off today.

title: Soviet Economy Slid in Quarter
description: MOSCOW, April 24  The Soviet economy sagged sharply in the first quarter of 1979, according to figures released today by the Central Statistical Administration.

title: A Simple Guide to Complex Carbohydrates
description: The following information can be used as a guide through the maze of complex carbohydrates.

title: Dance: Feigenheimer, Glenn Troupes
description: PARISHIONERS may be only dimly aware that anything else but church services are going on at the RiverSide Church, but the Theater of the Riverside Church had one of its busiest days Sunday, when it presented concerts by two choreographers who are probably as well or better known for their, fine performing careers. Irene FeIgenheimer is an alumna of the Cliff Keuter and Don Redlich companies, Laura Glenn of the Jose Liman company. There have been  and doubtless will be  better days than this for both.

title: Muzorewa Party Wins in Rhodesia With Bare Majority in Parliament
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 24 Bishop Abel Muzorewa's party was declared the winner of the Rhodesian election today and will have a bare majority in the country's first blackdominated Parliathent.

title: 22 Concerns Questioned On Pricing
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the Council on Wage and Price Stability, said today that his staff had identified 22 major corporations that apparently were in violation of the Administration's voluntary guidelines for price restraint.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  In the last few weeks, the leaders of the Soviet Union have been making some symbolic gestures of cooperation toward the United States. They seem to be saying they want an agreement with Washington on the control of strategic arms  and are in a bit of a hurry about it  and that they are also eager for an expansion of trade between the two countries.

title: Police Hunting for Gang Victims
description: A special New York City detective force has been excavating an abandoned West Side railway cut, looking for bodies of people possibly slain by a Manhattan gang, the police said last night.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Apparently it was a matter of face. Tokuji Akikusa, president of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, had fought against changing his company's unyielding policy against foregin procurement. But the Japanese Government insisted that buying from foreign companies be broadened in response to strong pressure from the United States. And so Nippon Telegraph changed its policy, and Mr. Akikusa offered his resignation.

title: Telecommunications Offer
description: An underwriting group managed by D.H. Blair & Company announced yes terday an initial public offering of 242,620 common shares of the United Telecommunications Corporation at $10 a share. Net proceeds will be used to aug ment working capital, meet inventory requirement expected from increased business, develop new application for company products and reduce bank indebtedness

title: Advertising
description: THERE are awards and awards in the advertising business, and at one time or another Doyle Dane Bembach has won one or more of each with its Volkswagen advertising. But none has been so lucrative as AdConcepts 79, sponsored jointly by the Newspaper Advertising Bureau and the International Newspaper Advertising Executives, which will split $25,000 between the pockets of Robert H. Levenson, vice chairman of the agency, and Charles Piccirillo, senior vice president.

title: Printing Council Will Take a Role In News Dispute
description: The 10union Allied Printing Trades Council agreed yesterday to have its president, George E. McDonald, and its adviser, Theodore W. Kheel, attend negotiations today between The Daily News and the Newspaper Guild of New York in their continuing dispute.

title: Stocks Gain 6.76 in Heavier Volume
description: The stock market posted a moderate advance yesterday in much heavier trading, with the oil and bluechip stocks scoring the best gains.

title: University Sues Over Fund Cutoff
description: RALEIGH, N.C.. April 24  The 16campus system of the University of North Carolina filed suit in Federal District Court here today to challenge the constitutionality of Federal requirements for desegregating the state's institutions of higher education.

title: Jeremy Thorpe: Is Hard Work Enough?
description: WESTWARD HO, England, April 24 There has never been an election contest like it, not in Britain anyway.

title: Wheeling and Dealing With Mrs. Refund
description: THERE was some suspicion among some people in a Waldbaum's supermarket in Mount Vernon, N.Y., that Susan Samtur was somehow pulling a fast one. When the cash register totaled her grocery bill at $48.87, she reached into her handbag and produced not a wallet, not a checkbook, but a fistful of refund certificates entitling the bearer to such items as a free halfgallon of milk and three pounds of free chopped beef. After the cash register subtracted all the refunds, Mrs. Samtur's bill shrank to $2.15.

title: Carter to See Panama President In May on Carla! and Other Issues
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (Reuters)President Carter will meet with President Aristides Royo of Panama here on May 10 to discuss the new Panama Canal treaties and other issues, the White House announced today.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: ONE of the most admiring things one can say about David Halberstam's The Powers That Be is that if you try to summarize its underlying thesis adequately, you would end up transcribing its entire 400.000word text.

title: U.S EXPRESSES HOPE ON SUMMIT MEETING
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  High Administration officials said today that they hoped the projected meeting between President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, could produce understandings to reduce tensions and enhance chances for negotiated solutions in the Middle East and in southern Africa.

title: HOUSE UNIT REJECTS WEEKEND GAS CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  President Carter's energy conservation program was dealt a setback today when the House Commerce Committee rejected a proposal to close gasoline stations on weekends during oil shortages.

title: Mauritania Breaks Egyptian Ties Because of Treaty With Israel
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, April 24 (Reuters)  Mauritania broke off diplomatic relations with Egypt today, the Abidjan radio said.

title: STRAUSS APPOINTED ENVOY FOR MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON. April 24  President Carter announced today that he had named his special trade representative, Robert. S. Strauss, as. AmbassadoratLarge for Middle East negotiations on Palestinian selfrule in the West Bank and Gaza.

title: Lipsig's Guide to Venue and Jury Selection
description: Once among the least prestigious of legal specialties, good negligence work is now widely respected. I try to give jurors a feeling of royalty, Harry Lipsig says, so they can feel royal in their disposition of the amounts in the case. It boils down to telling them they have the ancient power of the kings of vore.

title: Cardinal Wright Has Surgery
description: BOSTON, April 24 (UPI)  John Cardinal. Wright, America's highest ranking prelate at the Vatican, is listed in good condition at the TuftsNew England Medical Center after undergoing cataract surgery. Hospital officials confirmed yesterday that the 70yearold Bostonborn Cardinal was admitted April 6 for a general checkup and the cateract surgery on his left eye.

title: Mime and Merriment Spice Lunch at City Hall Park
description: White faces, dappled with bright bits of colors, enlivened lunch at City Hall Park as the Cumeezi Bozo Ensemble quietly danced, pranced and mimed their way into the hearts of the crowd there yesterday. The company of silent clowns was at City Hall to help celebrate the Mayor's Volunteer Week in New York. The group's perforrnarice lies somewhere between mime and the circus tradition, as they seemingly ftnprovise encounters with the public without a hint of staging. Eric Truies, director of the company, provides a vibrant verbal picture of the concept behind his silent players. According to Mr. Truies, they daily perform in nonordinary theatrical sights, trying to change the experiences of the pedestrians. The group relies on grants or private donations for funding, as Mr. Trules explains, because they are trying to elevate the street performer above the beggar  starving artist  pass the hat image. The 15 clowns have performed everywhere from Studio 54 to Mrs. Rodriquez's home for her 4yearold daughters birthday party in the Bronx, according to Mr. Truies, and can be seen May 28 at Central Park Zoo.

title: It's O.K. (and Cheap) To Eat Starches
description: THERE'S one simple way to save money: Eat the potatoes. Also the rice, pasta, corn, beans and bread. Strange advice, coming from a column on healthful living? After all, you might ask, aren't these the starchy foods. high in calories and low in nutrients, that our forefathers were forced to live on but that we, in our late20thcentury affluence and abundance, can afford to pass up or merely sample now and again?

title: Face on BubbleGum Card
description: A buzzer signaled the end of a period, and two or three mintues later the teacher pushed open the door to the faculty cafeteria. The teacher rubbered around the room. Then his eyes ?? upon a table where the head of the English department sat with a visitor. A big grin twisted his face. He came striding across the room with a rolling gait, the gait of a pitcher on his way to the mound. It is hard to say why he looked like a ballplayer, for the hair was tinged with gray, the big frame carried 15 pounds more than a ballplayer his size should weigh, and the face no longer wore the weathered tan of one who lives outdoors. Still, he did have the look of a ballplayer, which he was 25 years ago. This was Saul Rogovin of the Detroit Tigers, Chicago White Sox, Baltimore Orioles, Philadelphia Phillies and the English department of Charles Evans Hughes High School on 18th Street near Eighth Avenue.

title: 22 Concerns Questioned On Pricing
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the Council on Wage and Price Stability, said today that his staff had identified 22 major corporations that apparently were in violation of the Administration's voluntary guidelines for price restraint.

title: John Stops A's by 31
description: OAKLAND, Calif , April 24 Tommy John, with help from an opposing pitcher, gained his fourth victory without a defeat tonight as the Yankees trimmed the Oakland A's, 31

title: Yankees Fine Gossage $18,603, Johnson $5,586 for Scuffle
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 25 Unless an arbitrator decides otherwise, the clubhouse fight between Rich Gossage and Cliff Johnson will cost Gossage $18,603 and Johnson $5.586.

title: From Towels to Fashion Wear
description: Twelve of New York's largest banks have urged the Federal Reserve Board to liberalize further its plan to allow American banks to establish internationally oriented offices throughout the country.

title: Sound
description: MY English gets rusty when i am away for awhile; and after talking Viennese for amost a month, I haye a hard time getting my typewriter started. I had been away on a kind of busman's Holiday, visiting my native haunts and taking the opportunity to check out the Austrian audio industry. The existence of such an industrycomes as no Surprise in a country where musicaiinstrument making IS as much a tradition as music itself. In the 18th century, the fiddle makers of the Tirol rivaled the great masters of Cremona, and the woodcarving skill that produced those prized violins. is also evident in the superb altarpieces to be :foind in almost any village churchof the Inn Valley.

title: TeenAgers Visits to Prisons Criticized
description: New Jersey's experiment in controlling juvenile crime by having teenagers visit prison and be subjected to oral abuse by hardened criminals  a program that is being copied in some form by at least 11 other states and that is the subject of an Oscarwinning documentary, Scared Straight Goes not aeter crime and may even cause it, according to a researcher hired by the New Jersey Department of Correction.

title: Stage: Ed Metzger as Einstein
description: ALBERT EINSTEIN, who would have been 100 years old this year, was not only a great physicist, but also an outstanding humanist, a man of great insights and endearing eccentricities that brought him as much public attention, it seemed, as his scientific genius.

title: Out on a Limb
description: In Hackensack, N.J., a judge must soon rule whether a children's playhouse built on the branch of backyard tree is a house or a toy. If a house, it must be removed because local laws forbid two houses on a single zoning lot. If a toy, it can stay because the ordinances stop short of regulating playthings.

title: Amid Guessing, Robbins Creates for Baryshnikov
description: WILL he? Won't he? Mikhail Baryshnikov will dance with the New York City Ballet this spring season. which will open Tuesday at Nevi York State Theater, but will he then leave the company he joined only last summer? The young Russian superstar has dance fans, reporters, and a good many of the beautiful people indulging in a speculatory quadrille of immense and highly absorbing complexity.

title: PAG. Net Up; Colgate Gains
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the nation's largest manufacturer of detergents and household packaged goods, reported earnings of $1119 million, or V2.04 a share, for its third auarter ended March 31, a 14.9 percent increase over the comparable period in 1978, when it earned $147.1 million, or $1.78 share. Sales during the same period were $2.457 billion, up from $2.174 billion in the similar quarter a year ago.

title: MinorityRun Thrift Units
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today an assistance program that could bring $25 million into the 78 minorityowned and managed savings and loan associations in the nation.The aid, which will be in the forth of operating training and capital infusions, is aimed at overcoming the problems many small minorityowned associations have had through their lack of experienced managers and their location in depressed urban areas where deposits are difficult to attract.

title: Letter: On Soviet Trade Credits
description: To the Editor: March's recordbreaking Soviet Jewish emigration undoubtedly prompted your April 6 editorial, Time to Trade Up in Soviet Trade, which urged the Congress to support Senator Adlal Stevenson Jr.'s bill that would grant $2 million in foreign trade credits to China and the U.S.S.R. The bill would also replace provisions of the JacksonVanik Amendment that now require assurances on improved emigration with promises from the President that emigration will be. satisfactory.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, April 25  British voters will choose next Thursday between one of the most conservative politicians to lead a major party here since the war and one whose rhetoric promises radical change. The standpat figure is Britain's Labor Prime Minister, James Callaghan. The radical is Mrs. Margaret Thatcher, leader of the Conservative Party.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TransAtlantic

title: Pregnancy Concern Found Near Nuclear Accident Site
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., April 25  Private and state medical authorities appear to have allayed the fears of pregnant women here to the extent that there has been no rush for abortions as a result of the Three Mile Island nuclear accident last month. However, one of the two abortion clinics in the area reports a dramatic rise in the number of women seeking pregnancy tests, suggesting a significant level of concern among women who may have conceived recently.

title: Furniture Market Throws a Curve
description: HILH 13()V, I N.C. title: New Discoveries at Ft. Niagara
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., April 25 (AP)  An archeological team working at the 250yearold Fort Niagara, in nearby Lewiston, has discovered what it believes to be the remains of a barracks and some 18thcentury English cutlery and Indian pottery.

title: TV: Time Express, Another Ride
description: THE best thing that can be said about Time Express, tonight's new CBSTV series at 8 o'clock is that it isn't quite as blatantly obvious as NBC's Supertrain. Returning recently to the scneatue with a new overall concept, Supertrain proceeded to exploit such tired gimmicks as Zsa Zsa Gabor and girlie fashion show featuring minimal bathing suits.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: New York City and State officials appear to agree that there are excess hospital beds in the city, but each group insists that the other bear the responsibility to provide a list of hospitals that ought to be closed. At the same time, the state has gone to great lengths to attempt to save Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. These actions highlight the need to reexamine the present strategy of hospital cost containment and resource reallocation.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: Bargaining in international Conflicts, by Charles Lockhart (Columbia University Press, S12.50). Negotiating in historical crises.

description: 5:55(4)Ancestry in Attics

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday incorrectly described the earnings of the RCA Cotporation, which reported record firstquarter income of S62.1 million, 13.1 percent above the level of a year earlier.

title: Airline Cuts Anger Senator
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd,. complained today that airlines were abandoning service in some cities and moving to more profitable areas under the freedom granted by deregulation of the industry.

title: Unmarried Father Jailed in Wisconsin Custody Battle
description: MILWAUKEE, April 25  An unmarried father who has kept the whereabouts of his 3yearold child a secret for 16 months has been jailed here under a new state law that makes it a felony to interfere with the custody of a child.

title: Rhodesia Passes the Wrong Test
description: If the debate over Rhodesia's elections remains confined to procedural questions, then outgoing Prime Minister Ian Smith and his transitional regime have scored a major victory. More than 60 percent of those eligible voted for members of a new national assembly. Western observers called the election fair. And the guerrilla opposition was unable to mount an effective challenge to the voting. Not many black African nations have observed even this much democratic form.

title: Cronkite Faults Papers an.d TV, Citing Coverage
description: Walter Cronkite warned newspaper publishers yesterday that neither television news nor newspapers were adequately informing the public. The CBS anchorman characterized television news as primarily a headline service and expressed dismayat the publishers own statistics showing that 60 to 70 percent of the people  say they get most of their news on television.'.

title: Notre Dame, Navy Agree
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. April 25  Notre Dame and Navy, which have the longest uninterrupted intersectional rivalry in collage football. will play the 54th and 56yh games of their series at Glants Stadium in the Meadowlands in 1980 and 1982.

title: Cabaret: Chita Rivera at Les Mouches
description: CITA RIVERA, a vibrant bundle of energy, is back in New York for a brief showing of her nightclub act at Les Mouches,11th Avenue at 26th Street, through tonight. Supported by two singing dancers, Rick Mason and Michael Serrecchia, Miss Rivera's act, written and produced by Fred Ebb, is very busy, very slick and, often, very loud.

title: Senate Approves a Spending Limit For 1980, Rejecting G.O.P.'s Cuts
description: WASHINGTON. Thursday, April 26 After three days of debate, the Senate approved early today a 8532.6 billion spending ceiling for the fiscal year 1960. one of the leanest, Federal budgets in two decades.

title: National Steel Earnings Climb
description: PITTSBURGH, April 25(AP)  Tbe National. Steel Corporation announced today sharply improved firstquarter earnings but said, nevertheless, they were most unsatisfactory by any measure.

title: Arms Pact Timing Alters Carter's 1980 Political Strategy
description: With his first major address on a new strategic arms accord, President Carter moved yesterday to wrest the initiative from a rising chorus of critics and to set the terms of the national debate on arms control in hopes of not only winning Senate approval of the treaty but also reaping personal political dividends in 1980.

title: Gov. Brown, Differing With Carter, Bids U.S. Abandon Nuclear Energy
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. says that the nation should give up on nuclear power as a future energy source rather than speed up the licenting procedures for power plants, as President Carter has urged.

title: Backgammon:
description: The first Inter Continental Backgammon Tournament, sponsored by the American Backgammon Championships,was held here last weekend. Francois Desmornes took top honors and won the PepsiCola Trophy by defeating Steve Zolotow in an exciting 25point final match. Mr. Desmornes staged a dramatic comeback late in this match. After first falling behind 2013, he rallied, never lost another game, and so went on to win 2520.

title: Carter Trails Kennedy But Bests Brown in Poll
description: Democrats continue to prefer Senator Edward M. Kennedy over President Carter, and Mr. Carter over Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., for the party's Presidential nomination in 1980, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Swan Blanks Giants
description: Nobody argued with the substitute umpires or with Craig Swan last night at Shea Stadium as the senior pitcher of the New York Mets fired a twohitter thit stopped the San Francisco Giants, 20.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Special Committee on Nonuse of Force  10:30 A.M.

title: Pop: Reunited Allmans
description: FOR an anxious halfhour or so Tuesday night, it sounded as if the Allman Brothers Band had reunited in name only. Four of the founding fathers of the famous Southern rock group were on the stage of the soldout Palladium, making their first New York appearance together after three years spent pursuing separate careers, but they were playing with none of their original spirit.

title: Home Beat
description: MARK SHILEN, right, first traveled to India and Afghanistan on vacation some 10 years ago. About four years ago, he got sick of teaching and decided to go into the business of buying and selling rugs from the East. Now he travels between New York and Afghanistan four times a year, staying in New York for twomonth periods. He calls his firm the Khyber Pass Trading Company because, he said, I pass through there  the road between Afghanistan and Pakistan  fairly often. Mr. Shilen rents a 16by13foot vault/space at the MorganManhattan Warehouse, at 80th Street and Third Avenue. There he stores his kilims and dhurries and invites prospective clients to see his rugs. I've thought of opening a gallery or a store here, the 32yearold dealer said, but I think that would be too confining. The 6by8foot wool kilim, hanging on the wall behind him, is about 90 years old and sells for $600. On the floor, there is a 13by9foot kilim for $1,300. The largest piece in stock now is a 19by11foot cotton dhurrie for $3,000. To make an appointment, you can call Mr. Shilen at 9898664 (he plans to stay in New York though late May). He will arrange to meet you in the entrance of the storage warehouse.

title: News Summary
description: Verification of Soviet compliance with a strategic arms limitation treaty will be possible from the day a pact is signed, President Carter declared unequivocally. In a major address, the President warned that the alternative to the projected accord was a dark nightmare of unrestrained arms competition. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Carter Opposes Alaska Land Bill That Endangers Wildlife Ranges
description: WASHINGTON, April is  The Carter Administration leaped back into the Congressional battle over Federal lands in Alaska today with a warning that the President would not accept a new House Interior Committee bill permitting oil and gas exploration in some sensitive areas now protected as wildlife ranges.

title: Trade Offer By Japan Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 Less than a week before an official visit here by Japan's new Prime Minister, Masayoshi. Ohira, the United States has rejected the latest offer by Tokyo to open more Government procurement contracts to foreign bidding.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (UPI) The 79 J.M. Fields department stores, closed 10 days ago for inventory, will reopen Friday for the secondlargest department store liquidation sale in United States history, it was announced today.

title: After Seagram's, What's Next?
description: The statement from the Seagram Company had only one line about Frank S. Berger, saying he had resigned as president of the House of Seagram. It offered no explanation. The remainder of the statement dealt with William M. Wilbur, a 45yearold marketing specialist who succeeded him as head of the North American marketing arm of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, the American subsidiary of Canadianbased Seagram.

title: Tax Chief Defends Plan To Curb Refund Frauds
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)  The Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Jerome Kurtz, today defended his agency's efforts to crack down on fraudulent tax refund schemes that may be costing the Government millions of dollars a year. we nave a pretty good handle on the problem, Mr. Kurtz told a House Government Operations Committee panel that is investigating the tax frauds. The schemes involyethe filing of returns under fictitious names and using false W2 forms that list money never actually withheld.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE WineGlass Hangers
description: WINEGLASS hangers offer a convenient and decorative way to empty precious shelf space and put wine glasses within easy reach. Generally made to be mounted on a low ceiling, or under a cabinet or shelf. several racks can be mounted side by side to hold numerous stem glasses. Most wineglass hangers consist of wooden dowels in vertical rows. The base of the glass slides between the dowels so that the glasses hang upside down. Stanley Stemmer is a doweltype wineglass rack that can be put up on a wall or under a shelf. The rack can accommodate 12 to 18 glasses, depending on the size of the glasses. Stanley Stemmer costs $8 at the Pottery Barn.

title: Stage: The Frequency By Ketton at the WPA
description: LARRY KETRON'S characters have just wandered indoors from a smalltown Southern main street. Their conversation is deeply regional and provincial. The Frequency, at the WPA Theater, is the fourth play by Mr. Ketron that have seen in the last three years, and in common with its predecessors it is an amalgam of modest pleasures and minor irritations. In one crucial respect, it is a step forward. The playwright has had a tendency to end his sketches with a bolt of melodrama. This time he is content to let his people remain downtoearth and in character.

title: Market Place
description: THOSE limited partnerships in the real estate business have always been regarded as havens for the rich something the small investor simply couldn't afford.

title: Waldheim Gets Ready For Visit to Indochina And a Mediator's Role
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 25  In an atmosphere of deep anxiety about the danger of a major war in Southeast Asia; Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations made final preparations here today for a trip to Vietnam and China, hoping to persuade the antagonists to accent him as a mediator.

title: Yankees Scatter Chances in 10 Loss to A's
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 25  If the Seattle Mariners did not treat Jim Todd kindly last February, consider what Todd did to the Yankees tonight.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, April 25 (Reuters)  Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger met with Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia today.

title: At Corning Glass Show, Sculptural Whimsy
description: New Glass, a longawaited exhibition of work by 196 glassmakers from 27 countries, begins its tour of the United States today at the Corning Museum of CORNING, N.Y. Glass here. It is the most prestigious international display of glass seen in this country since Corning's Glass 1959 show.

title: 4 Winning Numbers For Olympic Lottery
description: ALBANY, April 25 (AP)  Four sets of winning numbers have been selected for New York State's Olympic Lottery.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE A Steel Executive Of a Different Mold
description: Another of Pittsburgh's sons, David M. Roderick, the new chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, can speak the steelmen's language with the best of them. But in 1962. when a younger David Roderick was sent to Paris to evaluate and help run United States Steel's overseas operation, he also had a go at speaking French.

title: British Owners of Esquire Magazine Negotiating to Sell It
description: The British conglomerate that owns Esquire magazine is negotiating to sell it.

title: Cities Find Conversion Of Old Military Bases A Boon to Economies
description: MOBILE, Ala.  When Brookley Air Force Base was closed in 1969 with the loss of 13,800 civilian jobs, there were bitter protests and acute apprehension.

title: Brandeis Honors Physicist, 8 Others
description: Jeremy Bernstein, a physicist whose writings have made relatively clear the complexities of computers, genetic engineering and nuclear power, and eight other artists and writers received Brandeis University's 1979 Creative Arts Awards at ceremonies yesterday at the Guggenheim Museum.

title: Chemical Vapors Force Evacuation
description: A fireman being led from the scene of a chemical accident at the NAMCO swimming pool store in Wethersfield, Conn. Noxious fumes, resulting from accidental mixing of chlorine and an algaetreatment solution, caused the evacuation of homes and businesses in the surrounding area. Eight firemen suffering from the effects of the fumes were treated at a hospital.

title: Events
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA, New York State Theater. Purcell's Dido and Aeneas and Strauss's Le Bcurgeols Gentilhomme. 8.

title: Mystery Writers to Award Alberto Tedeschi a Raven
description: Alberto Tedesdd will receive a special Raven from the Mystery Writers of America in the Edgar Allan Poe awards ceremony at the Biltmore Hotel tomorrow evening. It recognizes his 50 years as Europe's most renowned editor in the field of crime, suspense and intrieue stories.

title: Throwing Light on Dark Spots in the Home
description: BE FEDER has designed lighting for everything from Kennedy International Airport to the Bronx Zoo  and that includes the new Broadway play Carmelina and Buckminster Fuller's first geodesic dome.

title: State U. Raises Tuition, Making Fee $900 for All
description: Trustees of the State University of New York yesterday authorized a tuition increase for freshmen and sophomores at the system's 64 campuses. In another action, they rejected the nomination of the governing body of the Stony Brook Center of a candidate to head the Long Island institution.

title: New York Offers Rationale For Its AirQuality Program
description: In the face of some opposition to its new air pollutioncontrol plan, Koch administration officials yesterday offered a rationale for the program, which would include the afternoon closings of two crosstown Manhattan streets to all traffic but buses and cabs and the creation of traffic lanes for the exclusive use of buses.

title: Design Notebook
description: IT is not for nothing that this city likes to think of itself as the most beautiful in the nation. Even with the recent boom in construction of downtown skyscrapers, a boom that Pier 39 is a sign that San Francisco is succumbing to its own cuteness. has turned the financial district into something that looks more like Chicago's Loop than anything San Franciscan, the city retains an aura of lightness and grace that distinguishes it from every other American metropolis.

title: Flooding Mounts as Rainfall in Miami Is Heaviest Ever
description: Residents of the Red River Valley waited nervously yesterday behind miles of spongy dikes shored up by four million sandbags while a record deluge in Florida flushed out poisonous snakes, washed through resorts and flooded homes and highways.

title: Sonics Beat Lakers in Series, 41
description: SEATTLE, April 25 (AP)  Fred Brown's 10 thirdperiod points pushed Seattle on top and Gus Williams added 10 fourthperiod free throws to lead the SuperSonics to a 106100 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight and give the Sonics the National Basketball Association fourofseven playoff series, 41.

title: Soviet Six Retains World Title
description: MOSCOW, April 25  The Soviet Union retained its world hockey championship tonight by crushing Canada, 92, and taking a 3point lead with one game to play. The two other medals were decided earlier in the day at the Luzhniki Sports Palace, when Czechsolovalda defeated Sweden, 63. Czechoslovakia, which leads Sweden by 4 points, finished second and the Swedes third.

title: Terry Cloth: All Dressed Up
description: Terry cloth is out of the bathroom and stepping into the office, the board room and the dinner party.

title: JEWEL THIEVES LOOT A SAFE AT GIMBELS
description: Robbers who apparently hid in the Gimbels department store after closing time on Tuesday night Smashed Open a sale and escaped with diamond jewelry that one estimate said was worth as much at $1 million.

title: Chase Issue to Be Offered
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation's recently announced $300 million issue of convertible floatingrate notes will be offered to investors today. Initially the notes will yield 10 percent.

title: Bridge:
description: A tiny but fastgrowing minority of players realize that a twotable duplicate game, played at home or in a club, represents a highly satisfactory compromise between rubber bridge and tournament play. It is usual to play for a stake. based on international match points, but a reasonable alternative is to form a pool and eventually share between the winners.

title: Halston Stretches Sportswear
description: NOBODY has ever quite decided exactly what sports. wear means. Certainly the term has long ago transcended its origin in golf and tennis dothes.

title: St John's Schneider Wins
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (AP) Joe Schneider of St. John's University won two of the five events on the final day of competition and took the Penn Relays decathlon today. He totaled 7,543 points.

title: Hers
description: NEXT week, after four months in New York  where we came, in January, to escape the worst of a New England winter  my husband and my daughter and I are mow ing back to New Hampshire. So I'm packing boxes now, and finding  as I always do, going from one place to another  that the household goods we fit into our car coming here have now multiplied, and will require a truck going back.

title: On Corporate Takeovers
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has propOsed major changes in the rules that govein tender offers  attempted takeovers of a corporation through a bid made directly to its stockholders without the approval of its management. The proposals come at a critical time: Attempted acquisitions through invitations for tenders of stock are increasingly popular, and the United States Supreme Court will soon decide whether state tenderoffer statutes are invalid, either as an undue burden on interstate commerce or, because Federal law preempts the field.

title: Strikes in New York at a Glance
description: Apartment Houses: The twodayold walkout by service workers had slight effect on an estimated 2,000 buildings hit by the strike, but there were complaint; that pickets were interfering with deliveries to some bulldinas. The strikine union, LOCal 32832.1 Of the ServIce,E.rnployees, said 100 buildings bad made independent settlements, but there was no move to resume talks with the Realty Advisory Board, which represents 1,700 of 3,000 buildings organized by the union. A city hot line, 2679800, manned from A.M. to 5 P.M., was set up to handle emergency problems stemming from the strike. Page B1.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: New rules offering more freedom to cable television systems to compete with local broadcasters were proposed by the Federal Communications Commission. The F.C.C. moved to abolish rules limiting the reception of television broadcast signals via satellite by cable operators. The commission also agreed to propose an end to rules allowing local broadcasters to bar cable operators from televising the same programs as the broadcasters. [Page A1.]

title: The New York Times/John Solmnyor
description: A young man in red gym shorts peered anxiously through the lobby of his apart: ment building at 685 West End Avenue. Did you see anybody with a chest of drawers? he asked Enrique Sierra, who normally works as a doorman there, but who was on strike yesterdaY, along with five other service workers employed there.

title: Thailand Is Said to Let Pot Pot Forces Pass Through
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 25  Authoritative Thai military sources said today that it was Thailand's policy to allow soldiers loyal to ousted Prime Minister Pol Pot of Cambodia to traverse Thai territory in order to evade pursuit by Vietnamese troops and reenter Cambodia at the nearest possible point.

title: DR. B. SCHOENBERG, PSYCHIATRIST, DEAD
description: Dr. Bernard Schoenberg, associate dean tor academic programs and prefer,. sor of clinical psychiatry at the Columbia University College of Physiciansond Surgeons, died yesterday of cancer at the ColumbiaPresbyterian, Medical Center: He was 52 veariold.

title: Mark Lane Is Investigated for Alleged Grand Theft
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25The Los Angeles County District Attorney's office is investigating Mark Lane, the lawyer and author, in connection with allegations of possible grand theft in his association with the People's Temple.

title: Table Tennis Tourney In Pyongyang Protested
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea, April 25 (AP)  The 35th world table tennis championships opened today with a lavish ceremony, the likelihood of several nations protesting the exclusion of South Korea and Israel, and an apparent snub by President Kim II Sung of North Korea.

title: Iran Lifts Gas Export To Soviet
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 25  Iran annotmced today that it had exported 11.3 billion cubic feet of natural gas to the Soviet Union in the month that began March 21, the start of the Iranian New Year.

title: Leopold Ludwig Dead; Opera Director Was 71
description: LUENEBURG, West Germany, April 25 (UPI)  Leopold Ludwig, musical director of the Hamburg Opera for 19 years and frequently a guest director at the Metropolitan and San Francisco Operas, died today at the age of 71.

title: Carl Albert, in Oklahoma, Basks In Afterglow of the Speakership
description: McALESTER, Okla.  Every morning Carl Albert drives down Carl Albert Parkway, past the Carl Albert statue in front of the Federal Building and enters the office in downtown McAlester provided to him by law as a former Speaker of the House.

title: Dutch Dehizert, at 81; Star Basketball Player
description: Hairy (Dutch) Dehnert, a Hall of Fame basketball player who is credited with developing the pivot play, died of a heart attack last Friday at Peninsula Hospital in Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 81 years old.

title: Pop: Gino Vannelli Sings
description: GINO VANNELLI'S concert at Carnegie Hall Tuesday night could only have happened in the late 70's. Mr. Vannelli. who looks something like the biblical Samson, is basically a bigvoiced pop belter, Ake Tony Bennett or Vic Damone. But he is backed by a band that uses heavy amplification and no fewer than three players of electronic keyboard instruments to create a thick orchestral wall of sound, and his original music combines jazz harmony and rock and disco rhythms in a manner that would resemble conventional jazzrock if there was more improvisation in it.

title: Socal, 3 Other Refiners Post Gains for Quarter
description: Four more leading oil companies, including the Standard Oil Company of California, one of the industry's giants, reported sharp profit rises yesterday.

title: Deaths
description: FE RRIS  Arliwr N. M. it Meadow Lake. Hichetotem, N.J. Vernal rem m April 241h. Beloved &Nand of Arm Comer Farr* beloved father it Mrs. George Schirmer and /Ors. J Brawn. Fs furiffer Information contact the Never Funeral Horne. 302 Stodctos St.. 0110 folown.

title: Weizman, in Egypt, Causes Stir With P.L.O. Remark
description: CAIRO, April, 25  Defense Minister, Ezer Weizman of Israel arrived here today for talks and immediately caused a stir with a remark that seemed to invite the Palestine Liberation Organization to join the peace discUssions begun by Egypt and Israel.

title: Talking Business
description: The American Stock Exchange has long labored in the shadow of the larger and more prestigious New York Stock Exchange, usually listing companies too Iwith Arthur Levitt Jr. on Small Business small to qualify for the Big Board. Under Arthur Levitt Jr., its chairman, the Amex has been trying to take advantage of this traditional role by establishing itself as a national advocate for smaller businesses.

title: Police Press Inquiry on Rampage at East Side Grocery
description: Police officials pushed an investigation yesterday into a rampage on the Lower East Side Tuesday afternoon in which neighborhood youths allegedly wrecked an East Fourth Street grocery store.

title: Advertisinor
description: MAKERS of expensive goods and suppliers of chic services are always seeking media that will allow them to reach the rich effecientIv. Knowing this. media entrepreneurs are continually dreaming up advertising vehicles to reach one group and please the other.

title: Police Search for Bodies Near Abandoned Tracks of the Penn Central
description: Police officers, with the aid of a bulldozer, searching for bodies of lowerechelon mob figures believed to have been slain, according to an informant, by a West Sidebased gang thought to have ties with organized crime. Accord ing to the informant, victims were alegedly murdered sometime in 1976 1977. Search, which began last Thursday, is being made along tracks from 38th to 52d Street, and between 10th and 11th Avenues. No bodies have been found.

title: Home Improvement
description: WHEN heavy rains or large accumulations of melted snow come pouring off the roof of a house or down slope that faces the house, the ground soon becomes saturated. That increases the danger of soil washouts next to the foundation, and of course it can lead to flooding of the basement. A roof gutter system that is regularly cleaned out and properly maintained (as described in the April 19 column) will carry the water off the roof safely by channeling it through the downspouts and away from the house foundation.

title: LEARN ABOUT TRAVEL OR TRAIL As AGENTS
description: Course licensed by N.Y. State Dept. of Education! Prepare for a career in the expanding international travel field (full or part time) or start your own firm with our free Agency Advisory Service. Trips to Airlines, Hotels, Cruise Liners, etc. feature inthefield training. Phone, write or visit for Free Travel Career Uterallub.

title: France Says a Vintner Falsely Labeled Wine
description: PARIS, April 25 (UPI)  A Sturmdian vintner has been accused of shipping 70,000 bottles of elegantly labeled cheap wine to the United States in a scandal reminiscent of one in Bordeaux five years ago.

title: GARDENING
description: THE gardening boom of the 70's brought With it a flood of books. There were some excellent and original volumes; but. most were rather weak and wererapidly relegated to the remaindered shelf. More recently, gardening books have improved in quality and become more specialized, paralleling the gardeper's own trend away from generalism.

title: NUCLEAR COMMISSION GETS PLEA BY STAFF TO SHUT NINE PLANTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission recommended today that all power plants operating with Babcock & Wilcox reactors like the one used in the Three Mile Island accident be shut down immediately until their safety could be assured.

title: F.B.I. Fills Laboratory Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)  Bell P. Herndon, a 28year veteran of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was named today as assistant director of the bureau's laboratory division to replace Thomas S. Kelleher, who is retiring. Mr. Herndon is a native of New York City.

title: Hartfoid Passes A Plan to Revise Aid for Schools
description: HARTFORD, April 25  Five years after a state court struck down Connecticut's system of, financing its public schools as unconstitutional, the State Senate gave final approval tonight to a plan aimed at a more equitable system of dispensing state aid to schools over the next five years.

title: Concert: New Music via Cleveland
description: LIKE much new music heard around town, the six pieces presented at a concert by the Cleveland Composers Guild on Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hallappeared more concerned with texture and formal design than any sort of weighty emotional statement. The concert was a little too long, and none of the music seemed strikingly original. Still, it added up to an interesting and reasonably varied evening.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Canon and Fugue in the Old Style for 2 Violins, No. 3, Reger; The Marriage of Figaro, Overture, Mozart; Legende, Wieniawski.

title: Rangers Suddenly a Threat
description: For most of the season, hockey experts have insisted that the Islanders were destined to play the Montreal Canadiens for the Stanley Cup. So far, that prediction remains valid as both clubs have only to win their semifinal rounds to meet for the National Hockey League championship.

title: Ruling Spares State's Banks
description: A Federal court ruling last week that automatic transfers of funds from savings accounts to checking accounts are illegal will have no practical effect on customers of New York banks, Donald C. Platten, chairman of the Chemical New York Corporation, the holding company of the Chemical Bank, told shareholders meeting in New York yesterday.

title: ExManager of G.S.A. Store. Gets 4 Years in Corruption Conspiracy
description: BALTIMORE, April 25 (AP)  A former manager of the General Services Administration supply store in Baltimore was sentenced today to four years in jail for his role in the agency corruption scandal.

title: Theater: Marnet's The Woods' Redone at Public
description: DAVID MAMET's The Woods, which showed beauty and strength when it was performed in Chicago a year and a half ago, has gone very flat indeed in its new production at the Public Theater.

title: The Gook Hunter
description: LOS ANGELES  I have spent much of my adult life in Vietnam and the United States as a journalist and documentaryfilm maker. I have been with. American soldiers when they were killed or maimed. I admire America's admirable side and, like millions of Americans, haibor rational fears aboutits lethal side.

title: WellChosen Judges in New York
description: Governor Carey's choice of Bernard Meyer for the Court of Appeals is encouraging in two respects. The nominee is a distinguished lawyer and former jurist who brings intellectual strength and industry to the state's highest bench. And the choice vindicates the new merit selection system, thus advancing the Governor's plan to apply it to the state's trial courts.

title: Health Survey Finds Poor Habits Prevail
description: THE notion that the American family is caught up in a regimen of calorie counting, cholestrol watching, jogging through the park and other healthful pursuits was largely debunked in a national study released here yesterday.

title: These Olympics Are Special
description: Behind him,Peter Smits felt a tug at his sleeve. Turning, he looked down at a mentally retarded athlete with two Special Olympic gold medals hanging from ribbons around his neck. He was so small, only about 4 feet tall, I thought he was a youngster, Peter StriltS says now. i touna out later that he was 32 years old. But as the tiny athlete stared up at him on the running track at Brockport State College during the 1976 New York State Special Olympics meet, Peter Smits asked what events he had won.

title: Facts About Walkout Of Building Employees
description: The striking union, Local 32B323 of the Service Employees Union, represents 20,000 doormen, handymen, elevator operators, porters and some superintendents in 3,000 apartment houses and cooperatives in Manhattan, Oueens. Brooklyn and Staten Island.

title: Soviet Woman Caught in a Trap Between Divorce and Emigration
description: MOSCOW, April 25  Last week, while 18 members of the United States Congress were here discussing Soviet emigration restrictions with Moscow officials, Tatyana Lozansky, a 26yeanold chemist whose father is a senior Soviet general, despaired of ever getting out.

title: Michelangelo at Morgan
description: It has lacked the fanfare of the King Tut show, and the advance billing of Pompeii, but Michelangelo and His World, opening today at the Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, is the largest and most important show of drawings bythe Renaissance sculptor ever seen on this continent.

title: Negotiators, for The Daily News And Guild Fail to Reach Accord
description: Negotiators for The Daily News and the Newspaper Guild of New York yesterday failed to reach agreement on disputed issues that have held up a final contract settlement between the guild and The News and, indirectly, between the guild and The New York Times.

title: City Opera: New Manon
description: GLENYS FOWLES has proved her worth to the New York City Opera in a number of leading roles, but none have given her the scope that the part of Manon offers. On Tuesday night she sang the title role of Massenet's opera for the first time with the company, and she handled it With the confidence rind skill that have made her such a delightful artist.

title: Concert: Musica Aeterna Orchestra
description: FAURE'S Requiem is a strange and precious piece that can be puzzling bore in some hands. It demands virtuosity of a sort. particularly from the chorus, which is called on to murmur consolingly and whisper tenderly much of the time, but nothing could work against the music's effectiveness more than overt displays of technical skill. Perhaps the most common disappointment in Faure Requiem performances, however, is having to put up with performers who go to great lengths to emphasize the music's elegant manners and quiet expressiveness. What is more boring than the person who insists on letting you know he has good taste?

title: Speech by Pope Paul Viewed as an Opening Toward WorkerPriest
description: ROME, April 25  Pope John Paul II urged priests today to strive so that the gap between the church and the factory narrows and that the fumes of incense mix with those of industry.

title: Gambling Issues Help Lift Dow
description: Gambling stocks registered some of the stock market's best gains yesterday, while the general list rose slightly in active tradine.

title: State Justice Finds Preliminary Evidence That Striking Union of Prison Guards Is in Contempt of Court
description: ALBANY, April 25  Justice Edward Conway of State Supreme Court made a preliminary ruling today that the state had produced enough evidence to show that the union representing striking correction officers was guilty, along with one of its too officials. of contempt of court.

title: Notes on People
description: One of the two Bouvier sisters is about to marry again. The wedding of Lee Radziwill and Newton Cope, a San Francisco hotel and realestate millionaire, will take place there at a small ceremony next week. The couple met when Mrs. Radziwill, an interior designer, went to supervise the refurbishing of the Huntington Hotel on Nob Hill, which Mr. Cope owns.

title: State Trade Curb Barred
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  The Supreme Court has ruled that a state's efforts to conserve its wildlife violate the Constitution if they put outofstate residents at a commercial disadvantage.

title: Corporations Report Their Sales and Earnings Results for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: London Stocks at Peak Level
description: LONDON, April 25 (AP)  Stock prices in London reached a record high today, buoyed by hopes for a Conservative Party victory in next week's elections.

title: Panel Fails to Halt Loss of Banks in Fed
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  A fresh effort to deal with erosion of membership in the Federal Reserve system what G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has termed his highest legislative priority  failed to clear the House Banking Committee today.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 25. 1979

title: Justice Promises Parole to a Man In Stabbing Case
description: A Manhattan man accused of stabbing an actress last year has pleaded guilty to a charge of attempted murder in return for a promise from a State Supreme Court justice to hand down a sentence that would make the defendant eligible for parole on the day he went to prison.

title: TORMENT OF ULSTER IS ITS BIG VOTE ISSUE
description: ARMAGH, Northern Ireland, April 25  Harold McCusker, Member of Parliament, interrupted his canvassing for votes in this green, rolling farm district one afternoon last week to rush to the scene of a terrorist bombing in which four policemen had been killed.

title: Mexican Phone Workers Strike
description: MEXICO CITY, April 25 (AP)  Telephone workers struck the Governmentowned telephone company today in a wage dispute, causing the suspension of national and international service, a Communications Ministry spokesman said.

title: Borg, Connors, McEnroe Advance at Las Vegas Net
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 25 (UPI) Bjorn Borg, with a struggle, and Jimmy Connors, with no struggle, advanced today to the third round of the $250,000 Alan King tennis tournament.

title: VOL. CXXVII.. No.44,199
description: Copyright  1779 The New York Times

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The first fulltime White House speech writer was Judson Welliver, who worked with President Harding on his bloviation. and later helped Calvin Coolidge reach his rhetorical heights.

title: Q &
description: Q. I recently moved into a house that has slate floors in several rooms. These floors had heavy accumulations of wax and I am having difficulty removing it. I have mopped numerous times with various household detergents and with Clorox, but have had only limited success. I finally tried muriatic acid, which appears to be doing the job, but the grout areas still retain an ugly residue. Have you any suggestions as to how to treat these floors?C.T., Pittsburgh.

title: Ugandan Joins Kampala Army To Get Revenge
description: BOMB0, Uganda, April 25  Ali Lubega enlisted in the Uganda National Liberation Army today to join the fight against Idi Amin. But the war may well be over before he sees any combat. His wounds must heal first.

title: Televised Hearings Are Planned In Inquiry on California's Justices
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25  Televised hearings in which members of the California Supreme Court will be questioned about their handling of cases, the timing of the announcements of decisions and whether any court members gave inside information to outsiders will begin about June 18, the State Commission on Judicial Performance announced today.

title: Associated Press
description: NATO MINISTERS MEET IN FLORIDA: Hans Ape!, West Germany's Defense Minister, talking with Defense Secretary Harold Brown after twoday conference ended at Homestead Air Force Base yesterday. Defense officials from NATO countries gathered to discuss nuclear preparedness.

title: The Region
description: Citing new guidelines by President Carter, the Consolidated Edison Company said it had reapplied to state and city environmental officials to let it use highersulfur oil starting in May through August.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title
description: REILLVAntu Virginia on Tuesday. April 34. m. Devoted sister ef sr. EIKebeth. Hugh, Ruth Retlry. Mary Bradley and the late Peter Reilly. Funeral from the Conway Funeral Heme, Northern Blvd. t U St, Jackson Height on Friday. 10AM. Mass of Christian burial St. Joan of Arc Church. 1B:XAM. Interment St. Joseph's Cemetery, Lyndhurst. N.J. Visiting hrsJSftMOPM.

title: C. Robert Vogel, 63, Executive In Realty.Development Concern
description: C. Robert Vogel, senior vice president of the GalbreathRuffin Corporation, realestate developers and managers, died Monday of a heart attack at his office at 150 East 42d Street. He was 63 years old and lived in St. James, L.I.

title: STRAUSS VOWS EFFORT TO LEARN ON MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  Robert S. Strauss was explaining today that just because President Carter had named him as a kind of superambassador for the Middle East, it doesn't mean that I'm qualified to deal with Middle East issues.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: Article 5 -- No Title

title: Eastern's Bid for National Opposed
description: The Transportation and Justice Departments recorded their opposition yesterday to the bid by Eastern Air Lines to acquire Natiorial Airlines. They argued that such a takeover would diminish competition and increase fares.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 PM.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Robert Van Kleek, 55, Executive of J.C. Penney
description: Robert R. Van Kleek, vice president and director of special business operations for the J. C. Penney Company, died yesterday in the company's New York Cityoffice. He was 55 years old and lived in Madison, N.J.

title: OneYear Bills Sold at 9.235%
description: The Treasury auctioned oneyear bills yesterday at an average yield of 9.235 percent, up slightly from the previous sale of 9.230 percent.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television Cablevision, 8 P.M. Radio WMCA, delayed tape following Islanders game.)Yankees vs. A's. at Oakland, Calif. (Television  Cablevision, 10:30 P.M. Radio WINS, 10:30 P.M.)

title: Israeli Gunners Bombard Lebanon For 4th Day and Jets Buzz Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 25  Israeli gunboats and artillery bombarded Palestinian targets in Lebanon today for the fourth day, reportedly routing thousands of civilians. At the same time Israeli planes swept low over Beirut and other cities, stirring widespread panic.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DIGGING IN Each year, the Toscanini Memorial Archives sponsors free program demonstrating the relationship of original music T sources to performances, as previously with works by Beethoven, Gilbert and Sullivan and Rossini. Tonight's event at 8 o'ciocit at me Luicoin center canaryMuseum is a lecture and recital deyoted to Bach.

title: Washington Post Gains
description: The Washington Post Company, publisher of The Washington Post, several other newspapers and Newsweek magazine, said yesterday that its firstquarter earnings had risen 21.1 percent to $8.6 million, or 54 cents a share, from $7.1 million, or 43 cents a share, in the 1978 quarter. Revenues rose to $130.3 million from $112.8 million. The compant attributed the gains to improved advertising and circulation of its newspapers and magazines and to higher revenues in its broadcast division.

title: GasRation Plan Barred
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  Despite a lastminute public plea from President Carter, the House Commerce Committee handed the White House another setback on energy today, rejecting the Administration's proposal for rationing gasoline in national emergencies.

title: State Mutual Plans Sale of New Stock
description: State Mutual Investors of Worcester, Mass., a former real estate investment trust now in a management operation, said that its adviser, the State Mutual Life Assurance Company of America, had approved a previously announced plan to raise as much as $28 million through the sale of stock.

title: Dale Ratliff Dead at 47, President of Max Factor
description: Memorial services will be held Saturday in Mountain Lake, N.J., for Dale Ratliff, president of Max Factor & Company, who died last Saturday in Los Angeles of a heart attack.

title: EDWARD SCHIPE
description: Edward Schipe, an electrical engineer who designed general radio and radiomarine equipment, died Monday at his home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. He was 74 years old.

title: Hudson Guild to Stage Devour the Snow May
description: Devour the Snow, a drama about the survivors of the Donner Party wagon train, will be the final production in the Hudson Guild Theater's season. The play. by Abe Polskv. a television and motion picture writer, will open next Wednesday and continue through June 3.

title: British Football
description: SCOTTISH LEAGUE

title: Ballet: Pierrot Lunaire
description: ANTONY TUDOR and Glen Tetley are not choreographers who would normally be put into the same category. And yet both are concerned with expressing emotion through movement and both seemed drawn to the same theme in two ballets presented by the American Ballet Theater on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Ampex Revives After Reverses
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., April 25 The Ampex Corporation, the pioneering electronics company that developed the first commercial tape recorder and television instant replay device, has not always managed to benefit financially from its technical ingenuity.

title: COMMODITIES Gold, Silver Prices Up; Copper Futures Decline
description: Renewed talk of inflation led to price increases yesterday in silver, platinum and gold futures, while copper futures declined.

title: Blacks Buy Midwest TV Station
description: A group of 34 black Chicago business men and women has purchased WAEOTV. an NBC affiliate, in Rhinelander.

title: CART Suit to Challenge Rejections of Indy Entries
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 25 (UPI) The feud between the United States Auto Club and a splinter group for control of Indianapolistype racing appeared headed for the courts today.

title: CREDIT MARKETS No 40Year Bond Issue In Treasury Refinancing
description: The Treasury announced yesterday that it would sell 10year notes and 30year bonds next week to refinance notes maturing May 15 and to raise $2.5 billion in additional cash.

title: Young Warns Against Recognition Of the New Rhodesian Government
description: UNITED NATIONS; MY., April 25 Andrew Young, the chief United States. delegate here. warned today that recog. ninon by Washington of the newly elected Rhodesian Government would make much of southern Africa feel them. was no alternative but to. resort to military struggle.

title: Physicist Urges House Doctors For Energy. Efficiency in Homes
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  Creating a new profession of house doctor, experts in making homes and commercial buildings more energyefficient, was urged here today by a physicist exploring such improvements for the Carnegie Mellon Institute of Research in nearby Arlington. Va.

title: Over Bacon and Eggs; Governor of Montana Finds City Likes Beef
description: Although they ate bacon and eggs, not cornedbeef hash, city's political establishment turned out for breakfast yesterday with Gov. Thomas L. Judge of Montana to show that New Yorkers were not really serious abolit beef boycott.

title: House Panel Votes Cost Limits For Hospitals on Standby Basis
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)  A House subcommittee overrode solid Republican opposition today and approved President Carter's proposal for standby cost controls on the hospital industry.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: BOOKS fall from Garry Wills like leaves from a maple tree in a sort of permanent October. Confessions of a GanserCONFESSIONS OF A CONSERVATIVE. By Garry Wills. 231 pages. Doubleday. $10 vative is his third in less than a year, a prodigality that even his first editor, William F. Buckley Jr., at The National Review, must whistle at. And Mr. Wills will write a book about anyone and anything  G.K. Chesterton, Black Power, Thomas Jefferson, Roman Culture, Jack Ruby, Richard M. Nixon and the Roman Catholic Church. not to mention a thriller. Now he writes about himself in an intellectual autobiography that scintillates without quite satisfying.

title: E.C.C. Proposes Eased Cable Rules To Increase Television Competition
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  The Federal Communications Commission pro. posed rules today that could give cable television systems more freedorsi to csiriipete with local broadcasters.

title: Blind Needleworkers Display Their Crafts
description: AWALL hanging stitched by blind artisans is the most innovative example of needlework on view in the Biennial National Exhibit of Amateur Needlework of Today, on view at the Lighthouse, 111 East 59th Street, through Wednesday.

title: Sticht Moves to Top at Reynolds
description: Shortly after J. Paul Sticht was named president of R.J. Reynolds Industries in 1973, he told an interviewer: Colin and I look at this job as a total partnership. The job of running a corporatiorl uxiay Is very complicated.The Colin referred to by Mr. Sticht is Colin Stokes, who at that time was chairman and chief executive officer of Reynolds. And the job he referred to was running the giant corporation that is not only the nation's biggest tobacco manufacturer, but also a leader in food processing, shipping and other fields.

title: About Minisink Ford
description: MINISINK FORD, N.Y., April 24The bridge from here to Pennsylvania is a small and gentle gem across The Delaware River. Its low spans set a lilting line above the water's rush. Its strength is as sure as on the day it opened 130 years ago, when John A. Roebling, the genius of suspension bridges, designed it as a rustic prelude to his great urban symphony, the Brooklyn Bridge:

title: Options Marts to Combine
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the combination of options markets between the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the financially troubled Midwest Stock Exchange as a first step toward a full merger of the bodies. The S.E.C. said it would permit the Midwest exchange to relocate its trading floor next to the Chicago floor if the Chicago exchange adopted recommendations required for expansion of trading.

title: Opera: Saga, Folk Work, at the Lyric
description: EAST Fourth Street, down by the Bowery, may seem an unlikely place to find a folk opera about the westward expansion and settlement of the United States in the 19th century, but there, at the Wonderhorse Theater, is where Kelly Hamilton's Saga is being sung, acted and danced rather charmingly by the Lyric Theater of New York.

title: World Gold
description: WEDNESDAY, APRA. 25. 1979

title: PRESIDENT SAYS U.S. IS ABLE TO MONITOR TREATY WITH SOVIET
description: President Carter declared unequivocally yesterday that the United States could verify: Soviet conipliance with a strategic arms limitation treaty from the day it was signed, and warned that the alternative to the treaty was a dark nightmare of unrestrained arms competition.

title: Nuclear Arms Mishap Simulated
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 25 (AP) Five hundred military and civilian radiation experts at the Nevada Test Site have ended a weeklong, $1.6 million rehearsal for handling a nuclear weapons accident. The test involved a simulated crash of a C141 aircraft with six nuclear warheads and the use of lowlevel radium223 to add realism. There were no reporti of injuries.

title: Iranians Decide to Purge and Phase Out Vigilantes
description: TEHERAN. Iran, April 25  The chief of the revolutionary committees that have been acting as a rival to the revolutionary Government as a source of power in Iran announced today that the Islamic vigilante groups would be purged and eventually phased out. He said 4000 of their armed militiamen would be incorpor ated into a national police force.

title: PESSIMISM ABOUNDS OVER A RUBBER PACT
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  The fragile contract talks between the United Rubber Workers and Uniroyal Inc., the tire manufacturer, ended a second day here tonight with indications from all involved that the chance for an early resolution of the differences appeared remote.

title: Israeli Court Aids Bedouin Cause
description: JERUSALEM, April 25  In a move with important implications for Israeli military security and the treatment of Bedouins, the supreme court issued an order today forbidding the Government to expropriate lands belonging to the Bedouins of the Negev region until the matter is ruled upon by local courts With the signing of the IsraeliEgyptian peace treaty, a vast redeployment of military installations will take place over the next three years from the Sinai Peninsula to the Negev, in the south of Israel adjacent to Sinai. The court's decision may mean a delay in the construction of new military bases in the Negev, some of them on Bedouin land. But the court's Ming was also meant to assuage fears over Israel's behavior toward the 35,000 Bedouins in the Negev.

title: EARNINGS Kodak Profit Rose 40.1% in Quarter
description: The Eastriran Kodak Company, the woild's largest producer of photo. graphic products, reported yesterdays 40.1 percent. jump in firstquarter net income to $197.5 million, or $1.22 share, from $141 million, or 87 cents share: Last Friday the Polaroid Corporation, its chief domestic competitor. reported an 18 percent increase in firstquarter earnings to $17.1 million, or 52 cents a share.,

title: Volkswagen May Open Second U.S. Auto Plant
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, April 25  Vblkswagen is considering opening a second automobile plant in the United States to supplement the production, from its yearold assembly plant in New Stanton, Pa. A decision is expected by the end of the year.

title: Disks: Schubert Songs
description: CHUBERT'S Songs are a staple of our concert life, and in this 150th anniversary season of the composer's death we've heard them all the more. Hermann Prey, the German baritone, is one of the most commonly encountered lieder singers of the day, a man who has probably recorded more songs than anyone except Dietrich FischerDieskau. But this disk, a part of the observance of that anniversary, is still something special.

title: Prices Rise 0.9% in France
description: PARIS, April 25 (AP)  The French retail price index rose by ninetenths of 1 percent in March, compared with an increase of seventenths of 1 percent ih February, the statistical institute announced today. During the first quarter of this year the index climbed 2.5 percent, and over the 12 months ended in March it rose 10.1 percent.

title: Single by Rose Lifts Phils Over Dodgers
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (UPI) Pete Rose singled in Lonnie Smith with two out in the ninth inning tonight, capping a tworun rally that gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 54 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers and a sweep of their threegame series.
