title: Carter Shows a Lot of 76 Political Magic Remains
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H., April 25 It's good to be back in New Hamp. shire, said the shirtsleeved man on stage. One of the advantages of being an unknown candidate when I came to New Hampshire for the first time to campaign in 1975 was that my family and 1 could talk to you individually. or in groups of five or six, in living rooms and in kitchens, across the counter, at the drug store or on the street, in the beano halls. I don't get a chance to do that very much any more. And I miss it.

title: Beatrice Solomon Dead; Retired Federation Aide
description: Beatrice R. Solomon, an administrative staff member of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies until her retirement 24 years ago, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in New York City. She was 84 years old and until she became ill two years ago she lived in Brooklyn.

title: Jersey Limiting Visits to Prison By TeenAgers
description: TRENTON, April 26  New Jersey Corrections Commissioner William H. Fauver, moving to tighten control over controversial juvenilecounseling program that purports to deter crime, directed officials at Rahway State Prison today to allow only certified juvenile delinquents to undergo sessions withinmates at the maximumsecurity orison.

title: Movie: George Roy Hill Offers 'A Little Romance':In Love in Paris
description: PARIS in the spring. A beautiful, brilliant, American student named Lauren meets and falls in love with Daniel, who is French and as brilliant as Lauren. They both read Heidigger and share a fondness for American films, especially those, like "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" and "The Sting," that were directed by George Roy Hill. Though they act as if they were sophisticated, they are nave at heart. When Daniel takes Lauren to see her first porn film, she runs out in tears. She hadn't expected it to be "like that." "That," says Daniel, "isn't love."How old are Lauren and Daniel? It's difficult to tell. It's not only because Diane Lane, who plays Lauren, is tall and could pass for 18, and because Thelonious Bernard, who plays Daniel, is short and could pass for 13, but because the attitudes, manners and language imposed on them seem to be those of the screenwriter, who may be prematurely aged.Lauren and Daniel are, I think, meant to be comic and appealing in their mixture of innocence and worldliness. Yet Mr. Hill's "A Little Romance," which opens today at the Sutton, recalls most vividly the arch manner in which the Our Gang comedies workedby having their child actors ape not the behavior of children but of grownups."A Little Romance" is a movie that seems to have melted the minds of everyone of any stature connected with it. Fifteen years ago, Mr. Hill made one of his first big splashes in movies with that still-charming comedy, "The World of Henry Orient," after which he went on to do "Butch Cassidy," "The Sting," "Slaughterhouse Five" and "The Great Waldo Pepper." That's an impressive record in terms of art and commerce. Yet "A Little Romance" is so ponderous it seems almost mean spirited. It's been a long time since I've seen a movie about boorish American tourists and felt sorry for the touristswhich is one of Mr. Hill's achievements here.I'm sure nothing mean-spirited was intended, but such is the film's effect. This may be the main hazard when one sets out to make a film so relentlessly sweet-tempered that it winds uplike Pollyana  alienating everyone not similarly affected.Its most appalling spectacle is not the manner in which its two young actors behave. Although Mr. Bernard never makes a move that Mr. Hill does not seem to have directed, Miss Lane occasionally has some nicely spontaneous moments. The grim thing in "A Little Romance" is the sight of Laurence Olivier coming as close to making a spectacle of himself as he ever has in his screen career.Mr. Olivier plays the Maurice Chevalier role, a role in which even Mr. Chevalier finally became tiresome. Mr. Olivier is never tiresomesometimes he is quite funnybut he does seem desperate. As an elderly, extremely soft-hearted, French pickpocket who befriends the young lovers, Mr. Olivier is required to be not much more than cute. Because this clearly doesn't interest him, he gives the busiest, most lip-smacking, most eyeball-rolling performance of his career, outdoing even his impersonation of a West Indian Othello some years ago.Usually such outrageous Olivier behavior is fun to watch even when it doesn't fit. This time it's more suspenseful than fun. We keep wondering (and fearing) what business he's going to come up with next to take our minds off the essential foolishness of the enterprise. Typical is a sequence in which the old man learns from a Veronese newspaper that he is being sought for kidnapping, after he's accompanied the children from Paris to Italy under the impression he's taking them to the girl's sick mother. You've never heard so many grand variations of snorts, groans and whimpers. Yet because the film is so uninvolving, the performance comes to look like an inventory of the Olivier special effects. It makes one appreciate a little more what he did in "Marathon Man," "The Betsy" and "The Boys from Brazil," as well as the films themselves.The other players in the film include Sally Kellerman, as Lauren's heedless, much-married mother; Arthur Hill, as her stepfather, and Broderick Crawford, as himself, a role that really does not fit him very well. Miss Kellerman's material allows little room for her to move in, while Mr. Hill, playing the same part he had in "The Champ," seems in danger of becoming so self-effacing he may wake up one morning to find himself invisible.David Dukes is amusing as a movie director who may or may not be modeled on William Friedkin. Ashby Semple plays Lauren's best friend, a "Junior Miss" role, that of a tall, gawky girl with braces on her teeth. The part is gross."A Little Romance," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains some mildly suggestive sequences, though the porn film mentioned above is neither seen nor heard.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Consumer prices climbed 1 percent in March, keeping inflation firmly in double digits, the Government reported. The March increase produced the fastest rate of gain in living costs in the first quarter in four and a half years, the Government said. Prices rose at a compound annual rate of 13 percent in the quarter and were up 10.2 percent in the 12 months through March. Costs of food, energy and housing showed the sharpest increases. [Page Al.]

title: Rain Interrupts Mets Streak
description: The final game of the threegame series between the New York Mets and San Francisco Giants was rained out last night. The Mets, having pulled out of a sixgame losing spin, now will face the Los Angeles Dodgers at Shea Stadium this weekend with a threegame winning streak that cludes two victories over the Giants.

title: Market Place
description: TENNECO INC., the largest naturalgas pipeline company in the United States, has been lagging in the stock market relative to its industry since the beginning of the year, even though it participates broadly in the energy business.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  The talk of Washington these days is a serious analysis in the current issue of The Atlantic by James Fellows, a 29yearold former speech writer in the White House, on the character of President Carter and the personnel and procedures of his Administration.

title: Angry Jackson, Miss., Seeks Someone to Blame in Flood
description: JACKSON, Miss., April 26  The Easter weekend flood that caused an estimated $500 million damage to some of Mississippi's richest neighborhoods has left behind a whirlpool of recriminations, lawsuits and threatened grand jury in vestigations as this city looks for someone to blame.

title: Fear of Slides on Malibu Hillside Forces Evacuation
description: MALIBU, Calif., April 26 (AP)  A groaning, rumbling Malibu hillside could tumble into the sea at any time, destroying six $500,000 homes, an apartment building and a section of the Pacific Coast highway, geologists said today The houses and the fourunit apartment building situated on the ocean side of the highway were evacuated last night when a threefold increase in the earth's mumblings caused concern to the state authorities. The hillside and the homes were still there today, and some residents returned.

title: Letters
description: I have been an occasional visitor to Saudi Arabia, as consultant concerning the domestic development of the country. Out of my perception of Saudi Arabian attitudes I am writing to present an emphasis missing from Arthur Schlesinger's piece on U.S. military aid to Yemen [OpEd April 9].

title: Music: Pommier, Pianist, In Philharmonic Debut
description: IN the penultimate weekend of the New York Philharmonic season, Zubin Mahta last night took his men through a program of Schubert, SaintSatins and Stravinsky. The Schubert was a continuation of Mr. Mahta's series honoring the1150th anniversary of the composers death, and the work on this program was the Sixth Symphony in C, one of the leastplayed.

title: Brewers Conquer Tigers Twice
description: MILWAUKEE, April 26 (UPI) Robin Yount knocked in four runs in the second game and Gorman Thomas homered in each, game today, helping. the Milwaukee Brewers sweep a doubleheader from the Detroit Tigers, 51 and 75.

description: Theodore Sander Jr., former Mayor of Scarsdale, N.Y., died Monday at his home. He was 82 years old and had lived in Scarsdale since 1935.

description: Utility issues moved lower yesterday as the general market retreated after posting small gains in the four previous sessions.

title: The Pop Life
description: SOLO projects in rock are often illprepared ego trips. Musicians grow restless within the confines of a group, get together a more or less starry passel of friends, and out comes the solo album. The result, often as not, is sloppily considered, inferior work in which the artist indulges in some facet of music for which he's neither talented nor trained - guitarists sing, singers compose, Pte.

title: At the Movies
description: IT'S been real nice weather since we got to Nashville, Sissy Spacek reported the other day. The trees are abuddin out all over. We're shooting at the Grand Ole Opry. It's exciting because I'm working with all of Loretta's musicians.

title: Easy Victory Posted By Spectacular Bid
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 26  His trainer had wanted a tough, useful workout for him, but Spectacular Bid did not get it today in the $121,550 Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland. Instead, the favorite for the 105th Kentucky Derby hardly had to work at all.

title: General Public Cuts Dividend
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation voted yesterday to halve its dividend and to cut its spending for new construction, the salaries of executives and directors and stockoption plans to help cope with the costs incurred in its Three Mile Island plant's nuclear accident.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Weaker Abroad, Mixed in New York
description: The dollar was mixed in late New York trading after slipping against most major currencies abroad yesterday. Gold prices drifted lower, fading in Zurich to $242.375 a troy ounce from Wednesday's late price $242.625 and to $242.50 in London, down from $242.75.

title: Radio City Chandeliers Become Party Lights
description: One of the huge chandeliers in Radio City Music Hall's Grand Foyer being lowered to a height of about 12 feet from the floor as restoration of the famous landmark got under way yesterday. The lights, each two tons of steel and glass, were lowered from their normal positions, about 12 feet from the ceiling of the sevenstory foyer, for cleaning. The chandeliers remained lowered and the trappings of renovation left in place to underscore a spirit of renewal at a party last night given by Robert F. Jani, president, in honor of Radio City's second halfcentury. The Music Hall is scheduled to reopen May 31.

title: BIG RISE IN SMOKING FOUND AMONG GIRLS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 (AP)  Smoking among teenagers has declined by 25 percent since 1974, but for the first time more girls in that age group are smoking than boys, Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today.

title: Cowles Profit Up
description: Cowles Communications. Inc., a closedend investment company, reprted yesterday firstquarter net income of $1.1 million, or 28 cents a share, up 19 percent. Operating revenues gained 9 percent Investment income climbed 28 percent to $711,000 and net asset value of 888.7 million rose 21 percent. The company's operating properties are television stations WESH,TV, Daytona BeachOrlando, Fla., and KCCITV, Des Moines, Iowa. Cowles's principal Investment is 2.6 million shares of class A common stock of The New York Times Company, or about 22 percent of the common shares outstanding.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Prices of Bonds Decline Sharply

title: Canadiens Conquer Bruins in Opener, 42
description: MONTREAL, April 26  Pierre La. rouche, teaming on an extra line with Doug Risebrough and Guy Lafleur, scored the winning goal tonight as the Montreal Canadiens gained a 42 Stanley Cup semifinal victory over the Boston Bruins.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: IGATHER from one of the essays in The Medusa and the Snail: More Notes of a Biology Watcher that when Dr. Lewis Thomas is writing  and not presiding over Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center in New York City  he sits at his desk in an upperfloor room facing north on East 69th Street. It must be an exciting place to sit. On occasion, I place my pencil point in the middle of my paper  and make the sun revolve slowly around East 69th Street. Anyone can do this. It takes a bit of heaving to get it started, but after a few minutes of hard thought you can hold East 69th as the still, central point, and then you can feel the sun rolling up behind you from the right side, making the great circle around.

title: Update on New York's Strikes
description: Apartment Houses: There was no move by either side to resume negotiations in the threeday old strike by apartmenthouse maintenance workers. Meanwhile, tenants at 2,000 affected buildings in Manhattan continued their efforts to maintain their own services. Elderly residents and those with heart conditions were advised to climb stairs half a flight at a time in those buildings without elevator service. The Health Department certified eight areas as health problems, a designation that allowed city workers to cross picketfines to remove garbage. Operators answering the city's hot line telephone (2679800)  which is manned from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. to handle strikerelated emergencies  received 190 calls yesterday, mostly concerning garbage collection, hot water and elevator service. The striking union, meanwhile, said the managements of 100 more apartment buildings had made independent settlements, bringing the total to 200 since the walkout began. [Page 131.] Tugboats: A State Supreme Court justice, rescinding another judge's order, ruled that the state's courts could not order striking tugboat workers to haul city garbage. With the strike in its 26th day, the Koch administration was considering a complex plan, backed by the union, that would involve seizing tugs from the struck Moran company or chartering other tugs  at Moran's expense and hiring strikers to operate them.

title: Publishing: Ghost Story In the American Grain
description: IT takes a visitor no more than two minutes conversation with Peter Straub, whose Ghost Story, a supernatural caper, has just been published by Coward, McCann & Geoghegan and received favorable reviews, to learn that this author has more on his mind in his fiction than providing booklength entertainment.

title: Utah Towns More Hurt Than Angered By Suggestion of Deaths From Fallout
description: ST. GEORGE, Utah, April 25  It is doubtful that even the United States Goverment knows exactly how much radiation was blown over the pretty, pleasant streets of St. George In the 12 years of openair testing of atomic weapons just across the state line in Nevada.

title: Stage: 7 Mill Women In Long Wharf Saga
description: NEW HAVEN FOR Hillbilly Women, the stage at the Long Wharf Theater has been converted into a textile factory, a women's cooperative in a narrowminded town in Georgia. Seven women are assembled to celebrate the factory's second anniversary. Talking and singing to exuberant fiddle and banjo music, they swap stories and explain themselves to one another and to the audience. The flow of conversation becomes a justification of their lives. These are plain, honest folk, indigenous to the heartland of America.

title: The City
description: A measure that would ban the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the city streets passed the City Council yesterday by a vote of 31 to 7.

title: E.P.A. FINES TEXACO OVER GAS SWITCHING
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  The Environmental Protection Agency today fined Texaco Inc., a Texaco distributor in California and 11 Texaco filling stations in Alameda County there a total of $159,000 for illegaly selling leaded gasoline as more expensive unleaded fuel.

title: Trucks Carrying Bodies of Cultists Start for California
description: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del., April 26  Bodies of the dead from Jonestown, Guyana, triplesealed in green plastic, hermetically sealed in 18gauge gunmetal gray coffins, further encased in cardboard, were loaded on trucks bound for California here today long after the horrifying thing that happened in a faraway forest last autumn.

title: Screen: Unlikely Duo's 'Almost Perfect Affair':Sublimely Incompatible
description: KEITH CARRADINE and Monica Vitti, as the lovers in "An Almost Perfect Affair," are funny, sexy and sublimely incompatible. Mr. Carradine is cast as a scruffy young film maker trying to sell his first feature at the Cannes Film Festival, and Miss Vitti is the wife of a mogul along the lines of Dino De Laurentiis, a man so unmistakably successful that even his black dinner jacket is emblazoned with the Gucci logo. The mogul is played, delightfully, by Raf Vallone, whose wardrobe is indeed by Gucci, just as Miss Vitti's clothes are by Valentino. As the opening credits merrily proclaim, Mr. Carradine's wardrobe is all his own.The lovers' meeting is cute as can be, as French customs officers manage to confiscate both Mr. Carradine's movie and Miss Vitti's dog. Since the mogul's wife is well connected, she is able to get both the film and the animal out of stir. Since she has a lot of time on her hands while her husband wheels and deals, romance is in the air. Sparks fly until the last section of this enjoyably modest movie, when the couple begin debating about art and sacrifice and whether Mr. Carradine is brave enough to toss his only copy of the film into the Mediterranean for the sake of love."An Almost Perfect Affair," which opens today at the Trans-Lux East, was directed by Michael Ritchie, whose work on "Smile" and "The Bad News Bears" might seem to make him ideally equipped to send up a spectacle like Cannes. Curiously, this time Mr. Ritchie makes relatively slight use of his satirical gifts or his flair for the well-staged mob scene. The film festival becomes a backdrop and not much more, even though Mr. Ritchie shot a large amount of footage at the height of last year's hubbub.Real movie-business personalities turn up from time to time; Rona Barrett is also on hand, tripping on a stair as she tries to tape a television spot about the festival. But the camera is surprisingly nonchalant as it whisks by a landscape riddled with billboards and heads into the Carlton Hotel, an otherwise elegant building that has had a giant pink panther affixed to its doorway. If the film festival has any life to it at all, then Mr. Ritchie has passed up a golden opportunity. In any case, whenever the scene shifts to the festival in overview, Mr. Carradine, Miss Vitti and their spooning are sorely missed.The banter between the lovers, however winning, has a choppy feeling. There is an inexplicable amount of cutting from Mr. Carradine to Miss Vitti and back again, so much cutting that each actor's comic timing is slightly out of kilter. Nevertheless, these are sweet, spirited performances, as is Mr. Vallone's, though his appearance is far too brief.The cast is rounded out by Christian de Sica, son of the late director Vittorio de Sica, who plays Mr. Vallone's peabrained offspring. And Dick Anthony Williams is amusing as a black director who never misses a trick, and who has the comic brainstorm of renaming "Choice of Ending," Mr. Carradine's documentary about Gary Gilmore. The new title, which indeed seems better suited to the tenor of the festival, is "Shoot Me Before I Kill Again.""An Almost Perfect Affair" is rated PG. It contains a few scenes of partial nudity.

title: Rosalynn Carter, in Speech to Communicators, Makes Strong Feminist Appeal
description: Rosalynn Carter told a group of women communicators here yesterday that she thought her personal interests as First Lady  the mentally ill, the elderly, the handicapped and the poor  were being discriminated against because they are not sexy issues for a First Lady.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Obituary 3 -- No Title

title: A Blow for the Boys in Blue
description: The names are Bill Lawson, Phil Lospitalier, Merrill Hadry and Jerry Loeber. With any luck, they will some day take a place in the history of the labor movement right up there with Samuel Gompers, John L. Lewis and Eugene V. Debs. Wearing the plain blue serge of strikebreakers, the Messrs. Lawson, Lospitalier, Hadry and Loeber struck mighty blow for the unemployed umpires, of the major leagues the other night. A 28minute blow.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Union Pacific Railroad announced yesterday it had placed an order for 200 locomotives with wtotal value of $153 million, the largest such order in its 115year history.

title: Obituary 9 -- No Title
description: Braths

title: McCovey Eager to Play at 41
description: At the age of 41, in his 21st season in the major leagues, he had probably, eamed.the right to dress a little more slowly than the others  to hitch up his pants so they fit just right, to pull up his stockings so they formed a perfect orangeonwhite crescent at the back of his heel. In the 20 seasons before this one, Willie Lee McCovey had played in 2,423 games, hit 505 home runs, batted in 1,482 runs and had a career batting average of 272.

title: Desai Acts to End Killing of Cows
description: NEW DELHI, April 26  Opponents of the slaughter of cows, animals sacred to most Hindus, gained a significant political victory today as Prime Minister Moradi R. Desai announced in Parliament that the Government would introduce a constitutional amendment in this session prohibiting the slaughter of cows anywhere in India.

title: Guild Is Cautioned by The News
description: In a threepage letter to employees, The Daily News said yesterday that any unlawful activity, such as a slowdown or strike, would subject the Newspaper Guild of New York and the union's leadership to severe financial penalties and participating employees to disciplinary action up to and including discharge.

title: Brascan's Takeover Bid Assailed by Woolworth
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company yesterday again assailed a takeover bid by Brascan Ltd. and said that the Canadian holding company, if successful, might be compelled to strip Woolworth's worldwide assets to meet the financial obligations of the acquisition.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: When he was in high school and college, Geoffrey IL Moore wanted to be a chicken farmer. But fate had it that after graduating from the College of Agriculture at Rutgers University, his career moved in a different direction. He became a wellknown economic statistician whose name tended to be mentioned whenever lists of distinguished economists and statisticians were put together.

title: Mauritania May Yield Its Part of West Sahara
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Apri 26 (AP) 'flu official Libyan news agency reported today that Mauritania would turn over its part of the disputed Western Sahara to the Polisario Front, a guerrillafighting for independence for the Spomish colony, which ash divided between Mauritania andw Morocco, but Mauritania had a somewhat different view.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, April 26 (AP)  President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France arrived here for talks today and was greeted by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soyiet leader'.

title: Virginia Aide Named As McGuire's Deputy For Financial Matters
description: A 33yearold Virginia tax official has been selected to be the deputy commissioner for administration of the New York City Police Department.

title: PRICES CLIMB BY 1%; YEAR'S.RISE TO DATE AT 13% ANNUAL RATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  Consumer prices rose 1 percent last month, producing so far in 1979 the highest inflation in four and a half years and calling into question the effectiveness of the Carter Administration's economic policies.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON. April 26  Contract talks between the United Rubber Workers and Uniroyal Inc. collapsed tonight, setting the stage for a possible strike next week against one of the more of the Big Four rubber companies.

title: The Editorial Notebook Danger, Above Ground and Below
description: Are the subways safe?

title: Dance: Forti Troupe
description: ALTHOUGH Simone Forti has been a choreographer for almost 20 years, she has not choreographed many dances. And those dances have sometimes been presented in outoftheway places before small audiences. Nevertheless, she has been extraordinarily influential, partly because in the early 60's she was one of the first choreographers to make dances out of socalled natural gestures.

title: Prenatal Test Detects Hemophilia
description: BOSTON, April 26 (AP)  Doctors say that for the first time they are able to tell before birth whether a baby will have hemophilia, the inherited bleeding disorder that once plagued the royalty of Europe.

title: Iran Reports CeaseFire in Area VVhere Kurds and Turks Clashed
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 26 Kurds and Turks in the western Azerbaijan area of Iran exchanged hostages today as calm apparently returned to the embattled area, where five days of fighting left as many as 1,000 dead, the Iranian radio reported today.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DI STR ICT Thursday. April 26. 1979

title: Bridge.
description: In recent years, bridge has become highly popular in India. The standard of play has risen, and the national team won the Far East title in 1977. However, visitors from the West sometimes find that the organization of the game has a surrealistic quality.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8 P.M.(Television  Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio  WMCA, P.M.)

title: G.M., Ford Quarter Net Up Sharply
description: DETROIT, April 26  Record profits for the first quarter of 1979 were reported today by the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, the nation's largest and secondlargest automobile manufacturers, respectively. The results were considerably above what investment analysts had anticipated for both companies.

title: Notes on People
description: One &the moreserendipitous televi= sion interviews of latewas zichat that the CBS program 60 Minuteshappened to have on Aril 15 with Johnny Carson.

title: Striking Prison Union Is Fined $450,000
description: ALBANY, April 26  The union representing the state's 7,000 striking prison guards was found in criminal contempt tonight and fined $450,000. In addition, beginning at 8 A.M. tomorrow, a fine of $100,000 will be levied for each shift until the men return to work.

title: U.N.'s Council Commends Beirut
description: UNITED NATIONS; N.Y., April 26 The Security Council commended Lebanon today for taking steps to reassert its authority over the strifetorn southern region and implicitly warned the Israelisupported Christian militia forces there against further interference.

title: JOHN O. WROLDSEN
description: John O. Wroldsen, secretarytreasurer of Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines until his retirement last year and the fatherinlaw of Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire of New York City, died Monday at Imperial Point Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 72 years and lived in Pompano Beach.

title: Peking Rejects Hanoi Proposal for ArmsFree Zone
description: HONG KONG, April 26  China indirectly rejected Vietnam's proposal for creating a demilitarized zone between their two countries today at a second, round of peace talks in Hanoi, calling instead for the Vietnamese to withdraw their troons from Laos and Cambodia.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The new Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, has already become a familiar place for West Side concertgoers. Tonight, the hall will begin an effort to lure dance buffs, as well. Ballet Hispanico, opening twoweek season, will be the first dance troupe to set foot on the renovated stage. The opening program, which starts at P.M., gives a good idea of Ballet Hispanico's diverse repertory  works by Alvin Ailey, Geoffrey Holder and Louis Johnson. This program will be repeated tomorrow night at 8. Sunday afternoon at 2, the company will perform dances by Tina Ramirez, Paco Fernandez, Mr. Ailey and Mr. Johnson. Tickets are $4 ($3 for students and the elderly). Reservations: 38243710.

title: Wider Trading Proposed For Newly Listed Stocks
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed rules today that would prevent the nation's stock exchanges from applying restrictions on offboard trading to newly listed stocks.

title: F.C.C. Approval Set on Satellite System Facilities
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  The Federal Communications Commission indicated today that it would approve the construction of facilities by Satellite Business Systems that would allow the new company to launch its satellites on schedule. The commission did not vote, however.

title: Advance Betting O.K.'d For 2 Meadowlands Races
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 26  The New Jersey State Racing Commission granted permission today to Meadowlands Race Track to hold advance betting on its two biggest races this summer.

title: TheaterDance: Timm's 1phigenia
description: GREEK tragedy is about as far away from the colorful abstractions of Alvin Nikolais as you can get. On Wednesday, however, a former Nikolais dancer, Frederick Timm, presented his theaterdance version of Euripides's Iphigenia in Aulis. There is a good storyteller lurking beneath that elongated dancer's frame and mop of curls. The heart sinks when a gang of men come leaping onto the stage in bedsheettunics crying. War! War! in one early scene. But its simplicity and homely look are the virtues of Iphigenia, performed by the Frederick Timm Dance Theater at Playhouse 46 at St. Clement's through Sunday. The choreographer, who also directed, keeps things moving. His script is straightforward, although there are couple of thudders on the order of Your family awaits to see you.

title: The World as Forum
description: CHICAGO In the yews since their independence, the developing countries have noted what they consider to be excessive coverage by Western news agencies of violence and crises (such as the Nigerian civil war), and poor coverage of positive develop. meats (such as the universal, free, compulsory educational system that Nigeria is now building). Increasingly, these countries seek to remedy this sort of imbalance by imposing restrictions on newsgathering in the hope of avoiding a poor world image.

title: Art People
description: THIS year marks the 10th anniversaryof New York Painting and Sculpture at the Metropolitan Museum. Hard things were sa2d of that exhibition at the time. but as the definitive statement of one man's point of view it had then, and still has now, a historical fascination.

title: Broadway
description: Peter Allen going from cabaret to stage at the Biltmore.

title: Hotel Set at Disney World
description: Walt Disney Productions announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with Shimberg, Kennedy & Frost Inc., a Tampabased real estate investment concern, under which Shimberg will build a S30 million hotel at the Lake Buena Vista Hotel Plaza across from Walt Disney World Village in Orlando, Fla. Disney said it would receive ground lease revenues and a percentage of gross revenues from the hotel, which will be owned by Shimberg.

title: For Callaghan, Campaign Goal Is Reassurance
description: RAW,T, ENSTALL, England, April 26 As a campaigner, Prime Minister James Callaghan doesn't rush; he doesn't shout; he doesn't panic; he doesn't even pander much to the television cameras.

title: 3 Starters For Cosmos Sidelined
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 26  Franz Beckenbztuer, the Cosmos midfielder, will be out for at least two games with an injured right knee, the North American Soccer League team announced today.

title: Advertising
description: SINCE January, 3,000 copies of the prestigious and peachhued Financial Times of London have been arriving at 6 A.M., six days a week at Kennedy International Airport aboard a Lufthansa freighter from Frankfurt. Of that number, 889 are handdelivered to Manhattan subscribers before noon  usually well before noon  on the day of publication. It's all part of the shrinking world of international publishing.

title: Art: Yvonne Jacquette
description: ONE of the dividends of the return to favor of representational painting  painting based on what the eye sees in the big world out there  is that the modern city is once again a serious pictorial subject. From the beginning of the modern movement in the 19th centory until well into the 20th, the metropolis has inspired a great many painters, and now we seem to be in another period when painters are determined to win back some of this fertile terrain from the photographers and the movie makers.

title: Norman Marshall, 85; Salvation Army Leader
description: Commissioner Norman S. Marshall, national commander of the Salvation Army from 1957 to 1963, died yesterday at his home in Asbury Park, N.J. He was 85 years old.

title: A Blues Singer Brings The Delta to 4th Street
description: James (Sonny Ford) Thomas, blues singer from the Mississippi Delta who will be giving his first New York concert tomorrow evening at the Center for International Arts, has thought long and hard about death. You may be beautiful, he sings, but you know you got to die some day, and though the line is as old as the blues, for Mr. Thomas it has a speciel meaning.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Natural Resources Company, Detroitbased integrated gas holding company, has elected to its board of directors John M. Bissell, president and chief executive officer of Bissell Inc.

title: Rock Meets Disco: Where To Try It
description: THERE'S a different sort of disco in Manhattan these days, and its proliferation shows every sign becoming a genuine trend. These new wave discotheques are still mostly large, dark places with flashing lights and eager crowds dancing to pulsating, heavily amplified music. But the music they are dancing to isn't disco; it's rockandroll.

title: Education Office Gains in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  Opponents of a proposed new department of education lost a number of crucial rounds today as the Senate continued debate on the Administrationbacked legislation. A final vote on the measure is expected on Monday.

title: ISRAELIS AND P.LO. AGREE TO U.N. TRUCE; BOMBARDMENT ENDS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 26  The heavy artillery bombardments and air attacks that shook southern Lebanon for the last four days ended today after an informal ceasefire between Israel and the Palestinian guerrillas.

title: Gould Offers $300 Million for Fairchild
description: Gould Inc., one of the nation's leading producers of electrical parts and auto batteries, offered yesterday to pay nearly 1300 million in cash and stock for the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation. Gould said it had $150 million on hand for the venture and lending arrangements for further funds.

title: Carter News Parley on Monday
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) President Carter will bold his 48th formal news conference at 4 P.M. Monday, the White House ansiounced today.

title: Film: 'Les Rendez-vous':Enigmatic Character
description: THE heroine of "Les Rendezvous d'Anna," described by the film's director. Chantal Akerman, as "a sort of mutant . . . . perhaps a heroine of the future," is both so fearless and joyless she's almost a ghost. Anna, played with great care by Aurora Clment, is a young film maker traveling from city to city to promote her work. The movie spans several days and three countries, moving from one determinedly neutral setting to the next, as it suggests a rootlessness that goes perhaps too far beyond freedom.Anna meets a variety of people, listens closely to the long monologues they deliver and, upon rare occasions, volunteers tiny bits of information about herself. She seems engaged by everything and by nothing. She also seems, perhaps because of her attentive manner and regal bearing, to be in great demand as an audience and a lover. Everyone who encounters Anna wants more of her. But Anna, who is either a uniquely self-sufficient human being or a terrible pill, isn't often generous with her feelings. Other people interest her, but then so do the shoes and leftover dinner she finds outside someone else's hotel-room door one evening. She is presumably meant to have the absolute independence and receptiveness of a true artist.Miss Akerman's film, which will be shown tomorrow as part of the New Directors/ New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art, has a crisp, simple elegance at times, as the camera studies a hotel room or a train station with a patience like Anna's own. Miss Akerman's attention to detail, like Anna's, is at times peculiarly excessive, as when Anna finds a strange man's necktie in her room and feels obliged to report that it is "on two hangers, on the left-hand side of the closet."Most of the tales told to Anna cut right to the bone, to the very simplest level of despair, and yet the film's tone is too detached to seem bleak. If anything, the mood is mysteriously playful at times, as in a sweet, knowing sequence that shows an uncharacteristically light-hearted Anna singing a little song to one of her lovers. "A little sunshine can be so bright that it hurts," goes the refrain.For all of its emphasis upon discipline and precision, "Les Rendez-vous d'Anna" begins to seem unduly self-indulgent after a while, thanks to too many arid transitional passages and a stinginess with information that turns counterproductive. The film's handsome severity is impressive, but its restraint is ultimately more forbidding than provocative.

description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overMecounter. AAV (A)

title: Expense Budget Of $12.8 Billion Offered by Koch
description: A $12.8 billion New York City expense budget that would cut the number of teachers in the classroom and sanitation workers collecting garbage and temporarily reduce the number of police officers on patrol was proposed yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Otto Cohen, One of the Founders Of Charles of Ritz Cosmetics, 96
description: Otto Cohen, one of the founders of Charles of the Ritz, the cosmetics division of Charles of the Ritz Group, died Wednesday at his home in Miami Beach after a long illness. He was 96 years old.

title: White House Set Back On a Bill to Cony Out Panama Canal Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  The Carter Administration suffered a setback on its bill to carry out the Panama Canal treaty today when the House Rules Committee adopted a substitute measure.

title: Senators Warn Japan on Trade
description: WASHINGTON, April 26, (Reuters) - Senator Robert Byrd of West Virginia, the Senate majority leader, and Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, prominent Republican, warned Japan today of possible retaliation if it did not make concessions in trade talks with the United States.

title: Odetta Sings Tonight
description: Odetta, the blues and folk singer, will appear tonight at 7:30 P.M. in Theater 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees, 310 West 43d Street. The concert is the first in series of three sponsored by the union's Bread and Roses program. Tickets are $5 and can be purchased at the door. Future performances will feature Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee (May 18) and Sam Levenson (June 15). Information: 5821890.

title: For Children
description: FILM FUN FOR PRESCHOOLERS, short films far youngsters and their parents, Sunday from 2 to P.M.. presented by the Y.W.C.A. Parents Center and Parents Resources. at the Y. 610 Lexington Avenue. AdMisslen, S2. Call 7554500, extension 76.

title: Vance Says It Is Too Early to Judge Fairness of Rhodesian Election
description: WASHINGTON. April 26  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that it was premature to judge the fairness of last week's voting in Rhodesia and warned Congress that any action now to end economic sanctions against Rhodesia would be constitutionally improper.

title: REELECTION BATTLE UPHILL FOR TEEM
description: OTTAWA, April 26  For Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who is off in British Columbia continuing a pugnacious election campaign to keep his Liberal Party in power, this week started out on a sour note.

title: Abandoning Andrew Jackson High
description: There was understated drama in the way Federal District Judge John Dooling began his opinion last year about segregation at New York City's Andrew Jackson High School. Of the 2,532 students then enrolled, he wrote, 2,954 were black, 75 were Hispanic, 2 Indian or Asian and 1 is classified as other.  He thought that to abandon the school to segregation was impermissible and he ordered the Board of Education to correct it. But now the United States Court of Appeals says no; however regrettable such segregation might be, there's nothing the courts can do about it.

title: Amex Booms, Aided By Fuel Price Rises
description: A new breed of buyer, typically a businessman, who concentrates on assets and balance sheets rather than wings progression, has flocked to the Amex, says Michael Metz of Oppenheimer & Company.

title: DECISION OFF AGAIN ON NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, apparently weighing fundamental questions about the safety of nuclear power and the cost of losing it, postponed once more today a decision on whether to order the immediate shutdown of power plants with reactors like the one at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania.

title: With Spring in the Air, Designers Turn to Fall
description: As spring unfurls outdoors, fall fashions are being paraded this week in the showrooms of Seventh Avenue, where American designers, unlike their fantasyprone European counterparts, are keeping a clear eye on the dividing line between believable and imaginative clothes.

title: Zoo Announces Gorilla Record
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 26 (UPI)  A I7yearold gorilla named Toni gave birth to a female gorilla yesterday, giving the Columbus Zoo its fourth generation of the animal and a world record. Toni's mother, Colo, made headlines in 1956 as the first gorilla born in captivity.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: Braths

title: The Region
description: Judge Charles R. DiGisi of the Superior Court in Hackensack, N.J., yesterday upheld a lower court ruling that the treehouse in the backyard of the Self family in Ridgewood was illegal because it was put up without a building permit.

title: Restaurants
description: THIS week, Orsini's begins its 27th year as one of the city's most decorative and successful Italian restaurants, and almost since its opening on April 21, 1953, it has been a favorite meeting place for members of the highfashion world. The original restaurant consisted only of the present downstairs bar and small dining room with Pompeianred walls, touches of wrought iron and painting of a pubescent odalisque lending a somewhat sensual and romantic note to the setting, which is in every way, typically Roman.

title: Black Students Find Value In Oberlin's African Center
description: OBERLIN, Ohio, April 26  Almost exactly a decade ago, a handful of black students marched out of Willard Straight Hall on the Cornell campus with bandoleers slung across their chests and rifles in their bands. The scene was a harsh symbol of a volatile decade in which black student anger, polarization and radicalism seemed to increase with each turning of the calendar Dane.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Obituary 5 -- No Title

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 27, 1979

title: Waldheim in Hanoi to Pursue ChinaVietnam Accord
description: HANOI, Vietnam, April 26  Secretary General Kurt Walcheim arrived here today to begin a United Nations initiative to end hostilities between Vietnam and China.

title: Contamination Found Near Niagara Facility For Water Treatment
description: ALBANY, April 26  Traces of chemical contamination turned up in ground water near the Niagara Falls watertreatment plant, state officials announced today.

title: Big Surge In Supply Of Money
description: The nation's money supply surged dramatically in midApril, leading number of money market analysts to believe that excessive easing of the Federal Reserve System's monetary policy is directly responsible for the worsening rate of inflation.

title: TV Weekend Caged Bird 'Sings: Tale Of Girlhood
description: THERE is eine major television movie on tap this weekend, and it is.a gem. I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings, based on the autobiography of Maya Angelou, can be seen on CBSTV tomorrow night at 9 o'clock.

title: The New York Times/Edward Hausner
description: A report on construction of a $95 million international trade complex on 125th Street in Harlem was presented to Vice President Mondale yesterday by the Harlem Urban Development Corporation.

title: Mobil Net Rose 81.3% For Quarter
description: The Mobil Corporation, the last of the giant oil companies to report firstquarter earnings, said yesterday that its overall profits jumped 81.3 percent to $437 million, or $4.12 a share; from $241 million, or $2.27 a share, in the first three months of 1978. It was the biggest percentage increase reported by any of the five leading international oil cornoanies.

title: Klein Offers New Plan on Tax Cut: 10% in Each of 3 Years for Suffolk
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I. April 26  Rebounding from the legislative defeat of his taxpayers bill of rights two weeks ago, John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, today proposed cutting county taxes by 10 percent a year for each of the next three years.

title: Jumping a Tradition for Lewises
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 26  A 15yearold high school sophomore from Willingboro, N.J., leaped farther than the winner of the college long jump at the Penn Relays today, but no one was shocked.

title: Ballet: Gelsey Kirkland Shines
description: IN this age of so many good dance performances, the truly great one is not that common. Yet greatness radiated from every moment that Gelsey Kirkland and John Meehan were on stage Wednesday night with the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House. They left an audience stunned and delighted. In other words, they tore down the house.

title: Carter Statement on Oil Tax
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  Following is a transcript of a statement made by President Carter today upon signing a message to Congress about the proposed windfall profits tax on oil companies:

title: European Court Rules Britain Violated Pras Freedom
description: PARIS, April 26  The European Court of Human Rights ruled today that the British Government had illegally infringed on the freedom of the press when it prevented the publication in 1972 of a newspaper article on the drug thalidomide.

title: This Isle, Scepter'd
description: LONDONOnce again Britain is in the grip of election fever. I can feel itcreeping up my leg even as I write, and by the time polling day arrives it will have reached my brain, numbing it totally.

title: Gossage Says He Is Innocent
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 26  Rich Gossage and his agent, Jerry Kapstein, will meet with Al Rosen, the Yankee president, late next week as their first step in fighting the $18,603 fine imposed on Gossage for his clubhouse fight with Cliff Johnson last Thursday.

title: Anthony Russo, Jersey Crime Figure, Found Slain
description: LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 28  Anthony Russo, reputed underworld boss of Monmouth County, was found shot to death today in his fourthfloor apartment at the oceanfront Harbor Island Spa.

title: Test Pilot Killed in Crash
description: FREDERICKTOWN Mo,. April26 (UPL)  A McDonnell Douglas test pilot was killed yesterday in the crash or a $15 million F15B Eagle jet fighter that was making a sewed test ??? from the com Pany's St. Louis facilities. He was identified by the aerospace company as Gary L.Kincaid, 34 years old, of Chesterfield.

title: Close the Back Door on Housing Subsidies
description: Pssst! Wanna mortgage, cheap?

title: JOHN CARROLL DIES; WAS STAR IN FILMS
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 26 (UPI)  John Carroll, a star in Hollywood's swashbuckling era, who played the title role in several Zorro movies, died of complications from leukemia Tuesday. He was 72 years old.

title: Birth Notice 1 -- No Title
description: Birth Notice 1 -- No Title

title: U.S. Jury Studying Acts by Seaboard
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  A Federal grand jury has been quietly investigating Seaboard Coast Line Industries in connection with possible improper and lavish entertainment of government officials at the company's resorts, it has been learned.

title: Invention That Blinks Causes Scare on a Jet
description: An amateur inventor carrying a dqvice he called The Eternal Light six flashing red bulbs wired to two batteries and covered with epoxy caused the evacuation of a jetliner at LaGuardia Airport shortly before its scheduled departure for Pittsburgh last night when the authorities decided it might be a bomb.

title: Chemical Reactions With Sulfur May Explain Findings on Venus
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  Although the atmosphere beneath the cloud deck of Venus is clear. it appears to be in a ferment of exotic chemical reactions in which sulfur predominates.

title: Art: An Invitation to a Japanese Tea Ritual
description: TEA is tea, as every Englishman knows: when we are feeling rather dull we count on it as mild and lawful stimulant, and in times of stress it brings a traditional solace. Tea in itself is not a lot of fun. but it has set the scene for many a momentous enterprise in our Occidental affairs. How about a cup of tea? means we are in when we might have been out. Another cup? means that things are moving along very nicely.

title: Manitobans Ordered to Evacuate As Red River Floods Past Border
description: The swollen Red River flooded parts of Minnesota, North Dakota and Canada with new misery yesterday, prompting an order that thousands of people evacuate their homes in the province of Manitoba as the besieged area near Grand Forks, N.D., neared exhaustion behind sandbagged dikes.

title: Capital Budget Of 1 Billion Has Renewal as Aim
description: Four years after New York City's fiscal diffitulties caused an almost complete halt to construction projects, including even essential repair and maintenance, Mayor Koch proposed yesterday a $1 billion capital budget that would be devoted mostly to improving the city's roadways, bridges, sewers and watersupply system and to upgrading its masstransit equipment.

title: A Rise of 0.7% in Prices in March Reported for the New York Area
description: Consumer prices in New York City and northeastern New Jersey rose seventenths of 1 percent last month, largely because of higher costs of food, emergy and clothing, according to figures released yesterday by Herbert Bienstock, the Federal commissioner of Labor Statistics for the region.

title: CART Asks Judge to Help Teams Banned From Indy
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 26 (AP) Championship Auto Racing Teams asked a Federal judge today to force the United States Auto Club to accept entries of six dissident racing teams for the Indianapolis 500mile race.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Indian Airliner Down After Blast
description: NEW DELHI, April 26 (AP)  An explosion aboard an Indian Airlines Boeing 737.forced the pilot to make a crash landing at Madras airport today, airline officials said. Ten of 67 persons aboard were hospitalized. Witnesses said that the plane had overshot the runway and plowed through nearby fields before coming to a halt about a mile from the terminal.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE combination of high taxes, inflation and eroding respect for government is splitting every advanced industrial nation into two economies  an aboveground economy that, as Prof. Peter M. Gutmann of Baruch College in New York says, is legal and taxed, and a subterranean economy that is illegal and untaxed.

title: Umpires, League Officials Continuing Negotiations
description: CHICAGO, April 26 (AP)  American and National League officials are meeting with major league umpires at an undisclosed location to work out a settlement to the umpires strike, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said.

title: Hawks. Beat Bullets And Tie Series at 33
description: ATLANTA, April 26  What once appeared to be a short, if difficult playoff series with the Atlanta Hawks is now becoming a nightmare for the Washington Bullets. Even after his team lost earlier, Dick Motta, the Washington coach, pointed out that he never saw his team lose its composure. That happened tonight, in a 10486 loss that tied the series at three games each.

title: VETERANS LOBBYISTS ACCEPT BUDGET CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  Few lobbies have more political power in Washington than the nation's 30 million veterans.

title: Harry James :Back at Roseland
description: Harry James has the only established name band that can pull in ballroom dancers, the owner of Roseland Ballroom, Nancy Brecker Leeds, was saying.

title: Michelangelo At Morgan
description: WITH the opening yesterday at the Pierpont Morgan Library of the exhibition called Michelangelo and His World: With Drawings From the British Museum, one of the capital art events of the present decade has come to New York. Although the exhibition is small in scale. at least by today's blockbuster standards, and consists almost entirely of drawings, manuscripts and books, it is extraordinary in the glimpse it giyes us of the work and the culture of one of the greatest artists who ever lived.

title: C.A.B Approves Linking Southern, North Central
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)  The merger of North Central Airlines and Southern Airways into a new carrier named Republic Airlines was approved today by the Civil Aeronautics Board:

title: Problems Increasing in Building Strike
description: The third day of the strike by 20,000 buildingservice employees found both tenants and strikers showing signs of increasing distress yesterday.

title: Salant Talks About His Plans for NBC News
description: Richard S. Salant, who will begin a new job Tuesday as vice chairman of the National Broadcasting Company, says one of his major goals is to increase the daily national news program from a halfhour to an hour and to broadcast it in prime time, from 8 to 9 P.M.

title: Jazz: Red Rodney
description: CRAWDADDY. the New Orleansstyled restaurant at Vanderbilt Avenue and 45th Street, which has thrived on jazz that, if not strictly New Orleans in its orientation, is sufficiently traditional to seem atmospherically appropriate, is expanding its musical horizons with a trio led by Red Rodney.

title: COMMODITIES Futures Prices of Cattle And Copper Push Higher
description: Cattle and copper prices, which surged ahead in active futures dealings, captured the interest of commodity traders yesterday.

title: Rhodesia War: Outlook Bleak
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 26 Against prohibitive odds, Rhodesia's transitional Government has completed the Country's first universalfranchise election and cleared the way for a blackled administration to take office. Within weeks Bishop Abel Muzorewa will take over.as Prime Minister and set about the unpromising task of delivering the peace with which he and other leaders lured nearly two milion blacks to the polls.

title: Abortion a Big Issue in French Vote for Europe Assembly
description: PARIS, April 26  Abortion and population are becoming major political issues in France once again, injected into the election campaign for the Assembly of the European Community despite their irrelevance to the choice of its representatives.

title: EARNINGS
description: Pepsico Inc. reported yesterday 22.2 percent rise in net income to $45.2 million, or 48 cents a share, during the 12 weeks to March 24, from $37 million, or 40 cents a share, in the 1978 quarter. Donald M. Kendall, chairman, noted that the company. had hit the billiondollar mark for, the first time in the auarter.

title: U.S. Aide Decries Sears's Job Stance
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) The Labor Department's director of affirmativeaction enforcement accused Sears, Roebuck & Company today of mounting a campaign of resistance to equal job opportunity programs comparable to the South's massive resistance to desegregation in the 1960's.

title: Weizman Meets With Sadat on Pullout From Sinai
description: ISMAILIA, Egypt, April 26  Defense Minister Ezer Weizman of Israel spent an hour with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt today and said they had reviewed plans for normalizing relations and for withdrawal of Israeli forces from Sinai.

title: New China/Associated Press
description: KISSINGER IN CHINA: Henry A. Kissinger, former Secretary of State, meeting in Peking yesterday with Chairman Hua Guofeng. Mr. Kissinger is in Peking at the invitation of the Chinese Government.

title: Swiss Bank Details 1979 Dollar Sales

title: Mortgage Rates Top 11% on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26 (AP) Major California savings and loan associations, which have often led the nation in mortgage rate increases, are raising mortgage loan rates to 11 percent or more, the highest rate in four and a half years.

title: St. John the Divine Celebrates With Liszt
description: The world's largest Gothic cathedral, St. John the Divine, has cause to celebrate. Work is to resume next June to complete the structure, which has stood unfinished, at Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, for 37 yeais.

title: Striking Guards Say They Are the Prisons Real Inmates
description: ELMIRA HEIGHTS, N.Y., April 25  The men slouched in the lawn chairs could be a company softball team partying after a game, except for the patches on their blueandgold baseball caps. The words on the patches read: New York State Correctional Services. The men scorn what they have become. Correctional Services, says a man named Willy.

title: Japan to Give Asia Society $1 Million for New Building
description: The Japanese Government has approved a $1 million cash contribution to help construct a new building for the Asia Society at the northeast corner of Park Avenue and 70th Street on a site that was cleared earlier this year.

title: Zenith Reports Shock Potential In 67,000 1979 Television Sets
description: GLENVIEW, Ill., April 26 (AP)  The Zenith Radio Corporation has announced that 67,000 color television sets produced since Jan. 1 could give off dangerous shocks.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Quartet, excerpt, Mendelssohn; Etudetableau in C, Rachmaninoff; Linda di Chamounix Overture, Donlzetti; Etude in B minor, Chopin.

title: Morris Noss, 62, Mayor Of Cortland for 4 Terms
description: Morris A. Noss, former Mayor of Cortland, N.Y., in the Finger Lakes region, died Monday of cancer at the Memorial Hospital in Cortland, where be lived. He was 62 years old.

title: About Real Estate Endicott Conversion Leads Columbus Avenue Revival
description: The history of a neighborhood evolves in small steps. Take the case of Columbus Avenue in the West 80's, which is on the move largely under the impetus of the current conversion of the former Endicott Hotel into cooperative avartments.

title: The Press And Rights
description: In 1966, the Supreme Court set aside the murder conviction of Dr. Sam H. Sheppard. The Court described his trial as a carnival of publicity that denied him the right to be tried by an impartial jury and only on evidence presented in court. Nothing in the Sheppard decision said that The state could forbid publication in order to obtain a valid conviction. Thereafter, discussion of the freepress, fairtrial issue took a turn that is not uncommon in constitutional debate.

title: Auctions
description: THE painters are not exactly household names. Their portraits; scenics, genre subjects. marine paintings and classical themes are certainly far from familiar. Nevertheless, the art works in three 19thcentury European paintings sales next week are causing quite. a stir internationally in this segment of the art market. The auction activity begins Wednesday at Christie, Manson & Woods, Park Avenue, at 59th Street, with two sessions, at 10:15 A.M. and P.M., offering more than 250 lots. These include five from the Museum of Art of the Carnegie Institute, and one from the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Then the focus switches Thursday to Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, fora sale at 2 P.M. of 80 lots from the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington. The third sale takes place in the same house next Friday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M., offering more than 390 paintings consigned by other owners. Sotheby's is calling this presentation the most important such sale in both quality and quantity  ever held in its galleries.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Except for one factor  the failure of black nationalist guerrillas to disrupt the voting  the election in Rhodesia went entirely as expected. Some of the principal players in the former Smith Government have swapped seats, and it will now be called the Muzorewa Government. Little else has changed.

title: Mayor's Management Report Assesses 34 City Agencies, Warts and All
description: A substantial decline in the cleanliness of city streets, a potential loss of experienced park workers and a drop in absenteeism among fire and correction workers were among the findings in the Mayor's Management Report on city services.

title: Islanders, Rangers Get Aid From Above
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 26  Coach Al Arbour of the Itlanders and Coach Fred Shero of the Rangersstood behind. their teams benches tonight and pushed the buttons that sent players on and off theice, but the computers were high upstairs in the last row of Nassau Coliseum.

title: Dorati Talks of Helena
description: Antal Dorati, the Hungarianborn conductor, began his career in a typically European fashion, by serving as rehearsal pianist and coach at various opera houses. He made his conducting debut in his native Budapest in 1926, when he was 20, and was around two years later when Richard Strauss's opera Die Aegyptische Helena (The Egyptian Helen) had its premiere and made the rounds of the many Central European theaters.

title: Screen: 'Saint Jack,' Adventure Melodrama:Yesteryear's Exotics
description: PETER BOGDANOVICH is so knowledgeable about American movies that one can reasonably expect him to come up with a few surprises when he elects to make his version of a popular genre film, as he has done in "Saint Jack," which opens today at the Cinema I."Saint Jack" is a modestly conceived and produced melodrama of the sort that Paramount turned out in the 1940's and 50's, usually with Alan Ladd starring as a free-booting soldier of fortune, a fellow who assumes the white man's burden in the demimondes of Saigon or Calcutta or Shanghai, cities that then seemed incredibly exotic because they were more than 12 hours away by air.There are some pleasant things in "Saint Jack," but there are few surprises, except for the fact that either the movie's editor or Mr. Bogdanovich, who directed the film and wrote the screenplay with Howard Sackler and Paul Theroux (based on the novel by Mr. Theroux), hasn't found a simple way to indicate the passage of time. One result is that the narrative, which is primarily what movies like this are all about, sometimes becomes hopelessly muddled in trivial confusions.The time of "Saint Jack" is approximately now and the setting is a Singapore that  despite of the presense of a new Hilton hotel, which looks like almost every other Hilton hotel you've ever seen  is wicked in a way that Oriental cities were supposed to be in all pre-World War II movies.It's the tale of Jack Flowers (Ben Gazzara), a stateside dropout, who wheels and deals with the Singapore underworld to open the fanciest whore-house north and west of Krakatoa. Jack is not just a prince, as the late Mr. Ladd was, but he's also a saint for his essential goodness. He befriends waifs, whores, incompetents and bores, the little guys everywhere, no matter what their race, color, creed or sexual preference. Among his pals is a mild-mannered though gutsy Englishman, nicely played by Denholm Elliott, an accountant with a bad ticker and a dream of one day retiring to a Georgian house in the west of England.For a movie that is supposed to be a melodrama, "Saint Jack" is surprisingly low key, even when it's dealing with sex and violence. This is not said as criticism. There is something appealing in the way it digresses to introduce raffish characters principally because Mr. Bogdanovich met and liked them when he was in Singapore making the picture.Mr. Bogdanovich himself appears in an important role, that of a rich, mysterious Mr. Big who, for a while, becomes Jack's partner. Mr. Bogdanovich is not a bad actor, but he is a weightless personality on the screen. It's as if he were standing in for the actor who would come along at any minute and play the role.Mr. Gazzara, a very good actor, is maybe too good to be the kind of mythical icon that such a film demands. In style, he belongs to the films of today, not to the romances of yesteryear.Something of this sort troubles the entire film. In several of his earlier films, especially "The Last Picture Show," "What's Up, Doc?" and "Daisy Miller," Mr. Bogdanovich successfully revived and brought forward  in his own manner  movie genres of other eras. That takes nerve as well as talent, and it's nerve that's missing from "Saint Jack." One wishes it were more outrageous and less knowing.Though it's a movie composed of substitutes (Mr. Gazzara for Mr. Ladd, Singapore for the Paramount backlot, etc.), the movie hasn't substituted anything for the sentimental treatment of its hero. At this point I find it impossible to be moved or even much interested in this last vestige of a discredited colonialism. Jack Flowers is not only dead. He also represents a kind of fiction that wasn't all that great when he was alive.

title: Benefits Raised 9.9% Under Social Security; Average Increase $25
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)  The average Social Security beneficiary will find $25 extra in his Government check this July and some will get up to $50 more as a result of an automatic 9.9 percent benefits increase announced today.

title: UAL, Beset by Strike, Posts Drop in Net
description: UAL Inc., parent of strikebeset United Airlines, announced yesterday that its firstquarter earnings plunged 82.5 percent to $3 million, or 10 cents share, from $17.1 million, or 68 cents share, in the corresponding period last year.

title: Whatsyourpleasure Wins
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 26 (AP)  Whatsyourpleasure, ridden by Don Pierce, took the lead out of the gate and went on to score a halflength victory today in the $25,000 feature race at Hollywood Park.
