title: Folk Music of 2 Cultures At Balkan Center
description: A weekend of FrenchCanadian folk dances and Jewish music will be offered by the Balkan Arts Center at Casa Galicia, 119 East 11th Street.

title: Acquittals In Carton Pricing Suit
description: A Federal court jury in Houston yesterday acquitted the Continental Group, the Mead Corporation and six corporate executives of pricefixing charges in a case that the Justice Department had described as the largest antitrust criminal action in its history.

title: Old Theaters, Burlesque to Movie, Given New Life
description: In a seedy section of downtown Philadelphia, there, is an old. theater,, the Troc, that, until it closed its doors on April Fool's Day of 1977, had been a burlesque house as long as anyone could remember.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The nation is awash in credit despite the Federal Reserve System's avowed policy of monetary restraint.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 26.

title: CoverUp Allegations Charged in Indictment Of Chemical Producer
description: DETROIT, April 27 (UPI)  The Velsicol Chemical Corporation and two employees at the plant where it produced the toxic chemical P130. have been indicted by a Federal grand jury in an alleged coverup scheme at the height of a Michigan incident involving cattle feed contamination.

title: State Panel Opens Hearings On Violence in the Schools
description: A young librarian told a state legislative task force yesterday in frightening detail how, while eating her lunch alone one afternoon in a school library, an intruder walked in, locked the door and began to beat her.

title: Mrs. Ginzburg, in Moscow, Gets Glad News on Voice of America
description: MOSCOW, Saturday, April 28Arnie Ginzburg was listening to the Voice of America late last night when the program was suddenly interrupted by a bulletin announcing that her husband, Aleksandr, was among five of the Soviet Union's most prominent political prisoners who had been flown to New York in exchange for two convicted Soviet spies.

title: Lakes Form as Red River Flooding Maroons Hundreds of Rural People
description: Hundreds of rural residents, surrounded by lakes created by the flooding Red River, were marooned yesterday along a 100mile stretch of the upper Red River Valley. At some points the river was 15 miles wide.

title: The City
description: Ten persons  a clinic operator, six doctors and three workers at the clinic  were charged yesterday with conspiracy to improperly distribute large amounts of Tuinal, described as an addictive depressant, and Valium, a tranquilizer, at the Unity Health Care Clinic in the South Bronx.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: As a member of the working press for nearly a quarter of a century I am appalled that two of our calling's brightest stars, James Reston and Tom Wicker, could display as much contusion and moral blindness about the duties and ethics of journalism as they did in their columns on April 20.

title: Asaociated Press
description: MARVELLA BAYH HONORED AT SERVICE: President Carter, Vice President Mondale and his wife, Joan, singing a hymn during a memorial service at the National Cathedral in Washington yesterday for Marvella Bayh, the wife of Senator Birch Bayh. About 1,000 friends of Mrs. Bayh, who died Tuesday at 46 after a long struggle against cancer, heard her eulogized as a source of hope and inspiration to millions of suffering Americans.

title: NUCLEAR COMMISSION ORDERS A SHUTDOWN FOR SOME REACTORS
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today agreed to a temporary closing of reactors made by the Babcock & Wilcox Company. However, it also agreed to permit two such reactors to continue operating for a while, a step that may prevent electric power shortages in three Southern states.

title: Associated Press
description: HONORED FOR COURAGE: Marine Sgt. Kenneth Kraus admiring Legion of Honor Medal presented him in Miami Beach. Sgt. Kraus, 22j was injured'defending U.S. Embassy in Teheran when it was stormed by Iranian Insurgents.

title: No Answer Is the Answer
description: When Tony Aylward, an actor, purchased a secondhand telephone answering machine two years ago, he was, he reported recently, ecstatic, expectant and overioved.

title: RUSSIAN WITH 2 GUNS ENTERS U.S. EMBASSY
description: MOSCOW, April 27  A Russian armed with two sawedoff shotguns commandeered a taxicab tonight and forced his way past Soviet guards onto the grounds of the American Embassy, where he fired two shots harmlessly before American security officials persuaded him to leave the compound.

title: U.S. REPORTS DEFECT IN A MILUON AUTOS
description: Gas, Tanks in Ford Mavericks and Mercury Comets Are Tied to 31 Deaths in 26 Mishaps The Federal Government made an initial delermination yesterday that had found a)oteritially fatal defect in the fuel tank used in almost one million 1970 to 1973 Ford Mavericks and 197173 Mercury Comets still on the road.

title: HANOI CHIEF REJECTS MEDIATION ON CHINA
description: HANOI. Vietnam, April 27  Viet nam's Prime Minister tonight rejected; any United Nations or other internationall mediation to settle his country's continuing diSpute with China.

title: Flood Back in Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)  Representative Daniel J. Flood. Democrat of PennsyIvais, has been readmitted at Georgetown University Hospital. Mr. Flood, 75 years old, is awaiting retrial on bribery and influencepeddlingcharges. He was first admitted to Georgetown Feb. 5 in a state of complete physical ex. haushon and was discharged March 20.

title: Day of ntrigue And Confusion Shrouded Trade
description: Like a tale of international intrigue out of the cold war days in Berlin, the exchange of two convicted Soviet spies for five Soviet dissidents unfolded in fogshrouded New York yesterday in true cloak and dagger fashion.

title: A CeaseFire for Vietnam Veterans
description: Hollywood seems to have outdone the rest of the nation in welcoming home the Vietnam veterans  at a tidy profit. With awardwinning films like The Deer Hunter and the poignant television drama, Friendly Fire, film makers have been examining the human dimension of a war that Americans once seemed eager to forget. Perhaps this revival of concern can now be turned to the benefit of the reallife veterans.

title: Israel and Egypt Plan Air Link
description: TELAVIV, April 27 (Reuters)  Israel and Egypt have agreed on a civilian air link, Defense Minister Ezer Weizman said today.

title: Paul G. Reilly, 70, a Lawyer, Dies; Counsel to Indians in Land Case
description: Paul G. Reilly, a retired Manhattan lawyer and a onetime candidate for the House of Representatives, died Wednesday at San Pedro Cantira, Spain, after long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Books of The Times Reading a Modern Story
description: Confident that I had learned how to read a modern short story, I approached Hardwater Country by Frederick Busch in a sanguine mood.

title: Mariners Rally From 50 Deficit; 3 Homers in 8th Beat Yanks, 65
description: SEATTLE, April 27  With an electrifying barrage of three homers off Dick Tidrow in the eighth inning, the hapless Seattle Mariners rallied for a 65 victory over the Yankees tonight and brought their 11game losing streak to an end:

title: Dr. Bertram A. Lowy; Professor at Einstein Was Cell Researcher
description: Dr. Bertram A. Lowy, a professor of biochemistry and medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 55 years old and lived in New York City.

title: Your Money
description: FOR the woman alone, a major financial fear who will look after her should she become ill, disabled or senile.

title: Carter Induces Sears to Cut Prices; Council Cites Two Paper Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  Responding to President Carter's personal intervention, Sears, Roebuck & Company, the country's largest retail enterprise, announced today that it would reduce some prices next week to stay within the President's voluntary guidelines for price restraint.

title: 7 ThirdWorld Members of U. N. Term Rhodesian Election a Fraud
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 27 Seven thirdworld countries, denouncing the recent elections in Rhodesia as fraudulent, asked today that United Nations members refuse to recognize the new Salisbury government and asked for a continuation of the trade. embargo against Rhodesia.

title: Dissident Release Praised by Leaders of U.S. Jewish Groups Nand Others
description: Leaders of American Jewish groups and others who have fought for the cause of Soviet dissidents for years applauded yesterday's announcement that the United States had exchanged two Soviet spies for five Soviet dissidents.

title: Pentagon Delays Fort Dix Closing; Study Reauested
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  The Defense Department agreed today to defer its planned deactivation of Fort Dix to consider the possibility of a new investigation into the social and economic consequences of closing the base.

title: Bring Life to Fair Housing Law
description: The Civil Rights Act of 1968 was the last of the great antisegregation measures of the 1960's  and, it turns out, by far the weakest. The acts of 1960, 1964 and 1965 have brought progress in voting, public accommodations, education and employment; but the 1968 act, which dealt with housing, has been a failure. So says the United States Commission on Civil Rights in a report that evaluates Federal fair housing enforcement efforts. The agencies earn poor marks.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar scored strong gains against other major currencies in late New York trading yesterday, following a report showing the smallest monthly trade deficit in nearly two years.

title: Afghan Premier Charges That 2,700 Died in Iran
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, April 27 (Reuters)  Afghanistan's President, Noor Mohammad Taraki, charged today that 2,700 Afghan nationals had been killed in Iran, and said his Government had protested to the Teheran Government. the Kabul radin rennrtarl Speaking before a group of prominent citizens, he did not say over what period the killings had taken place.

title: G.A.O. Opposes Law Requiring Union Pay on Federal Projects
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (Reuters) The General Accounting Office, a Congressional agency, called today for repeal of the DavisBacon Act, charging that the law requiring union wages on Federal construction projects cost the Government millions of dollars extra a year.

title: The Soviet Spies
description: Assistant to Under Secretary General of United Nations  Age 39  Arrested May 20,1978, in Woodbridge, N.J., with two other Soviet citizens  He and one other convicted of espionage  Faced possible life sentence but got 50 years  calarged with attempt to buy classified information on antisubmanrine warfare from Navy officer on undercover assignment from F.B.I and Naval Intelligience  Identified by F.B.I. as officer of K.G.B., Soviet secret police  Was caught in act of picking up documents on basis of warrants issued by Federal District Court in Newark  Documents included sketches, photographs, negatives, notes and information picked up from drop sites on at least seven previous occasions  Material related to underwater acoustics, submarine detection systems, helicopter systems and other secret matters. F.B.I. said it was a classic spy case  Had operated on previous occasions with two other accused Russians  Detention led to retaliatory arrest of American businessman  Released in January to custody of Soviet Ambassador pending appeal of conviction, which was not filed in time  Confined to Soviet complex in Riverdale.

title: About New York
description: The continuing success of the city's grand and verdant contrivance, Central Park, is a matter of simple experience: Merely walk away from the streets of Manhattan, into its core, and nature distracts the urban soul now as it did a century ago.

title: U.S. FREES TWO SPIES FOR FIVE DLSSIDENTS JAILED BY RUSSIANS
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  Five dissidents were released from Soviet prisons and flown to New York today in exchange for two Soviet spies sentenced to 50yearprison terms in the United States.

title: New Hampshire Turns Down Bill To Delay Its Presidential Primary
description: CONCORD, N.H., April 27 (UPI)  The House has rejected a suggestion that New Hampshire give up its firstin thenation Presidential primary to comply with the wishes of the Democratic National Committee.

title: Dorothy Brewster, 96 Years Old; A Longtime Teacher at Columbia
description: Dr. Dorothy Brewster, a former assistant professor of English at Columbia University, died April 17 in a nursing home in Lancaster, Pa., after a long illness. She was 96 years old.

title: Pickets Scuffle at Coast Track
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 27 (AP)  Massive picketing by up to 500 parimutuel clerks erupted briefly into violence today at Hollywood Park Race Track as bettors ran their cars through picket lines at two gates and the police made 15 or 20 arrests.

title: Lauren's Impeccable Tailoring, Softened by Color
description: Instead of cowboy boots, the mannequins wore dancing pumps. Instead of flouncy frontier dresses, there were tailored suits. Ralph Lauren changed his tune in the fall collection he presented at the Hotel Pierre this weekand helped set the standards for the new season. BesideS producing clothes that are serene and beautiful in themselves, he hastened the demise of styles that are sleazy and noteworthy for nothing but their shock value.

title: Shipping/Mails

title: Letter: On Casinos for New York
description: To the Editor: The Governor's Casino Gambling Study Panel was specifically directed to evaluate the three proposed constitutional amendments on casino gambling before the New York State Legislature in its interim report of April 16, 1979. The panel was specifically not directed to consider whether casino gambling should be legalized in New York State, a question which will be decided by the Legislature and the people of the state.

description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed en the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the. American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Stopping Computer Chomping Of Privacy
description: EAST HAMPTON,  In world full of Monsters, real and illusory, human and technological, the beast that threatens each of us daily is the electronic Minotaur, secretly devouring our privacy and civil liberties in the underground labyrinth called the data bank. The monster is of course the computer.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 (UPI)  A moderate earthquake centered just south of San Francisco struck the coast of northern California. in a series of two or three quick jolts today.

title: Two Teen-Agers Held in Slaying Of a Polar Bear in Zoo in St. Paul
description: ST. PAUL, April 27 (UPI) Two teenagers have been charged in the slaying of a 600pound polar bear earlier this week at Como Zoo.

title: U.S. Weighing Trade Deal as Soviet Eases Exit of Jews
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  The United States opened talks with the Soviet Union today on the possibility of granting it trade concessions in response to recent signs of liberalization in Soviet emigration.

title: Samuel S. Duryee, 86, a Lawyer; Active in New York Philanthropy
description: Samuel Sloan Duryee, who was counsel for the law firm of Parker, Duryee, Zunino, Malone & Carter, died yesterday at his home in New York City. He was 86 years old.

title: Zaire Ends Tests by West German Rocket Concern
description: BONN, April 27  The Government of Zaire today renounced parts of a contract with a West German rocket company whose vague aims and virtually sovereign control of 39,000 square miles of Zaire's territory led to charges that a secret Western rocket base had been set up in the heart of Africa.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSSidrey J. beloved husband of Betty. Devoted father of Leonard, Marion Giants & Lynn Barfield. Loving grandfather of Julie & Janet Abrams, Karen & Stacey Glantz & Barnard Barfield. Services Sunder tom Boulevard Park West Chapel, 79 St. Cdurnbus Ave. NYC.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GREEN THEMES Today's street fair from noon to 4 P.M. at Brooklyn's Prospect Heights is called a PlantsPlus Sale, offering windowbox, homeraised and garden specimens, along with fleamarket items, handcrafts, foods and beverages. The street area on Park Place between Vanderbilt and Underhill Avenues will be closed to traffic, and the sponsoring Underhill Civic Organization is donating proceeds to beautifying the historical brownstone section.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Sears, Roebuck announced that it would cut some prices next week to stay within the Administration's antiinflation guidelines, following a personal appeal to the company by President Carter. The President was said to have telephoned Edward R. Telling, the Sears chairman, on Thursday, and in his absence spoke to a senior vice president. Meanwhile, the Council on Wage and Price Stability identified two major paper companies as probable violators of the price guidelines. In naming Crown Zellerbach and Hammermill Paper, the council made good on repeated threats to call attention to companies believed to be breaking the guidelines. [Page 1.]

title: Guild and Daily News Reach an Agreement; Times Accord Is Seen
description: The Newspaper Guild of New York and The Daily News reached an agreement early yesterday that settled an extended dispute over some terms of a contract that was originally negotiated last June following a fiveday strike.

title: Expos Trounce Giants
description: MONTREAL, April 27 (AP)  Andre Dawson and Gary Carter each hit two home runs and drove in three runs to pace a 17hit Montreal attack that powered the Expos to a 148 triumph over the San Francisco Giants today.

title: Reporter's Noteboo:Town Is Caught Up in Sahara War
description: SMARA, Western Sahara  Aside from soldiers, there are few men of fighting age to be seen in this bleak town in the heart of the contested Westem Sahara. Moroccan troops hold the garrison and Frenchmade light tanks protect the vital runway. Out somewhere in the windtufted dunes roam guerrillas of the Algerienarmed Pollsario Front.

title: Czech APlant Deaths Reported
description: STOCKHOLM, April 26 (UPI)  The newspaper Daily Facpressen said today that two men were asphyxiated two years ago when they entered a Czechoslovak nuclear power plant unaware that a cooling system had failed, allowing radioactive gas to escape. The report was attributed to unspecified sources in Czechoslovakia.

title: Music: Idil Biret, Pianist
description: Only a brave soul and a confident technician would set out in public to play Liszt's transcription for piano of Berlioz's Symphonic Fantastique, as. Idil Biret did at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night. Giving a full and accurate account of the Imes themselves would be enough to daunt most pianists, but in that respect the Turkish artist succeeded beyond reasonable hopes. She was at her best, in fact, when the music called on her to perform prodigies of keyboard dexterity and flights of Lisztian bravura.

title: World News Briefs
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 27 (UPI) 24hour general strike called to protest the military Government's inability to control inflation failed today. Most factories and offices operated as usual.

title: Three Generations of Peabody Women, as a Film Portrays Them
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  It was not your usual Washington party with talk of the strategic arms treaty, inflation and politics, for the conversation focused on three women and a film recently made about them.

title: Brascan Is Accused Of Misleading
description: TORONTO; April 27  An investment adviser in Toronto has accused J.H. Moore, chairman of Brascan Ltd., of grossly misleading shareholders as to the merits of Brascan's $1.1 billion takeover bid for the F.W. Woolworth Company.

title: 2 City Officials Pose Questions On Budget Cuts
description: Mayor Koch's plans to let the number of police officers on New York City streets decrease temporarily next year and to forgo the promised bolstering of 55 fire companies were questioned yesterday by two officials whose approval is im. portant.

title: William R. Murray, 63, ExJustice Of the New York Supreme Courl
description: William R. Murray, a retired justice ol the New York State Supreme Court, died Wednesday at the Albany Medical Center Hospital after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 23 Clinton Avenue in Troy, N.Y.

title: Dania, Taxi Actor, Is Knockout in Ring
description: Whether or not Tony Danza follows in the footsteps of Victor McLogien and becomes the second boxer to fight for a title and also win an Oscar remains to be seen. One thing was demonstrated last night, however, by the 213yearold Brooklynborn fighter and featured actor in the television series Taxi: He can take care of the boxing half of his career.

title: Gustav Thurm, 87, Doorman Held Post With Columbia for 50 Years
description: Gustav Munn, a doorman for 50 years at Columbia Unversity's Butler Hall, residence for graduate students, visiting scholars and faculty members. died April 19 in St. Luke's Hospital In New York City. Be was 87 years old.

title: Catholics Urged to Mount Drive for Human Rights
description: A leading Roman Catholic advocate of church involvement in social causes, Msgr. John Egan of the University of Notre Dame, has urged American Catholics to combat what he calls a loss of mission and purpose by mounting a drive in behalf of the church's teachings on justice and human rights.

title: Villanova Wins Penn Medley
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 27  Nei. cher rain nor wind nor a 3minute57.5. second anchor mile by Thom Hunt of Arizona could keep Villanova from its 14th consecutive distance medley relay title at the Penn Relays today.

title: To Defang Political Issues at Stockholder Meetings
description: STANFORD. Calif.  This spring, for the 10th year in a row, the annual meeting of many of the nation's most visible corporations has been the setting for a series of bitter political controversies.

title: Notes on People
description: She had built her own log cabin deep in the Adirondacks so she could live close to nature, far from the nearest road. A few years ago she wrote a book, Woodswoman, about her life, mostly alone, in her cabin. She's still in the Adirondacks, but this past winter, Anne LaBastille had to rent a house that would not leave her cut off from the airport because of all the traveling she had to do.

title: 2 Sentenced in a Marijuana Case Involving L.I. Prosecutor's Office
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 27 (AP)  A former Nassau County assistant district attorney and a Brooklyn lawyer were sentenced to four months in connection with a marijuanatrafficking case involving the Nassau County District Attorney's office.

title: Scripps Award Is Issued To Papers in Rochester
description: The Gannett Rochester Newspapers have won the third Edward Willis Scripps Award for the most outstanding public service during 1978 in the cause of a free press.

title: Nuclear Regulatory Commission Members
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Five men, three with backgrounds in physics. make up the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which has broad authority over regulating nuclear energy operations in the United States. Following are background sketches on the five:Began his term on the commission in August 1977  was designated its chairman by President Carter  54 years old  came to the commission from the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, N.Y., where he had been chairman of the department of applied science since 1975  also worked from 1955 to 1972 at Brookhaven  from 1972 to 1974 was deputy director for technical review of the directorate of licensing of the Atomic Energy Commission, the N.R.CS predecessor  holds a doctorate in physics from Columbia University.

description: WASHINGTON. April 27 (AP)  A Republican who headed the Census Bureau under the Nixon and Ford Administrations is expected to return to run the 1980 census, according to Government sources.

title: E.E.C. Prices Up 0.8%
description: BRUSSELS, April 27 (AP)  The consumer price index rose eighttenths of 1 percent in March in countries of the European Economic Community and was up 8.4 percent from a year earlier, the community's statistical office said in a preliminary report today.

Sweeney of Local 32B32J, Service Employees Union, who said: We'll move the picket line into the road. We're conducting a strike.

description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 27  A senior Rhodesian official said today that South Africa had offered substantial economic and military assistance to sustain the incoming government of Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa.

title: Trevino Leads in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 27 (AP) Lee Trevino, exhibiting a reditcovered puting stroke and his old confidence, came from three shots off the pace with ifiveunderpar 67 and took the secondround lead today in the $250,000 New Orleans open golf tournament.

title: TWO SLAIN, 31 HURT BY SNIPER IN TEXAS

The sniper, identified by the police as Ira Attebury, 64 years old, killed himself as the police closed in, the authorities said.

title: 3Month Geneva Arms Talks End With Little Discernible Progress
description: GENEVA, April 27 (UPI)  The enlarged Geneva disarmament conference ended its first session of 1879 today with little discernible progress in three months of debate.

title: Critic's Notebook: Spring Ended Theater's Drought
description: It is a Chaucer's April on Broadway. The drought, not just of March but of the whole season, is pretty well pierced to the root. A season that had been struggling along on a diet of feeble musicals  Sweeney Todd aside and a number of eminently forgettable plays  Wings and Spokesong aside  has turned into a highprotein festival. Three splendid productions of firstrate plays (Bedroom Farce, The Elephant Man and Whose Life Is It Anyway?) backed up by two others, interesting though flawed in some ways (Faith Healer and G.R. Point), and all in the space of three weeks.

description: WASHINGTON, April 27  President Carter's request to Congress for $150 million in emergency economic and military aid to Turkey provoked opposition this week from Greece and from American supporters of Greece, on Capitol Hill and elsewhere, Administration officials said today.

description: ROME, April 27 (Reuters)  The Roman, Catholic Church formally adopted a new Latin text of the Bible today, replacing the translation made by St. Jerome more than 1,500 years ago and known as the Vulgate.

title: A Golf GlobeTrotter Still Flying Playing.
description: AUSTIN, Tex., 27  Roberto de Vicenzo of Argentina began developing the art of globetrotting to golf tournaments long before Gary Player came along. Much of, his travel was in old propeller planei, with threeday trips from Buenos Aires to Miami.

description: WASHINGTON. April 27  Since the accident at the Three Mile Island reactor a month ago, a key aspect of the intense debate over what safety improvements the Government should require has been the question of how much these measures would cost.

title: Trade Gap Is Smallest In 2 Years
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  The United States deficit in trade with the rest of the world narrowed last month to the smallest total in nearly two years as a big, broadbased Increase in exports swamped gains in imports, the Goverornent reported today.

title: Steel Boom Squeezes The Smaller Buyer
description: CLIFTON, N.J.  Steve Tendler, who oversees the steel buying for the small Universal Metal Chain Company here, is worried he will not be able to get enough raw material for the light fixtures his company produces.

title: Rally Hails AntiKhomeini Cleric
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 27 (AP) More than 100,000 people in Iran's Khuzistan Province, demonstrated today in favor of a local religious leader who is critical of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's armed revolutionary committees.

title: Califano Talks to Navajos Abotit Health Problems
description: CROWN POINT, N.M., April 27  The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Joseph A. Califano Jr., arrived here this afternoon as part of a oneday tour of the Navajo reservation.

title: Chrysler to Continue Mitsubishi Motors Tie
description: TOKYO, April 27 (AP)  Negotiations between the Chrysler Corporalon and the Mitsubishi MotorS CorPoration ended today with Chrysler saying it would continue to act as the. United States dittributor for the Japanese company and with the reported resig.nation of Mitsubishi's president.

title: Prison Guards Chief Jailed as Strike Enters 9th Day
description: ALBANY, April 27  The head of the striking prison guards union was jailed today after defying a court order that he publicly urge the state's correction officers to return to workthis morning.

title: Latins Cite Foreign Curbs to Growth
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 27  The rising cost of energy, protectionism in industrial markets and unstable commodity prices dominated an appraisal of Latin America's development prospects issued by the United Nations Regional Economic Commission.

title: Mets Rained Out; Play 2 Tomorrow
description: The New York Mets postponed last night's scheduled game at Shea Stadium with Los Angeles. The contest was rescheduled as part of a doubleheader with the Dodgers tomorrow. The twin bill will start at 1:05 P.M.

title: Stage: Dina Merrill as Chic British Matron
description: SYRACUSE, April 26  Amy, the heroine of Olwen Wymark's new play, Loved, currently running at the Syracuse Stage, is a chic British matron, a woman who seems even more high class because she is played by Dina Merrill. Amy is barren of children, bored with her marriage, disillusioned with good works and beloved by everyone. Amy, we are told, stands for aime; hence the title of the play. Actually Loved wears its symbolism like a signature on a designer scarf; no matter which way the wind blows, we never forget the label.

title: 5.6 Percent Budget Increase Passed in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, April 27  A budget of 42.4 billion for the fiscal year beginning July 1 a 5.6 percent increase over last year  cleared the General Assembly this afternoon.

title: Walton Seymour Dies; An Authority on Power
description: Walton Seymour, an authority on public and private power uses, died of cancer Thursday in New York Hospital. Mr. Seymour, who lived at 70 East Tenth Street, was 69 years old.

title: Mexico's BirthCbntrol Effort Catching On
description: TEPATETIPA, Mexico  For Do. mitila Sebastian, the Mexican Govern. mantes bunnypia:ming program has per, haps come too late. At the age of 40 Mrs. Sebastian has been pregnant 14 times and has 12 surviving children aged 1 to 22.

title: Film: 'Kingdom of Naples,' 32 Years in the Life of an Italian Family:The Cast
description: As Bernardo Bertolucci learned after he spent almost as much money making "1900" as Jefferson paid for the Louisiana Territory, epic subjects don't automatically make epic films.Werner Schroeter, a young West German film maker, has purloined 32 years of Italian history for his new film, "The Kingdom of Naples," and transformed them into a series of random picture-post cards from the recent past. The film, seemingly influenced by Brecht, Godard and Bertolucci, though not made any better by their examples, is a series of sentimental tableaux featuring the members of a Neapolitan family from 1944 to 1976.Massimo, the son, grows up to find that his beloved Communist Party is something less than perfect, and his beautiful sister, Vittoria, who has a crush on President Kennedy in the early 60's, finds that all men are beasts and that she must obtain an education if she is to survive.The movie's dozens of scenes are often like blackout sketches without punch lines. Sometimes the overstatement is funny, but most of the scenes are without pointed style or important content. It's like seeing a revue put on the stage before the writers had finished the material."The Kingdom of Naples" will be presented in the New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art today at 6 P.M. and Tuesday at 8:30 P.M.

title: 32 Die in Dominican Floods
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 27 (Reuters)  Floods in northern areas of the Dominican Republic have killed 32 people, driven thousands from their homes and caused widespread damage to farmland, officials reported today.

title: Egypt Studying Rumanian Call for New Mideast Talks
description: CAIRO, April 27  Egypt is studying a proposal by President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania for a new Middle East conference at Geneva that would include other Arabs, including the Palestinians, an Egyptian official reported today.

title: Fed Nudges ShortTerm Rates Up
description: The Federal Reserve. apparently modifying its strategy of keeping interest rates stable,, nudged shortterm rates higher yesterday. The credit markets viewed the action as a significant move toward more restrictive monetary policy.

title: Maynard C. Wheeler, a Professor And Retired Ophthalmologist, 76
description: Dr. Maynard C. Wheeler, a retired ophthalmologist, died Tuesday in the Woodbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.

title: Convention on Balanced Budget Is Approved by New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N.H., April 27 (AP)  On the heels of President Carter's visit, New Hampshire became the 30th state to call for a convention to draft a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget, a move the President opposes.

title: Morris Moskin, 92, Was Founder Of the Moskin Clothing Company
description: Morris Moskin, the founder and retired chairman of the board of Moskin Stores Inc., died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92 years old and lived at 220 Central Park South.

title: Transbus Bid Barred by G.M.
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  The General Motors Corporation, as expected, told Transportation Secretary Brock Adams today that it would not bid on the Transbus. a futuristicdesign bus.

title: Draddy, Iona Prep, Wins Penn Mile Run in 4:09.3
description: PHILADELPHIA. April 27  Vince. Draddy, who said he was just running to win and not Winking about the clock, easily won the invitation onemile run for schoolboys today at the Penn Relays. His time of 4 minutes 9.3 seconds was the secondbest posted in the 16year history of the relay carnival.

title: Reilly Resigns as Director Of Incoming Break a Leg

Mr. Reilly said his lawyer, had asked the producers to remove his name from the program and the theater marquee.

title: Bridge.
description: Claims by the declarer, and less often by a defender, of the last tricks left to be played are a common source of disputes. The disputes can be diminished, however, if you follow a fevisimrole rules. Do not claim the remaining tricks in a hand unless you are sure of your ground. If you do claim, put your cards face up on the table and state your intentions. If your opponent claims, take a few seconds to verify that his claim is correct.

title: Sketches of the Men Freed by Moscow
description: Practicing member of Russian Orthodox Church  In childhood, after death of father, took name of mother, a Jew, in defiance of antiSemitism during Stalin regime  Reportedly in poor health  After sentence to third prison term in 1978, wife, Anna, said, He will die  Quiet, shy man of 42 years, but was portrayed as drunkard and debaucher by officials at last trial  In late 1950's published underground poetry journal thought to be responsible for first arrest and twoyear sentence  Wrote unauthorized account of Andrei Sinyaysky Yuli Daniel case for which he received fiveyear sentence for antiSoviet agitation  In 1974, with royalties donated by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, helped set up fund for families of political prisoners so they could pay for visiting relatives in Siberian labor camps and to support the children of inmates  In 1976, joined dissident group that publicized Soviet violations of humanrights pledges under the Helsinki accords  Arrested again for these activities and sentenced last July to eight years in strict labor camp and three in exile  During trial, asked ethnic background. replied, Prisoner  Married his wife while in prison camp in 1969, an act for which she lost her teaching job.

title: No Quick Fix for Inflation
description: The White House's top economists, who should know better, are calling for a quick fix for inflation. They want the Federal Reserve Board to tighten its already tight monetary policy. That would eventually reduce inflation, but at the risk of inducing an unnecessary recession later this year. For weeks, they have lobbied the Fed to move in this direction. The mystery is not why the Fed correctly decided this week to reject the advice. but why the advice was given at all.

title: Grand Festivities in Pyongyang
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea, April 27  Our first two days in Pyongyang consisted of wellorganized practice sessions, colorful festivities, and informal contact between players of the 76 competing nations.

title: Canada Increases Oil Prices by 9.4%
description: OTTAWA, April 27, (AP)  The Canadian Government announced today a 9.4 percent price rise for the light crude oil it exports to the United States to $20.51 a barrel.

title: MailOrder Star's Rise and Fall
description: ATLANTA, April 27  As recently as last fall, Kaleidoscope Inc. was considered one of the most successful of the new wave of catalogue mailorder shopping companies.

description: WASHINGTON AN industrial scientist received this week what he believes to be the first patent ever granted for motor powered solely by permanent magnets. He has operated small test models with success and thinks that with further development this revolutionary approach to motor power should make a significant contribution toward saving energy.

title: Lilco Is Denied Most of Requested Increase
description: The New York State Public Service Commission yesterday granted the Long Island Lighting Company an increase in electricity rates far below what the utility had sought and, at the same time. anflounced an investigation into whether Lilco had spent money prudently in constructing its nuclear power plant in Shoreham, L.I.

title: 120 CableTV Stations Will Carry CallIn Program
description: A satelliteborne program originating in New York will be carried by 120 cable television stations in 37 states from Hawaii to Maine tomorrow, and viewers will be able to make tollfree calls to ask questions or discuss The Lost Million: Is American Labor Becomine Obsolete?

title: 4 Jews Freed From Soviet Prison Are Allowed to Depart for Israel
description: MOSCOW. April 27 (Reuters)  Four Latvian Jews Jailed for their part in an abortive hijacking in 1970 left today for Israel after serving nearly nine years in prison and labor camp.

title: Comedy: Andy Kaufman Fills Stage With Parade of Odd Characters
description: There was a hint of the unusual about Andy Kaufman's Carnegie Hall performance on Thursday even before he loaded the audience onto charter buses and took everyone out for milk and cookies. For one thing, the announced showtlme was 8:03 P.M. For another, there were guest appearances by the Rockettes and a largely black delegation from the Mormon Tabernacle Choir. And the overture for the show, which included The Impossible Dream, Hound Dog and the Popeye theme song, turned out to be a perfectly accurate indication of Mr. Kaufman's tastes and his repertory.

title: Screen: 'Consequence' From West Germany:The Cast
description: The first and best part of "The Consequence" is a tender courtship episode, delicately rendered. Martin, a quiet, sad-eyed man of perhaps 30 years old, is imprisoned for having had sex with a 15-year-old boy, and while incarcerated he finds Thomas, the son of one of the prison officials. Thomas (Ernst Hannawald) has the cheek-bones of a female fashion model and the innocent beauty of an angel. And, more to the point, Thomas has a crush on Martin (Jurgen Prochnow) from the moment they meet.Their affair is consummated in the kind of gradual, intimate, not at all sexually explicit love scene one seldom sees between heterosexual couples on the screen any more. The director, Wolfgang Petersen, uses slow, steady camera movements and the natural warmth of his two actors to give this early part of his film  all of which is in black and white  an unusually rosy glow.The rest of "The Consequence," which is a West German contribution to the Museum of Modern Art's New Directors/New Films series, follows Thomas and Martin from one hardship to the next, with society persecuting them at every turn. Martin is denied parole after the prison guards read one of Thomas's love letters. Thomas loses his job for consorting with Martin later on. Thomas winds up in a reform school populated exclusively by goons, including one burly sadist who puts out cigars on the persons of his least-favorite students.Even before the other reform school boys try to force Thomas to have sex with a pimply, feeble-minded girl with thick glasses, Mr. Petersen makes it clear that he favors a stacked deck. Heterosexuality is represented, by this girl and by Thomas's dreadful parents, as the cruelest of fates, and everyone they meet seems determined to harass the lovers. Indeed, until one late scene showing Martin in a homosexual bar, there is little evidence that Switzerland and West Germany, where the film takes place, contain any other homosexuals except these two. Such over-simplifications eventually push the plot over the edge into unabashed melodrama.Still, Mr. Petersen keeps the love story so vivid and simple, in its way, that his more heavy-handed flourishes are easy to ignore. Much of "The Consequence" is sentimental in the nicest sense and genuinely romantic, too. Mr. Petersen demonstrates both technical proficiency and a sensitivity toward the gentler side of his subject.

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 27 Paul Alden's greatest fear, his neighbors said, was that his 60yearold wife would be left alone. A stroke victim, she was apparently dependent on him. Yesterday afternoon, thinking he was having a heart attack, he shot her to death, the police said.

title: News Summary
description: The Soviet Union freed five dissidents and sent them to New York in exchange for two convicted Soviet spies held by the U.S., who were on their way to Moscow. The White House announced the exchange. The five dissidents are Aleksandr Ginzburg, Mark Dymshits, Eduard Kuznetsov, Valentin Moroz, and Georgi Vins. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Update on New York's Strikes
description: Apartment Houses: Tenants in the nearly 2.000 buildings affected by the fourdayold walkout were urged to take their own garbage to the curbside in an effort to offset a growing health problem stemming from the refusal of sanitation workers to cross picket lines. The number of buildings certified by the Health Department for emergency pickups rose to 104, and there were 400 complaints to an emergency hot line. The union dropped, for the moment, plans to spread the strike to Brooklyn and Queens. Meanwhile, independent settlements continued, increasing to 300 yesterday. Talks were scheduled to resume at 11 A.M. tomorrow. [Page 29.

description: Jerome Singleton, who was released without bail by Judge Bruce McM. Wright, touching off a furor, appeared in Criminal Court yesterday for a pretrial hearing on charges he had attempted to murder a decoy police officer.

title: STAGE VIEW

The new name of the 41st Street playhouse, along with that rearing and no doubt roaring symbol of British energy, comes from the plan of the building's present owners and managers to specialize in bringing us new plays from London  especially plays we might not otherwise get. The notion that we might not,have got Brian Clark's Whose Life Is It Anyway?, which has reopened the house and in the reopening blessed it; is unthinkable. The play, like its mascot, has the strength often.

title: If You Go
description: to Mesa Verde National Park or the adjacent Ute Mountain Tribal Park, a good time for a trip is from midJune to Labor Day, Mesa Verde is open all year, but it is only in the summer that all regions may be visited and that all facilities are open. In the summer, too, the park service maintains the most services as well as a fun complement of guides. The summer season is also the most crowded time to visit the ruins, so at least two days should be allocated and some earlymorning starts should be anticipated.

title: Survival Suit
description: BREMERTON, Wash., April 28 (AP)  A fleet of 200 tuna boats lay drifting off Oregon's Cascade Head one evening last September when sudden galeforce winds whipped up 18foot swells, capsizing seven boats. The crewmen were quickly rescued, except for George Jameson.

title: The Screen: 'El Super,' A Cuban-American Tale:The Cast
description: For the last 10 of his 42 years, Roberto, a former bus driver in Havana, has been living in New York exile with his wife, Aurelia, and their 17-year-old daughter, Aurelita. Roberto not only suffers the life of an outsider, he embraces it as well as the isolation, the humiliation and the homesickness that go with it. Because he refuses to learn English, the best he can do by way of employment is a job as superintendent in a large tenement on the Upper West Side."El Super," a Cuban-American feature film shot in New York, opens early on a Sunday morning in February as Roberto tries to sleep while angry tenants upstairs bang on the pipes demanding that the boiler be turned on. They are entitled, but he has forgotten. Finally he rouses himself. Says Aurelia of the commotion, "I can't stand English the first thing in the morning."A little later, Aurelia surveys their neat basement apartment, furnished with all of the necessities, including a television set and an electric blender, and reports that she's tired of peering out the window and seeing nothing but people's feet. "It's like looking at the world from underneath," which is pretty much the way Roberto sees things.From this beginning you might suspect that "El Super" would be grim, but you'd be wrong. It's a funny, even-tempered, unsentimental drama about people in particular transit. Roberto thinks of his life as being a sort of long, boring, nonstop flight from Cuba that will eventually circle back there, while Aurelita and a number of their friends are losing no time in assimilating.The film, the first feature to be co-directed by Leon Ichaso and Orlando Jimenez-Leal, is based on Ivan Acosta's play of the same name that was produced originally by the Cuban Cultural Center in New York in 1977. It will be presented in the New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art today at 6 P.M. and Wednesday at 8:30 P.M. It is scheduled to have its commercial opening in New York in June."El Super" is not an especially political film, though it is concerned with working-class people who fled the revolution. Its most uninhibitedly comic character is a manic fellow named Pancho, a veteran of the Bay of Pigs fiasco, who is rabidly anti-Castro and everywhere sees Communist conspirators, including the loony man who pushes into Roberto's apartment one Sunday afternoon to preach Christ's Gospel."El Super" is much less about politics than it is about the disorientation of exiles who become living metaphors for the human condition. Such a person is Roberto, played with infinite good humor and common sense by Raymundo Hidalgo-Gato. The role, like the screenplay by Manuel Arce and Mr. Ichaso, is extremely well written as it avoids the usual impulse of such realistic drama to state in large, long speeches what it intends to be about. "El Super" works entirely within its characters and events.The film was obviously produced on a very low budget, but with care, intelligence and with a cast of marvelous Cuban and Puerto Rican actors. In addition to Mr. Hidalgo-Gato, they include Zully Montero as Aurelia, Reynaldo Medina as Pancho, and Elizabeth Pina as Aurelita.

title: Military Chiefs Undecided on Pact

Jones, said today that the nation's military leaders were undecided on the proposed new strategicarms treaty, but warned that the Soviet Union's armed strength was growing and outpacing that of the United States.

title: Meditation On a Life
description: IHAVE always, all of my life, been looking for help from a man, we are told near the beginning of Elizabeth Hardwick's subtle and beautiful new book. It has come A: many times and many more it has not. Th began early. What follows eludes ire mediate summary or categorization. Sleepless Nights is a novel, but it is novel in which the subject is memory and in which the I whose memories are in question is entirely and deliberately the author: we recognize the events and addresses of Elizabeth Hardwick's life not only from her own earlier work, but from the poems of her husband, the late Robert Lowell. We study in another light the rainy afternoons and dyed satin shoes and highschool drunkenness of the Kentucky adolescence, the thin coats and yearnings, toward home of the graduate years at Columbia, the households in Maine and Europe and on Marlborough Street in Boston and West 67th Street in New York. We are presented the entire itinerary, shown all the punched tickets and transfers. The result is less a story about or of a life than a shattered meditation on it, a work as evocative and difficult to place as Claude LeviStrauss's Tristes Tropiques, which it oddly recalls. The author observes of her enigmatic narrative: It certainly hasn't the drama of: I saw the old,

title: Bay State Court Lacks Funds

Judge Ann Gibbons told the Hampshire County Commission yesterday ,that her court has no money for postage, stationery, telephone, nothing. She reported outstanding bills. of $4,112, while one court account had a balance of $78.78 and two others were empty.

The concert instead featured six valued permanent members of the society playing works by the three great Viennese Classicists: Haydn's Trio in F sharp minor, Mozart's Quintet for Piano and Winds in E flat (K. 452) and Beethoven's Archduke Trio.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The following 24 questions are designed to test your viability this season as a film aficionado. A score zero, of course, means utter failure; you are reading too many books. One to four correct answers indicates you've been watching too much television, and you fail. Five to 10 also testifies to your failure, but you've lucked out. A score of 11 to 15 is Fair, 16 to 20 is Good and 21 to 23 Very Good. A perfect score is Excellent, and means you should investigate the possibility of editing book on trivia. You may also be an insufferable bore.

title: WASHINGTON Signals From Moscow
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  In recent weeks, there has been a marked change in the Soviet Union's communications with the Carter Administration. Questions raised by Secretary of State Vance with Soviet Ambassador Anatoly Dobrynin have been answered within days instead of weeks, and issues that have been on the shelf for months are now being settled.

title: The Life and Times of Balanchine's Apollo
description: For many experienced balletgoers the best news about the New York City Ballet season that begins Tuesday at the New York State Theater is that Apollo will be back in the repertory after an absence of several seasons. It is of no small interest either that Mikhail Baryshnikov will appear in the title role in the openingnight performance. While the sequence depicting the birth of the god is apparently to be eliminated in the coming performances, the essence of this 20thcentury choreographic masterpiece by George Balanchine presumably remains intact.

title: Woman Is Killed by Freight Train
description: GREENFIELD, Mass., April 28 (AP)  A 26-year-old Shelburne Falls woman was killed here after being hit by a Boston & Maine freight train, according to the police. Mary Leland was hit about 8:15 P.M. yesterday on tracks running behind a downtown shopping center. The police said that the area in which she had been walking could be reached only by climbing down a steep embankment, and tbey were unclear why sbe had been tbere.

title: Amtrak Trains Get More Time To Make Runs
description: BOSTON, April 28 (AP)  Most Amtrak train runs between Boston and Washington will be lengthened by 15 to 45 minutes under a new Northeast Corridor timetable that goes into effect tomorrow. But the longer runs will merely reflect reality, according to Amtrak.

title: Los Angeles'

MinneapolisSt.Paul, New York, Dallas, Detroit and Philadelphia submitted formal bids by the April 16 deadline. Los Angeles bid came this week, but with the stipulation that the convention not cost the taxpayers anything.

City this weekend.

description: ROME, April 28 The last King and Queen of Afghanistan, who once held court in their Joy of the Heart Palace in Kabul when they were not visiting the royal domains in the fertile valleys of their mountainous country, now live in a threeroom apartment here and try to keep down the grocery bills.

title: ART VIEW
description: In our experience of art, every shift in current practice opens up a new perspective on the past. So it was more less inevitable that the current turn toward Realism and related modes of representationalism in painting would bring in its wake a renewed interest in an earlier generation of American Realists. We have already seen something similar occur in the recent revaluation of firstgeneration American modernists. (Would critical opinion of the early color abstractions of Patrick Henry Bruce, say, be quite as high as it now is if we had not had a Arital contemporary movement in color abstraction? I doubt it.) It looks as if this spirit of rediscovery and revaluation is now at work in disin- terring the paintings of some of the Realists who, though once much admired, have in recent decades fallen into an undeserved obscurity.

But that is just the beginning of the fresh and imaginative offerings at The Gull. For one thing, a restaurant that avoids clams casino and other such menu cliched cannot be all bad. And as it turns out, this cheerful five-year-old restaurant more often than not lives up to its bright promise.

title: What's Doing in BALTIMORE

Dur- Ing the anniversary tne city will emphasize its maritime, historical and ethnic elements.

title: STAMPS
description: With the United Nations and the United States in the vanguard, and with countries from all over the world joining in, the philatelic recognition of the International Year of the Child is already well on its way to becoming the first big omnibus issue of the year. In fact, it may, by year's end, be one of the biggest omnibus issues of all time. The need to better the lot of children has universal appeal and few, if any, stamp designs are more photogenic and appealing than the faces of children.

title: State Still Lagging In Population Race
description: WASHINGTON CALIFORNIA, already towering redwoodlikeover Connecticut in population, added 2.3 million its total between the 1970 census and mid1978, a figure amounting to threequarters of Connecticut's entire population.

description: There were three developments last week in the effort by the Federal Communications CommisSion under its current chairman, Charles D. Ferris, to encourage greater competition in the industries it regulates.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The rule of thumb about the best choreography any idiom is that two aspects are inevitably bound to emerge. One will show a dance piece to be good that its richness, if not complexity, can be absorbed only upon repeated viewmgs. The second aspect is that the best works are those that stay with the viewer, even to the extent of affecting the onlooker more deeply after the performance than while the dancing is progress. If dance is the art of the moment, one of its paradoxes is that its great moments are distinguished by how long they linger in memory.

title: Police, Urged to Trim Top Jobs, Giving Promotions
description: Despite criticism by City Council President Carol Bellamy that the New York City Police Department is topheavy with management, City Hall has approved a new round of departmental promotions.

title: St. Andrews, a Loyalist English Town Founded in 1784,
description: Less than 20 miles into Canada after crossing the border at Calais, Me., and St. Stephen, New Brunswick, the traveler realizes that a curiously pleasing thing has happened to the landscape. The phenomenon is the opposite of what Alice experienced at the bottom of the rabbit hole, for as the visitor from the United States turns onto Route 127 and heads for St. Andrews on Passamaquoddy Bay, the human scale remains the same but the world around seems to shrink. Gone are the armorysized supermarkets, banks designed for automobiles and discount stores where the distance between house paint and children's socks seems scaled to travel by bicycle. Here, fields and farmsteads, stores and roads are just right for the human frame and the human spirit. Old words return to mind: cozy, tidy, neat, handy.

title: A Deadly Backdrop As Israel, Egypt Implement Accords
description: The new IsraeliEgyptian peace machinery coughed cautiously to life last week after a lastminute stall over key words. At the United States surveillance station at Um Khashiba deep in the Sinai desert, ratification documents were exchanired. An im- promptu jam session by Israeli and Egyptian military musicians enlivened a twohour wait while Israel successfully argued that autonomy on the West Bank and Gaza should be promised specifically for the 'inhabitants, not the territory. The effect was to steer the commitment away from Arab demands for a transition to Palestinian state.

description: SYOSSET ONCE you find your way to Portobello Square in Syosset, you'll be glad you did. This minimall, which opened last year at 44 Jericho Turnpike, houses 11 small shops in open stalls set off the main arcade, and all the shops are exquisite. Hary E. Strauss, Portobello Square's designer and builder, used unfinished wood paneling and dark brown carpet in the minimall to create an elegant yet casual setting for the shops.

title: CRIME
description: Margaret Millar's last book, Ask for Me Tomorrow, introduced a young, Spanish-speaking lawyer named Tom Aragon. He returns in THE MURDER OF MIRANDA (Random House, II3.95), but that is about all the two books have in common. Miss Millar is justly celebrated for her mastery, and she is not content to repeat the same formula in novel after novel. The Murder of Miranda is one of her more unusual books.

title: The Rock Country of Southeast Utah
description: Most travelers through the Four Corners area of the Southwest stay on the main highways, and they visit the same places: Navajo National Monument, Four Corners National Monument, Mesa Verde, with perhaps a side trip to Canyon de Chelly. There is nothing wrong in that. Those places are beautiful and rewarding. But a few miles away, in southeastern Utah, is a seldomtraveled country so different, so out of time, that it deserves a good long look.

title: Widow Wins Utility Compromise
description: BALTIMORE, April 28 (AP)  A 77yearold widow who received a $2,500 electric bill has been told by the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company that she need not pay $1,750 of it. The utility billed Anna C. Pierce for six years of unmetered gas service when it was discoVered her gas furnace was not connected to the meter. But Charles Franklin, a utility representative, said yesterday that the company had decided to void $1,750 of the bill because someone else was responsible for the property when the furnace was installed.

title: MUSIC

As old Will said, though, There is something in the wind, and indeed we now see that springtime and summer at Stratford will be aglow with Shakespeare once again.

title: DINING OUT Portuguese Food in Festive Setting
description: ON a recent Sunday afternoon a Portuguese family was celebrating the baptism of an infant at Viriato, a friendly Portuguese restaurant where such festiveness finds the perfect setting. The food is hearty, the wines and port robust, and the atmosphere lends itself to the enjoyment of the moment. Viriato, named after a secondcentury Iberian hero who repeatedly beat back the Romans, is typical of the kind of affable local restaurant one finds in profusion throughout Portugal, Spain and Italy. Butteryellow walls, dark woods, wellplaced tables set with starched white cloths, goodlooking china, and cruets of oil and vinegar, and a working fireplace (although here the fire is a fake one) all add to the conviviality, and the food is meant to be shared.

title: Film: Game Is a Symbol Of U.S. Life:The Cast
description: The two young basketball players featured in "The American Game," a feature-length documentary that opens today at Cinema II, have everything and nothing in common. Brian Walker comes from a white, gung-ho middleclass family in Indiana, with parents who are pushy about his career and an older brother who looks just like him; the brother, like Brian, is a basketball star. Stretch Graham, a black Brooklynite, lives in a housing project with his sister and sometimes wishes he hadn't played so much basketball, so that he could have spent more time with his mother before she died.Brian and Stretch are both high school seniors, both highly in demand and hounded by dozens of college recruiters. Both are as scared by their success as they are enthusiastic about the game. Both are exceedingly polite and quiet, not much accustomed to expressing their feelings through words. Both are, at least in the eyes of the basketball-watching populations of their communities, genuine heroes.But what other similarities do they really share? Beyond a certain point, the parallels between Brian and Stretch become vague, and "The American Game" is more adept at capitalizing on this than at trying to cast light upon it. The directors, Jay Freund and David Wolf, have simply juxtaposed biographical sketches of the two players and left room for the viewer to draw any number of conclusions, big or small.What does basketball tell us about American life? What does it suggest about American families or communities or the teams themselves? The film is too loosely structured to tackle such questions directly. Yet by profiling two players instead of only one it aspires to a certain degree of generalization. And by studying two instead of two hundred, it invites an audience to generalize on the basis of very limited information. In the end, the film hovers precariously between personality study and overview, never fully committing itself to either avenue of exploration.Brian Walker never comes through very clearly, but the townspeople of Lebanon, Ind., talk revealingly about how they view their basketball stars, and a hair-raising scene with Brian's parents shows how little voice the boy seems to have in decisions about his own future. Stretch's story, which is given equal time but seems a lot more interesting, is full of more complicated feelings about the game. Stretch's relationships with his coach, the coach's wife and his teammates is in a real-life "Welcome Back, Kotter" mold."The American Game" is best when it sticks to interview footage, and a little abrupt in the editing of its basketball sequences. People are constantly seen pretending to talk naturally, as if they didn't know there were a film crew underfoot, a tactic that becomes annoying after a while. Too much of the transitional material, with its blandly peppy music and emphasis on basketball fans having fun, looks and sounds like a soft-drink commercial.

title: SELECTION: From The Header Over Your Shoulder
description: THE most ancient European languages  those that have longest avoided infiltration by other languages  are the most complicated in their grammar and syntax. The age of a language can be roughly guessed by a count of its declensions, conjunctions, moods, tenses, voices, cases, genders and numbers. Latin is clearly less ancient than Greek, since it has no middle voice, no dual number and no optative mood  thus in Latin at least seven words are needed to express the sentence If only you two thieves had drowned yourselves, but in Greek only four. French is clearly less ancient than Latin, since it has no separate neuter gender and does not decline its nouns; also, its conjugations are far simpler. English is clearly less ancient than French: except for its pronouns, it is free of gender differentiation.

title: Excerpts From New Castle Decision
description: AS a general matter, at least in New York, ordinances restricting apartment houses or multifamily housing to one area or zone of a locality have been upheld, while ordinances barring them entirely have been invalidated. In all of these cases, however, only the competing interests of the general welfare of the particular community and that of the landowner desiring a more reasonable or profitable return on his property have been involved. Pressure for the relaxation of exclusionary restrictions on the part of those excluded did not then exist, and it was therefore in this context of competing parochial interests that the general rule against judicial rezoning developed. Zoning and landuse regulations were deemed to be legislative functions, to be exercised by and within the particular expertise of the local legislative body.

Today the clientele is younger and more casually dressed, but the atmosphere is likely to be just as intense as thousands of collectors gather at the County Center this week to view the 88th presentation of the Eastern States Antiques Fair.

description: HAPPILY there has been no theater production to review this last week, which allows me to think on paper about a matter that has been bothering me since the summer of 1976. That was when I purchased a pair of tickets for the American Shakespeare Theater at Stratford, Conn. I wanted my wife to see Arthur Miller's The Crucible, which was being done at Stratford with Don Murray  somewhat better known in films than on the stage  in the leading role. I had seen the original 1953 New York production, which spoke to an America in the grip of the McCarthy era in terms of the Salem witchcraft trials, and the play's power had stayed with me.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE EYE OF THE STORY, by Eudora Welty. (Vintage, $3.45.) In this selection of 35 reviews and essays, the distinguished novelist and shortstory writer constantly touches the painful place where literary critic and creative writer meet . She stands in the eye not only of the story but of the storm. She stands calmly, because she is sure of her ground. She writes not so much as a critic as a sensitive reader. She makes the relationship between reading and writing extraordinarilyclose, Victoria Glendinning observed here.

Probably no two people have had a greater Influence on American children during that time span than Maurice Sendak and Mickey Mouse's creator. Mr. Sendak's first color drawing, at the age of 6. signed Murray Sendak. was of Mickey Mouse. and, in his highschool magazine in 1945, the earnest young artist wrote admiringly, Walt Disney is the greatest exponent of a new art form which will leave its imprint on civilization.

title: Mayor Koch's Proposed Budget Does Not Count Very Much on Federal Money
description: WASHINGTON  Last December, aides at the White House could only wince as Mayor Koch heatedly accused President Carter of reneging on a commitment to increase Federal aid to New York City to help close a budget deficit projected at nearly $1.2 billion by mid1982. If the Federal Government does not honor its commitment, the Mayor said, the city will have no choice but to implement program of drastic reduction which will seriously impair its ability to render essential services. Later, Mr. Koch personally told the President he needed a minimum of $100 million this year.

title: Closing the Barn Door
description: The more closely the Nuclear Regulatory Commission looks at reactors, the less safe some of them seem.. Shortly after the accident at Three Mile Island, the commission concluded that there was no need to shut down similar plants elsewhere. Changes in procedures and minor adjustments would insure safety. Then sen- for staff members of the commission recommended that all nine reactors designed by Babcock & Wilcox, the builder of the Three Mile Island units, be closed for safety improvements. Now the commission proper has ordered a temporary shutdown, a reasonable and even overdue response to design defects that should have been corrected long ago. Whether the whole regulatory system is adequate to insure safety remains open to question.

title: IN BRIEF

The pro- posed merger of the BorgWarner torporation and the Firestone The and. Rubber Company, which would have been one of the largest combinations in American corporate history, was called off. Negotiations broke down after Firestone directors proposed a change in the terms that would have substantially increased the value of the securities that Firestone shareholders were to receive as'payment in the $1.35 billion merger. The merger of North Central Airlines and Southern Airways into a new carrier named Republic Airlines was approved by the Civil Aeronautics Board. title: How Giulini Made an Orchestra His Own

An improbable match: Mr. Giulini, the famously civilized and unpretentiotis conductor, wed to the mythic city of celluloid and silicone, the plastic land where even the lies have to be made up out of whole polyester. And yet, at Carnegie Hall this Thursday night when Mr. Giulini visits New York, he will be at the head of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, which he took over this season when Zubin Mehta moved to the New York Philharmonic.

title: More TeenAgets Seen Turning to Marijuana

A survey in the MarchApril issue of the Public Health Service's magazine, Public Health Reports, said, Among adolescents aged 1217, it is estimated that 53 percent have tried alcohol, 47 percent have tried tobacco and 28 percent have tried marijuana.

title: Timing Right for U.S.Soviet Swap
description: The rules of high diplomacy are often as simple as tit for tat. It seemed that way last week when five Soviet political prisoners were freed and flown to New York, on the day that talks began in Washington on liberalizing Soviet emigration and trade. Alex- ander Ginzburg, a human rights activist, and four other dissidents were ex- changed for two convicted Soviet spies released by Presidential clemency.

title: Rutgers Star Sees A Softball Victory
description: PISCATAWAY

title: All for Love
description: TWO IN THE CITY

title: T.E. Wyman Weds Elizabeth L. Stencil
description: Elizabeth Lee Stencil, daughter of Capt. Walter Joseph Stencil, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Stencil of Easton, Md., was married in Wye Mills, Md., yesterday to Timothy Edward Wyman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Wyman of New York and Easton. The Rev. Horatio Maunsell Richardson Jr. performed the ceremony at the Old Wye Episcopal Church.

title: Those NewCar Warranties: More May Be Less
description: OUR ultimate option, says Ford. One of the most important options we have introduced, says General Motors. And Chrysler, with a degree of restraint, merely cites faith in its own costly and complex engineering.

title: When the Maids
description: Philip Birnbaum, an architect who is currently involved in the construction of 10 apartment buildings in midManhattan, says there is not a maid's room in any of them.

title: The Bishop Must Prove That He's Not Smith's Pawn
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia  As much as anything, hymns caught the mood of this beleaguered capital last week. At the close of the polling that made Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa Prime Ministerelect, the country's leading whites gathered beneath the jacarandas of Government House for a flaglowering ceremony that ended with a police band playing Abide With Me. The night after election officials declared the Bishop's party winner, he led 1,000 guests at a victory reception in a chorus of Rock of Ages, his favorite. It took no familiarity with the Protestant hymnal to sense the congruence of the music with the solitude and melancholy felt by many whose fortunes ride with the hesitant prelate and his controversial partnership with the outgoing Prime Minister, Ian D. Smith.

title: Soviet Spies Got Data on Satellites To Be Used for Monitoring Missiles
description: LOS ANGELES, April 28  Information about several secret satellite systems that the United States expects to use to help verify the proposed strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union was purchased more than two years ago by Soviet intelligence agents, according to documents made available to The New York Times.

title: National Alcoholism Study Says TeenAge Intoxication Is on Rise
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) Teenagers are beginning to use alcoholat slightly earlier ages than the youths of 20 or 30 years ago and are getting drunk more frequently, a study by the National Council on Alcoholism shows.

title: Next Round in The Mideast: Realists vs. Pessimists
description: WASHINGTON  The exhilaration over last month's signing of the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty has long faded. The formal exchange of ratification documents last week that officially set the treaty machinery in motion was overshadowed by fighting in southern Lebanon and increased Palestinian terrorism. In short, as Egypt, Israel and the United States faced the next round of Middle East negotiations, the difficulties seemed greater than ever.

title: Carter Forming Panel to Combat Acts of Violence in U.S. Homes
description: WASHINGTON. April 28 (AP)  President Carter announced yesterday that he was establishing a committee to coordinate Federal programs for battered spouses and other victims of domestic violence.

title: A.I.A. Prizes Go to the Grand and the Modest
description: If the American Institute of Architect's 1979 Honor Awards that were announced this month prove anything, it is that the nation's architects are torn between a desire to make grand, monumental statements and a recognition that it is often the modest, unpretentious buildings that make more sense.

title: The Fantastic Mr. Pinkwater
description: IT was twilight, the witching hour of Walter Cronkite, hero of the hero of Lizard Music, when voice on the phone announced This is Daniel Manus Pinkwater. And the ensuing conversation was as surrealistic as reading the author who, all but unknown a halfdozen years ago, has now produced 20 children's books, including three new ones this spring, with three more scheduled for publication later in the year, and another, Java Jack, in progress with film maker Luaman Keele.

title: A Road by Any Other Name
description: IT was a halfcentury ago when H. L. Mencken first noticed that the developers of suburbs in low, marshy places have a great liking for adding heights to their names. Since then, developers have molded and modeled most of the Island and, true to form, they have favored rustic walks, lanes, drives and trails over more urbansounding streets and boulevards. For the planner knows better than the poet that a misnamed ruse smells not so sweet, and so, as he gives his garden spot its local habitation and a name, he listens attentively to the financial footfalls down Primrose Path.

title: Miss Horowitz Becomes Bride Of Jon Nagel
description: Susan Ellen Horowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius M. Horowitz of Woodniere, L.I., was married yesterday evening to Jon Alan Nagel of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur R. Nagel of Cincinnati. The ceremony was performed at the Carlyle by Rabbi Martin Zion of Temple Israel in Manhattan.

title: Boston U. Decides It Won't Sell All Its South Africa Investments
description: BOSTON, April 28 (AP)  The trustees of Boston University have voted against selling all of the university's investments in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: Soccer Strike Over, But Questions Linger
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  The aboprtive strike by the North American Soccer League players, more intricate and emotional than any contest on the field, ended as a confused fiasco in which the Federal Government played a critical but ambieuous role.

title: Of Mice and Cats
description: ASI read through 22 books about cats and mice. I kept in mind these verses by B. Kliban, sung by a troubadour cat, as a standard of excellence in the depiction of catmouse affairs:

title: Solar Power The Skies Have Not Yet Opened Up
description: For years the Government shunned solar technology, choosing instead to grant hefty tax writeoffs for oil and gas extraction, as well as outright subsidies for nuclear power development. That started to change after the Arab oil embargo of 1973-1974, when Washington realized that the control it once exercised over domestic energy prices had slipped into the hands of a foreign cartel. Solar energy suddenly started winning support.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: MUNICH, West Germany  In spite of material prosperity, there is throughout Western Europe an undercurrent of undefined apprehension. Though one cannot psychoanalyze a nation  much less a continent  the sources of that apprehension are worth exploring. Even a speculative diagnosis has value, for in shaping our policies we should understand as well as possible our allies state of mind.

title: Pessimistic Diversions
description: TEE LIBERA ME DOMINE

title: TV: College Sports Expose
description: The commercialism of bigtime college sports is a handy football for kicking around, given the greed, hypocrisy and exploitation that have been a fact of life in the major conferences for 50 years and more.

title: Why the Pop Scene Dotes on Novelty
description: Look at the record sales charts on any given week and you're likely to see a whole host of artists whom you'd never even heard of just a few months before. With the surge in the popularity of disco, we're experiencing an especially heavy onslaught of new artists. But at almost any time, particularly with singles, the record stores and the airwaves are full of new performers. So the questions become: Why this incessant upsurgeof novelty in popular music? Is the situation any different from what went on in the music of the past? And is it healthy or unhealthy?
