description: Anew medal to commemorate the signing of the treaty between Israel and Egypt in Washington on March 26 bears the biblical verse: I will give peace in the land Leviticus 26:6.

title: Open Season for Poachers
description: EAST LYME ON a lonely, twisting road on the northern fringe of Nehantic State Forest near here, two men sit in battered station wagon. Between them, on the front seat, are several boxes of 30caliber cartridges and a halfempty bottle of Scotch. It is 3 A.M.

title: Gay Meighan, Aide At Bloomingdale's, Wed to J.D. Corning
description: At the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday, Gay Meighan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mutter Meighan, was married to John Dawson Corning, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Townsend Corning. The Rev. Richard B. Martin performed the ceremony. Both families are from Mamaroneck. N.Y.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: You may go to the Museum of Modern Art and see useful and beautiful objects of everyday use on display in the galleries, and you may also arrange inspect a vast array of consumer and industrial products in the museum's Study Center. The Modem's Design Collection, established in the 1930's as an essential part of its radical theories about the nature of contemporary creativity, has long stressed innovative and handsome objects of commercial manufacture notable for their high levels of art and technology. Thus toasters and typewriters joined the traditional decorative arts as legitimate museum collectables.

title: Carlie Shields Is Married To Robert W.W. Squire
description: Carlotta Goodnow Shields, daughter of Mrs. W. Lyle Thompson of Middlebury. Conn., and William Shields Jr. of New York and Sharon, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Wilson Welles Squire. The ceremony was performed in Christ Episcopal Church in Sharon by the Rev. Frederick B. Stimson Jr. The bridegoom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur W. Squire of Boise, Idaho.

title: Judith Christine Bodnar to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bela J. Bodnar of Arlington, Va., of the engagement of their daughter, Judith Christine Bodnar, to William M. Scheck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Scheck of Malverne, Li. The wedding is planned for July 7.

title: On the Third Hand
description: GREAT poems for children are hard to come by. Apparently the genius that writes poems for adults  inhabiting Andrew Marvell, Emily Dickinson and John Keats  is more common than the genius that speaks in verse addressed to children. After Edward Lear, Lewis Carroll, A. A. Milne and Robert Louis Stevenson, it is a long march to the second rank. A small portion of Emily Dickinson can reach the child's ear; there is T. S. Eliot with his cats. and Theodore Roethke once or twice. But the failures outweigh the successes, and most poets who think that they will turn their hands to juveniles, in a spare moment, make unhappy moments in the history of publishing.

title: Is the Future Bleak For Intercounty TV?
description: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.

title: Mr. Koch at the Steeper Slope
description: In offering his 1980 budget, Mayor Koch says that New York City has safely come halfway up its climb solvency. He may be right. The city has encountered no recent cost overruns or revenue drops. But the second half of the climb looks much steeper.

title: April Memories Of Soviet Judaism
description: APRIL is marked by three related expressions of Jewish memory and concern. Passover celebrates the liberation of the Jews from bondage; Holocaust Remembrance Day commemorates the murder of six million Jews in Europe and the ghetto uprisings against the Nazis, and Solidarity Sunday today  gives us the opportunity to express our concern for the three million Jews of the Soviet Union.

title: Steelworkers Face Another Big Organizing Fight in South
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 27  One of the major union organizing efforts of the second half of this century has come to an impasse with workers at the giant shipyard here returning to work with little to show for a bitter 12week strike but a mass of lawyers bills and more to come.

description: Television is a very puzzling medium, Kirk Browning, the director of some 700 telecasts of operas, symphony concerts, musicals, dramas recitals and ballets, said recently. There is a tendency to look at television without responding to it.

title: By the Yardstick of Race Relations, Which Counts the Most, There Has Been Great Progress
description: BIRMINGHAM, Alabama  When Clifford Latting left for college, he had, he said, two requirements for my school. The first'was that it be outside Alabama. The second was that it be outside the South. After college and medical school at Columbia and a residency at the University of Chicago, Dr. Latting is back in his hometown, the first black physician on the staff of a hospital that had segregated wards when he went North 15 years ago.

title: Astles, Aide to Amin, Is Returned to Uganda By Kenya Authorities
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 28 (Reuters) - Robert Astles, the Britishborn aide to Idi Amin, the ousted President of Uganda, was flown back to Kampala today froth custody in Kenya, informed sources said.

title: Rules for Avoiding Common Mistakes
description: As travel gets more complex, more things can go wrong, and, increasingly, they do. Even experienced travelers are not immune to trouble, as the following examples will indicate. Some of the problems, to be sure, were unavoidable; others could have been prevented by more careful olanning. The best ad- vice: Travel cautiously. The time and money you save will almost certainly be your own.

title: Mary B. Davidson To Be Wed July 7
description: Mrs. A. Bruce Davidson of Lausanne, Switzerland, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Blake Davidson, to Jon F. Blickwede, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald J. Blickwede of Bethlehem, Pa. A July 7 wedding is planned in Toronto.

title: Federal Graiing Fees to Rise
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)  Fees charged for grazing cattle and other livestock on.national forest lands, mostly in the West, are being raised 22.5 percent this year, Agriculture Department of f cials said yesterday. The average fee will be $1.96 per animal unit month as against an average of $1.60 last year. An animal unit month equals the grazing for one month of one bull, cow, mule or horse, or five sheep or goats.

Zalmanson and her husband, Eduard S. Kuznetsov, were reunited in New York yesterday, fulfilling a dream nurtured in an agony of imprisonment and exile.

title: Headliners
description: Where was Hugh Hefner when the world needed him most? Last week, controversy raged over whether Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado had indeed worn a rabbit suit, or part of one, when she visited the Great Wall of China on Easter Sunday as part of a House delegation. Mrs. Schroeder has reportedly said yes, no, maybe, can't remember, and only the head. Denver talk shows have buzzed and growled, as though Colorado law prohibited impersonating a rabbit on Easter. But Mrs. Schroeder told reporters, If you ever want to borrow a rabbit suit, I know where you can get one.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING Thrifty Renovation vs. Rigid Code
description: WHEN Mike Woscznya, an interior designer, purchased a decaying 1865 Victorian town house on Buckingham Street in Hartford for $25,000 last October, intent upon restoring the home to its original beauty while remodeling it into four apartments, he never quite anticipated the degree to which the state building code would raise his rehabilitation cost and delay completion of the job.

title: ANTIQUES Collectors Take to Great Outdoors
description: NEXT Saturday the antiques trade moves out of doors. From then through the Columbus Day weekend, dealers and collectors will barter and buy on town greens and commons, school grounds and the yards of historic houses almost every weekend during Connecticut's 22week season of antiques festivals and flea markets. In all, 30 al fresco shows are scheduled and it is expected that others will be announced as the summer progresses.

title: Julie Harris: Comedy Is Like a Holiday
description: puttering around the galley kitchen of a friend's West Side apartment, borrowed for the duration of the new play she is about to appear in on Broadway. Julie Harris carefully set about brewing a pot of fresh coffee for a visitor and rummaged through cabinets in search of some cookies to nibble on Dressed in comfortably casual clothes and sandals and wearing her reddish hair in a short, feathery cut, she did not for an instant resemble the first lady of the American theater  a title to which many would say she now holds unquestioned claim.

title: If You Go
description: to southeastern Utah, the hiking and backpacking are wondrous, particularly in the spring and fall, when temperatures are mild and there is water in the canyon bottoms. Some of the biggest stretches of American wilderness south of Alaska are there: roadless canyons up to 50 miles long, emptying into the San Juan and Colorado Rivers; Indian ruins and wildlife, with everything from mountain lions to golden eagles to desert bighorns.

description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 39, 21, 8, 11, 12 and 17. The supplementary number was 22.

Delano, who is active in civic and philanthropic affairs and was the first general counsel of the Peace Corps, was named executive secretary of the New York City Bar Association, fulltime post. Mr. Delano. who is 54 years old and a graduate of Yale College and Yale Law School, will replace Paul B. De Witt, who will retire on June I after 34 years with the association.

title: Bullets Capture Series, 10094
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 29  Elvin Hayes laughed. There had not been much to laugh about lately because the Atlanta Hawks had almost stolen the Eastern Conference semifinal series from the Washington Bullets. But now he could. He scored 39 points today, more than in any game this season, as the Bullets finally eliminated the Hawks, 10099, in the decisive game of this surprising and emotional sevengame series at the Capital Centre.

title: British Polls Indicate Late Labor Surge Will Fall Short
description: LEEDS, England, April 29  New public opinion polls published in the last few days show the Conservatives under Margaret Thatcher clinging to a reduced lead despite a late surge by Prime Minister James Callaghan and the Labor Party with little time remaining before Thursday's general election. ...

description: President Carter has scheduled news conference for 4 o'clock this afternoon in the White House.

title: Amtrak Train Derails in Midwest
description: NEW LISBON, Wis., April 29 (AP)An Amtrak train traveling from Qicago to Seattle derailed this evening in switch yard near here. The authorities reported no serious injuries. Some of the 300 passengers said the train, with 11 cars and two engines, was moving slowly when the accident occurred. Witnesses said the cars tilted but did not overturn.

description: PHILADELPHIA, April 29  Maurice Cheeks drove down the lane for a basket with 10 seconds left, sparking a rally that gave the Philadelphia 76ers a 9290 playoff victory over the San Antonio Sours at the Spectrum today.

description: NEW ORLEANS, April 29 (AP)  A pair of critical putts down the stretch, one for a tiebreaking birdie and one for a victorysaving par, brought Hubert Green a onestroke triumph today in the $250,000 New Orleans open golf tournament.

description: WASHINGTON, April 29  The Carter Administration, after more than a year of intense internal debate, has proposed new legislation that would make it easier for the Central Intelligence Agency to engage in smallscale covert operations abroad, White House officials said today.

description: SAN ANTONIO, April 29  Mystery still surrounds the death of a former Federal drug agent, in jail facing bribery charges, who died here after more than tour months in a coma.

title: Populist Wins by a Wide Margin In Ecuadorean Presidential Race
description: QUITO, Ecuador, April 29  A 38yearold Guayaquil lawyer and populist leader who was originally a standin candidate swept to victory tonight in Ecuador's presidential elections.

title: Alaska Whaling Party Rescued
description: JUNEAU. Alaska, April 29 (AP) About 20 members of a blizzardbound whaling party on the Bering Strait were rescued today'by the Coast Guard icebreaker Polar Sea, a Coast Guard spokesman said. The whalers were from the village of Savoonga on St. Lawrence Island in the Bering Strait.

description: Even fencing tournaments have their surprises.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: After last week's rapidfire outpouring of bad news for the credit markets, money market economists renewed their predictions of much higher interest rates during 1979 Soaring consumer prices, record business borrowings, heavier-than-expected Treasury financing and a sudden expansion in the money supply depressed fixedincome security prices late last week. Then, on Friday, the Federal Reserve apparently decided it could no longer refrain from nudging shortterm interest rates upward.

title: Gasoline Supply Tighter Amid Threats of a Strike

Jersey and Connecticut.

title: AT HOME ABROAD Change In Rhodesia
description: LONDON  Those of us who have been skeptical of Ian Smith and his internal settlement have an obligation to recognize that things are not exactly the same since the election in Rhodesia. The political equations have changed, in Salisbury and London and Washington.

title: Refuse at 877 Struck Sites Removed as Health Hazard

description: Despite the recent slowing of eco. nomic growth and increasing inflation, business performed in a robust manner in April, the National Association of Purchasing Management says in its latest appraisal of the business climate, released yesterday.

title: Northeast and Midwest Joining to Save Industries
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 29  A loosely knit coalition of labor unions, religious groups and state and local officials has formed in nearly a dozen Northeast and Middle Western states to stem an exodus of industries and businesses from their regions to the Sun Belt and to other camtries.

title: Issue and Debate Legalizing Casinos in New York State
description: Until 10 days ago New York State appeared to be moving inexorably toward the legalization of gambling casinos.

title: Twins 5, Tigers 3
description: DETROIT, April 29 (AP)  Roy Smalley continued his hot streak at the plate today, collecting four hits, to help the Minnesota Twins defeat the Detroit Tigers, 53.

title: Dissident Hears Carter at Church
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)  President Carter and Georgi P. Vins, a Baptist pastor just freed from Siberian exile, attended Bible class and prayed together today.

title: President of Harvard Seeks a Restructuring In the Business School
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 29 Derek C. Bok, president of Harvard, has concluded that the university's business school is not adequately preparing its students for the problems they will encounter in the corporate world and has suggested major changes.

title: L.I. Youth Awaits N.F.L. Draft
description: JOHN MOHRING, a senior at C.W. Post College on Long Island, is one of several hundred football players who hope to be among the 330 chosen in the National Football League's draft of college seniors this Thursday and Friday. Because he comes from what is considered a small college (Post has 14.000 students), where the level of competition is modest, and because he would be shifting positions as a pro, from defensive end to outside linebacker, Mohring's status in the draft is difficult to extrapolate.

title: Idi Amin: A Savior Who Became The Creator of 8 Years of Horror
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  When Tanzanian soldiers and Ugandan exiles marched into Kampala on April 11, they found the carnage left by the institution. alized brutality of a state gone insane.

title: Roots and Offshoots
description: IN ANOTHER era, once the circus moved into Madison Square Garden, the Rangers moved out. If the Rangers were in the midst of a Stanley Cup series, too bad. They played all their games in the other city or shifted their Garden games to a neutral city. When the lions were snarling in the Garden, the Rangers were snarling in exile. Now. course, the Rangers get to play all their Stanley Cup games in the Garden, thanks to a modern circus surface that permits a quick changeover to artificial ice. And tomorrow night the Rangers and the Islanders will take their Stanley Cup skirmish into the Garden while the lions take a nap.

title: Iran Lists LongTerm Oil Pacts
description: Special to The New York Time

title: How Trainers of 7 Past Winners View the 79 Derby
description: How close is the Kentucky Derby matchup? Almost too close to call, say the five trainers who have saddled the last seven Derby winners. Three of those colts  Secretariat, Seattle Slew and Affirmed  went on to win the Triple Crown. Below, the trainers ana- lyze the race and discuss the pressures of Derby week. They also talk of Grover (Bud) Delp and Gordon Campbell, the trainers of the two top contenders, and Ron Franklin and Don Pierce, the jockeys.

title: Bruins Return Home Frustrated by Losses
description: BOSTON. April 29  The Boston Bruins were downhearted but not discouraged today after they had given up a'20 lead to the Montreal Canadiens in the second period last night in the Montreal Forum and lost. 52.

title: No. 6 for Hogan
description: NEW HAVEN, April 29 UPI)Marty Hogan of St. Louis captured his sixth consecutive pro racquetball tournament today. He scored a 2113. 2120 victory over David Fleetwood of Memphis in the final of the $25,000 Robert W. Kendler Classic. In the women's final, Shannon Wright of Las Vegas, Nev., beat Jennifer Harding of Portland, Ore., 1221, 210, 119.

title: Ranger Aide Criticizes Islanders
description: Less efficient use of the Islanders manpower has enabled the Rangers to dominate their playoff series, Mike Nykoluk, the Ranger assistant coach, suggested yesterday.

description: Dr. Coffin to Play Piano Tonight at Riverside Church

description: SATURDAY was a great day for swan watching at the Metropolitan Opera House, for the American Ballet Theater offered two performances of Swan Lake, each with different stars.

title: Judy Chicago and Trials of Dinner Party
description: The Dinner Party, the ambitious work by Judy Chicago which celebiates women's achievements through the ages, may be a feast for the eyes of those who flock to see it at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, but it has left the artist's cupboard nearly bare.

title: Refugee Mistreatment Reported
description: MANILA, April 29 (AP)  The United States Refugee Affairs Coordinator, Dick Clark, left for Washington today after a threeweek tour of camps in Southeast Asia to assess the Indochina refugee problem. He said at a news conference Saturday that what he saw in Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, Hong Kong and the Philippines was not very encouraging. He said that he found evidence of a continuing systematic persecution of people in Communist Indochina, particularly of ethnic Chinese and people once connected with the United States Government in South Vietnam.

title: National League

title: 2 REPORTS SEE RISKS IN NUCLEAR FUTURE
description: WASHINGTON, April 29  A major National Academy of Sciences study dealing with health risks of nuclear power and radiation hazards estimates that the price of atomic energy will bathe cancer deaths of 2,000 Americans by the end of the century. A second study aays that one person in every thousand develops the disease from all radiation sources.

title: Crude Oil Reserves Declined in 1978
description: The nation's proved reserves of both crude oil and natural gas declined once again last year, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute and the American Gas Association.

title: American League
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., April 29 (UPI) Steve Renko allowed only two hits over 8  innings today and Bill Campbell, in relief, pitched out of a basesloaded jam in the ninth to give the Boston Red Sox a 20 triumph over the California Angels.

description: LORAIN, Ohio, April 29 (AP)  Irving Leibowitz, 56 years old, editor of The Journal for the last 13 years, died of cancer in Cleveland today.

title: Federal Funding For News Coverage
description: Unlike most modem countries, America has few truly national news media that serve the mass audience. As a result, a diverse nation ends up with surprisingly uniform national news. A Federal Endowment for

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PARK CITY, Utah, April 29 (UPI)Phil and Steve Mahre of White Pass, Wash., and Cindy Nelson of Lutsen, Minn., the 1976 Olympic downhill bronze medalist, head the United States 20racer ski team for the 1980 Winter Olympics.

title: Orioles Trounce A's With 10 Runs in 7th
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 29 (AP)Gary Roenicke and Ken Singleton each belted threerun homers today during a 10run seventh inning as the Baltimore Orioles overpowered the Oakland A's, 131.

title: Audit by Goldin Calls Taxi Commission Lax On Safety Regulations
description: Many of New York City's 11,787 licensed taxicabs cruising the streets have been inadequately inspected for safety and maintenance, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: Reagan Camp Scoffs at Reports Support for His Nomination Is Dwindling
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25  Ronald Reagan and his campaign aides say that the only place his chances for the Republican Presidential nomination seem to be slipping is in the press.

title: CORRECTION
description: In The Times yesterday. it was erronsously reported that Jubus Rudel nad been dismissed as director of the New York City Opera. Mr. Rudel resigned from that post. The Times regrets the error.

description: Music

title: Imperiled Program Brings Fishing to City Youngsters
description: NEW YORK CITY children, many of whom do not have much opportunity to venture into the country for fishing, will be yanking catfish from six lakes and ponds in the five boroughs again this summer, a result of a vearold ef- fort that has brought urban angling back to New York after a hiatus of decades.

title: Ecuadorean Aircraft Spot Wreck Of a Missing Plane in the Andes
description: QUITO, Ecuador, April 29  Search planes today spotted the wreckage of small Ecuadorean Navy aircraft lost while trying to find a missing airliner. There appeared to be survivors.

title: ESSA Y  Africa Speaks
description: WASHINGTON  Two United States Senators of widely differing views  conservative Sam Hayakawa of California and liberal George McGovern of South Dakota  proposed last month that Congress send a team of bipartisan, impartial observers to monitor elections in Rhodesia.

title: Stage: Ira Levin Comedy, Break a Leg,
description: IRA LEVIN has written a comedy about a critic who finds fault with everything, and in this case I'm afraid there's nothing for it but to stet) right into the role.

title: Around the Nation
description: MOBILE, Ala., April 29 (AP) Sheriff Tom Purvis of Mobile County and seven of his deputies were acquitted yesterday in the death of an escaping jail inmate.

title: Mountain House
description: The startling, looming barns, the intricate profusion of trees along the highway, then a dirt road winding up through woods past melting banks of snow to the notch of a mountain, where a field opens out  all so newly marvelous to city eyes that it seems almost too good to be true that the house itself is still standing, ready for another summer's use.

description: Spectacular Bid Meets Flying Paster at Last

title: London Times Abandons Attempt To Put Out Paper From Frankfurt
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, April 29  The Times of London, whose publication has been suspended for five months because of a labor dispute, abandoned plans today to bring out an international edition here after threats of violence and an apparent attempt to sabotage its local printing plant.

title: Security Officer in Ulster Slain in I.R.A. Ambush
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 29 (UPI)  Provisional Irish Republican Army guerrillas killed a reserve member of the Ulster Defense Regiment today, the 13th member of the British security forces to die in a twoweek I.R.A. offensive.

title: Editor Declares Government Has Lied About Suppressed Nuclear Article
description: Erwin Knoll, editor of The Progressive magazine, which is under a Federal District Court order not to publish an article on the hydrogen bomb, told newspaper editors yesterday that the Government of the United States is lying about the suppressed article, which he said could in no way contribute to the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

title: Lillian Nassau, Art Dealer, Is Honored by New York
description: Lillian Nassau, the pioneer dealer in Art Nouveau and Louis Comfort Tiffany, was awarded a Certificate of Appreciation from New York City on Saturday at an allday symposium on Tiffany held at New York University's Gray Art Gallery.

title: Ashland Oil's Earnings Climb
description: Asniana Oa Inc. joined other energy companies in reporting sharply higher earnings for the first three months of 1979. The company over the weekend announced that net income soared to $27.2 million, or 71 cents a share, in its second fiscal quarter ended March 31, up from S15.5 million, or 29 cents share, in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: Phillies 4, Padres 3
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP)Manny Trillo's single capped a tworun Philadelphia rally in the ninth inning today as the Phillies defeated the San Diego Padres by 43 before a crowd of 50,722.

title: In Four Years Since Saigon's Fall, More Than a Name Has Changed
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, April 29 - Four years ago today shells and rockets were pouring into Saigon's airport and a terrified population scrambled desperately to get at helicopters shuttling Americans to the Seventh Fleet offshore.

title: United Press International
description: James F. Ross, a member of the Radiation Response Team, examining box containing radioactive waste after it was removed from overturned truck on the New Jersey Turnpike yesterday morning. Driver suffered minor in- juries. Team arrived about one hour after the mishap. Truck was carrying a load of pharmaceuticals in addition to the five-pound-package of radioactive chiorium nitrate. Tests indicated that there had been no leakage.

title: Indians 5, Royals 4
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.. April 29 (AP) Toby Harrah delivered a tworun double and Rick Wise retired 12 straight batters after a shaky fourth inning to give the Cleveland Indians a 54 victory over the Kansas City Royals today and snap a fourrrie lasing streak.

title: White Man in a Klan Robe Is Shot In Black Section of Decatur, Ala.
description: DECATUR, Ala., April 29  A white man wearing a Ku Klux Klan robe was shot twice in the back before dawn today in a black neighborhood, the police said.

title: Leningrad Hijacking: A Desperate Act
description: A band of 16 Soviet dissidents who in 1970 staged a desperate but unsuccessful attempt to steal an airplane to escape the Soviet Union did so with knowledge of a 99 percent certainty they would be caught and sentenced to labor camps, two members of the group have said. But

title: Federal Hearings Asked Into Malcolm X Murder
description: Two men convicted in the 1965 murder of Malcolm X are asking the 17member Black Caucus in the House of Representatives to press for a Congressional committee investigation into the killing similar to recent investigations of the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Carter Inquiry Is Examinink Delay In Bank's Transfer of Loan Funds
description: A lag occurred between the time Billy Carter has said Carter's Warehouse repaid a peanut loan to the National Bank of Georgia in 1976 and the time the bank passed the money on to other banks that were holding pieces of the Carter loan.

title: Pirates 10, Astros 5
description: PITTSBURGH, April 29 (AP) Omar Moreno and Willie Stargell drove in three runs apiece to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 105 triumph over the Houston Astros today.

title: H. VERNON SCOTT
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., April 29 (UPI)  H. Vernon Scott, a political fund raiser and lobbyist, died yesterday of a heart attack at Eisenhower Medical Center. He was 77 years old.

title: Washington Watch
description: Steven Rattner

title: 31 Hurt in School Bus Mishap
description: VILLA GROVE, Colo., April 29 (AP) Thirtyone high school students were injured yesterday when a school bus ran off the road and rolled over, the Colorado State Patrol said. Two boys from Centauri High School were hospitalized and another 20 students were treated at hospitals and released.

title: Unitarians Name President
description: BOSTON, April 29 (UPI)  The board of trustees of the Unitarian Universalist Association announced yesterday the appointment of the Rev. 0. Eugene Pickett as president, succeeding the Rev. Paul N. Carnes, who died March 17. The denomination of 180,000 religious liberals was formed in 1961 in a merger of the American Unitarian Association and the Universalist Church of America. Mr. Pickett, 53 years old, 53, a resident of Newton. Mass., has been director of the association's department of ministerial and congregational services since 1975.

title: Talmadge Faces Hearing Today on Ethics Charges
description: WASHINGTON, April 29  An uncommon human and political drama will begin on Capitol Hill tomorrow when, for the first time in more than a decade, the United States Senate will begin proceedings against one of its members for alleged violations of its code of ethics.

description: Morning

title: G.A.O. Study Faults Use of Profit From Military Base Liquor Sales
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) Package liquor sales on military bases are so profitable that they are allowing inefficiences in service club management, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Israel's Cabinet Votes To Endorse Execution For Acts of Terrorism
description: JERUSALEM, April 29  The Israeli Cabinet decided today to allow prosecutors in military courts to seek the death penalty for Palestinian guerrillas who carry out terrorist acts of inhuman cruelty.

title: Scientists Question Theory That Supernovas Produce Neutron Stars
description: One of the most dramatic fulfillments of a scientific prediction in this century occurred a dozen years ago with the discovery of those clocks in the sky  pulsars. Now, however, the theory of pulsars is in trouble.

title: Opera by an American Sought
description: The New York City Opera will sponsor a contest for a oneact opera by an American composer. The award will be f10.000 and a production by the company during the 1980 fall season on a program of oneact works. The contest is open to anyone holding American citizenship. The work should be between 30 and 50 minutes in length, scored for standard orchestra, but electronic elements and a chorus are allowed. For information, write to the contest administrator, American Music Center, 250 West 57th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019, or call (212) 2473121.

title: Phil DeBeaubien, 66
description: ORMOND BEACH, Fla., April 29 (AP)  Phil F. DeBeaubien, 66 years old, newspaper columnist and former publisher of The Detroit Times, died here yesterday after a series of heart attacks.

title: TV: Waging Peace
description: WAGING Peace, a threepart documentary series on PBS, is partly inspired by the stunning ceremony of reconciliation that took place in Washington between Egypt and Israel on March 26. On that historic occasion, President Carter compared the winning of peace with the waging of war. The quest for peace was seen as a positive act. In the words of Mr. Carter, Peace is aggressive, attacking.

title: Machine Tool Orders Rose
description: Orders for machine tools continued to climb during March, rising 7 percent from February levels and 48 percent from yearearlier figures, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported. The increase was fed by special factors such as demand from the auto and aerospace industries

title: Disruption, Uncertainty Beset Iranian Car Maker
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 29  The manager of one of Iran's major auto makers sat behind his desk sipping tea and looking forlorn.

title: Mets Split 2 With Dodgers
description: Don Sutton was too much for the Mets yesterday and Dale Murray was too much for the Dodgers.

description: Supplementary O-T-C Listings

title: A Tough Architectural Job
description: The announcement a week ago of I. M. Pei's selection as architect for the $375 million New York Convention and Exhibit Center brought to an end one of the longest and most complex architect selection processes New York has ever seen.

title: Public Divided on Reviving Draft But Favors Registration for Men
description: The American public is divided on the question of reviving the military draft but strongly favors the idea of having an optional plan of universal registration of all eligible young men, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: U.N. LEBANON FORCE SEEN TO BE IN PERIL
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 29  United Nations peacekeeping troops are in a warlike situation in southern Lebanon and cannot even defend themselves, according to Ireland's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs.

title: City Wearing Out, a Study Agrees
description: Supporting similar conclusions by earlier studies, a research report prepared for the Urban Instittoe of Washington has reported that New York City's physical plant is wearing out faster than it is being replaced.

title: Associated Press
description: SCHOOL'S OUT IN FLOODED MINNESOTA VALLEY: A oneroom schoolhouse near Oslo, Minn., was surrounded by water from the flooded Red River over the weekend. Residents of Pembina, N.D., near Canadian border in the upper Red River Valley, are still holding floodwaters behind 20foot dikes. Nearly a million acres have been under water recently in the 200mile valley as the river rose to highest flood stage in nearly a century.

title: Screen:'Manly Times':Bulgarian Folk Tale
description: OTHER peoples' folk tales are like the contents of another family's photograph album. You may recognize the occasions and the activities and appreciate the feelings that are recorded without feeling much yourself. Important associations are missing.This is my reaction to Eduard Zakhariev's "Manly Times," a new Bulgarian film based on what is apparently an old Bulgarian folk tale. The film will be presented in the New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art on Wednesday at 6 P.M."Manly Times" is a once-upon-a-time tale about a mountain fellow who makes his living by kidnapping brides for clients who pay him well for his success. In this particular narrative, Banko, the matchmaker, a brawny, resourceful man of middle years, makes the mistake of falling in love with the already-promised bride, and she with him.The film is full of pretty mountain scenery, quaint costumes and customs, and predictable turns of event. The performances match the material. The leading roles are played by Grigor Vanchkov (Banko) and Marianna Dimitrova, who looks like a dark-woman he carries off for another man. The movie is extremely picturesque.

title: Oil Revives Edinburgh as Bank Center
description: EDINBURGH  After decades of stagnation, this blackgranite capital has recaptured some of the glory it enjoyed in the 19th century as one of the world's biggest financial centers.

title: OHIRA IS DUE TODAY FOR CARTER PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, April 29  Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira of Japan is scheduled to arrive here tomorrow to meet with President Carter on Wednesday for discussions that Americans and Japanese officials have said are the most important between the leaders of the two nations since the explosive Nixon shocks of 1971.

title: The City
description: Cyclists, joggers and strollers won victory yesterday as the Department of Parks and Recreation announced extensively expanded hours for closing drives to motor vehicles in Central Park and Prospect Park in Brooklyn.

title: RockSlide Detour Irks Malibu's Residents
description: MALIBU, Calif., April 29  For two weeks, chunks of a crumbling bluff have tumbled intermittently onto the Pacific Coast Highway, isolating this elegant Los Angeles beach community behind two stateinstalled chainlink fences that are the tangible symbols of its anger and frustration.

title: Brewers 3, Blue Jays 0 Blue Jays 5, Brewers 3
description: TORONTO. April 29 (AP)  Consecutive home runs by Rick Bosetti and Bob Robertson leading off the eighth inning paced the Toronto Blue Jays to a 53 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers and a split of their doubleheader today. Mike Caldwell blanked the Blue Jays on six hits as the Brewers took the opener. 30.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, April 29 (UPI)  Chinese dissidents climbed atop a wall here today and quickly sold a collection of the most criticial wall posters published against the Government in recent months.

title: DISSIDENTS HONOREDAT RALLY BY 100,000 FOR JEWS IN SOVIET
description: The dissidents who were exchanged Friday for two convicted Soviet spies were honored yesterday in New York City by more than 100,000 American supporters at a rally that had been planned as a day of support for Soviet Jews.

title: Opera: Dido's
description: IF there is one thing Henry Purcell's vocal music needs above all for acceptable performance, it is steady, clear voices that can sustain lyric Jines without equivocation of pitch and tone. Unfortunately. these the first time, was in good vocal shape and sang his part commendably. Because he also acted creditably and looked like a young hero, he qualified as the most impressive figure in the cast. Jane Shaulis did well in her initial assumption of the role of the Sorceress, as did Penny Orloff in her time as a lady-in-waiting. An energetic and affirmative contribution was also made by John Lankson as a Sailor.

title: Nancy Ann Goldstein Bride of Charles Dunn
description: Nancy. Ann Goldstein, daughter of Mrs. Martin Goodman of Providence, R.I., and New York, and the late Larry L. Goldstein, was married yesterday to Charles M. Dunn, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Gerald Dunn, also of Providence.

title: Violin: Zukerman Plays Four Classical Sonatas
description: PINCHAS ZUKERMAN, that most fluent and sweet-tempered of violinists, turned up on the Great Performers series at Avery Fisher Hall Sunday afternoon. The pianist was Marc Neik- rug, and the program consisted of sonatas by Mozart (K. 304 in E minor), Beethoven (No. 8 in G), Schumann (No. I in A minor), and Franck.

title: Edgars Presented By Mystery Writers
description: Ken Follett's The Eye of the Needle (Arbor House) was chosen as the Best Mystery Novel of 1978, William L. DeAndrea's Killed in the Ratings (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich) as the Best First Mystery Novel by an American, and Aaron Mark Stein was awarded a Grand Master Edgar for his contribution to the craft of mystery writing over a period of many years in a series of Edgars presented by the Mystery Writers of America at their annual dinner Friday night at the Biltmore.

title: U.S. Issues Scheduled
description: The Treasury is scheduled to sell 10year notes tomorrow and 30year bonds on Wednesday, and both issues are expected to carry the highest yields on record for such investments.

title: Fall Fashion: Clothes for RealLife Situations
description: As the fall fashion collections unfurl, it sometimes seems that the only styles worth noting are the tailored suits. Certainly nothing seems more relevant to living today. But they are, of course, not the whole story.

title: Commodities
description: WITH the release of the Government's springplanting and stocks-on-hand surveys, grain and soybean futures traders spent a busy week placing their market spreads to minimize potential losses from both hedging and speculative operations.

title: PlowBack,
description: The petroleum industry opposes a new tax on the extra profits it will receive when the President lifts oil price controls next month. But with popular opinion on the other side, the industry has decided to roll with the punch. Its Congressional allies, instead of resisting the proposed windfall profits tax directly, woula exempt profits that are plowed back into oil exploration and development.

title: Minimal Impact Seen In CapitalGains Tax Cut
description: Just six months ago, the first part of the controversial reduction in the capitalgains tax went into effect, but thus far the cut appears to have had little. if any, impact on the American economy

title: Mile and a Quarter of Memories
description: THIS is the week when dear little old ladies in Shawano, Wis., get to know about sports figures named Spectacular Bid and Flying Paster. Spectacular Bid and Flying Paster are thoroughbred race horses, and there are vast and sinless areas in this country where they and their like are regarded as instruments of Satan 51 weeks a year. Then comes the week of the Kentucky Derby. and sin- less newspapers that wouldn't mention a horse any other time unless he kicked the mayor to death are suddenly full information about the steeds that will run and the people they will run for at Churchill Downs on the first Saturday of May. In cities all over the land stenographers invest their silver office pools, in cities and towns and on farms the sinless old ladies study the entries and on Saturday almost everyone tunes in on television.

title: Angels
description: Gene Autry, the former singing cow. boy, was for 10 or 15 years the No. box office attraction in Western movies. He established a Madison Square Garden attendance record with his rodeo that nobody's ever going to hreak henauge the old Garden is aone. and he has had hit records, such as Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer.

title: SAUDI RIFT ON EGYPT IS DENIED BY PRINCE
description: WASHINGTON, April 29  Leaders of Saudi Arabia have gone to unusual lengths recently to deny that some apparent fluctuation in their Middle East policies stemsfrom internal divisions.

description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (Reuters) An estimated 20 million illegal abortions are performed in the world each year and are a leading cause of death among women of childbearing age, a study issued today said

description: WASHINGTON, April 29President Carter, harking back to one of his 1976 campaign refrains, said recently that forcing oil companies to give up ownership of other fuels, essentially coal and uranium, should be explored thoroughly.

description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 29  Four professionals who in their individual ways have contributed to the legends of golf put on a stirring finish today to a betterball tournament called the Legends of Golf. One of the many remarkable things about them is that they are all over 50 years of age.

title: John Allyn, ExOwner Of Chicago White Sox
description: CHICAGO, April 29 (AP)  John Allyn, a major stockholder of the Chicago White Sox and former owner of the baseball club, died of a heart attack today. He was 61 years old.

title: Time to Try Again in Northern Ireland
description: Ireland's situation has changed greatly since the days when an important feature of American politics was Britainbaiting. So when two prominent IrishAmerican politicians, Speaker O'Neill and New York's Governor Carey, recently criticized British policy on Northern Ireland, Britain's leaders were quick to take offense. They particularly resented the jog from across the sea during an important election campaign.

title: Nuclear Power Yes
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  It is becoming apparent that nothing really happened at Three Mile Island to endanger the public, except in the fe. vered minds of some journalists. No employees were hurt or killed, nor was any citizen injured. Solar as I have read, the only damage seems to have been the release of a small amount of slightly radioactive water from the nuclear plant. Despite a wildly improbable sequence of human errors, the plant'S safety systems worked and the public was protected. The plant owner will lose perhaps a year of electricity sales and will spend tens of million of dollars to repair the damage, as a result of to his unwillingniss to invest in computersurveillance i systems to alert the operators that valves were in the wrong position.

title: Jersey Man Is Killed on Parkway
description: CRANFORD, N.J. April 29 (AP)  A 49yearold Cranford man was killed when he plunged from an overpass at Exit 136 on the Garden State Parkway into oncoming traffic today, the state police said. Authorities identified the victim as Nathaniel Brooks.

title: Anderson Denies Yanks Deal

title: Japan's Auto Exports Drop
description: TOKYO, April 29 (AP)  Japan's motor vehicle exports declined in the fiscal year ended March 31, the first annual decline in 30 years, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association has reported.

title: How to Clean a Bullhead
description: Place the fish on a waisthigh flat surface. With a small, sharp knife, cut under the dorsal fin from rear to front. This scooping cut ends at the head, and the flap of skin may be left intact.

title: Shipyard on a Different Tack
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va.  When the newly organized steelworkers walked out of this city's sprawling 470acre shipyard three months ago, many of them feared humiliating reprisals by the management of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Corporation if the strike failed.

title: Opera: Britten 's Dream
description: WHEN Benjamin Britten's operatic version of A Midsummer Night's Dream had its premiere in 1960 at Aldeburgh in England, it won enormous critical acclaim, in part because it was the first time that a Shakespearean play had been transformed into an opera in English with such a high degree of success. On this side of the Atlantic, Britten's creation has been respected and admired, but not to the extent that it was in his native country, and it has not enjoyed the attention given to such other of his works as Peter Grimes, The Turn of the Screw, The Rape of Lucretia and Albert Herring.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, APRIL 30, 1979

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bendix Corporation, Southfield, Mich., a diversified company, has named Louis J. Lawrence vice presidentproduction operations.

title: A Plane Missing Since December Found by C.A.P.
description: Ending a fourmonth search, a Civil Air Patrol pilot spotted the wreckage of small private plane in the rugged Adirondack Mountains near Lake Placid Saturday night, and state helicopters recovered the bodies of three men who perished in it last Christmas eve.

title: 3,000 Foster Children In Public Institutions To Get a Case Review
description: wan a new Federal grant, New York City's Human Resources Administration will review cases of 3,000 children in foster care in institutions in the hope of returning at least 300 of them to their own homes, having them adopted or putting them into less restrictive settings.

title: Antioch Patriarch in Rome
description: ROME, April 29 (Reuters)  The Greek Catholic patriarch of Antioch, Maximos V Hakim, arrived here today for a week's visit to Rorpe during Which he expects to have talks with Pope John Paul II.

title: Cosmos Win
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 29  The Cosmos took charge in the second half and defeated the Philadelphia Fury, 42. at Giants Stadium today before 46,375 fans.
